description:
Easily one of the better seafood meals we've had in a while.  We came to the city last Saturday the 20th for a night out.  

I actually called Tadich's earlier in the week to get a reservation, the manager told me they don't take them, but I asked what time to get there then on a Saturday evening if we had an event to be at 8:00 pm, he said to be safe arrive at 5:30-6:00 pm as there's usually a wait.

We got there right at 5:30 pm and there was an open pair of seats at the end of the bar top by the kitchen line, we took that offer right away.

This place has a cool vibe and look, a different look.  It's not a huge restaurant but long, the bar top isn't an actual bar, but a long counter with bar stools and they serve you right there.  I may be off but it seemed like this long U shaped bar made up about 60-70% of this places seating.  

While sitting by the food line you're both tortured and delighted to see all the dishes they put out.  

We started with the oysters rockefeller and then got our main dishes.  I ordered the charbroiled halibut steak, and my wife got the seared scallops.  Both were excellent.  They both came with mixed veggies and mine had a side of fries with it, my wifes had rice with it.  

Next time we return I'd like to try the seafood medley on the oven baked side with shrimp, crab, & one other.  We'll be back for sure.
author: Ryan A.

description:
We live here and were on our way to a concert. First and last time we will ever eat at Tadich Grill.
1. Upon entering, I stood waiting to get name on a list. A male server with serious attitude finally decided to acknowledge me. when I said "john for two" he began making snide smart ass comments "oh you dont look like john...or is it johan"? 
Ok dotard, stop being cute and put my frigging name down. Should have turned around and walked out at that first sign.
2. If you enjoy European style service where you wait 10 minutes to be acknowledged about anything then this place is for you. 20 minutes for a martini. 
FFS.
3. All male service, which in my opinion usually leaves poor attention to details and it was definitely the theme of the night.
4. Server forgot our oysters, which finally came after our salads and "reminding" him 25 minutes after ordering them.
5. Caesar salad was awful. Dressing was barely there, flavorless and watery. Shrimp looked canned and tasted worse.
6. Grilled halibut. Atrocious! It was so overcooked it could have been cat food.
I am from Seattle and have fished halibut, while the portion was fantastic, the overall execution was piss poor. My hubands wasn't as overcooked as mine but his was dry as well.
I honestly should have sent it back but instead chose to bury it under a gallon of their grainy, overly dilled tartar sauce. I ate about 1/3 of it before even the tartar couldn't hide how badly it was overcooked.
Just gross. Waste of $35

I am a server in San Francisco and honestly? I do not understand the hype of this place or why anyone would eat here. So many better places to go in this city.
author: Madison M.

description:
Bring earplugs, and/or learn sign language. Dined here on a Friday at 7:30PM. As there was a long wait for a table, we hovered behind the counter seating area and waited. Service was fast and efficient. It's still a great place for seafood and drinks. The counter is fun to sit at and watch the staff work efficiently in such a tight space.
It's been many years since dining here, and, we were at a table. 

But, the NOISE level was too high and made for a challenging meal with friends. As it got busier, more people lined up behind the counter seating along the wall. It's just a bit odd having people standing a couple of feet behind you waiting for barstools to open. It's like having vultures waiting on roadkill.
author: Leo W.

description:
Forbes named Tadich Grill one of the worlds top ten great classic restaurants worth visiting and as a Bay Area native you almost owe it to yourself to pay a visit. The restaurant is iconic and lives up to the hype! The moment you walk in you're greeted by servers who are dressed in classic white attire, there are no reservations and you can sit on the bar or be seated at a table. 

The inside of the restaurant is super simple and classic looking...all I was thinking was "if only these walls could talk"....i mean 1849....that's throwback and that is why it is named the oldest restaurant in California and third oldest in the United States. The seafood here is what they're known for however the red meat is AMAZING! 

Prices are $$$-$$$$ plan on spending over $50 and really enjoy yourself.  

We had the Chilean sea bass and the slow roasted prime rib with a half bottle of some great red merlot. The meal was perfection and just enough to keep the day going without food coma. I will definitely be back, this place made a huge impact and it's become one of my favorite places to have dinner at...hands down!
author: Karlos G.

description: I am a third generation tadich customer.  I was in the city a couple of months ago for holiday and took my girlfriend to tadich.  She had never been.  All I have to say is you never disappoint.  The oyster Rockefeller was great.  The clam chowder...  awesome.  Rex sole...  wonderful.  I am glad tadich is a constant in an ever changing world.  Strongly recommend.  Make sure you get there early due to tadich does not take reservations.  Worth the wait!!
author: Bryce M.

description:
WORST SERVICE EVER. Stay away from this place! The food is super ordinary, and the server we got was one of the worst we've ever had in San Francisco -- and possibly the entire Bay Area. His name is ALVIN. He said he'd worked there for 8 years but has been a server in SF for 20. Huh? He was a total jerk!

First off, he served us huge pieces of garlic bread stacked on a small platter. He refused to give us individual bread plates and said that we were "supposed to make a mess." Did he expect us to place the bread on the tablecloth? Gross!

Whenever we tried to ask for something -- more water or whatnot -- he would pretend not to hear us and would immediately turn his back and walk away. He rushed to take our orders, barked rude comments like why someone who was on the large side was seated where he was, and made fun of our friend who'd been having cocktails and was a bit red in the face, etc. Crap you wouldn't expect from your server!

When it came time for dessert, we ordered 4 different kinds to share, and one of them tasted rancid, like it was made with bad eggs. My partner told him that, and his response was, "Nice try! That's old school. That's how it's really supposed to taste. But nice try!" Nice try for what? A free dessert? Our food and drinks tab (without dessert) more than paid for that crap on a plate -- and he was defending it! He eventually took it off the tab, but only after we reacted pretty badly, which he probably overheard outside our booth.

He refused to take a group photo of us and gave us all kinds of dumb reasons why he couldn't do it, so we asked another server to do it. He said he would come back but never did.

I would have spoken to a manager on our way out, but there was no one in sight when we got up to leave. STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE. It may be a San Francisco "institution," but there are way more touristy places in the area where you could have better food, better service, and a lot better dining experience.
author: Mich P.

description:
Came here once bf and I remember liking the Cioppino.
This time I had the Mediterranean Sea Bass (Branzino)which I normally like but I wasn't crazy about the way it was prepared here....mesquite charcoal broiled? It was a bit bland tasting and needed some sauce or something. Didn't like the fries either.

Garlic Manila Clams were good though.
author: Linda W.

description:
Everyone Must Go to the Tadich at Least Once in their Lifetime

My wife and I started going to Tadich Grill over twenty years ago as visitors. For us, a trip to San Francisco was not complete until we had a bowl of cioppino (the best I have ever had) or some crab cocktail, or petrale, or crab cakes... at The Tadich.

Years later we moved to San Francisco, and the love affair continues. Now I take clients there, meet friends for a drink and oysters at the beautiful bar and host out-of-town visitors and family at one of San Francisco's quintessential restaurants.
author: John C.

description:
Came here after attending Phantom at SHN. This place has been in business for a really really long time. They carry traditions forward to today. Will not see you until your whole party is there, won't take reservations, and older staff.  

My husband met us at the restaurant, and put our name on the list as we were walking from the theater. He had a really good time with the bartender and enjoyed his drink while he waited for us. Once we arrived, they had our table ready and we were seated in one of the little side rooms, not a private one, but I shared one. Our waiter came with bread and menus and filled her water glasses almost immediately after we were seated. We chit chatted with him about the menu regarding appetizers and his favorite dishes. He left us alone to make our decisions and to enjoy the wonderful sourdough French bread.  Our bar drinks came out relatively quickly and they took our appetizer order. We had fried calamari and crab cakes with our drinks. The crab cake was delicious and the calamari was nice and crisp. It was also not oily.  The  calamari came with two sauces  tartar and a tomato-based sauce.    

Our main courses arrived and they were absolutely the most delicious things we have eaten in a while. Several of us had fish either grilled, and a cioppino, or sautéed. One of our party had a steak. The fish was cooked perfectly and his steak was done to order. There was a lot of food! Many of us couldn't finish what we had and ended up taking it home.  No room for dessert.

I can definitely see why they've been in business so long. They know how to do it right!
author: Susanne R.

description:
I had a lovely mid afternoon snack here. 

Super old school here and there are some strict house rules - for drinks and dining without a reservation, you have to remain toward the front of the bar.

My friend and I shared the following:

-hammersly inlet oysters on the half shell ($17.95)
-bowl of Boston clam chowder ($9)

The clam chowder was deliciously creamy without tasting too fishy. It also had the right amount of thickness.

I would highly recommend checking out the place if you happen to be in the area. Their menu is extensive and reflective of San Fransisco food to be: seafood based and fresh.
author: Trung N.

description: Great food and atmosphere ,service is professional and very helpful with menu.Halibut was excellent and the ice tea ,the bread was dry but butter helped.Thomas262 was my waiter at bar ,he was kind and attentive my glass tea and water never was empty.I will be back with friends
author: Terance C.

description:
We went here as part of a very large group. Our server did a great job of keeping things moving (a hard job with a large and unruly group) without being intrusive. The bread was a nice hearty bread (perhaps because the restaurant is Croatian owned?), the small side salads were very good but still quite large. We had a wide variety of seafood main courses (I tasted the Dungenes crab cakes, Pacific Rock fish filet, and the calamari steak and they all were great) and everyone really enjoyed their meals. 

On the down side, the restaurant is small, crowded, and noisy.
author: Dia D.

description:
Holy smokes! I wonder why I haven't been here!!!
What a surprisingly excellent meal and experience in Tadich Grill!!
After finishing up my errand in Japan Consulate, I wander around for a good happy hour place around. Ended up ordering a full meal, most delicious Cioppino I ever ate!
Generous portion of scallops, fish, clams, prawns, shrimps with amazing broth. Not forgetting the yummy toasted bread! Can't believe I finish the entire thing by myself!! Hahaha...
Charles is a wonderful waiter as well, and he told me this place is the third oldest restaurant in the States. Well, no wonder it survives this long.
Becoming a very happy (and full) person afterwards. Thank you!
author: Lisa S.

description: I usually like old restaurants with a history.I love buchbinders and Musso and Franks . Don't get me wrong this is a very good restaurant but their ciopino fell short. I know good fish soup. I  had the bouillabaise  in Marseille And the zuppa diPesci in Naples and the fish soup at the Crillon and ciopino in New York and Boston .The fish Comes to the table arranged like French art still life .This came to the table like mush. It looked like spaghetti sauce.Impossible to distinguish the components. It was accompanied by burnt I believe garlic toast. It was over salted and overcooked. Each  ingredient and should be added so that it gets the proper amount of cooking. This is a  presentation of fresh seafood not a melange.This is not sf's best .it is bad cooking and poor service. I had the grumpiest waiter ever.This may have been great but now it is a poor display of unconcerned attitude
author: Richard E.

description:
Ahhh Tadich Grill! You will always have a special place in my heart! This place treated me so well that I went there back to back nights on my most recent trip to SF. 

I was in town for the marathon and I got in on Friday. I was SUPER nervous because it was my first full marathon, I had put countless hours of effort, time, miles into this. I wanted nothing more than to run the SF marathon and have it be my first 26.2! Now I know from running enough half marathons that I have to be very careful about what I eat the two days prior to the race. I didn't want anything to mess up my stomach on race day so I had to be very careful about what I ate for dinner on Fri & Sat nights. As dinner time started approaching on Friday, I sifted through nearby places on Yelp (I was staying at the Hyatt). I started to get frustrated. All I wanted was a fish fillet and some rice. I couldn't seem to find a place that had it. Finally my frustration got the best of me and I figured "I might as well walk down a few blocks to this Tadich Grill and see if they can just make what I'm asking." (I had seen quite a few fish options and rice as a side so was hoping they could accommodate). 

When I walked in, I loved the feel of this place. The counter style service, men dressed in crisp, clean linen workshirts/aprons. I felt like I had timewarped back into the 1950's and I loved it!

I took a seat at the bar right when I walked in. The gentleman asked me if I would be dining and I said yes. He pointed me further down in the the restaurant where there were menus, napkins and silverware placed by each seat. I took a seat down there and was quickly helped by a server named Jose. Although I was nervous to ask for Jose to cook up something special for me, he had no problem whatsoever! I told him that I wanted a filet of fish. He named off three options for me and I went with the salmon. He said he could definitely do that with the rice. I asked what kind of veggies they had and he named off a few. I asked for just carrots but he then told me that it was a medley and they couldn't be separated. "Ok no worries!" I told him. I can't get too picky here! As I sipped on my water, he gave me a nice chunk of bread to snack on. As much as I wanted to use the butter he gave me, I left it there (pre-race dining is tough!). He noticed that I wasn't using the butter and quickly offered olive oil instead. I declined but I appreciated him asking!

Very quickly (I'd say less than ten mins) and my delicious meal was out! A perfectly cooked salmon filet (no oil or butter as I had requested), rice pilaf and a heaping mound of carrots (what a pleasant surprise!). It was a delectable meal. Perfect for a pre-race dinner! I scarfed the salmon down. It was amazing! I ate the rice too but honestly there were just too many carrots. I couldn't finish it all!

I appreciated the meal and service so much that I ended up going back the second night (Marathon eve) and got the same thing (without the carrots). There was no way I was going to find a better meal that close to my hotel. It was much busier the second night (the first time I went it was 3pm on a Friday, and then 3pm on a Saturday...keep in mind my body was on East Coast time for dinner). So Saturdays are of course much busier. I sat next to a local and he said it eventually gets to the point later in the night where people are standing behind you waiting for you to get up. I can easily see why!

They also proudly tout themselves as they oldest restaurant in the state of California! I love that they have their story on the front of their menus (I love history!). It was fun to read. Although they have changed locations and names a few times, you can tell this is a well established, family owned restaurant (has been Croatian owned/operated the entire time!). 

I really loved this place and if I decide to do the SF Marathon every year, I will definitely be coming here for all my pre-race dinners! Thank you Tadich Grill and Jose for making my marathon experience that much better with your delicious food! :)
author: Chelsea E.

description: I cannot say that I was overly impressed with the food here; however, I did thoroughly enjoy the ambiance. I had the seafood cioppino and at $35 I expected more in terms of flavor. The portion size was very generous but I felt that the overall dish itself was lacking. the crab meat was hardly noticeable and most of the meat was white fish. I also had a hard time swallowing Arnold Palmers at $9 a piece. I did enjoy the liveliness of the atmosphere and the built environment from the tile floors to the wood bar to the ceiling. Maybe next time I will try one of the char-broiled meals.
author: John C.

description: I'd say their reputation holds true. Food was great (we had the grilled halibut and also the sea bass special). We both preferred the halibut, actually. Portions are decent size and moderately priced. It gets busy and they don't take reservations, but we got sat pretty quickly. Tons of staff running around too so service isn't a problem!
author: Rob M.

description:
Old school done really well. Service is done with efficiency and competency. Food is reliable and exactly what you expect. I really enjoyed it.

Try the Cioppino- a flavorful bowl of seafood (clams, mussels, shrimp, salmon and local catch) with perfectly toasted garlic bread. It is filing and delicious and is flavored by the seafood with little to no spice. Excellent!
author: Edward F.

description:
The Tadich Grill is legendary, old school, and provides an exquisite dining experience.

Our party of four was ushered to a private booth, enclosed on three sides.  Our server was far more than that, he was a gentleman and waiter, and is noted as Jan111 on the receipt.

OK, A+ for both ambiance and service.  After being seated, we were immediately served a generous loaf of, you guessed it, San Francisco sourdough bread and butter.  What a great start !

My entree selection was a house specialty, Corned Beef Hash ($18.95), and it may well be the best corned beef hash I've ever had.  My wife ordered Calf's Liver ($20.95) and loved it.  

Do not visit The City without visiting Tadich Grill.  You will understand why Tadich has been around for over 169 years.
author: Bert G.

description:
old san francisco restaurant established in 1849. was staying in the embarcadero and wanted some quintessential san franciscan seafood. i really liked the ambiance of the restaurant despite hating crowds. we had to line up against the wall waiting for spaces to open up, so try and dine here in off hours. the bar and restaurant itself oozes history, much like one of my favorite restaurants musso & frank's in hollywood. 

also like musso's, tadich has excellent bartenders who make a great martini. i probably had 3 here. on a saturday night, it was a zoo with strange seating rules - first come seats towards the back of the bar where you can dine or wait for a table. front of the bar, also first come, you can only order drinks and apps. 

after nabbing a place at the front bar, started off with the crab cake, which was wonderfully fresh and perfectly balanced with crab meat. we then moved to a table to finish the rest of our meal. 

unfortunately, the main courses were just ok. we ordered the dungeness crab legs, which was fine, but the rice and veggies were plain. we also ordered the seafood ciopinio, which was touted as sf's best. i think i just wasn't a fan of the dish itself, it being in a watery tomato base. the seafood was fresh, but i did not enjoy the white fish that was in it or the overall taste. 

our old waiter did not check in with us until we shouted at him. i get it, you're busy. i did appreciate our younger bartender. the older guys who work here seem to be bothered by requests with an old school DGAF vibe, which is fine with me if the food and drinks are spectacular. but here, the entrees were not up to snuff. 

all in all, i'll come back to tadich some day for their great martinis and to try other dishes on their menu, just not the entrees we tried. tadich fell a bit short of being special as i think it has the potential to be. hopefully next time, i order the right dishes for a perfect night. overall, still a cool experience and restaurant, but don't do the entrees that we ordered.
author: Gee K.

description: Classic San Francisco. Always bring people from out of town to experience seafood perfection. The best cioppino in the country!
author: Esse Z.

description:
***The oldest restaurant in California!!***

HISTORY
Tadich Grill, originally a coffee shop, was established in 1849 by 3 Croatian immigrants. It transitioned into a seafood restaurant in the 1920's and utilizes mesquite charcoal to grill seafood, a traditional Croat method.

WAIT TIME
They do not take reservations so arrive early! I arrived at 5pm and was seated right away. If you arrive around 6pm, there will already be a long line ahead of you.

FOOD AND WINE
I ordered a half bottle of Husch pinot noir, a dry red wine that went went with the following dishes:

Boston clam chowder - a bit thick for my taste though amount of seafood was generous

Cioppino - I ordered this thanks to the numerous Yelp suggestions. Don't be fooled by its size; this dish comes with delectable shrimp, scallops, fish, clams, and crab served with amazing garlic toast. Highly recommend!

Dungeness crab + prawns a la monza - crab and jumbo prawns served over rice and mushroom sauce. Similar to casserole. A heavy dish yet was pretty good!

TAKEAWAY
Definitely a gem in the heart of FiDi. Highly recommended for date night and I can't wait to go back to try some crab legs!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
As much as I've been to San Francisco, I've never stopped in Tadich Grill.  It's was recommended by  Janelle's uncle and we figured why not! We walk in and I felt a little underdressed for the atmosphere. As mostly everyone were dressed in fancy attire. 

 We walked in and checked in at the bar and waited for a table technician to get a table ready. While waiting the bartender chatted a bit and is friendly. Our table becomes available and we're seating in a private booth with 2 doorbells and you can request a curtain be put us for extra privacy which the waiter will not come to your table unless doorbell is rung. 

 I ended up ordering a hamburger steak that comes with fresh mixed vegetable and nice sized potato wedges. When I tell you my food was good it was deliciously good. My only complaint is I wish they gave customers the option to have buns with the hamburger meat. The wife ordered the traditional Tadich Meatloaf. I tasted it and that too is very good. A couple one of the people in our group had a issue with there dish that couldn't be eaten and was still charged for it. Shady!  For the most part everyone enjoyed there meals. This is definitely not a place to dine if your not try to spend a lot of $$$ as it's pretty expensive and the menu changes everyday.

 As far as the service is concerned, I think our waiter could have been friendlier. Never once did he smile or if we said, thank you! He would have a facial expression that wasn't very nice. Whatever! 

 Would I come back? Of course! If I ended up with the same waiter would I request someone else? Yes! Customer service goes a long way.
author: Amy S.

description: Wow A great place to get seafood. You can tell there is a lot of history here. The service is so awesome and the service is great. Ciopinno is wonderful and crab cocktail is very good.
author: Tom K.

description:
When I first heard about Tadich Grill, I didn't think it would be a classy establishment. I seriously thought it was a BBQ joint! But after my first experience, I kept coming back for lunch and dinner! I would even call this a San Francisco classic establishment with its classy yet homely ambiance and stand out dishes! 

If it's your first time, I highly suggest getting the Oysters Rockefeller,  one of the Steak dishes, or the Cioppino.  They also have good fish, but it's all about their steak. The prices are on the higher side, but the portions are huge. They seriously have one of the largest Cioppinos in the city and the steak is so huge that it doesn't even fit on the plate. Even though i am a Filet Mignon kind of guy, their Bone-in rib eye is something out of this world! I just ordered this the other day and it is good every freaking time! 

With thoughtful servers and a full bar, Tadich Grill is a great time ALWAYS!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
We came here on the whim of a whisper from Yelp. Twas 7:30pm on a Saturday when we checked in with the host. We had no reservation, so we expected to wait! Tadich Grill has a fantastic layout. The epicenter of the restaurant showcases a bar and grill. Stools sidle along the circumference of this powerhouse, while tables parade and exquisite booths beckon from her tangents. Counter-side dining is first -come- first serve. Throngs of persnickety San Franciscans stand like middle schoolers at a dance against the back wall...waiting for their chance to join the inner circle. We consider joining the cool kids...until we spot two vacant spot directly in front of the bar. 

The dapper host informs us that we are welcome to order a cocktail from this perch while we await our table. I order a glass of house chardonnay and drink in the exquisite ambience of this institution: the lights, the glitz, the elegantly dress waiters adorned, the people in our midst. Before we knew it...the host guided us like Moses through the sea of reeds to our table.

I wish that I could remember our waiter's name. He was attentive yet good-humored.  Immediately we were served fresh bread with butter and olive oil...and the warning not to fill up!

For our main courses, Kyle ordered the prime rib! I ordered the Rainbow trout with potatoes and vegetables. It was decadent. I still can taste how deliciously the fish was cooked. The vegetables were cooked perfectly. I am a recent convert to the potato fan club....these may have encouraged my membership.

My glass was never empty! How attentive the waiter was....we felt cared for but not stifled.

The meal was so good...that we prolonged the experience with dessert. Kyle ordered cheesecake and I ordered a charismatic carrot cake. It had a little dairy in it...the frosting so I slightly regretted my decision later! But, there is no one to blame but my gluttonous self!


This was a magical experience!  I would definitely return to celebrate a special occasion.
author: Backwordbender F.

description:
My second time here and I have to say that the ambiance, the experience, and the wait staff are top notch. It's just that the food isn't going to blow you away. Come here for the experience.

The first time I came here I had the Cioppino, and while it was tasty, I didn't think it was something I would order again. The second time I had the fish and chips expecting to have my mind blown, and again, thought it was just pretty good. I realized it's more about the experience, possibly the alcohol, and the awesome wait staff that makes this place what it is. 

I'll definitely come again, I just won't expect 4 star food. Really fun place, and possibly better as a watering hold than a foodie joint!
author: Alex K.

description:
We ate lunch here recently with friends and I will say up front that my review is shaded by the fact that I got sick after eating here - not because the food was "bad"  - allow me to explain.

We were seated promptly, which was a surprise, but this restaurant has the process down to a science and they move people to tables faster than anyone I've ever seen.  We had a nice table for four set apart a bit from the others.  

We started with drinks and crab cakes, which were delicious.  Our drinks were good and my pinot noir was excellent.

Main dishes included a seafood curry, a cioppino, a corned beef hash and deep friend scallops.  All were excellent in taste and flavor.  My problem?  I picked the cioppino because I have to eat as oil free as possible and I was assured there wasn't oil in the broth.  Wrong!  My stomach does not lie - and if you check the Tadich Grill recipe for Cioppino online, you'll see that it has a lot of olive oil in it.  I actually called the chef to confirm - his comment was "very little".  I had a miserable night because of it, but most people would love it.  So there you are - I'm not going back, but you should!!
author: Karne N.

description:
After wandering around the tourist food attractions, searching for something real, something authentic, something that says San Francisco, we ditched the piers and headed into the city. Not far, and we made some stops along the way. The first couple of stops were far worse than the tourist hot spots. We kept walking. We kept Yelping until this little place on California St. caught our attention. Looked like it was worth checking out.

Ambiance. 10 out of 10. Long, huge counter and old booths offer fun or intimate seating. Bartenders are well seasoned veterans who obviously know what they're doing and care. We worked the specialty menu. Sazeracs, aviations, old fashions, Moscow mules, they killed it. Delicious cocktails. 

Food. Complimentary, sourdough bread was delicious. Why can't buttered bread be good for you? Side ravioli and meat sauce was a needed change after an ocean of seafood. Good sized serving too. Crab and shrimp stuffed petrale sole was baked heaven. The lady next to us at the bar ordered it. I want to personally thank her. Had I not creepily watched her enjoy her dinner, I would have probably never ordered it. Amazing! It looks too cheesy, it's not. It looks too creamy, it's not. It's just damn good. Bourbon bread pudding topped off our day of overindulgence. 

Highly recommend this spot. It's been there forever for a reason. We'll be back for more!
author: Joe E.

description:
Came here with friends on a Friday evening.  This place doesn't do reservations so we made sure we came here prior to the dinner rush.  We arrived here around 6ish which had no line.  They offer valet parking which cost $15.00 so that was very convenient as this restaurant was smacked in the middle of Financial District.  I'm sure you can find street parking if you really are patient in finding one but at least you'll know there is valet parking if you need it.  We were greeted by every staff member when we made our way into the restaurant.  The ambiance of the place is as vintage and "old world" feel to it.  "Old San Franciscan" as people would say.  The staff were wonderful!  Our server almost reminded us of 'Colonel Sanders'.  He was charming and knowledgeable and he made our first experiences here at Tadich Grill so great.
We were started off with a hot and fresh loaf of bread which was just delicious!  For entree, I got the 16oz bone-in rib eye with shrimp.  Let me tell you... that rib eye (cooked medium) was cooked to perfection!  It was tender, juicy, and absolutely an amazing piece of meat.  The shrimp that came with it were big and cook just enough so there is still a bite to it; a wonderful addition to the rib eye.  The entree came with steamed veggies which was good and their famous potato wedges (really big but wished it was cooked just a little bit more) but otherwise altogether, it was great.  I must say for our first time here at Tadich Grill, it was a marvelous experience!  From the wonderful and friendly staff to the amazing food; I will surely be back here again!!
author: Erna M.

description:
The atmosphere is nice, old fashion with a cool feel.  The place is very busy and not the best place to come if there are only two eating.  Only a limited number of tables for two, and they will sit everyone before you if they have three or more people eating.
The shrimp cocktail was a little bland, good amount of Bay shrimp and Crab meat, just needed more cocktail-sauce.  
The Shrimp Louie salad was good size, with the same bland seafood, but the dressing helped.  
Come for the service and atmosphere and the dinner will fill you up.
author: David E.

description:
Yes, the legend is true, Tadich Grill is one of the best seafood experiences you'll EVER have! 

Service: arrive, give your party's name, and enjoy the atmosphere... efficient, like a well-oiled machine

Décor: early 20th century like you stepped back into the '20s, but a classy joint with the servers uniforms, drinks, lighting, tile, doors, booths, and dishes to match...flawless

Food: getting to the best part of the evening, don't hesitate to take the waiter's, local's, and San Francisco restaurant reviewers advice...get the Seafood Cioppino! I won't describe the taste, aroma, or texture of this classic dish, but it's worth trying, and trying again if you return. Its the type of dish that makes you stare in wonderment after the first spoonful of broth or dipping of the garlic toast. Crab Cake is another winner, served any of their listed styles. Also, don't hesitate to indulge in their sourdough bread.

Stop reading reviews and go here for one of the classiest, tastiest, locally and nationally-known seafood havens around.
author: Gregory S.

description: We enjoyed the ambiance and service was great! The portions are huge, we had the halibut and rockfish both included 2 large pieces. could have enjoyed an appetizer and split a meal. Soups were delish, main dishes did lack some in flavor, would try again.
author: R W.

description:
Wife said the lobster Thermidor didn't tickle her taste buds like she expected. I guess they were laughing but not crack up.
Lucky me we get to go back because the food was delicious. Wife wants to go back and try the cioppino. 
The place isn't cheap for sure but you get a good value and the service was great. As much as I hate driving to San Francisco I'll go back for a meal here again.
author: Chad P.

description:
It's a San Francisco institution! Oldest restaurant not just in the city but in the whole strange! This place is a must go iconic San Francisco spots to dine at. Old school interior vibe, waiters in white coats and great service! 
They do not accept reservations so be prepared to wait, but honestly all the times I've been the wait has not been too bad even during peak times. The waiters are great at keeping things morning and they work quick. 
The food is really good. I've had mostly seafood when dining here but the steaks and pasta are great as well. 
This is for sure a must go to if visiting San Francisco!
author: Mica G.

description:
This place is an amazing landmark. The food is perfection, the service is spot on. I 
My husband had the sea bass & it was delightful. I had the sand dabs, one of my favorites, tasted like they were caught 5 minutes ago. So good. Did I mention that I started with a perfect Manhattan & a cup of delicious Boston clam chowder. LOVE this place
author: Linda B.

description: An old classic that never disappoints. Clam chowder to start, and sand dabs for an entree. Both are some of the best food I've ever had. Nice glass of wine, and I'm a happy diner.
author: Diane E.

description: This place has been a family favorite for over 40 years. Tonight  will be the last time. Worst overall experience . The waitstaff I incredibly snotty and unwelcoming.  If you go here please double check your bill as they will try to charge you for more drinks than were ordered. After this happened to us, we spoke with the bar manager who then boldly claimed that we had two much to drink and we were wrong because he had personally trained the bartender on how to up charge. Avoid this tourist trap like the plague !!
author: Marshall T.

description: The food is well worth the wait!!! The cioppino was amazing!!! Just plain great tasting good stuff
author: Carl H.

description:
I tripped through the door of Tadich Grill and fell into a remnant of a time long past. I was immediately struck by the sight of the long, dark wood bar with brass railings. I was delighted to be greeted by the wide smiles of the bartenders dressed in formal white coats. I immediately felt the history of this place and was eager to experience what they had to offer.

There were three of us, so we figured we'd order a few things to get a nice sampling of Tadich's menu. 

We got:

- a cup of the clam chowder: it was a larger portion than what I'd consider a typical cup (not a bad thing, right?). The chowder had a nice flavor to it, but was a bit thicker (pastier) than I would have liked.

- the fried calamari: they were fried well, tasted fresh, and were not oily. Unfortunately, they were pretty bland - it appears they didn't even salt the rings after coming out of the fryer (rookie move).

- the crab cake starter: the cake was full of fresh crab, which was a great treat. I can't stand when places fill their crab cakes with too much filler (crumbs). Unfortunately, it was sauced with a heavy, rather bland egg-based sauce that frankly takes away from the freshness of the crab.

- the seafood sauté which had two nice big scallops, two large prawns and crab leg meat. It was accompanied by rice pilaf and steamed veggies. This dish followed the same cooking style the other dishes adhered to: bland, soft veggies. Dull rice. A heavy, dated butter sauce that masked the flavor of the wonderful fish that was hiding underneath it. 

- crab and prawn thermidor: honestly, there was absolutely nothing good to say about this. It was a heavy, mess of slop that wasn't worthy of more than the first bite. I feel sorry for the poor crab and prawns that found themselves in this monstrosity. Do Not Order!

In sum, beyond the thermidor, everything was fine. However, I have a problem paying $165 for food that's just "fine" when there are so many amazing places to eat in this city. Having a rich history of being California's oldest restaurant is impressive, but at some point one needs to update the menu to align with contemporary tastes. The best I can say about Tadich is my grandparents would love it. 

 TLDR: bland, overpriced, heavily sauced, dated
author: Vincent B.

description:
Advertises that they are the oldest restaurant in San Francisco, I believe - 169 years.  

Long, huge counter and old booths - makes for an ambiance out of a 1920s movie. Bartenders are long time employees who take pride in their work - I got a great Black Russian with top notch vodka.  For food, it is brought by white-jacketed waiters.  For an appetizer, I got one of the best Oysters Rockefeller I've ever had.  They bring out free San Francisco sourdough bread.  Main courses revolve around a variety of seafood.  If you're really hungry... and on a date - you can try the huge Tadich Platter for two: (crab, oysters, prawns, herring, salmon, trout, calamari salad tomatoes, anchovies, and capers).  

I recommend you arrive before 6:00 PM; they don't seem to take reservations - and the place is so good... it fills up quickly.  It is popular with both the locals and tourists.

It's been there forever for a reason. I'll be back...
author: Dave C.

description:
The worst service of any restaurant in my life . The manager literally said to leave to open room for next  customer. 
The waiter was horrible as if he was doing us a favor 
Never ever will go back
Hope no one does
Terrible
author: Andy A.

description:
Possibly my best dining experiance thus far in San Francisco. Theres a reason this place is the oldest on the west coast and the 5th oldest restaraunt in the country and the amazing food and service. 

I ordered their famed cioppino seafood soup and several cocktails. It was chock full of shrimp, oysters, scallops, 2 fish fillets, etc and a side of delicious garlic bread as well as the regular fresh baked bread they give with all orders. I expected a soup to be light but I was stuffed and couldnt even finish it. Everything tasted amazing, the white coated service, classy atmosphere, and interesting conversation added to the experiance, and the unique cocktails were strongly mixed and left me feeling good on my bart commute home. Will definitely be back soon.
author: Sean G.

description: On the return, the cioppino was disappointing, which, life being life, is how these things roll. But this is factual too - and with a weaker tomato broth, 2 shrimp, one mussel, and near zero crab, this never came close to reaching its ideal orbit. Dining Companion One didn't finish her Halibut Florentine dish and didn't comment on it either. Dining Companion Two really liked his simply prepared mahi-mahi. This place is a wee bit too expensive to suffer any letdowns. 3.3 rounded down.
author: Brski B.

description:
It's hard to review institutions, given how much things change over time.  I remember when this neighborhood was only populated by women in dresses and men in suits and ties, often carrying brief cases (hard and likely leather).

Now, it's a different world with people younger than me... wait, I am getting up there now... in this part of town.  The waiters/waitresses in their traditional white jackets bring back memories of days gone by.  There were two counter seats open on the right so we saddled up and studied the menu.  I was tempted to try their touted cioppino, but, being lunch on a work day, didn't want to doze off in a food coma at my desk.  Their sand dabs are another signature, but I'm not that big on fish.  As a result, here's what I had:

1. Coney Island clam chowder (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=UeWAA_lf-Q1sjS2WR57nvQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Pretty good version and tomato-ey.  Clams were apportioned well and glad it wasn't mostly potatoes.

2. Linguine with clams, white wine sauce (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=oJ8EPvYiGh6ZojpR0zeFmg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Very simple yet clean tasting preparation which led to plenty of bread dipping.  My friend pointed out that the clams were still in shell, unlike most places where they serve this with chopped clams (possibly canned).

Our waiter was curt and efficient but not very amicable.  Water glasses and my iced tea were refilled as well as my host's coffee cup.  The vibe is a little different from what I remember with a mix of the local work force and tourists during this weekday lunch.  I enjoyed my meal and the sourdough bread went a long way in cleaning both food bowls.  

Guess I need to try their Cioppino next time. I certainly wouldn't call this fine dining.  
It reminds me of seafood houses on the East coast (Philadelphia and NYC) where it's more about preserving the history than moving forward.
author: Mike C.

description:
Food is 4 stars but the ambiance is 5 if you like an old school, no frills bar seating kind of vibe. 

Just get the cioppino - it's great plus it'll check an item off of your restaurant bucket list. I also got a salad which was average but again, that's not why you're going to a place like this. 

Highly recommend, just be warned that for a large party you might have a little bit of a wait.
author: Pearce D.

description:
I don't understand how this place has so many stars. It is loud, the service is subpar and there is nothing special.
Our waiter was in such a rush I couldn't even ask him questions about the menu. 
The clam chowder was bland and watery. The bread tasted old. I got a bloody Mary and I didn't want spicy, what I got was tasteless & watered down! 
My husband ordered the seafood sautee, they forgot to put the crab legs with his order. I tasted his and the whole meal tasted the same..... Like butter, nothing else.
I got a small seafood salad, it was a bead of iceberg lettuce, 1 prawn, a small amount of shredded crab, and a handful of what tasted like canned shrimp. 
I am so disappointed and will never come back!!!!
I could of got better food on the pier for less than half the cost!
author: Mariam R.

description: Well first off the bread was not good not the regular San Fran sourdough if you know what I mean. The calamri app was excellent with the two dipping sauces. The crab leg cocktail was great also. The lamb chops were just ok. The crab and lobster thermador was just ok too much cheese in it. The cocktails was not that great. This was a great restaurant to try cuz you can see the history in the building but not going to return.
author: Gina G.

description: Been wanting to give this place a go but it end up being quite disappointing. The service at the bar was wonderful. Can't say the same for our waiter.  Didn't bother checking in with us (while he kept on checking in with the table behind us) and made horrible remarks and I find it quite rude The steak was the usual quality. Nothing amazing. The chowder and calamari was great
author: Henry T.

description:
Such An experience.what a history since 1849. 
My first time in this amazing restaurant and I'm trilled. I highly recommend it. 
The food is super delicious, high quality. The service is phenomenal. You don't need to ask, they bring everything. It's not a quite and romantic restaurant. But you will have a great time. It's happening. There is a long lone but it goes fast. Also you don't need to wait for your food long. 

Delicious
author: Hani G.

description:
Been coming here for 40 years always the same 
Best real representation of San Francisco traditional culinary arts .. I would just go for the sourdough bread
author: Joe L.

description: Had a great dinner with friends and colleagues.  Never had a bad meal there.  Food is cooked perfectly and in my experience is superb.  Love the seafood and love the vegetables served with the meal.  A great place to eat.  A part of SF history with an old school feel.
author: John Q.

description:
Famous old-line seafood restaurant where the food is quite good and the service is absolutely dedicated and outstanding.  As a solo diner I walk in and take a seat at the bar, which is very long in comparison to the relatively small table seating area, and someone is always right there to offer the water and menu and, soon after, the chewy bread.

My usual dish is the lightly breaded sand dabs, which come with steamed veggies and fries and are seasoned with a lightly-applied tartar sauce.  I've also had the sole Newberg, which is a rich creamy sauce and two fillets of sole wrapped around shrimp and crab.  (Big meal!  Glad I didn't order soup that time: they have a good chowder and a creamy bisque.) 
 But though the dish was hot from the oven, the filling, though fully cooked, didn't seem to be very warm inside.  That was my one concern.
author: David B.

description: Thank you thank you thank you TADICH for doing it again.  Another fun experience another FABULOUS meal. Our favorite when we hit the city.  Never change and please pass on my compliments to your CHEF AND COOKSTAFF I love watching them but never want to interrupt.
author: L H.

description:
I decided to eat at Tadich Grill while in San Francisco, with my family members. We were all  shopping, walking all over creation etc... And was starvin' Marvin. My Uncle recommended we all eat at Tadich Grill. Why not? I've never eaten hear before. 

 They list there menu outside of the restaurant for those who want to what is offered before entering. The menu is never the same and changes everyday based on what fresh meat and seafood is available for that day. 

 We walk in and the bar area is huge! This is one of not the oldest restaurant in San Francisco. It's been in busy since 1849 and the family still owns the restaurant! 

 To dine in you must spend at $11.50 per per which is easy to do. Check splitting is $9.00 per person for those who like to split checks and No substitutions on food. 

 I ordered the Traditional Tadich meatloaf $18.95 I'm not a big fan of meatloaf, but the meatloaf here is on point! One of the best I've ever had. It's 3 thick slices wrapped in bacon and topped with a delicious mushroom sauce. It comes with mash potatoes and mixed vegetables. The mixed veggies were tasty and can't comment on the potatoes as I'm allergic. 

 My honey ordered the hamburger steak dinner $22.95, which came with insanely thick & huge cut potato wedges and mixed vegetables. She said the hamburger steak is amazing. Both of us had very generous dinner portions. 

 My sister ordered the scallop dinner which came with 4 seared scallops, rice pilaf and mixed vegetables. The portion was decent, but not for the price $33 which could have been a more generous portion( ie 2 extra Scallops would be nice) My sister enjoyed the sauce on Scallops, however the Scallops were a little on the chewy side and had a noticeable fishy aftertaste. She said she would order this dish again if, the Scallops are more on the fresher side. 

 My brother in law ordered the Seafood curry $30. This dish was recommended by our waiter. My brother in law was going to order the same thing, I did, but didn't since the waiter highly recommend this dish, he went for it. When my bro in law's food came out it didn't look appealing at all! It looked like, what I would call a bowl o vomit... you heard right! My bro took a bit and immediately said ,the seafood curry is terrible! The look on his face was priceless! My sister & I were thinking it couldn't be that bad and though he was being a bit dramatic. So, I offered to try it and trade dishes, if need be. Nope! Bro in law wasn't being dramatic, the dish is real bad! I took a bit and started looking for somewhere to spit that mess out. Problem number #1 whoever made this dish obviously didn't taste the dish, otherwise he/she would have known that the curry powder wasn't mixed at the  way, who wants grainy, chalky thick ass curry powder in there food? #2 seasoning goes at long way had the dish been tasted before serving.  #3 The seafood had an off taste seriously, I really want to know who made this dish they were out of pocket and should rethink this dish before ever putting it on the menu again. #4 when waiter comes back to ask everyone how there food is? My bro in law tells the waiter the seafood curry isn't good and would like to order something else. When, I tell you the waiter looked insulted he gave some serious side under his glasses i was almost laughable. The waiter then says, you don't like it? Bro say, No! Waiter says, you want something else? Bro says, Yes! Waiter says, okay. You'll still have to pay for the seafood curry! We all looked at each other like, WTF?! Dude have you tasted that crap?! That dish had a bite and a half out the dish. It's not edible! I posted a photo of this Terrible seafood dish! I'm glad it wasn't me would ordered that dish, I would have told the waiter, I'm not paying for nothing I can't eat. Bro is out an unnecessary $30 and the waiter had the never to put the food in a doggy bag, like you taking this food with you. Lol! Be careful what you order if it ain't cooked right not edible etc... you're stuck with it! My bro in law did order end up ordering the meatloaf.

My Uncle ordered the Sand Dabs which came with mixed vegetables He said it was really fresh and tasty. I unfortunately, didn't get a photo if his dish. However, It did look really good. 

 Tadich Grill for the most part is pretty decent as long as you don't order the wrong stuff. I would definitely stick to the basics when ordering, especially since they will make you pay even if, you don't eat something that doesn't taste right! 

My overall rating is 3.5 stars based on the entire dinning experience and for the waiter who helped us wasn't very friendly eithe. I don't think making a customer pay for food that isn't edible is right, first and foremost and I recommend not ordering anything that the waiter recommends for this reason. I would come back only if, Meatloaf is on the menu or something in the meat section of mJust saying... you'll get your money's worth.
author: Janelle M.

description:
An old SF establishment with people on expense accounts as it's not cheap.  While their Cippino was great, it didn't have crab leg like old SF standard one point 20 years ago.  Broth was good with generous fish portions but no crab again.

Been here 1/2 dozen times and had many items on the menu.  They over cooked my ribeye and was 2 grades over cooked than medium rare.  Clearly hard to do when the cut is so thin.

Chilean sea bass was minimal and bland.
Avoid the seafood cannelloni as it was cheesy but indeterministic insides.  And bland.

Service is good but never given me a booth after many visits even with asking.  Making me feel not so special.

Touristy pricey and mediocre
author: David H.

description:
I go here for steak of course. But their grilled oyster is just amazing... Make sure to get it!
Good food, good portion, good service. No reason not to go!
Parking is difficult but Embarcadero station is very close by.
author: Yeonhwa S.

description:
A couple of my local friends really like this restaurant and recommended that I check it out. Since I was in town for the SF Marathon, I came here on a late Saturday afternoon. I was dining solo and was able to find a seat at the bar. All of the servers looked very professional as they were all wearing white jackets. I ordered their Seafood Cioppino and the server started me off with some bread and iced tea.

*Seafood Cioppino*
This was some good stuff! This signature house special included clams, mussels, prawns, scallops, bay shrimp, crab meat, and white fish. It also came with garlic toast. If you like seafood, this would be excellent on a cold day.

The service was fantastic. My server was the best and he kept refilling my iced tea without me asking him once. This will now be one of my go-to places whenever I'm in town. I will definitely be back! The only bad thing that I can say about this place is that it is closed on Sundays.
author: Emil C.

description: Haven't had the food here, it's too rich for my blood. Ordered two beers for $5999. Great service, Spencer was great and so was his bald headed boyfriend Michael. I just love it when the bar turns into a movable sausage fest. Will definitely be back...thank you
author: Johny B.

description: Celebrated my mother's 75th birthday here on a busy Saturday night. Service was outstanding and the food was delicious but really huge portions. Give yourself plenty of time as this restaurant is packed and they don't take reservations, but we got a table for two within 25 minutes. All the staff were very friendly. The Crab and Lobster Thermidor was creamy and cheesy, and perfectly seasoned. Filet of Sole was crispy and flavorful. The berries with sabayon was the perfect dessert.
author: Kevin L.

description: Business began in 1849.  It is their 169th year as of 2018. It's awesome to see a business that has run this long and doing so well. OMG, this place doesn't accept reservations. It's walk in only. On a weekday you don't expect it to be too busy but boy I was wrong. We waited 1 hour before we got to sit down. Food was great because freshness of fish was on top.  However I wasn't too impressed with the flavor of sauce. It almost ruin the fish. Once you sit down and order, food comes out quick. But because this place is so busy, try to leave the table immediately after you are done eating for the next customers who's waiting.
author: June F.

description:
Had a group of 11 celebrated my bday.  Waited close to 1.5 hours starting at 6pm.  They don't take reservations, all people in the group must show before they seat.

If you come here get the seafood.  Started with r
Tadich sampler, all items were very fresh.  For entrees I had the crab cakes, best I've ever had, chipianno, best I've ever had, black cod, really delish, bone-in ribeye, mediocre, Indian curry, mediocre, chocolate torte cake, a little too sweet for my taste.

I'm summary come here for the SEAFOOD,  It's SFs oldest restaurant and lived up to the hype.
author: Ben C.

description:
"I'm sorry sir, we don't take reservations! Just stop in and we'll take care of you." And they did!! Beautifully.  End review. Thanks for reading.

There's more to the story, though. This place is wonderful. Reminds me of Lugers back east. Professional waiters. Old school vibe. Seafood, steak, yum.

We did not have to wait at all. We scored a table in the back next to the open kitchen. I love watching the line work. Started with shrimp cocktail, fried calamari and crab cakes. Couple of glasses of Sauvignon Blanc. Fabulous.

Off to the entrees. Oysters with crisp bacon, Cioppino, Strip Steak, medium rare. The Cioppino was extraordinary. Great broth. Delicious seafood. Garlic bread, albeit a bit salty, for dipping. One of the best seafood meals we have enjoyed. My son's steak was cooked to order. He demolished it in short order. My oysters and bacon, an odd combo, worked. I was sad there wasn't more. 

A righteous piece of choclate cake for dessert. Coffee. All meals have to end eventually. But we'll be back. Wonderful place.
author: David B.

description: I had an amazing late lunch here. We were seated right away and got bread and water very quickly. Service was great. I guess our calamari took longer than usual to arrive because our waiter apologized several times and gave me a free glass of wine. The calamari was delicious. Not too much breading, lots of meat. I ordered the seafood sauté and loved it! The sauce was so flavorful and the scallops, prawns and crab meat melted in my mouth. Even the vegetables were cooked perfectly. The restaurant has a classic feel. I would eat here all the time if it was cheaper.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Great place to have lunch and cocktails 
Visited the in May, great weather
The food was great and the decor is old time. You have to visit this place
author: Randy A.

description:
Before my dad died a couple of years ago, I asked him where I should go in San Francisco. He said Tadich Grill. I finally went last night, and it's just another example of how he was almost always right.

Reminded me of all that's good about food and service and hospitality in Louisiana. Everything they do is done with extreme care and effort. God I wish there were a place like this in Austin.

I'm going back today for lunch and again tonight for dinner. I can't imagine anywhere in SF being better than this place.
author: Carlton W.

description: Super old skool and classic seafood house. Service was amazing. Food was delicious. Higher end pricing so great for business meetings (on company dime) or special occasions. Been going here for years and will never stop.
author: O V.

description: Took my momma here on a Wednesday night, it was busy. Waited for about 15mins, service was outstanding from the moment we walked in. All male servers from what I noticed, our server was profesional and super nice. We ordered, food came on a nice timely pace. The atmosphere was everything I expected, friends catching up, couples having a lovely meal, tourists, a pretty mixed diverted crowd. Very San Francisco, and I loved it! 5 stars without a doubt!
author: Patricia H.

description:
Usually, I come during the work week for lunch when I have appointments in the City, and sit at the bar. The weekday service is always excellent. 

How surprising it was to find the service is totally different on a late saturday afternoon. When my friend and I were being seated, we mentioned that a third person might join us for dessert. The person who was seating us gave immediate attitude. His tone of voice became snippy. I could feel his eyes roll as he explained the seating policy - that Tadich doesn't seat partial parties. He gave us the option of getting a two top, then moving to a different table should the third guest arrive. Really? On a slow Saturday late afternoon? I get this policy, but I have, on previous occasions, joined an already seated party during the meal. The saddest part was the manager. Although he apologized, it was completely insincere. His apology was a non-apology. 

I ordered my favorite - the grilled petrale sole. When I asked to switch out the long branch potatoes for the shoe string, the server told me that would be an upcharge. How odd this is NEVER an upcharge when I dine during the work week. 

Both my friend and I have worked in the Financial District for many years, and have dined at the Tadich Grille on multiple occasions. This was a first for either of us - the attitude and upcharge. Both of us left feeling like we were treated as tourists. 

It's so sad that Tadich seems to have one set of rules for the business types and another for tourists. None other restaurants I regularly visit in the City do this. Based on this weekend experience, I doubt I will return for a weekend meal, and will reconsider recommending the Tadich Grille to out of town guests (both business and personal) looking for a weekend dining experience.
author: Sasha R.

description:
I have lived in SF for 25 years and recently went to Tadich grill for the first time.  What was I thinking?

Amazing old school SF atmosphere, perfect cocktails, professional service, and the best Cioppino that I have ever eaten. 

Go now!
author: Scott R.

description: We were visiting SF and my husband took me to this oldest restaurant in California. We ordered their famous ciopinno and it was very delicious. The portion was big, so I'd recommend ordering one ciopinno and something else to share so there are varieties. Since they don't take reservations, we went there at 5:30p and there was only a little bit of wait for them to setup the table.
author: Vivian L.

description: Great food though pricy.  Lunch was bustling with financial district workers and passers by like us. I tried this place over 15 years ago and was not feeling it. This time was excellent.  I won't wait another 15 years to return.
author: Charles S.

description:
Everything was too salty. I was super eager to try this place because a lot of sources talk about the history of this place. We were quickly seated at the counter tables which were first come first serve on a Tuesday night. More crowded than expected. The wait staff seemed to consist of mostly older gentlemen which felt like it aligned with the overall story of this place. 

We had a light dinner. The Boston clam chowder was pretty salty and I've had lots of clam chowder before. It was probably bottom 20%. We also got the Tadich Platter and several items there was too salty. Couldn't really finish the platter though it was nice variety. 

I wouldn't come back here again though because there are a ton of great seafood places in the city. The vibe and atmosphere bumped up this place to 3 stars.
author: Young Y.

description: Meh. The Tadich Grill is quite mediocre and the service is especially atrocious. Our party waited for nearly an hour and a half to be seated. The servers were quite salty at times and crossed the line between being humorous and offensive. We ordered the garlic bread and it was good, although too buttery. The Caesar salad was delicious but nothing special. For the entree I ordered the petrale sole stuffed with crab and Bay shrimp which was in a béchamel sauce served with rice. It was delicious until I found a hair in it. We sent the sole back and eventually I got the same dish without any hair in it. The vibe of the place is a sort of pre-hipster classic San Francisco vibe mixed with sort of old school tavern vibes.The Tadich Grill is an okay restaurant, however, you don't need to come out of your way to eat here.
author: Nick C.

description: This place is been a local financial district institution for many years prior to me even walking on this earth. It's hard bake bread sourdough bread, petrale sole & Cioppino Stew are among the highlights of the Menu. The waiters are all career professionals, and highly knowledgeable about the menu offerings. It's nice to patronize an establishment that has lineage and expertise behind all that they do. This place is definitely something everyone should check out in their life if they dine in San Francisco.
author: Robert C.

description:
It's been there a while!  This is the first time I've been (to my knowledge, anyways) and certainly (hopefully) not my last.  

They don't take reservations.  No OpenTable, nor over the phone- I'm sure a significant portion of their phone calls result in "no, we don't take reservations" but people will call anyways.  My dinner date and I arrived early so there were tables available.  We sat at the bar for a bit because this was our pre-Hamilton meal and that didn't start until 8pm.  

I've heard about this restaurant from my folks multiple times.  Heck, their folks probably ate here also- it's that old.  Which is not to say that old is bad, because it's not.  All of the waiters had dark pants and a white jacket on- felt so proper.  

Ordered some fried calamari to start the bar eats.  Larger pieces than I'm used to and just as tender.  While chowing those down, we saw the bartender make drinks like, well, like a pro.  Tadich has their own Bloody Mary mix and the ones I saw made looked PO-TENT.  Not sure I could walk up to the Orpheum after one of those even.  So I had an SF beer- Anchor Steam!

Eventually we sat at a table and ordered main meals.  My date had some sort of special with pasta I think.  Was way too consumed with my Seafood Cioppino with Garlic Bread to fully notice it.  I think this is a signature dish and it tastes like it.  

The wood-fire grill in back is impressive, leading me to want to order something cooked in it next visit.  

Pretty irrelevant but for those fascinated with purse hooks, they've got multiple purse hooks under the bar every few feet as well as coat hooks spaced similarly on the wall behind the bar.  Each dining nook has its hooks also.  No WiFi.  Didn't matter.

Holy cioppino!  Getcha some and enjoy!
author: David B.

description:
The food is outstanding and while our server was a little distracted from the party of 8+ he had, he was still a fantastic server. They do not take reservations but if you come in between 4-5pm, you should be okay! My table of four waited about twenty minutes for a table to open up, but with our drinks in hand it was not a problem. 

They serve real, complimentary sourdough bread while you wait for your appetizers and entrees. I was torn between the filet mignon and the cioppino and ultimately decided on the cioppino. This was a great decision!! I tried a bite of the filet mignon, per my girlfriend, and I instantly thought that the cioppino was better. 

For dessert my table ordered the bourbon bread pudding and the cheesecake. The cheesecake takes the cake, in my opinion. The bread pudding had a great sauce (?) and you can definitely taste the bourbon there. They were a great closer to the dinner. 

Loved the decor of the restaurant. The service and the food/drinks. I would highly recommend Tadich Grill to anyone looking for a good, quality dinner.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: great food and service! i like its original deco , with 169 years history, classic . if people don't bring out the smart phone, i don't remember in what eras we are in. Great experience
author: Vikki S.

description:
Cioppino! Get it :)

This restaurant has a classic story, history, and culture to it!

Great service, cool ambiance and delicious food and drink. Highly recommend.
author: Carina M.

description: Old school since 1849. How can you go wrong with an establishment that's been around for more than a century. The place is not cheap but if you don't mind having a delicious clam chowder it's a bargain. I hadn't eaten all day and I came by during the crazy lunch rush. I was able to get a stool at the counter and I ordered the clam chowder that comes with sour dough bread. The soup was delicious and the bowl of soup and bread made me full, so there was no need to spend a lot of money.
author: Franklin M.

description: Seafood restaurant established in 1849. Oldest restaurant in the city that embodies classic San Francisco. You will find white-jacketed waiters serving generous platters of food. It is a must visit!
author: Lucy M.

description: Our first visit to Tadich Grill it's the oldest restaurant west of the Mississippi we were greeted and seated promptly we started with calamari brought our own wine corkage was $20 main dishes ordered: crab cakes rice pilaf with veggies and petroli sole with veggies and potatoes food was good service was excellent parking wasn't validated we used a parking garage valet is offered after 5 pm tadich is classic sf with a lot of history.
author: Mark P.

description:
Exceptional clam chowder...best I ever had. Ordered the 8 oz NY was very tender and cooked perfect to MR. 
My friend ordered the sampler appetizer and the oysters were delicious!!
Fun date place and historic. Would dine again.
author: Jeannie M.

description:
After a fantastic lunch at Kokkari, we wanted to have some drinks in the area. Our friend, Valerie, suggested Tadich Grill. Just the other day a work colleague asked me about this place. During the many years we lived in the city and the Bay Area, we had never made it there. So I was excited. 

When we entered, we let the staff know we wanted to sit at the bar and have drinks. We were sent to the back. There were three open seats followed by many bar seats which were labeled closed. Since we weren't eating ( it was mid afternoon) , we were told we could not sit down and were sent back to the front where there were no free seats. Again we asked about drinks and were told that we could get something and stand. We decided to leave and ended up at Harrington's where we spent several hours and quite a lot of money. This place is resting on its laurels.
author: Nobbi L.

description:
Went for a late lunch around 3:15 with no wait at all 

Ordered fried calamari, grilled halibut, grilled Petrale Sole & two glasses of Rodney Strong Pinot Noir

Very Good Food, large portions, & Good Service

We really enjoyed ourselves
author: Jim D.

description:
So we came here on our first night in San Francisco 

My friend recommended it and couldn't stop raving about it

We were sat at the end of the bar, which was a great seat to witness the action 

I ordered the grilled trout dinner and my wife the rockfish dinner. While waiting we were served sourdough bread with plenty of butter. Very tasty

The food arrived and it was delish. We love seafood but this had to be some of the best we had ever eaten. Fresh..prepared well..just classic 

It was so good that we returned for an early dinner on our last night. We were seated at a table by the window. Much prefered the action at the bar but it was too early and the restaurant wasn't as busy 

Anyway we ordered the cioppini and crab cakes. Both were very tasty..especially the crab cakes. Service again was top notch

This place has to be one of the better restaurants we have ever eaten at

Highly recommended
author: Timmy T.

description:
This place is a true gem of the city. Great place for a fun lunch or dinner. Really good seafood as well.

My husband and I got the clam chowder. They have both the red and the white versions. I always prefer the white one - so good with the complimentary sourdough bread and butter!

They have a good selection of seafood but they have some meat selections too. 

Great place and I cannot wait to go back.
author: Cicely T.

description:
Other than it being pricy, this is pretty much as good as it gets.

At lunch time Monday, two of us were seated immediately.  We ordered two dishes to share: short rib and scallop.  The rib was melting-in-your-mouth tender and perfectly delicious.  The scallops were bedded in creamy polenta and extra "sea flavored" (no idea how else to describe).

I was grateful the companion shared with me.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description:
Oh Tadich Grill, you are one of the best things about living in San Francisco. This place is an institution and it never disappoints. For my last visit I had the scallop, prawn, and crab sauté. It came with rice and mixed vegetables. The fish was outstanding. While it made for a pricey lunch entrée ($35), it was worth every bite. I could eat here every day.

This place is run incredibly well and efficiently. Service is quick and the waitstaff is on top of everything. If you don't want to have a long wait for lunch, get there by 11:30. The restaurant will already be full but you'll be seated quickly. I went here for the first time about 25 years ago and it's just as good as it was back then. Do keep in mind that the staff wants you to move along after you're done because there are always people waiting for your table. Do not miss this place, there's nothing like it.
author: Lori M.

description:
The oldest seafood restaurant in SF! With great anticipation and hype we went as invited guest of a couple of regulars.  Two lawyers... that makes sense right? 
Well the place was cool big long bar with service on the middle.
Well lite area with wait staff all dressed in white smocks. 
Got there for an early dinner at 4:00. ...Ok they were really OLD lawyers!

We got a booth very quant and intimate.
Whiskey cocktail was weak! Had it twice both mostly ginger ale. 
Because these were civil attorneys we decided ahead of time it to NOT order the expensive stuff. 
She orders assorted seafood platter. 
I order fried one with double veg no fries. 

Beyond the fact that the food only rivals RED LOBSTER and not much better, the servers were aloof, not very attentive and food didn't come out for the four of us at the same time. 
My platter was well... Red lobster with linen tables cloths and napkins. I was not impressed for 36 smackers! 
I know some of the dishes are old school aka cheesy breadcrumbs cream sauce and the chopino is supposed to be to die for. But again we we're considering our hosts and tried not to go nuts. 

The high light was frankly the sourdough bread. Which I'm sure they can't take credit for. 
All the seafood tasted the same and the one oyster I did get was like the batter scooped out of oil at the end of the day. Hard dark and disgusting! 

To make matters worse, we had to ask for coffee, and got an incredulous look from the waiter...No offer for dessert. No refill of coffee and finally a waiter, not ours basically asked us to leave! 

I've frankly received better food and service, sans linen at Long John Silver!  As we were guest of regulars, we were not sure if bad service was because of them, or because they really are running on reputation. Either way when asked by our two lawyer friends for a return visit, I will gladly pay 4x to eat elsewhere.

I did take the two swizzle sticks that came with my weak ass whiskey cocktails. This may be on many folks bucket list. It wasn't on mine and I highly recommend you listen to the other reviews and adjust your expectations if this is still on yours. 

I'd hate to say I told you so.
author: Craig G.

description:
This was by far the worst restaurant experience I have EVER had !!!! The way the waiter treated our group was awful from the beginning it seemed like he had a problem with us.  We were a group of 6 and we spent over $600 in less than 3 hrs.  We were told we could not order anything further when we asked for a coffee after our dessert.  Then the manager actually asked us to hurry up and leave as they needed our table, but we were still eating our dessert !!! Then they literally ushered us out.  Once we were out one of the bar tenders shouted to us to close the door as if it was our job !!! When we didn't respond he shouted again.  I in fact closed the door and didn't even get a thank you. I have eaten in thousands of restaurants all over the world and never been treated in this manner.  I don't care if they were busy or not I was a paying customer who deserved to be there as did any other guest.  Maybe they didn't like that we were girls  (though we weren't being noisy) or that some of the party appeared foreign (though all have lived in US their whole lives and are successful professionals ) 
This kind of treatment is not expected at a burger chain let alone a supposedly fine establishment!!
As for their food it was merely mediocre. My suggestion would be to not book so heavily so that you can take care of your customers.  At this rate there won't be many customers to take care is soon .
author: Claudia K.

description: Loved my experience at this establishment. I have been twice but got the rib eye steak both times .. To be honest I am more attracted to the vibe and the fact that it's one of the oldest restaurants in San Francisco. Not saying the meal I had  was not good, it just wasn't one I would write about.. I will be going back to try something else..
author: Chris C.

description: Came here again with my parents and sister M. again. M. treated us for our bdays. Thanks to her. I was looking for something good that was cheaper--not possible...so I ended up getting the dungeness crabcakes. They were nice and it came with rice and a lot of veggies. Also had some of the creamed spinach good. I wonder though if some of the dishes could be 5-10$ cheaper. Meal is not economical and the interior experience is not that nice. Well, the history is special. And the menu is interesting and the food is dependable. Oh yeah, bread dishes!
author: Denise C.

description: Came here for a business lunch. I ordered the rosemary lamb shank and it was delicious. The staff are nice too. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone.
author: Ivy X.

description: I dream about the Cioppino here... This is one of the oldest restaurant in SF and it certainly has it's old school charm.  The staff are friendly.  The ingredients are fresh and I've only ordered the Cioppino here- which is pretty amazing!  It's a large bowl full of generous seafood such as crab, clams, prawns, bay shrimps, scallops, fish & mussels, topped with slices of garlic bread.  I've died and gone to heaven!
author: Melanie N.

description:
ALWAYS the BESTEST, FRESHEST SEAFOOD @ TADISH!!!!'
    As one of the oldest restaurants it NEVER disappoints ~ the servers most have been there forever, know their business and are a bit gruff, but in a nice way ~ very old schools with lots of dining options and if seafood isn't your thing they offer meat dishes also and the ones I saw looked very bit delicious as the fish  dishes taste~
    Ofcourse no reservations, and your entire party has to be present to get seated but you can't go wrong dining @ Tadish Grill ~
author: Becky L.

description:
My boyfriend and I went here for a romantic night out. We were seated immediately at a cute little table closer to the kitchen and our server came over with menus and water.
