I had never been here before, but my boyfriend had and had some favorite dishes already in mind. We started with an order of the calamari. It was delicious, crispy, and a very large portion for an appetizer. it came out about ten minutes after we ordered it and was piping hot. 

Because I had never been here before, I let my boyfriend order his two favorite entrees and said we could share them. He ended up ordering the Seafood Cioppino with Garlic Bread. It comes with clams, mussels, prawns, scallops, bay shrimp, crab meat, and white fish in a red broth. Although the various seafood is amazing, the broth has all the flavor. Make sure to use the garlic bread to soak up as much of the broth as you can because its the best part. Definitely get this dish.

For our second dish, he ordered the Dungeness Crab Leg Sauté. AMAZING. The crab leg meat was already peeled for us and then cooked in a delicious buttery sauce. The meat was tender and almost melted in our mouths while eating. It was served with rice and your choice of a vegetable.

Overall this meal was amazing. It was expensive, but you are getting great quality and huge portions for a great price. We ended up leaving the restaurant with enough food for another full meal. I will definitely be back!
author: Catharine P.

description: Great food, amazing service. Great atmosphere, strong drinks. I always try to stop by when my budget allows.
author: Jonathan S.

description: For our 15th anniversary we came to San Fran. I'm a foodie, and a little OCD so I researched the shit out of a place to find great cioppino (me) and steak (hubby). We decoded onTadich (no reservations). We arrived early, so that we could have a cocktail and relax after a busy weekend.  Cocktails were good. We were sat in a two top next to a bussing station so we got to hear banging dishes the entire time.. so romantic. We ordered the cioppino and a ribeye from our server, all Alvin... who had no personality. Food was mediocre, I've had better cioppino in AZ and steak as well. He was very unattentive, had to ask for more drinks, I would've liked some spice to the cioppino but he never came back to ask for tobasco. He never returned except to deliver the check. I gave him a small piece of my mind and we called it a night. So disappointed :(
author: Tara A.

description: Seafood really fresh. Great ambiance. Lack is seasoning on food however. That may be ok for some, but I was not thoroughly satisfied. Nice place though. Pricey. Portions OK
author: LaTonya T.

description: Great restaurant and neat atmosphere.  Food was fresh and well prepared. The desserts were fantastic.  The service was really good. Our food came out hot and tasted great.
author: Nathan T.

description: The best ciopinno and seafood salad!  I love this place.  I work a block away and and try to come every other month.  I've been coming here for 20 years and will continue.
author: Nanette D.

description: Tadich Grill is here to remind us that those who say old San Francisco is gone are full of shit and simply don't know where to go. Get in here and enjoy the professional service, the great drinks and the killer food. The next time Chet and Bethany invite you to some pop up nonsense in the Marina, tell them HELL NO, I'm going to Tadich.
author: Helmut R.

description:
In this neighborhood, Tadich Grill stands head and shoulders above most of the rest! Not only are the vibes excellent, the food is absolutely delicious!

Ambiance and decor are Old World-style, which makes perfect sense when you learn that Tadich is the oldest restaurant in both San Francisco and in California. The waiters are impeccably dressed in white and banter with each other and the diners in a playful (yet still appropriate!) way. There is a long high-top mirrored bar running the length of the restaurant; grab seats here (first come, first serve) for a quick meal or a happy hour drink. If you'd like something more private, there are booths tucked into alcoves along the opposite wall. 

The  menu is overwhelmingly large and prices at first glance seem a bit high, but when you get your plate you'll understand that not only are you paying for quality, but also for portions! MY GOD are these plates big! 

Bread service included in all meals. 

I tried the Fresh Alaskan Wild Halibut Filet in Soy Ginger Broth, found under the POACHED header. At $32.95, I really had my fingers crossed this one would be delicious and it delivered. The portion was large enough for two meals, as it comes with two separate filets and a large serving of vegetables (including an entire potato). Flavors were light and delicate. You really get the citrus and ginger in every bite. If I had one suggestion it would be to serve this one with a side of rice; it would complement the Asian-insprired broth. 

At the server's recommendation, my friend ordered the Cioppino. Typically I'd look at the $34.95 price tag for a bowl of soup and laugh out loud, but OMG! The bowl was MASSIVE and just absolutely packed with scallops, shrimp, clams, mussels, bay shrimp, whitefish, and dungeness crab. It was served with large hot slices of garlic bread. My friend ate and ate and ate and was able to put about 2/3 of it in a to go container. Absolutely worth the money. 

Even at this price point, highly recommended to anyone who wants some really exceptional seafood.
author: Lexi W.

description: This is one of the oldest restaurants in San Francisco. I wanted to try some different take on seafood and this is exactly that!the crab cakes were delicious and had a lot of crab meat. I tried the baked petrale sole and it came with stuffed crabmeat and shrimps. My friend ate the sand dabs. Everything was on point for both the dishes. Even the fries and veggies on the side were perfectly seasoned! I sooo wanted to try the bourbon bread pudding but i was too full to eat another bite!
author: Mugdha T.

description: We stayed at the Hyatt Regency on Embarcadero and the concierge highly recommend this place! Once we arrived, we realized we've been here before and it wasn't great then. I don't know what all the hoopla is about but this place is an overrated, over priced, I'm over it kinda place! The menu had half a book about the history of the owners who purchased this place, but great history doesn't translate into great food! And food wise, this place has much to be desired!!!
author: Puka M.

description: Go here for the ultimate SF experience. Delicious seafood, staff that is Uber attentive and kind. They seem like the group from Cheers- they know everyone and know their menu front and back. It was easy to eat here even with my gluten allergy.
author: Lindsey H.

description:
My friends recommended this place because we were looking for a restaurant that serves good seafood options. There were 4 of us, I was the only one that hasn't been to this restaurant. They were telling me it's history. That before, there were only male waiters. 

As fate would have it, we had a woman waitress helping us. She was nice but was in a hurry to take our orders. Checking in is to see if we were done not to see if we needed something (I know because she wouldn't ask - will just look at our plates and walk off). 

When we told her we want to see the dessert menu, she gave it to us and walked away for a bout a minute and came back to ask what we were having. My friend went to the restroom so we told her that we're waiting for our friend to come back to decide because we are sharing the dessert. She walked away and my friend saw her smirked! 

As that was my first time in this restaurant my friends said that this was the first time they received this kind of service. Usually, the waiter they've had in the past was as gentleman as they come. They would be patient, recommend dishes and just very courteous. 

The food was good by the way. We ordered the Manila clams in garlic and butter. The clams was cooked perfectly and we scooped and drenched our bread in that garlic butter. We also ordered cioppino (spelling?), seafood cannelloni in cheese sauce, prime rib, scallops. Their portions were huge. Specially the prime rib. 

One less star for the service but the rest was great! I would go back, hopefully I'll end up with a different waitress.
author: Celina S.

description:
Go for the old school ambience- a seafood oriented old school diner, they serve classics and the servers have an old world finesse you see in Europe. They know how to chat. Know how to make suggestions. Check on you perfectly without being intrusive. 

First of all, I love that the whole bar is first come first serve. This is by definition a tourist definition and I am not beyond doing touristy things. What's annoying about most touristy places is that your overplanning super party tourists try to pillage all the seating so locals and solo diners get screwed. After about a 20-30 minute wait, I snagged myself a seat. I enjoyed it because the process was fair and equitable especially with solo older men who seem like they're from here and just enjoy the food. The self seating process is by far a highlight. 

The bartender is old school and professional - asked for an old fashioned and asked what whisky I wanted which is most def how every place should do it rather than resorting to rail whisky like most joints these days. I ordered bulleit, and they had it. It was strong and no frills. 

As for the dinner menu- I say it's pretty solid. Given the choice between a grilled fish dish and the cheesy casserole dish of broiled fish and prawns, the server pointed me to the cheesy dish (forgot what it's called) and I appreciated it. Nomally I don't eat cheese and I don't like gimmicky food which I was afraid this was going to be. But it was absolutely solid. And for about 20 dollars, the portion was generous and delicious. There was almost a New Orleans vibe to the food and service - they just do it right and don't pay attention to trends. Unfortunately I didn't have room for my creamed spinach so I had to ditch it after a few bites, but that was also good. Once again, no frills creamed spinach, steak diner style - just plain good. 

The decor was kept the same throughout the years and it was absolutely gorgeous. 

I wouldn't eat here all the time if I lived in the Bay Area (I hate waiting) but definitely worth trying out as a tourist and bringing your out of town friends to experience golden age dining.
author: Lillian C.

description:
Lack of attention to details. Served fish cooked in butter to my wife with a dairy allergy (not intolerance), recommended a house special to me that was inedible, had to ask for drink refills, and billed us twice for a main course. 

While on vacation I called to find out the wait time and if they could accommodate a small child in a stroller. The person who answered said, "come in and we'll get you seated" and then hung up the phone before I could ask about the child. We arrived within 20 minutes and there was an hour wait.  Understandable for a highly rated restaurant, so we waited.  

My wife ordered the Sea Bass and told the waiter she had a dairy and gluten allergy. He said no problem, they would leave the butter sauce off.  For my dish the waiter recommend the Crab and Prawn House Special with a paprika sauce.  

They left the butter sauce off the Sea Bass, but also left the rice off.  When asked the waiter said she couldn't have it because it was gluten. Ten minutes later my wife started having a reaction to the fish. Turns out they cooked it butter!!

My "house special" was absolutely horrible, it tasted as if there was a cup of paprika in it.  I had to stop halfway through as I couldn't bare to eat it anymore.  That dish shouldn't even be on the menu, let alone a "House Special". 

The waiter came by our table rather frequently, however after the third time of him looking at our empty glasses I had to ask for a refill.  Then when the bill came the server had charged us twice for the Sea Bass. 

All these issues could have easily been avoided if the waiter just cared a little more.
author: Phillip H.

description:
Old world feel of this restaurant is welcoming. and we saw something about this restaurant on television and decided to try for ourselves. Bathroom is upstairs. They  accommodated my elderly FIL in such a kind way. Plus  the food was great. Hearty flavor of the cippinio was awesome. 
I had a pan fried Sol that was good but I would try something different. A friend tried crab cakes and raved about them.  Looking forward to a return trip
author: Renee C.

description: It has a very old vibe to it, including the set up. The bar was a super long table and their food seemed quite expensive. A mimosa was $11! We heard the food was really good though. We had the cup of clam chowder and my husband some oysters rockafeller with bacon added. Our bill came to $52.97 (including tip) which seemed high for just 1 drink, a cup of soup and some oysters.
author: Lysa D.

description:
Walking into Tadich Grill, for me, is like slipping on a comfortable robe knowing that I'm going to enjoy every moment!

We are talking food here but there isn't quite the right metaphor needed for how I feel about this place.

I first encountered Tadich Grill back in my graduate school days. I was asked to go to dinner with some big muckity muck on behalf of the school, with the bill being paid by someone else. I had no idea about this place but I remembered the food was good and comforting.

Years and gainful employment later, I find myself returning to Tadich Grill. When it's busy it look reminds of classic San Francisco dining...it should having been around for more than 100 years.

The sea food choices are great and their specialties are just fine. While service can be spotty when busy, I've found that when one waiter falls down on the job, another jumps in to take their place. Not a bad thing.

Better still I'm surprised by their dessert, with the bread pudding being a personal favorite. And the drink choices are wide and varied with plenty of top-shelf choices to wash everything down. 

In short, I suspect I'll be back again and again. I took my spouse recently and she loved it...forgot I took her in the past and insists on coming back.

Sounds like plan to me!
author: Ron C.

description: A classic. An institution. A feel-good place that is the kind of restaurant every major city has...the place where the established, old timers, local celebrities, politicians, pro-sports players, businesspeople etc. seem to gather. The bar at Tadich is at 100-foot long and you can enjoy dinner seated there or you can be seated at a white-tableclothed table for fresh grilled fish, raw bar and steakhouse styled salads and appetizers. The cippolino is fantastic and is in a tangy red broth. the Dungeness crab cakes are over the top delicious. Great for a business lunch or dinner, especially at one of the semi-private booths or just for drinks at the bar. No reservations accepted so you have to wait for a table, and no American Express.
author: Joseph P.

description: Seafood Cioppino. Superb here. Not overly "tomato-y" or salty. The pieces of butter garlic bread they serve with it is a great compliment to the dish. The server I had at the bar where I ate was super cool and fun. They have a decent selection of beer on tap as well. Watch out though, this place gets crowded.
author: Will C.

description: Amazing Louie's (shrimp and crab) plus we had Sand Dabs and trout. All well prepared. Great wait staff!
author: Victoria K.

description:
I've lived and worked nearby for 7.5 years, yet never stopped in.  So glad I finally got around to trying this classic San Francisco institution.  Not sure how the rest of the menu is, but the Cioppino is the best I've had.

Cioppino: The broth was perfect.  It wasn't thick like tomato sauce and it wasn't too watery; it was just right.  Every single shellfish piece was gigantic, so the counts don't really do it justice (2 Mussels, 2 Clams, 3 Shrimp, 3 Scallops).  My only complaint about the ratio would be that there was way too much whitefish compared to dungeness crab.  It was all delicious though, with enough leftover for a tasty lunch the following day.  Also, the two thick pieces of garlic bread were perfect for dipping in the broth; I liked that they were overly buttery.
author: Adam B.

description: I have Never been disappointed at Tadich Grill!!! Their seafood is so Fresh and so Very tasty!!! There menu is HUGE...So many choices, not only seafood. I have only been there about 5 times and each time I have tried something different!!! Each dish was superb!!! As is the service!!! This past time, our Server, José P. Maximillion, was The Best and ROCKED with his recommendations!!! Thanks José!!!
author: Louise L.

description:
Old school charm and great vibe.
Waiter suggested the Crab cake app and Cioppino and it did not disappoint 
I'll be back.
author: Art H.

description:
So happy we came across Tadich Grill! I'm a big fan of seafood and this is one of the best seafood restaurants I've been to. First of all, no need to book months in advance, they run a very efficient waitlist system. Secondly, service is impeccable! The wait staff were so attentive and knowledgeable. Their Best Ever Sidecar cocktail is exactly that - really really good. I ordered a prawn cocktail  for an appetizer, totally recommend it! The waiter said that the best item on the menu is cioppino and honestly, it was so good! My husband is not into seafood to the same extent so he had surf and turf which was also excellent. Portions are pretty big so come hungry. 
Overall, Tadich Grill is one of the best seafood restaurants I've been to. Great service, great food!
author: Alla Z.

description: I have eaten here twice in the last few months when visiting San Fran and both times it's been really good.  They have a long bar and one end is reserved for eating at the bar and the other In is a place to stand/sit to have drinks while waiting on tables. I ordered the sea bass that was really good and the oyster appetizer is absolutely amazing. This is a must stop when visiting.
author: Chris M.

description: I like this place.  It's unique and feels like you're eating in an retro art deco time period where table service was prompt, food was classic, and martini mix was fashion.  It's different from trendy or asian influenced restaurants that are abundance in San Francisco.  Eating here makes one wonders if there's a secret room that only those with the password can be seated.
author: Jenny G.

description: I love this place where is an old fashion style! Food was so great.  I ordered crab leg with white wine sauce that was so good. I took seat on the bar that service was nice and fast. Also, cheese cake was awesome! I would love to come back again.
author: Pinarat S.

description: Wow--a San Francisco classic.  The oldest continuously-operating restaurant in the city, if I'm not mistaken. Waiters are super charming and old-school. I ordered a Shirley Temple and he sang "A Shirley for Shirley!" which is cute. Food is classic, old school, and great quality.  Restaurant is light and airy thanks to the pretty, tall windows throughout.
author: Kati P.

description: You kind of walk back in time on this one! From the old school flirty bartenders, to the career waiters and giant wooden dividers between tables. The decor is sparse, but I feel like that's what you would expect in the 1920s? I had the sea bass and daughter had the crab cakes. Both delicious. In a nice part of town.
author: Rachel M.

description: Until last month I haven't been to Tadich Grill for many years. I have to say, it was even better than I remember which is hard to say about restaurants these days. Usually you find menus change, portions shrink, prices go up while the level of service goes down. Time improved this restaurant. The martinis were perfect, the salad was fresh and very  green and the scallops were perfectly prepared. They gave me 4 or 5 of the largest scallops I have ever seen. They were wonderful. According to my lunch guest, the crab salad was as good as Scoma's on the Wharf. The service was fast and efficient and the staff's white jackets bring you back in time. I will be back soon, next time brining my wife so she can experience this iconic restaurant, it's great menu and service. Definitely old San Francisco style.
author: Herman C.

description: Worst restaurent I have ever been in San Francisco. Zero stars. Waiters and manager were so rude and unprofessional , will never go back and I recommend you don't either.
author: Danville M.

description:
*** JBF America's Classic (1998) *** #14 **

In addition to being a James Beard America's Classic, Tadich Grill is the oldest restaurant in California.  They don't take reservations, but things move quickly here so the wait shouldn't be too long.  At prime time on a Saturday night (around 8 pm), it took about 30 minutes for our name to be called (and another 2 minutes for them to move on from us when we didn't show up immediately) but we were able to get seating at the bar within 5 minutes, which is what we had opted to do.  There seemed to be more bar seats than tables, so this is probably a better spot for 2 people vs a group.  What I liked about the bar seating which is first come first serve is that the bartender manages the seating and makes sure that whomever came first gets the next available seats.

It's a lively, friendly place with a cool old school vibe and very friendly staff.  Note that they only have wine by the bottle, not by the glass, but the prices are extremely reasonable and they have some great choices (oddly, barely a mark up on the ones I recognized).  

The menu is printed daily, but there are some specialties like the Cioppino, which is what I opted for and definitely a must get menu item.  I actually didn't realize that Cioppino is from San Francisco, so it makes sense that the best I've ever had would be found at the oldest restaurant there. The broth was thick and flavorful and so good that I was drinking it like a soup (I normally don't do that with Cioppino - I just pick the seafood out).  It comes with garlic bread which when dipped in the broth is just divine.  There was a generous amount of seafood - clams, prawns, scallops, bay shrimp, crab meat, mussels, and white fish - all of very high quality and delicious when served in the broth.

My sister had a daily special, the mediterranean branzino sea bass, which was also delicious. Even the vegetables that it was served with were full of flavor.  It was perfectly cooked and had just the right amount of flavoring to not distract from the natural flavor and quality of the fish itself.

Tadich Grill was the restaurant that we chose to dine at during our one night in San Francisco, and it was a great choice... fun and authentic and delicious!
author: Flora H.

description:
20 Trillion in public U.S. debt....

Two Stoli martinis please...and thus another lunch at Tadich Grill began.

120 Trillion in unfunded U.S Liabilities....

Tadich has been in business since 1848...think of that: The civil war had not begun. California would not become a state for another two years. The Great Gold rush had begun: fortunes would be made and lost and made again. Two world wars!!!

There are very few places left like Tadich Grill ( okay we still have Sam's, Schroeder's, and the old clam house)  but many have bitten the dust ( Trader Vic's,  The Old poodle dog, Vanessi's etc)

The food at Taddich Grill is still really good: Fabulous Cioppino served with their awesome french bread, Great broiled seafoods, off the hook crab cakes, lovely Louie salads...even good grilled meats. It's not cheap but its good

Service is top notch...these are professional waiters that do this for a living not to pay for college ( not that that is a bad thing). They know your name and remember your preferences.

Great bar and Great atmosphere with wonderful booths. Believe it or not you can actually have a conversation here!

The country may go bankrupt but I suspect that Tadich Grill will still be serving their classic fresh seafood well into the next century!
author: David G.

description:
Had a great time here. My son and I were seated at the counter and had some appetizers and drinks . We had two server's Michael and another server (didn't catch his name, had glasses) they both provided exceptional service and made our visit memorable.
Thank you guys!! : ) We will be back next time we are in town.
author: Myn V.

description:
I'm picky but this spot (I die) was worth the long wait on a cold rainy windy afternoon.  John was our waiter, sweetest guy ever!!!!
Best service! Cioppino is da bomb, the broth is hangova best. Loads of crab meat, shrimp, large shrimp, big scallops, mussels, clams and the bread for dipping for 33bucks is worth it. We licked the bowl
author: Vee V.

description: Tadiches is a San Francisco staple.  Food is excellent, service is the same.  All of the seafood is great.  Highly recommend it.
author: Katherine R.

description:
Okay at best. We ordered pasta (tasteless), burger (plain, but decent amount of vegetables so the 3 Star) brisket
(Okay) and seafood platter (not good surprisingly). 
The price and service are okay (not if you are in a budget of course).
author: Ari Z.

description: Their 'seafood en casserole' menu is really exceptional... there are cioppino places, there are chowder-in-bread bowl places, there are crab places, oyster places, Vietnamese spicy boil places, I wish there were more moules-frites places 'round here.... but.... seafood baked w/yummy things in little cocotte dishes; you don't find that so much. I've always expected to see a coquilles St. Jaques-type special w/bay scallops here, hasn't happened yet; they do have old-school lobster thermidor tho. Should definitely be on anyone's roundhouse list of Bay Area seafood places.
author: Kim D.

description: Love, love, love the cioppino but hated the fact that they don't take reservation . To get a seat at the bar is not easy too. They are busy everyday
author: Linda C.

description: Saw this restaurant on "check please" and it didn't disappoint.  We were there on a Saturday at 5:30 pm and was seated right away.  It was a little pricey, but well worth it.  Ordered crab cakes, it was delicious, next time I will try the steak.
author: Linda D.

description: Bartending service was spot on!  They make classic cocktails it brings you back to 50's era. The food was amazing. I ordered Patrole Sole & my husband Cioppino it was delicious. Overall I loved the atmosphere here!
author: Debbie M.

description: As advertised!  Fresh ingredients, lumps of crab meat in the crab cakes, cioppino's broth was perfect and accentuates the natural taste of the fresh ingredients!  Service was great, my daughter had to go back to work and our server made sure the food and bill were prompt. There's a reason why they have been around since the 1800's!
author: Ken L.

description:
Absolutely love it.  Bar service is great.    Scallops were large, fresh, delicious.   

I know some people feel restaurants like this are dinosaurs, but seriously.... if you want efficient service, good drinks, and good food with excellent size portions you'll like it.
author: Moses H.

description:
Yuck...for our anniversary dinner what a disappointment. The table was small and the food was disgusting. $200 that should have been spent somewhere else. I had the abalone and it was like nasty hockey pucks...and the calamari was almost as if it had freezer burn. We didn't even come close to finishing anything because everything we tried was awful...and my potatoes and vegetables were COLD. Seriously cold and disgusting. And my husband ordered rare and received a steak well done. The waiter was the only good thing about the place. But we would have rather gone somewhere where we could enjoy the entire experience. If you like old cold food then this is your place. 

Thanks for the response David. 

He did not fix the steak. We left most of our food and paid and left. He said we were full from our salads and it was busy. Did we want a box? I said no. He didn't notice the steak was charred and cooked through. My husband had a couple bites and we tried to share one of the 3 abalone pieces without the ability to finish that. It just was an off meal all the way around. We weren't given much attention because he was so busy and though my husband said it was our anniversary it wasn't noted by the staff. We weren't expecting any bells or whistles and sadly we just left with a bad taste in our mouth all the way around. It put a damper on our anniversary but we have each other...and that makes it all ok. But we honestly wouldn't be back to spend that kind of money for the service and the food we did receive. Thank you though for making an effort to ask.
author: Anna H.

description:
Hands down one of the best seafood cioppino with garlic bread; Clams, Mussels, Prawns, Scallops, Bay Shrimp, Crab meat, and White fish.
The broth is a great foundation to all of the ingredients.

Sea bass is excellent,  too.

Tip side dish of asparagus would compliment your meal.
author: Ric L.

description:
Absolutely wonderful seafood that is always fresh and made to perfection!  The experienced wait staff will explain each entree so you know exactly what your meal will be like. They take seafood seriously and it shows. Old school decor with white tablecloths and servers in white chef coat's. Love the center bar style and dark wood charm.  Bartenders can make any drink or suggest a drink for you. This place is always packed and a line waiting to be seated. But it's worth the wait...

Our family has visited Tadich Grill on several occasions and special events. You will always get consistent fresh flavored seafood dishes. We've tried so many dishes over the years and have brought guests to enjoy a piece of SF history.  You won't go wrong with their salmon, shrimp, Cioppino, snapper, mussels or scallops. Everything is so good! Might be pricey, but portions are large and you can always doggie bag it for lunch the next day. You will be excited for lunch the next day too!  LOL
author: Maureen K.

description: Great service and great place for lunch at the bar. Love the specials and best cioppino in the city.
author: Nathan B.

description:
Came here for an early weekday dinner with a coworker. We came because we heard that Tadich Grill is one of those SF institutions and has been around forever.

We shared the calamari appetizer and chowder. I had the famous seafood cioppino and he had the lamb. All portions were very, very generous, especially for SF. I don't think any of us finished anything that we ordered. All the seafood was super fresh. I had a ton of different seafood in the cioppino. Side note: I really liked how they had large lemon wedges just sitting out on the table for you. 

The service was very attentive. We came in around 6:30pm and didn't have to wait. Warning, they will not seat you until your full party is present.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Love this spot! Got seated @ counter for party of 2 in less than 15mins. I expected to wait up to 1/2hr. Pleasantly surprised.

Cioppino is delicious. Will definitely be back. Other grilled dishes while good, isn't anything to write home about. 

Decent bartender.

Cool decor and retro: men in white linen run the joint.
author: Anh H.

description: Tadich Grill is one of the great establishments of San Francisco! Sitting at the long bar brings about a certain nostalgia that many restaurants attempt to create, but miss the mark... Tadich is authentic and doesn't try to be anything that it isn't.
author: Scott H.

description:
Seafood Ciopinno was on point.  End of story period.  If you come here, get that dish.  If you love seafood, you won't regret it.  It tasted better than the seafood I had in Monterey.

The place was packed. Luckily there were only two of us and we got a place at the bar right away.   The servers are in their white lab type coats which gives the restaurant a classy and old school vibe to it.  The servers were efficient and get straight to the point. Our server was pleasant but all business.  

Eat, enjoy yourself, get out.  I would definitely come back.
author: Noah L.

description: Their crab cake is the best I have had, hands down! This will become a staple of my SF visits. Sit at the bar, it is a completely different experience.
author: Ryan B.

description: Came here on a weeknight and ordered cioppino, crab louie, crab and prawn a la monza, and lobster thermidore. The only thing I really enjoyed was the cioppino. Most of the foods were not prepared well and they used too much wine. Service is attentive. Street parking available. Prices were very reasonable.
author: Ruby G.

description: So here's an educated assessment from a customer since 1968(!)....great fish most of the time, some great servers, and a couple less so, and this evening had an awful experience with a server unbelievably rude. I am a local and a regular. I won't be rushing back. Management needs to address this kind of thing, it's not unheard of there as part of the 'ambience' of a  few of the staff. The website only invites to go orders in the 'contact us' tab so they may not be eager to hear customer feedback. I am giving three stars for the food and the majority of servers, but one poorly behaved bad apple sure spoiled it tonite. I sent visitors the other evening who didn't have a warm & fuzzy experience. This City has too many alternative for me to return for sentimental reasons.
author: ken k.

description:
To be honest, I'm surprised there are so many glowing reviews. I'm also surprised someone from the restaurant responds to every negative review in a super nice, apologetic manner...he obviously wasn't there last night. It seemed like everyone working there was in a bad mood. No one was friendly (including our server), no one smiled, and we literally got yelled at for following a host to a table after we were instructed to once our full party had arrived. I would say this started us off on a bad note, and the rude attitudes of everyone made the entire experience uncomfortable. 

The food was just OK, which was disappointing because they have a very exciting and extensive menu. The ambience I guess is nice if you like noisy, stuffy, and tight quarters. I definitely would not recommend for groups of four people or more and definitely not a great place for kids. This place has been around for decades and obviously has some strong appeal, because the place is always packed. Unfortunately, for myself and the other five people in my party it wasn't our cup of tea.
author: Leslie G.

description:
While this restaurant may be a San Francisco institution and wildly popular for unknown reasons (even if you're on an expense account), charging $30-35 for a salad that is barely edible is a crime. The prices don't bother me so much, but the food better be outstanding, and sadly, it's not.

UPDATE: Thank you, David, for the follow-up. I believe I had the Cosmopolitan or mixed seafood--something with shrimp/prawns and crab as I recall. I know it had iceberg lettuce which has virtually no nutritional value. However, I'm not sure what speaking with me would do at this point. I may end up going here again for a work lunch, but I would NEVER pay to eat here. I must say though, I'm perplexed by reviews above two or three stars.
author: Torrpedo T.

description: Had lunch here on my last SF trip. Service was great and the food was good, but I was expecting a bit more from the sand dabs based on the raves I had been hearing.
author: Saleem E.

description: First visit to San Francisco and had to go to the oldest restaurant in the city. Amazing waiter Jose P provided great suggestions and knowledge of the menu. Service was beyond exceptional. Glasses were never empty and he was very attentive. Seafood Cioppino was delicious and definitely a can't go wrong.
author: J F.

description:
Cioppino is a seafood stew that typically combines Dungeness crab, fish, shrimps, scallops, clams, mussels, and squids.  The broth is tomato-based with herbs and wine in the mix.  Regarded as the signature dish of San Francisco (that's right, it's not Rice-a-Roni), there are plenty to be had this side of the bay.

Established in 1849, Tadich Grill prides itself with its Seafood Cioppino.  Unlike most restaurants where the Dungeness crab legs are served in shells, they dish up a lazy man's version, i.e., no cracking is required because all the work has already been done in the kitchen.  They give out a good heap of crab meat on top of the stew.  Although the jumbo prawns and sea scallops helped make for a hearty bowl of cioppino, the broth didn't have much of that piquant flavor.  It was a bit lighter than my favorites over at Scoma's and Woodhouse Fish Co., but it was enjoyable nevertheless.

Aside from the Seafood Cioppino, the Dungeness Crab and Prawns a la Monza was another popular entrée.  Baked in a ceramic cookware, it had shell-free crab meat and huge prawns over rice with some mushroom sauce, spices, and parmesan cheese.  Everything blended beautifully resulting in a very tasty casserole dish.

Their Clam Chowder came in two varieties - Boston and Coney Island (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tadich-grill-san-francisco?select=Vw6QzcgZU9rRoHikz-AVug).  There were plenty of clams in both, but MA won this one over NY.  The Boston variant had a richer consistency than the other which seemed to have the same broth as the cioppino.

We've also tried the Calamari Steak with Garlic Butter Sauce which was served with a side of steamed broccoli and cauliflower.  The calamari was perfectly pan fried.  It was tender with a nice crust and the garlic sauce was the perfect supplement.

With 167 years of experience, Tadich Grill is a very viable seafood option in San Francisco.  It's a Financial District icon, having been in its current location since 1967.  It's always busy with no reservations, so be prepared to wait for that taste of vintage SF...
author: John L.

description: Been here several times across the last decade. A good place to head for sourdough bread and cioppino. Servings are large (especially when you fill your belly with lots of bread), and I always forget this and end up eating way too much. If I could remember, I'd share with a friend a single order of bread, a crab cake, and then a order of the cioppino. With a couple of beers that would be the perfect meal. If my schedule permits, I always try to go off hour so I don't have to wait for a seat.
author: J. Christopher E.

description: As always great food and service. We were lucky and got our favorite waiter Marion. He's the best.
author: Sandra K.

description: First time for us .... Amazing, the Sanddabs are a must along with the Grilled Sole. We also had the Bay Shrimp salad which is also a must. The small shrimp are fresh and sweet. Would definitely come here again.
author: Jim M.

description:
I'm surprised that I haven't written a review for Tadich before now.  I love this place for great food, big portions, and a classy atmosphere without being pretentious.
The seats along the bar are all first-come, first-served, so that's often your best bet to be seated quickly -- I've eaten there both times I've visited.  
The Boston clam chowder is my favorite north of Monterey.  It's a bit peppery, but I live it.  A big bowl of that and some bread is a little slice of heaven.  Both visits, I've also split the pan-fried petrale sole with a friend.  It is a HUGE portion, served with potatoes and other mixed vegetables.  Also very good.
I have yet to try the desserts, but the caramel sauce they ladle over the top of the bread pudding makes it tempting.  I finished last night with a cappuccino, which was lovely.
The one drawback is that the servers are a bit brusque, which is a bit surprising since I know the wait list to work here is long and they tend to stick around for a long time.  Our server last night got my friend's app order wrong, and continually mumbled to himself.  Also...  where are the women in this place??  I literally only saw one.
author: Calee S.

description:
It's a nice place. Very old school bar.

I would give this more stars but on my first visit to the place i asked for a Paper Airplane, which is a staple in SF btw, was told, "what the heck is that?"

I gave them the recipe and they actually didn't have the ingredients to make it.

What the heck?

Ended up with a watered down Pimms Cup.

I may give this another shot but frankly that was pretty lame.
author: John C.

description:
The service was excellent! The Chilean Sea Bass was very good. Unfortunately the Abalone was not prepared correctly. It was not pounded out to a  lacey consistency and put in a milk bath to take
away any fishy taste. It was chewy and had a fishy flavor. For $36 
it was very disappointing. The sides were nothing special, somewhat bland and vegetables cooked well done. The Crab cocktail sauce was good but the crab just okay. All in all we had a good time and as I said the service was great!
author: S S.

description:
My go-to in SF.  Always terrific from the food to the service. The seafood is as fresh as it gets and their salads and Louie's are the best.  The guys in the white jackets may get a little short with you, but give it back to them because they are all pros and used to it!

Love the chowder too.  

Cant miss....
author: rob a.

description:
Overall, this place deserves a full 4 stars. The food was seriously delicious, and one of the best meals we had in San Fran, but our wait service really didn't compare.

We came in and sat at the bar while we waited for our table and the bartenders were a riot. We had a lovely time enjoying a glass of wine, and chatting with them until our table was up!

When we got seated, we were unfortunately displeased with our server. I understand he was busy, but he never once checked on us during our meal. It took wayyy too long to get our check, and he didn't even ask if we wanted dessert. 

Anyways, I'm only knocking one star because everything else at Tadish was fabulous. The ciopino  was seriously to die for. Trust the reviews, you won't be disappointed!
author: Sara H.

description:
This place is a classic. Locals still come here despite the presence of clueless tourists wearing their baseball hats inside.

Our service was perfect. The waiter provided recommendations and was professional and friendly.

The complimentary sourdough bread was delicious. The oysters on the half shell were plump and juicy (although one had a teensy bit of grit).

If you don't order the cioppino, you're a fool. Yes, it is crazy expensive like everything else here. But it's wonderful. The crab cakes are terrific, too.

This is the third oldest restaurant in the country and the oldest restaurant in California. Long may it live.

And remove your stupid baseball hat. You don't need it inside the restaurant.
author: Craig W.

description: I think this is the oldest restaurant west of the Mississippi - yeah so what... the food is classic yes, but modern too. The waiters are grumpy, but hell it's a facade, they love their job, consummate professionals and have fun while at it. The food is old school, but the cioppinio was the best I have ever experienced in my life (sorry Mrs Farber)... The cheese cake was better than anything I've ever experienced. We liked it so much we came back the next day for lunch. Classic cocktails, classic food, classic waiters; it's a classic!
author: Kenneth F.

description:
If you ever wondered what it must have been like to experience San Francisco during the Barbary Coast days, Tadich Grill is the best place to go and play out your 49er fantasy. They don't accept gold nuggets as payment anymore, but what you will find is fresh seafood, expertly prepared, served by some of the friendliest and most knowledgeable waiters in town, in a classy and charming wood paneled room that harkens back to San Francisco's gold rush days.

When a restaurant has been around for this long, you know they have their system down pat. Despite its long history Tadich Grill manages to uphold time honored traditions without coming across as overly gimmicky or trite. It is an original and it's food stands on its own.

The service was spectacular and our waiter had us laughing like old friends. He was so great and entertaining and provided a wealth of information about each dish.

Wine is affordable here (Whites range from $34-$56, and less for half bottles) and the tightly curated list means every wine is great.

The crab cake was perhaps the most legit crab cake I've ever had--almost all crab and not bready at all. The Oysters Rockefeller were a real cheesey treat. We loved our grilled halibut and pan sautéed rockfish with crab. The hollandaise on the rockfish was very rich--maybe a little too heavy handed? Eh, I didn't really mind! I love hollandaise!

We topped it off with cheesecake (so good!) and espresso. We'll definitely work coming back soon for this cold day tradition!
author: Jeff K.

description:
I sat at the bar by myself and ordered the cioppino. It was delicious, chock full of seafood, and wonderfully seasoned. I would definitely say that was the best thing to order. It was a ton of food, and I took half home. The bread was also delicious.  

Great place for a business or casual lunch because of how long it has been there. It was a fun experience.
author: Lauren A.

description: Had lunch , place very nice. Open from 1850. Old atmosphere. Lots of wood tables and big bar. I loved it. The menu is Hugh. Any fish you want they have. Enjoy.  I would defiantly come back.
author: Aviv T.

description: If I wanted to go and sit in a dark corner, eat undercooked Food and be served by a surly waiter, this is where I would go!
author: Hava D.

description:
Classic great restaurant that embodies San Francisco. No reservations so either come early or prepare for a wait. Don't worry they have a bar you ca get a drink at while you wait for your table. 
The seafood is fresh and great! The sliced  tomato quartet is great. On a bed of sliced iceberg the seafood and tomatoes do all the work to make this a fresh and tasty treat. We also had the shrimp bisque, which is obviously rich but very good. 
Entree I had the petrale sole which was so delicate and delicious pan fried. It came with thick French fries and a simple medley of vegetables. 
We had no room for dessert. 
I have come here many times in the past and would highly recommend it for a consistently hearty tasty meal. You get a lot of food and it's worth the money. The clam chowder, chioppino, sautés and pretty much anything else are all very good.
author: Michael D.

description:
I like Tadich Grill's old school vibe. It always has a good, family style atmosphere covered with very nice folks; both waiters and customers.

We have occasional seafood cravings in my household and Tadich Grill is a great place to satisfy these cravings. I love the menu, dishes are usually simple and the seafood is the star. It might actually be a little bit too simple for some folks but I like the bare bones seafood experience with some fish and steamed/boiled veggies. Rockefeller oysters are amazing. I tried a couple of different things on the menu. I liked the halibut steak and the whole sea bass. It is definitely a $$$ place but the quality of food is upscale.

They don't take reservations and wait for a part of two is usually at least 20 mins. You can wait at the bar and get some drinks while waiting for your table.
author: Cem A.

description: A must try while in SF. Very cool, classic old school ambiance. The seafood cioppino was amazing and the service was good, servers always making sure you're doing well with a full glass of water.
author: Bebe E.

description: Dinner with my parents at Tadich - Great Food and service but extremely noisy. We were shocked to see how loud and disruptive the kitchen staff were, banging and clanging the dishes during dinner and dragging chairs as they were cleaning up. Tadich would need to look into that if they want to maintain their dining experience.
author: Madura R.

description: The perfect place for a bowl of clam chowder and a crab salad while you avoid the craziness of Market Street.
author: matt w.

description:
Seafood lovers - get in this.

Crab cakes were as good as promised, the drinks were on point, ambiance as well. Crusty service, but in the way it should be for an older established restaurant like this one. It felt as it should be and was attentive without being intrusive. Helpful with a large menu. Would absolutely return with visitors to showcase older SF vibe and our seafood. We really enjoyed ourselves for our lunch there on a weekday.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Been coming here I think forever but not as forever for the restaurant as it really has been serving food forever. So last night after stops and starts with a meeting I stopped here. 

Starting at the bar with the perfect small martini and the banter from the great bartenders that told me to f***k the cancelled meeting and just enjoy the place. Well, since I haven't been here for a few years I certainly made a great choice. So after a couple of those super cocktails I went down the counter for dinner. Now the counter is great and don't forget those great booths in the back that make this place special. So ordering I had the great steams clams, the great bread that is always present and the amazingly fresh fried seafood platter. I mean the food ordered was perfect. The service awesome and the only ding was my mistake ordering the custard rice pudding for dessert that had way too much nutmeg. 

So, this place remains great and it may be a few years again til I get back but I am sure it will be just as good as ever.
author: Rickey B.

description:
Tadich has gone downhill quite a bit since my first review.  I have been disappointed now on two different occasions.  

First dinner, I used to come here and always order the  cioppino but this time it was filled with seafood that didn't seem fresh and over seasoned.  Even the soup base was over seasoned.   The quality of seafood has dropped dramatically.  I pretty much decided to not come back any more.  That was more than a year ago.  

Well, last night my colleague invited me to have a drink here.  Drinks were fine but then we ordered an appetizer - oyster Rockefeller.  It was gross. Don't get it.  Tiny oysters topped with mushy spinach  and cheese.  I actually like spinach but this topping had no flavor and frankly all other places use large oysters for this dish.  It was probably by far the worst oyster Rockefeller I ever had.    I didn't think you can mess up this dish this badly.  

The only reason I didn't return it was I was not sure if our bartender has to pay for it.  He was good and nice.  I decided to tell him to just tell the chef we were disappointed.  

I will not be back.  Given all the history of this place, It's sad how badly this place has slipped in food tastiness and quality.  :-(
author: Lei H.

description:
SF's "original Cold Day restaurant" certainly knows how to warm you up and leave you feeling full! Ever since I set foot in the City for work, Tadich Grill was on my bucket list to try. I'm so glad I finally came in for one of their best-known dishes, the cioppino. 

One of the first things I noticed about the dish was the sheer amount of portions, which were *cue Trump voice imitation* YUUUUUUUGE! They definitely don't skimp out on clams, shrimp, crab meat, scallops, and the other seafood. Also, the tomato broth is piping hot and very hearty. However, as great as the broth and the seafood are, I really loved the garlic bread that came with the stew. It was perfectly toasted, and although at first it looked to be overly saturated with garlic and olive oil, it tasted just right. Perfect complement to the tomato broth! 

Compared to the other cioppinos I've had, this one is the best BY FAR. Sure, it's a little expensive (I believe it was $28, excluding tip and tax), but the portions are worth it. You WILL leave full and satisfied! 

I'm glad I had the opportunity to dine in one of SF's oldest restaurants, even if it was for lunch. I'll be sure to recommend their cioppino to anyone who is in need of something that's NOT ramen to warm them up on a cold day.
author: Viet N.

description:
You got to love the old fashion decor. Cozy private-ish booths. Dark wood all around. A long wooden bar in the front. This is what I would call a traditional restaurant. I been wanting to dine here because of it's history and known as one of the oldest restaurants in all of America. 

The food was good but yeah nothing like over the top. It's consistent I would assume because it has been opened for over 100 years. The menu is huge, so many things to choose from. My friend and I started with the **Steam Clams. So happy they have clams rather than just mussels. The clams were cooked perfectly and that garlic broth was very tasty. Can dip bread in it all day long. We also got a single order of their **Crab Cake. Yum! Crab in every bite. For entrees, my friend got their **Cioppino. Very tasty. Not the best I had but it was good. I got the special, **Crab and Shrimp Casserole. Loaded with cheese, crab, prawns and rice. So yummy. Heavy tho but so good. We ended the night with their **Bread Pudding. Its made with bourbon and very sweet. It was good but not amazing. 

The staff was friendly as well as our server. I will definitely come back because it's just a cool atmosphere.
author: Sandy B.

description:
The original cold day restaurant!

You see the above on the front page of the menu, but let me assure you that cold, freezing, warm or hot, one may stop for a meal here and leave fully satisfied! 

I am not going to beat around the bush, I stop here for the Cioppino! Every single time I tell myself, "try something different", and at times I have, but Cioppino is what I drool for and it is what brings me back! My second favorite is their fried calamari, but the portions are so generous that I can only indulge in this tasty appetizer if I have a hungry friend or two with me! 

Now let me tell you about the Seafood Cioppino! This is their signature dish. all the goodness comes in a large plate and is based in a delicious tomato based sauce. What is "all the goodness" you may ask? We are talking scallops, clams, shrimps, mussels, white fish, and on and on! Oh that sauce though! Just deep the sourdough bread in it, let it get soaked, put it in your mouth, close your eyes and let your taste buds tell you all about it!

Here is a tip, if this is your first time and it is only 2 or maximum 3 of you, sit at the counter and engage your server in a casual conversation. You may learn a thing or two about Tadich Grill's history or even San Francisco and food. Most of the servers have been there for years and can answer many of your questions.

At the end, if you have any room left, I recommend the Bourbon Bread Pudding and a cup of coffee (or tea).

Oh, and do not forget to read the history of the place on the front page of the menu! It is short and fun to read.
author: Afshin A.

description:
Not the first time here but worthy of a review.  It ain't cheap my friends but the experience may be one to enjoy.  The staff are professional all the way down to the white coats.  It is a seafood heavy place so come on with that on the brain.    Even if you don't need the bathroom walk up there and see the timeline on the wall from 1849!to current.  Very cool!

I swear by:  Scallops, crab and shrimp.  I watched a gent eat cod across from me and engaged with him to find out how it went.   Verdict is I will try it for my next round.   

This is a serious restaurant and they make seriously great food.
author: T L.

description: Classic San Fran.  Lunch was amazing with the rare combo of great food and service.  Guess that's why this place has been around so long.
author: Chris C.

description: Whenever I'm in San Francisco for business my go to spot for lunch or early supper w/ people I care about is Tadich Grill. Nice long counter w/ waiters in long white coats waiting you provides a warm nostalgic feel. Great place to go to let your hair down over the most delicious fresh seafood and steaks. Right on California Street in the heart if the business district. Try to get there before noon for lunch or else there will be a long line outside.
author: Ken S.

description:
Read the reviews, and saw some good some bad. Then I talked with the Bellman at the Palace Hotel who recommended Tadich, spot on. The place was busy, but the wait was, nice. Had a chance to sow down and visit with some of the other people at the bar. This is was eating out is meant to be, visiting with people you don't know, sharing stories, favorite places, just enjoying humanity. Then when it was time to eat, the place didn't disappoint. Maybe the best Chowder I've ever experienced. Not too dense, as some can be. Great texture, amazing flavor, the right amount of everything. I had the Swordfish, which was prepared perfectly. Even the vegetables were cooked correctly. My wife had the prawns, scallops, and crab leg medley, cooked just the way it should be. 
Don't be afraid of the crowds, or the people that whine about the food, you will have a wonderful experience if you choose to. 
Hats off to all the servers and wait staff. Thank you for a memorable time.
author: Mike B.

description: Tadich Grill is a must visit every time I'm in town.  I always say that I'm going to trying something different, but in the end I always get a bowl of Clam Chowder and a Dungeness Cocktail.  Friendly staff.  Fantastic bread ...
author: Mark F.

description:
Go here for classic old-world San Francisco style.  This restaurant is just oozing with nearly a century of character.  All of the waiters wear white old style formal button down attire.  The staff is impeccably familiar with the food offerings.  And the portions are large.

I have been here multiple times and the consistency is also on point.  You order the same thing, you get the same thing.

My favorite is the hamburger steak.  I opt out of the mash potatoes and get a heap of the steamed vegetables instead. 

A larger wine list and some specials would really perk things up on the menu.  I would love to have a reason to go here other than having people in from out of town.
author: John S.

description:
The oldest restaurant in SF, the waiters wear what looks like lab coats and they have a bar table top that looks like half a football field. 

I had to go with the seafood cioppino which was absolutely amazing. The price of the dish was around $33 which is pricey but it's darn good. The broth is excellent and there is a reason why this place is always busy. I noticed on the plates it mentioned it's "The cold day restaurant" and I couldn't imagine much more delicious warm soups than this.
author: Rod M.

description: Ambience was very nice and great detail in the setting. Wait staff was very good, and attentive. The portions for the price were not adequate in my opinion and the fish was not overly flavorful. Didn't offer any substitutions for "vegetable of the day" which I informed wouldn't even be touched as was not. Wish they were more flexible. Don't plan on ever returning.
author: Lucas O.

description:
I come here for the clam chowder. 
It's always great. Nice consistency, perfectly textured potatoes and plump clams. 

Also the service here is amazing.
author: Veronica S.

description:
The cioppino at Tadich is the best I have ever had. The light red broth, succulent white fish, layers of crab, tender tuna steak, and prawns all combine for an incredible flavor I find delicious .The menu is extensive, although I've only tried the also excellent crab cake appetizer. 
The staff at Tadich may be a bit rough around the the edges for some. I suggest going strictly for the food and the rest will grow on you.
author: Don A.

description:
Always always get the Halibut Floriintine and Seafood Ciippino!!!! Excellent every time we come here!!!!
Love this place every year we visit San Francisco
author: Robert G.

description:
Loved this spot. Great time and Tim our bartender was stellar. The place was packed and they don't take reservations and why should they?? Awesome stuff. 

If you can find a seat at the bar do it while you wait and it makes the "45 min" a lot less. 

Had the oysters Rockefeller and the cioppino were great. Loved this local spot for seafood. Nothing pretentious just great food. 

Will go back for sure!
author: David H.

description: Fell in love with this place the moment we walked in. The service was exceptional, from the bar to our table. We had the crab cakes & the Cioppino....and it was Perfection! There was so much flavor & plenty of seafood in this dish. The crab cake was my appetizer & the Cioppino was my main course. I was struggling to finish everything because I didn't want to waste one bite of these heavenly dishes. FYI, if you're able..ask to be seated at one of Marion's tables, he was phenomenal & has worked there for over 30yrs!
author: Myra T.

description: Wonderful Service and an older Manhattan ambiance - with the best fresh fish - Sea Bass, Crab, Shrimps and Abalone.  Great salads and side dishes - stay away from Fried fish though - focus on freshly broiled or poached or salads.  Fair pricing.  Only restaurant in Financial district open on Saturdays' for lunch - no reservations but no problem.
author: Ted D.

description:
Went here for an anniversary dinner this past January. Very upscale, very clean, the waitstaff were wonderful and patient. We took a few extra minutes to decide on our order and it was getting to be a "dinner rush" time, but we were not rushed AT ALL and they could not have been nicer. 

Our food was DELICIOUS. I ordered some fried shrimp with steamed vegetables, so it wasn't anything special or fancy as far as my choice of dish, but it was without a doubt the best fried shrimp I've ever had in my life. My boyfriend had some shrimp and scallops and felt the same way.
author: Elise S.

description: I've been trying to get to this historic restaurant for a long time. Well we made it there we made it there March 8th at Thursday and I'm happy to say we were not disappointed! Of course it is extremely well-known and popular so therefore it was very busy. At first I was like oh no we're have to wait a really long time before we get a table but that wasn't the case at all. While waiting for our table which was about 20 minutes we were entertained by all of the people coming in and by the wait staff in there neat clean old school white jackets. We were really lucky we got a seat by the window and to have Marion a 30 year veteran of Tadich Grill as our server. The service here seems to be impeccable which I really appreciate. The food was absolutely delicious  and Marion presented us at the end of our meal with a complimentary bourbon bread pudding! Honestly we can't wait to go back the whole experience was so much fun.
author: Karie H.

description:
Another classic San Francisco eatery. Fresh seafood,  60 ft of counter space for couples to dine, white
Coated experienced bar staff at counter to serve fast and elegantly. Booth tables more secluded also available. We
Enjoyed a simple mixed seafood salad with choice of dressing and lots of lemons handy if you want them. Super filling for $18 and worth it. Excellent service and quality. We will be back!
author: Diane A.

description: We have been here many times.  The clam chowder is a must!  Try not to fill up on the delicious crusty bread.  The branzino and cioppino are always on point.  The branzino is grilled with olive oil and lemon.  The sides are ok but the fish is the star here.  The cioppino is a bowl full of the freshest most tasty fish and broth!  A must!  Love the waiters! Never miss a chance to visit!
author: Marie S.

description: Thoroughly enjoyed my seafood meal and the entertaining server.  My daughter and I opted to sit at the bar and eat as there was no wait.  The service and our meals were excellent! The atmosphere is warm and friendly. A tour guide had told us this place was a must and we would not be disappointed. She was right!
author: Mary S.

description:
What can I say ? This place is wonderful & has been since before we were all born.
 
Good bloody Mary - as always. We also bought 2 bottles of the mix - which I can no longer find in stores (sadly). 
Our waiter was top notch ! Wish I knew his name.( Wait ! Yeah ! Ken !)
Food was plentiful & great. Filet of sole & Tuesday lunch special - pot roast .  Both excellent ! Prices are also reasonable.
author: Jackie L.

description:
The food is ok, but a bit overpriced. 

We came in for dinner last Friday and the restaurant was packed. Luckily, there were two open seats at the bar. I ordered the sautéed scallops and pisco punch while my boyfriend ordered the seafood cioppino and oysters (6) for sharing. The oysters were dry/un-slurpable and pretty bland. I had to pry the meat off the shell with the tiny fork. 

Dinner ended up being about $50 per person. I don't have an issue with paying for a nice meal but for some reason, we left Tadich Grill feeling like we paid a little too much for dinner. Maybe it was because of the mediocre service, or maybe it was because the dishes didn't quite hit the mark. I'm not completely ruling out Tadich Grill for future meals, but I would not go out of my way to grab lunch or dinner here.
author: Helen P.

description: Incredible fresh seafood. I always overeat when I come because I can't help myself and get a e bowl of clam chowder and then the petrale
author: Cathy G.

description: Classic San Francisco. Oldest restaurant in the City. Great for lunch or dinner - family or business. A must visit for those new to San Francisco or for old timers. Food is special and waitstaff interesting and knowledgeable.
author: Mike H.

description: One of the best San Francisco restaurants I've ever eaten at. From the host to the bartender to the waiter wonderful service the best cioppino I've ever had in my life.
author: John K.

description: I took my dad to Tadich Grill for his birthday because he LOVES sea food. Honestly it was amazing! We went in and were automatically greeted and attended. The wait was only like 7min and we were offered drinks while we waited, which was great. Once we sat down we met our amazing server who had a great sense of humor. He really made my dad feel special on his birthday, which we really appreciate. The food was great and they even had a vegetarian pasta made for me. The experience overall was amazing, we will definitely be coming back! :)
author: Hazel R.

description:
Nice front of house service and of course fabulous historic / folklore atmosphere. 

The food was less than uninspired - bland and composed of clearly very cheap ingredients. The waiter, a white haired gentlemen who looked the part, hurried us along, upselling every one in our party of 6, gave negligent and misleading wine descriptions clearly just trying to sell, and was generally unsatisfactory. 

What I will remember of this experience is the great old decor and the laughable food sold at an exorbitant premium. And The careless service. Not a bite of food was memorable. 

If you are seeking a strong whiff of a golden era, and also want to eat well, be treated graciously, and taste quality exciting dishes to boot, make the trip to LA and go to Musso's.
author: Marion B.

description: I sat at the counter, love counter seating esp at old classics like Tadich.  Was served immediately with some sourdough bread and a glass of water.  Very friendly service, excellent waitstaff.  I ordered the the combo seafood satuee with rice and veggies.  It was good, but the portion was meh and for the price, I could have gotten soooo much more at another SF classic, like Sotto Mare! But it is as good...but Sotto Mare's man....this was like the 3rd or 4th time there. Maybe I'll come back...only because it's an SF Native thang.
author: Jill P.

description: Dinner was delicious!  20 minutes wait for a Tuesday night is not bad.  I would say The average age group in the restaurant was interestingly 50-55.  :) We felt quite young since hubby is turning 42 today!
author: Bing C.

description:
Best seafood in San Francisco! 
The waiters were  quality and super friendly and made our group of 15 feel like at home. 
Food was outstanding, hands down very good restaurant. No wonder why they have been in business so long.
author: Gabriel A.

description:
Simple, classic, and extremely delicious. I see why this restaurant has such great reviews from the service to the food everything was superb! 

This place is a classic in San Fran establishment. When you walk in it feels like you step back in time. The serves are witty and quick. You can get a seat in their famous booths or you can go to the high tops near the kitchen if you don't want to wait. 

The menu is classic American. If you like crab or fish you will be happy with any of those dishes. The crab cake app was simply delicious. I also tried the classic dish of Chilean sea bass. The fish was cooked to perfection and very flavorful. Each main dish comes with steamed veggies and finger potatoes. No fuss added to them, but they are good. The protein though is the main star of your dish. 

If you get any sides go with the garlic bread!! I don't know what they do to this bread, but I almost ate the 4 huge slices by myself. 

Great spot, service, and overall experience. Closes early so don't come in too late.
author: Krizia C.

description: Classic San Francisco.  A reliable choice for perfect petrale and for a variety of seafood cocktails, most notably the sweet fresh dungeness version.  Old school sauces and old school atmosphere.  Step back into Tadich, and enjoy the moment.  This was a favorite of ours when we lived here years ago, and it's always worth a visit.  Servers are never warm, but they do know their stuff.
author: Bill M.

description: Tadich Grill as an accidental dinner choice on a Saturday evening. Turns out it was the first restaurant in San Francisco. The vibe of the place is very friendly and casual. The servers all wore a white coat and looked very crisp and professional but they were completely down to earth. Their seafood appetizer platter is to die for so yummy! I even left my phone there by mistake and they had kept ti for me safely. If you love seafood and love amazing staff and are in FIDI then this is a good place to stop and grab a bite, maybe a drink or two too!!
author: Marmarin V.

description:
Love the vibe! When you walk in the doors, despite how crowded and busy the place is, you're immediately greeted by an attentive wait staff. Expect to wait 30-40 min during dinner time, and your entire party needs to be present in order to be seated.

After I'm seated, I glance at the menu. The appetizers here are stacked with seafood items: rockefeller or raw oysters, bay shrimp, scallops, lump or king crab, and the delicacy list goes on.


Main courses span assortment of fish that's either sautéed, fired or deep-fried, and broiled or baked. Meats include small cuts of all the classics: ribeyes, lamb and pork chops, fillet mignons, and New York Strips. Meat prices are reasonable compared to steak house rates, because the meat portion sizes are smaller than what you'd get at a traditional steakhouse. I choose to order the cioppino, which is is more than enough for a main course. The overall quality of the meal was exceptional.


In conclusion? My overall thoughts of the dining experience are positive. Tadich has definitely lived up to it's classy reputation. I highly recommend.
author: Brandon O.

description: Great steaks and great ambiance! Tadich Grill is one of the oldest restaurants in San Francisco and with quality food and quality service, I have no reason to believe Tadich Grill won't be around for many more years to come.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Tadich Grill. Now there is a name I have not heard and been to in ages. I was treated to lunch here many times when I was working in SF by a manager and a colleague.  We had some family members come visit from overseas, and The Mother chose Tadich Grill for the family to congregate for lunch the day before Turkey Day. 

Tadich Grill does not take reservations.  Tadich Grill will seat their guests once the entire party is present, there is no seating of partial parties. Our guests of honor were already at Tadich Grill when The Mother and I arrived. I opted to wait for The Sibling and The Sibling-in-Law outside as the guests and The Mother were getting anxious for them to come as they were getting hungry. We were delighted when The Sibs showed up. And we were seated in one of the booths in the back of Tadich Grill. I was aware of the booths, never ate in one. The times I used to come, we would eat at the bar or at a table. 

So let's see, what did we order. We had various types of clam chowder (Boston or Coney Island) for a starter and one of us had a grand salad of lettuce and avocado with dressing on the side. The Mother and one of the relatives had petrale sole filet for their main dish. The other had a surf and turf special --a lobster tail with a skirt steak. The SIL had a lamb shank. I cannot remember what The Sibling chose.

As for me, I went with the bone-in rib eye steak served with steak frites with carrots, broccoli, and cauliflower. It is go big or go home when it comes to Tadich Grill for me. And I was able to get it cooked rare. It was so good, I attacked and savored every bite of the steak like the combination of the bear and tiger I am. Damn good rib eye steak I have had in a long, long time! I wish you all could have seen The Mother roll her eyes when I announced I was having the bone-in rib eye steak. It was quite funny--priceless!

We were attended to by a grandfatherly looking server whose personality has the wicked sense of humour of one's favorite uncle. The uncle you know who has all the wicked jokes and stories up his sleeve and in his repetoire. He wore the classic white shirt and jacket off-set with a black tie, black trousers, and black shoes accompanying by the classic old school service of being professional and attentive to the clientele. He kept my water glass filled and jokingly blamed my consuming water as the reason why there is a drought. My SIL ordered a bottle of white wine and the server let them perform the duties of a sommeliere and they declared it was good. We all had some to share. 

However, we were all too stuffed to have dessert except The SIL. They ordered a baked apple with caramel sauce on the side and offered samples to us. I politely passed yet I got to sample the caramel sauce.

Tadich Grill has been around the days of the Gold Rush days. They have the kind of classic, elegant service that is rare these days and back in the day, my parents' generation really appreciated. And I get it. I appreciated it even more when The Mother inadvertently left behind her cap and gloves. Fortunately, they turned up and I was able to retrieve them on Black Friday. Hope for a return to Tadich Grill ASAP.
author: Chiara A.

description: I wanted to like this place. Oldest restaurant in San Francisco! Totally old school all the way like stepping back in time. Atmosphere did not disappoint. However, the food did. I had the white clam chowder delivering chewy and fishy pieces of clams with an overdose of celery and leeks. Followed by sauteed Dungeness crab legs for nearly $40. The crab tasted like nothing. Even the Anchor Steam beer on tap came out flat. As far as I'm concerned this place isn't better than any other tourist trap but would still recommend it for historical value and unmatched atmosphere.
author: M R.

description:
Bring a lady here if you want to impress her. ;)

On our 5th date, before going ice skating, the guy I've been seeing asked me where I'd like to go for dinner. I told him to pick, since he knows the Embarcadero area better than me. So, he took me here, an Italian restaurant that's been in business since 1849. I've never heard of Tadich Grill, so this was a pleasant surprise. Clearly, this place has been doing something right to be running for so long. The minute we walked into this old-school restaurant that had an air of understated, rustic elegance, we were seated at a table for two, and were brought iced water and a standard plate of bread and butter. Our waiter was a kind old man in a white coat, kind of grandfatherly.

We ordered the house special Australian Lobster Tail, and Seafood Sauté. I had no idea they were going to serve us the lobster tail with the shell, only to take the shell away right when it was set on the table. Dang it, there goes the pretty picture I was going to take of the lobster with its tail! The lobster was delicious, though hard to cut through, but my date and I enjoyed it very much, and I finished off the vegetables that came with the lobster after my date said he was full. The Seafood Sauté was also very delicious, served with rice and vegetables, though somewhat heavy and creamy. Both my date and I were stuffed after finishing everything.

The bathroom is in the back of the restaurant. You have to go up the stairs, and there are a few stalls. There was no paper towels the first time I went up there, so I had to pat my hands dry on my sweater dress instead. When I went to wash my hands before leaving the restaurant, the paper towels were restocked.
author: Jo W.

description: As you sit down in the bustling and dimly lit restaurant of the Tadich Grill, you can't help but have the old school feel of San Francisco rush over you. A hearty portion of fresh Sourdough bread was delivered as soon as  we got comfortable followed by our drink order. My husband and I both got martinis (him a dirty and mine a cosmo) and they were quickly delivered, delicious and strong! We both ordered the Cioppino and man oh man were we not disappointed. The amounts of fresh mussels, white fish, crabs, scallops, prawns, halibut and swordfish was outstanding and oh so tender. As we sipped and slurped, our wonderful and iconic Tadich Grill bibs caught our mess. The garlic bread was a wonderful ending to 'sponge' up the remaining tomato broth. It's absolutley legendary.
author: Sarah H.

description: I was a bit torn toiling over a four or five star review. I settled with a four. I've been to Tadich a handle of times now and the service has been amazing. We have always always been provided with amazing servers who are very attentive and friendly. We enjoy ordering a bottle of champagne and having it nicely chilled during dinner, feels so fancy. Tadich was the very first place where I was first introduced and immediately fell in love with the seafood cioppino. If you have never tried it, it's something to try at least once in your life and you have to try it here. The cioppino is what they are known for. I ended up settling with a four star review because all the other entrees we have ordered have never included wow me reactions where your eyes light up because you ate something bomb. The reaction is usually oh thank god we also ordered something else or let me have another glass of champagne before I take another bite. We've ordered several different seafood entrees with their various assortment of fishes and they were all kinda bland, fresh, but bland. Tis all.
author: Ann A.

description: Cioppino so good it made me feel like a sailor. Big, too, we had leftovers. No reservations but wait not too bad, like 20 mins.
author: Brent B.
