description: Old-fashion but in a good way. The food is high quality of materials and decent cooking skill, no mistake. The service is impeccable. I was on the counter and was impressed by the engagements with customers other than me. Tom was good, attentive, professional and seemed keeping good relationship with a few frequent customers.
author: Chris P.

description: Pretty small restaurant with bar stools and mostly tables for two. But the drinks are frankly some of the best in the city.
author: Amani O.

description: Incredible. Everything every good review says and more. Red chowder and crab cakes lunch was perfect. Server was professional and delightful. In a world of high tech, corporate chains, fast food, it feels good to put away the phone and settle in for something that truly feels like the good old days.
author: Paul S.

description:
This place is amazing!  The food is always soooo good.  I have not had a bad dish yet. I had the Deep fried scallops, which was not over cooked.  Was very tender and moist.  Love the french bread that they always serve with the meals also. Just have to get there at off times or there is a long waiting list. It's an old time restaurant, claim to be the oldest in San Francisco. 
Good service too.
author: Linda F.

description:
If you know people coming to San Francisco and are asking for recommendations on where to eat....... this is definitely the place! 

First of all, they have the best seafood cioppino in the city!!! 5 stars just for this dish. It's a huge portion filled with scallops, clams, prawns, bay shrimp, crabmeat, and white fish. The garlic bread that accompanies this dish is great for dipping in the red cioppino sauce. 

I've also tried the breaded veal cutlet, pasta, and vegetable. This was more than enough food for one person. The breaded veal cutlet was soft and easy to eat. I have also tried a bowl of the Boston clam chowder. I wish it came with oyster crackers on the side but it was very good. 

The noise level is loud on a weekend night. Sometimes I felt like I was shouting to the person sitting right next to me. I'm not sure how it is on weekday nights. 

This restaurant is definitely good for groups. There is a big bar area where you can grab some drinks while you're waiting.
author: Mariah V.

description:
Hey I haven't been here in years and this place has been here for eons, since 1849!  It is an old school institution so you have to give this place a try. They used to be in another location but moved here in 1967.  There are no frills or reservations and the waiters wear white and take no guff as they have been here for years.  We went here on a double date and the boys dropped us off but they didn't realize that we cannot be seated until all of us are there.  No reservations and no seating until the entire party is present.  When we finally got seated, it was getting busy which was around 5:15 pm.  Get there early before the crowd comes which is around 6 pm.  

When the waiter came by, he pulls no punches as I was asking him about the sand dabs, which they are known for, and he said "Wait lady, I'm going to tell you all about it".  So we had the tasty french bread with butter and  I started off with a ginger beer, then split a crab and shrimp salad.  We ordered the oysters and shrimp creole, crab and salmon newberg, charbroiled mesquite rex sole and the pan fried sand dabs (which can be de-boned before it reaches the table).  All the entrees were excellent and I especially liked the sand dabs as they deboned it perfectly and I found no bones in my fish.
author: Karen W.

description: Excellent classic San Francisco restaurant- noisy, fresh seafood fare with little old waiters and bartenders who are obviously committed to this historical sf staple. Everything is fresh and delicious!!  best clam chowder I've had!
author: Carrie C.

description: Good soup (clam chowder), but with sand :(
author: Vladislav B.

description: Heard and read about Tadich all over Yelp and knew we had to take a chomp while we were in SF. Yes, the wait was long, but we spent the time having some drinks around the corner. I must say that the wait was worth it. We ordered the filet, Spaghetti, sea bass, and cioppino. The standouts were hands down the sea bass first and the cioppino second. That damn sea bass just melted in my mouth. Pretty awesome. In addition to the food, the service was excellent. Completely game for banter while being a total gentleman. Love this place! While you're there, get the carrot cake too!
author: Ann G.

description: Historical landmark restaurant. Great service. Good traditional food. Good portions - especially the salads. Must come here at least once for lunch if you live in SF.
author: Gloria T.

description:
I have been dining at Tadich Grill since the mid-eighties. After a move east my dining experience has been sadly limited to one or two annual visits. I like the predictability and the very professional service staff Tadich Grill specializes in. Some newer trendier restaurants could learn a lesson or two. 

The menu reflects seasonal offerings such as halibut or petrale sole. I had mushroom raviolis in a horseradish cream sauce, which was delightful.
author: Soul S.

description:
If you are ever craving a delicious bowl of seafood cioppino look no further than Tadich Grill!! 

The bartenders at the bar are not only the funniest, but the best , when it comes to building loyal customers.

I have had this dish at so many other places but tonight this by far exceeded my expectations. 
There is plenty of seafood to be had and the flavor of the broth delicious!

If you aren't with a big group best seats in the house is definitely at the bar. 

Tadich grill you had me at cioppino 
See you soon
author: Cat R.

description: Food and service was great. I had the Boston style clam chowder and sauté scallops. Both delicious. Super disappointed that they didn't take AMEX. I was traveling for work and had to pay on my personal account rather than my work AMEX.
author: Camille W.

description:
A quintessential old school dining experience. Super friendly and exceptional service. Delightful interior and wonderful seafood San Francisco style without pretension. We saw everyone from well dressed diners to tourists get a taste of SF to office workers getting some dinner before heading home. 

We came early on a Friday evening bracing ourselves for a line. But as it turned out we were ahead of the wave and were seated right away. We had side cars and oyster on half shell appetizer, while we decided what to order for dinner. The waiter brought a quarter round of a great looking bread. I had to resist having any to save room for the main event. 

We ordered the cioppino and the grilled crab cakes. The cioppino was amazing. The broth tasted of all the fish, shellfish, and tomatoes. All the fish and shellfish were cooked perfectly. It is as if they were still underdone when the dish left the kitchen and cruised to a perfect finish when it arrived. It is a filling dish, so go easy on the bread or you won't be able to finish the yummy cioppino! The grilled crab cakes are also quite delicious. Grilling is a nice change from deep frying. The crab cakes are like two fists on the plate. The side of vegetables were so so and needed to be a little warmer. The bread is really really good. Thick chewy crust and deep wonderful flavor. 

Just want to say again we had exceptional congenial service from David113.
author: Teresa F.

description: Did not have a good experience the evening were dined there.  My wife's dinner wad very spicy,  there was no mention of it being spicy.  The wait staff said that it eased not supposed to be spicy.  We think that it haff the wrong sauce on it.  My fish was very bland and not seasoned at all.  Maybe we just caught them on a bad day,  but with our experienced and the high cost I cannot recommend them.
author: Ben F.

description:
Quintessential San Francisco. Over 20 plus years I have successfully tried every dish at this amazing neighborhood eatery. The staff is professional, efficient, non-intrusive and even friendly - provided you have thick skin (local inside joke).
The feel and vibe here is just something you have to experience. Try the counter for something different. I wish I could give 6 stars for this darling of San Francisco dining.
author: Michael G.

description:
I really like Tadich Grill, which is an institution. Enjoy it for lunch or dinner. 

On this visit, we enjoyed the Halibut Florentine (Cheese Sauce and Spinach) and the Pacific Red Snapper, pan fried with a nice Sangiovese by Halo of Napa Valley. The cheese sauce was tasty, tangy, and rich in flavor. The spinach added dimension and contrast. Both fish fillets were thick, tasty, and substantial. Imagine the normal filet, then multiply the thickness times 2. Nothing was overly seasoned. Service was informative and timely.

We recently had the opportunity to dine at the new location in Washington D.C. It was very good and reminiscent of the original grill here in San Francisco. However, there they accept American Express, which they do not in San Francisco; likewise, for reservations-Yes in D.C., no is S.F. I don't understand the difference and, at least in the case of American Express, wish it were different.
author: Reyn J.

description:
I lived and worked in San Francisco for seven years and never stopped in to Tadich. My mistake. My husband finally took me a year ago and we had a classic, heavy lunch - fried calamari and fish and chips and cocktails. We came back again today for lunch and each ordered something we've never had at Tadich - he the ciappino and me the Dungeness crab salad with 1/2 avacado. Hands down the best ciopinno and best crab salad ever! 

We watched the waiters slice freshly breaked thick loaves of sourdough bread. We appreciated the Christmas decorations. We had a cocktail (or two) and fully realized that Tadich Grill is our very own San Francisco original European Bistro. The oldest restaurant west of the Mississippi is so much more than just the amazingly fresh and delicious food. It's he atmosphere and the people watching and the professional waiters (and one waitress) who could seamlessly refill our water glasses and replace small slices of fresh butter and carve through that delicious sourdough roll in their sleep. 
I noticed a gorgeous slice of cheesecake being prepared for a table and pointed it out to my hubs. When it came time to order dessert, we ordered a slice with raspberry sauce and two Irish coffees. It was the best cheesecake we have ever had. I cannot believe we missed this before. 
The experience was phenomenal and while there usually is a wait for bar seats, they're worth it. 
I count dining at Tadich Grill as one of the worlds great restaurant experiences (spoiler alert, Forbes does, too). The food is fresh and fabulous and the experience is worth savoring. Put down your phones and spend the time looking around, you may just find your next favorite Tadich dish. My neighbor ordered prime rib and french fries and I was having a serious case of order envy. I don't think you can go wrong with anything you decide on here.
author: Vanessa F.

description: After working nearby for a bit, I decided I needed to stop by sometime. A Wednesday afternoon at 2:30 was perfect for no line. While the whole experience was kind of interesting and something I'm really glad I did (once), the food was just serviceable - it was stunningly bland and plain. I will give it that the bread pudding was pretty good! The old-timey service was kind of fun to experience, along with the old-fashioned silly frills of the oyster plate and our drinks, but I can't see coming back.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Good and fast service. Busy crowd made up primarily of office workers. It has a feel of an old school restaurant which I am a fan of. It is not pretentious. Good food. Knowledgeable staff regarding menu, and friendly-ish. 

The price is definitely up, not a casual launch, but more like dinner price. 

SF landmark, I would comeback and also recommend.
author: Manny P.

description:
Tadich really has some of the fewest vegetarian options of any restaurant that I've been to in quite a while. I had some oversized French fries, a steamed artichoke, and some bread.

Drinks are cheap--$8 for cocktails or so--but are made with not-quite top-shelf ingredients, like no-name bourbon and Cinzano vermouth for my Manhattan. The bartenders are enthusiastic, though.

Tablemates enjoyed their seafood-heavy dinner, though, and the cioppino admittedly looked tasty!
author: Kevin P.

description:
Many of us grew up going to Tadich for special occasions. Their Petrael Sole has been famous for decades.
Guessing- their waiters turn tables and serve more lunches than many high end restaurants in the City. Sometimes you feel rushed. 
Table Civility  Rule #1 - Do not remove my date's empty plate while am still eating.
I sit at the counter if I am in a hurry and flying solo. Yes, I adore there French Bread.
Parking? Park at Sutter Stockton and walk down.
author: Miami S.

description: My fourth visit... great seafood.  Excellent service. Fair prices. I love dining here.
author: Tim B.

description: What can I say that hasn't been said already? Always a treat. Ya gotta have the cioppino!  Valet parking is a must. I love this place.
author: Howard B.

description:
There's good food, and there's kick ass food.  
I think this place falls into the latter category.

The one thing that gets me here every time is the Cippino.
It's pretty awesome - everything from the broth to the fresh seafood to the awesome garlic bread.  It's a perfect combination and shouldn't be missed.

I love the old school feel of this place.  There aren't many restaurants that offer the same classic tradition.  The service is friendly, but in a gruff, "hey how you doin" loud kind of way.  The counters scream old school.  It's all part of the cool experience of dining here.  In addition to the cippino, the clam chowder is also a solid choice.  There's no shortage of items on the menu worth trying, but you can't go wrong ordering those two items if you only have one opportunity to dine here.

If only they had a place like this in NYC ... I'd literally be here all the time.  However, it looks like DC folks will get a TG of their own ... lucky peeps!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Our dinning experience was very enjoyable celebrating my mother in-laws 86th birthday. We walked in and were immediately seated despite the packed-midweek dinner crowd. Quality of the food and service is a testament to the restaurants commitment to SFO's dinners and why they are still around. Waiters and staff were all pro's and really on the ball despite the crowd.
I will definitely return to Tadichs whenever I visit SFO. Cant beat consistency, it endures.
author: Benjamin D.

description: We are done with this place. Way overrated in so many ways. Yes old and cool inside, but it ends there. Very rude service. A real bad attitude.They are doing you a favor for you to pay $28 for a 8oz minute steak with 3 french frys and a few vegetables.  The place is living off their old reputation. Food is just ok. Caesar salad is one step above a chain restaurant. Much other better places to go that this place. Yelpers who still give this place high marks are either under 50yrs old and don't know better or are just lame. 4 & 5 stars, give me a break. Really dumb people out there.
author: Jacko F.

description: Tadish is amazing. Ordered the Cioppino, was absolutely delicious. Service was great. Establishment was wonderful. Will definitely return.
author: Kurt P.

description: So worth the 90 minute wait!  Do you like Cioppino? This dish was invented here at Tadich.  Once you finish the abundance of seafood, you want to chug the broth or at least sip the rest politely!  Old school bar making the classics artfully and efficiently.   The food is incredible and no wonder they have thrived for over 160 years in San Francisco!
author: Tony P.

description: Great place but dont expect any service while you wait.  Was told i had to move 10 ft down the bar to order a drink while further down rhe bar waiting.   Then had to beg for bread for my hungry son while waiting.  Too bad, such a nice place but inconsiderate atmosphere puts a big damper on it.
author: Eliot W.

description: We had a fantastic meal at Tadich Grill.  I really wanted to order a dish I had many years ago, oyster Rockefeller.  It met every expectation of mine.  It was a good price for what you received.   My BF had the whole branzini and really liked the smoke and charred flavor.  I had the most delicious cioppino with a pluthera of seafood.   Wonderful!
author: HOLLY P.

description: Bloody Mary Review - As the oldest bar west of the Mississippi and the third oldest bar in the country, Tadich Grill has its food, drink, service and especially its bloody mary down to perfection. Indulge in big tomato flavor all day, every day. But for that added kick, just ask for it spicy. A dash of hot sauce and a swirl of horseradish make this cocktail complete. Why go? A classic bloody mary done right. | Price: $7.75
author: Shelley B.

description: The place has its old time charm from the setting, the people who work there to the food. Love those booths which are spacious and offer a lot of privacy. For two people, sorry, you will more feel like sitting at a dark and narrow hallway right at someone's door. So it is not a right place for romantic couples. Speaking of food, we has crab and prawn casserole and surf turf. Both are superb! Cut off one point for crab leg cocktail. The crab legs are not fresh and cocktail sauce is old. Love the bread budding dessert.
author: Stan L.

description:
A mixed review. Been wanting to go here for a long time. As other Yelpers have indicated, staff seems to be in auto-pilot. Took my 80 yr old mom for lunch today around 2:15. Place was clearing out. We got sat at a two table and it was still a bit noisy. 

We waited about 10 mins to be acknowledged and offered water or drinks. 

My mom had previously gotten up and stepped into one of the many booth-like areas and felt the noise level was much less. I told the waiter my mother was having a hard time hearing and asked if we could move into the more private 4 table. He flatly says they are reserved for 3 or more followed by an insincere "sorry". 

I get it. Keep the 4 tops for groups of 3 or more. I also expect context to govern over rules in well-run businesses. It's a tweener time, plenty of room, and we're looking for an accommodation for hearing/age. We walked past 5 empty 4-tops on our way out...

We had the fish and chips. $23. Very good. Good tartar too. 

Food was a 5. Service was a 1-2. Avg 3. Try it for the food but don't expect a waiter that gives a sh**.
author: Scott J.

description:
*** In Short ***

Long-standing SF restaurant serving up a variety of classic seafood dishes.

*** In Depth ***

I LOVE places that specialize in seafood dishes - unfortunately, I've found that SF tends to be a bit lacking in these types of establishments, and the ones I've been to so far have been none too impressive. Tadich Grill is no exception to this, but does a solid job of fulfilling any seafood cravings you may have, with speed (entrees come out impressively quickly), convenience (being centrally located and all), and variety (25 seafood-centric entrees, by my last count).

So, if you're looking for something more classic, be it pan-fried, sauteed, fried, or cheesy casserole'd with a generous buttering, give Tadich a shot. If you're looking for something a bit more highbrow (like a pan-fried black cod provencale), well, you tell me when you find a place so I can try it too!

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The venue is pretty spacious, though accessibility may be difficult for some, given that the place is always packed and the spacing in between their tables is a bit on the narrow side. The center of the restaurant is taken up by the bar, with your typical bar counter seating.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description: I was introduced to Tadich Grill by an awesome co-worker years ago. He was a friend of Herb Cain and on Fridays he would gather his Ladies (I am serious!) Sam would take 5 of us over to Tadich Grill for cocktails and sometimes dinner on a Friday after the Stock Exchange closed on Fridays.  Forward I celebrated a birthday 6.5 & Tadich Grill was on my Bucket List. STILL the best most classiest place to me. The Bartender Bar 102 P at 4:22 PM was like the Alfred of Batman. He was classy, sort of rough looking like the 40's B&W movies (think Thin Man). It is obvious that the staff is Top Notch. And the food is beyond heaven! I didn't eat there for my birthday but it is always on the Bucket List.
author: Karolyn H.

description: I took my best friend for his birthday and that a was a good decision. This place has really unique dishes, good service, and  good drinks...
author: Jonatan A.

description: Tadich Grill puts the steak in swordfish steak.  Fresh and hearty seafood in an atmosphere of professional service.  Great for singletons and groups alike.
author: WatrBearer L.

description:
A staple of the SF culture. Though it is a small space, they seem to make it work. For such a high price, it would be nice to be able to make reservations. That would be my only beef with TG. The calamari was really tasty and the meat ravioli didn't disappoint. 

The bar tab will curb your drinking. $32 for 4 beers is a bit steep, especially for local beers like Anchor. Just show up early to get on the list. Off hours are probably best if you don't have a lot of time to wait.
author: David H.

description:
After living in SF for two years, I finally made it to Tadich Grill. I had heard so much about this SF institution. We arrived at 5:15 for an extra early Friday dinner.

She wanted to eat healthy and only got a dinner salad. I wanted to indulge in one of the casseroles but I found the menu to be incredibly overwhelming. There are so many items on it and so much text that I had a hard time concentrating. Even the Yelp photos didn't help since there were too many pictures to narrow down.

The waiter was extremely patient with my endless questions about the various sauces. I was concerned about the mushroom pieces in the sauce and he even brought out two of the sauces for me to taste before I committed to dinner.

I ended up picking one of the most expensive items on the menu, the Crab and Lobster Thermidor. Basically it consisted of a ton of crab meat and lobster meat with a rich sauce and baked in the oven. Sounds great, right? Well, aside from the insane quantity of crab and lobster, the dish itself wasn't that great. Even with the sauce, the flavor was just lacking. I think I've satisfied my curiosity for Tadich Grill now. Although it may be the oldest restaurant, it's certainly not the best.
author: Yi Z.

description:
I read somewhere that Tadich Grill is believed to be the 3rd oldest restaurant in the USA. The Mr. and I love food in general, and we particularly enjoy eating in historic restaurants with excellent service. Check, check, double check. Tadich Grill ticked all of those boxes. 

The Mr. had crab cakes and I had the seafood cioppino. I had a taste of his crab cakes and they were very good, but the *star* of that meal was my seafood cioppino. 

The cioppino was chock full of seafood, in a broth so delicious I could have eaten it alone. The homemade garlic bread that came with my meal, was just perfect for sopping up that amazing broth. It's a good thing they put a bib on me! :) 
As tasty as it was, I couldn't finish it. I have to admit the Mr. was very glad I left him some, and he gladly polished it off for me. 

While in San Francisco, the Mr. and I had many great meals, but none better then our dinner at Tadich Grill! #Grin
author: Kym T.

description: I had the famous Cioppino it was Awesome. Worth every penny. Also our kinda dead pan waiter cracked a bit of a smile and a hint of a chuckle it was a great moment.
author: Jimmy J.

description: Best ever as always.... amazing. Sit at the bar and you'll be transported back to a better time and place. Hint, crab cake....BonAppétit!
author: Eric S.

description: Great historical place in SF.  Old school.  Fish was grilled nicely.  Wine by the glass and old school bar. Waiter was good.  It can be a bit touristy but locals hang here too   I didn't get the Ciopino.  Had clam chowder which was decent.
author: Jeff C.

description: Wow! The Cioppino alone is worth the trip to SF. Huge portion and the broth is just amazing. SF has so many amazing restaurants but all I can think of is that cioppino. The bread was pretty tasty as well. The one bad thing is how over crowded it is. They definitely should take out some of the tables in the walk way or expand. A must try when you are in the Bay.
author: Mari T.

description:
Oh Tadich Grill, Oh Tadich Grill,
Thy seafood so delicious.
Oh Cioppino, Oh Cioppino,
Thy shrimps were so humongous. 

Not only was the stew amazing,
But also was the garlic bread for dipping.
Oh Cioppino, Oh Cioppino,
Thy dish was so glorious!

Each single bite,
Each single smile,
No one alive had fed me so well.

Oh Tadich Grill, Oh Tadich Grill,
Such pleasure do you bring me!
author: Hoyan L.

description:
I ordered the salmon fillet and it was excellent in quality and portion size. My dad ordered the red snapper fillet and when I tried a little, there was a piece of bone which kinda ruined it for me. 

Also, the bread wasn't warm at all and the butter was cold and hard, so that's a little annoying. Veggies were ok and the potatoes felt like they were a little old. 

In terms of portion, it's great. Don't expect having a soup or salad with your meal without having to pay a big price. Staff was friendly and attentive, and it's got that old school atmosphere which is nice. 

I was expecting this to be a 5 star restaurant considering this is a pricey restaurant, and only worth visiting once in my opinion.
author: K. A.

description:
Tadich is very old San Francisco - a great spot to enjoy on a foggy day if you feel like treating yourself an expensive lunch. Comfortable seating, masculine decor, and a classic, extensive menu. However...

Five stars for the cioppino because it's all I've been able to order so far. I'll let you know when I've tired of it enough to try something new.
author: Natasha P.

description:
Have been going to Tadich's for years, and have always had a terrific meal and top notch service.  I suspect the reason that Tadich's has achieved its status as one of the oldest restaurants in the country, and the oldest in San Franciso,  is because many have experienced the same throughout the years.   Although Tadich's leans towards sea food, they have an extensive menu and offer several meat options including some old classics that harken to the early days.  With that said, I recommend going with the fresh, local sea food dishes. Start with Dungeness crab cakes which are heavy on the crab and light on the filler. Succulent, juicy and amazing.  For an entree, recommend the outstanding and consistently excellent cioppino which is loaded with Dungeness crab, fish, mussels and clams. The tomato based both complimented by garlic bread is perfect! Service is top notch offered by waiters who have been there forever and are the best in the business. 
Tip: Tadich's does not take reservations, but no worries; the line moves briskly. Enjoy a nice cocktail served by some of the best barkeeps in the city at the expansive wood bar.  Can also eat dinner off the full menu at the bar if desired.  Does not take AMEX.  For a more intimate dining experience with your party, try being seated at a private booth.
author: Roy A.

description:
Saw a glowing TV review about this place on  PBS "Check Please Bay Area" and my 87-year-old seafood loving mother from England was visiting so we thought after a day of slow sightseeing it'd be a nice treat, oldest restaurant in CA bla bla bla...
 
 What a huge disappointment!! 
The place was jammed. My mother has mobility issues and uses a collapsable walker. One of our party was stuck in traffic and even though we told them we were going to be quick diners they wouldn't let us put our name on the list until everyone arrived. They made no concessions at all. We were chill. Determined to enjoy the experience and not let all the silly rules and "macho" bartenders get in the way.  
In fairness they grabbed a small chair for her and she sat like a child below the bar getting jostled and bumped and yelled at. Didn't complain at all. Finally our daughter  arrived and now we have to wait another hour for a table.
Eventually we're shown to the table, ( no "thanks for waiting", "sorry for the delay")  I swear before my ass had even hit the seat the waiter came over and asked us what we wanted to drink...! we told him to give us a minute. Less than a minute later he comes back. What do we want to order?. Again no discussion about the menu but we go with the flow, anticipating a fantastic meal ahead so we order some Calamari and shrimp cocktail as apps for the table. he says .. " you need to order everything now because we're busy" 
WTF. I worked in the restaurant business for 25 years. Calling bullshit. Both me and my wife said, "no we'll order when we're ready and we've just waited the best part of 2 hours for this table so please go away and stop hounding us". (she was nicer than I was!)

 But we soldiered on.  To sum up the food: if you like massively overpriced, bland 1970's style seafood, padded out with rice and vegies then this is the place for you. I don't mind spending money on special occasions but I left pissed off that I fell for the hype and nonsense.
By now my mother had lost her appetite so she just had a bowl of soup. The server forgot to order my sons clam chowder so he grubbed on bread and then when it came he couldn't eat it. So it was really $300 for 3 people including drinks. Not surprisingly, there was no one waiting for our table. We will happily never set foot in there again.
Save your cash . Don't believe the hype. There are so many superior places in SF and Oakland to eat.

 Update: The owner contacted me by phone and on here. Basically gently suggesting that I would alter the review. Kinda disingenuous. Nothing alters the fact that our experience was appalling. The food was terrible. My Old Mum, not wishing to complain at the time recently told me that her soup was just stock and absolutely disgusting.So, I'm sticking to my guys. Avoid.
author: Stephen D.

description: Absolutely awesome! Had the Calamari steak and it was cooked perfectly. Also try the oysters Rockefeller.
author: Craig C.

description: Had the Coney Island chowder and the grilled bass. Both were excellent. The service was also excellent.
author: Miguel L.

description: A classic SF 'go to' for me! Great service, great company, excellent food - always a fun evening!! Waitstaff is uber-professional and always nice to chat with the regulars! I'll be back!
author: Steve S.

description:
Very nice restaurant, it's been open since the 1840's so it's got to be doing something right.  I would come again, it's not on the "Value" side but the quality is high.

Our waiter was kind of a dick. ( Kept hearing him saying it was his first day, it if was my restaurant I would warn him to warm up and quit with the snarky attitude or he doesn't, he doesn't need to come back to work) 

Red clam chowder was very good.  Lobster Thermidor was a first for me and I liked it.  At $36 I was not complaining due to the generous amount of Lobster and Crab within.
author: Sean M.

description:
We came on a Saturday night around 7pm and was lucky enough to find street parking for free! When we walked in it was super crowded and people were just lining up against the wall to wait for a table. There is open bar seating and it's based on the honor system on who came first. We tried putting our name down and even that was difficult because it was just a crowd of people at the front. No waiters were around to take down names. Thankfully I stood by the wall and there were two seats open at the bar and I was able to get them since no one wanted it near me! 

We sat down at the bar and our waiter gave us a very detailed old school menu. I ordered the cioppino of course and my partner ordered the crab cakes. The cioppino came piping HOT. Filled with crab, fish, scallops, shrimp, baby shrimp, clams and mussels. Even though it was around $35 for both of the dishes the cioppino was def the better of the two deals. In terms of taste, it was okaaaay. I mean the broth was tasty and it was packed with seafood! But it's one of those where you have for once and I don't think I'll ever crave for it again. Crab cakes were okay as well, nothing to rave about. The sauce on top made the dish really heavy and it came with rice and steamed vegetables. 

Overall, dishes were decent and I can see why you should come here for the old school vibe. I would recommend coming here at least once to experience a restaurant that's been open since 1849 but the food was decent. Not AMAZING. 

Tip: look out for open bar seats!
author: Sarah I.

description: Bring patience and comfortable shoes you may be standing a while depending on the time of day. The atmosphere and service were outstanding. We ate at the first come first serve bar instead of waiting for a table and our waiter/bartender kept us smiling the entire meal. The food was delicious and very hot when it was served.
author: Randy H.

description: Such a large mentto choose from. Appreciatef the help from our server. Settled on cioppino which is the BEST so far is SF. Branzino on mesquite was super good. Portions are generous. Sidecar cocktail very good, as was Aviator. Tadich rice custard for dessert was very very good, as is house coffee. Very nice Monday nights must eat restaurant for old style SF experience.
author: Epernay W.

description: Favorite restaurant in San Francisco! We make a point to eat here every trip. Old style and oldest restaurant in California. No reservations taken so you just check in and Wall hang until your called. Seating at the bar is a must to try. Food is excellent. Service top notch. Must try and you will return often as we do.
author: Cyndi G.

description: Very classy, old fashioned American Restaurant.  Very delicious food. Superb service. Highly recommended if you enjoy sea food and grill.
author: Sergey T.

description:
My wife and I went to Tadich Grill for lunch yesterday, on the last day of our San Francisco vacation. When you are from out of town and ask what is a a true "traditional, authentic San Francisco restaurant." , it is Tadich Grill. It's been around for 166 years. It's not only San Francisco's, but also California's, oldest restaurant. Dark wood paneling with large mirrors cover the walls and very high ceiling. I have been dinning here for over 40 years.
We started with a bottle of Concannon - Pinot Grigio, California, 2015. It had a citrus, crispy and fresh flavor, great with seafood.
I ordered the Boston clam chowder. It was thick and creamy, perfectly textured potatoes, plump sweet clams with a hint of spice. I generally order tabasco sauce with my clam chowder and this is the only restaurant that I have ever been to that automatically brings it.  It was probably some of the best clam chowder I've ever tasted!!!
My wife ordered the Mixed Greens Salad with blue cheese dressing. The Bleu Cheese dressing had a rich, creamy flavor and was truly delicious.
I had the Pan Fried Petrale Sole filet and it was cooked to perfection. It is served with Long Branch Potatoes, Vegetable of the Day, and Tartar Sauce. The tarter sauce has horseradish in it, totally unique, and was delicious. Highly recommend their Petrale Sole! It's the local sole.
My wife ordered the Seafood Sauté - Scallops, Prawns, and Dungeness Crab Legs sautéed with mushrooms in a light Cream Sauce and served with rice and vegetables.(carrots, asparagus and brussels sprouts). The rich white wine cream sauce was absolutely phenomenal. The seafood was so fresh and tender.
This places ambiance is absolutely amazing and the service by our waiter Marion was exceptional
author: John C.

description:
It's an institution, so you have to come in here expecting tourists.  If you're lucky enough to come at lunch, you'll get a lot of regulars who know to sit, order, and get out.  

My kind of place though.  Long counter.  Jacketed waiters.  Good food.  Don't forget to  expect a wait as they don't take reservations.

Known for their fresh fish especially the sand dabs and cioppino.  My first experience here was a long long time ago, and I know this place will still be around a long long time from now.
author: Ron L.

description: Went in there wanting a good steak. Ordered the New Yorker and received a thick fat steak cooked nicely. I only waited about 10 minutes for the food even though it was fully packed. The lighting was good and there was a nice buzz. This is a good place to come to by yourself as it has a massive bar seating area where you can dine.
author: Yama H.

description: A friend recommended we come here for lunch. One of the oldest places in SF apparently. Awaited a table but ended up sitting at the bar. Had the seafood mix platter which was quite good. And the seafood cippolini stew. Highly recommend. Comes with delicious garlic bread.
author: J. Karim A.

description:
Get the Sand Dabs and you won't be sorry.

Service could have been better, but the quality out weighed the negative.
author: Dennis L.

description: Whatever you do, don't go here when they "ring the bell" an hour before closing for the day.  The service goes downhill.  We ordered steak and scallops. The steak was good. The seafood was not.  But it was the rushed service once the bell rang that threw us off.  The bartender was excellent while we waited before the meal. And then the bell rang!  Enough with the bell. If we go back it would be for happy hour.
author: Emily P.

description: It is a tourist trap. Overpriced. Food is yuck.... But the service is good. I could have made a better choice being drunk.
author: Charles M.

description: This is a MUST VISIT if in San Francisco. Came here on Saturday with five friends for a birthday celebration and looking forward to go back again soon! We sat in a booth, which was cozy and awesome. Wood panelling is beautiful and added to the old school charm this place has. Our meals were great -- we ordered a seafood platter, fried calamari and crab cakes to start, which were all so fresh and delicious. Many got the cioppino for their main dishes and raved about it; I'm looking forward to trying that as the weather gets cooler. I had white clam chowder soup and a crab and avocado salad. The soup was so yummy and the salad was huge, fresh and tasty! So much fresh crab and pretty much an entire avocado. Will definitely be making it into my rotation for ordering delivery for office lunches. Prices were very fair, especially for the freshness, quality and HUGE portion sizes. Staff was helpful and quick -- you could tell they've all been doing this for years. Now I see why this place is considered a SF classic; it's an institution. Love the authenticity, history and overall experience (so much that I finally created a yelp account to write a review!)
author: Emily W.

description: This place is a must try whether you are just looking for a drink at the bar or a full meal! I came here around 5 pm on a Thursday for drinks and appetizers only and had a great experience sitting at the bar. Their calamari and martinis were both delicious. The ambiance of this restaurant alone makes this place a great spot!
author: Becca T.

description: I really wanted to love this place because of the historical significance of the restaurant and the good reviews. I got the clam chowder, such was excellent, and the crab and lobster thermador. The crab and lobster thermadore had a very strange curry or saffron taste to it? Not sure what it was but I expected a thermador to be the tangy, garlicy, bread crumb, creamy goodness that you attribute to thermadors. I couldn't really get past the first few bites. To their credit, there was a ton of crab and lobster, but the sauce was watery and bland. It just wasn't good, especially for near $40.
author: Angie P.

description:
Classic, old, vintage restaurant. Love this place. It was my first time dining here. There was a long line by the time we arrived. We were told there will be a 30 minute wait. We stood along the wall for our names to be called. After a few minutes, 2 spots open at the bar area. No one wanted to order drinks so my husband & I sat at the bar. I ordered a Vesper martini drink. Wow. Strong & good. Just how I like my cocktails. My husband had ginger ale. We asked if we can eat at the bar. No...only appetizers at the bar. Within a couple minutes, we were seated at a regular table. I was impressed how fast service was when there was a long line. My husband mentioned to me, it's probably because we ordered drinks and they treated us to a table. Or it could be, we are next on the list for a table of 2. Great customer service.

My husband have been here before and he always get the cioppino. I was undecided and didn't know what to get. The waiter recommended the sea bass entrée or crab cakes entrée. I chose the crab cakes entrée. Bread & butter was served. Next came our entrees. I sampled the cioppino and it was hearty. Very good. Oooh, that garlic butter toast that came with it was very "buttery melt-in-your-mouth." The crab cakes were divine. There were a lot of real crab chunks. Loved it. The sides were plenty. Luckily, we didn't order any appetizers. We were full and satisfied. Pricey, but worth it. We will be back!
author: Amy H.

description: I been wanting to try their seafood cioppino for the longest time. Finally, I had the chance to and was completely disappointed. They are generous with the seafood but the soup base was not for me. It was salty and not flavor profile I was expecting... I did however, enjoyed their garlic bread but that was not the star of the dish. Service was pretty good for lunch hour.
author: Ann L.

description: The food here is absolutely delicious. The wait staff is amazing and the ambiance is perfect. Best dinner we had while in San Francisco!
author: Alanna L.

description: Never a bad meal at Tadich. I love, love, love this place. We've eaten there so many times, I can't count. True you might have to wait a while to get a seat, but so worth the wait. I prefer the counter anyway, so wait isn't usually too terribly long.
author: r m.

description: Our bald waiter sucked! He was trying to be clever and funny but just came out being an a hole! Chilean sea bass was bomb which he recommended so I give him props for that! Also salmon was good and had some gluten free options for this sis. The family had a great time here, great atmosphere but stuck up waiters. Very expensive but make sure to order the seafood, the steaks come out way too rare!
author: Shan And Marko X.

description:
Definitely worth stopping by this classic San Francisco restaurant for a quick lunch or busy dinner.  As soon as you walk into the place, you will feel like you were transported back in time.  The wooden counter tops, waiters in all white suites with ties, and the small wooden booths.  Much smaller than I imagined and not the most elegant place in the city.
If you stop by for lunch, they will seat you on the counter, along with the rest of the downtown crowd and obvious regulars.  Once again, this is not a fancy, formal restaurant.  Instead, you will find an old fashioned, service oriented staff that acts more professional than friendly.  
Routine:  
1.  get seated and look at the menu
2.  place drink and order.
3.  bring water and slice sour dough bread in front of you.
4.  delivery your soup, offer fresh ground pepper and/or tobbasco.
5.  bring out your entrée 
6.  hand out your bill

They will go down the line, and follow the exact routine.

Menu items
Clam chowder, I prefer the Boston/White chowder.  Absolutely fantastic!  Small chunks of potato and clams, and not too watery or thick.  Amazing taste and flavor!
Crab and shrimp soup over fresh greens.  I ordered the small serving, and it was enough.  Fresh chunks of Dungeness crab over a bed of greens and a tomato wedge.  Loved it!
author: Richard H.

description: We thoroughly enjoyed our dinner on a very busy Saturday night. From the very gracious and attentive bartenders to our server, John, from Prague, our party of six left very happy. Petrale sole was delicious. I would have preferred mashed potatoes to the long branched fries, but overall enjoyed our meal. No wonder it has been around this long.
author: eileen c.

description:
I was with my best friend and we were so tired of walking all day we stop by this place and we sat by counter bar, we ordered the food and we were trying to talk to each other but we lost our appetite eating our food because of this bald guy keep interrupting me and I was about to lose my mind 
Our waiter was such nice guy with dark hair 
In picture 
I was going to ask for the manager to complain 
But we didn't have enough time to wait for him 
To complain from him
author: Moe K.

description:
Update: I unexpectedly came back exactly a week later, also for lunch (got the cioppino; it was great), but was disappointed by the service. One of my biggest pet peeves at restaurants is when they clear people's dishes while other members of the party are still eating - it just makes you feel rushed, and I find it very rude.

Well, last week they did that, but I attributed it to the fact that my friend indicated he was in a rush, so I didn't take offense. But yesterday they did it as well. The waiter was literally hovering outside our booth to take away people's plates while 2/5 people still had ~1/3 of their food left! It wasn't even crowded by that point, and we weren't in a rush. Not nice.

Twice in a row = star deduction. Leaving it at 4 stars because the food is still delicious!
author: Liz F.

description:
Old school but still very cool. 

The menu is traditional, with lots of seafood and hearty meal options. 

I loved the size of the portions and how many fresh vegetables came with each meal! It is pricy, but when you see how much meat or fish you get, it makes sense. 

While waiting, I sat at the bar and the bartenders were so much fun! They were engaging and happy, talking me into a shirley temple which is random but reminds me of my childhood. Also, space is rather tight! I would love to sit in one of the more private booths.
author: Stephanie D.

description: This is IT.  This is THE restaurant in San Francisco.  It is what defines San Francisco for me since moving here over 20 years ago.  First - awesome seafood including dishes that were created in San Francisco.  Second, friendly staff even when it's crazy busy.  Third, no reservations - to me that is the ultimate in "everyone is equal, there is no snooty attitude, just come on by for great food first come first served".
author: Greta R.

description:
Love it here - this is one of the places I think embodies San Francisco.  Great drinks, amazing services and of course, superb food.  Other trendy, overwrought places come and go, yet Tadich remains.

I used to come here pretty regularly for lunch when I was a student - it was halfway between school and work.  Fast forward six years.  I basically just told my compatriots that we were going to Tadich Grill for dinner - if you want to go some other place....God Bless.  We finished our pre-party champs and headed down California.  The warm glow of the sign beckoned to we three, hungry (slightly buzzed) ladies needing sustenance after our first day on a biz trip that started at 5:30 in the morning.  Got there around 8:30, it was pretty busy, that is to be expected.  We got lucky though and were seated immediately at the Bar, which is my jam.  I have actually never sat at a table there, now that I think about it.  Our waiter Charles came 'round quickly and it went a little something like this:

Drinks:
I had a Tito's Martini with a twist-up; Ms Angela had here usual bizarre concoction of Tito's, 7-Up and green olives; Ms Elaine had a Kir Royale.  All came out quickly and all were just as desired.

Food:
I got the Cioppino, A got the Fried Shrimp platter and E got Clams and an artichoke heart.  My Cioppino was f***in' amazing, of course.  Tender sweet scallops, handful of crab, a few mussels, a few clams, several prawns, bay shrimp and whitefish.  All cooked to perfection in the most amazing onion, celery tomato broth.  The garlic bread was heavenly and you know I ate it all.  Mmmm, I wish I had some now--oh well. :-( 
A loved her shrimp platter with the awesome potatoes and perfectly cooked veg.  Sometimes veg can be mushy, but never here.  It is called QC people, don't act like you are too good to check a piece of cauliflower before sending it.  It is the little details that make Tadich a place to keep coming to.
E's clams were swimming in a delicious garlic, butter white wine sauce.  She loved them-of course!

I have a baby shower in Alameda this weekend.  I think I will be heading over via BART afterward to get another fix before heading home.  Thank you Tadich Grill for another great San Francisco memory!
author: Monkey B.

description:
I'm not sure what else I could add to the tons of accurate and positive reviews for this place. Our party of four met before the doors were opened. Thank goodness we did, because people actually started to line up. Given, there were a few parties only, but by the time we left, there were people waiting for tables. 

It was a booze free lunch today. Which didn't even matter because the food was fantastic. The oysters in the half shell were fresh and delicious. I can't get enough of the ocean-y, brine-y goodness. I ordered the red snapper, charcoal broiled. I love red snapper, and the portion was extremely generous. I didn't try any of my friend's ravioli but that dish was dinner-sized too. He really liked it and finished the whole plate. Lastly, two people in our party ordered the cioppino. Since it's what they're known for, I have to admit that they do it very well. Most restaurants either make it too much like a tomato based red sauce, or its just too watered down with zero flavor. The broth was so rich and packed major flavor. Not to mention, they give you two slices of roasted garlic bread and a medley of seafood (mussels, shrimp, scallops, white fish)- all of which is cooked to perfection. I stole a slice off of my friend's plate and annoyingly dipped my slice of garlic bread in my boyfriend's cioppino. Even the white fish was flaky and surprisingly buttery. Ok, I just had dinner but it's making me hungry as I sit here and write this review. 

The service was excellent, pairing nicely with the food. We all really loved the wooden dividers that created what were mini dining rooms for each party. Super cozy and private so that you could really unwind. My favorite thing wasn't just that, or the fresh cut lemon wedges at the table, but the coat hooks!! Our table for four had one in each corner of the mini dining room! I was ecstatic because the space is on the smaller side and I hate setting my purse on the floor. It usually ends up behind me, in my chair. 

It was a lovely lunch to kickoff a day of the best weather in the city.
author: Venna Q. T.

description:
While I thought the food was good, it wasn't great, and for these prices, in San Francisco, you can have great.  We ordered a number of different dishes, and I made sure to try all of them.  We had broiled sea bass, salmon newburg, crab & shrimp newburg and the pan fried sand dabs.  All the items were fairly monochromatic in flavor as were the vegetables and appetizers.  The dessert we ordered, rice custard, was just OK, the rice was a hard layer at the bottom and the custard on top, while very smooth, again lacked any complex flavor.

Beyond this, the front-house people were quite brusque, though our waiter and busboy were very nice and attentive.  The restaurant design is good; we got a booth, which is nice for the high wood walls - it makes conversation easy and I like dark woods.

Ultimately, I probably won't choose to go there, but if somebody else is making the decision and that's where we go, I won't hate it.
author: Jim M.

description: WOW!  All I can say is WOW!  Great experience...wonderful food, great drinks!
author: Robyn R.

description:
Old bay all the way. 

Impeccable service. A San Franciscan relic. Old worldly ambience, decor and atmosphere. 

I prefer the classic seafood dishes like the shrimp Louie salad, fried calamari, jumbo prawns, cioppino and crab. 

If you're an adventurous eater I would suggest the baked en casserole dishes. They're unique and especially satisfying on a cold day. 

If you want to stay on the lighter side, my favorite is the pan fried filet of sole. Super thin and tender. The breading is just right. Never overcooked, always perfection.

It's all in the details. This special place thrives on its details and tradition. The fresh sourdough bread and butter. Smooth drinks. Tartar and cocktail sauces are house made. The servers are exceptionally attentive and present every aspect of your meal with suave and swift movement.
author: Rosalyn W.

description:
We enjoyed having lunch here. Was able to come in and get seated at a table pretty fast (to my surprise). 

My wife had the Chilean sea bass and enjoyed it. I had the Pacific red snapper and loved it too. I wasn't the biggest fan of the potatoes or veggies but the fish made up for it. 

Go try it, it would be worth a good lunch.
author: Jared M.

description: Haven't been in a couple yrs but this place doesn't fail me and co. Sat at the counter had a great server, was very sweet and attentive to my mama and me. The food is Devine! Split a cup of clam chowder which was hot and fresh. Mama had a beautiful lightly battered calamari steak with veggies. I had a lovely , most delicious seafood sauté. Crab leg chunks, scallops, and prawns in a amazing white wine sauce . What flavor!  As side to mix up with the entrees you must order the mushroom sauté! Amazing! All around a great seafood experience, best in SF and a classic staple of the city. Go!
author: Ladyreyes R.

description: Walked in with my husband and toddler and the place was so crowded that I walked around the bar and the guy at the register came up to me and said "can I help you" I said yeah just want to put my name down for 3 and then he yelled at me and said "stand over there against the wall" as I was walking over there, he yelled at us again and said "keep this area clear, MOVE" #nevercominghere
author: Shivani S.

description:
This is a unique place to visit however be aware they do not take reservations and so you could be in for a wait. If you are lucky enough to find a spot at the counter be prepared for a fast food style dinner where the waiter seems only to want to get you served and out in order to get the next people seated. He seemed more interested in maximizing his tip opportunity than in our dining experience. 
That being said the food was good and so I'd say overall worth visiting - once. But we won't be going back.
author: Robyn K.

description: We had such a awesome time. Service MICHAEL AND DAVID were A++ I wouldn't imagine going to San Fransisco without coming to Tadich Grill, mic drop!
author: Laura L.

description:
not bad at all!

Came here Thursday night with a party of 4 ladies, we were seated only after arrival of our whole party.  We had a waiter who was absolutely humorous because he did not smile, but said the funniest things.

the complimentary bread is a waste of stomach space, just save it for when you want to clean off the last of the delicious soups!

Clam Chowder
- absolutely delicious, creamy and generous on the clams!  the clam meat was minimally sandy and the flavor is definitely one of the best i've had

Panfried Sole
- bland, but good texture.  i would not recommend

Seafood Stirfry
- 2 scallops, 2 shrimp, and some fish: it came with steamed veggies topped with butter and a paella-like rice with a cream sauce.  make sure to eat this dish first because the flavor is nice and lightly savory

Cioppino
 - WOW!  i love a good seafood-tomato stew, and this was definitely the star of the show.  honestly everything i ate after the cioppino was quite bland.  next time i would order 2 cioppinos!

Chocolate Caramel Torte
- SO SO SMOOTH!  it was light/not too sweet, and deliciously chocolaty.  definitely recommend!

good service and pretty good food!  i definitely wouldn't mind coming back here for some more!
author: Tina A.

description:
Food was nothing like what I expected it to be. The portion sizes are huge and hearty which is very unlike SF. Prices are quite high for this kind of food (and hence the 3 stars) and I felt like the place is like a glorified fish market restaurant. 
Their bar is good, we had the Moscow mule while we were waiting for a table (~40 minutes) and loved it.
author: Sharanya A.

description: Very cool "old school" spot.  You HAVE to try the cioppino.  It might be the best thing I've ever eaten
author: Scott M.

description:
First time here on a business lunch meeting.

The place was pretty crowded but that would be expected for lunch time in this location.

We were a large party of 9 and they did a great job considering it was a last minute walking at lunch to get us seated.

Decor is "historical" as this place has been around since the 1800's.  BUT the seating is TIGHT if you aren't in a "cubby".  

I ordered the Seafood Cioppino , it was pretty good served with some garlic bread.  Had two large prawn, small shrimp, some white fish, crab, mussels and clams.  It was a pretty good portion but thought it was a tad high in price but not complaining it was worth the menu price.

My only con was we had to wait for bread, actually had to ask, the sodas are a per glass price (no re-fills).  Not that it is an issue for me but the bathrooms are up a flight of stairs which if you have someone elderly or disabled would be a pain.

Overall it was good not great but I would dine here again.
author: Tim V.

description: You can't get more San Francisco than this place. Had Cioppino with a few glasses of Chardonnay and lots of fresh warm sourdough bread with butter and soaked it all up. Delicious!
author: David S.

description:
I had not been to Tadich Grill in over 30 years. Tickets for 4 to see Wicked in SF and I was tasked with finding the restaurant for our pre show meal. I picked a hands down winner. Our meals were great! Service was spot on, and I picked the perfect place that had something for everyone in our party. Cocktails were expertly prepared. Decent wine list, but being from wine country we brought our own. Reasonable 20 dollar corkage for SF, and they provided great wine service for the fee.
Impressive, yet unobtrusive service was a major plus. Historical ambience. 
30 years was way too long to stay away! I will not let that happen again!
author: Mary V.

description: Super fun old school atmosphere. Long wait for seating but prompt service once we were at our table. Had the cioppino, can see why it is the house specialty! Recommend.
author: Eileen C.

description:
Tadich is a fabled San Francisco restaurant.  Fabled for having been in business for such a long time, and for churlish service. 

The quality of food is variable.  I had an excellent cioppino, full of goodies with a very tasty broth.  My partner had a Petrale sole that was overcooked and tasteless.

The service, however, is badly in need of some supervision and revision. It lived down to its reputation, and was uniformly poor. There is no excuse, especially when there is hardly anyone in the place (we went for a late lunch) for sullen, inattentive, argumentative and rude service.  I don't expect a waiter to be omnipresent, but I definitely expect professional service which requires that the server constantly keep an eye on the customers (not be off somewhere else for long stretches of time), and be aware that when they are sitting looking around for the waiter it means they need some attention.  The service was of the worst sort:  snooty, snotty, and very unprofessional indeed.  It made eating there a chore rather than a pleasure.  Tadich Grill needs a forceful reminder that it is the customer ithat pays the bills, not the staff.  Not recommended.
author: Jeff D.

description:
The hype for this place is unreal. I understand that it is an SF institution and one of the oldest restaurants around but I was so underwhelmed when I came here earlier this week.

I did like the interior and the feel of the place. It felt very old school and it struck the right level of class mixed with nightlife. The service here was atrocious but whatever I can understand that.

I came here for the Cioppino, which made the top 100 list both this year and last year. Why it is on the list is beyond me. While I'm not the biggest fan of Cioppino, I have had much better versions of this dish at many other places. Everything about this dish was average from the sauce to the seafood to the garlic bread. The only thing not average about it was the price at a whopping $32. At the very least it needed more salt but it could certainly stand for improvement in other areas as well.

Overall, I'm pretty sure this place is skating by on reputation. Perhaps the oyster and bacon frittata is what I should have ordered but I don't think I'll be coming back to find out. "I've experienced better."
author: Mark O.

description:
You Should Go to Tadich Grill If You:

1) Are in the mood for cioppino.

2) Don't mind eating dinner at 5:30pm or waiting in long lines.

3) Like a 166 year old school vibe. 

4) Are charmed by a white jacketed server who calls you "Young Lady."

5) Love sourdough, butter and garlic toast. #WhoDoesnt

6) Want a cuppa Boston clam chowdah and heavily breaded calamari without tenatacles. #SeriouslyWhyNoTentacles

7) Wear a bib. (Or you don't mind getting mussels, clams, fish, shrimp or tomatoes from your OK-But-Not-As-Good-As-Scoma's-IMO cioppino onto your clothes.) ($32.50)

8) Eat undercooked Chilean Sea Bass in a pile of congealed butter ($33.95).

9) Want to check a historic San Franciscan restaurant off your list.

DONE.

1/2015
author: Amy C.

description:
Finally had a chance to dine at this historic SF restaurant and I was not deterred by the slight wait during lunch hour. The crowd leaned toward older generation but it was not a surprise to me given the price and history of the venue. The menu is quite diverse although it seems heavy on seafood dishes. 

We started our meal with their soups. My clam chowder creamy style was rich and thick with tons of clams. For entree, I tried their famous Cioppino, which is a tomato wine broth based seafood mixture stew. It came with mussels, clams, sea scallops, shrimps and huge chunk of fish fillet. I was really full before the Cioppino even arrived! Nevertheless, I tasted it and the soup was savory and clean. Seafood inside was very fresh and there was no fishy smell. It also came with two heavily buttered toasted sour dough. 

Overall, I had a great experience here and loved their seafood dishes. I also saw people ordered steak and other things. I would definitely return for more!
author: Athena C.

description:
The Rib-Eye was good, I'd say 3 Stars for sure.  The service from the bus boy was top notch ~ his name is Jose.  The server, however, also named Jose....I give him 2 Stars.  Brings bread then doesn't bring the plates.  We told him that the carrot cake was too sweet and he got really defensive.  Like I accused him of making it himself.  I mentioned it to him because its his job to take that feedback to the chef.  He has an arrogance about him that I didn't really care for.

The Pork Chop was tough and not very flavorful.  Very disappointing.  The Crab was over powered by the tomato sauce.  Both those dishes are 1 Star so don't get them.

I was happy with my Rib-Eye and they should have just ordered the Cioppino as we found out later on, it was what they're known for.  

Prepare to wait.  We waited 2.5 hours for a table of 6 however, the bartenders were AWESOME!!!  Loved them.  Drinks were a bit weak but oh well.  

Overall, I will not intentionally go here.  They're mostly hype and not worth the wait.  If I'm invited, I will definitely try their Cioppino to see if my opinion of their food changes, otherwise, I wouldn't go out of my way.  

The old school decor was nice though, I appreciated that.  But the food?  Just so-so.
author: Ivy M.

description: The food was solid, the service was pretty good. My boyfriend and I went early to avoid the wait, and were glad we did! By the time we left the place was stuffed to the brim, as were our stomachs. A lot of food! I had the salmon broiled, and it was good! The veggies were my favorite. We started with the crab cakes which were expensive but also were really good. Would go again!!
author: Samantha S.

description:
Very nice historic restaurant. I was impressed by the ambiance and menu selections. The service was a bit underwhelming, considering the expectations, but food was great.
Take the opportunity to experience this gem!
author: Roger C.

description: Another perfect review for the capital of fish in SF great food great service. Delicious halibut. This place is a must stop in SF
author: JoAnn W.

description:
A coworker comes here all the time during travel. We wanted to give this place a try and came in for lunch. The food was reasonably done and the seafood was fresh. The two stars are for food quality.

However the service we received was not good. The server was a complete minimalist - he didn't say much nor was there much expression nor did he come around much. The hostess was the same. She didn't say a word, not even responding to my "thank you" after she sat us down. It is tough to make the argument  that both of these employees were having a bad day.  The experience certainly didn't live up to the 4-star Yelp reviews, the recommendation, or the check we got.

Typically I would have been a lot more vocal and descriptive. But....I was angry enough to pick up the phone to speak with the manager and he was apologetic and was genuinely try to earn our business back. 

So, in order to differentiate from a business whose management will do nothing about a complaint, I will say that when management cares and follows through, there is still hope.
author: Julie T.

description: Ah Tadich Grill, what a treat.  An Old School San Francisco restaurant.  Great food, great service, great ambiance. From the minute you walk in, you are greeted warmly.  The waiters are friendly, professional and make you feel special. The seafood dishes are classics and well prepared and fairly priced.  On a Monday night, there was a good mix of locals and out-of-towners.   With all the trendy, hip, 'here today, gone tomorrow' restaurants in the city, it's nice to have a classic meal in a top notch restaurant with staying power.
author: Debbie W.

description: Had a fabulous experience at Tadich Grill! From the crab cake appetizer to our meals of ahi salad and sea bass, everything was incredible! A bit too much sauce on both, but easily could have ordered on the side and will know next time. The cheesecake was amazing! But the best part was the service- our waiter Barry had the perfect sense of humor and made the meal even more enjoyable. I highly recommend it and will definitely be back!
author: Christie H.

description: Excellent and friendly service very helpful when it came to ordering. I got the cioppino of course which was amazing if not a bit to abundant. I couldn't finish the entire dish. I will definitely go again whenever the area
author: Trever S.

description:
Amazing Food - more than food, Amazing Service! The staff's attitude speaks of their legacy.  Their's is the kind of service and food one may find at an old classy restaurant in New York or England, where folks don't just do a job, but take pride in serving their customers and making them feel special. It has often been written that the passion of an artist is found deep within the soul, separating those who settle for the mediocre or the good, from those compelled to provide greatness and seek perfection. Such skills could be applied to serving food, an ancient ritual in all cultural traditions. I am not a senior citizen, however, well aware of history and the classy bygone era. Back in the old times, the notion of being "in service" to someone was held in high regard, with initiations and teachings maintained as a special privilege until perfected - that is exactly what this restaurant is like if you want to get an idea about how it feels to dine here.

Tadich Grill's food, demeanor, service and attitude reminds me of this Chinese saying: ""Before enlightenment, chop wood, carry water. After enlightenment, chop wood, carry water" -  It means (loosely translated), take great care and deep satisfaction with awareness and appreciation, in whatever you do; for the simple act of doing it is reward enough, and alone, can bring great transformation and joy. Great service is a subtle art form and Tadich Grill has done a splendid job! It is indeed an honor and a privilege to dine here.
author: Sun B.

description:
I've been coming here for a couple of years, brought clients several times. Tonight, I decided to eat by myself after work. 

Walked in, and I asked for a table. The guy up front motioned me to a seat on the counter. Can I get a table, I asked? No, I can't. Because I am by myself,  I don't deserve a table. Even though there were several empty two-tops. I guess if you are by yourself, you are a lesser human being. 

So, I voted with my feet, turned around and left. Certainly won't be bringing anyone over here again. The food is ok, I suppose, nothing really special, so it's definitely not worth the bad attitude.
author: James D.

description:
We wanted to go to Wine & Wall, but they were closed on Saturday. Seafood sounded good so we checked out Yelp. Tadich Grill was close by, so walked on over.

We arrived around 2:30 on a Saturday and were seated immediately. We got our own little "room", which was very nice. We were off to a good start.

The waiter arrived quickly, but we weren't ready. We were a bit confused by the wine menu and hadn't made a decision. The wine menu lists 99% full bottles along with two half-bottles. We noticed a $20 corkage fee at the bottom and wondered if we purchased a bottle of wine if we would be charged the fee. At the bottom of the wine menu it stated some wines were available by the glass and to ask the server. We found out the fee didn't apply to bottles purchased at the restaurant and learned which wines were available by the glass. We were able to make a decision. Yay!

The sourdough bread was delicious, but the butter was cold and hard, thus hard to spread. What made it more difficult was none of us had a plate for the bread. We placed the bread on the tablecloth, buttered it up and ate it off the table. Weird. The waiter brought additional bread on a plate. He thrust the plate toward the plate of bread already on the table and fwap! it landed on the plate. That lacked class and was not the behavior I expect at a restaurant where the average meal is over $30. 

I ordered the seafood cioppino. I had the most incredible cioppino at Boudin Bakery and have been looking for another good one ever since. This was not it. While wonderful seafood was listed on the menu, it was not listed like ingredients are listed on a package (by weight/quantity). Instead the ingredients were listed by tastiness... you know, things you WANT in your cioppino - clams, prawns, scallops, bay shrimp, crab meat, mussels and white fish. This serving had two clams, two mussels, one scallop, two prawns, super mini shrimp (bay shrimp?) and a LOT of white fish. Don't get me wrong, it was tasty, but it was not worth the price. 

My dining partners both got the grilled patrale. I took a bite. It tasted burnt. Neither of them cleaned their plates. 

Our meals were certainly not the quality one expects for the price.
author: Scott N.

description: I have Ben coming to Tadich Grill since 1967. Their food, service and cocktails have yet to disappoint. Treat yourself to a piece of history.
author: Bonnie L.

description: Ciopino to die for. It had 4 oysters, 3 good sized shrimp, good portion of white fish, 2 scallops, many small shrimp, crab meat, mussels all in a delicious tomato base. Every mouthful had seafood. The serving is huge so a couple could do an appetizer and share this wonderful meal.
author: Christopher D.

description:
Let me get started with.. The 1 star is for the service of this place or so called ESTABLISHMENT.

A few weeks backs a friend of mine visiting from NY and called me out of the blue to meet up for lunch at @ 1:15 pm. I was already done with my lunch but I did oblige and told him that I will take him to a nice place. 

Based on the reviews and some research I picked up Tadich Grill. First time and probably the last time for both of us. We get seated and within a couple of mins the server came to ask if we were ready to order. We asked for a few mins and asked him to get the water. As soon as the water came in the server came back to check if we were ready. I told him that I would go for a coffee and my friend ordered from the Daily Special the Mediterranean Sea Bass or a Salmon. So far so good.. But NO and this is the FIRST FOR ME......  The server told me that I cannot order just coffee and need to order something to eat else we cannot be in the restaurant. 

Already in the restaurant, seated and  I really did not want to get up and leave, so I went ahead and ordered a plate of Fries. The server finally left the table with our order.

The food to follow was OK.. wouldnt rate it highly. I am rating it purely on the looks, since I did not eat the fish and probably just had a couple of fries.. Never the less, I have probably seen the last of this Establishment, thanks to the attitude they carry.

All the Best to all who visit this place. Please ensure that every member of your party going in through the doors is ready to order something to eat, not just come there to accompany you and probably have a good chat while you have ordered food.

A good lesson learned.

Thanks
author: Sony B.

description: Oldest restaurant in SF I believe. Very traditional setting, outstanding fresh seafood and great location. You must have a minimum of 3 people in our party to get a booth, but not biggie. Very good!!
author: Lee J.

description:
Came here after a long day of doing touristy things with a friend who was visiting. First thing I noticed upon walking in was the really cool, old-school ambiance and decor. We thought the wait would be long, given how many people were there ahead of us, but they seated us within twenty minutes.

We started off with some drinks - gin martini and Moscow mule. No fancy-dancy tricks here, just good ol' strong and straightforward drinks. The Boston Clam Chowder was a nice surprise, and worked well with the unlimited bread (love that!). Super rich, creamy, and full of clams. We also ordered the Blue Point Oysters Rockefeller (again, touristy things), which were delicious and baked/broiled to perfection.

For entrees, we ordered the Mesquite Charcoal Broiled Petrale Sole Filet and the Seafood Cioppino with Garlic Bread. The Sole Filet was another item cooked to perfection, and my friend described the potatoes as "pretty outrageously delicious." Also, I can see why the Cioppino was a house special. So much seafood in that thing! And it had a clean taste to it, to counterbalance the heavier Boston Clam Chowder we had earlier.

Our waiter was entertaining and recommended some pretty good food and drinks. He recommended a couple of steak entrees, which I'm hoping to try next time. Overall, great service and a great evening.
author: Eryn H.

description: What a great birthday dinner experience!! The servers were spectacular! The food amazing and the ambitiance nice!! The sea bass was out of this world - like butter!!
author: Sharmila C.

description: Very disappointing in service and food. Paid a visit while in the city on recommendation from locals. It is apparently an institution but we felt our fish was overlooked, (simple grill and a mixed seafood plate)vegetables from a frozen bag that were cold and flavorless and the service was slow and inattentive. Don't waste your money. There are so many fabulous restaurants in the city.
author: Christi H.

description: Didn't live up to the hype for me, I get it, oldest restaurant, yada yada. Restaurant looks more 1930's art deco than 1849's (whatever that looks like). Came for the hyped crab cakes on Check Please Bay Area, but was severely disappointed. Not bad, but we were wanting Boston quality, guess that is too much to expect. Chowder was Ok, but not best ever for sure. Prawn sauté was phenomenal though. Service was very abrupt, again that's their style, but not mine. Overall, if I'm going to spend this type of $, I want courteous service and good product all around. Won't be looking for return visit to Tadich any time soon, but they don't seem to have problem packing the joint anyways.
author: Jordan S.

description: We went for lunch twice. Marvelous everything. On honeymoon, a casual couple we were treated like the fanciest of regulars. Highly recommended. First meal had melt in your mouth ahi seared tuna Caesar salad...second meal spinach ricotta ravioli in a lemon caper sauce topped with smoked salmon. Spouse ordered meat ravioli with meat sauce on both visits! All meals served with a portion of sour dough loaf and butter. And their coffee was exquisite. I had thought I would want their signature Ciopponi (sp?). Very happy with my decisions. Super super super. Dreaming of it now...
author: Regina H.

description: Super excellent! It's been around forever for a reason. The wood fired grill makes it for me. Want to keep coming back.
author: Zachary H.

description:
Always a great experience here. It's California's oldest restaurant and the charm is still here. 
We ordered a crab cake appetizer which my mom loved and said was full of crab. My fiancé loved it as well as it tasted like crab not just filling like a lot of places. 
Next I had the sand dabs which wth the tartar sauce tasted like filet o fish from McDonald's but upscale. I loved that they did a simple steamed vegetables to ft down on the richness of the fish and sauce. Then they added a few fresh cut potato fries to soak up the remaining tartar sauce. Delicious! If they don't have it order the Manila clams in butter sauce in the appetizer section. I always bring home the extra sauce and toss in some fresh pasta and it's amazing. 
Finally their famous dish, cioppino. It has fresh crab, scallops, mussels, clams, large prawns and bay shrimp all stewed in a rich tomato sauce and it comes with a side of garlic bread that is to die for. Each bite is full of seafood and the bread is a perfect vehicle to dip into the delicious sauce. 
Service is old school but your waiter will remember your name as you leave. I love this place and even not being a seafood lover and allergic to some, I would highly recommend this place. Don't be afraid as they do have non seafood dishes that are just as well prepared as their seafood dishes.
