author: Jen C.

description: This place had a long wait and even this hangry girl decided to wait it through. I came with a party of 5 on a Saturday night around 6 pm and the wait was around 45 minutes. I heard this is the place to go in SF if you want seafood or meat. After being seated I looked over the menu and decided on the cioppino. When the cioppino came out it was absolutely glorious. It had big chunks of seafood and the cioppino broth was absolutely divine. The portion itself was enormous too that I had leftovers for the next day. I had a bite of the steak which was also perfectly grilled. The food here is amazing and the servers here were good about getting people in and out so no one lingered for too long. I would definitely come back here for seafood and grilled meats.
author: Abigail L.

description:
Yo Pete, you make a good & dirty grey goose martini! We like that sorta thing, & we like how your big personality makes a couple of red-lipped girls feel welcome. 

Tadich captures the feeling of old school San Francisco, perhaps because it is the oldest restaurant here (& in all of the state.) No female servers, just waiters in pressed white coats with no stuffy putting on of airs. 

Reservations are never accepted, but our party of 13 didn't have to wait long for a cozy table in one of the rear wooden booths, giving us a bit of privacy. 

I tried: 
-- crabcake: enjoyed this appetizer especially because of the mustard sauce, & in spite of it not consisting of lump meat crab. Beware tiny wayward crab shells that many of us found in the mixture. 
-- dungeness crab & prawn a la monza: one of their house specials, baked en casserole. Our doll of a waiter made it sound so good, but I should have picked a dish where seafood, & not cheese & bechamel, was the shining star. 
-- chilean seabass: my friend & I both agreed that this was bland & small in portion, especially compared to their other sizable entrees. 
-- cheesecake: I rarely order cheesecake, but was in the mood for it (for lack of more appealing options, I think.) A good decision! Not too dense, very creamy & flavorful. A nice ending to an unexceptional meal, which is an unfortunate reaction to our oldest restaurant, but I calls 'em like I sees 'em.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
This came highly recommend and I now know why. 
My crab cocktail starter was just that!! Filled to the top with the tastiest crab I have ever had. Smooth and rich in flavor. 

My main was the seafood sauté. 
Loaded with prawns, scallops and crab all sautéed in a wonderful wine butter and lemon reduction.
The staff worked like a well oiled machine in this packed to the door establishment.
I finished my night here with a glass of Benedictine to toast my beloved late Wife Brenda and my Friend Dan MacNeil.

Just a great experience.
author: James B.

description:
Well, since Sam's had upped their ( rather low, to be honest ) ante, I had to try Tadich again after so many years, and the results were about the same: old-time ambiance ( nice ), service people are stiffs ( not so nice ), food is so-so ( as was usual ), and the prices high ( UGH! ).

I won't go into a blow-by-blow analysis, but the highlight was the crab cakes. 

People around us really seemed to be enjoying themselves, so I asked one obviously out-of-town family if the cooking was the reason, and they said that their seafood restaurant back in Kansas was better, but this was a REAL San Francisco EXPERIENCE!

UPDATE: The manager was kind and caring enough to contact me, and I neglected to mention that when everything clicks, Tadich is great, so I raised the rating a star. The service had been exemplary in this century, so I felt especially sensitive, but upon reflection, it was no where as bad as in the 80's and 90's, just gruff. And, I meant the "REAL San Francisco EXPERIENCE" as a praise, that people have a good time regardless, so this is a place that one should visit at least once during your stay in the City and judge for yourself.
author: George T.

description: In town for business and had colleague bring me here. I had the lamb shoulder, which was excellent. It came with potatoes and vegetables, which were fine, but nothing great. But I didn't mind because the lamb was so good. Service was also a little slow, but it was fairly busy.
author: Cory O.

description: I was thinking about going to there to have a nice meal with some of my out of town guests.  I called them and was told that they didn't take reservations.  OK.   Then, I asked her about how long we may need to wait for dinner tomorrow.  She said anywhere from 10 mins to an hour.  I was more put off by the unfriendly attitude than the unhelpful response.  She was super inpatient the minute she picked up the phone and constantly saying "all right?" meaning she couldn't wait to hang up.  It's not that I kept talking and talking.  I was asking two very simple questions and the whole conversation lasted for an minute.  Terrible phone etiquette really does not speak well for the restaurant, and we were literally turned away.
author: G C.

description: What a great restaurant. The cioppino is unreal. Will always come back when in SF and will stick to that order. Other food looked good but this was the winner
author: Trey B.

description: On a tip from a fellow Uber rider, we took in this gem. Be ready when you walk in, no reservations and how many in your party....go stand over there till we call you. Which is not a problem but half the bar is table waiting patrons and half are diners so knowing that could have netted us a drink to relax and wait for the table. Outside of that the bar staff was pleasant and helpful. Our waiter, Marion was excellent funny. attentive and made terrific recommendations. The chioppino and blackened swordfish were outstanding! Great recommendation by Ron and great meal at SF's oldest restaurant!
author: George E.

description: So worth the wait! Great service and outstanding food! An absolute must in San Francisco!
author: Eric G.

description: Wanted to go out to a nice steak dinner and this didn't disappoint - coming from the East Bay we used BART which is always an experience and usually not in the best way.  However, BART is an easy way to get there - very quick walk from Embarcadero station.  A three person group, we had a fish meal and two different steak meals and all were great.  Bread flowed freely (still a little discombobulated about no bread plates. . .) and they were very on it with drink/water refills.  We had one of their booths which is awesome because it makes it more intimate and you can hear your table mates.  My recommendation too is to go here late afternoon/early evening as we had no wait at all on a Saturday going in around 4 pm.
author: Shannon L.

description: Enjoyed the crab leg cocktail immensely! Big chunks of Dungeness crab legs and spicy cocktail sauce!! And of course delicious sourdough bread!! I could have feasted on those two things alone!! Old school SF and I loved it!
author: Darlene G.

description: Sensational!  Great service, great food, and wonderful atmosphere. I had the calamari steak and my wife had the petrale sole, both were perfectly done. Our server was very knowledgeable about the menu and extremely helpful and attentive. Such a quaint place for friends, a romantic dinner, or even business.
author: William S.

description: Very old-timely. Good food, but I paid $22 for an average salad. I'm sure the steak and seafood are worth it. Very loud in the building. Just hella expensive.
author: Allison F.

description:
Ever since I was a little girl, whenever we came to the city, my dad would bring me to Tadich Grill. I loved the rustic feel and timelessness of the interior and the great service you receive every time. 

What's not to love about Tadich? Their menu is packed with fresh seafood and classic dishes. My favorite by far is the cioppino - packed with seafood and the perfect broth, this dish is the epitome of Tadich Grill for me. 

I love their clam chowder (white) too - rich, creamy, and filling. Recently I tried the Tadich Platter for two (appetizer) and was thrilled to discover a new favorite. 

To me, Tadich Grill speaks to the heart and soul of classic San Francisco food - so stop by the next time you're in the city.
author: Courtney P.

description:
Old world charm.  Private booths.  Waiters in white.  Big old bar to sidle up to and eat solo alongside the suits at lunch.  Or sip a dirty while looking fancy...

Cioppino is a bowlful of warm, rich seafood stew.  Clams and muscles, crab and shrimp with large chunks of fish crowd the bowl.  Thick slices of garlic bread for dipping and sopping each drop.

Fresh shrimp and crab are mounded atop crisp iceberg lettuce with a healthy dollop of creamy Louis dressing for a refreshing salad that's filling and yet light.

Steaks, chops, fish, all prepared in large and quality portions.  Nothing bad here.

NOTE:  After reading this, I felt compelled to pass it along:  t.co/E9fzukW4E5  Perhaps if everyone knows, then it won't be a dirty little secret anymore.
author: Sondra H.

description:
Christmas was pretty dead around FiDi with a lot of stuff closed for the holidays except for Tadich Grill which had people queuing up during a cold blustery lunch. It's the oldest restaurant in SF and it doesn't seem to have aged at all. Part of the charm of the place is the fact that they maintain the booths and bar service - a good 'ol businessman's lunch place, in and out with minimal fuss. Servers still wear white coats and check in with you frequently but with no stuffiness or airs - just no nonsense. The food is good but not great but you don't come here just for the food. 

I sat at the bar with a friend and ordered the hangtown fry. A little pricey for brunch but the serving of eggs with chunks of bacon and large oysters (plus bread) was enough for two lunches for me which made it seem not bad value. The eggs/bacon/oyster were tasty - possibly an SF classic - not I'm not sure I would call it amazing. Decent. Served up the way it's always been (this is not a flash place). I wasn't into the "fries" which were huge slices of potato. Bland and dry.
author: Jean K.

description: I've been coming here since My first visit to SF in the 1980s, but the restaurant has been in existence since 1849! It is the oldest continuously run restaurant in the state and worth a visit if just for the decor. The bar is made from one tree and it is beautiful! The restaurant has booths along one side with a huge long bar on the other side. A copper pipe divides the bar into a bar vs food service, so if you want to eat at the bar aim for a seat past that bar. They will not serve food in the "bar" section. Their drinks are great and the wait-staff, all mature men who are experienced, fast and efficient will remind you of how the place must have been 100 years ago, when the purpose was to come and eat. The menu features seafood every which way - I loved my bay shrimp and tomato salad and hubby enjoyed his mixed greens. Dressing was served on the said, along with a tub of the best tartar sauce for hubby's sole. I had the Chilean Sea Bass (I know I know not very environmentally friendly but hey, I didn't have kids so I'm allowed). The Chilean Sea Bass (not really Chilean Sea bass but that is another story) was mild, well cooked and broiled to perfection! The plate was full of freshly steamed broccoli, carrots and cauliflower as I had requested no rice or starch. We loved sitting at the bar enjoying our food watching all the activity. Highly recommend while you are in the City!
author: K J.

description: My dad used to take me here as a little boy(I'm 65 now!) Its still a must every time we are in San Fran. Tried Cioppino all over the world and there is none better! Actually I challenge you to find anything that's not excellent here! I have dreams of eating here!
author: Mark B.

description: I have a seafood allergy. Don't come here if you have a seafood allergy.  I was with a group and could not get out of it. The menu is one of the most seafood-centric I have seen.  That said - the ravioli with meat sauce was very good, the service was fine and the martini was perfect.  Everyone in my group raved about their seafood dinner.
author: Elan F.

description:
Old school location
Great tasting fish
Both me and my wife ordered different meals
We shared and both enjoyed
Crowded with patrons but we sat at the counter
Very enjoyable
author: Willie N.

description:
When I first walked into this restaurant, I knew that I wanted to order something that tasted exactly like how this place smelled. The aroma of seafood wafts strongly toward you when you enter...it's magical. It's a classic "nice restaurant." White table cloths and napkins, waiters in aprons, a friendly bartender. They don't take reservations, but if you time it right, you won't have to wait too long.

The food is exquisite. My #1 favorite entrée is the scallops sauté. It's TO DIE FOR. And yes, it tastes exactly how this place smells when you walk in. The sauce is creamy and sinful. It's served with saffron rice and steamed veggies. The scallops are seared to perfection, and the sauce and rice are so good that I even took those as leftovers and it still made a tasty meal without the scallops. Yes.

I'd highly recommend this place to anyone who wants a taste of classic San Francisco.
author: Kelsey S.

description:
When we lived in San Francisco and Marin County, we visited Tadich Grill regularly. However, we moved out of the area 33 years ago and it has been that long since we dined at Tadich. On this trip to California we looked forward to visiting one of our all time favorites. How did it turn out? Mixed.
In the "old days" they served the house wines in water glasses for one dollar per glass. We knew the $1 was long gone but amused to discover so were the water glasses. Our waiter says they introduced wine glasses about 30 years ago. That's just a fraction of the time that Tadich Grill has been in existence as it dates back to the gold rush days of 1849.
Otherwise, very little has changed. As no reservations are taken, one signs in upon arrival, fights their way to the bar and drinks standing until a seat opens at the bar. One can order food at the bar if they choose not to wait for a table. Part of the fun of the place is one can have fun conversations with locals or tourists during the 30 to 45 minute wait. Tonight we had a great time talking with two local male millennials until they departed and then we took their stools. Our places were immediately taken by three visitors from Sweden: father, son and fifteen year old grandson who were enjoying a three week holiday. What fun we had listening to what fun they were having on their trip.
At this point,we would have given Tadich a rating of 5. Then we were seated at a table and ordered dinner.
My wife ordered sea bass because the Swedes were returning because they had really enjoyed the sea bass the previous evening. When served, she found her food warm but not hot. She also thought the sea bass was less well seasoned than that which she does at home.
I had pan sautéed rockfish with mixed vegetables and cottage fries. The fish was served with a bland tartar sauce. The fries were hot. The fish was warm. The veggies were well cooked but cold. My wife had the very same veggies (broccoli, carrots, zucchini, etc.) but hers were warm. The best rating we can give the food is 3 and for the overall rating a 3.5 or 4.
author: Joe S.

description:
I'm not sure what I can add about this restaurant.  The only truly historic restaurant in SF?  Patronized by tourists, locals and all the community of all ages?  The only place open on weekends for lunch downtown worth frequenting?  The list goes on and on.

I love the fish and seafood specials at Tadich.  Getting downtown is usually a holiday treat for me as I live far away and don't make it there often.  I'm always glad when I do.  I've been going for decades and never wrote it up.

I've never had a bad meal there, I love the old school booths, the PROFESSIONAL AND WONDERFUL STAFF:  From Host, to bar back, the service is spectacular, truly professional wait staff on par with Europe.  I love going there.

Everything I've had has been truly great food, not overly done and presented food, but old school, traditional and perfectly cooked and the freshest and choicest cuts of food.  It's great for young and old, day or night, and their specialties are worldwide known (think Anthony Bourdain) such as Hangtown Fry, Cioppino and really, anything that comes from the sea.

~ Ms. Ali
author: A W.

description: Cannot and will not ever be disappointed when coming here.. My wife and I discovered this place about 5 years ago or so. We can't come as often as we want but if we are in the city we will definitely end up here
author: Josh G.

description:
I really like their old school decor. The wooden bar counter and booths remind me of the Big4 restaurant at the Scarlet Huntington hotel on Nob Hill. Should come early to get in line to get the table. The bar seating is not that bad. 

We ordered Oyster Rockefeller, Cioppino and fillet sea bass. The food was so delicious! I would say it is a little pricey for some but it is worth it.
author: Ffaahh N.

description: Excellent dining spot in the city. Went with a group of friends and enjoyed the bar service for predinner drinks, the pleasant waitstaff and the amazing meal. I had the sautéed shrimp, crap and scallops. Delicious. Will return again and again.
author: Victoria M.

description: Considering the clout of this establishment, I wanted to throw up a five-star rating, but truth be told, my first meal here was pretty mediocre. I ordered a mixed greens salad plus the scallops plate. The salad and dressing were mediocre, while I found the scallops to be stringy and bland. The pilaf was also ultra-basic and the veggies just ok. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing but not too impressive; At 50 bucks a plate for lunch, I expect nirvana.
author: Ryan C.

description: Seafood Ciopinno!! You need to try this!! Amazing!!! You might need to hang out a few minutes before your name is called but its worth it. Great wine menu as well.
author: Allen O.

description:
Absolutely excellent! The service was very good. The food was delicious. The wait for a table was more then twenty minutes but, less then the half hour quoted. Why am I not giving five stars, one might wonder? I reserve my five star reviews for the absolute best of the best. Places that either have a Michelin star or likely should.

We had the appetizer platter. Most everything was very good. The cocktail sauce was as fresh and tasty as any. It had zest! The mussels, oysters, crab, smoked salmon, smoked trout, and pickled herring were all fresh and delicious. The calamari was a little chewy. It was well seasoned, fresh and tasty. My sweetie was not impressed with the tomatoes so I had both of them. I thought they were tasty.

The Cioppino was excellent! We found that together with the appetizer platter it was ample food leaving room for dessert. We skipped dessert as we had a show to attend.

This is a traditional seafood place that has service, ambiance, and food that echos last century and beyond.
author: Tom A.

description: Wonderful environment, food and staff.  Our waiter Barry professionally served humor, advice, and amazing wine and food.   Must see this gem, the oldest restaurant in Ca!
author: Rob P.

description: No wait at all, even though there was a line, seats were open at the counter. I had mesquite broiled halibut that was perfectly cooked. The potato wedges were perfectly cooked as well. However I was not allowed any substitutions for the mixed vegetables. The other downside is only four beers on tap.
author: Rich G.

description:
Awesome seafood restaurant in the FiDi!  May I also add that it is the oldest in San Francisco AND California?  That makes it an extra effort to check it out!

Do get their Clam Chowder as a starter and Cioppino!  It feeds 2 people and it is oh so hearty!  It had everything you want from the sea and the savory seafood flavor is delicious with the stew!  I didn't waste a drip!  I used their crunchy and soft on the inside bread to soak up the remaining sauce! 

I like the old, feel good bar seats setting while digging in to my homely meals!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
As many reviewers have noted, this place costs a pretty penny. However, it is a slice of old San Fransisco culture. Good drinks, I had the side car. Great fish stew, the house specialty. Waiter was a character and just added to the experience. 

Desserts were average at best, thus the missing star. Despite this, it is so worth the experience. Had a great time with quality people.
author: Mike Z.

description:
Having a perfectly good evening with typical Tadich old school plates of food sitting at the counter with Thomas as our server. That is until an aggressive bartender sprayed us with thick red juice from all the way across the bar. Splattered my face. My shirt is destroyed. My pants have juice splattered on my knee (now that takes a lot of juice to hit a knee under a bar - it must have hit my face first and fallen). My wife's face, her dress was soaked. Our half-eaten food. In and on our wine glasses. On our napkins - which only made the matter worse. Just a disaster.  It looked like we witnessed an ax murder!

After asking for the manager expecting top notch service/resolution - Tim Scully - the evening manager flew by, TOSSED two cards next to our plates, and said he'd "cover the dry-cleaning." and flew on along WITHOUT ANY COMPASSION! Really not ANY!  There was no - "I'm so sorry." No offer to replace the ruined food. No offer to replace a Faconnable shirt or the designer dress my wife was wearing. No, let me treat you to a dessert or another cocktail. No engagement to find out what we would need to have a better evening - nothing! 

Thomas tried to have Tim return, but I couldn't even look at him. I believe I said, "Don't even think about approaching me after that." We paid and left - after upending our ruined bottle of wine across the bar service.

After sending a note to the manager the next day - not one response. What absolutely terrible service from the leadership! I've always been proud of this place - and I was ashamed to have brought my wife - a Master of Wine to dinner here. I will never return. Even Thomas the server was ashamed of how his manager treated us.  

So, tho you didn't get a tip Thomas - I suggest you take it out of your manager's bonus this year - you earned it! And he is the one that ruined our night with you.

Avoid this place at all costs. ALL COSTS. Its faint claims at history are not worth the treatment, or the cost of ruined clothing.
author: David M.

description:
Tadich ... the quintessential San Francisco fish house, in the heart of the fancy Financial District.

My partner and I visited for dinner on a warm Thursday night in February. We arrived at about 6 p.m. before the impending crowds. We were graciously seated as soon as we arrived.

For starters, we had a Caesar salad and cup of clam chowder. Although the Caesar could've been slightly more fishy with the mandatory anchovies, the chowder was perfect. Steaming hot and seasoned well. I enjoyed it, and so did my partner.

For the mains, we enjoyed the Turbot Stuffed with Crab and Bay Shrimp a la Newburg, Rice, and Fried Seafood Plate (Oysters, Scallops, Prawnsand Calamari). The turbot hit the spot -- perfectly creamy enough and a more than satisfactory amount of the tasty white fish. Turbot is such a delicate fish and Tadich knows precisely how to prepare it. And the crab and bay shrimp -- well, that makes my mouth water just writing about it and remembering the divinity of it all. As for the fried seafood plate, a cheat day for sure. It's pretty hard to go wrong with anything deep fried. The accompanying tartar sauce and cocktail sauce complement the fried goodness quite well. My fav fried picking: the calamari. 

For the sinful dessert: the moist and huge slice of carrot cake. A must try. 

Price: quite high, but service and quality are top notch. You shouldn't be disappointed.

Tadich: you did quite well on my visit, and the reason why you've been around more than 150 years. I'll be back, along with my partner.
author: Cameron M.

description:
Every time I've dined here I have had professional service and an excellent meal. This last time we were in a hurry to see a show so only had time for a drink and dinner.

I had the crab and lobster thermidor and it was excellent. They don't skimp on ingredients-instead it was full of crab and lobster meat.

My husband had the calamari steak and it too was very good (although I would have had modified it to be Oscar).

And if you like oysters Rockefeller, Tadich makes the best I've ever eaten.
author: Tiffany M.

description: I was told 3 times I was next on the list and still did not get called. My wife and I sat down at the bar and did not get acknowledged.... 45 min later we got a table and the menu. I ordered charbroiled snapper and my wife ordered pork chops. Both were overcooked. The snapper wasn't even edible. Considering plates run $25 and up, I would spend my money elsewhere!! Not all what it's cracked up to be.
author: Chris C.

description:
Reservations not accepted. Although wait times have never been a problem for me as my whole party is there, 

Reasonably priced seafood, especially for the financial district.
author: Cassandra T.

description: My dad took me to Tadich, I've taken my kids, and most recently my grandkids.  When in town at a meeting I'll take friends or go by myself at the bar. I miss some of the old time waiters, whom I knew by names. The drinks, bread, salads, fish, and non fish dishes have daily specials and timeless standards that always measure up.   The crowds can be tough - go very early or late!
author: David B.

description:
This is an old institution in San Francisco that should not be missed, should you be a tourist, day tripper, or City local.

From lamb shoulder to beef, oysters to shrimp, you'll always get a good meal here coupled with top notch service unparalleled in San Francisco. 

I invite you, dear reader to come here for the excellent food and service, and judge for yourself the high quality product Tadich delivers.
author: Frank L.

description:
This place is great. Common sense and no pretensions.

They don't take reservations. I got there at around five, and got a seat at the long bar immediately. But within half an hour there was a huge press of people crammed into the entry waiting for a seat. The restaurant has a no-bullshit policy for seats at the food bar. Three different times during my meal when groups of FiDi types with rolexes and rolled-up shirtsleeves and hair gel tried to sit down and order a drink while waiting for a table, the waiter shooed them away and told them to wait with everyone else. 

The staff yell up and down the bar and hustle back and forth with plates and refills. Since they're going back and forth down the line it's easy to flag down your waiter as he passes if you need something. At the bar, you sit down, get bread, order fast, get your food fast, eat fast, and get out fast. I don't mean that I felt rushed, but the staff was quick and efficient once I decided what I wanted or when I asked for the check. 

My waiter was super energetic and friendly, like some kind of fantasy-novel innkeeper, bustling from one task to the next, jolly but busy and short. He'd take down an order with a few scribbles of a pen, say "Done!", snap his pad closed, and hurry on down the line. And lo and behold, a few minutes later he'd reappear and present the person's food with a flourish.

My food was great, by the way. But you can get great food in many places in SF. This place has a really unique, fantastic atmosphere.
author: Brian G.

description:
Getting to swing 'round this place made the experience up front and personal! Tadich Grill's interior is divided into two long sections, with an extended bar the length of the room anyone eats full meals at (which was our choice), and some booths for families or groups of 4+ on the other side. That must be a system that works well, considering this spot's been around since 1849!

Onto our early evening orders:
-Tadich Platter for Two: Medley of Crab Legs, Oysters, Prawns, Marinated Herring, Smoked Salmon, Smoked Trout, Calamari Salad, Tomatoes, Anchovies, Capers, Garnish
-Luncheon Special: Slow Roasted Prime Rib, au Jus, with Mashed Potatoes and Vegetables
-Orange Juice

My other half and I shared a ginormous seafood appetizer, which by all accounts wasn't an appetizer but a meal on its own due to its size! Goodness me, the smoked trout and smoked salmon may make you moan... Their calamari salad was distinguished with garlic and other spices. Don't get me started about the herring... May have been my favorite!

This was my first visit here, and when I saw Prime Rib on the menu, I had to reach out and grab it! However, while it was very good and prepared medium-rare as requested, I then learned that the "specialty" here is actually seafood! It's SF -- that simply makes sense. Fully explains why our shared appetizer for seafood sampler blew my shoes off.

I enjoyed everything we had, and would totally come back for a seafood only occasion. Pick your arrival time well -- we got here just before the rush, as there are no reservations! Lines as long as the room WILL develop otherwise.
author: Garett T.

description: The food is very well prepared, the menu is varied and the service is operational. I highly recommend the crab cake.
author: Jaiden R.

description:
The wait can be long and daunting and sometimes confusing (the bar seating is confusing as it is first come first serve). However, Tadich Grill is still the best and always will be. Loud, busy and in old school setting. 

Get there early. It's busy all the time due to tourists and locals. Best to put your name down on the list or wait for a bar seating at the same time. We've always sat at the bar and its always been great service. The Cioppino is the best in the city. The seafood sautés are also great. A must get is the boubon bread pudding with caramel sauce. Yum!!
author: Katie Anne N.

description: Enjoyed our visit. Nice atmosphere. Jose our server was great!  Service might have been too fast if that's possible. Food is fine but a little pricey.
author: David S.

description:
Checked in at about 7:15 on a Saturday night for a table for two.   Told we could sit first come first served at the counter, or wait for a table.   We grabbed drinks and waited maybe about 30 minutes for our table.  Easily worth the wait.   Big, meaty bites of calamari for an appetizer.   The best cioppino I've ever had as an entree, full of so much seafood that I'm not sure I can order cioppino anywhere ever again.   Fun environment, with a wait staff that enjoys bantering back and forth with the customers.

Worthy of the hype.
author: Jake L.

description: I am so glad that I got to have my last meal in SF at this classic restaurant.  Waiters are dressed in their white service coats, and are super friendly and attentive.  The bummer is that they don't take reservations (I mean, a popular joint like this---who needs to?)  Luckily, we had an early flight home the next day, didn't eat a big lunch, so we went to an early bird dinner, so there was no wait for our party of 5.  The menu is extensive...seafood galore, but really, when you're in SF, and the weather is chilly, all you need is cioppino.  Loads of seafood in EVERY bite.  My cousin got hers without the fish, so she ended up with more scallops, and mussels...I think I am going to order mine like that the next time!  Everyone ordered it and everyone LOVED it.  It comes with the most amazing garlic bread too.  Dreaming of the next time I can return to the City by the Bay...and Tadich!
author: Kanilehua K.

description:
This is a classic restaurant that you have to try if you come to San Francisco. It has a giant bar where you can order the full menu and also a series of private booths around the perimeter (with curtains). The waiters wear crisp white coats (not dinner jackets, but the old-school waiter outfits).

The food is very good but not great. Nothing is likely to disappoint; nothing will be life-changing either. It's seafood oriented. They have an excellent hangtown fry. Calamari also is recommended.

The only downsides are it's noisy and there can be a wait. But it's crowded in a good way -- festive.

A couple of times, I have ducked in here in the late afternoon, by myself, for raw shellfish and a glass of white wine. Easy to get a seat at the bar. It's a solitary respite.
author: Frank W.

description: Fun atmosphere with a unique spin on sea food and great steaks. Ingredients are locally sourced, including seafood such as Dungeness crab, so this is a can't miss spot.
author: Brian A.

description:
My mom and I drove up to SF from LA saturday, encountered a nightmare double decker bus crash in front of our hotel, and arrived starving. i was craving sushi, but the place we wanted to go to was packed, and then we found Tadich. I had been wanting to come to Tadich, as the 2nd location just opened in DC where I live, so it was serendipitous that we stumbled upon the place. There was a 20 minute wait for a table, so we sat at the front bar and ordered two martinis. 

The service at this spot is, for lack of better words, colorful. Basically, attitude is the shtick, so dont expect warm and bubbly service. Though its a white tablecloth kinda place, people were dressed in all types of clothes, i think SF in general is more casual than DC, NY or even LA. 

Onto my 2nd martini, we both ordered the clam chowder to start and it was delicious! Also delicious is the crusty sourdough bread they bring to the table with cold butter. There is truly nothing better in this world! I had the bone-in ribeye for my entree, and my mom had a whole fish (branzino i think). She was a little turned off, as the fish came fully intact, bones at all, but that kind of sitch doesnt bother me! My rib eye was perfection, ALMOST too much to finish, but don't worry, I did. 

My mom had been to tadich 25 years ago with my dad, so it brought back a ton of memories for her. The place has a fun history and ide recommend it to anyone visiting SF who wants a taste of history!
author: Caitlin O.

description: Went here for my parent's anniversary and I have to say I was impressed.  The bread was so delicious.  I had the calamari and fries and it was so good.  They give a lot of food.  My parents ordered their most famous item on the menu: Cioppino and devoured it.  If you really want a fine dining and seafood experience then this is the place!  It's located in the Financial District.  The customer service was really good.  Our waiter took care of us!  Def would come back!
author: Mikayla M.

description:
I understand why some people complain about the service, or the seating rules. It's a busy place with long-established rules. We stopped in on a Thursday night recently, and I put our name down before we had all arrived. Almost an hour ater (!) when the last straggler finally got through the traffic we were seated immediately (and there were plenty of people still waiting to be seated). Service was very good, our server was very professional: quick, accurate and jovial.

Cocktails were good and strong. I had a Manhatten that took the edge right off that hour-long wait. 

The house specialty Cioppino is delicious here, and when you're done with that giant bowl of clams, mussels, fish chunks, and scallops in a thick tasty tomato base you can dip that decadent garlic bread in the broth until you can't eat another bite. Then take the leftovers home, because that's how big the cioppino is (for me anyway). 

Crab cakes were loaded with crab and not too much filler (breadcrumbs, I guess), and were crispy on the outside, creamy on the inside. They were generously-sized as well---about 2" thick and 3-4" across.

Oysters Rockefeller are topped with cream spinach and parmesan and then popped under the broiler till everything is nice and bubbly. An order comes with 6 oysters, plenty for a table of 4 as an appetizer.

The 4 of us had 2 servings of creamed spinach for side orders because that's how much we love our greens braised with cream, onions and garlic.

The steamed vegetables that come on the side are nothing to rave about but at least they balance out the butter and cream (if you're ordering like we did anyway...but it's very possible to get your seafood without all the extra goodness if you want).

One point off for the crazy prices (Cioppino was $33!) and for the noise level. I think they need to put some sound dampening panels in the ceiling.
author: Annabelle S.

description: Worst service I have ever had!  Eaten here many times. Food is great. Can longer stand the service. It's almost like a gimmick, be rude to customers and they will keep coming back.
author: Cian S.

description: Food is very good... Vibe is tasteful and historic.  Some of the waiters are surly--every time.  We brave them anyway.  Crab cakes A-1.  Mushroom rice is a wonderful meal itself.  We will continue to eat there every visit.
author: Jane H.

description: Food is always fresh and delicious. Service is great. Love coming here for seafood, the cioppino and the clams and mussels in particular are our favorite.
author: Vera K.

description: An institution. Incredibly friendly, accommodating staff. No nonsense. Delicious, traditional food. Crab cakes were a little bland but the broiled sea bass was amazing, as was the sautéed shrimp and cioppino. Ravioli wasn't my favorite. Awesome cocktails filled to the brim.
author: Beth K.

description: Love this SF Classic and we are never disappointed! Been here dozens of times but recently twice in the last couple weeks!! The staff is wonderful, food is scrumptious! We had Crab cakes which are the best ever!! I had the Chilean Sea Bass as recommended by darling John, our waiter! Can't wait to go back!!
author: J. L.

description:
One of the great things about San Francisco is how little restaurants can change over time.  You can visit a number of institutions in SF, and it still has the same atmosphere as it did ten, twenty, thirty, forty years ago. Exhibit 1 is Tadich Grill - an ageless restaurant in the city.  The waiters dress in classic white.  Quick, speedy service.  Drinks are made to order - strong.  There's no fussing around here. No hoity toity-ness.  Tadich reminds of a time when food was simpler.  Big prawn cocktails.  Clam chowder.  Garlic bread.  There are no fusion, deconstructed aiolis here.  Just great hearty food. 

You have to try the cioppino.  No exceptions.  Plentiful amounts of seafood (mussels, shrimp, fish, etc.).  A robust, hearty tomato broth.  Two slices of crunchy garlic bread to soak up the juices.  It's heaven in a big bowl.  I recommend ordering the plain pasta if you like eating it with your cioppino. I also enjoyed the clam chowder (order a bowl and have it split in two); The prawn cocktails were delicious. 

I had no expectations when I visited, and I enjoyed my time here thoroughly.  Along with House of Prime Rib, Tadich Grill belongs in the City's pantheon of timeless restaurants.
author: Huy D.

description:
Amazing food. 
Great staff. 
The real deal when it comes to seafood. 
Only negative thing, it was way to cold, every time the door opened. 
They didn't have a curtain or something like that. 
But besides that a definitive must go! 

Will be back for sure!
author: Jeyla M.

description: An institution. A must when in SF. No reservations taken so you have to wait at times.  The seafood Cioppino is the house specialty and worth the wait.  Scallops, clams, shrimp and fish all in a fragrant tomato broth/sauce with garlic bread to sop up all that juicy goodness.
author: Pratik P.

description: We had a wonderful experience!  The food was amazing and the service was outstanding.  We were in town to celebrate a good friends life and many times had mentioned to visit and eat at Tadich!  I'm from Texas and we don't have this back home!  The charm of the restaurant took me back in time....a must to come to!
author: Cecilia M.

description:
Sadly, was not super impressed. Given that we paid about 50 bucks each for three people, I didn't feel like we got the bang for our buck. I do like the fact that I can say I've been to the "oldest restaurant in SF" though. Now onto the food!!

Clam Chowder [2 stars] - my friend said that this was the best he's ever had. I say it was okay, decent maybe. It was maybe a notch below average, I know I've had better clam chowder before (like in Monterrey Bay). They didn't give a lotta clams but for $8.50, it was a decent size to share between two people as an appetizer. It could even be a lunch entree!

Oysters Rockfeller [1 star] - not worth the money. For $20.95, you'd think it'd taste a little more flavorful but it was just a glob of cheese with some baked spinach over fishy oysters. Biggest disappointment of the night as it's one of their more popular/famous dishes. Not worth it. :'( I know you're sad too.

Calamari Steak [4 stars] - really good! I actually liked this the most outta our whole meal. If I went back, I'd get this considering it's just a huge piece of calamari beaten down and fried to perfection with some light garlic butter sauce on top. It came with brocolini and garden carrots as well. Yum!

Seafood Ciopinno [4 stars] - pretty good as well. I am fan of seafood and tomato broth and soup so this was a great combination. At $31.95 a pop, it does fill you up. I ate perhaps 1/8 of it and called it quits though because I was so full from everything else. Big shrimp, big scallops and big clams with two slices of garlic bread. How can you go wrong?

My other friend ordered a charcoal grilled fish but I didn't have a taste so not sure if it was good or not. It looked decent and he gobbled it down with no comments so can't tell if it's a plus or minus!

Either way, I'd def. order only the last two items I reviewed (calamari and ciopinoo) if I were to recommend it to anyone. I think it gets pretty full on the weekdays, even on a Monday at 5:30PM so be sure to have your full party present or else you'd have to wait in line. Decent experience, wouldn't be back though.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
- cioppino........enough said
- oh one more thing.......the branzino was pretty amazing too

5 stars - would eat here everyday
4 stars - definitely coming back
3 stars - average
2 stars - we paid for this?
1 star - where's the exit.....
author: Mike Z.

description:
Walked in on a lark after getting off the California Cable Car line. VERY IMPRESSED with service and more impressed with the food for the value.

Instantly greeted by a friendly and professional bar staff. He poured excellent martinis (all the way to the top). We ordered the Tadich Platter app (medley of crab legs, oysters*, prawns, marinated herring, smoked, salmon, smoked trout, calamari salad, tomatoes, anchovies, capers, garnish). More than impressed with the quality of the food for the price. I'm from Chicago and this app would be twice as much at any restaurant where I live.

Supposedly it is the oldest running seafood restaurant in San Fran. Either way, it was a good experience. However, fair warning, it is a bustling place after 5pm. I lucked out and got a seat at the bar before it filled up.
author: K. B.

description: The history of this restaurant alone is reason to visit, and the food matches the restaurant's historical value. Ordered the seafood cannelloni, crab cakes with rice and vegetables, "Manhattan" clam chowder, and salad. The food was all excellent. This is also a restaurant where it isn't uncommon to see a few well known people.
author: Frank M.

description: Today was my first "date" with this amazing restaurant and for sure not the last one...It will be a long relationship! The Oysters Rockefeller just perfect as a prelude for the Seafood Cioppino, hot tomatoe soup, plenty of well cooked prawns, fish, mussels in an amazing balance of flavors. Good selection of wines, and a very good espresso.
author: Enrique B.

description: All of the food we had was excellent, especially the New England clam chowder.  Service was excellent at the bar and it was just a fantastic experience in San Fran.
author: Matt H.

description: My date suggested we go here for dinner and it was a great suggestion.  It's a very nice, old school, classic restaurant.  I felt like I was in a movie... an old one.  Loved the white tablecloths.  The tables were kind of tight, but overall, I still enjoyed the warm ambiance.
author: Chloe M.

description: Horrible service. We had a very rude waiter ( he never told us his name but he is Caucasian and bald). He was unpleasant the entire dinner then as soon as our bill came and he got his tip ( of course), he proceeded to tell us we were going to have to leave because "there were so many other people waiting." My brother in law barely finished his beer! Plus, the tons of people waiting were nothing more than a handful. We proceeded to go to the manager to inform him and he was incredibly unhelpful. Food is good to mediocre, expensive and service is HORRIBLE! Beware of this place!!   David, your response from last night... thank you for your response. However, you are mistaken with your time line of events. I will admit I was on the phone at the Beginning of Supper and before we ordered only!!! I have 3 young kids who I wanted to FaceTime prior to their bedtime and something I will not apologize for. Giving our waiter the benefit of the doubt, it was literally 2 min after we received our bill and he received his tip that  he pushed us out the door.  Also, he had a huge chip on his shoulder throughout dinner and couldn't have been less helpful. For example, when we asked him the difference between white or red clam chowder, he wouldn't elaborate and acted like we were an inconvenience to his "time." As a pharmacy manager and one that likes to back my employees, I understand the want to do this. However, this is not the time! He was rude, short and "annoyed " with us from the moment we sat down. If you continue to back these kinds of employees, your business will go under. There are multiple exceptional restaurants in the bay area and service is Everything. Lastly my family is not one to complain but we will stand up to this kind of bad service and behavior.
author: Lesley L.

description:
Preface: I came here with my aunt and uncle visiting from NYC who wanted a San Francisco gem. Tadich Grill has been slinging seafood for over 166 years... that's a lot of years, so they must be doing something right.

We went at about 6:45pm as a party of 5 on a Monday night and had no problem getting a table. This place is old school. No reservations, your whole party must be present to be seated, older servers type place.

This place runs the gamut on menu items. From bacon and eggs, to steak to seafood, the last which seems to be the star of the show. Known for their cioppino, I of course had to order as a recent Bay area transplant. It didn't disappoint. Not a cheap meal, priced at about $34/35 it was chock full of seafood. A hearty portion of white fish, ginormous shrimps (3), mussels, clams and small bay fish in a not so salty, subtly flavored broth. This was accompanied by 2 large, salty pieces of garlic bread to soak up the rich flavors of broth. It was really good! A little pricy for what it was, but I wasn't paying so ::shrug::.

The guy had the shrimp and crab in a casserole and it was also good, although I preferred the cioppino. Service was solid in the old school manner. Free bread is always delicious; not the best, but a nice option to have. Far from trendy, but satisfying nonetheless and a definite San Francisco staple; a great spot for seafood and to feel like a tourist or at least taste a bit of old San Francisco
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Just as sad and bad as the last time I was here. I've learned that I will not bother to expect anything stellar from the  cioppino any longer from that last few trips. It's not what it once was. None of us are.  Ok.  My birthday lunch I thought I'd try an old favorite. Lobster crab thermador. I have had many times in the last 30 years.  Today it came out very yellow smelling strong. I took a bite and thought they gave me the ala monza dish / it was curry flavored. The waiter haggled and took it back then he brings a dish of sauce over and says this is the sauce no curry chef says. So I try the sauce it's f'g curry (don't even get up in my palate)   I tell the waiter this is curry. You try it.  He did and said omg there's curry. He comes back trying to apologize saying the chef gave me the dish of sauce to show the curry sauce. Wtf?!   I know this dish is white. He brings a white sauce w mushrooms and says this is the sauce. I say yes. But what do you know ? My dish comes back w same sauce mixed w the white. It's still curry. Waiter says when were you here last ? This is the new chef. No thank you. $38 entree was crap. I took it to go. It's not the waiters fault. Smelled bad under my desk. I asked receptionist who has cats doesn't this smell like dried cat food a little ?   Oh yes.   Dish went right into the circular file. What a waste of money. This tradition / memory is dead
author: Suzy Q.

description: Best seafood meal I've had in a while, amazing experience and the waiter was kind enough to serve us free cake when he found out that it's my boy friend's birthday that day
author: Lin X.

description:
I love the ambiance of this place and they always have great service.

I always get the Cioppino soup when I come here. It's so bomb and can feed two people. Great assortment of seafood and the broth is delicious. The garlic bread is great to go with the soup. Best meal for cold weather. Definitely worth the $. Will be coming back here for sure.
author: Jessica S.

description:
I can't believe its taken me this long to eat here. Awesome seafood, great service, wonderful ambiance, especially with the super long bar and old world, room sized booths.

The only negative is that you cannot make reservations. Its unusual for a restaurant in this price range to make you wait in line.

Loved their Cioppino and also the seafood casserole.
author: David T.

description:
Wanted to love this place based on the recommendations and history and the cuisine served. I've been twice, once for dinner and once for lunch. Didn't have to wait more than 5mins for a table because we came at the right times. 

Decor/atmosphere - nice and old school yet good for business and date-night alike.

Service - they seem to be cool and unattached, for lack of a better description, at least my servers both times. They come once a while to see what you need, drop off the food, and off they go without a word. Barely a smile, but not rude nor rushed. 

Food - ciopino is worth trying at $33. The seafood platter for 2 wasn't really worth imho - just wasn't too tasty with the varieties. The shrimp salad was good and filling, plenty of shrimp and the dressing was nice. The grilled fish is good, the sides of rice and veggie was lacking in taste. Clam chowder is decent, pretty standard.
author: Lisa Z.

description: We wanted a light dinner so we went to the Tadich Grill. We got there early and sat at the bar. We both ordered clam chowder (Boston and Cony Island), and mixed green salads. For dessert, we shared the apple tort. It was all very good, but at $10, the tort was overpriced. Also, the waiter (?) at the bar lacked personality. So...I give it 3 1/2 stars overall.
author: Joanne K.

description: Oldest restaurant in California and I can see why it's outlasted the competition. The service was impeccable and the seafood fabulous. My husband had the cioppino and says it's the best he's ever had. I had a dish described as baked shrimp diablo with rice and avocado. I was so impressed that it was mostly shrimp, just enough rice to sop up the delicious sauce, and half an avocado. Yummy!  They don't take reservations and they are always busy. We went at 5:30 and juuuust beat the crowd. Every table was full even then, but we didn't have to wait. By the time we left there was quite a crowd waiting 30 minutes or more to be seated, and this was mid-week. So, go early!  But if you like seafood, definitely go!  Oh, and decent wine list and good desserts, too.
author: M W.

description: As always the fish is spectacular! Had the halibut Florentine and the famous pan fried petrole sole. So flakey and tender.
author: Tim J.

description:
First of all, I've been coming here for over 40 years. 

I brought my millennial daughter here for a taste of Old School San Francisco, and to show her the cool places I haunted as a young man. 

At about 430p on a weekday we were seated at a 4 top, as all the tables were empty. Before the appetizers came, my daughter got a text saying her boyfriend  was in the area. We told him to stop by. He did. He sat down. The waiter came over, and took our additional order and delivered martinis. The Manager, Mr. David Hanna storms over to our table, and says it's against Tadich rules to add guests after the service had started. We stated it hadn't started, as our food had not been delivered, just drinks. Not good enough. Keep in mind the place is empty. Mr. Hanna's loud, rude and abusive language created an embarrassing scene. Other diners were now paying attention. We were embarrassed, too, got up, and proceeded to leave. He said we had to pay for the food that had not arrived. We protested, and paid under duress. And left. Suggest ancient management of this place replace rude and abusive staff, and learn to treasure loyal customers with respect and deference.
author: James T.

description: I enjoy coming here regularly.  The Calamari steak is my favorite.  The service is always good and they keep their waitstaff for years.  I remember seeing the same waitstaff from 10 years ago.  I also prefer sitting in the booths as they provide a more intimate dining experience.
author: K B.

description: Really a mixed review.  1st time at this establishment.  Went here for lunch and sat at the counter.  My server was really good and gave me a few recommendations, however the sole was not tasty and the price was ridiculous!!! More like Denny's quality fish...definitely farmed...many better restaurants in the area to try.
author: Gregg B.

description:
Charles our waiter was excellent! Great service ,
Great food! We had the Caesar 's salad, clam's w garlic butter, and the crab cakes!!!! Can't wait to come back again!
author: Kanoe R.

description: Definition of old school and it always delivers.  Great clam chowder.  Excellent cioppino.  Quite frankly I've never had a bad lunch here and been going for 22 years.  Customer service is consistently good.
author: Bryan V.

description:
This is the place to go to experience old San Francisco. It is like stepping back in time where customer service is excellent and everyone knows your name. Went for an early dinner and had the calamari steak. As I'm not used to detailed seafood, it took me awhile to order. A lot of food and delicious.

The restaurant is expensive, but it is great every once in awhile. It isn't fancy, but comfy.
author: Janice O.

description:
I am trying to go through the 100 big eats of SF (7x7 list) and could have easily come here and to Barbacco because they are right across from my office but hadn't until now because the $$$$ signs scared me. I finally came though and the food was WELL worth it. The seafood cioppino which was on the list was so delicious!! We also got the  croque madame, Which I am going to suggest should be on the list next year.
Only suggestion is be prepared for a lot of stinky burps after the cioppino. :/
author: Julianna I.

description:
Wanted oysters tonight and missed Hog Islands 9pm close time so this was a nice plan B. A half dozen Samish oysters on the half shell hit the spot (5 star), coupled with a bowl of Boston Clam chowder (4 star) and Sapphire gin martini (3 star, a bit on the bitter side, I judge this staple martini by smoothnessa). Open till 930pm and got a last order in so good. Popular as judged by a nice noisy crowd even at this last hour.
Easy to find (large neon sign you can see from two blocks away). Sat at the counter for fast late service. Server was fine and staff attentive.
Will not hesitate to come back for more seafood.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
5 stars for service (old jolly guys who are great at what they do), 4 for value (the entrees are $20 dollars less than at most surf and turf places). Classic yet casual steakhouse atmosphere. The food is mediocre--the new York strip was passable although oversalted. The branzino was good. The halibut was also good. The giant potato wedges that come with everything were like something from 7/11. We took to dipping most things in the lemon butter sauce so they'd have more flavor. 

Worth a visit, probably not worth a return one until you're feeling very nostalgic.
author: jones z.

description: come here for the seafood cioppino and the jovial service, it's amazing.  don't miss out on the oysters rockefeller either!  tadich platter is definitely only good for two as an app, and the dungeness crabs weren't worth the price. But the cioppino itself makes this place worth the visit!
author: Jennifer C.

description: I hate to give Tadich Grill a rating of only three stars:  one star for the ambience and one star for top-notch professional service, and a third star for their clam chowder served with sourdough bread.  No stars for the Caesar salad, which is just so-so, and no stars for the pan-fried sand dabs, which might have arrived frozen to their back door. The sand dabs, which at one time were a one-of-a-kind must-have fish entree, fell completely apart on my plate in an unappetizing mess.
author: Jack H.

description:
I ate here ~15 years ago and remember seeing the infamous Brown sisters. I also recollect that my food tasted a bit better. The halibut cheese casserole I had was generous in the portion of fish but lacked much in the way of flavor. 
Our waiter was not especially friendly, but that may be part of the experience...
author: Mark E.

description: Would be very nice if they displayed the fact that they don't take reservations on the website, instead of having you call, then being rude to you. If you suspect San Francisco might be a hick town, this experience should confirm it. Jerks.
author: Max D.

description:
A San Francisco classic.

This place may have the highest number of "regulars" among all the restaurants in the city. I have never seen anything like it in San Francisco. Waiters knew almost all the people who came to sit at the bar except for me. Have to say that the average age inside is pretty high. Both the waiters and the customers seem to be here for years. 

I have had salmon and lobster caserole as well as the clam chowder and they were both delicious. Of course, you are paying $$$ for it.
author: Gokhan T.

description: First time...went for lunch. Boston clam chowder was very good! We had the seafood sampler...delicious! Bloody Mary was weak, not much flavor in a small glass & only one olive! Staff friendly and you can watch the cooks if you sit closer to the kitchen. Was within walking distance of our hotel. It's Christmas eve & their not open tomorrow..or Wed go back for dinner.
author: Barbara F.

description: Really fun atmosphere.  A San Fran classic that did not disappoint.  Bar tenders were a lot of fun and the appetizers were solid. Crab cake was especially noteworthy. Wish the entire bar had access to the full menu, but overall a great experience.
author: Anthony J.

description:
The Tadich Grill
went there April 4 for my birthday, it was delicious I had the prawns,crab,scallops dish in a butter wine sauce, it was scrumpscious.
author: Liz C.

description:
Dine: This place has been here for years and it was my first time with my BF.  

Atmosphere: I thought since they don't take reservations, we would have waited forever to get seats on a Monday night.  We got lucky and got seats right away.  It was a small restaurant, but nice setting.  They don't take reservations, so come prepared to wait if you're not lucky. 

Food: I ordered the Seafood Cioppino and it was great! It was rich in flavor and made to perfection.  I forgot what my BF ordered, but he cleaned his plate pretty fast, so I presume it was just right.  We'll be back, hopefully soon!
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I have to admit that I probably wouldn't have considered dining at Tadich Grill if I hadn't seen Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations.  And of course, bring the copycat I am, I got intrigued by what he had for the lunch, The Hangtown Fry.

Well it took a while, but I finally got to try the Hangtown Fry!  In all its fried oyster and bacon omelette glory.
http://bit.ly/15pYkWH
I must say, this is definitely hangover food!  The oysters and bacon are just wrong on so many levels which is what makes it so good!  I can't say much about the side of fat fries though.  They were really just there for added starch but they weren't much to brag about.

I know this place is supposed to the one of, or if so, the oldest restaurant in SF and you can see it with the old school decor.  It gives the place some charm actually.

Would I come back again?  Not anytime soon, but I know that if I have a mad craving for a good Hangtown Fry, I know where to get it since not many places around SF make it as good as Tadich.
author: Rodney H.

description:
One of the oldest restaurants in the city. Walking in, I can imagine, is very similar how it used to be. The bar is long so there should be seats avaialable. I sat down somewhere in the middle of the bar between two couples. 

I ordered a pinot grigio to start with to go with my cioppino, which if you don't know what it is, it's a tomato based stew with a ton of seafood. Tadich Grill's has clams, mussels, scallops, many different types of fish, and some shrimp. They gave bread with the dish, but they really should give a lot more. I like sopping up the stew part of it with the bread. I did have some leftovers - probably about a third of the left and having it two days later, it was still super delicious. 

Protip: Get the cioppino, it's pretty good. The service was spotty at best, and they were very loud and distracting.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Beware of the BOLD waiter!

The BOLD waiter spoiled for us.... We looked forward to this culinary experience to visit a staple in San Francisco, a place highly recommended by our attorney friends and all went down the drain due to our BOLD waiter...

Our visit was on Saturday 3/11/2017 and we were pleasantly surprised to get seated shortly upon arrival. We were greeted by a very welcoming gentleman who seemed to be one of the bartenders. Our table was on the left side, walking in, next to the kitchen. The pleasant flavors from the kitchen were unbelievable. Our arrogant and unpleasant waiter was a BOLD gentleman that went out of his way to cause the unpleasant experience. The water arrived to our table after asking four times for it. He did NOT recommend any items, offered NO specials of the day nor showed any respect to us. Took only 10 seconds all together to take our order during which time he yelled at someone across the restaurant and disappeared as we were telling him what we wanted, and reappeared from another side to continue and finish his 10 second order taking. 

Food was good and if this BOLD waiter would have had a different attitude, we could have even enjoy it. He avoided our table during the course of our stay with the exception when he dumped the food to us four, of course at different times, and the bill. In order to ask him anything, we had to extend our hand to stop him... ahhh, the BOLD waiter.

We will try again this place in hopes that we'll be able to taste the food without the BOLD ingredient. I left in this review clear directions on what to avoid so that I do not get sidetracked on commenting on the least important part of the restaurant and talk about the dishes that a person should visit a restaurant for.

...BOLD waiter
author: Allen B.

description:
Date night!!

Came around 5:30 so we wouldn't have to wait to get in!

Sat by bar first to order drinks before getting seated. BF ordered whisky sour - and was dissapointed... Drink was made with syrup and mediocre whisky. 
Was not the traditional, classic drink you'd expect.

Then Food came . . .

Cioppino my heart!! God, that big beautiful seafood bowl looked good, and tasted even better. It was chocked full of fresh seafood, that was actually really filling. Loved that it had actual crab!

I ordered the salad... Wanting to be healthy:( But I shoulda really gotten the cioppino! Salad was good, fresh and hefty portioned, but little bland. Too many salty bay shrimps!!

However service was fast (but not friendliest), and environment was nice and casual.

I'd come back for you again cioppino! Next time you're mine!
author: Jean K.

description:
You may not believe this, but I've never been to Tadich Grill before (photo: http://bit.ly/13zCyNa). I guess I've never been all that motivated, especially since they don't accept reservations, and frankly none of my friends and colleagues ever mention it as a place they've ever wanted to try. I remember there were work lunches and dinners scheduled there over the years, but for one reason or another, I bagged it or suggested some other place that was higher on my wish list. But last week, I decided I should give it a try since it was in the middle of the afternoon well after the lunch rush. I was in meeting hell at work until about 2:30PM and decided I needed to get out of the building.

I was sincerely thinking of getting a sandwich at Andersen Bakery across California when it struck me that Tadich would likely be empty at that hour. I was right. Except for a couple of lady barflies near the entrance, there was nary a diner at what turned out to be the full dining counter that dominates the long space. You could almost smell the long history in the place filled as it is with rich dark woods, faded mustard walls, and a brass railing that separates the bar from the dining counter (photo: http://bit.ly/1emSaVF). There were quite a few waiters flitting about all looking like old-school veterans uniformed in ties and white linen jackets. The highly traditional menu is dominated by seafood, but you can get meats prepared on their charcoal broiler if you are feeling more carnivorous.

I heard their $31.25 Seafood Cioppino with Garlic Bread is their house specialty as well as their $23.95 Pan-Fried Sand Dabs with Steak Fries. Neither appealed to me at that hour since they struck me as filling and probably a bit messy. I was drawn to the $30.95 Poached Wild King Salmon Filet with Chopped Egg Sauce because it sounded like it could be a comparatively healthier dish (photo: http://bit.ly/16WzPvz). Not really. The thick egg sauce was ladled quite liberally on the salmon which I have to admit was a hearty portion and quite fresh-tasting. It came with boiled potatoes and a bevy of steamed vegetables - broccoli and cauliflower florets, baby carrots and diced tomatoes. It was nothing too excited but certainly good enough for an undiscriminating palate.

Understand this was on top of a large hunk of sourdough bread and a constant replenishment of frozen butter pats (photo: http://bit.ly/16o29XN). However, this didn't deter me from ordering the $6.95 dish of Tadich Rice Custard Pudding (photo: http://bit.ly/13zCn4l). This was a rather disappointing wedge of blandness with the right consistency but lacking any distinctive flavor even with a spritz of whipped cream on the side. I have to say my virginal visit to the city's oldest restaurant was not an earth-shattering culinary experience, but somehow I knew that would be the case. Unlike Swan Oyster Depot, which turned out to be a true revelation, this one I can simply check off been-there-done-that my list.

FOOD - 3 stars...big portions but prices are on the absurd side and while quality is good, execution is downright boring
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...as old school as old school can be
SERVICE - 4 stars...definitely attentive from waiters who live up to their own standard
TOTAL - 3 stars...if you need a traditional SF seafood dining experience, then hop on the California Street cable car and go to Swan Oyster Depot...leave Tadich Grill to the Fodors-dependent foreign tourists
author: Ed U.

description:
I wanted to hate Tadich Grill. 

1) SF institution = boring, uninspiring dishes. 
2) Tourist trap. Fanny pack time!
3) Overpriced food. Lettuce and avocado for $9?!?!
4) Rude waiters. 
5) No reservations. An hour wait on a Tuesday night?!

But looking at the cougar with fake tits that doubled as her chin rest while waiting for our table was surely entertaining. 

As the oldest restaurant in SF, Tadich Grill caters to tourists and nearby FiDi business peeps. Most SFers know better than to go to tourist traps like this and/or to the pier for seafood but sometimes curiousity kills. Some people (Iike moi) wanted to know how Tadich Grill has survived for so long. Short answer: Tourists. Duh. 

The menu is overwhelming and prices are not posted on their online menu; I'm guessing to not deter people. Entree prices ranged from $19.95 to $49.95 with most in the high $20s to mid $30s. Not too bad and expected given the area. See my menu pics for prices. 

Finding metered street parking is easy before 6 pm; both weekdays and weekends. Most are yellow meters though so don't leave your car till 6 pm. Valet is $10. 

Aside from all the preconceived notions, I kind of enjoyed dinner at Tadich Grill (this would have been a 3.5 star review had the mishap didn't occur). Some of the food was good but not great and definitely overrated. 

Jose, our awesome busboy made up for our rude waiter who gave us "the hand" when trying to flag him down to order. Oh no he di'int! Yes, he did! Rudeness seems to be one of the qualifications to be a waiter here so beware. 

Like Steve Urkel, I had cheese on my mind when I suggested the Oysters Rockerfeller (6 pieces -$20.95) for our shared appetizer: http://bit.ly/1bhNrIz. I was salivating upon the arrival of the bubbling platter. The ooooey gooey spinach cheese concoction was ridiculously good but the oysters were so tiny it was like trying to find a needle in the haystack. 

We also shared a salad but don't bother ordering one as they're a very poor value. Our boring Shrimp Louie Salad ($24.95) reminded me of Garden Club's which is a favorite of the AARP community: http://bit.ly/15Jp8fD.

With all the mixed reviews, I decided to play it safe and order their signature dish: The Cioppino ($31.25):  http://bit.ly/15JpjHK. Tadich Grill claims to have the best one..."anywhere". That may have been true a century ago but today as the city with the most restaurants per a capita, I can name a handful of restaurants in SF that make a better cioppino (Anchor Oyster Bar and Sotto Mare are my top two favs). Don't get me wrong, it was good but certainly not worth the wait. 

Served steaming hot (I burned my tongue), the Cioppino had an array of prawns, clams, mussels, crab meat and white fish. The fish and crab were perfectly cooked but the prawns were dry and the clams had sand in it. Dunking the hot, crusty buttery garlic bread into the herbaceous tomato broth was the best part of my meal. 

However, what I found odd were the mussels. Most were closed:  http://bit.ly/1bhOtEo. But I figured, hey, these guys have been doing this for over 160 years so the chef would have tossed them if they weren't good right? So I pried one open and ate it. Stupid me...

BAD. BAD. BAD IDEA. 

Two hours later, I was pissing out of my ass. I woke up at 5 am and continued to piss out of my ass. 

Tadich Grill, I officially hate you and so does my ass.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Freedom!  We are out without the kids for the first time in 5 long days of a 26 day road trip.  I don't know how we are going to make it the remaining 21 days, but having a night out at Tadich has given us hope that we are gonna make it.  The atmosphere although loud, was so energetic and relaxing at the same time you couldn't help but feel 15 years younger.  Classic drinks without umbrellas or awkwardly shaped glassware was like finding a small bit of sanity in this backwards world.  The food comes out fast despite the constant flow of people pouring in.  If the sourdough bread they bring to your table before ordering isn't any indication that you are in for an amazing meal then order the Oyster Rockefeller and you'll realize these people have mastered the art of true hospitality.
author: Jon F.

description: Ok, real talk, the food didn't necessarily blow me away, but everything about the experience was lovely and perfect from start to finish. The wait staff was so friendly. The Best Sidecar Ever was actually the best Sidecar I've ever had. Strong, but not like lighter fluid. Our waiter (didn't catch his name, but he had great glasses on) was the sweetest. And the food was filling, tasty, and well priced for the amount you get. I got the seafood saute with butter and wine and mushrooms. So rich and fabulous. My dude got the snapper which was simple and fresh and delicious too. The crispy potatoes and tarter sauce it came with were delightful. The ambiance is also unbeatable, it's very much like Buena Vista in that you can feel the history. I loved it and will definitely come back soon, and bring out of town visitors.
author: Christa C.

description:
From 5 stars to 1. Wow - the definition of rude. Went here with a friend. Arrived at 6. Ordered a meal and drinks. Spent more than 100 bucks for the two of us. Asked to leave at 7:15 because they needed to turn over the table. They did this mid-conversation. No warning. No offer of a free drink. Dinner was decent, but this is unacceptable.

Called the manager, who listened to what happened and didn't even ask for my name. Very dismissive. This place is truly for the birds.
author: Andrew K.

description: One of my new favorite restaurants in SF! Amazing seafood pasta and great martinis! Beautiful restaurant and definitely a great place for a fancier date.  Will go back soon!
author: Shiloh B.

description:
Abysmal terrible uninspiring food. Restaurant is ancient and so is the food and the plating. 

Seafood plate tasted like something out of Safeway ready foods fridges on top of not even remotely fresh lettuce and tomatoes. Terrible. 

Steaks were dry as fu** lousy quality meat. Except for this place looking like a museum don't expect anything especially not enjoying the food. We were a party of 4 and everybody felt the same. Never again.
author: Ido K.

description: Outstanding old school Cali restaurant.  Waiters in white coats type of place.  Seating at the bar is first come first served but expect a wait.  The Dungenous Crab Cake may have been one of my favorite crab cakes I've ever had.  Ordered a ribeye for my entree, which was also very flavorful and delicious.  Came with some veggies and potatoes that were somewhere in between a French fry and a baked potato.  So very tasty!   Dont overlook this place if you want a great dinner in San Fran!
author: Nate G.

description: Stopped in for a quick drink and appetizer.  It was about 430 pm on a Thursday.  I sat at the Bar. The service was very poor...not attentive and very slow. The calamari was overly breaded and tough....very disappointing.  I would recommend you don't order it.  I was thinking of having something else but decided against it after the experience that turned me off a bit. Very quaint ambiance and the bread was good.  That is the best I can do for my positive comment.
author: Steve Y.

description:
I finally got to eat here on May 25th for my wedding annivesary.

Let's keep it simple.  I love it!  

The food was awesome, portions were large and the Moscow mule was wonderful, and I don't like mule.  We ordered the appetizer seafood platter, which was so much food.  They did not skimp on the seafood.  We appreciated that they put in a good portion of lettuce which made the platter more like a seafood salad, yummy.  That alone is more than enough food, but since it was our anniversary we ordered more food.  I had the specialty cioppino.  It was the bomb!  The husband had the white branzino sea bass, grilled whole with potatoes and veggies.  Two thumbs up from the husband.  We did not have any more room for desserts.

I hope I don't wait for another anniversary before I get to eat here again.
author: Maria R.

description: Incredible! Had lunch here. Drinks were great. Best oysters Rockefeller I've ever had. NE clam chowder was delicious. I had the grilled crab cakes. So fresh and delicious. Consistency of the crab meat was soft and full of meat. The sauce with the vegetables was incredible. My wife had the seared ahi tuna salad and chicken noodle soup. A must in the city.
author: J S.

description: Amazing customer service. Very quick & very friendly ladies served me today & they packaged my items & answered every question I had. Very great experience, I'll definitely be returning.
author: I007naruto ..

description:
Put down the menu!! No need to read it. Just order the Seafood Cioppino. You'll be glad you did and you'll still be talking about it days later. You're welcome. 

One of the best meals in recent memory. Will definitely be back when we return to San Francisco.
author: Renee W.

description: This place has a cool old world feel to it. The food was just mediocre. Had a steak that was a nice size and cooked well but also very salty and the fries and veggies with it were just ok. I'd come back again because of the environment but would try a different dish next time around.
author: Steven G.

description:
While my own order of the cioppino was fairly good as promised (though I have never tried cioppino elsewhere to compare it to), the garlic bread was burnt and my mother's order of fried shrimp was plain and lackluster, completely unseasoned. 
My biggest complaint about this restaurant, however, was the service. When we arrived, people were waiting in a crowd at the front of the restaurant. The host yelled unceremoniously and somewhat impatiently for parties to follow him when a table was available. The atmosphere was so-so, though I understand that it is a crowded and old-school restaurant. Once seated, our waiter was quite snarky and rude. The most horrifying moment of my night was when the waiter insisted on grabbing a bib out of my hand and tying it around my neck without so much as a "May I?". First of all, I am a grown adult and the concept that a stranger can decide for me that I might need a bib to eat my food is insulting. Second of all, he showed a complete disregard for personal space or social cues. He also spoke to me in a rather condescending manner (though I'm sure it was supposed to be "charming", I did not perceive it to be at all whatsoever). We also witnessed him being attention-seeking and rude with other customers. The food was overpriced, the service was uncomfortable, and we are sorry we wasted our time here.
author: Sarah C.

description: This place is a must whenever my parents visit! They have excellent Seafood Cioppino and martinis.
