It's hard to say if the Cioppino is better than Sotto Mare in North Beach, but I know for sure you won't be disappointed with Tadich Grill's version. Their Cioppino is rich in flavor with a nice balance of tomato and spice. There's a LOT of seafood in the dish. There were two mussels, four clams, four shrimp, scallops, baby shrimps, and crab meat. On they side they serve garlic bread, which is great to dip into the Cioppino. The scallops and the Petrale Sole Filet entrees were flavorful too, but the textures weren't on point this time. The sear on the Petrale Sole was well-done on one side, but missing on the other and then the scallops were a bit rubbery from being overcooked. Other than the textures, it was tasty. We ordered the fried calamari appetizer to share and it was just okay. The calamari was tender and not chewy and it came with standard dipping sauces of tartar sauce and cocktail sauce. The ambiance is classy, yet casual. The servers, hosts, and bartenders all wear long white coats and each and every one of them is friendly!
author: Aimee I.

description: Service. Food. History. Character. Vibrant. Nuff said.  An awesome way to spend an evening.
author: Steve B.

description: I really liked Tadisch Grill. We were seated immediately, received great service from Ken, the restaurant has a lively feel and the food was delicious. There's honestly not much more to say on this one.
author: Tamara J.

description:
I had been itching to try the "oldest restaurant in California" for quite some time, but I found the entire experience to be sorely disappointing.

First off, the bread was cold and hard. Already off to a bad start.

Second, I am an artichoke lover, but the artichoke that people rave about on Yelp was so bland that I actually chose not to finish it. They give you melted butter for it, but then it just became a butter dish with a side of artichoke.

Third, and most offensive, I asked for a vegetarian dish since there was nothing listed on the menu. The waiter said the chef could whip me up some pasta with marinara sauce, so I took it without questioning the cost. The pasta itself was overcooked, but I'm willing to forgive that because this really isn't their specialty. However, the horrendous part of this was that when the bill came, this pasta with marinara sauce cost $30. THIRTY DOLLARS. My friend's oyster omelette plate cost less!

Lastly, we ordered the bread pudding as a last attempt at salvaging our dinner. When the bread pudding arrived, it seemed promising. It was decent, until we got to the middle and it was still ice cold. Fantastic.

I'm sure their seafood is excellent, but I wound up leaving Tadich Grill wondering if they survive solely on the basis of marketing themselves as historical.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Always wanted to try out this SF institution after seeing it on Anthony Bourdain's show and passing by it for several years.  Tadich Grill is an SF institution and I must say it's actually quite larger inside than I thought.  They don't take reservations, but my co-worker and I were lucky the other week when we dropped in we were able to get a table on a Wednesday around 1:30.  Though it was towards the end of the lunch rush, many tables were still occupied.  

Their menu is very extensive.  Though they are known for the cioppino, I have a sometimes like hate relationship with clams, and it just sounded a little messy.  I was torn between a crab and prawns casserole, a crab, scallop and prawns dish or the crab cakes.  So, I asked the waiter his suggestion and he suggested the crab cakes and so I did.  Bread came out shortly before our dishes came out.  The crab cakes were huge and served with some sauce with capers and alongside some rice pilaf and steamed veggies.  I wish the menu actually provided descriptions with the dishes!  The sauce was fine, but I felt like perhaps should have been to the side, it didn't take away from the dish, but only added a little bit of creamy/tartness to the crab cakes.  Though the crab cakes were huge, they had some fillers such as breadcrumbs and shrimps in there.  It was still satisfying, but not one of the best I've had, especially for over $30 for the plate.  Rice pilaf was good but standard, same with the veggies.  My coworker always gets some sort of salmon plate and so she did.  She enjoyed it.  

I can definitely knock off Tadich Grill on my SF dining bucket list.  Perhaps I ordered the wrong thing, though again, the crab cakes were fine, but I expected more for the money and more due to the hype.  Would I go back?  Perhaps to take anyone else who wants to try them out for a seafood fix and experience a bit of SF culture.  Service was attentive enough but not really too friendly (just got the job done).
author: Cat C.

description: I am a fan. However, when I have spent $300 for four people to eat lunch I dont need some surley AA flunkee in a white smock stink-eyeing my party because he wants the table. I never mind the short conversation of the servers, its part of the schtick. But dont be offensive about it. Its a basic seafood restaurant, dont ruin the cache
author: Karen M.

description: Arrived at 9:32. The restaurant would not let us in. They have strict rules about closing at 9:30. When we asked if an exception can be made for two minutes, the bartender was not very nice and very arrogant about telling us that the rules were strict and absolutely not we could not break the rules. I have eaten here many times and never had this very bad experience.
author: Michelle B.

description: The old style of this restaurant (which doesn't look like much from the street) is truly reminiscent of old San Fran.  Whether you choose to sit in their old style wooden, private booths or take a seat at their long bar, the experience is great.  The wait staff is nothing but professional and prompt.  The menu can be a bit overwhelming (there is so much on it) and seem like a diner menu, but the food is top notch!  A must stop when in San Fran!
author: Colleen R.

description:
I am a fan!  This was the best Cioppino I ever ate!  Our concierge recommend this place to us.  I am so happy she did.  We had a early dinner and was walking past Tadich Grill before we left.  I just had to try the Cioppino so I ventured in. 

The Cioppino was so fresh.  The fish, crab, clams, mussels, and shrimp tasted like it was harvested from the ocean moments before they cooked it.  The broth wasn't overly thick and the flavor was outstanding!  

They take no reservations so you got to go early.  But the wait is definitely worth it, especially if you want to eat the best Cioppino in SF!
author: Dwayne Y.

description:
This place has been around for some time for a reason. It's good. The cioppino was delicious and so was the Chilean sea bass. Not one thing we had here was bad. They had a wait but got us in at a reasonable time with no reservation. The mixed cocktails are done with care and bread pudding was fantastic.

A staple of San Francisco, definitely worth the stop.
author: Alan B.

description:
So I am a bit harsh when it comes to dining out so I must remain on scale :)

This place is a staple, I get it - in regards staple status - it is a 4.0 BUT for SF restaurant status it is a lower on my bar - aka- I probably won't be back.

The service was great. It was a bit slow but our server was really nice and helpful. For some reason, this place made me feel a tiny bit uncomfortable. They probably don't have a lot of black patrons but it is the kind of old school place that can make a brown woman feel like she's in the 60s (or what my parents told me about it) for some reason - maybe just me? I don't expect most to relate to this but lets just say everyone in the restaurant is staring at you wondering how you found out about the place lol

Anyway, I hate cold bread at restaurants so this was a bummer. The butter was good though. I really hate refrigerated butter and theirs was room temperature. They have a pile of lemons on each table and my fiancee and I weren't sure why? Seems a bit unsanitary to have everyone breathe on the same lemons all day :) I'm not picky so, I dropped one in my water! 

My fiancee and I shared the clam chowder and it was perfect. Salty and clammy and good. 

Then my fiancee ordered some fish dish with mushroom sauce. It was good. I had a crab cake and a side of hashbrowns. I LOVE hash browns but theirs lacked seasoning. No salt no pepper - nothing. The crab cake was ok but I found the outer crust to be rubbery. Also with the flavor of the cake - combating the cream they added on top - combating the sauce on the bottom - it was too much. I ended up mixing the cake and hashbrown together and that was very smart!

For dessert, I ordered bread pudding but they don't have ice cream so I took it to go. I had ice cream at home. That was pretty good but I've had better.

All in All it was ok but not good enough to come back unless I want hashbrowns for dinner that  I'll end up seasoning myself.
author: Jazmyn W.

description: Fun place to visit. Old school. The abalone was delicious, tender. The liver was a too strong and the portion too large. Next time I can't wait to try the oysters Rockefeller and the halibut. Nice waiters, good drinks, non pretentious.
author: Tammy N.

description:
OMG. As if I walked into 1973. Very stale, stuck-up feel and look. The wait staff is old (nothing against the old folks, but just to paint the picture) and our water was totally disinterested. Treated us as if we were kids who wouldn't be able to pay. We waited about 15 minutes to order because he had to finish his conversation w the guy at the bar and we were sitting right next to the bar. so it couldn't have been a stretch to look over, take the order, and continue on...

Had calamari and two steaks. Really, nothing special. The prices are definitely NOT justified. This is San Francisco - plenty of choices all around! 

Had high hopes, but no.
author: B G.

description: There are almost 1,600 reviews for the Tadich Grill. There isn't much that I can add, except to confirm it is a classic place, and a classy joint. The waiters are famous for their service and the white jackets. Booths are cool, but eating at the bar is awesome too.  Seafood is not the cali fusion recipes of the hipster restaurants in vogue nowadays, but is more traditional recipes - charbroaled, sautee, fried, deep fried, with steak potatoes and steam veggies for example), but the seafood quality is top shelf, and the chef doesn't dry the heck out of the fish. Mean vodka martinis too!
author: Massimo M.

description: Milestone check-in accomplished. It was a very classy restaurant. Low key type of fancy I like it very much. I got the salad with blue cheese. I am not sure if it's I am hungry or its just really good. I finished my plate completely, which is rare. Also, the very place I feel I wanna go back again soon with friends.
author: Donna Z.

description:
A good place to eat if you're in the financial district.

This place feels old school from the moment you walk in. You'll find bartenders in white coats yelling out orders and directing traffic. The place is LOUD as in LOUD. There are many people hovering around the bar waiting patiently for a table and all chatting at the same time. We had to wait around 30 minutes to get a seat (very reasonable considering it's a Friday night) and we had a wonderful waiter that made excellent recommendations. Ended up ordering the Chioppino and seafood sautee. Both were excellent.

Overall, I'd give this place 5 stars if not for the noise. It's just too crowded and a tad noisy for me.
author: Tim L.

description: Great service with even better food!  Came with my family and everyone loved their meal!  The crab cakes were exceptional!
author: Chase B.

description:
I love this kind of old school restaurant. with waiters who have been there forever and where the atmosphere could be from any decade in the last 100 years It feels like an old-timey steakhouse but substitute seafood for beef.

they don't take reservations, but get there at 5pm, put your name on the list and have a drink or two at the bar. the bartenders are great. white jacketed, funny and personable. 

the menu changes every day, depending on what's fresh. cioppino is outstanding. halibut is in season so we also had that too. there are lots of salad choices too and they are hefty. 

wine list is not extensive, but okay. wine prices are pretty good.

not a place to visit every day, but definitely an institution in SF and worth the experience. I'd like to eat at the bar next time just to chill with the bartenders.
author: Bob U.

description: This by far was the best meal I had in San Francisco.  We went for lunch, and I could have gone back for dinner. It was that good!  They do not take reservations and we went expecting to wait, but immediately was seated (there were four of us).  We loved our waitress for her curt sarcasm. Many would find her rude, but we found her to be real.  I had the clams and linguini, which was very good.  The clams were fresh.  However, my friend had the best dish...the crab cakes.  Oh. My. Word. these were the best I have ever had.  I was a staunch advocate for the crab cakes from another restaurant, but I think these were hands-down better.  Fresh does not even begin to start the description.  You cannot go wrong in making this a food choice!  I will definitely return to Tadich Grill if ever in San Francisco again.
author: Lisa M.

description: Simply amazing, can't wait to go back, will be a regular stop on all future trips to SF. Crab cocktail amazing, seafood sauté and cioppino both amazing!! Everything was perfect, recommend to sit at bar if just 2 dining. Great service, cool history too.
author: Neil M.

description: Never ceases to amaze! Great wait staff. Awesome food.  If you come to SF For a historical experience, you need to come here and eat.
author: Linda B.

description: Could be better the food was not to be desired. I expected a steak that was 16 ounce and look like a 9 ounce and that the vegetables could've been steamed and much more softer than what I received.
author: Bradley B.

description: All I can say is that the waiter (I didn't catch his name) we had today was very unfriendly or should I say rude! I think he might have said 10 words to us the whole time ... after he took our order he had to come back and let us know that they were out of fish and chips and recommended another dish (about four words)we said no and he shook his head and walked off very abrupt... really bad. The food was ok nothing to write home about but maybe it was the service that just made everything seem so bad he dropped off the check he picked it up and brought back the change with a grunt .....I really wanted to like this place because of the previous reviews I had read... but no I would never go back or recommend.
author: Susan A.

description:
My friends and I stopped by here on a Monday night, he'd been raving about the Cioppino & Oysters Rockefeller for weeks.

Entering the doors was like taking a step back in time, in the center is a beautiful classic wooden bar that stretches the length of the dimly lit restaurant. An abundance of waiters dressed in white coats and long white aprons bustle around. 

There were two top tables all along the edge of these sectioned off, almost private areas reserved for 3 or more.

AFTER BEING SEATED, it took about 10mins to get the waiter's attention for some water, and another 10 to grab the attention of another waiter to take our order. With all these waiters, you'd think the service would be quick. It wasn't until we were ordering that the waiter felt he needed to rush us. 

1 Cioppino
1 Oysters Rockefeller
1 Shrimp & Avocado Diablo
1 fried seafood platter 

2 Stars for the delicious ciopinno & garlic bread that comes with it, & +1 star for the just the fried scallops from the platter.

I feel like the Oysters Rockefeller had potential. It may have been because it was the end of the night, but our oysters with covered in so much sautéed spinach that even after finding the oyster in a sea of spinach and scraping off half, all I tasted was spinach. My friend who had been raving about it for weeks, even felt the need to apologize for them and mentioned that he was no longer impressed. 

As far as the Shrimp Diablo, we were no were near impressed, it was a goopy casserole dish of bay shrimp in a thin cheese like sauce topped with avocado, not at all worth ~$30. And if you were expecting spicy, it isn't.

Lastly, we could've have done with the fried seafood platter, and just had the fried scallops. yum! 

Overall, 3 stars... Aside from the Ciopinno, everything else was Overpriced & Underwhelming.
author: Erika K.

description:
After seeing so many great reviews, I had to bring my friends here for dinner. Based on their site, they don't take reservations & your whole party needs to be there. Tidich Grill (say it 5 times fast, really try it lol) is a old school restaurant and still has that feel based on the interior & wait staff. Side note, I didn't see any woman working there, maybe there are women but who knows. 
Anyhow, even though our waiter was a little standoffish, he knew his stuff. When we would ask if he recommended X or Y, he confidently told us and it would be great. We started with the amazing smoked trout. I wish I had a bowlful for myself. The sourdough bread they bring to the table was decent. I had the sautéed scallops & yummmmm. The wine cream sauce they make is a great additional to the perfectly done scallops. The dish came with rice & veggies. My friends each had a fish and really enjoyed their meals. For dessert, we shared a chocolate pecan pie (I think) and it was decadent. Just so smooth & silky. 
The bathrooms upstairs are tidy and this place gets packed. Also, Tidich Grill is a seafood & steak kinda place, there isn't much else on the menu, but who needs anything else when you've got such amazing food :)
author: Sarika S.

description:
Tadich Grill is a living historical site and a fabulous place for great seafood.  I've been coming here for many years and it always feels like I'm stepping back in time when I walk in and see that super-long bar counter.  I can imagine the generations of workers who stopped in at Tadich for lunch over the last century taking a quick respite from their labor to fill up on Ciopinno and sourdough.

The bonus is that the seafood is fantastic here.  Tadich serves Dungeness crab 10 different ways and the cioppino is a fabulous, authentic SF staple full of scallops, mussels, bay shrimp, prawns and fish.

The wine selection is decent and corkage runs $25/bottle, which is a bit pricey but not the worst corkage fee that I've seen in the city.

If you are visiting SF, make sure to stop in at Tadich for a meal then stroll  20 minutes down to the Buena Vista for an Irish Coffee.  You'll get a glimpse of SF history and have one of the best basic meals that SF has to offer.
author: Lance W.

description: Cioppino - 'nuff said. It's a perfect piece of art that you can smell and eat. May have even been invented here. So damn good. Food and ambiance are classy, no frills and catered to people who like nice things and don't have a lot of time for hugs and kisses. If you have the cioppino and throw anything less than a 4 you are sad or not interested in food.
author: Rahul H.

description: Lively, old-school American restaurant that's definitely worth checking out with a group of friends, but probably not a place we'd go by ourselves.  The food is predictable but pretty decent.  The steak and scallops are both fine, but the cioppino is disappointingly similar to tomato soup, without all of the rich seafood taste deeply infused into the broth.  The service is ... interesting.  The waiters are attentive but weirdly curt.  It's been this way all three times I've been here, so I think it's intentional and part of the place's "personality."  So don't expect a wide smile and a friendly, welcoming environment when you come here.
author: Simon L.

description:
There are only 364 days a year that I eat better food than this. The chef-boyardee casseroles are to die for, I literally died a bit inside when I ate it. The sourdough broke my tooth, but in a good way.

The sweet smell of urinal passed by our table, reminding us of their 186 year history coinciding with the birth of the plague. The waiter kindly reminded us how lucky we were to eat there and how their spinach, made from PopEyes frozen corpse, was their specialty.

I am now on the toilet while my girlfriend holds my trembling hand, bringing us closer together than ever. Thanks Tadich for making it such a memorable experience!
author: Robby S.

description:
You already know this place is a SF institution, but you should know why. When you walk into Tadich Grill, you can already feel its pulse. The waiters/bartenders are all wearing old-school white frocks, dishes on dishes of fresh seafood are steaming out of the kitchens, and words such as, "I can take a party of 2 with no wait at the counter!" boom from behind the bar. Even when you read their paper menus, you get a feel for the rich history of this place. It is a quintessential SF experience.

For the people who say service here isn't good, I have no idea what you're talking about. The only thing I can say for sure that takes this place down a star is the price of dishes. Otherwise, the seafood is incredibly fresh, and the service is speedy. Bartenders have a huge swatch of space to cover, but they do it with incredible speed, and they're constantly checking bar and table space so that they can call out what's available. They'll make your drink as soon as you order it and plough on to the next person. This place is honestly serving some amazingly fresh seafood and heavy-handed drinks. I can't ask for more. Yeah, you're going to have to wait a while for an actual table, but bar space is pretty easily attainable if you're alone/with one other person. Be warned, if you're at the bar, you can only order salads, apps, and desserts (and of course, drinks). The actual entrees come out to tables that you'll have to wait for.
author: Danny C.

description:
Midweek 7pm -- 15 min wait to table! Score 1 for Tadiche's!
Calamari was lightly breaded but cut in thick rings; not really seasoned enough for my taste. The cocktail sauce was good,  but should that be the star of the dish?
The Boston chowda- thick and hearty, good balance between clams and potatoes (I liked it better than Neptune's Oyster in Boston ), a little too much pepper but your preference will prevail on this one. 
Where's the crackers?!
Fried oystas - nice large ocean gems but over salted and the breading tasted like it bathed in old oil (heavy and burnt) that could not be corrected with any amount of lemon and tartar sauce. 
Chilean seabass - others have commented and I can concur that it tends to be mushy in texture and the sauce congealed. 
OK - checked off my SFO "try out list"...next
author: G D.

description:
I will break my review down from service, visit, drinks, appetizers, entree and service. 

1 Star Service: Our server was Barry #165. My husband and I are pretty chill when it comes to a server being busy or taking on too many tables but this wasn't the case. Barry gave us nothing more than buffet style of serving he took our orders, tossed our spoons on the table for the clam chowder, never asked how anything was, openly admitted to other customers at the bar how he's grouchy today. I mean, I worked at Applebee's for 6 years and you learn better table-side manners/ placement etiquette than that. Even then a server has to check-out their emotions at the door to serve $2 mozzarella sticks to a bunch of drunks. 

Visit: It was our first time going to Tadich grill and we were both really exciting. We heard such great reviews of the restaurant from my father who had such fond memories of it growing up at a child. The restaurant was very clean and the aesthetics were on point. 

Food: we ordered the two "fresh" glasses of orange juice that were not fresh at all. The juice was incredibly acidic and you'll find better fresh squeezed at a Mexican burrito joint. It wasn't worth the $5 each glass. 

Appetizers: we ordered the Coney Island clam chowder. And it came out perfectly. The vegetables were finely diced and the viscosity to the broth was on point! 

Entree: Crab cake Benedict and cosmopolitan seafood salad (large) both were equally amazing. The crab cakes were a bit salty but still great.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
One star? How can it be? How about they raised many of the prices for the post-Christmas dining crowd 2 weeks ago the Abalone meal was under $30.00. Yesterday it was $36.95. the same with the crab-leg salad and the same with their Filet Mignon.

PLUS the abalone we received was old. Chewy and stringy. What a ripoff.

We've enjoyed TG for years and always had wonderful food. Never, ever a problem. Their choice to gouge holiday diners is at best, userious.

There are other grills to enjoy in SF and that's where we're going from here on out.
author: Wendell C.

description: Classic. Tadich lives up to the hype. Food, service, and ambiance were all first class. I recommend the seafood sauté. I'll be back on my next trip.
author: Andrew S.

description: To be clear, my review is not based on the food as I did not get to eat here. I went today for the first time, taking a friend out for his 65th birthday. It was almost 3pm but the place was packed and very chaotic. Nobody was up front and I was not addressed for a couple of minutes. Finally someone came and barked "how many in your party?" I asked "how long is the wait for 2?" and he replied "not long" and took my name and told us to stand in the back until our name was called. The counter was filled but the back we empty. When we got to the back, there was a sign that said "counter closed past this sign" but we were just waiting. An older gentlemen came forward and yelled at us that the counter was closed. We informed him that the guy in front sent us back here to wait for our name to be called and he yelled "well the guy in front is WRONG!!" So we walked out. I didn't come here to get yelled at. I won't be back.
author: Sam R.

description: The avocado crab Diablo has an overpowering mustard sauce. It needed a hotdog then I would have been set! You are probably best ordering seafood without any sauces or baked in casseroles here, so that was my mistake. Our waiter wasn't rude or anything, but not exactly a beacon of the service industry. I've never seen anyone dump leftover butter from one plate to another before, that was cool. I think older customers got a little better service.  No wait on a Monday. Ambience 5 stars, service 3, food flavor 3, overall experience/likelihood of me returning 1-2.
author: Morgan J.

description: A must for anyone visiting, for that matter locals as well! We enjoyed the crab cakes and Chilean Sea Bass for lunch; prepared as needed unspoiled by needless spices and delivered by experienced staff in an elegant environment! A must experience!
author: Tim L.

description: This is a classic San Francisco dining experience.  If you're looking for luxe, this ain't your place. While the menu is pretty extensive (there is something for everyone), TG is known first and foremost for their seafood.  The food is simply, but deliciously, prepared.  The drinks are strong and straightforward.  I had the prawn and crab la manza bake (very good); my guest had the seafood sauté; we were both happy and full when we left.
author: Donna G.

description: I have been to Tadish's Grill over a dozen times  as I have lived in the bay area &  we frequented this SF institution when ever possible. For out of towners who want to experience SF old style seafood restaurant without the touristy food & crowd that you get at Fisherman's Warf, I would highly recommend this place. I usually get the Sea Food Saute - especially if crab is in season.
author: Dan R.

description: Always a great time at Tadich Grill :) Excellent service and fresh seafood! I can't believe this is the oldest restaurant in California!
author: Emily L.

description:
Oh the old school glamour + Croatian charms! 

Like they say, old is gold. Old really is gold. I love all things with history, stories and a little age behind it. And this place? A good 165 years of history!! Now that might be the oldest restaurant I've been to in the States. Overseas however is a different story. But California? That's just rare in my opinion.

My super cool, super talented Croatian best friend brought me here. She also took me to the amazing Croatian winery in Napa which I happens to still love so when she suggested this place, I didn't think twice :) I visit San Francisco often. Like 3-4 times a year often. Add a few more if there's work related trips. I'm bummed I've never came across this place. I usually stay in Union Square or Financial District area and this place is literally a walking distant from my hotel! Can we say score? yes. Lets!

The space was beautiful! We had a late reservation and still had to wait a little because the place was packed on a Friday night. No worries. We waited as we check out all the dishes passed by. Hmmmm!

And viola! We got our seats and we had a feast. it was amazing, it was tasty! It was warm, cozy and oh so tasty. The end!! 

Ok ok I kid.

Food- 

Oyster rockerfeller - yummm!

Cioppino : it isn't cheap but it is worth every penny. As a shellfish obsessed person, this was on point. It had halibut, clams, prawns! Even crab I believe. I love the broth too. So tasty. There's nothing old about this dish.

Sand Dabs! I love this fish. I think it's my San Francisco thing. I eat a lot of sand dabs here. Like a good whole lot. This one was pretty good as well.

We also had seafood sautee dish with rice! It was a little heavy for me. And the portions are ginormous!!! Like major- 5 times more than I can eat big. I prefer tiny portions. But its not bad if you are sharing with someone.

It was a very filling, tasty and delicious dinner. The place feel like a steak house but with that history and charms. All the servers/staffs are in white lab coats :) They were all older gentlemen and were very pleasant to us! Thanks gents!! We sat by the window, ate, sip and closed this place down. I mean! There's nothing outdated about this place. Great food, great service! You still got it @165 years , Tadich! Now let me see if I can time travel back to when it first opened.! Hmmmm!
author: Latifa S.

description:
Wow, the fried shrimp platter was the bomb! Not cheap at over $30 though. Great service at lunchtime at the bar and a seat was available almost immediately around 1:45.

Came back a few days later and once again had great service. This time I had the sand dabs. They were filleted already, which was a bonus. And there was like 6 fillets. Nice!
author: Tommy G.

description: Classic restaurant. Foood was so amazing, the ciopino was so fresh. David our waiter was classy. It is a treat for sure. Keep in mind no reservation. We came after 8:30 and had a small wait. The price point is $20 to 50 very dinner.
author: Jason B.

description:
Really
Awful
Chowder
I
Stand by my statements
This place should be avoided
Sam's Grill is better
author: Matt H.

description:
It was our first time in San Francisco and this was a restaurant that was recommended to us from a friend who used to live in the city. When we were talking about it amongst each other on the way back from our Alcatraz tour, someone nearby overheard and said, "yes you have to definitely go there" 

When we arrived at the restaurant, we knew right away this place was special. The ambience was so traditional and felt like home. We arrived at 5pm for an early dinner and got seated right away but noticed shortly after the restaurant got extremely full and busy with a much longer wait. Also, every single person in the party has to be present if not they will not sit you as the demand and line get long. 

I ordered the clam chowder to start and it was delicious! We ordered a side of garlic bread and shrimp cocktail to share. Very good as well! 
For my meal, I ordered a seafood plate but I can't remember the name of it. My apologies! But it was very good! My friends ordered the NY strip and the rib eye and she devoured it. I tried a little piece and it was perfect! 

For dessert we shared the bread pudding! Delicious as well! 

The best part of our entire meal was the amazing service we received. Our waiter was witty and funny and very good at his job! Loved him! 

Definitely a must visit restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Millie A.

description:
I was blown away by the Tadich Grill. My dad and grandpa have been going here for years and I've been wanting to try it. It's a very old school seafood place with a great atmosphere. We got there around 11:30 and the wait time was already 40 minutes. I was shocked at how popular the establishment is. We ordered some drinks while we waited and enjoyed watching all the dishes come out. 

We were seated fairly quickly and started off with some sourdough bread which was incredible. We already knew we wanted to split the clam chowder. We were amazed at how great it was. Growing up in San Francisco I have had some amazing chowder but this was hands down the best I've ever had. My dad felt the same way. I ordered the pan-fried petrale sole and my dad got their famous ciopinno. 

Meals came out quickly with huge portion sizes. The filet of sole was simple and delicious. The ciopinno was very flavorful with a ton of different types of seafood in it. We left very full and very happy. The Tadich Grill is a great find and we will be back for sure.
author: Christina G.

description:
Everything was amazing. Highly recommend if you are visiting San Francisco and only have time for on  memorable meal. Superb wait staff, and warm, traditional/classic atmosphere. 
We had the shrimp crab salad, clam chowder and pan fried Petrale fish.
author: Gaye M.

description:
I went here with my family when they came and wanted a taste of San Francisco. Big mistake. 

The service was really slow, and they screwed up 4 of the five orders. My burger was too rare; my father had asked for salad dressing on side; mother's entree was lukewarm.  And the server was just rude about it. 

The place is also very loud and cramped-feeling. This is a place that seems to trade more on its status as a SF landmark than on its food....which is mediocre at best.
author: Danny Z.

description: Absolutely delicious crab salad with avocado. The sourdough bread is also just perfect. The cherry on the Sunday is the wonderful service... Very friendly and efficient. I wholeheartedly recommend this landmark restaurant. There's a reason they have been in business for 168 years!
author: Julie B.

description: Food was awesome had the deep fried plate and the dungeonous crab appetizer. Guest had the seafood sauté and other dishes no complaints from anyone.  Service was excellent.
author: Patrick B.

description:
I've come to the place for years but am not sure if I'll be returning any time soon.  

I've never had such an unpleasant exchange with both a server and host. The server was actually quite amiable - up until the moment when we gave her a tip. At this point she very abruptly shifted and refused to even refill our waters, insisting that we leave immediately. Even when we tried to explain that we'd ordered a pretty significant amount for a celebratory dinner (3 courses, two rounds of cocktails, nice bottle of wine, dessert), and neglected to mention that we had left a sizable tip just five minutes before, she turned it on us.  With experience in the restaurant industry, I can truly say I've never seen such hostility from a restaurant employee.  Perhaps that's the mood of this place, but it's disappointing to look back on what WAS an enjoyable evening with such negative vibes.
author: Patrick M.

description:
Tadich Grill reminded me of the place in the Godfather where Michael shots Sollozzo and McCluskey except it was crowded, wasn't an Italian restaurant nor was it in New York. 

We came as a large group of 9 but were able to find a booth despite their no booking policy. I was assured by Julia D's mom that the waiter is usually surly but he opened by telling my grandmother not to dance on the tables again and kept up the great service and comedy throughout the meal. 

The food was delicious, I had sole which was huge so I surprised myself by being the only person on the table to clear their plate. Everyone else had a fish dish too and all parties were happy with no complaints. I would definitely recommend.
author: Matt B.

description: The gastronomic assortment is extensive, and the cold cuts leave nothing to be desired. Gruff service adds to the ambience. Take the server recomendation.
author: Paula M.

description: A must anytime I am in the city.  If you like seafood, go hear now.  The cioppino is so so good.  I suggest sharing that and another dish with a friend.  Great for 4 or less.  Bread is amazing.  Be prepared to wait during peak times.
author: Chris D.

description: Great service!! We were greeted immediately after stepping in. We were just having coffee and they seated us promptly. Server gave us a little history. Great location and very welcoming and friendly atmosphere. Coffee was good too ;)
author: Michelle F.

description: Worst service I have ever received. Cannot believe how rude they were to me. They will never get my business again! And the food wasn't even any good! I do not recommend anyone ever go here!
author: Stacy F.

description: I went  at 9:30 pm.   The wait staff changed during my meal and the lack of communication showed as my waiter was replaced by a waitress with an attitude who later admitted she had worked a 12 hour day and was burnt out.  Well, that's not my problem when I'm paying $50 a head.   I still want excellent service.  For example, two people told the prior waiter it was a birthday night and to bring cake with the bill, one reminding the waiter after the meal was done.  The birthday cake never arrived so the culminating surprise ended with me leaving zero tip for the first time in 30 years after a night of bad service.   And when I told the waitress I left zero tip, as I should  as everyone needs to know why and I should not just sneak out,  she brought over a second waiter and they went off on me in front of my dinner party.  To start an argument with me over service at the dinner table was THE WORST SERVICE ever.    I only wish I video taped so I could post it.
author: Phil B.

description: Tadich Grill today with wifey on our San Francisco get-away. 3rd oldest restaurant in the US. Seafood is the name of the game at this Croatian family owned restaurant. So, I had the pan-fried Sand Dabs. The plate was absolutely perfect for what I was looking for!  Cooked perfectly. Wifey had a bowl of the Clam Chowder, which she savored every spoonful with the sourdough bread. The service is excellent. The atmosphere is classy and the menu is prepared daily. Yes, the actual menu that you select your meal from...made daily. If that's the work they put into the menu...just think of the care they put into their prepared dishes! Located in the heart of the financial district of San Francisco, it's just a slight walk from the Ferry Building on the Embarcadero. Come and enjoy this gem, you won't regret it!
author: Darren D.

description:
A wasted dinner in San Francisco, which is heartbreaking considering the other options.  The restaurant looks great, and the waiters wear white smocks that make them look right out of the 30's.

The food, though.  I had the Cioppino, which I was told was a house special.  The shellfish was like rubber, and I couldn't even eat them.  The shrimp was indistinguishable from what I would get frozen at Sam's club.  The crab cake was acceptable, but not what I would expect for $14.

Please, please do a little bit of research and go somewhere else.
author: Steven S.

description: Excellent choices ... Cioppino was the best my husband had ever had (we live in LA so we have a lot of fresh seafood nearby). I had the Sea Bass - also fantastic.  Dessert was bread pudding with carmel sauce --- perfect size to split.  David was our waiter - such a nice gentleman. The charm and attention at this older establishment brings back memories of how dining used to be. Nice to see it hasn't totally gone away.  A must in my book!
author: Nancy K.

description:
I tried to boil Tadich Grill down to a single tag line. But I couldn't settle on just one, so here is three.

"The cioppino is rapturous."

"If you love seafood, you must eat the chippino at Tadich Grill at least once before you die."

"I walked 15 long blocks uphill--both ways--to have the cioppino at Tadich Grill."

I had the pleasure of visiting San Francisco two years ago for the first time. I asked a friend who was from the area for some restaurant recommendations. One of his suggestions was to go to Tadich Grill and have the cioppino. I ate at a lot of good restaurants, but there was only one I vowed I would return to if I was ever in San Fran again, Tadich Grill. 

Forward two years to the present, I am in San Fran on a business trip. I discover to my delight my hotel is on California Ave, the same street as Tadich Grill. So here I am, sitting at the long counter, with drool running down my chin as I wait for my cioppino to arrive. 

It's just as good as I remember. 

The dish is LOADED with seafood. Prawns (shrimp to those of you on the East Coast), mussels, clams, scallops, crab, white fish, and what they call "bay shrimp"-- teeny tiny shrimp the size of your pinkie nail--all in a slightly sweet, perfectly salted, and mildly spicy tomato broth. There is also a fair share of onions, celery, parsley, and lots of large chunks of tomato floating around in there. If that wasn't enough, it's served with two pieces of garlic bread on the side. Which, when dipped in the broth, become sponges full of yumminess. And, it's served to you piping hot.

If I ever have the pleasure of visiting San Francisco a third time, Tadich Grill will be the first restaurant I step foot in. I won't even have to look at the menu. When the waiter takes my order, I'll just say, "I'll have the cioppino".
author: Steve N.

description: I visit San Francisco several times a year and finally tried Tadich. We arrived approximately 3:30 PM and the first think that struck us was a pungent odor.  If that was not bad enough, the server refused to readdress his table choice.  So, Moby Dick died in the kitchen only to be topped by an uncooperative server.  There was several open tables at the front window, and that area was being served. The character insisted it was the best seat in the house. Rude outweighed Odor and we left.  How long have you been in business?
author: Art G.

description: Great, classic seafood in an oldschool, non-pretentious space.  I had cioppino here and it was amazing - - the shellfish was great, the scallops, the fish, the sauce with its little bit of heat.  I wish seafood were a little cheaper in the Bay Area, but that's not unexpected.  I'd eat this again for sure, and I look forward to bringing some other people here.
author: Brian S.

description:
My wife and I began a tradition of having dinner at Tadich every Christmas Eve. This year we decided to get there early (5:00) in order to try and avoid the crowds, since they don't take reservations. It worked out great as we were seated quickly. Tadich is a very old restaurant in the traditional sense. It's a seafood restaurant that your grandparents and great-grandparents would have dined in for a fun evening out. That said, the service is professional and refined. Don't expect the waiters to entertain you, they can come across as aloof if you're accustomed to restaurant service where the staff tries to be your best friend. So relax and let the service staff provide you with good professional service. Order a cocktail, say thank you when they bring your food and drinks and enjoy yourself. 

The food is old school seafood. Don't expect them to try to focus on the next food trend. They've been in operation since the gold rush. Expect this place to be the same in one hundred years as it was one hundred years ago. 

In a city where so many restaurants try to be the next big thing, it's very nice to have an easy, elegant, and traditional place to have a nice grown-up dinner. Restaurants like this become part of the personality of the city. That should be your expectation when you dine at Tadich's.
author: Charles W.

description: Been here twice. First time I ordered a casserole (was my first night in SF and I didn't know better) and I did not enjoy it. I had a number of people tell me to try again and so I went back and had the ciopinno. Wow, it was excellent!  Great broth and fresh seafood. The atmosphere is very "old school " but that's also Part of the charm. Stick to the fresh seafood items and I think you will be happy.
author: Zillah T.

description: The historic Tadich Grill was always a must stop for us when we visited San Francisco. Not any more. The bartenders have become loud and rude and all the veteran waiters have disappeared replaced with a staff that seems to be going through the motions. The food is still good, not great and they still don't take reservations. Sorry Tadich we won't be seeing each other anymore. Was good while it lasted.
author: Mark M.

description: Came here cause I saw great reviews on Yelp. The interior of the restaurant is very quaint and has an old charm feel. It is supposedly the oldest restaurant in CA. However... The food is honestly pretty disappointing. We got clam chowder (okay, nothing special), oysters (slightly unfresh, fishy taste) linguine and clams (pasta way over cooked, the sauce is blend, the clams are fishy and unfresh), red snapper (the fish came luke warm and rubbery), the only dish that was half way decent was the ciopinno (the broth was light and flavorful, scallops was fresh, mussels and clams not so much). Mind you, this is not an averagely priced restaurant. The total cost was around $150. For the quality of the food, it's definitely way over priced. Now about the service: average, doesn't seem very happy to be working there. When asked about recommended dish, didn't smile once and gave one worded answer.
author: Carol W.

description: A+ for being a super old establishment. C- for being overpriced. A- for the stupidly extensive menu. B+ for the clam chowder. B- for the classic/crusty/rude waiters.
author: Nick K.

description:
Loved this place and can't wait to go back again. It's first come first serve so we were here at 11:45 on a Saturday so there was a steady trickle of people but it wasn't packed. They won't seat you until everyone in your party is there. So We waited by the bar and enjoyed drinks, calamari and bread with lots and lots of butter. the bartender was great! felt like i was in a classic movie, there is so much character in the restaurant and the people, you forget you're in a very urban city. 

Besides that loved the food. We had the oysters Rockefeller, Tadich sampler? Sea bass and several bowls of cioppino. If you come here and no one in your party gets the cioppino, you are doing something wrong. That broth was magical and every piece of seafood is cooked perfectly. And garlic bread smothered in butter? Yes please. I was happy with the rest of the food but nothing compares to that cioppino. I drool thinking about it.
author: Erin T.

description: Absolutely loved the atmosphere, service from entry to exit, and the food was just what the Dr. ordered. Crab cakes, halibut steak, seafood cassoulet, and simple linguine w/ gravy (tomato sauce) were all pleasant to the eye & palate. Great interior design & vibe. Bartenders  & our server were attentive, cordial, and engaging. I agree w/ others that this is a must-do when in town.
author: Earl T.

description: Delicioussss seafood cioppino, pretty good clam chowder (lots of clam bits inside, not sure if it's fresh or canned though). The creamed spinach, however, was awful. I'm pretty sure they accidentally dropped some soap or something in there because it just did not taste right.
author: Betty T.

description:
They don't seat you unless your whole party is there.  The service was very slow and not that friendly.

Fresh seafood but poorly executed dishes.  The prices are high. 

The prawn cocktail has giant plump prawns but the cocktail sauce wasn't good. The crab cocktail was ok. I think i prefer Swan's.

The cioppino was sludgey. Not enough broth and tre the taste was not great.  The seafood was big and fresh though. Maybe I'm just not a fan of Cioppino.

The best thing was the manila clams in garlic butter. It was pretty flavoful. 

It took about 1 hour to get all our appetizers. And we spent about 1 h 40 m total to finish our food because it came out that slowly.
author: Heejin L.

description: This has been a favorite restaurants of mine since I was a kid. I continue going there as I grew up. When someone wants seafood I always recommend Tadich, tell them don't go to Fisherman's Warf. The food and service is the best.
author: Diane B.

description: Awesome and wonderful. Great atmosphere and personal service! Always a winner with my family! Make reservations or be prepared to wait! I love sitting at the bar! Delicious bread pudding ends a great meal!
author: Laura S.

description:
OK OK I really shouldn't be giving Tadich's 4 stars, but I can't help myself.  IT'S A SAN FRANCISCO INSTITUTION. 

Anyway, the food is pretty meh.  Standard old school Italian American fare.  

Why 4 stars? Drinks are good, service is amazing, bread is BOMB BOMB BOMB, and the atmosphere is fun.  It's a place you take your aunts and uncles who are visiting from out of town.
author: Josie A.

description:
You probably read all the hype of this restaurant being a SF classic. I've gone twice now. The first time the Cioppino and garlic bread were great. The garlic bread melted in my mouth. The service was rushed and not very friendly. 
The second visit we ordered to much food. A small shrimp and crab salad, fried calamari, and Cioppino. We could've skipped the calamari. It was dry and not very good. The salad was ok, not anything special. The Cioppino was delicious but this time the garlic bread was not as good. It was not warm and it did not melt in my mouth. The server was a little warmer and less rushed but maybe this was because it was a Monday night. Either way hands down the Cioppino is the way to go. Don't except friendly and warm see it's not their motto.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
This place came highly recommended and we did enjoy it. Went for lunch and had to put our name in... Had a drink while waiting. It certainly has the old fashioned feel to it with brusque wait staff who just brush you off. 

Once seated, service was quick. I had the sand dabs which were tasty, wife had the crab cakes which she said were ok. The bill was darn expensive at the end... Overall glad we tried but wouldn't go back.
author: Josh Y.

description: I can't believe this place has been around since 1849- which makes it the oldest restaurant in California! It's a traditional seafood restaurant that reminds me of a McCormick & Shmicks. They even have the same uniforms- big white jackets and a black tie. They are known for the crab-cakes which had a lot of breading and not enough lump crab meat. The mustard sauce was a nice interesting touch though.The calamari was good but not outstanding (a little much with the crab cakes). The Chicken Piccata was decent but they went crazy on the capers. Service was of course, impeccable. If there wasn't much of a wait, I would be back to try the sand dabs which was the other popular dish.
author: Linh T.

description:
This place is as overrated as it is overpriced.

Even with coming at the early bird special time of 6 PM on Friday, there was still a 20-30 minute wait for a table, so we opted to sit at the bar. Bar seating here is actually better than at most smaller places, as it is very roomy and at the same time intimate.

Once seated, there is some mediocre bread waiting for you (it is already placed at each seat at the bar). You can only imagine how long that bread has been sitting there, and it shows. I wouldn't waste myself on it.

For the entrees, sure, the much hyped about Sand Dab Filets are pretty good, but for $24? That's a little silly. They come with the vegetable of the day, which was some weird thing that seemed like Chinese broccoli for some reason, and a starch. The fries didn't look so great, so we opted for the rice, foolishly thinking that it was the San Francisco Treat. The vegetable was pretty tasteless and the rice was nothing more than what you would get out of microwave minute rice.

We also got the Pacific Red Snapper which was also very tasty, but again, not worth it. We opted for the boiled potato with this one, and it was just as tasteless as it sounds.

It's a good thing this was just a snack to tide us over until we made our way to In-N-Out later (another reason we opted not to get the fries).

I expected much better from this place, especially after seeing it on the 7x7 list and on the Food Network's The Best Thing I Ever Ate.
I would probably add a star if it wasn't so overpriced, and maybe if I wasn't allergic to shellfish, as I hear that the Cioppino is supposed to be really good. But if you are allergic to shellfish and you like a really satisfying meal without feeling like you are being gipped, then I would not recommend this place.
author: Mike C.

description:
It's old school.  Like really old school for California.  And the parking is a mess.  Just getting there can be a pain.

Still, there's something about settling into a bit of history.  Especially when that bit of history serves up an excellent martini and has one of the better cioppinos in the city.

If you're by yourself the bar is great, but with friends I like the private-ish booths.

The seafood is fresh and they do a bang up job on the crab and shrimp cocktail.

The cioppino has one of the most flavorful broths around and some of the freshest ingredients.  Its almost big enough to be shared.
author: Joe E.

description: Great fresh food...from the fish to the steak to the side dishes. Impeccable service!
author: Chen L.

description:
An amazing dining experience sums it up, wish we had a more leisurely time rather than rushing through lunch to make ample time to get to our meeting!! Did not even know of the place as I work in the South Bay and a colleague made the lunch reservations .

Starting with the wonderful SF sourdough bread, followed by the best clam chowder ever. The portions were generous.

I had the most amazing Chilean Seabass, it was just prepared to perfection and was to die for!!! Never had one this tasty and moist ever before!!!

The service was great, loved the setting of the old SF charming sitting booths with the private bells on the wall I know I will be back with my family for another amazing experience, and will make sure to try the desserts next tine
author: Mehrnaz H.

description:
I recently moved to San Francisco from Southern California to take a new position. Everytime I visited during the interview process, I'd ask my driver where they recommended that I eat. Most all of them mentioned Tadich Grill. I tried and tried to get in but it was always super busy. Well, last night, some friends were visiting and invited me to join them at Tadich Grill, si I finally got the chance to try it out. 

It was very busy but we had a drink at the bar while we waited.  The bartenders were very pleasant and engaging. After about 15 minutes, we were seated at a nice table. 

The waiter arrived promptly and helped us choose an excellent bottle of wine (one that was actually cheaper than the one we were considering). Unfortunately, they were out of the Sand Dabs and Patrale Sole.  My friends chose instead the swordfish and the seafood sauté. I went for the ribeye. All of the dishes were excellent. I've been to a couple of steak houses recently where the steak wasn't nearly as good as this - cooked perfectly, just the right temperature, thick but not too thick. The portions were ask so large that we were not able to finish them. 

Looking forward to my next visit.
author: L L.

description:
We came in Valentine's Day and had quite the wait, not unlike any other place on this holiday. Loved the long bar, but my mojito was a bit mouthwashy. Yuck. Stick with wine here to go with your meal.
Other than those hiccups. Amazing food and service. Every dish at our table was amazing- clam chowder ( regular is way better than the red, which tasted like vegetable soup). Chilean sea bass melts in your mouth. Seafood Sauté had a yummy light creamy sauce and the crab legs/ scallops melted in my mouth. The lamb had great flavor! 
Then we got cheesecake! OMG so good without being overly rich.
author: Vicky S.

description: I don't get it. Packed, funky atmosphere, I was psyched for some great seafood...but it was very bland.  Pan fried red snapper (bland) with shrimp in some kind of bland sauce, with some bland mushy fries and some bland steamed vegetables.
author: J S.

description: Before I can go for any modern restaurant for a next certain day, I thought I could have lunch in Tadich Grill, the oldest restaurant in SF.  I pretended to go back to the nineteenth century and get a good feel of what its atmosphere is like.  There were a lot of customers; its space is so warm; the noise was loud from all the talking.  As I looked everywhere, made me think I'm dining in Manhattan in the black and white era.  Since its interior was remodelled, nothing mattered to me.  I was so eager to have a seat between hungry Americans since I'm the only one.  For today's lunch, I had a vegetable combination with blue cheese sauce.  My order didn't take long because the vegetables never needed cooking.  To me, it's like eating a salad with blue cheese as a dressing.  I had to remove the egg since I'm not a fan of eggs.  Unlike others who didn't finished their main courses, I manage to eat an entire crowd of vegetables on my plate.  I know I wanted to go for very tasty meat dishes on my second visit, but eating more greens is more helpful.
author: Jimmy C.

description: The food was excellent.  My wife myself were in town and Tadich was recommended by a friend.   Seafood  Aplus
author: Kelly H.

description:
Consistently great seafood
Offers a crowded atmosphere that actually lends itself the whole enjoyable experience
Don't miss this place!
author: C Z.

description: Dined here for lunch and I hate giving a three-star review because I think I just made a blah selection for the restaurant. I was in the mood for healthier quick salad for lunch and we walked in here greeted with a bustling restaurant. I really like the ambience and old-school flare, especially the all-male dressed in white coat wait staff... it really adds a fun feel! I ordered the rare tuna ahi salad, my coworker order the crab and prawn seafood casserole and the other order the ravioli along with their clam chowder. Again I was trying to opt out of just one meal without bread but couldn't resist the large sour-dough slab on the table! My salad came with a large amount of tuna and apples, but the apples weren't very crispy, could have used more lettuce and slightly overdressed (I should have asked for on the side) and definitely a pretty penny ($26.00). My coworkers definitely seemed pleased with their meal but this just isn't the type of lunch I'm usually interested in and I think you need to commit to the heaviness of the meals. I will say I've dined here for dinner and had the cioppino which was fabulous. I would come back for dinner, but just not my style for lunch.
author: Aryn C.

description:
Came here to lunch with one of my boss'. He was from Atlanta and said he's been eyeing this place the past couple days. So we walk in and it was pretty packed. Good thing we came just in time because they sat us down immediately. 

I ordered a pasta with shrimp. Very creamy, you can taste the ingredients in it. Not like olive garden type of pasta. It was a pretty decent sized serving too. My boss ordered off the breakfast menu. He looked pretty satisfied with his meal. This place is a little gem in the Financial District, stepping in there takes you out of the big buildings and skyscraper environment into another world. Like stepping into the 1950's.
author: Dara S.

description:
A historical restaurant that serves delicious food. The prices are a bit steep, but everyone who visits San Francisco should try theTadich Grill at least once. 

Be sure to read the menu completely, as the history of the place is interesting, and there are a large number of items each day. Quite often there is a line of people waiting to be seated, but sitting at the bar is certainly an option as it is rather entertaining as well. My favorite are the enclosed booths as the privacy is a special treat, but without a group of four, the odds are slim that you'll get seated there. Back to the food, though... 

Whenever we visit and they have Osso Buco on the menu, that is my goto dish. However, I have never been displeased with a meal there.
author: BettyLou H.

description: The issue I had with this place occurred about 17 yrs ago.  My business partner and I were attending a conference in SF and decided to have lunch there.  I was a long time resident of Tiburon and African American, my business partner was White from Los Gatos, and we had no presumptions about this place other than that we heard the food was good and the service excellent.  It turned out to be a very short lunch as no one from the wait staff came to take our order and we were pretty much ignored.  After about 30 minutes, we both got the picture, left the restaurant and never set a foot inside that place again.  I never spoke of this until this recent "racial" dustup appeared  in the press which only confirmed my suspicion.  Now that all of this is out in the open. I can only hope the Buich family understands that racism and how you treat customers of "color" will eventually affect your your bottom line and  no matter how long you've been in business, this type of stain and stench cannot be arbitrarily brushed aside by the city's elite.
author: B. W.

description:
Let's start with the good....the food was absolutely delicious.  We both started with the shrimp bisque which was so creamy and flavorful. Onto the entrees. Hubby got a grilled snapper dish which was delicious. The filet was generously sized, moist and flaky and so flavorful. The accompanying mixed veggies were fresh and steamed perfectly.  I ordered the seafood canelloni Florentine which was melt-in-your-mouth buttery goodness.  The apple torte finished off the meal perfectly.  It was dense and packed with apples.  We absolutely loved the food.

Now for the not-so-good.  Service was brusque, not particularly friendly, and a bit unpolished. We asked for water twice before we received it. We were seated near a bussing station which didn't prevent the waiters from throwing their dishes into the bucket with great force, making an ear-splitting racket.  Although we went to dinner early, and the restaurant was not full, it was so noisy we could barely hear each other.  Hubby commented that with all the noise and commotion, it was like eating in a bus station.  

Other issues:  the bread was hard, dry and flavorless.  Prices were high: most appetizers in the $15-$18 range, entrees were generally in the $25 -$35 range and desserts were $9.  Food was great, but given the service quality and bus station atmosphere, we think prices were too high.  The thing that must irritated me, however, was the size of the beverages.  Both alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks were served in glasses that were about 30 percent smaller than what you find in most restaurants.  I would guess my Coke was served in a 6 ounce glass filled halfway with ice and they had the nerve to charge me for a refill ($2.75 a pop).  Similarly, hubby's martini was about half the size of any martini he's ever ordered anywhere but priced like a full-sized martini. So we felt a bit ripped off, especially since we were paying so much for the meal.  I mean, come on.  What does soda cost them?  2 cents a glass?

In summary, great food but not-so-great everything else.  For the price of this experience, we were a bit disappointed.
author: Patty V.

description:
I've not been here in AGES -- never seem to have time.

It's great.  I made a point today to go in early and have the Hangtown Fry.

Perfect.  And the tomatoes served with it were awesome -- nice tasty beefsteak slices.

Couldn't linger since I have meetings and things to attend to, but I could easily sit at the bar and snack on oysters and white wine all afternoon.

Person to my left ordered the Cioppino -- it looked incredible!
author: Larry C.

description: Very good food in the financial district the chowder is packed with clams and the right consistency. The overall service was prompt and unabashedly fun and jovial a place for having some fun and laughs during the lunch break.
author: N A.

description:
Came here for a very belated bday dinner with a friend of mine.  Since hearing about this place from a cousin of mine, I have been wanting to try it.  She just went on and on and on about their Ciopinno.  Got here around 6:15pm and was seated about 6:45pm. While waiting for a seat, you can site at the bar and have a drink if there is an opening.  The first half of the bar is for drinks only and the back half is for drinks and eating.

Appetizers - Since it was our first time here, we ordered 3 different appetizers to try it out.

Dungeness Crab Cocktail - Yummy.  I will choose crab over shrimp any day.  Made just like the shrimp cocktail, but with meat from crab claws instead. Came with some veggies and cocktail sauce on the bottom.

Pacific Oysters Rockefeller (6 oysters) - Made with creme spinach and cheese.  I thought this was okay only.  The oysters were pretty small and the oyster shells were loaded with creme spinach and topped off with cheese.  All I was able to taste was the creme spinach.  I personally prefer raw oysters instead.

Garlic Buttered Manilla Clams - Yums!  This was the best appetizer of the night!  We ordered a dozen and finished it in no time.  The clams were huge!  The white sauce it came with was very delicious and tasted very good with the complimentary bread.  

Entrees:

Seafood Ciopinno - OMG....sooo good!  I don't care for Ciopinno to start out with, but this Ciopinno was delicious.  The broth was a little salty if you sip it, but the seafood in the dish tasted amazing and it wasn't salty.  The garlic bread was a compliment to the broth.  I'm drooling just thinking about it.  Very tasty and yummy dish.

My friend had the Charcoal Broiled Fresh Alaskan Halibut and thought it was just okay.  He said the fish was pretty bland and wish it had more flavor.

Overall, it was a good experience and I will definitely come back here for their Ciopinno.
author: Ashley L.

description:
I've dined in 3-star Michelin restaurants, and I travel all over the world; this is my favorite restaurant on the planet. There is no other place like it--honestly. If you are put off by having to stand along the paneled wall waiting for a seat, don't worry; that line moves quickly even at high traffic times. An abundantly civilized place where time stands still; nothing else does, however, as the staff (some grumpy, some cheerful, all out of central casting) are running around like crazy. The menu may have changed in the last 50 years, though I rather doubt it. Order a rib eye or bronzino; your martini will come in a glass that Sammy Davis Jr. would have raised in a toast to Dean Martin. 

Three semi-colons in one review. Perhaps a record?
author: Mark B.

description:
I haven't had much cioppino at all, but Tadich claims to have the best.  For $35 a serving (which includes two big, deliciously toasted buttered up garlic toasts), they'd better have the best.  And I am happy to report that I was not disappointed.  From what I remember from past cioppino experiences, cioppinos are way too salty.  But this was not the case here.  I especially loved the big slabs (yes they looked like slabs) of fish, which were buttery and flaky.  And I have never seen bigger scallops and shrimp.  They sure do pile on the seafood!

All in all, I'd say you'd need to try this place, even just once.  Twice if you really like it.
author: Annie A.

description: Da bomb. Chicago level. Calamari. Grilled swordfish. G & T. A night with friends. The boys at the front are  really cool and professional. No favoritism. Just be ready with your party when you say 7!
author: Surfer Dude D.

description: A rainy night in San Francisco -- a good friend and I just left Embarcadero cinemas and wanted warmth and good food and drink.  Ahhh, Tadich!  Always delivers --- exactly what I expect.  White coated bartenders/servers (mostly men who've been there forever!) --  I ALWAYS wait for a bar seat.  This particular Thursday rainy night in December we waited about 40 minutes, but worth it.  Great drinks, wine list and classic food.  Had salad and linguine w clams -- friend had calamari steak.  The bread alone -- true Italian bread like I had growing up in Chicago, and enough of it -- you don't need to ask for more.  Service with a smile, food served up piping hot and perfect.  No wonder it's an institution.  Go.
author: Katherine E.

description: First visit in more than a decade.  Still the quintessential San Francisco restaurant, favored by locals and tourists alike without pretense.  Tadich Grill features fresh fish and seafood with classic, simple preparation; round loaves of only-from-San Francisco sourdough bread; solid libations; old-school, gruff but rock-solid waiters; and an interior featuring a long bar, white tablecloths, and if you are lucky, sitting in one of the private curtained-off rooms. This place has changed very little -- if at all -- since I began coming here as a child with my parents in the late 1960s.  Was great to experience it again with my own son now, who also appreciated its provenance.
author: Jon L.

description: Why is Lobster Thermidor so hard to find? Tadich Grill is one of very few restaurants that serves it, but I'm not sure why they had to ruin it by replacing the lobster shell with a casserole dish and filling half of it with rice. But maybe I shouldn't give a shit because the cioppino is one of the best in the city. That broth would probably taste good even in a Bloody Mary. Right?!
author: Suany W.

description:
Most delicious seafood I've had in a LONG time. Will definitely be going here whenever I'm in SF. Loved the ambiance and drinks, too. 

Service was also extremely quick, efficient, and accommodating. 

A new favorite!
author: Nate S.

description: Pricey, noisy, mediocre food and rude service about sums up our dinner.  The calamari, salmon and oysters were all disappointing. Veggies were boring. I was expecting a lot more for these prices. Don't think I'll be back.
author: Sadie S.

description: The real deal. Walked in with a group of seven on New Year's Eve afternoon and was seated in 15 minutes in a spacious private booth -- even hooks to hang our coats on. The cozy well-set booth was gracious and welcoming, and engendered cheery, warm conversation. The restaurant was festive but not overdone; the waiters in classic white coats and black bow ties were neither overanxious to please nor condescending but exuded old-school cool and professionalism, sardonic banter, and excellent service. The food was fantastic, with generous portions. I had one of their classic plates, Ahi and avocado. Fabulous!  The ribeye steak, veal scallopini, and sand dabs were also big hits. A perfect martini, an ideal Negroni, and well-priced wines by the glass made everyone happy. Bonus: old-style sourdough bread!
author: Kathryn M.

description: best seafood lunch I've ever had.great cocktails, avocado shrimp salad and melt in your mouth filet of sole.waiter was excellent and left very happy!
author: gretchen y.

description:
If you like your restaurants old and your servers surley, this is your spot!  Tadich Grill offers heaps of history, and an excellent spot to "power lunch" if you're so inclined.  

The food was good, though prices were a bit high for what you get.  I had the salmon and bay shrimp casserole, which is essentially bay shrimp (i.e. small shrimp - not the oxymoronic kind), large pieces of salmon, and rice, all in a tomato based sauce and topped with melted cheese.  It's delicious and there are large portions of shrimp and salmon.  My only gripe was that some of the shrimp had not been fully cleaned and some of the salmon had not been fully de-boned.  I would have expected better quality control at an establishment of this caliber and with servers this gruff, but perhaps the lunch rush could be factored into the snafu.  

Overall, eating at Tadich Grill is a fun experience, and their menu is extensive - they literally have something for everyone.  The ambiance is stellar, and bread is excellent.  I'll be back again, though the prices and preparation will ensure that I'll be walking, not running.
author: Tom G.

description: Been here many times! If you are looking for great dining place or seafood lover, this is the place for you! The menu choices are breathtaking with the variety of fish and different cooking options! They even have Crab and Lobster Thermidor and everybody knows that Lobster Thermidor  is Batman favorite! The desserts and cocktails also deserve highest  appreciation!
author: Ally M.

description:
I can't believe I've never been to this SF institution until last night when my friend dragged me there.

2 words: crab cakes!! 

Anyhow service was great. I'll be coming back!
author: Julia H.

description:
I am well aware this is the oldest restaurant in SF and California, and it is very popular. It reminded me of one of the old Manhattan bars with white jacket and apron waiters. 

With a couple of the guys, this might have been a good choice. However, it was noisy, rushed and crowded. The table for 2 was small as well. 

The baked crab and prawn offering was good but not outstanding as was the snapper with bay shrimp.
author: Tina S.

description:
It has been my experience when eating at an establishment that is an institution, that it tends be a letdown.  That was not the case for lunch today. I just had the best cioppino in my life, hands down. 

It was abundant with extremely fresh seafood, flavorful and well balanced, piping hot but each bite was still succulent and cooked perfectly.  In essence it was the perfect seafood stew....let alone the best cioppino.
author: Jacob O.

description: Hands down the best friggin cioppino in the city. Worth every penny. Yes it's a little pricey but when you break it down, it really isn't that bad. There is a crazy abundance of seafood in this baby. Crazy. I only ate half, took the rest to go and I'm currently noshing on it for breakfast. The wait is what you'd expect but we were a party of 2 and waited amongst the bar for an opening. There was an amazing woman that came down and told us that a spot was opening up and that she saw us waiting when they arrived so it was ours to grab. How amazing is that? Our server Thomas was fantastic. He was friendly, fun and on top of it. I will be back for sure.
author: Sarah M.

description:
...this place has the greatest cioppino (a cornucopia of seafood stew) in all the land and is a 'must stop & consume too much food' destination in San Francisco.  

Skip dessert and eat more sourdough bread.  

Yes please.
author: Jake F.

description:
I was visiting a friend in SF and asked her to choose a popular SF restaurant. She suggested Tadich Grill. We met up around 5:30 and the wait wasn't too bad (less than an hour) for our group of four considering they don't take reservations. We could have been sat earlier, but our complete party hadn't arrived yet.

Once we were all there we were seated in a cozy table towards the back, so there was some privacy from the hustle and bustle of the restaurant.

We ordered:
Seafood Cioppino (2 orders) - big portion..we should have just ordered one. It was good and this is what they are known for, but I was expecting it to be the best cioppino I ever had and sadly it wasn't.
Seafood Saute- Our group actually enjoyed this dish the best! Fresh seafood with some butter, lemon, and light seasoning...simple always tastes good - especially with butter! 
Dungeness Crab and Prawns a la Monza- The flavor combo wasn't what we were expecting. I'm glad we tried it, but couldn't really taste the seafood since the sauce and cheese in the dish were overpowering.

5 stars for service. This place is definitely an SF institution...the service is top notch, the servers are older gentlemen who seem like they've been doing this for decades. The ambiance is old school with dark rich woods and dim lighting. You can find out more about their history on their website..fascinating!

Overall a solid 4 1/2 stars. Also, this restaurant is a lot more casual then I thought and not at all pretentious. It's a mix of business people, tourists, and locals. It's expensive but that's expected since you're paying for the quality and experience :-)
author: D.J. K.

description:
Seafood fare in a traditional dining institution where wood panelling is the standard decor, private booths befit groups and the long boisterous bar awaits your drink order.

The worthwhile wait +'s:
+ Cioppino. It's the signature dish and it's big and it's good.
+ Chilean sea bass. Is it on the endangered list? If it is I feel bad but the flaky buttery fish was cooked to perfection. The side brussel sprouts didn't even spoil it and I hate brussel sprouts.
+ Table spacing is pretty good which means you can have a private conversation without too much eavesdropping.
+ Reservations can be snagged at Open Table else wait at least 45' on a Saturday evening
+ Great place to advise your visitors to dine. Can capture some of the old spirit of SF where tourists and regulars cross.

The unworthwhie wait -'s:
- Service was questionable. He looked weary. Walked off when we couldn't decide or refused appetizers.
- Sourdough bread is complimentary and not memorable.
- Location is in the dead of Financial District. There is nothing happening down here on the weekend.
author: Yiven C.

description:
Excellent food and great service.  Our dining experience was the best I have had in several years.  45 minute wait on a Monday wasn't an issue as the bar is sufficiently stocked with nice booze and the bar staff was efficient and knowledgeable, making great old fashioneds.  Dinner was excelent. Started with calamari and clams... clams are great! Aslo shared the Tadich platter which consisted of smoked trout and salmon, calamari salad, jumbo shrimp, crab , and pickled fish. Excellent.  Like everyone else, cioppino for dinner.... BOMB!  Can't wait for my next time.

Oh, and nothin like great SF sourdough. ... complimentary!
author: Manzano A.

description: Simply put great dishes !! Well executed and flavorful! I will come back the last true restaurant in SF . And not for you tech snobs . Just great American cuisine. I will be back . The lamb chops were succulent and my wife's stuffed Turbot was immaculately prepared. Five Stars .
author: Chancellor E.
