description: It was during the holidays, that we decided to stop in at Tadich Grill, since it had been quite some time since our last visit. We had to wait about an hour for a spot to dine. Standing room only. There are no reservations. It was a cold night, so everyone was pressing to get into the warmth. The staff at the front desk, are there to greet, but also thwart any possible stampede. They may be salty, but well-meaning. We were seated at a comfy little table. That night, there was lots of holiday energy in the place. My husband and I knew the entrées we wanted, but it was nice to have them affirmed by our server. He served the meal thoughtfully. We thoroughly enjoyed his filet! Grilled to perfection, and beautifully seasoned. I enjoyed the crab cakes. However, as I have written previously, I am not a fan of a mixed bed of steamed veggies. I would have appreciated more creativity with the side. Bites of the steak, enhanced the enjoyment of the crab cakes. We caved, and had the bread pudding, with hard sauce. Really rich, and best when shared with more than two people. It was nice to return to an old haunt. Overall, a delightful time. This place has a long and rich history. I wouldn't want you to miss it!
author: BL L.

description:
Iconic restaurant in the Financial District serving great seafood!
We followed what yelpers recommended, and ordered the Oysters Rockefeller and Cioppino. Shared both, had lovely experience, great service, a wonderful bottle of wine...
A must to try this place. Even just for historical SF respect.
author: Amy O.

description: Remarkably subpar for the prices and the 'establishment' that it is. Wasn't 4 star at all.
author: Deb R.

description:
Old school kind of place, with wooden booths and coat hangers on the side of the booths. The place has been here since the California Gold Rush days :-) . The Mr jokes that this was one of the few institution that's older than he is.  Haha 

The menu is very straight forward, and the waiters are what most would consider "Professionals" - this is what they do for a living, they are for the most ,part not side line actors or actresses. The waiters are old gentlemen dressed in white, expect to step back in time when you enter. 

The portions are huge for lunch! The Mr had pork chop and they gave him TWO! It was very tender and juicy! He started with their house salad, which was straight forward. I started with their clam chowder, I've never had so much clams in a soup before! Awesomeness!!! It was very good, I got a cup and I suggest you should as it could be filling. I finished with the pan fried trout with a lemon cream sauce which was surprisingly light. Both entrees had bok choy as side vegetables! We both love bok choy so it was a very pleasant surprised (because you usually get stuff like carrots, or asparagus). And be prepared to see the coolest cut fries!! They were huge, out your index and middle finger next to each other and imagine the fries being that thick on all four sides - and on the inside fluffy deliciousness awaits you! We did not finish our entrees, but it was still very good nonetheless. 

This restaurant is an institution to visit if you're in the area! 

Cheers!!
author: Nancy N.

description: What a terrific place for New Years.  High energy, great bartenders, and a homey feel.  The crab salad was delicious and the portion was more than ample.  That's their thing - large portions of good home cooked food.  Old school drinks and no fuss.  It's very popular as the oldest restaurant in Cali, and since they don't take reservations, be prepared to wait.  Definitely a must try.
author: Rachel V.

description:
I've been here a couple times, and after the last visit time to review both of my visits. I love the space, the old school service, sitting at the bar between meetings and getting some iced tea and food:

1st Visit : This was 5 star with some local California King Salmon on a salad (it was a special and isn't on the menu normally) and great service. The bread is always good.

2nd Visit : This was more of a 3.5 star visit. I got the smoked salmon app, it was very good and a lot of Salmon with other nice garnishes. Avoid the Caesar salad, it's really meh. Once again good bread and service.
author: Jonah K.

description: Stopped into this gem for just a drink while waiting for dinner at Mina.  Tadich never disapoints, Classy and romantic San Francsico jewel!
author: Carol P.

description:
How can there be anything less then 5 stars posted here. Are you people crazy?! 

Amazing classic old spot in the city. If you want the best sea food then you found it. Order the oysters Rockefeller, it was invented here!
author: Julia R.

description: Have yet to even eat anything other than the bread and I am so disgusted with the manner my mother, her friend, and I have been treated since the second we walked in the door. The bartender had a terrible attitude as he was telling us we couldn't eat at the bar, interrupting our question saying, "look ladies I need to get this across very clear," as he  pointed to the items of food that were served at the bar. We decided to sit at a table to have the option of the full menu. After finishing the little tray of butter with our bread we asked a server that was changing a table if he could grab us some butter. He abruptly said "when I'm finished with what I'm doing, yea." I've worked serving people for 3 years and I would never speak to a customer in that way. Terrible service, take a good look at your staff Tadich Grill. You're lucky your food is delicious....*munching on fried calamari*
author: Taylor T.

description: The Tadich Grill has a bitchiness (the staff is pretty cold unless you are a regular..) that can be off-putting, but it's got an authentic vibe and some of the dishes on the menu can be stellar. The cioppino *is* worth the $32.95 charged - a large bowl of shrimp, mussels, fish and crab served in a slightly spicy tomato broth. The garlic bread that comes with the cioppino adds to the dishes flavors. I've had the crab/shrimp salad. Pretty basic - served on bag salad - but fresh and memorable with the Louie dressing. Some good local wines available. Menu is quite extensive so if you aren't in the mood for fish or seafood there are other options available.
author: Mark H.

description: So I always thought that this was a tourist trap. WRONG! So yes tourists are attracted to the place but there's no  denying,  the food is world class. Get the cioppino, you will not regret it. My only complaint is that the Manhattans I got were very inconsistent. A result of free pours, in my opinion.
author: Martin Y.

description:
This review is limited by the fact that I only tried their NE clam chowder, based on reviews here which I generally interpret as 'one man's (or women's) meat is another's poison.  

Why the inferior rating? I detest grit in my chowder and there was noticeable grit in Tadich's version. Nonetheless I finished it, settled my bill and exited back into a rainy San Francisco afternoon, disappointed for sure. And it lacked the rich, creaminess of certain other restaurants, see below.

This place is as old school as it gets - - and the servers were extremely prompt and efficient. Maybe I should have commented my sentiments while there but oh well, time to watch The Masters.

In my book Scoma's is as good as it gets in the chowder department, creamy, clammy, rich bowl of goodness (complimented with Tabasco) and room temp butter for their fresh sourdough bread. Maybe I'll return to Tadich for other fare but for me the chowder is off my list.
author: Art M.

description:
Went there for an early dinner during a business trip a few weeks back.

Sat at the bar, which was surprisingly crowded at 5pm. Service was swift and "somewhat" friendly.

Of course I ordered the Cioppino ("when in Rome...."). It was good, although not the best I had in CA. Bill came to $60 for dinner and drinks. Certainly not cheap, but also not overly expensive by San Francisco standards.
author: Michael T.

description: Highly overpriced for an out of date menu with only average tasting food and super snobby workers.
author: James A.

description:
Okay--help me out here. What, exactly, is SO special about this place?!

My boyfriend and I are from LA and were visiting SF this past weekend. We stayed at Le Meridien and were recommended Tadich.

The ambiance was great, we were seated immediately--but everything else went south from there. Our waiter was rude and had nothing to say about anything. We started with two bloody mary's which were literally vodka and tomato juice. We ended up putting lemon and lime and salt and pepper in it to spice it up ourselves because it was so "blah." Then he ordered the clam chowder, which was very watery and nothing special. We also got the shrimp cocktail, which was a huge surprise in general! I must not be used to shrimp (vs. prawns), but besides for that, the cocktail sauce was really very gross.

On to the main dishes--

My boyfriend got somewhat of a seafood medley, which he said was "OK." I absolutely LOVE swordfish, so I thought that would be a good dish to try, given Tadich was supposed to be one of the best spots for seafood. It was actually inedible. It was SO dry and chewy I only ended up eating a quarter of the thing. The "vegetable of the night" was gross soggy carrots and broccoli. Really? And our waiter recommended creamed spinach to go with our meal and since my boyfriend loves that we decided to try it since he made it sound like a specialty item. It was also inedible. It had nutmeg in it? And tasted like baby food from a cafeteria (if that even exists). 

All in all, this meal came out to be $150. We could have dined next door at Michael Mina's and paid a similar price for some of the best food in the country. This was a HUGE disappointment and it was truly very surprising to us both that this place is still so popular. For any of you who watch Restaurant Impossible, I kept imagining Robert coming in and making comments about the food and service. AY!
author: Jamie S.

description: Really?!?  Ordered 2 things for lunch and regretted both.  One was the mixed seafood plate...forgot the name but it had herring, shrimp cocktail, red onions and etc.  What a disgusting dish!  My bro and I shared my sister's favorite, the pan fried sand dabs.  What was so special?!?  The best thing about my lunch was the martini.  Honestly, maybe I ordered the wrong items but not sure if I would go back because their dishes are just too generic along w. the outdated décor and waitstaf..
author: Ricky C.

description:
I've eaten at the Tadich grill at least 60 times over the past 40 years.  I like it!  You've read everyone else's review that calls this place "old school".  That means the wholesome, butter enriched high calorie food and European level of table service makes this place a gem.

The food here defines "comfort" for me. I grew up in New York City a loooong time ago (the 1950's).  There were 100's of restaurants there and then that served dishes like Tadich makes today. The creamy sauces and par boiled vegetables at Tadich take me back to a time when I was young, innocent and appreciative. The aromas at Tadich do powerfully rekindle old memories.

Well, more than a half century has passed since my childhood and I can now appreciate a bracing cocktail at the Tadich bar, while patiently waiting for a table to become available. And then once seated, I read the copiously populated menu to tease my taste buds.

I often order sand dabs. This humble fish was once so available when I was a kid that it was practically given away for free.  Now it's on the endangered species list.  What! an endangered flounder?  None the less, I order it and enjoy it.

I'll probably eat here another 30 times before my journey to the great beyond.  And I hope that the Tadich grill is still serving sand dabs long after I'm gone.
author: Tom S.

description:
Cioppino! Don't have it anywhere else, and by all means have this when you're there. Put this place on your to do list when in the Union Square area. Both my
Wife and I had their legendary Sicilian Fish Stew (Cioppino) loaded with crabmeat, scallops, mussels, shrimp, clams, and..other frutti di mare, we also sampled the shrimp bisque which will knock you out. It's a perfectly blended bisque with a rich multi-layered flavor and aroma profile, and a silky finish! The waiters are fun, professional, and they're a throwback to a better time when appearances mattered. They are all neatly coiffed, dressed in black trousers, white shirt and tie, starched white jackets and long aprons. If you miss this place when you're in the area, you're missing a bucket list experience.
author: Joe P.

description: Great dining experience...our waiter been here 40 years...he's fantastic...good food great service...what more could one ask for...building is long and narrow...little private booths on one side and a bar top that must be 100' long...seafood...steaks...did I mention great service? Thx Ken!
author: Bob G.

description:
5 stars for the cioppino. This is the ONLY reason to come here.

Service? Meh. We told you before-hand when we wrote our names down on the waitlist that 3 out of our 4 would like to get seated first, and then our 4th will come later. You guys acknowledged this, and yet, refused to seat us when it became our turn. Oh, and this is after you totally skipped over our name. DO YOU NOT UNDERSTAND THE WORDS THAT ARE COMING OUT OF MY MOUTH? *channeling Chris Tucker*

Skip the sand dabs. They just taste like a "meh" fried fish. Not sure why it's on the 7x7 Big Eats list...
author: Kazu O.

description: My friend and I went in for a late lunch/early dinner. Marion was our server. We chatted with him about his homeland. My friend visited there many years ago as a young adult and they relished about their history there. Good times and not so good times were mentioned and it brought a realness to our visit. The food was great (Cioppino & crabcakes....amazing). Marion made our visit one to remember!
author: A A.

description: I've been going to this establishment on every visit to San Francisco for over 15 years.  The entire staff makes a great effort to make everyone happy.  Compared to other eateries, it is a stand out.  I'm always so satisfied with my dining experience, I have to let everyone know about this place.  I always give the chef and management my compliments.  It's a great environment with good food and you get the feeling that everyone working there is glad you are there.  You cant ask for much more...
author: Isaac G.

description:
LOVED!!  Had wanted to come here forever, came on a whim when nowhere else appealed to anyone in the party....I basically ate the loaf of sourdough (this is not just a problem when in SF...I usually eat all of the table bread! ;)  

Food was traditional, delicious (exception, the salad - very boring, seemingly bagged lettuce that would have benefitted totally from a rinse & chill---was dry and room-temp).  Ordered steak, was cooked to perfection....veggies were everything steamed veggies are supposed to be - not overdone, mercifully. Potato wedges were great.  If you are looking for traditional, classic with professional wait service & not just the latest, frilliest thing in town, this is the place for you.  

MAJOR gratitude to the gentlemen at the valet stand - we took a taxi to & fro, but Valet 1 helped move on a homeless gent who accosted me the moment I emerged from the restaurant (THANK YOU, SIR! Wasn't expecting that - accustomed to that in certain parts of the city, but wouldn't have expected it here) and the second valet who was diligent in helping us locate a cab (not an easy task at the time).
author: Missy P.

description: Loved this place! Even the attention from the waiters seems to be from better times, the food was exquisite, ask for the ravioli!
author: Diego B.

description: I still cannot believe my experience as I write this review.  I had friends in town from out of state and was excited to take them here.  A party of four, three of us arrived and gave our name for the wait.  We were seated by Justin (who took our name and knew we were a party of four with only three there).  The waitress arrived and we ordered for the missing person so we didn't delay our waitress or the restaurant.  She apparently informed the host Justin that we were seated without our entire party (apparently something they never do).  Justin (mind you he took our name AND seated us), came to the table and grabbed the menus and indicated we needed to get up, that we shouldnt have been seated.  We told him we already ordered and he literally threw the menus back down on the table and stormed off.  Not wanting to create any additional awkward tension, we sat through our meal and paid the check.  After paying we asked the waitress to please have the manager came, and guess who that happened to be?  Justin.  My friend let him know how rude and strange his behavior was.  His response "there was an issue with the front staff and I took it out on you.  Sorry."  That was it.  While the food was tasty I have never seen such behavior and quite frankly was embarrassed for my friends having to witness that in SF while on vacation.  Great depiction of the city Justin and just how friendly everyone can be.  Avoid this place if you want to be treated with even an ounce of decency.
author: Sean B.

description: I love Tadich Grill. Every time I eat here I feel transported to another time. I love this place. The people (I think they are all men) are so nice. The food is delicious and worth every cent! Whenever I have anything to celebrate, I want to come here.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Highly recommended!!  I had the charcoal broiled petrale sole. It came with 2 good size pieces of fish, long branch potatoes (basically just oversized French Fries) and the vegetable of the day. I was barely able to finish everything. Had the berries for dessert, the fruit was as fresh as the fish. The waiter was excellent and very attentive and I never had to wait for a drink to be refilled. 

The only complaint was there are no refills on soft drinks, and they come in 10oz glass. After walking 10 blocks to get there, I needed more than just a few ounces of soda. I switched to water.
author: Stephen R.

description:
Very solid restaurant, actually better than I expected.  To reiterate what others have written, this place is old school, traditional and in many ways a little phony old school in that they play it up.  Waiters are very formal and professional.  Classic SF dishes.  Between the formality and dishes, this is more of a tourist spot than a locals restaurant.

That said, and I was ready to hate it for those reasons, it's pretty good.  First, although the service is formal, we had a great and very nice waiter. Second the food is good.  I had a salad Louie to start.  Salad with crab and tiny shrimp with Louie dressing (creamy French).  I then had cioppino.  The cioppino had fresh ingredients, though the highlight was the garlic bread to soak up the broth.

Overall, a very solid experience when you are looking for old school SF cuisine.
author: Lloyd M.

description:
Love this place and have been coming here for years since I was a little boy. Best cioppino and sourdough in the city imho. The atmosphere buzzes and the wait staff is a little crude and old fashioned but great. 

Not a lot of detail in this review but I can say from a somewhat picky foodie to another this place is the real deal and u won't be disappointed.
author: Bryant S.

description:
Visited here for a pre-BART cocktail last week. I've been to the Tadich before years ago and it's definitely a SF classic, hence the tourists. 

Love the white jackets. Reminiscent of the Balboa Cafe, another one of my favorite watering holes that now seems like it's on the other side of the world. 

The Manhattan was really good, much more so than I expected after hearing the bourbon options that are rather old school and non-descript. Reasonably priced too. The server was professional and polite. 

It's possible that I will return for lunch or dinner in the near future.
author: Amy Z.

description: If this place took reservations I might once a month or more. I've loved everything I've every ordered here. Their meat is really good, not just the sea food. It's my go to if I'm going to sit for dinner immediately after work, right when it opens.
author: Deirdre M.

description: A no nonsense great restaurant we tried both chowders and they were excellent. The shrimp cocktail was ice cold and very fresh. My wife had the Rex sole which she loved and I went for the pasta with meat sauce which was a ten. Prices are reasonable and the waiters are real pros. I highly recommend this place.
author: Tim H.

description: This is an experience I've been looking forward to for about 4 years.  After having seen the Tadich Grill on several Food Network shows, I was almost embarrassed that I haven't been there before now.  I went in during the supposedly not-busy time, Saturday afternoon at around 3pm.  The bar had several seats open, so that's where I sat.  I was promptly greeted by my server, who (you could tell) was a 40-something professional (score one right off the bat for not employing teenagers).  I felt obligated to order the Cioppino, their signature dish.  Needless to say, the legends were true.  Huge shrimp, massive clams, and an abundance of other seafood so fresh, it has to be seen to be believed.  This was an absolutely fantastic meal in every way.  Having walked the Golden Gate (twice) an hour earlier, I was hungry enough to eat a horse, and the portion size of the Cioppino was surprisingly large.  I washed it down with two vodka martinis, and put the whole experience in the "win" column.  Tadich Grill is the oldest restaurant in San Francisco, and I was impressed by the minimalist decor inside.  "Stately" is the word that comes to mind, but not overly adorned with photos or art on the walls.  Decoration was simple, presumably because the food is the star of the show here.  I highly recommend this place.
author: Tom B.

description:
Dungeness crab coctail legs only awesome.
NY Strip medium rare knocked my socks off.
Service great.
Vibe old school and solid. No BS.

Go here and eat good food and shut the fuck up about anything else.
author: Jeff K.

description: Great food in the heart of the city! Was open late so we could enjoy a nice meal while traveling on business.  A bit on the pricey level but it was worth it!
author: Nikita B.

description: The wait was long, very long (about 55mn when we were told about 30mn when we arrived) but the food made up for it. Amongst the best sea food I have had anywhere. They don't take reservation so no way around the wait but if you are in the area it is one of those you should absolutely try.
author: Frederic B.

description:
The Tadich Grill is the oldest continuously run restaurant in California.  It is a fish house located in the Financial District that is hugely popular and always busy.  It is composed of a barroom and a large dinning room split into two sections.  It is attractively decorated with walls clad in dark wood and furnished with white-cloth-covered tables.  This restaurant is closed on Sundays but open the rest of the week for lunch and dinner with the same menu for both times.  Items designated "Today's Specials" are available for lunch and dinner.  Not surprisingly, it has an old-time ambiance that is really comfortable.  

This restaurant does not take reservations.  However, you can call in and ask for approximate wait times.  

The entrance leads to the barroom.  At the head of the bar a host takes names for seating.  Note that customers must be waitlisted for both the dining room and for the bar.  The bar is long and divided in half by a brass railing for drinks exclusively on one side and for meals on the other side.

After calling to determine the wait time, my wife and dined there on a crowded weekday evening.  We checked in with the host and had about a 10-minute wait for a stool at the bar where we each had a drink.  (My wife sat and I squeezed in next to her.) We were also put on the list for the dining room and after about 20 minutes were notified when a table for us was ready.

My wife had the grilled crab cakes with rice and vegetables.  I had the cioppino, the restaurant's signature dish, which is a seafood stew made with a tomato-based sauce and an assortment of shell fish and also white fish.  My wife thought her food was very well made with fresh ingredients and very flavorful although a bit on the rich side.  My meal was expertly prepared with extremely fresh ingredients and was sensational!  It was very filling but tasted so good that after devouring it I wanted more.  I enjoyed this extraordinary dish so much that it has become one of my all-time favorites.  The bar and dining service was professional and efficient as well as unhurried.

We had a fabulous dining experience at the Tadich Grill, and I most strongly recommend it for its throwback but very enjoyable atmosphere, excellent service, and most of all for its marvelous food.
author: Michael D.

description: Wonderful dinner for large family party on a very busy night! Best service ever from Alvin and his crew. He made our hungry crowd laugh and enjoy our evening even more. Food was fabulous as were the cocktails. We loved our experience here!
author: Roy R.

description:
I spent three days eating incredible food all around San Francisco, and yet, the cioppino I had at Tadich Grill stands out as the highlight.  I love the history of this restaurant, and really love the long lunch counter and the impeccable service and attention to detail.

The cioppino is the show stopper though.  I have never had so much fresh seafood in a bowl of cioppino in all my life.  I posted a picture of the cioppino.  It is mouth watering just to look at it.  Bring your appetite as it is a really, really big meal.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Although I had intended to have some sort of steak for dinner, when I asked the bartender what he would recommend he pointed out only seafood dishes. So I quickly came aware that Tadich is more of a seafood restaurant. From the bartenders recommendation, I ordered the seafood cioppino. It was a tomato soup-like dish with a plethora of seafood (ie shrimp, scallops, mussels, clams, lobster, while fish pieces, etc). I loved the flavor of the broth, but it definitely had a lot of garlic. I love garlic though so it was super tasty to me. The garlic bread was also delicious: buttery and garlicky just the way garlic bread should be. They also give you a chunk of delicious sourdough when you sit down. This was a lot of food and I couldn't finish it all. Although I couldn't take the left over seafood (no fridge) I did ask to take the rest of the bread. Instead of wrapping up the piece I had been served the bartender cut a fresh piece with no slices since it would keep better for me. 

While I was eating I noticed a lot of people that came in to eat at the bar seemed to have some sort of connection with a bartender. I don't know if this was coincidental or if there are a lot of regulars in general but I thought that was pretty cool. 

Overall, the food was delicious and the bartender was friendly. Great dinning experience!
author: Jenny F.

description:
The food was okay. Don't order steak they don't how to cook it. Took it back twice while the person I was with already finished their food. Ciopino & calamari are good. 

Also, don't expect a friendly vibe. All servers are rude & arrogant. Especially the bartender who made us wait double the time. If you see a guy with salt and pepper slicked back hair. Don't waste your time talking to him. 

Overall I wouldn't recommend to my friends.
author: Marissa H.

description:
They will ask you to leave immediately upon putting your fork down on the table. They are extremely busy, loud, and rude. Some of us loved the meals we got and other meals were just not cooked well. 

The place feels very old school inside and it's pretty neat, but there are just too many other options in San Francisco where you will not need to settle for less.
author: Katherine J.

description: Whenever I'm in town for business or fun, I always make a bee-line to the Tadich my first night in. Sitting at the bar with a dish of Calamari and a Grasshopper to drink is pretty much my definition of Heaven on Earth. Have a back-up in case the crowds are too big, but once in it can't be beat for a wonderful low-key night in San Francisco.
author: Stephen C.

description:
I love cioppino and order whenever it is on a menu. Tadich has the best cioppino I have tasted. The broth is flavorful and complex which is hard because a lot of time cioppino broth is very one note (tomato). I like that the crab is served cracked already because as much as I love crab, I hate cracking it especially when it has been sitting in a piping hot broth. The portion is generous enough for two people.

This place is good food simply done with matter of fact service. Don't come expecting to be fawned over and be prepared to wait. If possible call ahead or have your hotel call ahead and get your name on the waiting list. Saves time.
author: Annie B.

description:
Tadich Grill: One of San Francisco's oldest establishments.  You can definitely feel that San Franciscan charm from the minute you first walk in - refined, traditional, and simply classic.  

Tidbits:
- Sit at the bar.  The waiters/bartenders are really friendly, plus you don't have to endure the wait!
- Traditional menu, prices are a bit steep.  Feels more like you're paying for the experience of dining at one of SF's oldest establishments.
- Definitely an older business crowd, or may that's just because I usually go for lunch on a weekday.
- I do recommend their creamy New England clam chowder.  It's perfect for the many cold and foggy days in SF.
- Cioppino was good, but not the best I've had, contrary to what many think.  It was too salty for me.  However, there was definitely plenty of it.  Oh, and the garlic bread.. yum
- I love the 'old school' waiters with their white coats, curled mustaches, and spectacles.  Ok, maybe they don't have the stache and the spectacles, but you get the picture.
- Bathroom is a bit out of the way.. really..

Overall: 3.5 stars
author: Cecilia S.

description: Had the pan fried rainbow trout, it was good fresh. Large portion with side included. Fresh hot sourdough bread melts in your mouth. Others with me had large portion shrimp salad. Everyone left happy and full.
author: AL H.

description:
Came here for lunch for a business trip.  You walk in and it's buzzing with people.  The old guy behind the counter takes down your name and gives you an approximate wait time.

We waited maybe 30 minutes for a table, but sometimes long waits translates to good food.  And good food this place was.

I got a bowl of clam chowder to start off with.  Lots of clams so that's always good.  I hate it when it becomes 99% potatoes and 1% clams.  Here, every spoonful until the end, I had clams.  I also got some dish where I was given the entire fish.  I was thinking maybe a small filet, but this was the entire fish.  Came with some snow peas and fries.  The fries were really hard.  Luckily, I wasn't craving fries at the time.

Great food.  Small place, but the food is awesome.
author: Sedine S.

description:
Trust me, just order the cioppino and everything will be wonderful!!!

When are they going to hire some women though?!  Isn't this a lawsuit waiting to happen?
author: e w.

description:
Food, ambiance and character all warrant 4 stars.

Service warrants one. I came to Tadich to celebrate the upcoming departure of a friend from the Bay. We told the barman/host that we would be joined by a friend shortly and we're looking for drinks as we waited. 

He offered to seat us at a table. We accepted, and after ordering drinks were told quite rudely by our server that we MUST order food as they did not seat incomplete parties.

The fact that they had in fact seated an incomplete party seemed lost on him. He would not let us order an appetizer and wait for our friend, nor a second round of drinks - but demanded we order food. 

We did. And when I relayed my dismay at our poor service to the manager, he haughtily informed me that his server was correct and that this rule had "been what made them successful for 167 years". This line he repeated twice, and literally told me he did not care that I had a bad experience. His words were "some people like it, some people don't". 

He's right. I don't appreciate poor or arrogant service hidden behind a facade of some ancient pedigree of excellence. I will never again patronize this establishment. Clearly they do not need folks like me to run a "great" restaurant.
author: Ja G.

description: There was Nothing really .good. i went there depending on foursquare reviews .. and it was really not good at all. From the waiter at the entrance till the waiter on the table ... the food was ordinary and even tasteless ... i really advice you not to go there... and there was a minimum charge
author: Nahid A.

description: Had the ciopinno and it was really disappointing. Broth was not flavorful, and the seafood didnt taste fresh. Also ordered the dungenous crab ala moda, not good. Service was not the best either. For an $80 lunch, highly dissapointed.
author: Amanda S.

description: Oh I forgot had I had clam chowder. Very tasty. Lots of ingredients. I'd have it again.
author: Nancy F.

description:
This place really wasn't what I expected. Server seemed extremely rushed and seemed to not even care about us. Older white guy white hair. Food was tasteless and not what I expected for a 40 something dollar steak. We ordered it well done and it came in medium rare.  The shrimp casserole was also tasteless and the shrimps were so small I couldn't even tell they were shrimp. Expected large shrimps with spicy seasoning since it was called "diabla" 
Extra star for private ish booths
author: Alex G.

description: From the moment we walked in we were  greeted with a warm welcome and a smile. The restaurant was very busy, but we only had a short time to wait at the bar. Food and service was excellent. I enjoyed the sea bass and my husband had the to try the cioppino that everyone talks about he was not disappointed. I would def come here again.
author: Liana H.

description:
Tadich is awesome! Old school restaurant with seafood cooked to perfection.

Service was not the quickest for lunch, but the food was tasty! 

I tried the deep fried soft shell crab w/ salmon and hearts of romaine.  The crab was fried well, and the salmon was just cooked to perfection.  Nice and pink, tender!!

The seafood bouillabaisse was delicious too! Large shrimp, scallops, mussels, clams, and fish in a nice tomato like sauce perfect for bread dipping!  Yummmy! The seafood was soo fresh and tender... 

I crave more seafood after eating here!! I can't wait to come back! 

Tadich is a tad bit pricy for lunch, but Ooo soo good!! :)  I'm glad I finally got to try it!!
author: Tramy V.

description:
Best cioppino I've ever had, by far! Every piece of seafood was succulent & fresh down to the piece of Dungeness. It comes with a standard crostini in a savory tomato base. A must in San Francisco.

They claim to be the oldest restaurant in SF! 

I'll definitely be back for the cioppino soon
author: David L.

description: Called to ask if I could make a reservation (I didn't see that it wasn't possible) and was answered with this, "NO f***ing put your name on the list." Guess I won't be putting my name on the list. :)
author: Krissy J.

description: Great place to check out for sure with a lot of history too. It's actually fairly reasonably priced too for seafood. Everything was extremely fresh. Jumbo shrimp to die for.
author: James W.

description:
This place was exactly as described. Chose it after seeing Anthony Bordain eat an oyster and bacon omelette while drinking a martini at the bar. There were so many other items on the menu that I wanted but decided to go for what they are known for , the seafood Cioppino with garlic bread. Best I've ever eaten!!  They do not skimp on the seafood.  Fish, crab, shrimp, mussels, clams and more in every bite and plenty for take home. The martini was perfect. Dessert... Usually don't order but had to indulge. The tiramisu was light and not too espresso bitter. 
The previous comments about service- the wait staff is knowledgable, cordial and efficient just what I like. When on a date I don't want a chatty drop in waiter hovering every bite. Can't wait to go back.
author: Rob D.

description: I made my second visit to this venerable establishment yesterday, and I was very happy with my decision to return.  On my previous visit, I'd ordered the cioppino, which was excellent, but I wanted to try something new, so I ordered the seafood saute; the crab, prawns, and scallops in a cream sauce were all delicious. Also, my dining partner ordered the cioppino, and he pronounced it excellent as well.  I also ordered a Caesar salad, which was fine but nothing special.  The reason for 4 stars and not 5 was that the service was pretty slow and inattentive.  Perhaps this was due to being seated at the bar instead of a regular table.  Overall, I'd like to return on my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Robert M.

description:
This place is old school -- right down to the well lit room.  Without question, it has a truly top-flight seafood menu -- and the signature Cioppino is about the size of three full entrees.

It's one of those places that many people make sure they hit while visiting SF -- and those that do generally do it right:  they sit at the counter.  Who needs a table at this place?!
author: Rick W.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night around 5:45 with a party of 4, expected wait time of an hour and a half (they don't take reservations) but we had expected that. You wait alongside the bar, and if seats open up, it's first come first serve to eat there which we were able to do. The atmosphere is fun and old timey. 

The food, however, isn't that spectacular - it seems like any other overpriced seafood restaurant you would find on Fisherman's Wharf. And to top it off, it gave me the worlds worst food poisoning. It's fun to say you went to the oldest restaurant in California, but not if it left you on the bathroom floor for the next 12 hours...
author: Anoushka D.

description: This is a great restaurant.  The staff was always professional and they anticipate your needs.  You don't need to ask for water they know to come ask for water before you will.  The food is excellent.  Top notch.  This a great place to take business clients or a date.
author: Allen B.

description:
This place must be surviving on reputation alone, because the host/waitstaff aren't worried about pissing off prospective diners.

My bf and I stopped by for lunch after running some errands on a Saturday afternoon. There was no line, and we were greeted and told that the wait would be 20-25 minutes for a table. There was a group of four guys also waiting to be seated who arrived after we did and when they heard that the wait would be 20-25 minutes, they turned around to leave. However, the host told the group of four he could seat them right away. Which means he could've seated *US* right away as well, but chose not to. We decided to leave and we won't be returning - for the markup, I expected more class and better service. I'll make my own bacon and oyster frittata!!!
author: Bella L.

description:
I get it that SF is one of the premier foodie snob cities in N. America and can only assume that this is the root of some of the 1 and 2 star reviews of Tadich Grill. 

This foodie snob from the great state of NC won't be duped however. I've had better meals than what's to be had at Tadich. In San Fran certainly. But also in NYC, and hell even in Charlotte. But that doesn't mean that the Cioppino I always order at Tadich isn't frigging great cause it is!  To dip that crunchy garlic toast in that broth, chock full of seafood is to know savory joy. This is good stuff!

Add to it the professional service from well trained servers and a nice stiff drink and all I can say is life is good.  As Arnold told his housekeeper, I'll be back...
author: Tom C.

description:
This was 1 of the quickest & best seafood dinners I've ever had! As well as 1 of the best vintage San Francisco places to eat, established in 1849 (?).

Loved the Seafood Medley of sea scallops, crab, & prawns! Melted in m' mouth. Not sure if the sauce was Gluten Free - didn't ask.

The bone-in ribeye was a delicious Gluten Free option, cooked exactly to order!
author: Ariane S.

description: This place was absolutely amazing. The food was great and our server Barry was the best!
author: Tony V.

description: This has been one of my favorite restaurants in the world for years.  The food is always great, though extremely filling.  The service with an attitude is what it is.  It's a little slice of restaurant history.  I never miss the opportunity of eating here when in the Bay area.
author: Roscoe T.

description:
A friend had me over for drinks as we watched "Streets of San Francisco" - the 70s detective TV drama series set in the city with a young Michael Douglas, some tight pants, and an expressway over the Embarcadero. I could've swore I saw the Tadich Grill in it. Not surprising considering it is one of the oldest businesses in California. 

Not that it's a bad thing. You feel like you're nostalgically stepping back in time the moment you walk into the restaurant. It's the old-school fussy SF dining experience but something to definitely try because service here is extremely attentive to say the least. 

Like the Mad Men we are, lunch started with some martinis and big prawn and dungeness crab cocktails. Nothing extraordinary here but the seafood was definitely fresh and tasty. I had the Ahi Tuna (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WxxE5kE8omgQhJE8sWIvmA?select=CLU9u86IviLcVu3V0YAW4g) which came with a big mound of wakaname seaweed and a side salad. The fish had a nice char on the outside and the slight sweetness of the seaweed was a nice counterpoint to the meaty fish. All in all, it was an enjoyable meal. Or maybe that was the martinis talking. 

Tadich Grill is just one of those places where you have to go to check off your list. The food is good though not spectacular but the place is absolutely charming in how it has stood the test of time. Coupled with the personal service, dining here is quite the treat.
author: Jon L.

description:
My crab cake was fantastic. I asked the waiter about having sea bass or Pacific Red Snapper. He stated that the sea bass is much better, so I got the sea bass. The sea bass was a little small for the price point. However, the taste was perfect. One problem: the little shrimp that came with the sea bass, and no joke it really is a little shrimp, was not cooked. I called the waiter over and he said: "That's not cooked, don't eat it. I will get you a new shrimp. Sorry." When he came back, he apologized again. He was a really good waiter.

I would definitely eat hear again.
author: Robert S.

description:
There are restaurants with innovative menus, chefs who slaughter their own rabbits and grow their own produce.  We have grown accustomed to local cheeses, artisan baked bread, farm-fresh eggs, heirloom tomatoes and molecular gastronomy.  Beautiful, hand-crafted, house-cured, local, sustainable and organic is de rigueur... 
Unless you are  Tadich Grill.  

In which case, you disregard everything I just wrote, and change for no one. 

Last night, I walked a section of California and with a few strides, went back in time: beyond the supremely young and upbeat  Barbacco; past my beloved Perbacco's celebrated food and exemplary service... To the Oldest Restaurant in San Francisco.  

I'd already grazed my way through the Ferry Building, but I was feeling the chill, and a drink from the bar sounded nice.  "Drink, drink, who needs a drink?  Whooo... Needs a drink?" was the convivial welcome from the white-jacketed bartenders for patrons to belly up to the dark wood bar. 

Bartenders are seasoned veterans who move at lightening speed up and down behind the counter, deftly avoiding collisions and other injuries one normally associates with hockey while vigorously shaking martinis for vodka-voiced matriarchs and bastions of the Suit and Tie sets.

My beverage was a Decaf Bailey's and instantly warmed me up.  As I sipped, the din dissolved into a pleasant cacophony of clattering dishes.  I pondered the menu, stocked with the usual suspects, and decided to proceed with caution after the kitchen hollered to Peetie  that the pasta special was  "Noodles"   He laughed, shrugging, "Whaddaya gonna do?"  

I ordered a side of "noodles" dressed in olive oil and garlic.  Shortly thereafter, I was rewarded with a platter of flaccid spaghetti, baptized in olive oil and piled high with minced garlic.  Hmmmmm.

The Dungeness Crab Cocktail ($16.25) tempted me because it's local and in season - it was served in a sundae glass, with just a bit of lettuce and two dollops of cocktail sauce, with more on the side.  What a delicious indulgence!  It's probably the very best I've had in a long time: bright, clean, fresh and sweet.

Not a hint of that ammonia-frozen taste or smell... My only concern was that there were some fingernail-sized chunks of shell and cartilage still in the cocktail, so I had to spit, sputter and pick my way through, cautiously.  I really just wanted to inhale the gorgeous thing, so in the end, it was probably better that I was able to savor it longer.

The cocktail was a bit underwhelming, and Peetie did offer to remake it with some different liqueurs and turn it into a really snazzy drink for me.  His pitch was very much appreciated and  sounded absolutely delicious.  I did not take him up on it, since I did not want the first drink to be wasted.  

I can imagine myself coming by again for the experience and maybe another Dungeness Crab Cocktail before the primo season is over.  Tadich has set a new standard for the simple, beautiful pleasure of sweet crustaceans.

There are other more glamorous, inventive places I could enjoy this straightforward treat... But I'm going to enjoy an oldie but goodie at this oldie but goodie.

"Whaddaya gonna do...?"
author: Kim D.

description: What can be said about this place that hasn't already been said. The Cioppino is amazing. The bread is perfectly sour and slightly rough needing some hot soup dipping :) warms you up on a cold day and keeps you warm all night. Can not recommend highly enough.
author: Jaye P.

description:
This restaurant blew my girlfriend and I away! The service, the food, the atmosphere....stunning!

You really couldn't find a better Cioppino anywhere in the Bay Area. The freshness of the seafood and the flavors of the broth is captivating. Mussels, clams, crab, shrimp, fish, scallops and 2 large pieces of garlic bread for dipping! There is nothing this dish is lacking. Just try not to burn your tongue, it is served piping hot! 

Another favorite is the Tadich Platter. A cold appetizer dish that gives you a taste of everything Tadich Grill has to offer! Smoked salmon, calamari salad, crab meat, prawns, raw oysters, smoked trout, pickled herring and anchovies, all on a bed of mixed greens, avocados, tomatoes, onions and capers. 

Truly a seafood lover's paradise!!!  Also, Tadich Grill is probably San Francisco's oldest restaurant!
author: Philip K.

description: Classic bar with okay bartenders. Very old school. Great to grab a regular drink. Our bartender was friendly although some staff members coming into their shift seemed a bit unprofessional  to me but other than that great little place to pop in for a cocktail. I don't know if I would eat here though.
author: Angie S.

description:
Sure, it's old school, it's an SF institution, it's historical, blah blah. But really, yelp friends, there's not that much to rave about. The food is standard all American seafood joint but what gets me in he door at lunch is the location - next to my office.

Yelpers, the line is crazy between 11-12:30. Lunch rush - gulp! Wait until 1, it's worth it.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Perfect size Martinis. Small enough that they stay cold, perfectly dirty. First one had 2 olives, second only had 1. 

-1 olive.
author: Gregory P.

description: Tried the oysters Rockefeller, which were quite cheesy and delicious. For entrees we got the seafood sauté which had a delicious white wine and  mushroom sauce and came with rice and veggies. Also had the grilled swordfish steak with veggies and potatoes but this overall was pretty average and a bit dry. It was like something I might cook for myself: not bad, fairly healthy but not something I'd tell my friends they needed to try. Skipped dessert because the couple next to us said their bread pudding was cold and they left half of it in the plate.
author: Emily L.

description:
I came here before a show at the Punchline for Fathers day with my dad and his GF. I can see why the place has been open for so long. We sat at the bar and had a cocktail before dinner, and really enjoyed our bartenders. 

We sat in the back near the kitchen, but hardly noticed it, as opposed to some restaurants where that is the worst seat in the house. My clam chowder was fantastic. I had the Petrale Sole, which was solid, but a little plain. I am not the biggest fish eater, so I won't put that on the restaurant - I probably should have ordered halibut! 

I would go back! Fun night out, like turning the clock back 40 years. Truly a San Francisco treat!
author: Sam A.

description: After walking the golden bridge i was starving we ended here be ready for a wait.. the bartender was rude when he over herd my conversation about the mix reviews on one of their items on their menu when i told him i read it on yelp! Implied that i never been anywhere .. any how we ended up having dinner we had clam showder and oyster rokerfeller for app wich both where very good. . Main course was chilean seabass with vegetables and rice the vegetables where my favorite  3 broccoli, coliflower, and Brussel sprouts cooked aldente also came with rice tasted like uncle bens rice to me wich was a downer... me and wife both had old fashion wich where good.. will i come back? No
author: Vic C.

description: Love this place for the awesome set up with one side with bag seating the length of the restaurant and tables on the other. Loved the Mediterranean White Branzino Sea Bass and the Seafood Sauté! The Bourbon Bread Pudding was alright - dense and heavy and certainly a dish to share. I'm coming back for sure!
author: Stan L.

description: Beautiful decor. Rich in San Francisco tradition. Good service. Tasty food. We had a party of 7 and we're sat with no waiting. Off the main track which was a plus!
author: MC S.

description: What can I say that I haven't already said or written about this wonderful SF institution....I had dinner here two nights in a row. Start off with a drink and a great story from Pete your lively bartender and then a great meal of the best chippino, sole, sand dabs or just anything on this great big menu. The ambiance is old SF and a style of service too few have.  I can't wait to get back to my Tadich.....keep a bar stool open for me.
author: Jeff G.

description:
***UPDATE***
Spoke with the GM today  and left the conversation very satisfied knowing that this restaurant takes critiques like this very seriously. They promptly addressed the situation and have been very kind with us about trying to rectify the situation.

___________________________________________________
If this place wasn't so legendary and historic and have some of the most amazing food in the city, I would've given it a one star. 

My family (myself and my two senior citizen parents) just had the worst experience with one of their bartenders, Pete. He verbally abused my father as he asked for a drink. All people around were shocked by this mans completely unwarranted outburst. Telling my dad to get his hands off the bar, get out of the way, and "I have 14 other drink orders, I don't need your hand waving around in the air."!And then the worst part was that he made our drinks & served them with such animosity and was asking us if "happy now?!" In the most rood manner.

This was such a shock because this place is known for great waiters. I was hoping he wasn't just a complete asshole, but then he just turned around to another couple w/ all smiles.Completely night and day. So stunned by this.

And to top it all off, it's my parents anniversary dinner. 

Pete needs to be addressed by managers because that kind of attitude does not match the level of excellence this place usually exudes.
author: Benjamin S.

description: Sometimes history is not enough. The staff are rude and the food is just out dated and plain awful. There are so many great restaurants in SF, but this is not one.
author: Jenny B.

description: Came here for a business lunch.  We shared the seafood platter which was a nice spread; definitely tasted fresh.  I personally ordered the seared ahi tuna lunch special.  The tuna was seared perfectly and were huge/plentiful pieces.  The salad underneath was good as well, complete with arugula, avocado, and artichokes - great combo.  The bloody mary was supposed to be famous but I was underwhelmed.  It wasn't horrible but I wouldn't order it again.  Ambiance is great - very classic.  We sat in a booth so it was very private.  Definitely want to come back again and try some of the other stuff cause their menu is huge!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
5 stars on food
2 stars on service

Love this place, I eat here every time I'm in the city, I bring my friends, and recommend it to others. I always order the samething, the lobster Thermidor. It's such a satisfying dish. I noticed this time they've cut back considerably on the sides - there was one potato fry and no veges. They did give bread and the bread is excellent. And a few other items I've tried in the past have all been excellent. 

My on going complaint, and particularly of the last 2 dining experiences is the service and how rushed I felt. The waiter kept pushing me and my friend out the door - a rush to order, rush to eat - I was not even offered dessert or a wine refill, and he brought my check without being asked. I even commented to him that he was rushing me, but it didn't seem to matter. Regardless of what time you go, prepare to eat in a hurry. The food is delicious but you hardly get to enjoy it because you're stressing out about the line of people waiting for a seat. Tadich staff seem more interested in turning tables and making money than actually offering repeat/loyal customers the time to appreciate the efforts they put into their wonderful food. Disappointing.
author: Shelley C.

description: Atmosphere great, bar staff terrific, all our food was wonderful, wait staff could be a little less rushed and should have asked us if we wanted coffee and dessert (handed us the check and we then asked to see dessert menu) - overall a very good experience but they do need to get the wait staff to pay attention just a tad more to the clientele.
author: Denise B.

description:
No bull$$hit, no frills seafood.

Cioppino.
Cioppino.
Cioppino.
Cioppino.

Just get your name on the list and wait off to the side. Listen and pay attention carefully for your name to be called. 

WAIT
WAIT
WAIT

Once it is, scurry on over to your seat and order. 

EAT CIOPPINO because it is FULL of seafood. They do not skimp. Crab legs and claws, tons of fish, clams, mussels, all they need is to give me more of that delicious crusty garlicky buttery garlic bread so sop up that beautiful rich tomato broth.

Do me a favor and get out so I can eat, thanks.
author: Susy C.

description: favorite place to eat in SF.  The Cioppino is the best I have ever had.  I also recommend the clam chowder.
author: Phil H.

description:
I keep falling in love with this place. The dark wood alcoves. The white waiter uniforms. The best long branch potatoes, unequaled. 
But the seafood always delivers, like the pan roasted sand dabs or Lobster Thermidor. Classic, and just getting better with each dining experience.
author: Richard B.

description:
A San Francisco institution that delivers on the hype. Not the greatest seafood I've ever had, but definitely a solid meal in a memorable setting. The clam chowder was outstanding, and the seafood cioppino hearty and delicious. But what really makes this place stand out is the atmosphere. It's the oldest restaurant in San Fran (although not always at this location), and the white-jacketed waiters and bartenders add to the old-school experience. 

Tadich Grill is also a GREAT place to eat if you're looking for a place to dine solo, as I was when I visited. Sit at the long bar (it's first-come, first-serve - so don't be shy about jumping in when a seat opens up), melt into the crowd, and enjoy one of the best dining experiences the city has to offer.
author: Joe P.

description: Love the old school ambiance! The staff is awesome and food is to die for! We ordered the cosmopolitan salad which delicious and exceeded my expectations; The calamari both fried & the steak were delicious and tender as well as the pasta with meat sauce! Nobody left disappointed. I had been here once as a kid with my grandma and it was just the same as I remember 30 years later!
author: Lea M.

description:
We went with a party if 4 at 2pm and were seated quickly.  The waiter was ok and the service was fast.  The rest of the party had pan fried fish and it looked and tasted great.  I had the prime rib.  The vegetables and mashed potatoes were good.  The meat tasted good however it was an EXTREMELY fatty cut.

No interest in resolution from the restaurant.  For the price, don't think I'd go back.
author: Nate W.

description:
If I were a fine GQ looking young man, where would I eat? 

At Tadich Grill apparently.

This place is filled with men. I was like the only girl in the restaurant all of the handful of times I've been here. And the men who eat here are pretty attractive (actually maybe only one or two was each time, so I wouldn't go here just for that, but I felt the need to point it out as I rarely ever notice guys anymore, especially when I'm with someone, but this place makes me notice them)


Food wise, this place is delicious! There was a good amount of years where I just didn't like eating seafood (other than sushi) so this place was a great way to ease me back into seafood as the food didn't taste too seafood-y.

My two favorite dishes here are:
      - Cioppino - I'm sure you can tell by skimming the rest of the Yelp reviews that this dish is the way to go, and it is.
      - Seafood Sauté - This dish was very simple, but tasty and leaves you feeling just the right amount of full. It had shrimp and scallops sauteed with some mushrooms and then veggies on the side and rice with wine. 

After my first time eating here, I wanted to give this place 5 stars. However, I think after coming here again and again, some of the dishes were overly rich and some too buttery, so I give it 4 stars. 

The only thing I'm really not feeling about this place is the waiters' uniforms. They look like lab scientists. I understand that they're trying to preserve the old fashioned look, so I guuuess. But other than that, love this place and the historicness and manliness of it.
author: Jeanie F.

description:
Just ate dinner after a very very long wait. Lots of fruit flies hovering around. Super "fishy" tasting food. Veggies were like from a senior center. Crab cakes ( hard to screw up) were awful. Calamari must have been supplied by a bait shop.
The sourdough bread was the only delicious part.
Not worth the long wait.
author: K D.

description: Never a dull moment waiting for a table or squeezing up to the bar.  Dishes are classic and yummy.  Generous portions, so the prices are not that bad.   Staff is impeccable.
author: Kathy K.

description:
I'm a first time Tadich Grill customer.   I stopped by last night with my wife and daughter (wife's B-day).  We arrived about 8pm or so and the place was relatively busy (~60%) but we were able to be seated right away in a cozy booth.  The food was fantastic!   The atmosphere was classic and upscale.   The service however...unfortunately not so good for us and this was a disappointment as I was a really memorable dining experience.   

We shared a crabcake as a appetizer and it was the best ever!  Our entrees came out relatively quickly and we each were impressed by and enjoyed our dishes.  The service however started to breakdown once the food was on the table after which our server was nowhere to be found.   Fortunately after the food was delivered we really didn't need anything but I certainly noticed that the server never bothered to check on us.  After we finished our food one of the guys (not a server) cleared the table and we found ourselves waiting for a dessert menu.   After I couldn't take it anymore I flagged down any server and just requested a dessert menu which was given to me right away.   I assume there was some server to server communication because within a minute or so our guy shows up and asked if we'd like to order a dessert.  I asked him if he'd forgotten about us and he said he had not forgotten about us but he had other tables to attend to.  I understood this poor excuse for poor service to mean that it was more important for him deliver good service to his other table than to our table.  Nonetheless, if he didn't realize that I/we felt we weren't getting adequate service...the fact that I told him I thought he forgot about us should have put him on notice.  

Our dessert was delivered timely (Bourbon Bread Pudding) and it was great but again I found myself waiting for the server and the check.  At this point I was kind of over it...I just wanted to settle up and get out of there because this guy was really starting to work my nerves.

When I finally got the server I just asked for the check (and gave him my credit card) which he brought quickly but when looking it over I realized that he'd charged me for a $38 steak that we didn't order.  Pointed out the "mistake" and he quickly agreed that it was something we didn't order.   It took him 10 to 15 minutes to go an resolve the check issue which tried to explain was the result of another party wanting separate checks?  He also stated that even though the $38 steak was on our bill we weren't actually charged for it.  

In summary, the food was outstanding but the service was at best a comedy of errors.  I'd actually like to go back and give them a try again (the food was that good).  I'd like to think that my experience was an anomaly...a restaurant doesn't enjoy as much success for so long as has the Tadich Grill unless they know how to delivering great food with great service.
author: Michael H.

description:
best meal i had in a long time.

let me try to sum this up as quickly as i can.

1. great vibe/ambiance
2. great customer service -- Pete the bartender (AWESOME!), Aaron and Jan too! 
3. waited for a while but the only reason why was my friend got off at 6pm but if you get there by 6pm you should be fine. of course 7pm is PRIME time.
4. vintage style restaurant
5. oldest restaurant in SF
6. STRONG DRINKS - try to find a seat at the bar if you have to wait. bartenders are super nice 
7. THE FOOD
8. Cioppino ---- i want more!!
9. SEABASS
10. I WANT TO COME HERE AGAIN AND EAT SEABASS AND CIOPPINO! 

:)
author: Carol Y.

description:
I'm a sucker for seafood, it's no secret. When my friend Bernadette R. told me she was meeting me for lunch first thing in the morning and was craving crab, all productivity and concentration went out the window. I picked a place close to my office known for fresh seafood. 

The last time I came here was for a work lunch, they said "Order whatever you want Rebekah.... ", which I said "Thanks, I'll have the Lobster Thermidor". It was rich and quite delicious, but this time I had crab on my mind this time around.

We arrived a little after twelve, trying to beat the lunch rush and there was already a line for seats. Bar stools are first come first serve, as soon as one opened up I was on it like a hawk. After being seated, we were served fresh sourdough bread - nice big crusty and doughy soft sourdough with chilled butter.

Since we were in the mood to share and try a little of everything, we ordered the Seafood Appetizer Platter ($21) which had oysters, crab, smoked salmon, smoked trout, calamari, shrimp, anchovies, avocado, tomato, cheese and lettuce. This is a huge plate and great for snacking. 

For our main course we split the Deep Fried Crab Legs platter ($31), shell-less crab meat breaded and fried served with broccoli and Yukon gold potatoes. I'm not big into fried food, but these were not greasy and very delicious.

I have to say the House Cocktail sauce mixed with their Horseradish is the perfect dipping sauce for all seafood. There is nothing like fresh sauce to go with your fresh fish or seafood.  

We left full and happy. I went back to work, just knowing that I scored big at lunch. I can't wait to go back, I was staring down the Crab Louie sitting next to me and next time - he's MINE.
author: Rebekah T.

description: The Cioppino is amazing. Old restaurant steeped in tradition and they are proud of it. Excellent seafood in general. No wonder it's been around for so long. A must visit when in San Francisco.
author: Joe C.

description:
I'm surprised that with my many trips to S.F. over the last few years that I've not been here.  A classic dining experience, with old, dark walls, big booths (surprisingly private), starched shirt wait staff.  A big menu, lots going on.
 The service was great, pretty much flawless.  Bread was awesome.  
 We were there for a late lunch, I had the pot roast, which I think was listed as a lunch.  A huge portion, and wonderfully tasty.  Halfway through, I told myself I needed to stop... and did for a while, but ended up eating it all, as the taste, texture, flavor was not to be missed or denied.
 I was there with clients and I can't report too much on their meals, but there wasn't much left on any of the plates when we were done!
 Highly recommended.
author: Tom C.

description: I loved the atmosphere and the food.
author: Tim O.

description:
Ate here Friday night about 6:30. The place was very busy and loud. We needed a table for 3 and had about a 20 minute wait at the bar. Tables for 2 were much faster than for 3.
It was WORTH the wait. The food was wonderful and the service was excellent. I had pacific red snapper with bay shrimp and a tomato and anchovy salad. The salad was unique and I will have to try to make something similar as I love anchovies. My wife and daughter shared a shrimp bisque. Rich, creamy and flavorful but lacking in shrimp pieces. My wife had scallops and my daughter had the Cioppino. Both were very happy with their selections. 
An old school restaurant with delicious food. We were very satisfied customers. We will go back on our next trip to SF.
author: Ed V.

description: A must visit place whenever we are in San Francisco!!! We went there two straight days in a row! Their chippino is out of the world good and the seafood platter is amazing. Our waiter worked there longer than I have lived and he was absolutely one of the best. It is so packed any given day and the price is not too bad considering how great the food is. It is actually a very good deal in a major city for such a high quality seafood! Love love love this place and this place is the reason why you keep thinking about the city you visited for years!!!
author: Sujin J.

description:
We were running in the San Francisco rain towards a German restaurant called Schroeder's located around the corner. It wasn't going to be open for another 1.5 hours so we needed shelter for our heads and empty stomachs. We looked towards the sky at falling raindrops and drifting clouds. We looked peripherally and saw a welcoming restaurant with a wooden/quaint interior design housing servers dressed in white coats and white hair.

Anyway, we tried the $30 Ciopinno and a bowl of their Clam Chowder. As much hype as this place gets, I don't think either of these dishes are stellar. They are average to my taste buds. The Ciopinno red sauce wasn't as flavorful as I hoped. The chowder seemed to be overpowered by potatoes. If I had to come back for some reason, I for sure wouldn't order these again. Go to Fisherman's Wharf for some good Boston clam chowder.

The servers could smile more. I mean they did their jobs well, but damn how about some service with a smile. It doesn't matter how old you are, if you were in customer service, you must be happy and smile no matter what. If you can't do that, then work somewhere else that better suits you. I'm also thinking that they've worked there for so long and don't really make that much money in San Francisco so how could they smile. I know this is really irrelevant but I mean this is my experience and you'll probably see the same thing. I guess this place is not Disneyland.

Nonetheless, I can't say that they don't serve fresh seafood and there's lots of SF history here so that might warrant at least one visit here to understand/feel/experience the calming/homely SF vibe.
author: Marlon T.

description: Stopped here for a terrific old fashioned. This place is clearly a local favorite, and it was nice to take in this experience shortly before leaving San Fran.
author: Cherine F.

description:
Oh, Tadich Grill - we could have had a beautiful relationship, but now I will never know. This review is based purely upon the shocking customer service I received from your bartender there today. 

My boyfriend and I planned to meet at 4:30, but I finished work early and thought I would go ahead of him to sit and have a drink and wait for him there. When I walked in, I was greeted by the bartender who snidely asked me if I was lost by way of a joke. I said no and that I was there to meet someone in an hour but wanted a drink and to get an appetizer. I asked for a table and he told me that I couldn't be seated at a table. I asked why and he said because the rest of my party wasn't there. 

1) so Tadich grill, you don't seat people at a table if they're a party of one? I don't think so. I'm not a 16 year old who was going to drink your water and eat your bread and loiter around. You lost out on not just the cocktails and dinner we were going to have today, but on future dinners we would have had there. 

2)  get someone who greets patrons with warmth and sincerity instead of thinly veiled hostility.
author: Brynley W.

description: Went there with my girlfriend for lunch, it seemed like we were somewhat ignored, and service was slow.  Food was decent enough, but now I understand that us being the bi-racial couple we are was the reason for the service being the way it was.  I was willing to give the place a second chance, no way I will now.  This might be the one time I would welcome a long-time San Francisco business closing down and a condo occupying its place.
author: Scott E.

description: This is a must!!! Do yourself a favor and make certain you stop by for lunch/dinner/drinks. We make it a point each time we visit the city by the bay we have at least two meals here. Fortunately we visit during a weekday in the early afternoon so there is no wait time. They do not take reservations and on Friday and Saturday nights be expected to wait quite some time. For 40+ years we have been coming to this absolutely wonderful restaurant for the greatest meal in town.  Love sitting at the counter and converse with the staff who some have been there as long as we have been going. My husband usually orders the seafood cioppino which is always the best he has ever tasted. Their claim chowder hands down is a winner. Our dinner consisted of Petrale Sole,  their Salad Special which consisted of Ahi Tuna, a couple bowls of clam chowder, their fantastic sour dough bread and a wonderful bottle of wine.  Their food is consistent in flavor and freshness. You can't beat this restaurant for food, atmosphere, service and price.
author: Pam M.

description:
I give it 4 1/2 stars.

Visited my friends and made the opportunity to go here.
I had heard about this place for years and watched Anthony Bourdain visit here and heard all the hype. It lived up to everything iv'e heard and seen about it.

Had raw oysters to start, then the (what else?) Hangtown Fry. Eggs scrambled(sorta omelet like) w/ bacon and fried oysters. F*#@*!!  awesome. We also had the SF made pils on tap.

Finally,to say the service was great is an understatement. This is real old-school bowtie and vest service.Never missing a beat. Excellent.
author: Paul C.

description: Probably one of my favorite restaurants anywhere. The old school charm and service and amazing food. You really can't beat it. The average tenure of the servers is probably 20 year. Seriously. These guys stay around forever and they exude character and humor and it really is a pleasure just to speak to them. If they're not too swamped, they enjoy shooting the bull so take some time and have fun. Ask them how long they've worked there... or what their favorite dishes are... or where they're from. Have fun with it. Oh... sand dabs are amazing. Eat that.
author: J C.

description:
For years, I have been reading about this place in the Chronicle. My daughter is home for a visit, and I invited her out yesterday for lunch and shopping in the city. I chose Tadich Grill out of curiosity and because it features fish, a favorite of my daughter's. It was a pleasant surprise that Tadich Grill is so close to the Embarcadero Bart station; the walk was quite short. We planned on arriving at 2 PM, because we did not want to wait around for a table. Our strategy paid off. The restaurant was not crowded when we arrived, and we were seated immediately. 

Ambiance: This is a white tablecloth place, but people were not dressed up. I saw a number of people in blue jeans and t-shirts and tennis shoes. Others wore coats and ties. I felt more comfortable wearing a dress and jacket, but this is 2015, and times are more casual. There are a number of larger tables for four in very private, inviting little rooms all along the west wall. I would have loved to have been seated in one of those rooms with a larger table, but I understand that those are for larger parties, even though most of those rooms were empty throughout our meal. 

Food: Perhaps I should mention up front that I am not a big fan of seafood. My daughter ordered a cup of white clam chowder and a shrimp-avocado salad, which she thoroughly enjoyed. I had an avocado salad, and I found it delightful that other items were included in the salad. As well as the lettuce and avocado, there was a radish, carrot stick, tomato wedge, large slice of cucumber and even an olive. The house dressing is delicious. I also ordered the crab cake entree, because crab cakes are a specialty of the house, and because crab is one type of seafood that I do enjoy. The crab cakes did not knock my socks off, and the side vegetables were a bit too garlicky. The waiter suggested a plate of asparagus on the side, which we both loved. My favorite item was the sour dough bread and butter. Portions were generous, and we were, as usual, unable to finish all of our food. We left with a box or two. 

Service: Somewhat efficient but not friendly. My daughter was unpleasantly surprised that freshly ground black pepper was not offered with our salads. The most annoying thing about the service was the size of the table. We were seated at a table for two, and with our appetizer, entree, side vegetable, bread, butter and drinks, we were quite crowded. I am a slow eater. I like to take my time. It is healthier to eat slowly. So our entrees came out before I had finished my salad, and there was really not enough room for everything on the table. This was not the fault of the waiter, of course, but it made the meal less pleasant and relaxing. 

Cost: It is San Francisco, so I simply expect higher prices. We both had tea. My daughter ordered one cocktail. The grand total, including tax, was $106. I think that is high, but the food was fresh and quite edible, and this is the business district of San Francisco. 

Would I return? Honestly, there are too many other choices in the city, and there were at least 3 other quite well known restaurants on the same block. Nothing that I ate at Tadich Grill made me say to myself, "I want to go back and order that again." This place is not calling me back.
author: Gail E.

description: I will say overall the food was very good,  I don't think it was such a standout for a 5 star rating.  It was a Thursday evening, arrived about 6:20 pm.  Place was busy but there was seats available at the counter but wife (her birthday) and I opted to wait for a table, only about a 15 minute wait.  Our waiter "Alvin" (I don't think  that was his real name lol) was great and smiley and joking around when after taking our order without writing it down took off before we finished .  Brought out my salad, told him wife wanted a salad too and that he took off before we finished our order, he slides my salad over to her and hurried off to get another.  We like to dine at nicer restaurants so have eaten at a lot off nice places.  Overall it was good, a little loud but we definitely are willing to eat there again when in the city.
author: Mike V.

description: amazing food. old school.  White coats. sourdough bread. fish cooked to perfection.    Fillet of petrale sole was perfect. White clam chowder was great. I can't say enough about this place. Chardonnay is Wente riva ranch. one of the oldest and best cali winerys. sour dough bread and butter. yummmm
author: David C.

description:
Been coming here for over 50 years...a San Francisco classic!  It's been the "go to" family occasion restaurant for us since my Grandad's day.
Petrale, Cioppino...whatever...Tadich;s is the restaurant I'd request if I could choose a place for my final meal.
'Nuff said.
author: Matt D.

description: I have been to Tadich many times as I had worked across the street for many years.  I miss this place since I have not worked in the Fidi.  I loved their food and atmosphere .  Where can you go to see the old world charm of servers wearing white coats and using vintage registers during this day and age?  Their bread is always crispy and I loved their crab bake.  They are always crowded during weekday lunchtimes.  The gentlemen servers are always interesting to watch working the tables and clinging the vintage registers behind the counter seating.
author: FG L.

description:
The service was good, very much like you would expect at an older establishment. Though, I didn't see any women on staff. Mostly gentlemen. Interesting.

The food was good. However the ribeye had too strong of a char on it. I thought I was biting into charcoal on some pieces of it. Though, it was juicy and deliciously fatty...cooked in point at Medium. 

The seafood sauté; for the price...ehhhh. I'm not so sure I would get it again. The pieces of seafood at best was 2 crab legs, 2 scallops, 2 prawns...for, $30? I think it was. I felt like the majority of the plate was sauce. Which was good sauce, don't get me wrong.
