Cocktails were all right. Took a bit longer than I was anticipating.

The atmosphere was good. Seemed bustling towards dinner hour on a Friday night. Everyone was prompted quickly.

Definitely recommend it to people who haven't tried it. Not sure if it's a repeatable destination.
author: Sara M.

description: The service was probably the worst I've ever had in a restaurant. The waiter acted like they didn't want to even serve us. They made my friend and I feel very uncomfortable by avoiding our table. It was at the point that another server stepped in to clear our table and asked if we needed anything. There is also a minimum dollar amount.
author: Rachel R.

description:
I'm going to let you in on a little secret of mine,  I go to three different people; hostess, bartender and server independently and ask them "what here is going to change my life and bring me back a second time?" All three employees independently said "get the Cioppino"

Trust me......Get the cioppino......

The only negative thing is I can never get cioppino anywhere else but here........ :(
author: Frank R.

description: Classic, historic, and incredible food!  Best seafood around!  Cioppino is a must if it is your first time and end with the bourbon bread pudding, you won't be disappointed and will keep you coming back.
author: Kirk K.

description:
This is old-school San Francisco at its finest. We had a great server (Gary?) who had a relaxed attitude but knew every detail about his counter-- who was waiting to be seated and in what order, and his favorite dishes (incidentally, not the most expensive ones). 

It also seemed we arrived at the right time: at 7:15 on a Wednesday we got the last two open counter seats instead of waiting 45 minutes for a table. 

Only downside to the counter is that a bussing station was set up right underneath our part of the counter, so we had bussers constantly walking up to empty dirty dishes in front of us, which was distracting while we waited and a bit offputting while we ate. Maybe they could find a better spot for that tub? 

Other than that it was a great experience that I'd recommend someone try at least once.
author: Krista L.

description: My first time at this establishment.  My group ordered multiple drinks, an appetizer, four courses, wine and dessert. With that we tipped 20% even though she didn't really deserve that much but we like to tip high. The food was great and the service was good enough. However once the bill was paid we were asked to leave within 5-10 minutes. Our group was shocked at the host telling us that we need to leave because they needed the table. This is unbelievable. After leaving we noticed that there was only one group waiting to be sat. Our group has never been treated like this and honestly I don't see us returning.
author: Sasha G.

description: Excellent staff, drinks, hustle and great menu!  If you are looking for a fun energetic place, you e found it!  Seafood galore, yet steaks and salads, large portion (not necessary) but enjoyed everything about this place
author: Leslie K.

description:
COOL WOOD BOOTHS WITH TRADITIONAL DINING

We enjoyed everything we ordered here and after two martinis ... we really enjoyed ourselves. Attentive service, nice menu selections. The potatoes were excellent. Raves about the cioppino.
author: Desiree P.

description: As good a cioppino as you will find. Classy must try son Francisco land mark on the financial district.
author: Geanr L.

description:
Fantastic restaurant, one of the few in SF that live up to the billing.

It's ran like a restaurant where the people working there don't have to kiss your azz, which is refreshing as someone that worked in the restaurant industry for 7+ years. If you get treated like dirt, maybe it's you. I've been here 10-15 times at least and never had an issue.

Wait for your table, order your food, enjoy, pay and then get the heck out.
author: Janie L.

description: Chilean Sea bass was excellent. Service was mostly attentive, but could've been friendlier and more efficient with our greeting/order.
author: Lindsay C.

description: best cioppino anywhere. been coming here since the 70's and it remains an all time hall of fame, sure thing place to go. Professional waiters who know what to do. Not trendy, not foo foo, just a place a person could go to get a great meal for the last 140 years or so... My great grandfather told me that he'd take me here when I was a kid. Well, he passed away before we could quaff a beer and have some cioppino, but I made it in my youth and just keep coming back. Thank God some great things never change! We are going today to celebrate Independence weekend and I can already taste it!
author: Cowboy L.

description:
4.5!

My stars:  (5=epic "best of") (4=really tasty and want to go again and again) (3=good and will go back once in a while) (2=fair, might return for a visit if there was some glimmer of hope) (1=avoid at all costs)

Go or No?  Go!

Tease:   An SF institution!

Why I went:  We wanted to try the cioppino!  We needed a good restaurant after a long day of bumming around the city.

When:  5/31/13

Food:   Between my friend, wife and myself...we dined like royalty!  Between us, we had the following:  prawn cocktail (classic and fresh), Boston clam chowder (extremely tasty...would put this up against any in SF!), seafood cioppino (Simply perfect!  Best I've ever had!  Their reputation is based on this and it is obvious why!), crab leg sauté (again...fresh and tasty), seafood sauté (which was loaded with shellfish and some whitefish...also very tasty).  Cocktails were classic and well done.  

Service:   Jose P rocked!  He treated us like royalty!  It gives a steakhouse vibe to the service...

Hints/Final thoughts:  It truly is an institution!  You really have to go for the cioppino!
author: Andy R.

description: I used to love this place - classic SF, lots of history.  This week, I ordered the corned beef & hash and after finishing, immediately could tell I had food poisoning.  Was laid out for days.  Missed work.  When I finally got back on my feet, I called the restaurant to let them know - the guy who answered the phone transferred me to a manager, who hung up.
author: Adam F.

description: I live a few hours away and stop here as much as I can.  Not pretentious, good food in a busy, vibrant atmosphere.  A plus is the counter where I can dine when alone and meet lots of interesting people.  Oysters rockefeller, fish in every style and almost all varieties, good steak and hearty sides. Not for a diet, the trick if in need of comfort food.
author: Liz B.

description: Steak was cooked perfectly and was really tasty! Portions are just right. They do not overload your plates but at the same time you don't need a magnifying glass to see your food. Very busy at lunch and dinner times. Not always the best for a large group but if you are going to meet a colleague or friend here it will work out just fine. Seafood is tasty and well presented.
author: Kevin L.

description: Great and simple place. Old school restaurant where you can find good old steak fabulous crab cake and amazing garlic bread.
author: Shachar M.

description:
I have been to SF many times but never ate at the Tadich grill because I thought it was overhyped. Last week I finally stopped by with my wife and daughter. Wow it was really good. It has an extensive menu and the wine list was pretty good and not totally over the top in price. 

We started with the fish appetizer for two which included smoked salmon, Dungeness crab, herring calamari and oysters. Very delicious! My wife had the crab cakes which she declared to be the best ones she has ever had. My daughter got the lamb shank which was generously sized and served with awesome mashed potatoes. I could not resist the cioppino. Very good and served in a tomato base. Portion was amazing and I struggled to finish!

Service was efficient and friendly and it has a classic wood décor atmosphere. I will return!
author: George T.

description:
Good experience
Quality ok but not excellent
We have eaten better in Frisco
Histrory and tradition is not all
author: Rudolf F.

description: The halibut florentine is one of the best I've ever had....the employees are long time workers and professional at their jobs... The food and employees are the reason this place is a S F institution not the owner....rate the food not the family!
author: Mike L.

description:
+ nice decor
+ yummy cioppino (way better than sotto mare)

- chilean sea bass was disappointing. i think it was a little overcooked because it wasn't flaky. 
- service was interesting...our waiter was kind of weird. my friend felt like we were at the house of terror.
author: Margaret R.

description: If you're in San Francisco,  you HAVE to go here. It's the oldest restaurant in San Francisco and the food is amazing. The service is perfect and everything I tried was great. I ordered the shrimp curry and a slice of cheesecake for dessert. It's also nice because it's not too touristy. They hand write the mean everyday, it's a really unique experience!
author: Heather W.

description:
Was recommended that if we eat at one place in San Francisco that this should be it. I was glad we tried it. Ive never seen a place like this. Waiters in white lab coats running around like men on a mission. The service was impeccable. Bread, water, wine replaced instantly. We ordered scallops and  filet of sole dinner. Both were good. Would try something different next time though. 
It was a great dining experience and a cool place with a lot of history and old school atmosphere.
author: V R.

description: The (white) Clam Chowder was VERY good and their cup was plenty!  I also enjoyed the appetizer portion of Calamari, which was a huge serving.  Very tasty and not greasy.  The tarter sauce has horseradish in it, something I had never thought of, and was delicious.  I typically pass on the tarter sauce since most taste too much like mayonnaise.  Prices are a little high, but well worth it.  The staff was super friendly too.  You can wait for a table or sit at their counter.  I will definitely come back for another meal here.
author: Lynn H.

description: Loved this place!  We were staying nearby and decided to give it a try for lunch.  Lucky for us we made it before the rush hit.  Loved the Cioppino, but I think I will order the short rib next time.  YUM!  You get to sit in a private booth area and the waiters have been there forever.  A great splurge.  I will definitely go back when in SF.
author: Diana C.

description:
Came here on a Monday evening round 8pm. This place gets 0 stars for the food, 1 star for the wine, and 1 star for the service. I brought one of my best friends here to celebrate his birthday and it was an AWFUL experience all around. I got sick from the food and have literally been nauseous from it all day. They had also run out of a ton of dishes like Lobster Ravioli that I really wanted to try. 

1. Firstly, they don't take reservations so we had to wait 20-30min. 

2. I told our server it was my friend's birthday and he implied they would do something and I guess he forgot because he didn't do anything or even offer us a dessert menu! I have never gone to a restaurant on someone's bday and not ordered dessert wth?!

3. Only food that was good - cups of Clam Chowder with red sauce and white sauce. Both were spectacular!

4. Food that probably made us sick - Tadich Platter Appetizer + Dungeness Crab and Prawns a la Monza + Crab and Lobster Thermido Baked en Casserole. We hated the last two so much we only had 2-3 bites of food and our server took both dishes off our bill. We didn't replace them because we were so put off by the gross bitter taste from both dishes! At the end of our dinner service, our server told us that one of the chefs had messed up on the sauce in the baked dishes, which explained the awful flavor. If he had messed up, why the hell were they still serving those dishes?! Plus, the meat in both dishes was overcooked. I'm still feeling so sick from eating this and I know I won't be touching seafood for a while. 

5. Food that was good but not great - Seafood Saute. You can't really go wrong with this. 

Even with our 2 main dishes taken off the bill, it came out to $120. Let's just say, I'm never ever coming back here. I hope I can make up this terrible birthday dinner to my friend!
author: Kriti R.

description:
- seafood stew special of the house was WAY too salty 
- server never brought water to the table. No one ever checked if we needed some even. Given how over salted the meal was, I felt parched afterwards 
- shrimp cocktail didn't taste especially good or fresh 
- Fried calamari tastes like disgusting bar food, deep fried in a grease pit and served in giant clumps of breaded fry
author: Laurence S.

description:
Seafood is great! Fast service too. 

I loved their cioppino, the tomato broth was very fresh and light. I still think sotto mare has better cioppino in terms of quantity and amount of seafood, but this came pretty close to winning my heart. 
Halibut cheek stew was amazing also! It was very meaty, yet tender served in a light cream sauce that really complimented the dish.

Cons: octopus salad was too hard, and barely edible.
author: Nancy Z.

description: It's really hard to create a meal that I consider to be complete perfection. Everyone in my family was overly satisfied. I had filet mignon with crab and mashed potatoes. It was complete perfection. The way it was cooked, the food it was paired with- good god! It was absolutely perfect! The old fashioned, classiness of this restaurant is unlike any other.
author: Micaela N.

description:
The seafood cioppino with garlic bread and dungeness crab and prawns a la monza were delicious! I literally ate everything off my plate. The seafood was fresh and literally melts in your mouth. 

The staff was way nice! The bartender heard me talking about bloody marys because I saw that they make their own bloody mary mix and he served me up a bloody mary just so I could sample their mix! Very nice! And it was good too! :)

The place is pretty cramped but the setting and ambience is nice. White table clothes, waiters in white collared shirts, well dressed customers. 
I highly recommend ordering the cioppino!
author: Latda V.

description: Iconic restaurant which has stood the test of time. Not just seafood (which is consistently excellent), but other dishes as well (also consistently excellent).  Service is prompt and to the point.Full bar and one of the last places where you can still get a decent Ramos Fizz. Staff knows their business here and tend to it well. Busy at lunch unless you go early. No reservations. I have no qualms about recommending this place and have been going there for some 50 years.
author: Doctor T.

description:
STILL MY FAVORITE

place to have lunch. We had the Oysters Three Ways & the Dungeness Crab Louie.

To die for...
author: John D.

description: Old style San Francisco popular spot hasn't lost a step.  Still, charming guys behind the bar make classic drinks and entertain people waiting for tables.  (They don't take reservations, but waiting there is fun!!) The classic architecture, wooden little rooms and table cloths help create a sophisticated but comfortable vibe.  Outstanding waiters and food.  Recently enjoyed fresh Cioppino, Crab Louis salad  and my favorite, local Petrale Sole. Yummy fresh veggies and the best Sour Dough bread made this a very memorable dining experience!
author: Carole D.

description:
Self absorbed host who wasn't happy to have new customers. Sorry Tadich Grill... we decided to spend our hard earned $$$ on you today.

After we sat at the counter, everything was very factory like. I don't mind that as long as the food is good.

But, the food was nothing special either.We ordered the crab cocktail, clam chowder, cioppino. The clam chowder and the garlic bread were good, but honestly speaking I could make that cioppino at home.We also ordered the choc mousse and the bread pudding.Meh..

I will not come back, unless it is someone else's party.Not worth the money.
author: P D.

description: Everything is excellent! Try the swordfish or the sea bass. The New England clam chowder is fabulous. Sourdough bread--yummy! Caesar salad is plenty for two to share. Wine list is good. Waiters are fun and friendly. The restaurant pops with noise and laughter. Seriously, go have dinner here when you are in SF!
author: Ellen M.

description: Tadich Grill is the only reason for me to go to San Francisco.  Great menu and everything is wonderful.  Favorites are the Cioppino and the Short Ribs.  Full bar and totally "Old school"!
author: Glenn H.

description: The food was amazing ( I had the "seafood sauté"), drinks were great too!  The "cioppino" looked amazing and I'm going to have to get that next time, but I was very pleased with the "seafood sauté".The waiters were also very friendly and the wait time was minimal as my hubby and I quickly found 2 seats at the bar.  This is a casual dining spot with high quality service and food!
author: Jonisha S.

description:
This place was buzzing tonight. It doesn't take reservations and was out the door jam packed on Saturday night. Although there was a bunch of people waiting for seating, it was Valentine's night, I only had to wait a minute literally to get a seat. 
Staff were super friendly and helpful, fast paced ordering feels like it belongs in New York. I had the clam chowder to start which came with sourdough and the main was Lobster ravioli with jumbo prawns in Rd pepper sauce. Delicious. The prawns were cooked to perfection and the sauce was fantastically rich. Get in!
author: Bartley D.

description:
TG's service and decor felt like the black and white  portion of the movie Pleasantville. 

No reservations and your full party has to be present or you're out of luck. Wonder if this is their tactic to increase their liquor revenue. Drink while waiting for latecomers.

Peak time is 6-8pm so stop by after 8 to avoid the chaos.

The cioppino was one of the best I've had. Seafood heaven of fish, scallops, clams, crab, shrimp, and mussels. Serving size is best for sharing although two foodie friends polished off their plates without any problem. I packed mine to go and relived the  exquisite experience the next day. Deliciousness replay.

Skip the desserts. Terrible disappointment.
author: Sophie C.

description: Very bad service! Very rude! I was there with one friend who was visiting Bay Area from NYC, another friend was on his way. The waiter wrote down our name and asked us to sit at bar chairs for waiting. When we said we didn't want to drink anything, his started to be very rude. He said couple times that "I'll ask you ladies to stand up when somebody come." We did stand up when somebody came for drink, but he said loudly that "I can't let somebody sit if they don't drink or eat!", repeating several times. It made us very embarrassed. Excuse me? It is you that ask us to sit there waiting.. Even the other guy who was also waiting felt that the waiter is very rude to us. II'll never come back again!
author: Brenda Z.

description: The Service was outstanding! They seriously take their time explaining the dishes to you! The Seafood Ciopinno was absolutely amazing. I highly recommended for everyone to come and eat here! Everything is absolutely outstanding!
author: Daniel V.

description: Very good meal!  Clam chowder was awesome, fried scallops with homemade tarter Yummy and Short ribs were delish. Big portions was worth the hour wait.
author: crystal s.

description:
We finally made it!!!!
How can you go wrong eating at one of the oldest restaurants in California? Can you say one of San Francisco's landmarks? Hell yeah! 

We got here around 5 pm on a Fri and to our amazement no line and the place was half empty (SCORE!). Walking in we were in awe, the deco looks as if the place didn't change since opening, taking us back in time. Huge long bar where you can eat, drink or BS, scattered small tables, and semi private booths for groups of 4 and up. The servers were very attentive and made sure we were well taken care of. 

We shared a small seafood salad that had good amounts of fresh crab and shrimp. It was perfect for two and super good. Bread and water was always on hand but the entree was the star that shined. Cioppino (one of the signature dishes) for the both of us because sharing was out if the question. Talk about seafood galore, I mean it was loaded. Clams, mussels, fish, crab, shrimp and prawns in a tomato base.  It must have been simmering for a long time to get this amount of flavor to come through. The garlic bread for dipping to soak up all the flavors hit the spot. Sharing is not a bad thing if you don't have a big appetite, the wifey had to pack half of the dish to go. Can't wait to come back an try some of the other dishes.
author: T L.

description:
Sadly this place lacks polish and manners and most of all, decent service and food.  Some loud, rude clod named Gary enjoys the pretense of power and plays God at the door/bar. 
Never mind he forgets to tell you 12 twosomes are ahead of you, never mind he fails to mention the wait is 1 1/2 hours. But when the ASS seats people who walk in after you first - that's when you vote with your feet!!!
author: Katalina O.

description: Outstanding, bustling, one-of-a-kind place.  The staff (all men, it appears) are pros who want to read your mind, and usually can.  We're eager to head back and try more of the huge menu (and large portions).  Truly the best cioppino.  Great, memorable experience.
author: Elliott O.

description: The cioppino here was great.  I didn't think the calamari was that good to be honest, but the restaurant over all is a great classic San Franciscan must try.  Service however was just ok.  The server was quite grumpy and kind of yelled at another server as well.  Overall.. just ok but will take visitors here for being one of the first restaurants in SF and also the ciopinno.  Portion was huge!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Can't go wrong with their infamous cioppino!  I've been coming here for years and each time would tell self "try something new", but never fails, I can't steer away from this delicious stew!  It is one of the best cioppino in The City (IMHO)!  The fried calamari was not as good as I remembered from my previous visits, the batter was too heavy.  My sister had the crab cakes and raved about it.  They were big thick patties and served in pairs with steamed veggies.  It's crab season so this must've been extra yummy.  The Mixed Seafood Louie is piled high with fresh crab meat, bay shrimp and a few large prawns (also has avocado, tomatoes and cucumbers).  Perfect for sharing!  Don't come here for their desserts! ;-)

They don't take reservations and will seat you only when everyone in your party has arrived.  But, have a few drinks at the bar and you'll forget about the wait.  I love the "mean" cocktails they serve.  

Service is ALWAYS excellent!!!
author: The Q.

description:
Words cannot describe how amazing this place is.

Oysters rockefeller, dungeness crab salad, corned beef hash, ciopinno, crab cakes, sand dabs, you'll love it all! Sit at the counter-- think of your perfect night as clam chowder, seafood saute, and chocolate mousse cake being served to you by Anton, as he tells you a joke that has you smiling from ear to ear. Marion will shake your hand with a smile, Jan will greet you like the friend you haven't seen in ages, Petey will have you sipping your sobriety away (they only have manly old-school drinks), Barry will have you scowling at his quips, and Tony and Maite, all the while, will be showering you with compliments. Everybody here has their own unique personality, and together, they emboss the symbol of utmost excellence. Huzzah!

Nevertheless, I stop by approximately thrice a week to stuff my long face I get after a hard day's work (always five minutes before closing, and have yet to be lynched!). Thrice a week, inducing my own mercury poisoning by means of savory gluttony!

Always crowded, but unlike many restaurants, the servers can still be on their toes and keep everyone happy. Walk over and sink your teeth into the most delicious garlic bread you've ever tasted in your life. Feel your eyelids fall and taste the buttery, crisp sensation smacking between your lips... Mmm...
author: Elaine N.

description:
Best cioppino in CA. 
The atmosphere can be matched by none I've tried. The mood and feeling of the joint feels like you're taken back in time with the long wooden bar and the waiters long time status.
author: Jacob B.

description: Great old style place. I heard about this place several times and finally tonight we went there . Let's start from the cocktails : I finally had a great Martini ( with gin as it should be) then we ordered a Cesar salad and 2 Cioppinos. The Cioppino for those who don't know is the equivalent of an Italian fish soup and this one is as good as the one my mom makes. For those who don't know my mom it is insanely amazing. To sum up: great old fashion place, amazing cocktails  and incredible food who wants more?
author: Francesco R.

description:
Tadich Grill needs my review like (as my grandmother would have said) a hole in the head.  They have more than 150 years of reputation to establish their creds.  They must have been pretty damn good to stand the test of that time.  My first time there was when my dear departed mom took me to SF for a 16th birthday weekend celebration.  I won't say how long ago that was, but it was not long enough ago that I didn't remember it.  Don't remember having been back since...

Fast forward to Monday.  I met my sister and friend there for lunch.  We got there right at 11:30, to avoid the rush and lucked out and got seated in a booth.  After all agreeing to have a martini, even though it was way too early for cocktail hour, we set about making our selections.  

I have always wanted to try hangtown fry, so went for that.  S got the calves liver and K got the petrale sole.  These selections were so 1930!  I was a little disappointed with mine.  It was cooked too long.  The eggs were way well done, and the oysters were beyond the point where they retained any of their luscious liquors.  Also it definitely could have used more salt!  

S.'s liver was perfectly medium (just pink) with lots of sauteed onions.  There aren't a lot of places where you can order liver at all, let alone perfectly cooked.  K's petrale sole was also expertly sauteed.  It was a large portion and very fresh.

Our waiter was efficient to a fault, but pretty cold in demeanor.  I definitely got the message that he wanted to take care of business and turn the table.  Unfortunately for him, we weren't that kind of gals.  We lingered and talked, and though he didn't shoot us dirty looks, I'm sure he would have preferred if we'd left faster.

There were so many other classic retro dishes I'd like to try.  I loved the feel of the place, just disappointed my dish didn't live up to expectations.

Food:  31/40
service 15/20
atm/intang:  19/20
value:  16/20
Overall:  81=B=4 stars
author: Diane B.

description:
Humm...

I been here like twice I think, about 7 years apart.  Anyhow, I just went there last night and I got the pork chops w/ applesauce.  My wife got the Cioppinno and my friend got the pan fried fish (sole to be exact).  Let's review going from the best to worse.
1. Cioppinno - It was just okay.  Everyone raves about it, but it didn't taste that good.  it's not bad either, but it didn't wow me.  The best place is by far, Sam's Chowder house in Half Moon Bay for Cioppinno.  That place, the broth is much more depth of flavors.  

2. Pan Fried Fish - well, it was a good piece of fish that was well fried.  The fish was huge.  Besides that, the side veggies were lame - simply boiled.  Overall a good fish, but not worth $28.  No where near.  I had fish like this for $8.

3. Pork Chops w/ Applesauce - Why do people rave about this and why did I check yelp on the photos?  There were so many photos of this, so I thought it was good - bad mistake.  These chops were over the top terrible!!!!  I cannot express enough, DO NOT ORDER.  To me it seemed like the chops were deep fried w/o any breading, and you know what means, it's basically being boiled in oil.  And after, they must have taken paper towels or put the chops on a wire rack to dry and then seared some grid lines with the grill.  I can tell all this because the meat of waaaayyyy overcooked and it had this rubbery texture, which often happens when you deep fry white meat without an outside casing such as breading.  Anyhow, the worse of all was the applesauce.  Geez that was literally applesauce!!!  Who serves plain, canned applesauce for a thick piece of pork chop.  To make it even worse, I could taste some white wine in the sauce.  So it basically was can applesauce mixed with white wine uncooked.  That is sooo freakin nasty.  

Anyhow, the only real positive was the ambiance.  it was a very nice historic place.  But overall, that's not enough to make me go again.  It was waaay tooo pricey for such amateur cooking.
author: Mark S.

description: Love love love the clam chowder here! Petrale sole with lemon butter sauce is great too as are other seafood fishes including the sand dabs.  It can get pretty packed for lunch so make sure you get there early to get a seat.  A SF institution for good reason!
author: V B.

description: Recommended by a local.  The whole experience of eating at a counter with waiters in white jackets was unique and a fun vacation memory.  The cioppino was generous with the perfect spice and mix of seafoods.  Dipping in the sourdough bread was heaven!
author: Mary F.

description: Tadisch Grill has a soul and it's kept it for nearly two hundred years. And while we're at it, one order of Petrale sole, pan-fried please, and don't forget the excellent house made tartar sauce. The waiters are as efficient and crisp as their white dinner jackets. The wood counter that you dine on is sumptuously solid. There's a masculine feeling to the joint but it goes down smoothly and everyone is welcome. One of the rare surviving heritage restaurants that continues to age gracefully. A beauty.
author: Mr. 1.

description: We were walking down the street and we passed by this place. i hand never evenr hear of rhis place but from the outside it looked kind of interesting so I decided we would come back latt that evening. I'm si happy we did!! The food, the service, the feel!!! wow this truly on of this city's hidden jewels!!! i would come back tomorrow but I'm going home.
author: Jesse G.

description: I went to the Tadich Grill because my chef at my culinary school highly recommended it.  It is over 100 years old and it is the oldest restaurant in San Francisco.  We had the Filet Mingnon and the Veal Parmesan and both were cooked to perfection.  The service was excellent and the ambiance made you feel like you stepped back into history.
author: Abigail K.

description:
I had dinner here because of its reputation as one of the oldest restaurants in San Francisco and its seafood cioppino. 
Food: 4/5
The cioppinno served with garlic bread was good. Although the food was good and the seafood very very fresh, I would have expected a more generous ration of seafood (more mussels, clams, and prawns).
Service: 4/5 
I have nothing negative to share about the service. The host guy who assigned us a table was very friendly (my French accent probably helped here start a friendly conversation). Though it felt like a touch of connection/warmth with the waiter while dining would have been not too much asked. The service felt also a bit rushed at times, which is not really what you expect when you go out to relax after a busy day of work.
Setting: 4/5
It looks like an authentic 'old school' establishment that reminds me of the old Paris in many ways: bitrot-style, "cubby" for larger groups, waiters' uniform, the central bar with people seated at the counter. The place was a bit too noisy for me.
Value: 3/5
Even though the overall impression was good, it seemed overpriced.
author: Sabrina B.

description:
Came here specifically for the Cioppino and was very impressed! Everything in the dish was fresh and cooked perfectly. I wish I had more things to dip the sauce up!

Overall the service was excellent and they even provided bibs as to not dirty your shirt as you dive head first in to their delicious food.

Beware - potential tourist trap!
author: Michael S.

description: WOW. I am not even a lover of seafood and this was incredible. Everything was beyond perfection and look forward to the next visit. Staff were just as pleasing and attentive.
author: Jay F.

description: We were in town for work and one of our local friends recommended that we try Tadich  and we are glad he did.  Very nice initial old-school restaurant feel from both the look of the restaurant and the appearance of the staff and it's actually legit since they are California's oldest restaurant!  There was a relatively short wait for a table (20 min) at prime time on a Wednesday night which worked out well since we had a chance to have a drink at the bar.  We were served by Michael - who was fantastic!!  He made excellent drinks, was quite the witty conversationalist and had a great sense of humor.  We had the Cioppino and sole, the sole was good but the Cioppino was excellent - very rich flavor without any piece of it being overpowering.  There was a nice mix of seafood in it and the bread to soak up the juice was delicious.  After we finished our meal we went back to the bar just to have another drink by Michael since we had enjoyed chatting with him when we first came in.  We feel very comfortable recommending Tadich and recommend that you ask for Michael at the bar.
author: Bill P.

description:
Food overall quality was a 3
Overall service a 4
I struggled with this one but can not give a 4 star, it just isn't that good.
Fun place though.
author: Raymond H.

description:
Great food and atmosphere. It took an hour for a table and the reservation system isn't with the times. Once we got seated it was with it.
Best seafood in the city.
author: T M.

description: Had my birthday dinner at this classy restaurant. Food was great! Ordered Seafood Cioppino, Sand Dabs, and Rockefeller. All of them were tasty. It's just they don't take reservation, so we waited about 30 minutes.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
If I ever come to Tadich grill, it would be for the atmosphere and their really delicious New England clam chowder...and fries. Oh!don't forget Seabass, that was pretty phenomenal too!

Other than that, I remember everything else not being that good. Their oysters on the half shell tasting like water..and the Petrole sole way too heavy on the butter. 

Its also always packed with tourist. I prefer their bar seats because you can just get your clam chowder fix and leave.
author: Amber S.

description:
Has turned into a tourist trap!  

Everything is way overpriced.  The waiter brought the food with the aps.  My main came cold.  We had to ask for every little thing (tartar sauce for example and that is one of their well know things) and at those prices they should be falling over backwards for me.   What really chaps me is that I have been going here my whole life and it was always my favorite.   

Booooooo - Hisssssssss
author: Dick R.

description:
The clam chowder had a lot of clams, but lacked flavor. Why the hype? 

I also had the dungeness leg cocktail, which was also disappointing.
author: David H.

description:
This place was AMAZING! Visiting from Vancouver, Canada, my dad and I have never eaten at a restaurant that felt so old. Not only was the cioppino the best my Dad has ever had, the steak melted in my mouth and the atmosphere and our server Jack just added to the experience. 

Jack was attentive and we could tell how much he loved working there. He was full of information and history on the place. The prices were very reasonable for what we got. They don't cheap out on portion size and the recipes have apparently never changed.

I think some of the poor reviews are from people that don't realize that this place hasn't changed much since they first opened their doors. It's designed to get people in and out and maximize efficiency. The more people they can fit in, the more people that get to try their amazing food. It's meant to be old school, so expect that when you get there. It's not suppose to be like your modern day restaurant. The servers aren't there to polish your shoes and create small talk. It's suppose to feel like you've gone back in time... and that's exactly what it felt like to us. I've eaten at a lot of the popular places in San Francisco, and this places tops them all, 100%. Couldn't have asked for a better experience. Thanks Jack for adding to it!
author: Bradley S.

description:
Cool ambience. Like the history. Nice staff. And the food is good. But not that good. The ingredients are solid. And nicely cooked. Fish is moist and tender. It's  just prepared in a very dated, unexciting way. Maybe that goes with the antique schtick. But, while I used to go to this sort of place with my grandparents, I'd rather not spend my money this way as an adult with other choices. Especially since you have to wait a long time because it's such a touristy destination.

My recommendation, sit at the bar. Have a drink. Soak in the ambience. Banter with the white coated staff. But them eat elsewhere.
author: Jon T.

description:
Impressed by their food, but not for the price. Service was solid. Atmosphere was very hustle and bustle. Not going to complain though because in the Financial District a dinner is worth an arm and a leg unless you are an investment banker- they take arms and legs for a living so they can afford it!

I tried the filet mignon with lobster tail. The filet mignon was so on point. The sauce that went with it is a different story. I could have sworn they put a block of butter on the broccoli. It was so delicious. The lobster tail was a bit overcooked, but still extremely delicious. I tried some of my friend's Mesquite Broiled Chilean Sea Bass Filet with Prawn Garnish and that tasted amazing! Some of my other friends got the sampler and were not impressed! 

Don't think I would try this again because it's a bit pricey for great food. But still, good experience. 

Bill Tip: While you are waiting 90+ minutes for your seat, get a drink at the bar. The bartenders are hilarious!
author: Bill C.

description:
I have been wanting to come here for so long and we finally made the trek across. We got there kind of late so the wait was long but it went fast sitting along he bar.  The bar tenders had a fun vibe keeping guests entertained while staying busy to make sure our drinks were full. 

Once we were seated there were so many tasty options on the menu it was almost impossible to make up our minds.  We started with the Dungeness Crab cocktail since they are supposed to be in season and it was so fresh and tender it was gone within two bites.  We also got the clams in a white wine and butter sauce.  The sauce made the dish and we were dipping our bread in and practically licking our plates clean.

The only downside to showing up late is they were out of the sand dabs and sea bass which are two dished we really wanted.  I ordered the halibut which was really good but I wish I went with something a little more adventurous for the restaurant.  My boyfriend got the Cioppino which was by far my favorite dish,  Loads of seafood from sea bass, scallops, oysters, shrimp were piled in the tomato broth which gave flavor to the entire dish.  Grilled bread came on the side to dunk into the sauce.  

To end the meal we had a bourbon bread pudding which was to die for.  The bourbon sauce drizzled over the top had a perfect sweetness and the pudding was soft but not mushy.

I will be back for another special occasion and ready to try another one of there many options on the menu.
author: Sutton A.

description: David was incredible!  The best service ever!  Atmosphere was terrific - Highly recommend it.  Great wine list!
author: Elizabeth E.

description: Great food, quick service, and amazing recommendations from the servers. A must try if you haven't. Ordered the Ciopino and was delicious!
author: Greg G.

description:
I don't understand why this is such a beloved SF favorite.  I mean the food wasn't bad, but at this price, I would rather eat elsewhere with bigger portions or better flavors.  Service was mediocre at best. Our waiter, Charles, was borderline rude when one person in our party didn't order anything because we wanted to share to try different things. We were also celebrating a birthday here but he didn't offer a free dessert so much as wish the birthday girl a happy birthday.  (Have to say the bartenders and other servers were really nice though)

Rockefeller oysters -  6 pieces for $20.   They were oysters on the shell cooked under a bed of garlicky cheesey spinach, but the oysters were tiny, and two of them didn't even have oysters in it.  Flavor was delicious, especially on their sour dough bread but I'm extremely upset about the missing/tiny oysters

Fried calamari - slightly crispy texture on the outside with a perfectly chewy squid texture on the inside.

White clam chowder - this was good, and I have nothing to complain about. Nice and creamy, not too salty, chock full of clams.

Cioppino - strong tomato base with jumbo shrimp, mussels, clams, and fish. Was enough to share between two ppl.

Dungeness crab a la monza - casserole with rice baked in cheese.  Delicious but very heavy

(Would be 3 stars but our waiter and an oyster appetizer missing oysters brings it down to 2)
author: Emily C.

description: Another fantastic meal, this place just can't be beat. The oldest and best restaurant in SF and you know why once you try the food! Been eating here since I was a baby (early 70's). And has to be my favorite place of all time, the food is just impeccable and service always ON POINT. Don't leave without trying the steamed clams in butter and garlic....omg. And I ALWAYS get the seafood saute. ...it's amazing.
author: Lance M.

description: Great food, fun atmosphere.  Valet parking right in front for $10.00.  I give this place 4 stars for quality.  The only thing.... my bill for 2 people was well over $100.00 and what got me was they didn't give free refills on the small glass of soda I ordered.  That's really all I can complain about.  Everything else was phenomenal.
author: April G.

description:
Since Tadich Grill is one of the restaurants that is an institution in San Francisco, it's been on my to-try list for a while. I tried to eat here once before, but they were out of sand dabs (around 8:30pm on a weekday night), so I decided to come on another day. We came for lunch right when they opened at 11am on a Saturday, and were seated right away. We ordered:

-Boston Clam Chowder (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WxxE5kE8omgQhJE8sWIvmA?select=1LDUn7AO5zhjFnD4tWcN7Q#xoSxyx_LS9kVktkGirVMxA): Solid clam chowder! Very, very creamy and rich tasting, so I was glad we opted for the smaller size to share.
-Dungeness Crab Cake (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WxxE5kE8omgQhJE8sWIvmA?select=1LDUn7AO5zhjFnD4tWcN7Q#oWYXlaqIzdX95Mg9FeIXSQ): Ok.. I was expecting a little more. I didn't like the sauce it was served on top of, and I also didn't think the chipotle aioli went well with it. I much preferred the tartar sauce they give you.
-Pan-Fried Sand Dabs (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WxxE5kE8omgQhJE8sWIvmA?select=1LDUn7AO5zhjFnD4tWcN7Q#FKlE_4uCC20DQP1WoUHzLQ): Again, only ok. This was recommended by both Anthony Bourdain and on the 7x7 2012 Big Eat List, so I had really high expectations. The sand dab meat was really firm, and had a nice crust from the pan frying. However, there were still a lot of tiny bones, so it was hard to eat it with confidence. They give you a small bowl of tartar sauce, which I loved and dipped everything from the steamed veggies to the french fries to the sand dabs in. 

The service was very accommodating here, especially the host, who greets you with a warm welcome and also thanks you for dining there when you're heading out. Unfortunately, I didn't have a dish that I would rush back here to eat again, but they have an extensive menu, so I'm sure I can find something I enjoy, especially because I want to dip it in more of that tartar sauce! They give you complimentary bread and butter, so that is a plus as well. Parking should be fairly easy to find in this area.
author: Amy D.

description:
According to our waiter, this is the oldest restaurant in SF, California, and possibly the West Coast, now that's history for you!

I've always wanted to try Tadich but was wary of the no reservation policy. Finally one night we decided to try this with some friends and I was not disappointed!

Decor is lovely. Reminiscent of a place straight out of a movie where people used to ride trains to get around and ladies and gets would wear coats and hats. I loved the huge long table/bar booth that extended all the way back to the open kitchen.

We arrived at 7:30pm, party of 4, and waited approximately 1 hour for a semi-private booth table area.  

Of course cioppino is the way to go here and it was delicious. Not too salty, not too sweet, and lots of chunks of seafood.  2 of us ordered the Chilean sea bass and it was grilled to perfection (from my perspective).

Clam chowder was a bit watery and the rice pudding dessert was a bit of a let down to an otherwise delicious meal.

Our friend noticed that all the folks working in the restaurant were male. I didn't even notice until he said it. It didn't bother me but it was an interesting observation.

Tip: 
*For parties of 1-2, sitting at the bar is the way to go, first come first serve!
author: Betty C.

description:
We walked in to this lively, bustling restaurant filled with great aroma of food and cheerful diners.  As a party of 2 we were seated almost right away.  Atmosphere noisy (you can't help at 7pm) but has a great vibe.

We were impressed as soon as our appys arrived - Boston chowder and smoked salmon salad.  The chowder was beautiful; creamy and smooth with a generous amount of tender and juicy clams. Excellent comfy food.  My date loved the salmon as well.  I was in need of some hot tea and they had a good selection of herbals.

For thr entree I had the Alaskan Halibut which was chargrilled and delicious with the tar tar sauce. The side vegetables were boiled mostly which is unfortunate since brussel sprouts could be done so much better pan fried.  My date had a seafood curry with gigantic prawns.  Freshness of seafood, comfortabl cuisine, are the keywords in my exprience this time.  Our server was very professional also.  Good stuff!  Will like to come back again.
author: Ray C.

description:
I always order their salmon and potato wedges with vegetables. And for dessert, the chocolate mousse. Never got tired of it. I can order it every day, because it gets better every time I order it.

What's better than the food is their service. There's this waiter who I feel like he's just everywhere. Usually I believe some waiters are responsible for one area in restaurants, but this waiter seems to be in charge of every table. He's friendly and makes eating a pleasure, and you can tell right away he loves his job. 

I highly recommend coming here!
author: Hina W.

description:
We visited your establishment Saturday, January 11th, 2014.  We arrived around 11:30-11:45 AM..to celebrate my sister's birthday. 

We had just finished a wonderful morning in Japantown at Kabuki Spa and Springs.  We were all in a wonderful and giddy mood.  All starving , but definitely in great spirits and ready to eat some exciting food..! However the experience we received was quite the opposite. 

We had 5 ladies in our group and were extremely excited to eat at Tadich Grill, given all the great reviews that Tadich Grill has on YELP.  More so,  my cousins boss recommended this restaurant because he said the food was delicious and the service was outstanding..  Well, I beg to differ after my experience.

Our waiter was Barry,  He came off as rude and arrogant and completely acted like he was too good to be waiting on us.  We decided not to make a big deal because we wanted to have a really good experience at Tadich.  So we brushed off Barry's attitude and continued....

We started off by ordering calamari and oysters on the half shell, some soup and a few soft drinks.

The appetizers came out very quickly and we were greatly appreciative considering we were starving! The calamari was great and so were the oysters.  Calamari came out hot and the oysters were fresh..!

Barry brought out my coke... with a lot of ice and in a very small glass. I thought it was kind of weird for soda to come out in such small glass, but no big deal. 

Barry came back after a few minutes and we ordered the lobster thermadore, ciopinno, shrimp curry and 2 orders of the petrale sole.

The ciopinno was one of the best I've ever had.  The rest of the of the food was mediocre.  Pretty blahhhhhh.. Not a lot of flavor or taste.  Needed a lot more spice and salt.  Not worth the money we spent that day. 

I think what killed it for me was being told to pay for a 'REFILL' on a coke.  C'mon, are you kidding me!!!! We are paying well over $25-35 per entree...and Tadich Grill charges for refills on soda..and to top it off, the soda comes out in such tiny glasses..with an abundance of ice....!!!! Absolutely preposterous!!!! I was so turned off by this...  I could not believe it.  But even more so, to add insult to injury... When I asked Barry for a refill, he very rudely says, "I can't REFILL it for you, but you can RE-PURCHASE another one. Of course, I RE-purchased another coke.

Now Barry brings out the bill..total $207...and some change. We place a $50 bill, plus 3 credit cards and tell Barry to put $50 cash towards the bill and split the remaining balance between the credit cards.

My aunt then wants to pay $100 with her card and advised Barry to put $100 on her card, put $50 towards the remaining balance and then finally split that balance between the 2 cards.

Barry pockets $50 because he says that it was understood that it was going to be his tip...!!! Barry...ARE YOU SERIOUS!!!!! What in the world would make you think that you deserve a 30% tip.....!!!!!!! He didn't even deserve a 18% tip...Even though we still ended up giving him a tip..!

When Barry came back with the screw up..we told him that he messed up and we needed it corrected.  Instead of apologizing and fixing the issue. He mumbled an array of rude remarks under his breath an came back and pretty much threw the bill at us. I've never been so appalled in my life.  And to top it off... he never once made a reference to my sisters birthday.. !!!

On another note: We tried to stop another waiter to ask for some water refills.  The waiter simply replied that he would find Barry, but he was doing absolutely nothing..just standing there. He could have easily refilled our water glasses.  Extremely rude and lazy.

I'm not only disappointed in the food, but I'm disgusted with the service.
author: Shalini M.

description:
We had dinner at theTadich Grill on July 11, 2015.    I asked for a New York Steak "medium rare".   The steak came out and was well done around the perimeter and medium on the inside.    I asked the waiter about it and he immediately developed an attitude.   Now, no matter which way I go, the meal is spoiled (send steak back and girlfriend eats alone or eat steak not prepared the way I asked for it).    What really bugged me was the waiter kept asking me if I "could live with it"?    This is almost a $40.00 steak!   I ate it, but was disappointed.    Amazingly, the waiter became even more rude as we went on (he has been there for years and must assume he is entitled to do this).

We have been eating at the Tadich Grill whenever we come to San Francisco (probably a dozen times in the last 20 years).    I am afraid this will be my last and would not recommend the smug attitude of the employees.     I am truly disappointed.
author: John B.

description: Iconic SF restaurant. Excellent service - timely, attentive and helpful. The bread is excellent and be careful to not eat too much of it. The fish and the steaks are fresh and while basic are still very good.
author: John G.

description:
Places that stir, not shake, my manhattan deserve recognition. 

That being said, this is mainly a booze review. The food here? I don't think it's worth the money. There are far better seafood places in SF to drop your dough on like Woodhouse Fish company, Hog Island or Anchor and Hope.

However, their manhattans and martinis, LOVE!  The classic martini involves gin or if you MUST use vodka (sigh) the version here at Tadich is dry and served with pimiento stuffed olives. 

Their Manhattan is made with Old Crow whiskey and Cinzano sweet vermouth. Don't be aghast if Mr. barman puts a maraschino cherry in your glass, instead of some fancy housemade brandied cherry, because that's the way they've always done it and they won't change it for you. 

Tadich is the oldest resto in SF (they have a sign that says so!) They've been here since 1928 and you bet that they stick to their traditions. So, don't go looking for "fancy and new" cocktails -- visit the past and stay there for a moment. This is definitely one place where you want history to keep repeating itself.
author: Janice C.

description: Doesn't get better than this. A "cup" of their Boston Clam chowder and "small" Dungeness crab salad was quite the midday meal. Outstanding and not to be missed. Classic gin and tonic was the best sampled in the city. Old time decor and service can't be beat.
author: Jennifer V.

description: The experience was great.   The Ciappino was the best I've had yet.
author: David K.

description: Had an excellent meal at the Tadich Grill last night. I was told beforehand to order the cioppino and it did not disappoint. They even give you a bib to wear throughout the meal when you order it! My girlfriend order the crab cakes and they were delicious too.
author: Scott H.

description: So, I found Tadich Grill because of Yelp, and when I heard that it was one of the oldest restaurants in the city, I knew I had to go. My fiancee and I went on a Monday night around 5 P.M. because we were hungry and it was a short walk from our hotel. We were seated immediately and brought bread and butter. The butter is so cold and hard that you cannot spread it on the bread. This may not be a big deal to some people, but I hate plain bread. My fiancee ordered the ribeye, which he said was good. The ribeye is served with potatoes and vegetables. He asked our waiter if he could sub those out and the waiter said no but that he could order something else a la carte. I had the crab cakes with rice and vegetables. I grew up in Virginia and have always ate Chesapeake Blue Crab, and I honestly think that the Dungeness crab tastes a lot different, not in a good way so it was not what I was expecting. They put some sort of remoulade/tartar sauce on your crab cakes, and I was not a fan of that either because it tasted a lot like just mayo and dill. The vegetables served were lifeless, no seasoning whatsoever. The server was rude, he made little comments and what he did say came out very short and curt. I was honestly afraid to ask him for things. Lastly, having experienced Tadich and the quality of food they serve there, I would say this restaurant is heavily overpriced. There is no culinary genius going on there, it's just a restaurant capitalizing on its history. Do yourself a favor and book it over to one of the restaurants in the Ferry building before it closes instead of going here, your taste buds and wallet will thank you.
author: Caroleigh N.

description: Very yummy good and great atmosphere.  I took a friend from out of town and she loved it.
author: allison h.

description: This is the classic tourist trap. There are no reservations so that meant we waited for one hour to be seated. Once we got seated we order crab cakes and snapper. Both were mediocre at best. The food was very bland and there was nothing special about it. There are many good restaurants in SF, stay clear of this one.
author: Carlos A.

description: Awesome service. Delicious food. Excellent drinks! As a tourist to SF this was really one of my favorite places to eat. The ambience is great! The service was amazing. I will be recommending it to anyone visiting San Fransisco
author: Jazmin P.

description:
Beautiful old building with a strong history (160 yrs) I mean holly cannoli!! 

I'm just 34 and it's hard to grasp how much history this establishment holds. Staff that look like they jumped out of the 20's in their starched white coats and true dishes that stand the test of time. Everything changes, all the time and it's awesome to know that some things only change a bit. 

I've been here several times right around 4:30-5 which is the perfect time. Past the time of the lunch crowd and just before the dinner rush. 

I sit at the counter which is A+ service with the waiters passing by every other minute. There are a few different servers that work the counter and my favorite who's name has escaped me is a young light hair gentleman. He is friendly, personable and never leaves you wanting something. Drinks refilled, lemon for the fish, whatever your request.
author: Jessica M.

description: I have been coming here once a month since '77, eating the Chopino  it WAS the best in the country.   It is really off now, i noticed it going stale and very watery the last few times.  Finally the last time a few weeks ago it tasted like airplane food.  I have tried everything else over the last 30 yrs. and the fish tastes like fried fish sticks.  The Chiopino was the thing at Tadich as all the locals know. To bad another tradition i have to give up on.
author: phil b.

description: Great seafood. Great service. The cioppino (seafood stew) was loaded with fish and shellfish. It's flavored like a Louisiana shrimp creole. A companion also had the Chilean sea bass and said it was great too. Minus one star because they don't take Amex.
author: James H.

description:
I had heard some good things about Tadich Grill and read some more on their website. Sounded like my kind of place, a nice traditional (and historic) Seafood and Steakhouse restaurant.  So I took a co-worker there for dinner.  What a disappointment.

We arrived just before the dinner rush (around 5:00PM) and were seated immediately. Our waiter was not what I would call the friendly or outgoing type. He spoke to us in very short phrases, offered no information on the menu or drinks available, and seemed disinterested in us throughout our meal. When he brought us our food, he reversed our orders and seemed almost annoyed when my co-worker and I started to switch our plates.  He grabbed them from us, without a word, and then placed them in front of the proper person.  That was odd to say the least.

The food itself was completely lack luster. I ordered the New York Strip. I was surprised first of all to receive a steak that was less than an inch thick. At a steakhouse like this I would have expected a nice thick cut, especially on a NY Strip. The steak was cooked unevenly. I had ordered medium yet on one end it was done to a very well, in the middle it was about medium, and on the other end it was almost rare. The seasonings were OK but overall the flavor lacked any real character.  The steak came with their house potatoes, basically broasted potato wedges. These had very little flavor at all, and in fact I had to dip them in steak sauce just to make them palatable.

My Co-worker ordered the "Jumbo" Prawns which turned out to be anything but jumbo. Definitely not what you'd get if you went to any super market and bought a bag of shrimp labeled "Jumbo".  He did express that despite being smaller than expected they were tasty.

We both agreed this was a fairly negative experience and chose to pass on dessert, not even looking at the dessert menu. For all the build-up and the appearances presented, the experience was surprising and unfortunate.  I must say that the food and service that I had at a different chain steakhouse earlier in the week was far more enjoyable than this day's dinner.
author: Tony M.

description: Come here for the Cioppino! You won't be disappointed. The only strange part about coming here is that there are no female wait staff. Kind of old fashioned if you ask me.
author: Pam C.

description: Great time! Great food!  Not to be missed.  They don't take reservations so go early. They also won't seat you until your whole party is present.  Not to fret because the bar experience is not to be missed.  The bartenders are witty and knowledgeable.  If you feel brave tell your waiter what you don't like and let him pick your meal.  Marion was our waiter and he picked the perfect meal.  It can be noisy.  There are tables that a like small,private dining tables, we were lucky to have one and can be worth the wait if you don't like noise.  The dessert was good, nothing special. A great part of San Francisco history.
author: Renee H.

description: The Tadich Grill is definitely old San Francisco, and I thought it was more of a tourist trap than a high end restaurant.  They have disclaimers in the menu that if your fish comes with any bones, they don't care, and I thought that was the attitude of the restaurant itself.  The waiters, in their white jackets, look as though they've all worked there for years, and our waiter seemed annoyed because we asked too many questions (he said he had been there for 18 years).  Their menu is extensive, and I ordered the fried lobster.  Definitely should have chosen something else.  Very chewy and not at all flavorful. Their drinks are small (my martini was about half of what I would get at any hotel) and the same price.  This restaurant is packed and noisy, so it's definitely somewhere everyone seems to try, but it's very expensive, and I didn't think it was worth the money.  I'm sure there are plenty of other seafood restaurants in the area that are better.
author: Maureen C.

description:
Phenomenal cioppino and garlic bread.  Exactly what I was looking for and didn't disappoint.  Very good wine list - try the Morgan Metallico Chardonnay for a very different but pleasing oak-free Chardonnay experience.

The one negative: a friend and I both ate our fair share (and more) of cioppino, and our stomachs were a little upset afterwards.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Love the history behind this place, and the old-fashioned lunch counter/bar...but the food is rather bland and all tastes like it's as old as the restaurant (in style, not quantity) ... There were still iceberg lettuce salads on the menu (all the rage in the 50s and 60s) and a lot of sauces and preparations that I only see in vintage-store cookbooks. My crab cake (which was nice but not outstanding) had a little hollowed-out cherry pepper hat that I thought was actually a cherry at first - a bit disconcerting!

Service is adequate, but not attentive or friendly. 

I did love checking out all the old woodwork!
author: Celeste T.

description:
Worst service ever.

A friend of mind arrived and was sitting at the bar with a drink. When I showed up with another friend, they immediately sat us.

Me: Thanks buddy, this worked out perfectly! Friend: It was easy, I just asked for a table for three.
Me: Oh, it's actually four.
Waiter: (Death glare) This is a problem, we do not seat parties until everyone arrives.
Me: I'm so sorry, it was a miscommunication. We're ready to order for all four right now if that helps.
Waiter: It doesn't. (Crosses arms, scowls deeply). This is a very serious problem. Where is the fourth person?
Me: I'm not sure, I think he's on his way. 
Waiter: Well this is a very serious problem (walks away).

I'm frantically calling the 4th person who has just arrived. Everyone at the table is taken aback by how utterly hostile and pretentious this waiter acted. Policies are policies, but it was an honest mistake and they had lots of open tables anyway! We would have happily gotten up and waited at the bar if the waiter had asked, but he just glared and yelled at us. Super. Helpful.

SF friend: This is old school SF. Still, geez.
AZ friend, in town visiting: What a jerk. Way to start the dinner off horribly! Well, this is awkward and uncomfortable.
Me: #!%€£!&)#?! Let's go somewhere else.
Friend that arrived last: Why do you guys all look so startled/upset/pissed?

We stayed, because my friend visiting really wanted to try the cioppino, but the waiter made us wait a really long time before coming to take our drink orders - as punishment, I suppose - and everyone was mildly concerned that spit and/or non-food would come with our entrees. Every time the waiter came to our table, he had a supercilious smirk on his face, God knows why. 

Not going to review the food, because however good or bad it might have been, the waiter's deplorable attitude left an awful taste in my mouth!
author: Crystal M.

description: I went here last night as a first timer and I will continue to come back. I had the Bone in Rib Eye Steak and my friend had the Cippino. The food was to die for and the service was excellent! I've never had a steak prepared to perfection. Since it was my birthday I ordered desert and when the waiter brought it out the whole restaurant began to sing happy birthday to me. This place was awesome and I would totally recommend it to all my friends.
author: Ayee M.

description: The building is cool like an art deco train depot. The servers all dress like dentists which is pretty funny. Lively place with lots of happy, well-fed, liquored up crazy San Franciscans--pretty entertaining. Got shrimp cocktail as an appetizer, pretty hard to screw that up but it was delicious. I got a crab leg and lobster thermidor: quite indulgent, heavy cream sauce, but it was absolutely brilliant. Great place I felt taken care of. Make sure to read the history lesson on the menu of the Original "Cold Day" restaurant, a staple of SF since 1849.
author: Clark S.

description: The oldest restaurant in SF! It still looks old school on the inside with the style and decor, but the restaurant has been well maintained. It was pretty packed so expect a 20-30minute wait. The menu is huge and seems to be printed everyday, I think they switch up a few things on the menu based on what kind of fish is available. I had the corn beef hash which came with one egg, potato, and vegetables. Unfortunately I wasn't allowed to choose what kind of potatoes or vegetables I got. The waiter told me it would be a mix of broccoli, zucchini, and more, but it came out with cooked spinach? And I was expecting hash browns but I got a boiled potato. Neither the spinach or the potato was very good, but the hash was amazing! My dad ordered a lobster and crab dish, and mentioned that while the dish tasted good, the crab was not shelled very well. His dish came with the long potatoes which weren't great, they were like very thick fries. Overall it was good food but not great, I would still recommend though, it especially for the atmosphere.
author: Buford C.

description:
This was my first meal off the flight and I was not disappointed. I walked in around 6pm and I was immediately seated at the bar, in my opinion, that's the best seats!  I looked around and felt I time traveled back to 1849! The feeling on its own is reason enough to come here.

My mission was to try their oyster and sand dab. The waiter recommended the Rockefeller instead of the trio and the sand dab over every other fish. This is my first time so I went with it, and boy was I rewarded handsomely on a culinary expedition..

The Oyster Rockefeller was baked with plenty of cheese and spinach with a hint of Pernod.They were tasty, even though the size of the oyster was very small, it was very good. Wiping the shell up with a piece of Sourdough bread was a great way to finish each oyster. There were 6 and 1 baked tomato in the center. I knew I also have the Sand dab coming so I offer the person next to me a taste of the oyster and to help me managed all the food a little bit.

The sand dab, came de-boned. with a serving of steamed cauliflower, Brussels sprout tossed with butter and chunky steak cut fries and a side of tartar sauce.  The fish was pan fried, with crispy exterior coating that was just right. This is my first sand dab, I must said I liked it, and I liked it a lot! The flesh is very delicate, mild and tender. Pairing it with a tab of the house made tartar sauce reminded why I was hooked on this heavenly combination all those years ago when mom first introduced me to Fish and chips, except this is on a completely new level.

I spend my time finishing my sand dab, the only caution I must made is that there are residual bones here and there, so do be careful. Take your time chewing the crunchy bits while looking out for bones was a experience on its own.  The Tadich veggie is better than most, I loved the B.Sprouts, the fries with the Tartar sauce was just the way I like it. everything was so simply made it was great.

Over all, the bill came to just shy of $50, looking back, compare to Yank Sing, this was money well spent. Next time I will try the luscious Cioppino....
author: R's C.

description:
I already feel guilty for giving a 1-star rating, so need to provide full justification.  Here goes:

The girlfriend and were being perfect tourists in the awesome city and decided to go to a local-favorite.  Yelp suggested Tadich and the place looked interesting.

We spoke to the person behind the counter and asked if we could get a table for 3 (were expecting a friend to show up later).  First of all, we were only offered a table for 2.  Which is fine.

What wasn't fine was the way this person was talking.  He'd interrupt our sentences very rudely.  This wasn't even the worst part.  While were talking to him about the seating and menu stuff, he interrupted us again and started talking on phone.  This happened thrice in a matter of 5 minutes (out of which we probably got only 30 seconds worth of his attention).  

At one point in time, I really thought that it was some kind of a trick or something.  Or probably this guy was doing an extremely unlikeable version of Mr. Bean's character from Love Actually!

That was when we decided to head out.   I really think that these guys earned a 1-star here.
author: Ankit C.

description:
It was a blistery cold night that we wonder in and how glad we were that we did.  Along with the most delectable fish, we'll get to that next, it just the cutest place I've seen in SF.   Ok it is the oldest restaurant in town, so it has built in charm and luckily the owners haven't tried to change the setup.  They have a very long horseshoe bar with little booths along one wall. One might expect the waiters to be snooty but they couldn't be lovelier.  The place has a fresh feel especially for being so old.  Not sure who cleans it but my house could use their help.  
Now for the piece de resistance.  The fish, oh the joy each dish brought us. I had the cioppino, my daughters the seafood saute and the calamari steak.  We couldn't keep out of each other plates and didnt want to share as each was cooked to perfection with the right combination of ingredients.   Our only regret was not getting the clam chowder which the gentleman next to me had and I was trying to steal a taste so we are headed there for lunch before leaving town.
author: J W.

description:
Not entirely sure what the fuss is about, but it's a decent restaurant. My $15 "large" Caesar salad was overpriced, without chicken, and too small for what I paid -- despite being told the food came in big portions.

Having said that, it tasted good. I liked that tables had a place to hang my coat and bag. My waiter was attentive and shook my hand at the end of the meal, which was somewhere between a nice touch and too personal. Each table had a big half loaf of bread on it, which to me is a cheap ploy to fill people up with empty carbs and distract them from a lack of real food.

I might try it again because it had that "old white man" throwback atmosphere to it, and some of the fish selections looked really delicious.
author: David S.

description:
Great San Francisco establishment.  Can not go wrong here.  Lots of history and ambiance.  Fast and efficient service.

Cioppino is a must.  Have to order it every time I come into town.
author: David M.

description:
This place sucks.

The wait time for a party of 2 wasn't that bad for a saturday night, like 25 minutes when we were told 45, but what really ruined it was the service. We weren't ready to order when the bald waiter first came up to us so he waited about 17 minutes to even acknowledge us again. Other tables with white patrons received standard comments like "enjoy" and other chatter, but he said absolutely nothing when he placed our dishes in front of us or at any other point in our meal. 

I ordered the seafood cannelloni florentine and it sucked. The cheesiness overwhelmed the unrecognizable seafood mush. The cioppino was really good though. 

I would avoid this place, there are tons of better options in the city with better prices. I regret not deciding to go to osha down the street.
author: Ryan C.

description: Hands down best seafood I've had! Definitely worth checking out. This is one of the oldest restaurants in SF. If you want a table you'll have to wait awhile, but I love that you can grab a seat at the bar. I come here for the scallops and I'll definitely be back.
author: Katie E.

description:
I came here for the work group lunch. I had a seabass, a whole fish dish from the special menu. The fish was fresh and well prepared with cocktail and tartar sauce. The vegetables are not cooked enough, too hard for me with no flavor. I would say, the food was no more than an average, I definitely wasn't blown away.

They are pretty strict about their policy, no reservation and not being seated until everyone shows up.

I'd never come here if I have to pay for it.
author: Yoko S.

description:
They don't take reservations.

You go, check in with the host, ask for an estimated time. Tables are a longer wait than the bar.

Luckily it was about 6pm, a table came up in about 20min.

The pork chops were good, however, the entree comes with brocolli and potato. Um... three brocolli and one small potato sliced.

Street parking.
author: qirk z.

description:
Have been wanting to come to Tadich Grill for years! We finally went last night. It has such a cool old San Francisco vibe, and the service is great!

We ordered the Oysters Rockefeller for our appetizer, and for dinner I had the Seafood Saute, and my husband had the Rib Eye. The oysters were on point, and the Seafood Saute was delicious. The butter sauce was amazing, and I can't stop thinking about the crab leg meat....Mmmmm! The Rib eye was pretty good as well, but definitely not the best I've had.

For dessert, we had the bourbon bread pudding. Good flavor, but the bread was a bit dry. I prefer the gooey bread pudding.

Overall a really good experience, and would like to come back again!
author: Jackie G.

description: I thought the waiter was pulling a fast one on me when he said this is the oldest restaurant in SF. I looked it up, it is true! It has been around from 1859. I love the old school decor with a lot of wood and booths. Our waiter was a nice older gentleman.  I got the cabbage and corned beff. It was a big portion and filling. Note this place is not a good option if you don't like seafood. They do get busy, get there early. Worst case, no worries, there are a lot of other good restaurants in the area.
author: Sunil R.

description: It was over 10 years since we last enjoyed a meal here.  Came in for lunch and the enjoyed some clam chowder, sourdough bread with crab cakes and some sauvignon blanc wine.  Still great food and great service with an old world charm, love it!
author: Ruben C.

description:
The food and service were as good as always. 
The sourdough bread is so good. Fresh and crunchy with lots of real butter. 
The red clam chowder is always one of my favorites. Full of clams and crisp veggies .

The sand dab dinner was very savory. A generous portion of pan fried sand dabs, stir fried pea pods, and these huge potato wedges.

Our server 9.bar2 was fantastic. 
Only negative, no dinner reservations.



Don't miss the Tadich when in San Francisco.
author: Bill H.

description:
GOOD FOOD. HORRIBLE ROTTEN WAITER
It is such a disappointment when you hear about a restaurant for years-a San Francisco "institution" finally go there for a special occasion  day before Mothers Day and have a huge dent put in it by a very crappy waiter. 3 hours ago my 81 year old mom and me were at Tadich Grill. We ordered sand dabs. The waiter asks filet or bone in and we both say filet. Nearly every mouthful of very tasty sand dab had bones in it. I mean tons of bones. I counted 42 in less than half my order and i still have a few lodged in the back of my throat.I told the waiter there were a LOT of bones in my sand dabs and he says over his shoulder as he exits"Yeah they have a lot of little bones in them" HUH? What does filet mean? I have probably sent back 3 meals in my life but the waiters response was the WRONG ANSWER. And so casually said. And we had to beg for bread and tarter sauce and water. I tried to get his name but he passed us on to another waiter named Ken (wonderful waiter) without even telling us. Even Dennys does better than that. So if you see a bald stocky waiter(I think his name was George) RUN. A real loser. A detriment to Tadich Grill. Booo
author: julie a.

description:
What can I say it's a San Francisco staple. It's the oldest surviving business in the city and it's what it's supposed to be. It's where the hodge podge meet for lunch. Where attorneys go to speak legalese over some cioppino and chowder and where brokers go to seal the deal over something like hanger town fries. It's where I go for power lunches. It's not just lunch, it's a statement, it's a power play. 

It's a pretty penny for its old style charm and appeal. It's a time capsule and it continues to be the FIDI draw. They don't have to change a damn thing. They just need to keep pumping away at the power lunch hours and happy hour and they are set. 

You have to have the chowder, calamari steak, hang town fries and cioppino, you also have to do the braised short ribs and the lobster ravioli. Nothing cheaper than about $20. For two expect to pay at least $100 with appetizers and drinks. 

Enjoy it for what it is. Don't mind the waiters, that personality is part of the appeal. It's like mystery dining... There is so much more that goes into it than just the food.
author: Ryan C.

description: This place has the best cioppino in town. I tried several other places while I was in SF, and wished that I had time to go back to this place. Serving was generous for two persons - plenty of seafoods. Tried their crab cocktails as well, but as other crab cocktails, nothing beats cracking and eating the freshly steamed crabs straight.
author: Tommy C.

description:
Been coming here for 20 + years when I travel to SF.
I am from Brooklyn Heights and East Quogue.

This is the Best on the West hands down!
Order whatever your waiter tells you.
