This is the West Coast at its best.   These guys have been fishing the SF Bay since 
1846.  
 
Its the bomb for the West Coast.
When I arrive in SF I go directly to 342 California.
The waiters have been there many for over 20 years.
The seafood is the absolute freshest and best.
Amen!
Namaste!  
KT

PS.  A
ll the side dishes are made to order.
Rely on your waiter but forget the price.
Just enjoy.
author: Karen F.

description:
The cioppino was among the finest meals that we have ever eaten.  My wife and I agree that it is definitely one of our top ten!

The cioppino's broth was and delicious, and a generous helping of prawns, fish, oysters, and crab meat was just icing on the cake.  My wife could not finish the plate, so I gladly took over.=)

The dungeness crab and prawns a la monza were perfect!  The style of the dish reminds me of baked HK dishes at Maxim's or Garden Cafe, only this was SO MUCH BETTER.  The quantity and quality of crab alone...you couldn't even see the rice underneath.  

The only thing that needed improvement was the sourdough bread that they give you - it was really dense.  Oh yes, and don't get soda/ice tea.  There are no refills, and they give you such a small cup that held more ice than soda.
author: Steve L.

description:
I enjoyed my meal very much. I had the Oyster Rockfeller dish. For my meal, I had the curry shrimp casserole dish with some chutney. Delicious!!!

Service was amazing. The waiters were very pleasant and willing to serve us. I'm very very pleased!!!
author: Rufus B.

description: Great food! I loved the fact the restaurant has the old style charm! We ordered the jumbo prawn appetizer, a bowl of Boston clam chowder and the pan fried petrale sole. The food come out beautifully and tasted great! I will definitely go back and try the branzino and ribeye!
author: Jay D.

description:
Boy friend brought me here for my birthday dinner! Seafood everything. I was pretty satisfy. Old style seafood restaurant.
Foods was flavorful and pretty big portion. 
Pretty pricy for a regular date night dinner. But for special occasion, this is a good place!
author: Jasmine Y.

description: We visited this warm establishment after it came highly recommended by a tourist visiting San Diego. We were not disappointed! The cuisine was the best sea food I've tasted in San Francisco, and the staff were courteous. The ambience reflects a retro vibe that is accommodating to small and large groups.
author: Sean A.

description:
We read about this place in the Contra Costa Times. We hit the door about 3:45 on a Tuesday and there was plenty of tables available so we were seated right away.

The service was great. My husband had the ravioli with meat sauce. He say it was pretty good. He liked the nice thick pasta of the ravioli. He found the sauce a bit mild. I had the cioppino which was great.
author: Rachelle M.

description: Extremely disappointed with the service specifically from the Asian server behind the bar. My boyfriend and I had come in for a drink to check out the ambiance we had heard so many great things about. I was asked to get up from the bar because the seating was reserved for diners only. What kind of place asks a paying customer to get up simply because we were having drinks only.
author: Heather B.

description: Good lord. So much good food. We were here for Father's Day and probably went a little nuts ordering. The calamari and shrimp cocktail appetizers were both very good. Between the four of us we put back two steaks, crab cakes, a gorgeous broiled halibut filet and some sautéed shrimp. I tried all of it was not disappointed by a single bite. The service was excellent and the booth was nice. Would love to go back and try some of their wine and bar offerings and deserts another time. The fact they don't accept reservations looks to be a little daunting (we got in right before dinner rush apparently), so take that into consideration prior to making your way out there. And parking is a mess, I would highly recommend shelling out the 10 bucks to take advantage of the on site valet parking. Regardless of some very minor detriments I would absolutely repeat the experience at TG.
author: Kevin L.

description: Excellent old school restaurant in the financial district. Suggest the New England clam chowder and broiled halibut.
author: Mark H.

description:
She's an old time beauty set in old world deco....

Got to the restaurant around 8:30 PM on a Thursday night. We were told the wait would be about 40 minutes for a table but could wait at the bar. Sat down at an opening at the bar in about 20 minutes and after 5 minutes of perusing a menu we were seated. 

The waiters tend to remind you of the "what you see is what you get", no frills, East Coast attitude type of fellas, but I was chagrined at how they all smiled through the chaos and gave you the impression that, even w/ the noise and the big crowd everything was going to be alright. 

It's all about the ambiance....nothing pretentious. Hell, the most modern item I found in the restaurant was the hand-activated paper towel dispenser in the men's room. I love the mirrors on the walls of the restaurant and mahogany décor and dimmed lighting. Another Yelper described the restaurant as a venue you might see in the 60's show Mad Men, but I would say less formal. At one point in our dinner, 2 women and a man at the bar were obviously "sloused" and making an albeit "happy"  commotion...to the point that we could clearly hear them from 75' away. I thought they would surely be escorted out, but the barkeep actually continued to banter with them and continued to make their experience the best. I got the feeling that the staff recognizes we all work our "arses off" during the work week, and they are willing to cut you some slack at this establishment. 

The Cioppino was very tasty and the portion was very large. 

Overall, I can see myself dropping into the fine establishment a couple times per year.
author: Jim L.

description:
Glad we were able to experience this place on a recent trip to san fran. Reminded me of Joe's stone crab in miami beach. Waiters who know their trade and who have been there decades. 

Ciopinno was spectacular as were the oysters rockefellar. Will be back next time we in san fran.
author: Jorge G.

description: Pan fried petrale sole was more like deep-fried petrale sole. Had I looked at dozens of pictures online BEFORE ordering, I would not have made this mistake. There is one pic in Feb 2015 where the sole looks pan-fried and not overdone. Overall very disappointed in our dinner on a celebratory trip to SF for my daughter's b-day. Sourdough bread was just ok. Our waiter was super-friendly...until the minute he took our order. After that, he lost interest. Not sure I will return to Tadich after this experience.
author: Suzie E.

description: The place has decent food, but the service was bad. My waiter was so rude. He messed up with my dish, instead of apologizing, he blamed me it was my fault. Not going back to this place for sure.
author: Linda J.

description:
I usually try to avoid old fashioned restaurants because the service is usually awful. This place was no different but the food was so good it didn't even matter. 

They don't take reservations so we had a 35 minute wait along the wall next to the bar. We tried to get drinks but apparently you can only order drinks at one part of the bar so we just gave up. 

Once we were seated, the waiter took our drink orders and gave us bread. I hated the bread but my date loved it. It was cold and crusty. 

Crab Leg Cocktail: This was the best thing I've tasted in a while and it was just crab meat and cocktail sauce. The crab was like fucking butter and the cocktail sauce had a good kick to it. We were about to just get the crab cocktail because I thought the crab leg cocktail came shelled but our waiter told us we had to get the crab leg cocktail since its the better part of the crab and it was shelled already weeeeeeee. So fucking good. 

Cod w/ Polenta: I completely forgot the name of my entree which is funny considering it took me a good 20 minutes to figure out what to order. Their menu is extensive. My entree was sooooooooo good. I wish I had better adjectives to describe it. It was so much food I had to get most of it to go though. It had capers and shrimp and cream sauce. All my favorite things! 

Bourbon Bread Pudding: I think the sauce was straight up reduced bourbon. This dessert was far too heavy considering I was already food coma'd out. It wasn't the best bread pudding either.

Rice Pudding: I thought this was going to be an actual pudding but it was in a cut up square form. It was nice and light. Way better than the bread pudding. I wish I had ordered that instead. 

The ambiance was nice. The restaurant is incredibly loud and I found myself almost having to yell across the table. It seemed almost a little too touristy. My date and I are both huge seafood lovers and I told him to surprise me with a restaurant. I was definitely impressed. 

The service sucked though and I hate bad service. I even heard my waiter yell 'OUT OF MY WAY' to a customer who was trying to walk back to his table. WTF? Our waiter would also walk away before we were even done ordering. The restaurant reminded me of a steakhouse but for seafood. 

Also I had no idea the new Michael Mina was located next door. Its so pretty!!!! Me wants me wants.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Tadich Grill is a time machine; you step into this place, you step back at least 75 years to the San Francisco of old; the people were surly but eloquently opinionated, vivacious, stylish, and famished -- but that's okay, because they were also affably drunk, and the oceans were salubrious and brimming with delicacies.  

I have been coming to TG for almost 15 years.   Once or twice a year I indulge in a long weekend trip to San Francisco (up from Los Angeles), and I never miss dinner at Tadich Grill when I am in town.   If you could try cioppino only once in your life, it should be here.    True, it now costs around $32.00, but it's like devouring an ocean of flavor in every succulent spoonful.  

I've witnessed very few changes here over the years, and I am grateful for that.
author: Aidan B.

description:
Came here to reunite with my dad & my sister for lunch. The food was amazing & the service was impecable. Seating was great & our booth gave us the privacy to speak with one another over a fab lunch during 2013 Christmas season. Ive fond memories here & would chose this place again for only a very Special occassion. It was expensive & very fancy, but you pay for it with first class food drinks & experience.

Menu is a bit massive - we all had different seafood dishes which were tantalizing. My choice (cant remember exactly) melted in my mouth like golden butter.... I really was impressed here!
author: Julian I.

description:
Items selected:

Tadich Sourdough Loaf

Seafood Cioppino with Garlic Bread - daily preparation including clams, prawns, scallops, bay shrimp, crabmeat and sand dabs

Tadich Rice Custard Pudding

Bourbon Bread Pudding

One of the oldest and most well known restaurants in the entire Bay Area, Tadich Grill had been on my 'to do' list during each of my previous trips to San Francisco yet for some inexplicable reason it was not until lunch at Perbacco the day prior that I finally resolved to go, a midday seat at the famous bar with the full attention of a longtime server named Anton my reward for dining at an off hour.  A restaurant with a menu almost as extensive as its history it was with much debate and discussion with Anton that I eventually decided on the Cioppino as opposed to the sand dabs or the thermidor but taking him on his word that 'every first timer should try the cioppino and the sourdough' I can only say that if the other options were somehow better I'd be shocked as the garlicky tomato based broth overflowing with fresh seafood was undoubtedly an archetype of the dish - impressive on its own and all the better when sopped up with the supplied garlic bread or the tangy sourdough.  Never one to pass on dessert I again deferred to my server once the cioppino consisted of a dry bowl and a few clam shells but this time when he recommended the rice custard pudding I did the only thing logical by taking a large scoop of the creamy caramelized rice flan to go while indulging in a square of the restaurant's sourdough saturated in custard and topped with boozy caramel plus whipped cream right there at the counter.
author: Michael U.

description:
This place is old school with all the waiters wearing aprons and the place to sit is at the bar.  This is a good place to go if you are in San Fran solo since you can sit at the bar and make friends with the folks beside you (no gaps are allowed between place sittings).

The fish is the way to go ... I always get the sole but the Cioppino is supposed to be great too.  I always enjoy a glass or two of white wine (nice selection) and the rice pudding makes a great dessert (special recipe).

Also the Dungeness crab appetizer is spectacular.  This is a solid bet every time I am in San Francisco.
author: Michael C.

description: Excellent food with old school charm. Classic cocktails with outstanding seafood options.  This place has been in business for over 150 years!!!
author: PJ F.

description:
Ok I really wanted to like this place, mainly because it was my idea to go here for lunch one day while in the City.  My group was in the mood for fresh seafood and when Yelping on my iPhone, this restaurant came up.  

First of all, the service is so disappointing.  Our waiter was extremely rude, condescending, and seemed to talk down to everybody.  My party thought it was just to us, but then we paid attention to his interaction with others and noticed similar behavior.  Oddly, this didn't provide us with much comfort.

The food was just mediocre.  Fish quality was just mediocre.  One thing - all dishes were heavily salted.  We ordered the following: 

prawn cocktail appetizer - shrimp was overcooked and rough 
clam chowder - WAY too much starch!
seafood plate - pretty good.  the tartar sauce is different and tasty
branzino - just ok
crab louie salad - pretty large portion.  very salty even with the dressing served on the side.  

Between the brash and condescending service, mediocre and salty food, and strange vibe in the restaurant (feels like a Republican convention given the clientele that was there), I think it takes a special kind of person to enjoy this restaurant.
author: Anna M.

description: Tadich Grill doesn't take reservations. When we got there at around 8:45 on a Friday night, they put us on a list and said that the wait would be 45 minutes. Our party of 3 people came back at 9:30, which also happened to be the closing time of the restaurant. In fact, the doors were locked and the kitchens were closing, but the waiters were *super nice* and let us in. Props to Tadich Grill for that! I ordered a fish plate (I forgot the name of the plate since I ordered so quickly). For something so expensive ($20-$30), I was expecting a little more...the fish was too fried for my taste. I'm chalking that up to the fact that they were pretty much closing by then though. I might come back and try this place again when it's less crowded.
author: Daylen Y.

description:
I love the Tadich.  When I lived around the corner it was one of my favorite weekend lunch spots.  My favorite was cruising in with my paper in hand and starting off with a crab leg cocktail and finishing with cioppino.

The crab is tasty and fresh.  The cioppino is ridiculous.  100% seafood in a hearty broth served with crunchy garlic bread.

Highly recommended to both locals and tourists alike.
author: Phil S.

description:
Tadich Grill is where I take my family and closest friends if we are to only have one meal together while they visit San Francisco. 

90% of the time I order the Seafood Cioppino, 10% of the time I regret not ordering the cioppino.

Cioppino is a beautifully hearty tomato stew, of fish, shellfish, and really all sorts of substantial chunks of seafood. It originated in SF (and Tadich has been doing it for I think 160+ years) and the one here is truly an experience that will connect you to your time in this wonderful city. I've had excellent cioppino at Swan Oyster Depot, but this will forever be my favorite and one of my top 5 memorable dishes of all time. Be sure to share this experience with the best of company.

***

Please trust that you need not read anymore than this: if a $30 dish is in your price range and you enjoy hearty, flavor-rich stew, go try this cioppino.

***

If you've already penciled it into your calendar and are seeking validation and increased anticipation of your (excellent) choice, then read on for details.

Entering the long and narrow restaurant, you were invariably see a crowd of people in front and lined shoulder-to-shoulder behind the diners at the bar along the right hand wall, most of whom are clutching wine glasses while waiting. The decor brings you back in time, refined yet understated, with a long U-shaped bar comprising the main dining space. Do not come in your ill-fitting t-shirt and hoodie--not because the Financial District locale pretentiously demands business-casual attire, but because you respect the tradition and dignity of this place, and the experience it will grant you.

The servers behind the bar and generally grandfatherly, and seemingly no one has changed position from the first time I ate here 7 years ago. You will be seated and treated to delicious sourdough bread and butter, and have the opportunity to choose from a solid wine collection. You will not impress a date with how much you know about whatever chateaus on the wine menu, you will be impressed with the quality of the night's house chardonnay.

On to the cioppino. You will receive a plastic bib; wearing it is optional. You will instinctively reach first for one of the two hunks of garlic bread toast rising from the stew, because the assemblage of seafood in the center is initially overwhelming. The bread, softened at the base by the briny tomato broth, is sublime. 

Each element of the cioppino is fresh and cooked well. The broth has enough of a salty bite to engage your palette and bring all the chunky seafood elements together, and is layered and rich on its own. You may not be able to finish the entire dish. But you sure as hell will try.
author: Eddie L.

description: Visiting from Seattle for my hubby's 50th birthday.  I saw this restaurant mentioned on the food network and have wanted to try the sand dabs ever since!  We don't often have the opportunity to treat ourselves to such a great dining experience and were looking forward to the delicious seafood.  We both loved the sand dabs, deep-fried scallops, and the Chilean sea bass was so incredibly fresh and tender.  My son didn't love the pasta with marinara because of all the veggies in it, but he devoured the garlic bread.  The only thing I didn't love were the potatoes that came with the sand dabs and scallops.  Kind of like giant jo-jos without seasoning.  I personally was excited to eat at one of the oldest restaurants in the US and being Croatian myself,  it felt like a little bit of having my Grandparents again because it reminded me of them taking me out to nice restaurants when I was a child.
author: Elissa C.

description:
Ok ok ok, so it's a little pricey here, but this is the oldest restaurant in California. So you are kinda sorta paying for the "history" lol.

Don't bother wasting time on the mixed greens salad, it's not all that special..  But I must say that the Seafood Cioppino is ahh-mazinggg! It is soo delish! I am a seafood lover and I'm proud of it! Everything was properly prepared and well cooked. I will always look for an excuse to come back here again for the Cioppino.

I also like the ambience here, it's warm and welcoming (except when it's crowded for lunch lol). I also like how the employees here wear white lab coats (well, at least that's what they look like to me).

Overall, a worthwhile experience. I will be back for more Cioppino!! ; ))
author: Y. Abigail H.

description:
Amazing Amazing dinner. This restaurant is apparently the oldest restaurant in California, way to be a tourist attraction! This is one of those pricey places that you can't just have once, you have to have several time.

I came in a party of 3 and we were seated immediately. I think it'd because the other parties were of 2 so they had to wait for the appropriate tables.

We started off with Crab Cocktail and Pacific Oyster Rockefeller.
1. Crab Cocktail- so fresh and juicy. The pieces of crab were hearty and perfect with the cocktail sauce
2. Pacific Oyster Rockefeller - I usually am not a fan of oysters but I sure so like these! They're smothered with cheese and spinach and freshly baked. It basically feels like you're eating a fancy spinach artichoke dip. 

For the main entrees, I had the Seafood Cioppino. BEST AND ONLY CIOPPINO I'VE EVER HAD. So delicoius and the seafood broth was perfectly seasoned. They definitely weren't stingy with their seafood, which included clams, fish, scallops, scrimp, mussels. The whole I was eating this, I was like "omg... this is so good. mmm Mmmm yummm". It came with two pieces of crispy garlic bread to bathe in your broth.

I am definitely going to be, no doubt about it.
author: Joyce M.

description: Was very disappointed. The waiter was fantastic but the food left much to be desired.
author: Rhonda B.

description: Always the best sea food presented in the classic to me freshly repainted room. My oysters Rockefeller and wife's new England clam chowder are a perfect late afternoon meal. Arriving at 3pm means no lines and the usual professional service.
author: mik L.

description: Great experience on Saturday night.  They don't take reservations.  Arrived at 7pm and waited about 10 min in bar. Cioppino was outstanding and wife's seafood sautée was equally tasty.  Dessert was carrot cake - delicious. Atmosphere was fun and high energy.  Waiter was good, though could have been friendlier.  Will return and recommend to friends
author: Kailua N.

description:
5-star Cioppino! The best in the city! Do not go anywhere else!

Cioppino is a fish stew that originated in San Francisco. And, what better place to have it than in the oldest operating restaurant in San Francisco!

I have explored the city far and wide for the best cioppino for the last 9 years, and without a doubt, with multiple fantastic chefs in the family to back me up, the cioppino here is the best! Enjoy the fantastic portion size (2 ppl can share!), the voluptuous and overflowing variety and quality of fish and the unforgettable broth.

This is the place to impress out-of-towners!

Bon appetit!
author: Anna C.

description: After nearly 35 years of patronizing this fine establishment I was truly disappointed. We had invited another couple visiting from Laguna Beach to experience it for their 1st time. We ordered appetizers which included 2 orders of the Oysters Rockefeller. The spinach part was delicious as always but the oysters were missing from the dish on both orders!  Really crazy when you consider that each order cost nearly $21 per and didn't have the oysters. The rest of our meal was fully 5 star. I don't know what's going on there but this local SFer was embarrassed and saddened that Tadich Grill would let those dishes come out of the kitchen missing the main ingredient.
author: Kk P.

description: I have been here before but it has been a while.  The three of us got here at 6 pm on a week night so did not have to wait for a table.  Our waiter was charming, informative, professional.  We ordered the seafood salad for two to share and another salad with shrimp.  They were delicious and the waiter generously brought us the louie dressing and house french vingarette dressing on the side to try.  Two of us had scallops (with the vegys and rice).  They were the best I have had in the city for a long time!  The 3rd person had the lamb chops.  They were cooked to perfection.  We shared a bottle of Pellegrino.  The bill with tax and tip came to $180.  That is a lot of money for a regular visit but without a doubt a go to place for special occasions.  Also, I love the atmosphere...an old time SF restaurant that still has a happening vibe!
author: H. D.

description: Had a chance to dine here last night.  We were greeted promptly and seated immediately Had the charbroiled Red Pacific Snapper which was cooked to perfection. Our waiter suggested the clam chowder to start which was also fantastic.  I enjoyed our waiter as he was brief and to the point but was not wowed by the service.
author: Mike C.

description:
Very Old School Restaurant. Don't look to be walked through the menu with a lot of pleasantries. Go in, know what you want, enjoy your food and leave.

Cioppino was delicious, as was the clam chowder and pan fried trout. I could pass on the oysters rockerfeller, but its just not my thing. It was like creamed spinach and cheese on top of a baked oyster, just too much mushy stuff together.
author: Johnny C.

description:
BEST MEAL IN THE CITY! 

Seriously. I have dreams about going to Tadich's. Go there immediately and don't order anything but the cioppino. It is TO DIE FOR! I like a nice salmon fillet, or some sushi...but I've never been a mussels and clam sort of a girl. This is so delicious though. The broth is seriously something from heaven and all of the seafood is so tender and perfectly cooked its magical.

I wish I had time to go here every day. I think the cioppino is $31 and $9 more dollars to split a bowl. Honestly, don't eat all day and get your own bowl : ) 

I also love their atmosphere. It's the oldest restaurant in SF and it feels exactly how it should. Very proper waiters/waitresses and it just feels right to get an old fashion gin martini here to match the theme : )

Go here right now. Seriously. Or actually you might not want to because then you'll crave cioppino every hour of every day like I do now. Your choice : )
author: Juliet S.

description: I used to be a regular here but now only come a couple of times a year.  The Manhattan clam chowder is the best anywhere. When available, the sand dabs are outstanding.
author: Frank S.

description:
No nonsense.

Says so right on their website: http://www.tadichgrill.com/

"Whether you're a regular or a first time visitor, the service is always the same: professional, no-nonsense and efficient. Come see for yourself."

So we did. Keeping in the spirit we'll keep this a no nonsense yelp.

Impressive origins dating back to 1849: http://www.tadichgrill.com/history.php

Vintage vibe and decor.

Server that was so efficient and no nonsense that it felt almost like a burden asking him to come back because we weren't ready to order. Smiles were hard to find.

Cioppino deserves the accolades. Outstanding broth begs to have bread dipped and consumed. It's like nachos for the seafood crowd. Fan favorite by far.

Swordfish steak reminded me of tuna. Liked it. Very light. Not overly seasoned. Appreciated the healthy prep (grilled) and sides (steamed veggies, boiled potatoes).

Usually would consider the $30 entree average overpriced. But at least here it comes with a celebrated slice of history on the side.

Worthy of another 164 years? Debatable. Worth checking out to say you were a part of the first 164? Sure.
author: Jason B.

description:
I went to the Tadich Grill at 8.45 pm last week after a longer than normal  day in the office, The place was half empty with plenty available tables at  but as I was on my own they refused me a table only telling me tables were only for parties of two or more I was offered a bar stool but I suggested that as there were plenty tables and it was late and I would prefer to sit at a normal table and chair but  I was refused in a brusque and impolite manner(by the 50ish balding bar  person ) perhaps I should have left immediately but it was late and I needed to eat so I took the bar stool they offered me.

My stool at the end of the bar right next to the kitchen and was handed a menu by another equally rude waiter(Asian waiter) who promptly told me to order as the as kitchen would be closing at 9.30 which was nearly an hour away I ordered anyway and asked for Dover Sole and mashed potato not long branch potato ie fries).A few seconds later I heard the waiter speak my order to the  the cook/chef and say Swordfish not Sole and neglect to change my side order, the waiter walked by me a few seconds later I mentioned this to him and in an instant and again impolite manner was told it was not my order he was talking about.(you the Asian waiter)

Well you guessed my order came out wrong and I just eat it paid and left.

The funny thing is I have eaten at the Tadich Grill many times over the last twenty years but usually with three or four others for business purposes,It is expensive and in the past I always let the arrogance and rudeness  of the waiters slide even as I paid the tab but sometimes I felt a little embarrassed that the waiters seem to view the customer with contempt  and several of my guests in the past have mentioned to me that the service staff had an attitude.

I for now will not be going back for a while there are plenty fine Restaurants in San Francisco with pleasant  staff.

I hope the ownership of the Tadich Grill   are paying attention as I would hate to see a an old and fabled San Francisco institution disappear.
author: Gerard O.

description:
At long last, I tried Tadich Grill!!!

This place is 2 blocks from my work, and I'm amazed it took me so long to eat here.   I just met a friend of mine today and we had lunch here today and, quite frankly, I'm ready to come back tomorrow...  By myself, and order a bunch of seafood and a couple of martinis, while you're at it...

Now granted, I'm in that romantic period between jobs where you've given notice but you haven't yet started your new gig...   That basically means that, while you have to make an effort to try and wrap things up as best you can, you still get to have a relatively stress-free couple of weeks...   I figure it's a good time to work on my lunchtime tolerance level and boost my drinking habit...

All jokes aside, the food here was great.   I ordered the deep fried seafood platter, which comes with deep fried oysters, scallops, calamari & shrimp.   The dish also comes with some French Fries and Tartar Sauce....  It was a great lunch and, while steep at $28, more than filled my tummy up.
author: David O.

description:
Tadich is a no frills, no nonsense restaurant and bar where the waiters wear white coats and know everything on the menu and how to make every drink you've ever heard of.  

Though it's been around since before Lincoln was President and most of the staff remembers where they were when Kennedy was shot, it's anything hit stodgy. 

Step in and take a seat past the brass bar for dinner, or just sidle up for a martini.  Food is fast, if pricey, and delicious.  There's not a lot of room and there's no reservations, so keep the party small for faster response.
author: J. K.

description:
Classic SF place. Waiters wear white serving aprons.Wood panelled booths.Huge Bar.Tadich has been there since the Gold Rush days.It has a loyal local clientelle as well as a tourist destination.
The specialty is seafood.
All the fish is fresh n the best available.
Forget the cals.Indulge.And worth every penny.
Best time to go...Sat Afternoon about 2.30.
author: Mike H.

description:
My review is a few years late, but I felt I needed to share my experience. We had the best experience here in 2010. We were visiting San Fran for my birthday in October. Someone recommended it to us so we gave it a shot. Turns out there was more to it than just food. 

The lighting is low and the building is old with high ceilings. The waiters wear long white aprons and white jackets. Many of the wait staff are older gentlemen who move swiftly and efficiently. They often decide that you "don't' want" to order what you've asked for and gently nudge you to make a different choice. While this approach doesn't sound like a positive, it really is. It's all about the atmosphere. 

We were encouraged to order the cioppino & the seafood sautee. Both were excellent choices. During our dinner, the Giants were playing in the World Series and even though there were no televisions, the quiet murmur of the restaurant suddenly erupted into applause and yelling. The Giants won the World Series during our dinner. It made for an even more memorable dinner experience.

Go to Tadich. Order the cioppino and remain strong. Don't let your waiter talk you into something else.
author: Amy W.

description: 3 star experience, nothing remarkable, and I wouldn't write home about this place....just yelp about it.
author: Urban G.

description: Good was delicious! Their bread pudding was very yummy. I am not a huge bread pudding fan but I thought it was done just right. The atmosphere is kind of loud so if you are trying to have a conversation you may have to request a secluded booth.
author: Heba A.

description:
I came here with a friend for lunch after hearing about their seafood cioppino. 

Their Seafood cioppino was bomb!  Lots of fresh seafood: scallops, dungeness crab, jumbo shrimp, cocktail shrimp, lobster, mussels, clams etc. it also came with two slices of garlic bread.  yum!!! It was a bit pricey but definitely a must try.

My friend ordered a simple meat pasta. That was good too, cheesy and flavored nice
 
Aside from the food, the decor of the place really makes u feel a bit homey. The staff were friendly as well.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Good menu.

Small space.

They DO NOT ACCEPT RESERVATIONS for lunch or dinner, and WILL NOT seat your party until every attendee has arrived, UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCE.

The host was very RUDE.
author: AP S.

description: Excellent!! As usual, I try to order something different but the waiter asks me what I like and refers me to something different.  He did not disappoint!!  The cioppino is amazing, crab louie out of this world.  Don't forget my favorite, the salad dressing...it is excellent to dip bread in.  Great wine selection and cocktails.  Good fast service, don't be surprised if you end up on the wall waiting for a table though.  This place is just that busy.
author: Kristi C.

description:
#67 on the 7x7 List: Sand dabs

-Tasty?  I don't know, because we didn't get that far

-Service:  Polite but the "policies" of this place killed us

-Ambiance:  Cramped, stuffy, old-school for old-time business people who uphold a certain uptight attitude

-Worth the trip/try?   No.  First of all, it's sand dabs, a flat bottom feeder fish without a ton of meat.  Second, they have a splitting charge of $9.  I can understand maybe a $3 charge but $9??  Third, each person in the party must order at least $11.50 each.  This does not mean an average $11.50 per person for the table.  For example, if Bob orders a $23 fish, Jane must order something $11.50 even though the average would have been $11.50 with Bob's order alone.    

These policies are pretty ridiculous, considering that we already had three other "dinners" this night and we cannot fit an entree each in us.  We weren't allowed to tack on a dessert with the sand dab either.

Lastly, they only take up to 4 credit cards and each must be charged the same amount.  Why?  How hard is it to jot down whose card wants what amount?

So, instead of killing ourselves with way-too-much and possibly-bad food and service, we just got up and left.    I don't care that this is the oldest restaurant in SF.  There's an "oldest restaurant" in every city.  

Hello, this is America!  The customer should be free to order as much or as little as he or she wants.
author: Winnie L.

description:
The only reason this place has four stars is because of tourists can't cope with the fact that they just paid $45 an entree for mediocre seafood and have convinced themselves that it's anything but.  It might have been an institution 30 years ago before anyone knew any better, but it sure as shit isn't one now.  

I've come here twice - once for the Chilean sea bass and the second time for the swordfish steak.  The sea bass was slightly undercooked, and the swordfish was dryer than Michelle Bachmann on prom night.  Everything from the fish to the fries was under-seasoned, which, given how fresh this fish is supposed to be, is a bit like eating caviar with handfuls of dirt.  It's just wrong.

This place is a mess, and the prices they charge are straight up offensive.  Spend your hard-earned money somewhere else, tourists.
author: Kevin C.

description:
The surf and turf was though there was good flavor but not worth the money, the soda was in a small glass and the majority was ice with no refills at $2.75

It's a very nice place with good  atmosphere but need to work on quality and service, again need to reflect the price.
author: Richard R.

description: Dined here today with the family and all I have to say is,  extraordinary!!! From the old school ambiance to the tasty meal, it was absolutely wonderful all around! We had a party of 7 and showed up right when it opened at 11:30. There was a line already forming out the door before opening time!  I ordered the seafood saute and it exceeded my expectations! The cocktails were up to par too. Will definately be back when I come back to SF.
author: Valerie C.

description: When you walk into the Tadich Grill you are transported back in time 100 years.  I recommend eating at the bar, that's where the action is.  The wait staff is great and very attentive.  The food is good, but can lack flavor.  This place is more about the experience then the food though.  It is must try when you are in the city.  I suggest going during the week around 11:30 to get seated quickly
author: matthew s.

description:
This place is a very traditional American eatery. The seafood is what they are known for. If you go early (5:30 or so), there's no wait. Later, expect to wait. Also, I've heard they run out of things on weekdays. 

Good cocktails. Historic restaurant.
author: Amy L.

description: This place came recommended and didn't disappoint. I would recommend the sautéed crab legs, which were fresh and delicious. More noteworthy was the level of service from the staff. Our waiter was attentive and helpful but as I waited for my uber who was across the street, the valet attendant stopped traffic to ensure we crossed safely. Above and beyond, eat and drink here!
author: Adam S.

description: I was forced to order something to eat while accompanying my colleague for dinner. First they would not let us sit at the bar because my colleague was having dinner and I was having drinks only. The server was extremely impolite and preached to us about why he couldn't split our tab. The bay shrimp cocktail was lame. I would not recommend this place.
author: Mirza P.

description:
I came here last night with a friend and his parents. They have been long time fans of this restaurant and have been coming for several years.
This was my first time at the restaurant last night. We arrived about 5:45 pm, and
the man at the front informed us that we could either wait 15 minutes for a table, or be seated right away but next to the kitchen. We opted to wait for a table. 

The first thing the waiter did was inform us of several items that they had run out of. We were a bit surprised, being a Saturday night, relatively early, running out of clams and tri tip, two main dishes for a restaurant. Being as flexible as we are, we were okay with that, just a bit puzzled.

I ordered the Spinach and cheese ravioli with lobster meat on top. It was fantastic and would highly recommend it to anyone who loves ravioli and lobster. It was a part of the special for the evening. 

All together it is an older restaurant with the ambiance of a 1920s feel. I probably would come here again if taken out but not on my own. It isn't really my style, being in college, but fantastic for the older generations, 30+.
author: Annie C.

description:
Wow! Love this place! It's going to be my new go-to for a great, hearty, old-school meal. They don't take reservations, but when I arrived at 6:10ish and put our party of three on the list, we were seated by about 6:30.

We shared a shrimp cocktail. And when we asked for crab cakes, the server automatically scaled the order for three. Yay! The crab cake was wonderful, but oddly, it was resting in a small pool of Italian dressing. 

I had the crab/lobster gheifor, which was delish and too rich to finish. My friends had the ahi and the avocado/shrimp pasta casserole, all winners.

We all want to try the cioppino when it turns cool. :) 

Very prompt with the beverage service, too. 

We noticed that there were NO women employees here. At least not in the bar or dining area. Odd.
author: Karen Z.

description:
The place was packed when I was there, but there's a good reason for it (I also take a packed restaurant as a sign that they're doing something right).  The food is DELICIOUS!  

Clam chowder - Amazing.
Mussels in garlic sauce - to die for
Cioppino with garlic bread - super yummy!

You just can't go wrong with Tadich Grill.  I would certainly visit them again the next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Alina J.

description: One of the oldest restaurants in California.  Expensive, but earns its title. The food are in large portions. I ordered clam chowder and we had fried calamari as appetizers.  Best clam chowder I've ever had.  I didnt want to order anything else since the meal could probably feed two people and I was just there for lunch.  The place is very vintage and western, great place to eat with coworkers and friends!
author: Ellen Z.

description:
How have I not written a review for my cold weather go-to place?

Tadich grill is perfect for the chilly days with those breezy winds.  I've been highly recommended the cioppino so to be honest, I have no had anything else there.  But I can tell you that out of any seafood stew/soup in the city, this is the best. 

The cioppino has SO much seafood in it! They don't skimp out on it, and it's large. Keep the bread eating beforehand to a minimum!  Wonderful flavor, ample amounts of fresh seafood, served with perfectly toasted thick toast? ahhh, get me there pronto!

It's 4 stars because I have only tried one dish and can not justify giving a 5 star.  Also the service was a little frantic and rushed.
author: Hannah W.

description: The best waiter ever! CHARLES was attentive and spot on. We asked for a binch of extra stuff (bread, butter, mayo, drinks, etc) he forgot nothing, good attitude. Well done.
author: Bob T.

description:
I love this place. 
You feel like you have gone back in time. So classy and Mad Men era. I like to sit at the bar where the action is, plus it is first come first served. 
Do not miss the Cioppino. Full of tons of fresh fish and shellfish with an amazing broth!!
author: Adrienne G.

description: The Tadich Grill is a San Francisco classic.  I have been here several times, and it never disappoints.  They have great service with a very experienced wait staff and a full bar.  Everyone in the Bay Area needs to try this place at least once in their lives.
author: David K.

description: Old school restaurant in the FiDi. While you will have to wait for your table, it is well worth it. It's hard to find good seafood in SF, but this is the best. My husband and I brought my inlaws. We all ordered different dishes and loved them all. Then, I brought my parents back for my dad's birthday. He loved the chiopino and bread. Mom and I shared some fresh fish dishes and white wine. A great place for a work or special occasion dinner. Great service.
author: Leah B.

description:
This claims to be the oldest restaurant in San Francisco, although I have seen other places in town make that statement over the years. However, it may be the loudest restaurant. The Tadich Grill positively explodes with energy and noise. 

We went on a Monday night after calling ahead and discovering the restaurant doesn't accept reservations.  It took about 20 minutes to be seated and we were promptly welcomed by a server who had to be at least 70 years old and acted like a man half his age, quick-witted and fast-moving. The only hiccup was when he failed to inform my wife that her dish was quite hot. She burned her finger.

The food was ok. My wife enjoyed her oysters Rockefeller (pre-burn) and plowed through a baked crab and prawns casserole (the offender) with her digit resting in a glass of ice water. I had grilled Alaskan halibut that was a little disappointing - perhaps a bit undercooked and lacking the strong texture of the very best fillets. The sourdough bread was probably faithfully San Franciscan but cold and a little too chewy. 

I'm glad I went - this place is legendary. But I don't see myself returning - not with so many enticing choices in SF.
author: Steve L.

description: The host was incredibly rude and pretentious.  Having noticed this restaurant as we walked by, me and our my three friends decided to check it out for an impromptu dinner.  I stepped inside to see a menu and inquire about wait times, while my friends stayed outside for the moment.  I understand when restaurants don't want to put a party down on a waiting list without everyone being present, but the host pointedly refused to give us a casual time estimate... even I showed him our party was literally outside the door!  I didn't bother to call them in after being served such attitude.
author: Steve G.

description:
No wait @ Noon on a Saturday. Food & service were good (mostly).  One of the 4 at our table had the cioppino and is a self proclaimed expert who raved about it. I had the salmon & swordfish grilled combo, nicely prepared  and just the right amount of food. That is where the goodness ends.

One of the kids (oops she is a junior in high school and has the proud status as a self imposed vegetarian) wanted a plain small salad, no fish, no shrimp, no crab ... basically nothing that ever walked, swam or crawled. The experience takes a quite unexpected turn. She was informed by the waiter with a heavy Ukrainian or Russian accent, that the small salad didn't meet the per person minimum charge that this stalwart joint requires. Had that foot soldier - matter of fact type of voice and demeanor. 

Proceeding to up-sell her, she cried uncle and ordered it with crab & shrimp (turned out to be mostly shrimp)..... on the side. Happily, the smallish pile was up for grabs at the table. I don't recall the "minimum" which the waiter proudly said was posted somewhere. 

Pricing is as robust as their longevity; but wouldntya think that with four people at a table for four you could cut a kid some slack who wants a small green salad for lunch? The bill w/o the salad was about $80, w/ salad with the sea creature meat $91. Upsell on the salad took it from about $ 7 to $11 a whopping $4 more dollars to get a tip on. I couldn't help but wonder if the kid, wasn't hungry and just ordered, say, and heaven forbid, a glass of water or a soda? Would the kid be asked to leave the restaurant? Asked to shuck oysters for an hour? I doubt John Tadich had a minimum at lunch time, maybe a seance is in order to answer that question.

To me age is not the only requirement for respect. I think I'll leave Tadich's vintage feel and misconceived notion on per person minimums to the tourists seeking the" true SF" grill experience; the other folks on an expense account with money to grill, ooops I meant burn.

When I get that itch for an old, really old,  stalwart restaurant I head to The Old Clam House: http://www.theoldclamhousesf.com/ , serving up meals since 1861 IN THE SAME LOCATION, and in the same building (ok, they replaced the awning after about 125 years). 1861 was the year Lincoln, the guy on the penny was inaugurated president and 10 Years before John Tadich arrived in America, and 51 years before "Tadich Grill" was opened in 1912.  Now all of this math heads up the grill flue if you use the "new math" as displayed on the Tadich website proclamation that they are the "oldest restaurant in California". Well true if you believe that a Coffee Stand under a different name and ownership that had a grill (read the ancestor of the BBQ), that cooked fish counts as Tadich's. That was 2 or 3 locations before where Tadich is today, and each under a different name. That's why above "in the same location " is in all caps. Wow, I just realized that if you extend this logic, and used the Ohlone Indians who were grilling fish around the San Francisco bay beginning in the year 500 (or there abouts), you could claim to have a restaurant "Over 1500 years old", just by serving fish.

The name thing, is particularly curious due to a prominent statement on their website: "A restaurant by any other name has no relationship to Tadich Grill".

I guess this is "much ado about nothing", since every one knows what the real "San Francisco Treat" is, and there even was a jingle to prove it. Ahhh, but that gets into "truth in advertising"; wouldn't want to go there.
author: Matsuo U.

description: Perfect! Perfect! Perfect!. Old school San Francisco at its best. Youngest waiter must be 60 and that is why they know their stuff. After a short wait you are escorted to your table and previewing the menu at at every table you pass. Once you sit the smell of warm Fresh sourdough bread that has been delivered warm starts to make your mouth water. You can spot the rookies a mile away as they delve into the bread as it was the last meal they will ever have. When you go resist the temptation, trust me what ever you order will be much better than the bread.
author: Manny G.

description:
Being one of the city's oldest restaurants, this old school spot still gets a lot of action. No reservations and expect 45 min+ wait for dinner. We came in around 630pm on a Sunday evening and there was a line of people against the wall waiting for a bar seat. The bar seating situation is a bit awkward because it's first come first serve. Imagine hungry pier 39 seagulls scavenging for food. 

Finally, we just waited for a table and was seated about an hour later. We started with some oysters on a half shell and the clam broth. I ordered the cioppino and the mister ordered sea scallops that came with steamed veggies. The cioppino is well done and probably one of the top cioppinos available in the city. It was hearty and came with a great portion of seafood. It may be too much for one person to finish. The toasty buttery bread is to die for dipped into the broth (be sure not to eat all of the bread in the beginning or you won't have room to finish your food!). The sea scallops were tender and creamy, but we found that the entree had way too many for one person to finish.

Overall, great place for good old traditional dining. Perfect for those chilly nights that need a good bowl of seafood stew to warm you up!
author: Stine H.

description:
Well, I've been there dozens of wonderful times over the past 50 years, but must admit that I have never had anything but their sandabs and cioppino (the wonderful  bread of course, and salad and chowder).  Unless you live close enough to be able to go there often, how could you order anything else? Where those two dishes are concerned, they are peerless.

And besides that it can be so accessible if you play your cards right, not to mention  atmospheric, with exceptional service by pros who are reserved and very efficient. Some may mistake this for disinterest, but they generally don't have time for the Chatty Cathy routine so curb your urge to be cajoled and pandered to, and go before 5:30 if you don't want to wait. Think about where you are, and the fact that places like this are so rare in California these days. Consider yourself lucky, as I always do when there as it covers up a multitude of little irritations.

Yesterday, when the embarcadero, wharf, etc. were absolutely mobbed, and we were entertaining dear friends from Mexico, we were able to park close and get into the Tadich in the afternoon with no wait, get typically great service and their fabulous sandabs in record time.  During the week or at peak hours it's another story, of course, but still......
author: Nora C.

description:
one of the oldest restaurants in the city? I guess so!

I had a great experience here. the cioppino was perfect! and the platter was packed with fresh seafood! old school.. maybe i got to taste a little of that.

the service was just superb... they don't take reservations, so try to be there when they open (11 am) if you don't want to wait!
author: Sung C.

description: My husband and I went there when we were in town over the weekend. They were very busy as it was 8pm on a Saturday night be we were lucky to get a seat at the bar within 15 minutes. The environment is upbeat, buzzing, and fun. We had the crab cakes for an app and by far the best we've ever had. My husband had the cioppino and I had the scallops. Everything was excellent. We finished off with the cheesecake for dessert. If you are looking for a hearty, delicious meal in a fun environment definitely come here! The staff is old school which I like. Highly recommend.
author: Brittany N.

description:
What would you expect from a restaurant open 160+ years?

Exceeded expectations, our waiter totally dealt with our need to rush to get to a show.

Food was solid, quality old school.
author: J. G.

description:
What a San Francisco institution (the oldest in SF)!  Great experience...  Old school seafood done right, and a great bar!

Place gets crowded nightly, but you can definitely spend your waiting time drinking with your friends at the long bar that inhabits the entire length of the restaurant.

Appetizers consisted of raw oysters and crab cakes (rich and satisfying).  Had the seared opah with wakame seaweed salad and seared scallop.  A colleague of mine recommended ending it up with a B&B, which was kind of fitting for the establishment...  Nice end to a great meal.

Definitely not a place to try to get in and out of in a hurry.  I totally recommend this spot if you are in the area.
author: Lawrence L.

description: On New Year's Eve this year, I took my family there, food quality was great, how ever service was by far the worst I have ever seen any where in my life. Our waiter was showing attitude.
author: Kambiz E.

description:
Love the history of this place and it's been years since i have eaten here.
All you need to know is ...cioppino!!! 
You will not find it's equal in the states.

Yeah baby....it is the highlander of fish stew.

The broth of this stew will blow your mind!
author: Denice Z.

description: What a great experience. Since they don't take reservations, be prepared to wait a bit on a busy night. Just the experience of lining up on the wall can be an interesting bit of people watching and scoping out meals as they are served. You have the option of grabbing a counter seat if one opens up while waiting for a table to be called. My significant other and I love sitting side by side at a counter and it worked out perfectly. I had the Cioppino, and she had the Swordfish. Both very enjoyable dishes served promptly. Service was great.  All in all well worth the visit.
author: Bob H.

description: In a city with a thousand great restaurants, why do I always eat at the same one? Because this place has character!  Staff is friendly in a nice, grumpy kind of way.  They will go our of their way to make sure you are having a good time.  Food is hearty and satisfying. Try the cioppino!
author: Philip T.

description: Food was really good. Very fresh an authentic! Would had rated 5 if service was a bit friendlier or personable. As a person visiting from Chicago I would had appreciated coming to an institution like this and being made to feel more welcomed. Our waitress asked if we "had made a selection" referring to the menu as oppose to a standard greeting. I introduced myself and my companion and proceeded to ordering. Will be back, not sitting the same section.
author: Angel D.

description:
I'm a big fan of cioppino and since i'm not in SF that often, I needed to try it here since I was in the area for labor day weekend. 

First off, this place does not take reservations so get there early. My wife and I opted to eat an early lunch. This place opens at 11:30 am and we arrived roughly at 11:40 am and were seated quick. Our server was very stoic but professional. Just remember that when coming to this place, it's more of an old school feel. Very professional, waiters looking in the mirror to fix their ties but not too many smiles; sort of like a rustic steak house feel, which isn't a bad thing. 

I hopped right on the cioppino and the flavors were on point. Of course it's always about quality over quantity but when you have both, it's even better. The amount of seafood was wonderful. I know seafood can be expensive so I really appreciate that huge muscles, clams, pieces of fish, shrimp etc found in my cioppino. It also is accompanied by two toasted pieces of garlic bread, which you can used to dip into that wonderful sauce.

My wife had the sea bass with brussel sprouts and potatoes. The potatoes were average at best. They were kind of like a really fat french fry, if that makes any sense. It comes with a rice pilaf if you don't like potatoes. Her sea bass was pretty damn big once again! They definitely aren't shady with portions at this place.

If you're a seafood lover, you need to try this place. I can't vouch for anything other than the 2 dishes I mentioned, but based on that, I'm fairly confident that you'll have a pretty good dining experience. Just be sure to get there early.
author: James K.

description:
This is a place that should be superb, lovely lay out, great noise and bustle in the dining room and frankly direct but charming staff.

The wine list is really unshowoffy but perfectly serviceable and generously priced.

The menu has clearly not been updated for 40 years and is in fact rather sweet in a time capsule sort of a way (not very much that you really want to eat) - does anyone smother their fish with cheese these days? - smoked haddock excepted.

But the cooking was shocking; by far and away the worst meal I have had in 3 months of living in SF - nothing was inedible but nothing giving any joy - people wnet for the classics, sand dabs, sole, crab cakes and that big plate of semi soup whose name i forget but starts with a 'ci'

And while they dont charge like a bull rhino they arent giving it away either

Never going back - but more in sadness than in anger

Funily enough I had lunch at that other SF tourist clip joint the slanted door yesterday and it was great, busy v busy, lots of wating around but once they got going - great food, great service and a real joy
author: Max A.

description:
The Manhattan clam chowder was the best I've had.  Chunky, flavorful, and the hint of spice was great.  My main was the crab and prawn casserole over rice.  Looked fantastic and was pretty good.  However, it was missing that special zest to put it over the top.  The tomato sauce was a little too tomato soupy.  It could have used some fresh mozzarella.  The dessert, the rice pudding, was downright bad.  I don't think I've ever had a more flavorless dessert.  

Service was decent, but they don't take American Express.
author: Mike F.

description: Just left the restaurant. We are from Southern California and visit San Fran frequently. I had heard great things about the restaurant and the food did not disappoint. However I will say I am incredibly disappointed that only a few moments after paying our $300 lunch bill- our waiter actually asked us to leave. Never in my life has that happened before.
author: Sydney G.

description:
Good food!.  Loved the prime rib. Polite service.

I came with with a diverse group of friends, and all had a good time.
author: Steve L.

description: The food was awful. The crab cakes with soggy. The coffee was tepid. And the waiters seemed to have an air of disdain about them. They barely paid attention to us. Not worth the money. Not worth half the money. Worst dining experience in a decade.
author: Jodi S.

description:
Went on a 10-day vacation all around California and the Cioppino here was by far the best thing I ate.

Tadich Grill is a well-oiled machine. From the time we were seated to when we paid the bill, everything was done in an efficient manner. 

When I return to San Francisco, this place will be on the top of my list.
author: Paul M.

description: Eating here is a real treat every time I visit San Francisco.  The Petrale Sole, Sand Dabs, and Red Snapper are excellent.  An order of asparagus and garlic bread make a wonderful meal.  This is one of the oldest seafood restaurants in San Francisco with a fine history and ambiance.  The wait staff do an excellent job.  If you want a truly fine dining experience, this place is for you. It's the food and service that bring my family and me back time and again.
author: Mike B.

description:
I always look for the positive and give several opportunities for redemption.  Unfortunately, little was positive and nothing was redeemed.

Since my first visit a month and a half ago, I have not stopped raving about this place, telling all my friends and clients who haven't been, to come because I loved my experience.  However, I am not sure I will come back as tonight was the polar opposite from last.

My friends from New York City flew in for my birthday and took me here because they knew how much I had liked it.

So the review:

No wait, walked right in, sat at a 4 top.  Awesome, too good to be true.
About 12 minutes had gone by before we were even greeted by a waiter.
Bread was dropped off in a rush with no words.
Another 5-6 minutes went by, he came for our drink order and rushed off.
Another 10 minutes went by, our drinks came but our order was not taken.
Finally, after how many more minutes, he came by to take our order.
The food came out quickly.  I ordered a dinner salad and my friend ordered a bowl of chowder, pre main course.

Halfway through my dinner salad, my boyfriend noticed something moving on a piece of bay shrimp.  It was a very alive and green caterpillar -  or fat worm.  I wasn't grossed out, in fact, I was glad it was still moving as I looked at it to be fresh greens, but my party was not amused.  After flagging down three employees, we were ignored, given the "wait a minute" finger and overlooked.  Finally, when our waiter came by with our entrees, we let him know and he took the plate, asked if I wanted another which I declined.

Finally, the main course.

My Chilean Sea Bass was good, not as good as before.  Seemed like it sat for awhile and had time to cool off.
My boyfriend's ravioli was ok, he said it wasn't as good as he's had there before either.
My friend's pasta with clams was over cooked, mushy and clams were on the fishy side...very disappointing...and her husband's Rainbow Trout was probably the only satisfactory dish.

The clam pasta was not touched, my boyfriend shared his ravioli with my friend and both fish dishes were finished.  

After one last table check, we declined coffee/dessert as we just wanted to go home at this point.  Our check came and the worm salad was still on as well as a drink that we hadn't ordered.  When told that it wasn't ours, the waiter said that it was from our bar tab - which we had never been to, nor did we order a drink.  

I can understand when it's been a long shift and you're tired, but one of the most redeeming qualities in people is when they're forthcoming and humble.  I think it's safe to say that most human beings would be reasonable and forgiving of mistakes - but the grumpiness, lack of service and unfriendliness was unnecessary.

I hate writing reviews like this because I'd rather leave a good one, but I was extremely disappointed and am hoping it was just an off night as I really do like this place...hence the extra star.
author: Alex T.

description: What can you say about Tadich's.  Their food is still great as I remember 50 years ago; and the waiters are still cranky is their own way, but very helpfull. Always go their for the Sand Dabs, and ask them not to bone them.  That way, they stay hotter longer.
author: Steven W.

description: Delicious! Excellent service! Hubs had Cioppino & I had the seafood plate! Both were delicious! Don't be afraid to eat at the bar, very comfortable!
author: Jenn B.

description:
Tadich Grill officially takes the title as MY FAVORITE restaurant in SF! The food is awesome and its one of the oldest surviving restaurants in the city. The servers are very professional, they wear these fancy white coats. The tables are all separated by partitions so you get a ton of privacy, I would say this is a great place to come for a date but maybe not a first date because its $$$$ PRICEY $$$$. 

If you're not sure what to order, get the Lobster Casserole, you'll love it!
author: V I P.

description: I've been here twice, several years apart. The waiters were surly both times. The food (grilled salmon) was good the first time, but the lobster Thermidor was dry and overcooked. Worst of all, when I asked the waiter to change a twenty, he brought me a five and five ones and insisted that I had only given him a ten. Never again.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Often classics are misrepresented as tourist destinations. The oldest business in SF is Tadich Grill. When people ask what's SF like... show them this place. Old, refined, a little bit stodgy, a little bit boisterous, and a restaurant where the main attraction is the bar. 

I've dined at the bar, I've drank at the bar, and my last experience was with a group so we dined in one of those private nooks with a table of 6. I have to say... those partitions are genius -- it makes the experience far more private and liberating. If you're not prepared, the stodginess of the server team can catch you off guard, but just know going into it... it's all older gentlemen that will take care of you here. 

If there's a place to check out Cioppino, it's here. If there's a place to sit at the bar and have a gin martini lunch, it's here. While the prices at first glance are stifling, all the dishes are large enough for two -- or even three -- to split. 

"When you have lunch at a bar, it makes you feel like you're getting things done." Don Draper. If anything, having lunch here makes you feel like you're accomplishing the task of taking a look back at history and hopefully what the future will continue to look like.
author: Jon A.

description: Favorite restaurant ever. Best fish and chips i have had in a long time.
author: Jordan B.

description:
San Francisco, CA - California St. - Oldest Restaurant in CA est. 1849.

In my opinion Tadich Grill has better Cioppino than Soto Mare, SF and Phil's Fish Market, Monterey Bay.

So, it's a must for at least one person in your dining group to get the Cioppino.  

- Cioppino is served standard or you can request "spicy".  I prefer spicy.

- Bib isn't mandatory but may help protect your clothes, plus it's one of best photos you can take.

* 30 - 45 Wait always expected.
* 20 plus seats at counter/bar are first come first serve and full menu is available.

12/17/2011
author: John C.

description: Cranky waitstaff, overpriced even by SF standards, food decent (some friends had recommended the dungeness crab, and it was average at best - with a small portion size), plus generally a fairly decent wait for a table or seat at the bar. Not worth the time, energy or cost to visit this "institution".
author: Eric D.

description:
Reading what other Yelpers had recommended, I tried their sand dabs plate with fries, and the vegetable of the day, baby bok choy. This place is pricey, averaging $20-$30 for a lunch entree. I definitely expected more from Tadich Grill food-wise, as established as it is. Without the tartar sauce, the sand dabs were quite bland. Without the Heinz ketchup, the fries were uninteresting. And the bok choy... well it's bok choy. The interior has charm for sure. Old, worn woodwork framed the extravagant bar, which I'm certain that at night, would be filled with regular and once-regular patrons reliving the 1800s. 

+ Old, charming establishment with an extravagant bar
+ Great location in the FiDi
-  Food requires condiments
author: Michael Paul C.

description: Best cioppino i have ever had.  Fantastic atmosphere and waiter. I sat at the bar with a colleague and had an exceptional experience. Thank you cousin Louis for recommending!
author: Robert B.

description: After dining at the Tadich Grill I asked myself, why?  You have to wait in line because they do not take reservations.  The food is nothing special, and it is expensive.  While the restaurant might be a landmark, it is one to avoid.  You can find better prepared fish and steak in lots of restaurants in San Francisco.  On the positive side, the waiters are great,
author: jeffrey l.

description: Just like the old financial advisors who earn a percentage of assets under management (Tadich's ideal customer), this restaurant is a dying breed - and it should be. Absolutely terrible customer service, rude all around. You can do way better food quality wise and with nicer service. Not worth it.
author: Raul Q.

description: Ohhh lala great food decent price, excellent service! I had the curry seafood dish and although the curry was mild it was still very tasty. This place has A plus service. All of the waiters were well trained in dining etiquette, courteous and accommodating. Get there before 6:30 or you will wait!
author: Lakieta E.

description:
Old time SF at its best...

Came by after an unsatisfying (amount and quality) meal at a nearby restaurant. Just wanted a snack to top it all off. Yes, it was a second dinner. I do that a lot. Don't judge.

Split a crab cocktail and cioppino. The cioppino itself is  a meal an a half and by far the best cioppino I've had. Huge oval bowl of an abundant variety of seafood in a wholesome, tomatoey broth. The crab cocktail was quality eats as well and better than Swan's. I guess it's because I didn't have to wait in a ridiculously long line. 

So why is Swan's that great? I've had it a handful of times, and never found it was worth the hype. Sure it's fresh, but why do you want to eat at the fish store. I get it, no frills. But Tadich is just as no frills without the fish smell and long lines.

I'll get off the soapbox now...
author: Al L.

description: Excellent restaurant with amazing food and service.  If you're visiting the Bay Area it should be on your list.  If you're a local then you already know and go there.  Great cioppino!
author: Kris K.

description:
Go early ( before 630 pm)to avoid a wait or late (past 9 pm). The cioppiono was just excellent along with the Dungeness crab cakes and rice pudding desert. Halibut steak was ok, bass and scallops very good.

Ambience is old SF and waiters are well attired and business like. Expect about $50 a head without alcohol.

I would recommend it.
author: Gavin K.

description: The cioppino here is easily the best I've ever had. Filled to the brim with delicious and fresh seafood, and topped with some killer garlic bread. More importantly was the excellent service from the general manager there. As many parents can attest, a fussy baby with a dirty diaper is no fun at all, especially when it comes to finding places to change them! The GM was so nice and took us up to his office and let us change on the office tables there. Definitely a fan for life and will be back there. Thank you so much!
author: Tien-Yeo H.

description: I visited Tadich Grill upon recommendation from folks at a nearby hotel.  Our party of 3 arrived shortly after 5:00pm and were seated immediately. I had the Boston clam chowder and the mesquite grilled swordfish. The chowder was rich and creamy, some of the best that I have ever eaten.  The swordfish was equally excellent.  Service was very prompt and attentive.  This is a place that I'd definitely repeat given the opportunity.
author: Parker E.

description: Food was AMAZING, server treated us like royalty and the wait to be seated wasn't bad at all I think it was maybe 15 minutes, but they served drinks while we waited so it was perfect. It's a loud place and very small with a super high demand. I wouldn't recommend taking kids.-a great place for a nice couples dinner. Dressy or casual, all are welcome. I'm definitely going back.
author: Elvira G.

description:
In town for a convention. Took some clients to the Tadich on a Thursday afternoon for an early dinner. The food was off the rails. Old joint that suited my Southern upbringing to a tee.  All around great joint to eat at. Not your typical snobbery white linen chow joint. Waiter had been working there for 23 years. 

I will be back.
author: Bob P.

description:
Food was great and bartender could make my drinks.

Get there early or will wait in line. Everything on the menu is great.

They have sit down or bar and everyone is dressed in white coats. 
This place was great and now my new place to visit.
author: Jeffrey D.

description: I think I'm being generous with 2 stars.  I loved the way the place looked and the concierge at our hotel recommended it so in we went.  The clam chowder was a good portion, but not that flavorful and so gritty.  I mean, yes I expect some sand but not in every bite!  I ordered the pasta with meat sauce which basically tasted like Hamburger Helper with very over cooked pasta. My husband ordered the bay shrimp curry which was SO over seasoned he couldn't finish it.  On top of that if you're a waiter I would assume it's because you like serving people, but our waiter sure didn't seem like he enjoyed it.  I would not recommend this place at all.
author: Janice H.

description: Just what I expected from a San Fran staple that has been around since the gold rush. Lovely atmosphere and a very polished older all male wait crew dressed in white serving coats. I had the cioppino which was delicious and definitely enough to serve 2.
author: Joe H.

description:
Dear Tadich,

I now look for live worms in all of my salads, because that is the bar you've set for "fresh food!" 

In all seriousness maybe it was just an unlucky day where we had bad food and bad service. I'd be willing to go back and try the cioppino that everyone raves about. Their clam chowder and sourdough bread was good. I had the fried rainbow trout with steamed broccoli and fries, which was ok.
author: Michael K.

description:
We went just because Tadich Grill is considered a SF institution. Stick with their signature dishes: clam chowder, cioppino, and sand dab filets (on 7x7 big eat 2012). While the clam chowder was not short of clams, the flavors were a bit heavy. The cioppino on the other hand could use a little more spice. Sand dabs were just plain bland. 

We got there around 5:30 pm, and had to wait for about half an hour. Our server looked like someone who had worked there a while. He was nice and service overall was prompt. I'm glad that I got to try Tadich, but won't be coming back.
author: Aldo H.

description: I have been coming to the Tadich Grill since I moved to San Francisco in 2000- and have loved it ever since. I can't tell you how pleasant it is to be able to have complete confidence knowing I am enjoying the best Crab Louie in town, sitting at the beautiful bar and enjoying a properly made, no-nonsense drink. The atmosphere can vary depending on the time of day (I recommend saturday lunch for peace & quiet) - but the room is gorgeous to be in at any time. The bartenders are always attentive, the food may not be particularly innovative, but it is fresh, local, and always perfectly prepared. Expect to see a bit of the old San Francisco style here-- no reservations, no hand-holding or coddling, no fussing. What a relief in this day of over-complicated and pompous service! I always sit at the bar (it's one of the longest in town) and recommend that for one or two people. They also have more private booth seating for larger groups. The Petrale Sole & Salmon are also delicious. It's difficult not to order the Crab Louie every time (with a giant bowl of French fries on the side). I am always surprised when I hear someone hasn't been to the Tadich--- what-- are you nuts?!
author: Brigid S.

description:
A San Francisco classic ... some may be put off by the unique system of not allowing reservations. We ate there on a Saturday night and arrived at 9 p.m. just before the restaurant officially closed at 9:30 p.m. Technically they close the doors at 9:30 p.m. but if you get in before then, they will serve you as soon as a table opens.

There are only a handful of tables and booths here ... which is why it is not impossible to wait 45 minutes to an hour during peak times. There is a big 'lunch counter' as well with barstools and if places open up at this long counter, you can sit there without a reservation. However, this does kind of make for an uncomfortable situation as I have often seen people standing behind the stools of someone eating dessert waiting to get their spot at the counter.

Personally, I prefer to sit at the counter but when I am there with guests, it is next to impossible to find 3 or 4 stools open, so we wait for the table.

The food here is fresh and the recipies have been time tested. The Cioppino is some of the best you will get in San Francisco. I have had better than the last time I went, but I am chalking that up to an off-night. Normally it is full of hearty scallops and shrimp, crab and pieces of white fish. The tiny salad shrimp being thrown in there, I am not a huge fan of ...

The sour dough bread is amazing ... a San Francisco thing.

Drinks are stiff and inexpensive. $8 for a Martini and two will knock your socks off. The menu is very extensive. They have mostly fish but they do sear steaks, etc. I always order the Cioppino which comes in a giant dish. Easily enough for two people if you are dipping bread.

The restaurant is chaotic, old school and interesting. Some people would be very put off by busy nights and the mayhem that their system produces. I'd recommend a slower weeknight if crowds bother you.

This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco ... and one of the oldest. On the inside not much has changed since the 1930s. The waitors are usually pretty good ... although the last one I had (hispanic gentleman) was constantly pushing drinks on us and because we came in a half hour before close, he was rushing us through the meal. Never had this happen before ... normally they are very laid back. Give it a try if you are downtown and want history and good food.
author: E T.

description:
Old school charm with great good. Been here 3-4 times now and never been disappointed. The cioppino is the best in SF. 
Halibut florentine is another dish I recommend. 

Get here early if you're looking to avoid the lunch rush since you're smack dab in the middle of FiDi 

If you're dining alone or one other person avoid the long wait by eating at the bar
author: Ro S.

description:
"The original rainy day restaurant."

This place is all about old school charm.  Actually, it's the oldest restaurant in the state!  Be sure to spend some time reading Tadich Grill's history that dates back to 1849, very interesting.
