We bellied up to the bar and ordered dinner.  We started with the lobster bisque and Boston (cream based) clam chowder (other choice is Coney Island or tomato based, we're guessing).  Both soups were substantial and hearty.  The lobster bisque had nice sized chunks of lobster goodness, while the clam chowder was probably the best we've ever tasted.  The chunky bread was also a perfect accompaniment to our soups on a cold, windy day.

Fish is their mainstay, so we ordered the King Salmon that came with fries and steamed veggies; and the fresh Halibut.  Both dishes were perfectly prepared, extremely moist and good sized offerings.  Although we didn't have room for dessert (which doesn't happen very often, believe me), their selections looked insane:  Rice Custard Pudding; Bourbon Bread Pudding with an amazing looking caramel sauce; thick and dense NY style cheesecake; Chocolate Raspberry Truffle; and the list goes on.  Our only disappointment was that we had none of these.

The guy next to me ordered their signature Seafood Cioppino which looked amazing with clams, prawns, scallops, bay shrimp, crabmeat and white fish.

The tenured waiters in white coats are quick and efficient.  Their no nonsense approach is both refreshing and charmingly retro.  With all the hip spots to dine, this place will always provide a dose of reality in a sea of fads.
author: Kalani C.

description:
It was an awesome experience! I was pretty much drawn into the OLD look the moment when I stepped in. Love the high dome, the central bar and the private booth... It was picked by a friend, who came here since her childhood. Things have never been changed, I believe it was like this maybe a hundred years ago!  Most of the waiters are old, kinda matched with the ambiance. They were fun and knowledgable, and service quality was good.

This place is famous for its seafood, so all four of us picked sea bass. One is chilean sea bass, the other is mediterranean sea bass. They both were great, the former one is more American style, the latter one is like a grilled whole fish, yummy but very light! We also shared crab cake for appetizer, it was awesome! The wine selection there is pretty good, price was reasonable comparing to quality. 

I will definitely come back soon to try other stuff on their menu!
author: Shell J.

description: I started going to Tadich's when I was 22 years old and still love it to this day. Just go, get some good eats and watch the people.
author: Rex B.

description: Ok, everyone knows the famous Tadich Grill, and lots has been posted about this very well known food mecca. After many years of living in SF we finally had dinner here and now we know why people love it. The food was amazing, oysters to start, and the Ciopinna, and grilled salmon were done to perfection. We sat at the bar and a great conversation with the bartender who actually was very engaging considering how busy they were. Definitely coming back!
author: Michael C.

description: I've been a regular diner at Tadich Grill since 1982, when I moved to San Francisco.  I love the food, the waiters, the ambiance, and the history.  I always start with the dinner salad with crab and shrimp, with lots of blue cheese dressing.  That's enough for a meal right there.  The Manhattan clam chowder is wonderful; I sometimes get that instead of the cioppino when I'm trying to eat light(er).  And when possible I love to try their house zinfandel; it always changes but it's always a good one and turns me on to new wines that I would never had known about.
author: Paul B.

description:
At 9pm on a Saturday night, our party of 2 waited about 15 minutes to be seated. It was a wonderful excuse to belly up to the bar. The bartender was friendly and fun and made a wonderful whiskey sour on the rocks. Don't skip the chance to have a drink. Your good experience at Tadich starts at the bar! 

I know many of us skip the bread on the table for one reason or another. Low carb and dieters beware. This is THE BEST BREAD I have had in a looooong time. Don't skip it. EAT IT. 

People aren't kidding when they say they have the best cioppino ever. Someone at your table MUST order it. Then the others can be jealous. The cioppino had generous amounts of seafood, a heavenly sauce and was put over the top by the garlic bread for dipping. 

If you don't want to order the cioppino, the swordfish was cooked perfectly and did not need the side of tartar sauce with which it was served.  

Service was attentive but not overbearing. 

We will DEFINITELY be returning in the near future.
author: Stephanie P.

description: Just simply my favorite place to eat in San Francisco. The feel, the decor, the fabulous service, and the absolute to die for ciopinno. After each meal I have had there over 10+ years of going, I feel quite okay that I've experienced the best of it all. And though it would be tragic to be run over by the California line street car, that's as fine a last meal money can buy all told.
author: Jake W.

description: My favorite restaurant in the city hands down. The chapino is to die for and has so much seafood in it that you kind of have a seafood hang over so be willing to share. You must go here if you are in town. I take anyone that is visiting here and they always ask to go back.
author: Kyle F.

description:
I've been walking in front of this restaurant for the last 3 years and wanted to try it for the longest time. However there has always been a line and unfortunately they don't take reservations. (also it is hard to tell the capacity of the place by just looking through the front window:)) 

Either way, I've ready that they have the best Cioppino in San Francisco, so I wanted to try it. The experience started a little weird as we were greeted in a fairly serious manner and it was a little crowded. After a 55 minute wait for a table of 4 (it you are alone or just a couple, it is much faster to get a spot), we were taken to our table by the open kitchen. 

We got the recommendations from the host, which were:

1. Seafood Cioppino with Garlic Bread
2. Oysters Rockefeller (appetizer)
3. Chilean Sea Bass with Prawn Garnish
4. Lobster and Crab Thermidor (Baked in Casserole)

We started off with a hearty bread and butter. This was great as we were very hungry and there was still time until we get our food... Then came the oysters. The spinach and the cheese with the oysters were great. By the time we finished the bread and the oysters, we were already full :) 

Then came the entrèes. I've always loved Sotto Mare's (North Beach on Green St.) Cioppino, which I still love, but Tardich Grill's Cioppino was exquisite. The tomato sauce was fresh and delicious. 

Even though I thought the rice and the sauce could get some improvement, the Chilean Sea Bass was the most moist and soft fish I had in San Francisco, just delicious. However, my second favorite was the Thermidor. With a little brandy flavor, the bechamel sauce and the huge chunks of crab and lobster, this was a seafood lovers delight! 

Overall, I think it was the best seafood I had in San Francisco. Very classic and traditional place, good service. I felt like it was a little pricey at first, but for all the crabs and lobster and other seafood goodness they serve, I believe it is worth it...
author: Doruk G.

description:
so highly recommended yet so disappointing.  Seems to be coasting on laurels earned long ago. 

Staff seemed to be all grumpy old white men in white coats in a hurry.  
Tiny martini glass and my Manhattan had a bug in it, which was quickly replaced but without so much as an "I'm sorry about that"  
Sea bass was good, but not special enough to justify $30.25.  
Garlic bread was basically burnt french toast.  

Net: Skip this place, too many good restaurants nearby.
author: Ken W.

description:
Great restaurant! 
Great service, nice staff (I don't know what the other reviewers had against the staff! It's nice to see a change from the cookie cutter fake nicities! I wouldn't mind a waiter with a little cheerful-yet-edgy attitude..)
I had the shrimp curry, which is really one of a kind! Served over white rice, PLENTY of shrimp, a nice spicy curry sauce, and get that.. WITH MELTED CHEESE ON TOP!
A little on the pricey side (good thing our meal was expensed!)
author: Hanna A.

description:
Tadich Grill is the epitome of a great traditional San Francisco restaurant.   Some of the waiters are a little bit surly, just enough to add color.  The food is excellently presented and many items are still cooked on a wood stove, which is not so easy to do  The menu is expansive, yet in my over 75 years of going there I have never seen them run out of any item on their printed menu which is printed daily.  My dad used to take me there as a little tot when they were on Clay Street.

There is none of some of the current stylishness as  in many restaurants nowadays in which some courses mix fruits & vegetables (ugh!).   The noise level is optimal which adds to the color.  They still refuse to take reservations which shows up in not catering to tourists.   Up until a few years ago they wouldn't even take credit cards, but were forced into it after some scenes with tourists who showed up without any cash.  Their independence also shows up by not opening on Sundays and closing at 8:30pm.  Their staff turnover rate must be as close to zero as is possible and that says a lot about management.
author: Harold R.

description: I've been here twice and I love the cioppino probably the best cioppino I've ever eaten!! Highly recommend for any seafood lover.
author: Trung N.

description:
I've been meaning to go here for years. Staff was friendly and knowledgable. Our waiter Barry has been there for 19 years, very nice and attentive. I ordered petrale sole and my friend ordered something like Bresolle fish (I know I'm spelling/saying it wrong). My fish came with roasted potatoes and brussel sprouts, everything was fabulous!

We arrived about 6:30p on a Wednesday and had about a 45 min wait for 2. This place was bussling! At least 15 people milling around the entrance waiting to be seated.
author: Mary C.

description: I love this restaurant. Used to go all the time when I worked in SF.  This time didn't disappoint. Seated promptly at 12:30 pm on a Monday. Great traditional petrale sole and ahi tuna salad. Good
author: Keith M.

description:
If you knew me, you'd know that I absolutely love traditional American dishes! Meatloaf, pot roast, mashed potatoes, all that goooooooooood comfort food that is becoming a rarity in our epicurean culture. Tadich Grill has it all!

I came here for lunch with a co-worker and it was crowded! Most of their restaurant is dedicated to counter seating, which is great for single diners of parties below four. They also have tables for larger parties. The wait was quick though! I ordered a pot roast ($20), which was heavenly. It came with a side of mashed potatoes and bok choy (guess it was in season lol).

I will definitely come back next time!!
author: Cheri S.

description: Saw this place featured on Check Please and figured it's worth a try, since it's one of the oldest restaurants in the city.  The decor is very classic, with a long bar and then smaller rooms for private parties.  The waiters all wear ties and a white jacket, so it reminds you of movies set in the 40s and 50s.  The menu is also very classic, with a ton of seafood options like shrimp cocktails, steamed clams, baked fishes.  We went with a baked casserole and the cioppino.  While the casserole was good, it was a bit underwhelming in flavor.  The cioppino though...holy crap it was good.  The broth was extremely tasty and soaks up bread like a boss.  They also include a ton of huge prawns in the dish, and plenty of fish and other goodies in there as well.  If you go here I'm pretty sure you have to get the cioppino; other dishes are probably hit or miss but this one is a must have.
author: Tommy Q.

description: As historic and quintessential as SF dining goes yes? I love thee long bar in the entrance flanked by booths of folks of all reaches enjoying the fresh eats of the city. Mixed seafood cocktail, crab cakes, calamari steak, and lobster thermidor with clam chowder sure hit the spot. Service is very classic, and they take good care of you. Take a lazy weekend day, show up late to avoid the tourists and enjoy.
author: Kim N.

description:
This is Vintage San Francisco. That means every inch of what you think it does. It boasts the antique milky glass fixtures, the all wooden interior - booths, bar, floor, alcoves - you name it and the Waiters in White with Waistcoats.

This ALSO means that the cuisine is nowhere near innovative, but it is the ultimate in comfort and classical style. They are known for their cioppino and once you get it, you will understand. This is heavily loaded with all sorts of seafood and naked crab lumps and the broth is so flavorful, you may even need more bread than the sourdough loaf that is already waiting for you at your table to soak all its not-to-be-wasted taste.

Ancient dishes like "Newberg" and "Thermidor" are alive and kicking here and are worth the novelty to give them a spin. So far, my favorite is the simple seafood saute with crab and prawns served with buttery rice and steamed vegetables.

Let me tell you, you will pay dearly for this throw back in time - but the seafood is fresh and worth it, the drinks are strong and the waiters are professionals. It's worth a go and your parents and or grandparents will think you are the height of fashion should you waltz them through the door.
author: Katie W.

description: First class joint with ambiance, history, great food and service. Gary the bartender and the rest of the crew top notch. If your in the City and you don't check it out you lost.
author: Steve A.

description:
The food here is very good. A pretty solid four stars. The extra star I gave is for the service here. I am always fascinated by how the waiters work. These are true professionals and not college kids doing a summer gig. Most of the staff has worked here for decades. 

The waiters are efficient in telling you about the menu and the specials. They are also great at making recommendations, taking your orders, serving your food promptly, etc.--stuff you expect them to do. Here's an example of the superior service I've witnessed: I was sitting at the counter and next to me was a couple. As the waiter brought out their two dinners, one of the customers had just turned around to head to the restroom (and didn't see the waiter coming). Without a word, he set down the one dinner for the customer who was still there and put the other dinner under the heater to make sure it didn't get cold. The minute he saw the customer walk back from the restroom, he took the dinner and put it in front of her as she sat down. He didn't make a big deal out of it; it just showed that he's been honing his attentiveness for a number of years.
author: Vince L.

description: I guess this place survives on tourists and history. Food is okay but the attitude of the servers if just appalling. They seem to have the attitude that the restaurant will always be full so no need to show respect to the customers.
author: andrew p.

description: Our last stop on the way out of San Francisco.  This place has it all. Ambience, quick service, attentive wait staff and the best seafood ever!  Oysters Rockefeller - there are no words!, crab cakes....I'm spoiled now for wherever else I eat those. And even reading the menu with the history of the restaurant was entertaining. It's all good!
author: Susan O.

description: This place is fantastic. Looked like a long wait but they move fast. We sat at the bar and I had the cioppino. Amazing. Good portion size.
author: Bill C.

description:
Old school place. Not very good service except by the bartender who let us try some random drink she was making. Server acted like we were inconveniencing him by being there. 

Dungeness crab and prawns a la monza - super rich. very heavy. seafood + cheese and sauce worked in this for me. 
Cioppino - came here for the sole purpose of wife wanting cioppino. she loved it. said it might ruin ordering cioppino at other places. i really liked it as well. lots of depth to the broth. good ingredients. 

great bread.

horrible bloody mary. straight tomato mix + vodka it seemed like. not tasty. 

expensive lunch. $31 for cioppino. $27 for my dish. $26 for somebody's crab cakes.
author: J A.

description: This is our third time at the Tadich Grill and it just does not get any better than this.  The service is impeccable and the food is absolutely divine!  You must try this place!  We shared the clams in garlic butter broth; delicious.  The best Caesar salad we ever had and a perfectly cooked seafood saute, with perfect scallops, perfect shrimp and crab with a lip smacking sauce that had you saying YUM with each bite.  Yes, it's expensive, but Oh So Worth It!  Was a great treat for my 50th!
author: Deb U.

description: True San Francisco cold day restaurant. This place is a hole in the wall that seems deceiving from the outside. Surprisingly the inside is very spacious. The bar takes up the majority of the restaurant with seating on one side at the bar and table seating on the other side. There are little knooks for table of 6-10 which is good. I sat at the bar with my dad and we were helped immediately. The servers have been working there for over 20 or 30 years. They're well seasoned. The food was amazing. Plain and simple. I definitely recommend this place for anyone looking for a good dinner!
author: Alyssa M.

description: This place is so good that every time I'm in town.  I make it a note to go there.   The food is pretty good but I love the old school vibe.  Super traditional and the food is awesome and for SF, it's reasonable.
author: Larry L.

description: We picked this place at random for a business meeting. Cramped atmosphere made things kind of weird. The waiter was trying to hard to be pushy when it came to ordering. He didn't bring one of our ordered drinks. They didn't take Amex. The food was great but the rest of the experience fell short of expectations.
author: John L.

description:
You haven't dined in San Francisco until you've been to Tadich Grill! Most seafood restaurants don't even try to prepare sand dabs, a very delicate fish native to northern California. Mine were perfectly pan fried and accompanied by steak fries and seasonal veggies.

My companion enjoyed a wonderfully seared ahi and we shared a fabulous crab cake and perfectly steamed artichoke! After 162 years, Tadich has it all figured out! Great food, the best service in the City. A visit to Tadich Grill is a "must" for any visitor who wants to experience "old San Francisco" at it's best.
author: Mark O.

description:
Ok sometimes you have to recognize the tried and true.  This place is so incredibly awesome that there is a reason why its been open so long.  I can't add any more to whats already been articulated about this restaurant.  This place is the absolute best and enjoy their martinis so delicious.  

Cheer and happy eats!
author: Kevin K.

description:
Falling in love again ... What am I to do..?  I can't help it..!

Hit the TG right before the Holidays w/ a few other well-dressed gentlemen (it helps here, dress like a grown up... get treated like a grown up!) hung my coat and hat on a hook and nestled into a fantastically poured martini (or two).

Dinner followed, oysters, pretty good, cold and fresh... friend at the table complimented that the chowder hit the spot... and on to my main... my last time w/ their Cioppino was so/so... this time it was right on the money. Good sized portion, good quality seafood and hot but not burn your tongue out of your mouth hot.

Finished off w/ a Rhum Old Fashioned and off to a holiday well started!

Thanks Tadich, my faith is restored, Cheers & Here's How!
author: Morgan D.

description: So close from getting a 5 star. A little adjustment to the front of house attitude would help. We came in with a group of colleagues and their was one employee that continues to deliver a east-coast like service in a well established west coast environment. We are your customers - don't forget that. Besides the front of house service, our server was great and the food was dead spot ON!  Delicious, good serving amount, and warm as promised.  Now fix your front of the house as those are the first to interact with your customers. Cheers!
author: Vik M.

description: Can I give more than 5 stars please?! This was the best lunch I have ever had! I had the cioppino, and it was amazing! My husband had some sort of crab dish. I tried a bite and it was very good too. The service was great! Our waiter filler our drinks before they were even close to empty. He was also very friendly. This will definitely be a must for future visits to San Francisco.
author: Jessica S.

description: ...went last week...invited by a friend...ordered the cheapest special on menu...corn beef hash and eggs...$25 with tip...not worth it in my book...but this is San Francisco
author: jim b.

description:
Tadich Grill had the atmosphere of an old school steak.   The wait staff are all men in white butcher covers with a polite no non-sense style.  

Clearly this restaurant is catered towards the pin stripes crowd with Amex charge cards.   Everything on the menu is inflated price-wise.   

There are some unwitting tourists checking out the FiDi scene....sucks for them.  

I came here with a friend who saw this place on the food channel. She had a crab cakes salad and a cup of chowder.  I had half a dozen Blue Point oysters and a cup of lobster bisque.   Oysters didn't taste particularly fresh, all the liquor was drained out.   Lobster bisque was too salty and too much heavy cream.  

All said and done out the door at $67 for two for lunch.   And I paid $21 parking across from 555 California to avoid a parking ticket.  Too bad I couldn't my lunch  with a friend on an expense report like most other patrons.
author: Mia W.

description:
As enjoyable as a depression-era bread line.  Of course, this restaurant was around then, which probably explains their attitude.  Old, grumpy.

The food is fine, but it's fine at 20 other restaurants within a 2 block radius, and if you're not dining at SF's version of L'Idiot you don't need to be subject to the usual cruelty.  And there's no Patrick Stewart either.  This is SF Story, not LA Story.

Pass.
author: Harold M.

description:
A must see if you are ever visiting SF 

I had a great time from the moment we pulled up to the Valet
The valets out front were pretty funny and we were cracking jokes

We stepped inside and got seated within a minute or two

I decided to go with a classic drink to start
My friend ordered a drink as well
Both drinks came very promptly and very stiff

I had a strip steak and it was cooked very well
my friend ordered a seafood dish, she loved it

Our server was a bit frank and didn't seem to have much of a sense of humor
He was on top of everything though 

Great Place I would recommend it to all my friends
author: Max P.

description:
I'm in agreement with those who would call this an overpriced tourist trap. I had read some yelp reviews good and bad before going today and decided to just order an appetizer first and my son wanted chowder. The waiter up sold me to a $20 crab cocktail and the cocktail sauce was pretty much pure ketchup, no detectable horseradish. 

He was a surly old geezer of a waiter though the busboys were nice. Son's chowder was fine but that's easy. We left. They don't take Amex, so the waiter tossed my card aside letting me know that. I'm used to eating pricey seafood all the time. Heck we are in a $700/nt room at the Mandarin oriental. But this place is a sham and you ought to seek out only 5star places.
author: K A.

description:
I stopped eating fish almost 3 years ago but every now and then I'll eat some. Today I broke the rules and had the Mahi Mahi. This was the most delicious grilled fish steak I've had. Period. 

The service was really good and fast. I now feel I have a place where I can go for a work lunch and just treat myself with amazing seafood.
author: JD M.

description:
ABCD Season One, Episode Four: "Getting Grilled"
Conversation overheard here. Loosely translated.

A: It really wasn't necessary to invite us out. It's not cheap here, you know. 

C: Nonsense! We're so happy you two can help us simple Midwest folks from the Windy City find a decent place to dine. This is a famous spot, huh? Around since 1849. Impressive!

B: Well, technically that's true. But also not. They've only been at this location since the 60s, before that they were elsewhere in the city, they changed ownership, wrangled over who would keep the name, and had profit-centered conflicts all too typical of the capitalist free market. 

A: Could you please drop the political economics for once? It's ruining my appetite, and I am looking forward to a serious seafood feast right about now. 

D: Oh let him talk. I like listening to your friend. He's so passionate about his views. I can respect that. And I've never eaten at a Croatian restaurant before. What should I get? The oysters Rockefeller? Or maybe the Lobster Thermidor? And what exactly are sand dabs, anyway? Wow! Looks like the menu for the Titanic.

A: I don't think this place is like that. I mean, it's not really Croatian in that they don't specialize in regional or ethnic dishes. They are basically an all-American seafood, meat, and potato sort of place with a good bar, decent beer and wine selections, and a throwback, classy sort of wood-paneled atmosphere. It's not like a stereotypical Greek or Italian restaurant, in that sense. 

C: Well I don't know about you two gentlemen, but D. and I are ordering the Tadich Seafood Platter. A little bit of everything, from raw oysters and crab to smoked trout and marinated herring and shrimp cocktail. It will go great with a  few pints of Sierra Nevada. Hey! Is that Condi Rice on her second Dirty Martini? That's what I'm talkin' about, sistah!

A: (ignores him). 

B: You know, it's hard to say exactly what a Croatian restaurant even should be like. The country has had a complicated history. Until recently, it was part of the Habsburg empire. After the First World War it became part of Yugoslavia. When it gained independence, it was under the influence of the Nazis (a touchy subject, still), and after that it was incorporated back into Yugoslavia under Tito. By the time you get to the 1990s and Croatia reemerges as a sovereign state, the whole mess in Bosnia and Kosovo further disrupted things. Now things are quieter, of course, but the bullet holes and emotional scars still very much remain. 

D: Well, we're hoping to take an Adriatic cruise next summer and see Dubrovnik. The pictures are gorgeous!

B: Pictures can be deceiving, especially the glossy touristy kinds. There are still a lot of ghosts to deal with from the war. But that's true all over Europe, and beyond. Most people don't even know that the worst armed conflict in recent times happened in Central Africa, while Yugoslavia was falling apart at the seams.

A: And no history lectures, either! Shut up and eat, for once in your life, OK?

C: Look, here comes the seafood. Wow, that's a lot to handle!

D: It sure is. They really pile it on the plates, don't they? No minimalist presentation here or gastronomic-molecular food display. This is about eating good in the neighborhood.

B: (laughs). Cool pop cult reference. Such a public health catastrophe waiting to happen. You won't see me in THAT suburban 'hood anytime soon ... I'll see your Applebees and raise you an IHOP: come hungry, leave honkey ;-)

A: (snorts Sierra Nevada through his nose). Now that's more like it! Keep Marx and Engels in their cages for a while and show me some corporate franchise tagline luv!

B: (slurps a raw oyster, then continues) Don't get me started, 'cause then I'll never stop. How about this one? WalMart: Always low wages. Always.

A: McDs: I'm leavin' it! Touche, amigo.

C: (confused). Poor Sam Walton. And Ray Kroc, too. Such good businessmen. They deserve a statue or something.

B: (undeterred) DeBeers: A blood diamond is forever. Back atcha ...

A: (makes a tennis backhand motion) Nike: Just Outsource It.

B: With a name like Smuckers, it has to have corn syrup. (plays the air banjo) High fructose, that is ... 

D: I've got one! Timex: It takes a licking to keep him ticking. 

C: (turns bright red) That's just not a proper thing for a lady to say.

D: You didn't mind last night, you crazy-sexy Dirty Harry, you ... 

B: Hey, it's nothing I haven't seen before. I grew up in Berkeley. 

A: Where else, ya' pinko? (winks). Let's wrap things up, shall we? In honor of our meal here at Tadich, I'll go old school on your a#$. Taco Bell. Before they started thinking outside the bun, they urged patrons to "make a run for the border." How un-PC can you get? Watch out for the minutemen on your way to the Nachos Supreme!

C: (motions to waiter) Check please! Maybe we should be leaving. I think it's almost time for "Monk." 

And leave they did.
author: Bradley N.

description: OMG the ravioli taste  AMAZING!! very authentic.. Loved it!! Friendly waiter very courteous, cute little spot.  We sat at the bar for dinner which I recommend because you feel involved with the place you can see what's going on... Very fun!
author: Frenchie B.

description: Great experience.  The food was delicious.  I loved the Manila Clams. Our server was very good
author: Christine L.

description: This was a fun place to go to. I had the steak which was a little chewy but thier raviolli was to die for! My co worker had a seafood soup and that was amazing as well. Friendly staff and fast service is a huge plus!
author: Cecilia L.

description:
Amazing historic SF restaurant can't believe it took me so long to get to. 4.4 stars

Food: 4, Atmosphere: 4, Service: 4
Cost to worth it rating: 3
Return worthiness: yes
Eve award: best cioppino ever, best garlic bread 

Highlights:
- Cioppino: knock your socks off delicious. Packed full with so much seafood from clams to shrimp to crab to white fish. Every piece was fresh--even though tiny bay shrimp that often aren't so appetizing or fishy. The star however was the broth: tomatoey and deceivingly
packed with flavors. I drained that large bowl of fluid either by drinking it out if clam shells or sopping it up with the most outstanding pieces of garlic bread. This Oscar-worthy supporting star was thick, grilled crispy, and buttery. Sounds standard but it was nothing short of perfection. 
- Atmosphere: long room reminiscent of a train car. Loved the long counter seating area. You could just feel the history of it and imagine old school politicians making deals here. Felt like I was 
- Waiters: full of personality 
- House bread: sourdough at its finest, presented on a small plate with thick pieces in loaf form

Lowlights:
- No free refills on soda: when refilled charged for another one
- Bar: super small area up front so gets crowded

Was thrilled this lived up to my expectations, as have been wanting to come here for years. Is a gem for locals and tourists alike.
author: Eve K.

description:
There are many things i really like about Tadich Grill- i love the old school ambiance, the white coats the staff wears, the seafood is delicious and doesn't try to get too fancy with flavors, the cocktails are delicious, and the wine list is simple and affordable.

Three of us came here for dinner on Saturday- we waited a bit, but it was totally ok because we were armed with our manhattans.  When we sat down, we shared the steamed clams to start and then had cioppino, the dungeness crab salad, and the monkfish.  everything was really delicious and tasty.   I really love how all the food accentuates the freshness of the seafood but still is super delicious.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Never go to SF without a meal or two at Tadich. 
My kind of place, excellent food unpretentious atmosphere and service.
author: Jim C.

description: Amazing meal, clam chowder & scallops were delicious. Sat at the counter and was greeted by a friendly waiter who was very attentive. Ambiance is classic SF and would highly recommend. Ended the meal with a few bites of decadent cheesecake. Yum!
author: Heather J.

description: The greater was gracious and accommodating. Our waiter was excellent and best of all delicious seafood.
author: RC G.

description:
Had lunch at the "oldest restaurant in SF". 

We shared the prawn cocktail and had a bowl each of the clam chowder, both of which were fine, nothing amazing.

The sand dabs were lightly coated and fried, served with boiled veggies. The fish was underseasoned, and I didn't like eating it with tartar sauce. 

The hangtown fry, which Bourdain enjoyed, was fine, but didn't really showcase the fresh seafood. 

Fine to go once for history's sake, but I wouldn't come back.
author: Derrick V.

description: Came back after 2 1/2 years from the last review....nothing has changed.  plan to have your last meal here...the best. Had Hangtown Fry today. Lord have mercy what a great place.
author: Rick C.

description:
Incredibly overpriced.
Service is good, but so loud and bustly that you can't hear yourself think. 
Even as an institution, the hype is unwarranted. The food quality itself does not stand alone. 
My partner got a red snapper and was asked if she wanted shrimp on top of it. She said yes and got some Geisha mini-shrimp/cream sauce. It was not described that the shrimp would be of the "practically canned" variety and cream sauce was not mentioned. She is lactose intolerant. 
We tried to send it back and got a terse explanation of what the dish was on the menu. I said, "Cream sauce is NOT listed on the menu and she's lactose intolerant. What do you suggest?" 
Of course, with attitude, the waiter took her plate and she got another bland meal in its place. 
I'll not return and I'll not recommend.
author: Melody M.

description:
Wanna travel back in time?  Step into this place and you suddenly feel the history of more than 150 years come through.  The decor and furniture remind me of a time when SF was still in the roaring 20's.  A long bar / countertop eating area to the right....to the left are walled off booths that make for a semi-private dining area.  Even on a Monday night the place was packed and the noise level tremendous.  Fortunately, we were lucky to secure 2 seats at the counter.

Perusing the moderate sized menu and the prices are well...just as advertised $$$.  Expect to pay about $30 / entree.  With such a large menu I was expect the food to be so-so if not mediocre.  I chose the Chilean sea bass and my friend, the Dungeness crab and prawns a la monza. (and btw, the menu is printed with date on it daily to showcase freshness)  My friend's baked casserole type dish was definitely tasty.  It's presentation was less than spectacular and more reminiscent of homecooking.  However, the taste was awesome!!!  My sea bass was soft, flaky and melted in my mouth.  Every part of my dish had a unique flavour that surprised me at each bite....the sauce, the prawn's seasoning, the fish.  The vegetables that mine came with though were nothing interesting...just brussel sprouts that were slightly undercooked if the piece was large or overcooked if it was a small sprout.

Overall, I liked my experience and would return to try other great sounding seafood entrees from the menu!!!
author: Cary L.

description: Sorry for the long review but this story had to be told. Went here on the recommendation from the Omni Hotel. It was a Friday night, very busy. We got a table with privacy walls and were very excited for the upcoming experience. My wife and I don't drink so we ordered sparkling water from the server who barley acknowledged us. He was visibly perturbed by the order. I caught him, barley, before he walked away to also order some appetizers, Crab cake and pasta with meat sauce. Again he seemed annoyed by this order. While waiting for appetizers and considering entrees we both said we felt like the server saw us an annoyance because we did not order expensive drinks and probably thought we were having appetizers for dinner. He came back with the appetizers, slamming the pasta down and tossing the spoons at the bowl while turning and leaving before they hit the table. He returned and asked if we would like anything else. I asked him, "What do you recommend?" He shortly responded, "People like the Cioppino." I told him we needed another minute to decide and again he was annoyed. At this point my wife was boiling and refused order one more thing. Too bad because the crab cake was good, pasta average, and we were looking forward to some fresh seafood. When came back and asked "What else?" I responded, "I think we've had enough." He then says, as though he expected this answer, "Just so you know we have an $11per person minimum." I told him we thought he was very rude and that is why we are leaving. He pressed why we thought that and things got even more uncomfortable as the privacy walls now felt like an interrogation room. I told him the comment about the $11 is exactly how we felt he was thinking from the start. He did apologize and I thanked him for that but still asked for the bill. He pressed further "Even after I apologized you still want to go?" I told him yes and at this point we officially were the most uncomfortable we had ever been in a restaurant. I almost expected him to keep arguing with me until I ordered more food but he eventually brought the check. In conclusion, there are so many great restaurants in San Francisco I would recommend you try them all before this one based on the service alone.
author: Adam D.

description:
The food was 4 star.

The location is 4 star.

The ambience is definitely the Quarter from New Orleans, so 5 stars.

Our waiter was ok, cold to start but warmed up, so 3 stars.

Food was around the table was ok, so 3 stars.

If you are staying in the Omni then definitely eat here.
author: Best P.

description: We enjoyed lunch at Tadich Grill on our way through San Francisco on the Monday after Christmas. Family recommended we grab lunch there and we had a 'list' of recommendations including the Bloody Mary's, steamers, crab cocktail, san dabs (lightly pan fried fish) and chowder. After having dined there myself now, I would have only ordered a double order of steamers. The best steamers (with garlic and butter as they are on the menu as 'steamers' or 'garlic and butter') I've had in a long time. The Bloody Mary's could have been spicier but they did have plenty of vodka. Maybe you can order a spicy version? The San Dabs were delicious. I would skip the crab cocktail and the chowder as they weren't so fabulous as to pay the high price. So in hindsight, the perfect lunch for us would have been the steamers (with the delicious bread to dip in the broth) and a couple of cold beers rather than the Bloody Marys. The other items were not really worth the high price. But definitely a fun lunch in San Fran and the steamers were the best! Now I know!
author: Heidi S.

description: Classic. Get the breaded scallops, with the braised rib if I remember. wow!
author: Ryan R.

description: Went to this restaurant in a party of four. The drinks, the wine and the food were great. The food came quick and the quality was great.  However, as soon as we finished our dessert we were told by the host and the waiter to leave.  We were literally told that they had people waiting so we had to go.  We couldn't believe it. As soon as the tip was given and check was taken, the waitress was horrible and basically said that our experience didn't matter and that we were taking too long.  The thing is we were literally only waiting for our uber driver to pick us up, which was a 7 minute wait.  And all four of us order cocktails and got a second round. Also got an appetizer plus the four entrees. The most expensive white wine and dessert. Apparently all that wasn't enough to be able to relax after eating for 10 minutes after the meal.   I am very disappointed in this restaurant and even though I thought the food was great, I will not return.
author: Nick F.

description:
A fresh menu prepared daily! This place has been in San Francisco since 1869 and the service is 21st century. From the moment you walk in and see the long bar that is filled with people and the crowded dining area, you can sense the feeling of excellence. This is not your run-of-the-mill restaurant. They want to provide the best possible experience by quickly serving each customer. The service is quick and accurate. These waiters' are professionals at what they do and they know how to serve a customer, with strong wit and quick service. 

This was my second time back, I highly recommend trying any of their daily specials, but make sure to get here early so they don't run out of ingredients. I usually have their oysters as an appetizer, very good and fresh. The fish they serve tastes so fresh it absolutely melts in your mouth.
author: Theodore S.

description: Fabulous cioppino- the dish can be a tad bit too sweet for me, but I love the thick stew with all of the goodness from the sea. I was very fond of the Rockfella oysters -- the spinach was surprising a great complement for the oyster with the generous covering of cheese. The dungeness crab had fresh crab but was a bit bland. Try going on a cold weekday evening, bundled up (no heating in the building) to avoid lines.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Food was delicious! The server had a snotty attitude and it tarnished our experience.
author: Krissi S.

description: Great historic eatery that bespeaks all things great and small. Connections made here are kept only by time and tradition way longer than any life we will live. Try the San Dabs or a myriad of endless ocean's best, fresh. Only New Orleans has rivals these few. If you go tonight, bless you my person and think of me. I was there once, twice, three times I'm gone. In testament to my great friend Wolfe Rudman who knew a thing or two about great food/dining "chasing them in the heavens".
author: Russell S.

description:
Definitely one of the best Cioppino's I have had. If there's a wait, check the bar for empty seats. You can avoid waiting altogether if you sit at the bar.

Since this is the oldest running restaurant in SF, I'd recommend bringing any out of towner here. It is an authentic SF spot to visit and eat.
author: Laura C.

description: Our party of five stopped in here on a Saturday night, and we were seated fairly quickly. Some people may be daunted by the "no reservations" policy, yet it's all a matter of timing. There are lots of tables for two. We were fortunate enough to get one of the booths along the wall, which was cozy and felt like a semi-private dining room. I dined on the filet of Pacific red snapper with bay shrimp, which was very tasty and good value for the money. Another in our party had the cioppino, which looked very good. That's what I'll have on my next visit. This is a classic San Francisco dining experience! You must make time for dining and drinking at Tadich Grill, The Original Cold Day Restaurant.
author: Jeff D.

description: Good location to have dinner and see a show. Any restaurant offering great service, good ingredients, and wicked great bartenders is a winner. Great place to take a date.
author: Frank C.

description:
Love it -- this'll be my new go-to when I stay in FiDi. 

Tadich is old-timey done right. My benchmark cocktail for these types of places is a gin gimlet, and they definitely do it right with the perfect amount of Rose's Lime. And the bloody marys? Absolutely AMAZING, and even better extra spicy. 

The food is pretty awesome too--my fave is probably the cioppino, which is complemented by two slices of thick, buttery bread and rivals Sotto Mare's as the best in the city. 

If you plan to dine at the expansive bar, just make sure you sit past the brass rails that cut in about a third of the way into the bar--the front counter offers a limited menu only.
author: Eeeeestar T.

description: Their seafood is truly outstanding and whenever I'm in town, I try to slip in here by myself at off hours to get a seat at the bar.  The only disappointment is a vegetable medley is quite possibly the saddest side ever created.  Brussels sprouts, spinach, broccoli, literally anything cooked in a pan with a little garlic, pepper, and oil/fat would be preferable.
author: Dan O.

description:
A lot of old restaurants coast.  You know the type, too much hype about their age and classic status and not enough focus on the task you're paying them for.  Tadich Grill has avoided this problem.  Sure, they have the mandatory story on their menu about having been established when your grandfather was in diapers but they also have a professional waitstaff, some of whom may have been providing unobtrusive and outstanding service since about the same time.  The menu at Tadich is so comprehensive it probably doesn't need to rotate constantly and everything I've tried in multiple visits has been high quality, excellently prepared, and well deserving of a permanent spot on the menu.

Yep, you're likely to wait in a line out the door and no, you cannot get a reservation or cheat with a call-ahead.  The bartenders are outstanding and there are great drinks to keep you busy while you wait.  Allow some time and enjoy your stay.
author: Kevin N.

description: Tadich has redeemed itself. Great experience. Arrived at 4 pm and had no problem getting a table.   Wonderful old school feeling. Great menu, great food. Our waiter - David - was fantastic. We had a nice 2 hour dining experience. Cocktails, appetizers, salads, entrees, desserts, etc. the entire package.  Dining at Tadich Grill was a highlight of our evening!!  Way to go and make us proud of your SF heritage.
author: J K.

description: at 7:30 Pm on a Tuesday night, it was packed, but interesting to sit at the crowded bar, we ended up eating at the bar instead of waiting for a private booth.  the Red Snapper was the best grilled fish I have ever eaten.  Great aldente veggies and I was not a fan of the fried potatoes. It's not elegant but classy, after all it is downtown San Fran. This restaurant has been opened since 1848, the upkeep is terrific, still the same after all these years.  Clean and traditional.  Next to Joe's Stone Crab in Miami, I loved the atmosphere.and will be my #1 to go place on the West coast.
author: Jane W.

description: Cioopino is not as good as expected regarding this pruce. The fish does not have flavor. The garlic bread is good though.
author: Huibing L.

description: Surprisingly the place looked packed but the wait was only about 20 minutes when they told us 30 . Cute old school resturant.  Delicious fast service.  We had the crab cocktail *alot of crab! But nothing fancy. And the seafood cioppino had a variety of seafood and it was delicious. Must try like the fellow yelpers stated
author: Jenn D.

description: We had heard amazing things about Tadich Grill, and since it is the oldest restaurant in SF we had high hopes. Service was good: we were seated quickly even though the place was hopping. We started with the calamari, which was a good choice for appetizer.  Breading was light and crunchy, the squid was tender with good flavor, and the portion was huge. Unfortunately the main course was a letdown. While I enjoyed the cioppino which had plenty of fish, jumbo prawns, clams, and mussels in a hearty tomato broth, my wife's crab-stuffed red snapper was bland, unseasoned, and overcooked. I had a couple bites of her dish and was thoroughly unimpressed even though mine was actually pretty good, and more than I could finish. So while I can endorse the calamari and felt the cioppino lived up to billing, the red snapper wasn't, in my wife's words, worth the calories... or the price.
author: Andrew E.

description: Opening in 1849, this is the oldest restaurant in California. Stop there for a martini and a cup of clam chowder after a Giants game. The clam chowder was excellent, subtle yet refined.
author: Doc L.

description:
I'm a fan of the steak fries, bartenders & atmosphere...I wasn't a fan of my food. I ordered it b/c it was on the 7X7 Eat list & I should have ordered the tuna steak salad the couple beside me had...they couldn't stop raving about it!

But, the sand dabs were interesting. Something that's California & not found too many other places. A white fish they pan fry, very mild & I found it hard to distinguish any real flavor to the fish. I kept the bones which were easy enough to remove w/ knife & fork, the meat does fall right off the bones so the fish is very moist & flaky - a great combo! 

The steak fries are amazing! I didn't want to like them but I ate them all & wanted more but didn't go that far...settled for the steamed veggies instead. A mix of the norm - carrots, brocolli, cauliflower, etc - steamed & served on the side. 

The building/atmosphere is awesome - so old & with lots of history. The bartenders all wear white lab coat uniforms & make really good drinks - I recommend getting a cocktail! 

I'll be back to try their other dishes although a bit on the pricier side so this won't be a regular go-to restaurant.
author: Marissa H.

description: Ambiance, fine service, a feeling of history emanating from the walls. Expect to pay a lot; it's meant to be a special experience. I wish I could have stayed longer and tried more of the menu options to make the most of it. Luckily Tadich seems to have an ability to stick around, so I'll just have to try it again on my next trip to San Fran.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I would give Tadich Grill zero stars if possible.  My Mom came in recently alone to dine and wanted to sit in a booth and was told "sorry, single diners have to sit at the counter"?????!!!  WHAT??

My Mom & Dad have been dining at Tadich Grill for years.  They would make the drive from Fairfield to San Francisco just to dine here every few months.  On April 17th my Dad passed, he and my Mom had been married 46 years.  

Now here is my Mom recently widowed and wants to visit a restaurant she and my Dad dined at many times.  All she wanted was to sit in their favorite booth.  She told me she felt discriminated against and awful, especially being recently widowed.  She also said she will probably never return after this incident. Put yourself in her shoes Tadich Grill and imagine how you would feel?

I do not often write reviews such as this but you made my heart ache for the manner in which you treated my Mom.  It is unforgivable that you treat single diners this way and why?  Because you make less money?  Disgraceful!
author: C C.

description: I have lived in San Francisco for 40+ years and this has always been my go-to place for excellent sea food.  To those who think the waiters are too gruff...that's the point idiots!  If you want your server to kiss your ass go elsewhere or grow a pair.
author: Dennis B.

description:
B. and I finally went for dinner at Tadich Grill 7/1/06.  It's really close to Embarcadero Bart-a block away.  We got there around 6pm and there were people lined up for a table, we decided to eat at the bar.  Eating at the bar is fun and you can get your food faster it seems.

Sourdough bread and butter brought out quickly, and ice-water too.  We ordered Boston clam chowder, Coney Island chowder, pan-fried sand dabs, and cioppino.  Boston clam chowder in a cup is $5.25 and pretty good-not the best, but decent.  Coney Island chowder is a tomato based chowder-and just ok; we liked the Boston clam chowder best of the two.  Sand dabs were decent-lightly crisped from frying, some boring veggies, and 3 wedges of fries I didn't eat.  Cioppino was pretty tasty-lots of chunks of fish, some crab, shrimp w/ two slightly burnt toast.

Total with tip around $60.  Nice to go once or on someone else's tab.

Free Matchbox by the register/check-in.  "The Original Cold Day Restaurant, established 1849.
author: Ann L.

description:
I came during my lunch break and this place was jiving.  So many people and it was packed.  There are tables as well as a center bar area.  I felt a little transported to either a place in England or oldie times.

~ Sand Dabs ~
I ordered the Sand Dabs to go.  I had to go all the way in the back to get my order.  The order didn't take too long to get and I was ready to munch.  The fish was flaky and moist.  It was so expensive though.  I don't think I would go here unless it was for celebratory reasons.  I really only came to do the 7x7 list.  If you do want to try something, this was definitely a good meal.  Plentiful and fresh.
author: Carolen M.

description:
Excellent Casseroles!!
So great that I beat myself up for not remembering the name or address of the place (randomly dropped by for dinner). And then it just dawned on me that I could search for casseroles in the financial district on yelp, and thanks to the wonderful people who takes picture of the store front door and interior, yayy there's my long lost favorite restaurant in SF! Definitely will be back next time I come back to the west coast!
author: Cheryl D.

description: I go out of my way to get seafood here! Very fresh and the staff is amazing. The best part is its not necessarily first come first serve and a lot of people don't know that. Theres usually a big crowd inside just waiting for people to leave but you can go stand behind anyone at the bar and if they leave you can take their spot. It usually doesn't take very long to be seated.
author: Libby S.

description:
(From July visit)
After a couple hours wandering around the city, my friend and I went to Tadich Grill for dinner. It was a Saturday night and quite busy, but we managed to snag two seats at the bar. We both ordered gin martinis, which got us a nod of approval from Barry the waiter. And with good reason: their martinis rock. Smooth and cool and delicious. 

I fussed over the menu a little, as I am a picky eater and I am gluten-free these days. I ended up deferring to Barry the waiter, who's worked there for 22 years and knows his stuff. (He looks kinda like one of the Observers from "Fringe," to be honest.) When I told him I needed to avoid gluten & wheat, he recommended the Chilean sea bass and started me off with the lettuce & avocado salad. The salad was delicious, chock full of veggies and avocado and not too heavy on lettuce. The sea bass was awesome as well: nice and mild for me, the picky eater with a delicate constitution. Barry even had the chef plate it with boiled potatoes instead of the rice, because of how the rice was prepared/seasoned. I love a waiter who looks out for his customers.

I would definitely go back to Tadich Grill based on the service alone, though the food is top-notch as well. And those martinis. Woo boy.
author: Corinne L.

description:
On a whim, we stopped here for lunch with a visiting friend on a Saturday.  I love the hustle and bustle of this historical San Francisco establishment of a restaurant.  I've been wanting to come here as I've heard so much about it over the years, and plus I had to come here since Anthony Bourdain's visit here on his San Francisco episode of No Reservations.  

There were three of us, no wait (although the restaurant was quite crowded), and we were cheerily led to a sectioned booth towards the back - loved it that we could catch up together in our semi-private little space.  

The famous San Dabs are on the 7x7 list, but I gravitated towards the dungeness crab cakes with rice and brussel sprouts - I just couldn't help myself!  YUMM!!  I loved it!!  My bf had the catfish (tasty!) and our friend had the pasta with clams - a very healthy portion, and the clams were wonderful!  I finished off my meal with coffee - I love restaurant coffee!  

For a very busy place, our service was on par.  And it's a good thing we came in when we did because as we left we noticed the wait for a table was strewn all around the front area almost out the door.  

I'll be back - love you, Tadich!
author: Maile N.

description: Have been wanting to dine @ the Tadich Grill since I heard in the mid 90's, that Wilkes Bashford  and Mayor Willie Brown frequented it. And have been several times since. On this visit, i came in just after the lunch crowd, so seating was ample. Pulled up to the near side of the bar and was attended to promptly after the bar tender finished making cocktails. Ordered a martini and it was well crafted and increased my appetite for the upcoming lunch. Requested the New York Cut Steak (medium) and is was served as ordered. Very flavorful,moist and tender with just the rich amount of chew ( gotta use those choppers and knife right?). Also have a baked potato with butter and chives and that might tough to screw up or make great. And finished with a crisp, tasty anchovy accented ceasar salad that was a tad bit cold while eating the steak. Very good experience as usual. And i prefer the bar to see the bartenders, (not mixologists) work. And faster service.
author: Kelly J.

description: If you can only go to one SF restaurant, this is it. Best seafood. Surly waiters in white jackets. No reservations. Great sanddabs, calamari. It's also the oldest restaurant in SF, founded about 150 years ago. Some of the waiters are at least that old. You can sit at the counter all alone and have a leisurely feast. Awesome.
author: Jacob C.

description: Second time there and second time the food was fantastic. I was not happy waiting 40 minutes for a table when we got there at 11:45am and were told 15 minutes. If that happens again I won't be going back; I can't kill my lunch break waiting for a table even if I get there before the lunch rush. It would be nice if they took reservation vs first come first served. Again, the food is excellent and the service just as good
author: A. C.

description:
A true  "San Francisco" experience..
One of the oldest restaurants in the city
Tadich Grill has great service, really good seafood, and atmosphere that is from another time.
Classy but not too formal..
I usually order Sand Dabs as it's getting harder and harder to find this small pacific flounder. 
The Chippino is also very good
previously featured on Bourdain's "No Reservations" 
Exceptional service, good food,  a lot of history.... Worth a visit..
author: Mike T.

description:
A great "Old School" Place with Modern Comforts

.Had the pleasure of dining at Tadich during a stay in SF. Walked in on a Saturday evening and was lucky enough to get 3 seats at the bar. Service was friendly and courteous even though we had a young child with us. Every food item we ordered was exceptionally well done and fairly priced. 

One of the best cioppino dishes I have had. Just saw that they are opening in DC. They should do very well here.
author: Peter S.

description:
They seated us in a booth, which brings you back into a time before fancy/trendy places. Also, they had a really nice bar (which stretched from the door all the way to the back!) 

We ordered a cioppino, grilled sea bass, and Rockefeller oysters for three....and it came out to a little over $100! My friend also got the sidecar, which was really befitting in this place. 

The cioppino is spot on and that tomato broth with grilled bread is just delicious! 

For me, I love the history behind this place since it is supposedly one of the oldest restaurant in the US (dating as far back as the Gold Rush in 1849!) The food is simple, but the quality is amazing. Go during a weekday so its not as crowded.
author: Bonita Y.

description:
I have eaten lunches out of my office for  over 40 years in SF financial district, including Tadich Grill on occasion. 

My most recent visit will be my last. The big guy at the entry gate has now been hostile for the last time for me as he is not welcoming whatsoever. The waiter this week must have had orders to 'get them in and get them out asap' and he had no bedside manners as he rushed us to order and to eat. Because we ordered a first course, he obviously did not hold back ordering our main course (rex sole) as when it arrived, it was luke warm. He shuffled by our table constantly hoping we would pick up the bill which we had not yet asked for. Incidentally, with an expensive bottle of wine, we were already pretty good fish for him.
I can forgive a lot, but when given 'attitude' at the front door, and then the bum's rush, Tadich will only be a destination when I need some variety in the future. This is not the old Buich ownership I used to enjoy.
author: Herb E.

description:
Whenever I visit the Bay area, Tadich Grill is usually my first stop that I grab a bite at.  Not only are the fresh seafood entrees outstanding, so is the service by the wait staff.  As far as old school places are concerned, Tadich Grill is as good as it gets. Simply put, this is just a cool place to eat at that also happens to have great food.    

For me, I cannot think of anything better to eat on a cold windy day than their seafood cioppino.  This Italian seafood stew of clams, shrimp, scallops, fish, and crab is just out of this world.  Served with garlic bread and sourdough bread on the side, I have yet to taste a better version of this dish outside of San Francisco.  

Located in the Financial District, Tadich Grill does tend to get crowded so I would recommend eating here in mid-afternoon after the lunch crowd has died down.
author: Ryan T.

description:
The Tadich Grill is not your ordinary foofoo joint. The only place that can measure up is Union Oyster House, Boston, MA the Oldest Restaurant in America. 

First of all at the Tadich you have Bar Waiters who the junior person is in their 50's. They wear the white smock with bar towels wrapped around their arm.

 They were printing up large daily menu's way before desk top publishing! 

The varieties of Sea Food are enormous and the Power Lunch crowd tells you why! 
If your planning on a booth or table you need 2 or more; but just walk in and take a spot at the long Oak and Brass Bar. 

They don't do French here they do old fashion Sea Food so just sit and enjoy California's oldest Restaurant. Try the Hang Town Fry for late Breakfast or treat...
author: Ira G.

description:
"Once you get past rude service and the price points, there are a ton of good seafood choices."
When you walk inside, there is an abnormally long bar (which you more than likely won't find a seat at in the evening). The dining options are open tables or secluded tables closed in with wooden walls. We had one of the secluded tables since it was a large group. 
They don't take reservations and it was a 40 minute wait, which is fine since we took the pager and went next door for wine at Michael Mina. We went back in once paged and met the ever so "friendly" waiter with the mundane personality. I was already thinking...this should be fun. We receive some bread after a little while, good flavor, but cold and a little hard. Which is usually typical in San Francisco restaurants. 
I started assessing the menu and what to choose. I knew I would come out with a hole blown through my wallet no matter what I got, especially since I wanted seafood. After much indecisive frets and the waiter getting impatient with our table (wait, who's paying who? I'm sorry I didn't know I was catering to your needs and wants-all inside thoughts of course) I chose the seafood sauté. While waiting for the food the table decided on splitting a bottle of wine and apparently we decided our fate in not getting refills for our water. 
The food came out, smelled and looked delicious. One person in the group got the red snapper, it was pretty tasteless and lackluster. Which is sad for the price point being near $30. The seafood sauté was very flavorful and cooked just right with the 2 large scallops, the shrimp and the crab. The sauce was a little much, I could have done with less. After we all finished eating our food (that we were never even asked how everything turned out), we looked at the desserts and decided we were done. 
The waiter finally comes back around with one check and when we asked to split it he refused to do so. Basically he threw his tip out the window the entire night. I am glad we tried Tadich though and might return if given the chance and try some different entrees, and hopefully a different waiter.
author: Amber B.

description:
The historical ambiance was really our purpose for dinning here, like everyone else ...

Unfortunately, the wait staff are "seasoned" beyond their years and don't enjoy serving people anymore. 

To bad it could have more potential, they really need to add reservations - the line up at the door thing doesn't work very well. 

The food was so so, not memorable enough to return.
author: Catherine L.

description: What can I say. This place is a true San Francisco classic. Been going there since I was a little kid with the folks and the petrale sole has not changed one bit. Still amazing!  Great service, atmosphere, and a bit of the "real" old San Frnacisco.  I was born here so I still remember. Yes, little old twins wandering through Union Square, the doggy diner, etc.
author: Rene H.

description: The food and service aree over the top,what a find,great place,we will be back to try other dishes.Thanks
author: Robert D.

description: All the staff tonight were an older crowd and we had a great experience from entry to bar to dining table. Our waiter Ken was terrific and food was very tasty so overall we recommend.
author: Joe B.

description:
Classy. Seriously.

My sister brought me here as a surprise as a start to my day off to celebrate my 21st birthday. We ordered some drinks and waited until we had a table ready for us and then got down to the real important stuff.

I had the clam chowder, and this crab salad, and I was barely able to finish my crab salad. I was stuffed and ready for a nice nap after downing all the food. Everything tasted fresh, and the atmosphere was to die for.

I imagined my grandmother and grandfather on a date in the city back in the 50's enjoying some drinks and ordering some food here, and then I could see myself bringing some dates to this place because it is the perfect way to impress someone. This place has so much charm and class I felt way under dressed no matter how I would choose to come and prepare myself.
author: Michael M.

description: This was one of the most disappointing meals of our trip. No it was the most disappointing! We had a seafood cocktail with one prawn and one tiny piece of crab. The rest of the cocktail was filled with soggy little shrimp like the ones served on the strip in Vegas for 99 cents. I had the sand dabs. They were sand drabs with too many bones. My husband had the halibut and it was decent, but nothing to write home about. The bill was way to much for the quality of the food. We had very poor service and the waiter somehow added 10$ on to our bill from the time he took it from us and returned it for our signature. Save your money and go to Scoma's!!!
author: Sherry L.

description:
A group of my friend and I went here for a pre-party snake. The clam chowder was amazing. I had the chowder along with a cesar salad.

This place is the least bit pretentious. It is the oldest restaurant in town,and I was told the menu has not changed very much. When food is good why change it? 

The only reason I did not give a 5 star review is because the waiter was not super friendly.
author: MoMo A.

description: As the staple of SF restaurants explode with limited menus, farm to table and boutique restaurants I'm still glad there's an old school style restaurant out there. The Cioppino here was pretty good. You cant go wrong here. It's a must eat if in SF.
author: Antonio I.

description: Not sure what the buzz is all about. I had the pork chops and thought they were kind of blend. It's a cool place to go with friends but definitely not a intimate atmosphere for a birthday dinner or date. The desserts were amazing! We had the bread pudding and rice custard! Wow!
author: Mariana A.

description:
The ambiance and service was exceptional.  Not only did they continually have someone waiting on us continually with refills on water and bread, but also cleaning off bread crumbs and putting on bibs to protect against the messy but delicious food.

I got the Cioppino and was very impressed by the amount of seafood and the rich flavors included.
author: Michael D.

description:
If you are visiting San Francisco and only had one place you could eat, you should go to Tadich Grill.  

Very old school restaurant...in fact, it's been in continuous operation since 1849!  Waiters in white waiter coats.  You NEVER see that ANYWHERE! 

The wait staff are a little abrupt, but it's all part of the atmosphere, and if you don't have a sense of humor, or can't take a little sarcasm, then you may find the whole experience a little overwhelming.  This place turns A LOT of business, and the line is out the door. They want you to order, order quickly, enjoy your food, and then free the space for the 30 people waiting for it.

The ciopino is incredible, and huge.  The steaks are perfect, and the fish is probably some of the best anywhere...not just the Bay Area.

All in all, there is a reason this place has lasted over 160 years.  Go and discover that reason for yourself!
author: Devin C.

description:
This is a pricey place. Might as well get that out of the way. But you are in San Francisco, where pricey is the norm and cheap is a challenge.

I have been here a few times. I love the nostalgia that Tadich inspires: the black-and-white tile floor, the tuxedoed waitstaff, the old wood bar and booths. I personally like sitting by the bar and watch the bartenders preparing drinks and having conversations with them (when they have a chance to, that is) or my neighbor (which helps me forget that SF can be such a cold city sometimes). Bonus: They have hooks under the counter so I can hang my purse and jacket.

My favorite dish is the cioppino.  It is seafood heaven, with the mussels, clams, shrimp, fish, etc.  It is a pretty generous portion so you will not leave hungry.  My second favorite dish would be the pan-fried scallops.  It is cooked perfectly and without too much fuss as to mess with the flavor of the seafood. The calamari steak is also quite good and their clam chowder is one of my favorites.

If I can afford to, I will be here at least every two weeks. But as it is, I consider this a place well worth going to if I were celebrating something.
author: Clarice O.

description:
I wanted to give this one star so i wouldn't have to wait to be seated but obviously it would do nothing to its rating.
My family and i vacation for the weekend in SF quite frequently. We always tend to go to different restaurants and Tadich has become my ultimate SF restaurant! 
I order the seafood mixed saute which was excellent! The scallops were cooked perfectly and there were huge pieces of crab in the dish! My grandma order the cioppino which was some of the best i have had.
If i could remember the other names of the dishes i would review how amazing they are.
Also, our server John was awesome! He had such great recommendations and made the dinner even better than imagined!
author: Natalie R.

description:
I visited here on an unseasonably cold evening in SF - not a surprise but I was unprepared for it and freezing. I needed something warm and NOTHING is better than a bowl of hot Cioppino on cold day! Ding, ding - time for Tadich Grill!

Since I was solo finding a spot at the bar wasn't a problem - I actually prefer sitting here because you get the full experience, the sense you are stepping back in time. The bar top is probably 100 years old, the chairs even older. The decor minimal but timeless, and the waiters curt, professional and appreciative. 

I went with the classics - bowl of clam chowder and the Cioppino (along with a pint of beer). Unfortuantely they were out of the white chowder so I had the pink. While this is essentially Manhattan clam chowder it's quite tasty, if not overly salty this time around. However, this is where the Tadich condiments come in handy. A squirt of lemon, some hot sauce and the chowder is perfect.

Soon after the the GIANT bowl of Cioppino came out - a serving bowl filled with about a pound of clams, mussels, shrimp, and fish, held together with a delicious tomato-based broth that is laced with garlic, onions, bay leaves and other spices. Each bite is an explosion of flavors, each better than the last. To top it off, Tadich gives you the ultimate accessory with it, two slices of garlic bread to sop up all the extra broth!

This is the perfect SF meal - it represents the character, history and essence of San Francisco and should not be missed.
author: Andy B.

description:
Love this place. Food is always good here. You really can't go wrong with any of their seafood dishes. I recommend ordering:

Oysters Rockefeller: Delish! Best oysters Rockefeller I ever had! Any other restaurant does not compare!

Cioppino: Love having this on cold rainy days. The seafood cioppino here is loaded with lots of seafood and the garlic bread that comes with it is so buttery and good!

Chilean Sea Bass: This is always good! Fish is moist and buttery.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I grew up in a seafood restaurant so I'm kind of picky. With that said the place was great. Very old timey. They do not take reservations for lunch so arrive about 11:45 -12:00 to avoid the wait. At first, I was a little thrown off by all the middle age to old men in lab coats but they run a well oiled machine. 

I am so used to going to a restaurant in the financial district at lunch and being hurried through my meal (Per Diem told us that our reservation allowed us 1 hour from the time of the reservation - pressure!) The server walked up and basically gave the impression that not only did we not need to rush but that rushing would do us no good as long as he was in charge. It was wonderful to just sit and enjoy the meal and not worry about how long we were there.

The food: 
We started with the Caesar which was good. It came with anchovies on top which my companion loved but I avoided like the plague which worked out well. For the second course we had the white clam chowder. This was one thing I loved at my family's restaurant so I may be too picky here but it was very fishy tasting. Not in a bad way but it was too strong for me. For our meals we both got the grilled trout with steak fries and veggies. The fish was cooked perfectly, the tartar sauce was great, the veggies were nicely cooked. The fries were another story. They were done well but I felt like with a meal so nice, it should have come with something other than fries. I will ask to substitute next time because fries aren't really my thing at a $30 per plate restaurant. 

Overall, the food was really tasty, the service was great, food came out quickly, and the bread was good. Plan to spend some time and money for a good time here. I will be going back for sure.
author: Brittany M.

description:
We now have a new favorite restaurant in the city.  

We started with the fried calamari.  Oh boy what a treat.  Absolutely the freshest I've ever had.  

The seafood cioppino came with fresh prawns, muscles, clams, shrimp, fish, and crab meat all in a beautiful sauce.  

The veal scallopini with veal sausage ravioli was wonderful.  The ravioli was a delight.  

We can't wait for our next trip to the Tadich.
author: Jon M.

description:
Food was excellent. Service was incredible. The only reason I am giving this four instead of five is that the wait was quite long and it is very pricey. 

However, I would definitely go here if you are in downtown. Don't go there full.
author: J W.

description: Good stuff.  It's worth coming for the history and the grub.  I'd like to try the lunch sometime.
author: Brian H.

description: Best cioppino!!   A must stop when in San Fran!!  Love this place for sure!  Oldest restaurant in CA and best classic ambiance.  Classic professional servers that don't miss a beat.  True professionals that have perfected there craft!  Not a college student or an actor trying to get by!!  They don't miss a beat.  The food and bar service is also remarkable.  Posting this to offset my shi"&@y experience with the San Fran Ferry!  I make it point that if I am giving a 1star review to someone, I have to find somebody 5 star acknowledgement.
author: Jason O.

description:
Old school charm. It's a historic restaurant.
The staff in their white jackets.. The old white guy business lunch clientele..

It's a long restaurant. Mainly a long bar with little tables around it and hidden booths. We sat at the bar where the menus were placed out for us along with bread and butter. The bread was cold and stale.

Tadich Grill is on 7x7's 100 Things list [#67 in 2009, #64 in 2010 and 2011] for their Sand Dabs ($22.75) with an option to be boned for an extra fee. I asked for boned and perhaps our server didn't hear me.. I got bones. Many little bones. It was good but it didn't seem like something to have for lunch. It came with steak fries and snap peas. Like steak fries, don't really like snap peas. I'm glad I tried the Sand Dabs but I felt like I would have liked other things on the menu over it.

Like-- The Seafood Cioppino ($29.95)! It's enough for two people and came with garlic bread. All around great dish.

Visa/MC or Cash Only.
author: O M G.

description:
Score! I crossed another restaurant off the 7x7 list I've been seriously obsessing about the past few months. Yessss!!!

I managed to "pre-Yelp" the spot, seemed to have read a good amount of reviews so figured I'd try it out for lunch.  I decided to lunch it up w/ a good Yelp bud of mine and agreed to meet @11:30AM-early. Thank God we did because there were no seats readily available, and come 15 minutes into lunch people were standing waiting around for spots at the bar to open up.  Good sign: people standing around actually waiting for a bar spot! 

Ambiance: Old school. Looks like somewhere a meeting between the Godfather and his mobster crew would go down.  There were lots of table seats, bar seats, and even private booth seats.. all were completely occupied during our lunch visit.  What's up w/ the lab coats though? Everyone- from the hosts, waiters, to the cleaning crew were fitted in what looked like white lab coats. 

Food: Ordered the Sand Dabs (to cross off the 7x7 list) and my pal ordered the Half Avocado w/ Dungeness crab salad.  

The Sand Dabs are fried fillet strips, topped w/ a light crème sauce, sautéed brussel sprouts, pieces of thick steak fries, and a heaving cup portion of their thick tartar sauce. A few Yelpers reviewed that it was the tartar sauce that made the dish because of the yummy chunks of blue cheese. To the contrary, the waiter broke it down as some simpleton ingredients: mayo, pickles, potatoes, and no blue cheese. Hmm okay, not quite the description I expected. It sounded pretty plain actually. 

The Crab Louie Salad, however, looked pretty generous considering it was a "half" salad. It was filled w/ the works: fresh avocado, tons of fresh crab, lettuce, tomatoes, carrots, beets, olives, etc. My friend raved that every bite included a piece of chunky crab meat. Yum! 

Bottom line: Food was good, but not good enough to justify $60... especially for lunch. Next!!!!
author: Joy A.
