description: Excellent service and delicious food. Had the cioppino that was mouth watering and very full of seafood. The shrimp must have weighed 8-10 oz. HUGE SCALLOPS. Try the chicken livers if they have any left.
author: Patrick A.

description: My daughter is a Celiac, and I dined at this well established restaurant on June 13th for lunch. My waiter was a pompous fellow named Barry. He assured us that our food would be prepared gluten free. Two hours after eating the seafood dish my daughter threw her guts  for two hours to the point she had to be admitted to the hospital for gluten !!!  Barry told us he has worked there for 22 years and assured us everything would be great " I guarantee it "When I called and spoke to the manager he barley apologized - just said said that he will bring it up on His staff meeting. IF YOU OR ANYONE YOU KNOW IS A CELIAC OR EVEN GLUTEN INTOLERANT- I URGE  YOU TO STAY CLEAR OF THIS OVERRATED PLACE.
author: Steve S.

description:
It's been a while since I've been to Tadich Grill but so what? Order their Cioppino. DO ITTT!! Yes, it's about $30 and no you're probably not going to be able to eat the entire thing (unless you're really hungry) but it was worth every penny even though I could only get through half. The seafood was cooked perfectly and they didn't skimp on it a bit. The broth had tremendous flavor and wasn't too tomatoey. Sublime taste all around. 

The only downfall is that stupid bib they put on you. ;)
author: Dobby P.

description:
Wow, this is straight up old school.  

It looks old, there are old people working there, and old people dining there.  It's one of those restaurants full of regulars I would imagine.  Although I'm not sure how their pockets keep up with the regularity.  

I decided to get the two most talked about dishes: the Seafood Cioppino and Sand Dab Fillets.  The former is very different here.  The soup base is lighter, the seafood flavor is strong, and well, there is a LOT of seafood.  I'm talking clams, jumbo shrimps, scallops, crab, and I don't know what else.  I seriously feel like after 5 minutes, all the soup disappeared or maybe there just wasn't much to start out with.  This dish is so perfect for a gloomy SF day.

For the latter, you get about 6 little sand dab fillets plus veggies plus four french fries and a LOT of tartar sauce.  Trust me, you will want to have dollups of tartar sauce with each bite of fish because it's just that good.  The sand dabs itself were cooked nicely but I don't know if I would get it a second time unless I was really craving it.

I can't help but imagine that everything else is just as delicious.  It's kind of pricey though so make it a special day.
author: Shannon L.

description: I'm giving this 3 stars because it wasn't anything special but it was still good. I got the broiled red snapper, which was tastey and fresh but unfortunately had bones in it. My dad had monkfish, also good, and my sisters seafood cannelloni was very good as well. My other sister however is a vegetarian and ordered the veggie plate, which was a disappointment. all of the vegetables, not just on her plate but on my dad and my plates as well were all undercooked and not seasoned at all. The service was pretty good, although there were tons of people rushing by every table. Overall, this place I would recommend, but not strongly. There are definitely better places to eat in San Fran.
author: Anthony D.

description:
If you love a vintage atmosphere.. this is the place! 
From the interior to the waiters, this place is romantic and very original. 
The food is great... the cocktails are better (lol)
author: Cindy M.

description:
So... Everyone is talking about Cioppino- a seafood stew in tomato based broth, I had to give it a try. There was very little seafood and lots of onion and tomato, but very flavorful dish. It was worth the try, but I wouldn't order it again for $30.

Seafood Louies- Seafood on a bed of lettuce, very unique. This is a large plate, good for sharing. 

The ambiance of the restaurant was my favorite- dark, old school, mysterious. We had our own booth with jacket hanger- classy!

Servers were attentive, maybe a little too attentive, kept coming back to ask if we were done with our dishes.
author: Pauline H.

description:
Although I live far from the Bay Area, I have dined at Tadich several times over the years, and enjoyed the experience each time. Beautiful, men's club style dining room, fresh sourdough and butter to accompany your drink as you consider the menu. There's a lot to like. I visited most recently a couple of weeks ago with my wife. She had, and enjoyed, the sauteed scallops, served with a vegetable medley and a rice pilaf. It was one of those "expensive but worth it" ($31) dishes. My dinner was an entirely different experience. 

I noticed a fish on the menu that I had seen on prior visits, but never had tried, the sand dabs. I asked the waiter about them, and he said that they were "baby flounder," and that they were very good. I'm careful eating fish, and I know that the occasional fish bone is part of the deal. This, however, was something else entirely. I only had about 4 or 5 small bites of the three "filets" served to me. Each bite contained MANY bones, as in more bones than meat in each bite. I stopped with about 2  1/2 of the 3 "filets" remaining on the plate, because I could not continue, and eating was no longer feasible or pleasant, as my gum was bleeding where a fish bone had punctured it. For what it is worth, even the fried potatoes served with my dish were nasty: though browned on the exterior, they appeared to have sat on a steam table too long, rendering them soggy. That said, they were not even cooked all the way through. 

There's lots of fault to go around: our waiter seemed completely uninterested in anything except turning the table, and said nothing about the bones in the sand dabs when I asked about them, though I said I'd never tried them. The prep staff either didn't filet the dabs, or did a terrible job of it. The bus person picked up my plate on which most of the fish was untouched, and either didn't communicate that to our waiter, or our waiter just didn't care. I'm deeply bothered by this experience at a restaurant I had enjoyed and at which I expected an "expensive but worth it" dinner. I used to go to Tadich each time I was in the Bay Area. I don't know if I'll go the next time I'm in town, but one thing's certain: I'll never order the sand dabs again.
author: Bill F.

description: I've been going here for years.  I was disappointed to here how the handled Gene Upshaw.  But I came in at 3:30 on Dec 22 to sit 8.  We had 7 and they refused to sit us even though the seat was open.  Happy to take our business to SAMs. Merry Chrismas you racists.
author: David G.

description:
Very pricey, but it's QUALITY food:

1. Salad with crab and bay shrimp $10 - YUM, they've just raised their salads a dollar and made their portions smaller

2. Half Dz Oyster Rockefellers $20 - Cheesy, spinach goodness...oysters are baked yet still raw.  YUM.

3. Chilean Sea Bass - $30  HUGE HUGE HUGE portion of fish.  By the time I got my entree, I was already full.  I ate some, and the left overs still looked like a HUGE portion.  This was served with rice and broccoli.  

No dessert...but their bread pudding is pretty good.  

Stay away from their coffee = table turned faster...
author: Janet L.

description: Everytime I visit NorCal I end up trying a new restaurant.  I was very pleasantly surprised with the food. The clam chowder (white) was Amazing!!! I also had fish and chips, this fish was So incredibly fresh and was lightly fried rather than all batter. The service was also great. Very attentive staff all around and our waiter was wonderful.
author: Brianne D.

description:
Since this restaurant has been in business longer than California has been part of the United States, I just had to go! I've worked in the neighborhood on occasion, but was not familiar with the history of this place.

We drove in from the Central Valley, so we parked in 3 Embarcadero an walked around the corner. There was room at the counter, so we opted for dinner up there where we could enjoy some people-watching. It was not yet 5 PM, so the place was not crowded - indeed, it seemed that that restaurant was filled with locals who visited frequently. They'd wander in, pull up a stool next to their favorite or second favorite waiter, and a drink would be served with not more than a nod.

Because it was my first time here, I felt obligated to try the Cioppino. Not a bad deal! I'm a seafood guy. This was definitely some high end comfort food.  A little expensive, but the quality matched the price. My date had the New York steak with shaved asparagus spears. It was fabulous (I know because I took a bite).

Service was professional -- and non-intrusive. I wouldn't consider this a date restaurant, but someplace solid for people that know what they want to eat of American cuisine, and would concentrate on the food for an hour. Well worth it.
author: Jim S.

description:
There's a reason this place has been here for 165 years. Yes, that's right, one hundred and sixty five of 'em. It's not only the oldest restaurant in San Francisco but actually the oldest in California as well. 

If those walls could talk, just imagine! It's a business that has lived through the Great Depression, World War II and not one but TWO major earthquakes. All the while managing to remain a family-owned business. The same family, in fact. For 165 years.

With all the hipsters talking about the latest trendy spots with names like "SPQR" and "State Bird Provisions", I have to smile to myself at Tadich's longevity. Call it a tourist spot if you will, but I challenge these newer places to remain in business for 165 years. It takes a lot to be a small business in San Francisco, or anywhere for that matter. It's really quite an accomplishment to survive one year, let alone sixteen decades. And there is good reason for their success.

I myself am not a tourist. I've lived here 27 years. After discovering it a couple of years ago, Tadich Grill has become a favorite of mine. It's a great, very relaxing place to share dinner with someone special as I've done several times now, and it's also a great place to come alone too. They have a long, wooden, old-fashioned bar that you can just plop yourself down at and order a full meal. The servers are true gentlemen who wear neckties and stand politely with their hands behind their backs, ready to be attentive to your every need but in a manner that sets you at ease. They have sweet little plates of fresh sour dough bread laid out to greet each bar stool, complete with a fresh pat of butter. It's just very inviting and elegant and thoughtfully presented. Tonight, on my way home from a gorgeous walk along the water, I stopped off for some clam chowder and a shrimp cocktail. I was asked questions like, "Would you like both dishes to arrive at once or one after the other? And, if that, which would you prefer arrives first?". Gosh! I felt like a queen - it was truly classy treatment. And perfectly timed. The shrimp cocktail arrived the moment I'd finished the last bite of my soup.

The food is delicious, but the real draw for me is the atmosphere. Save for the computers the bartenders use to ring up the orders, there is not a trace of anything that might give away what year it is inside the restaurant. There is - happily, in my view - no TV, no modern music blaring, nothing that might make you think you've arrived at anything beyond a classic movie scene from the 1940s, 50s or 60s. I love the wooden panels on the walls, the crisp white tablecloths, the feeling of classic permanence. It's as if time really could stand still - in a GOOD way - as if, just when you wished everything didn't have to change at breakneck speed and there could be just one place that remained permanent and still standing with timeless grace, you suddenly found it. Tadich Grill is that place.
author: Heidi-Jane S.

description: Absolutely nothing to complain about. Walked in sat down at the bar ordered food  rib eye and filet, great service, great food.
author: Tracy G.

description: Everything I've ever tried here has been amazing.  Cioppino, desserts, bisque, clam chowder, all of it - great!
author: Annie C.

description:
Why haven't I written about Tadich? Probably because deep down inside that the restaurant is so old that writing about it on the internet seems like blasphemy.  Not that this review will hurt or help it's reputation. Hell it's over 160 years old. I'm pretty sure they don't need press or praise. Not to mention I'm sure they've had a negative customer or two.  

Simply put it's my comfort place. Nothing is ever made bad and everything is good. Food is fresh and a piece of San Francisco history every time I take a bite. The service is consistant and exact every time.  I'm not sure what is cleaner the counter there or the white jackets the servers wear. Arguably this is the best place to dine alone because you are almost sure to make friends if you sit at the bar.  Highlights of the menu are by far the Cioppino, one of my favorite things to eat in the world right now.  The hangtown Fry is delicious but the story that goes with it is even better. Order it and ask about it.   

There might be more amazing places for a foodie to go but this is one of my comfort food places so it's hard for me to give it anything less than a 5.  But like I said they were around before my parents parents parents were born so my review will never be part of it's rich history. I'm just happy I got to be a part of it as a patron.
author: Joco F.

description: Surly waiters?  Never found that to be the case.  My dining experience was true to all recommendations by locals.  Although there are other places that have Chipino on the menu, I was told not to miss the Tadich Grill.  A packed house told me the truth as well as the service and food.  I  can't complain about anything here.
author: Rick S.

description: Awesome! I've been coming here for years . We had Ken serve us again. He is the best!!! Great attitude , friendly, fast , funny and on it. The food is delish and the drinks great. I love how old school it is inside with private booths. This place isn't closing EVER so they don't tolerate rude people or special requests from special people I LOVE that. I've ordered everything on the menu and I'm never disappointed , the scallops are my fave. If you're in SF you gotta check it out!
author: Cecilia D.

description: Decided we had to eat here after hearing my friends enthusiastically discussing it at dinner last week. So glad we did. The food was beyond good. It may be old school but nothing boring about seafood so fresh, such high quality it almost jumps off your plate. The best seafood salad! We had the combination seafood with vegetables salad to start. The menu is HUGE. Portions are too. Then we shared the Calamari steak. The service was delightful. We came early, about 3:30, no wait.
author: solell s.

description: Literally the best ciopinno I have ever eaten. They don't take reservations so get there early. This place is a must in San Francisco .
author: Carmen S.

description:
The five stars are for the service only.  I don't even like seafood, so I can't really weigh in on the seafood bit - though the lobster and shrimp a la manze I think it was, was amazing - but I wanted to write the review for the awesome customer service.  

Saturday night, and at 7pm with no reservations the wait was 1hour and 45min.  The guy taking names seemed a bit overwhelmed.  Not wanting to go elsewhere really we went to Barbacco for appetizers and drinks (also very nice).  After an hour I went to check in at Tadich, and the guy said "Where are you? I will come get you when I need you."  Sure enough, 45 minutes later he walks into Barbacco to tell us our table is ready.  That's about as good customer service gets!  Keep it up!
author: Margaux B.

description:
Disappointed with this highly rated place!  

Knife was dirty. Waiter brought me a new one which looked like the same knife!

Water had some fairy dust in it so I ended up requesting bottled water!

Ordered Shrimp diavlo--it was bland!

Cream with coffee was bad so I had stuff floating in the coffee!

Not the best dinner experience!
author: Ashish G.

description:
Very cool, very old school and great service.

Pricey but yummy

Good seafood spot
author: Beau C.

description: When I first rode into this town about 40 years ago, this was one of the first restaurants I was taken to.  I seem to remember the layout quite differently but it has been 40 years and it makes no difference.  So a friend took me here for lunch this past week and I still love the place.  it's got reliable quality food--nothing too artsy or "fusion."  I got sand dabs last time but I've heard sand dabs are being over fished so decided to not do them this time.  And got a mixed seafood salad since I did have to go back and work, didn't want to get overly full and sleepy (nap time!).  All the staff was delightful and didn't ignore us, even if we weren't drinking like whales.  My friend started with clam chowder which is homemade and looked delicious (they brought me a spoon too but I controlled myself and didn't take a taste because I just knew I'd want a bowl for myself and that along with my salad would have been too much food for me).  And he got the liver which also looked good (he said it was perfect--not too many places do liver anymore).  My salad was wonderful, full of seafood.  And although I ordered the small size, it was still pretty sizeable.  They don't rush you.  People around us seemed really happy about their food and about the service (guy at another tables did some last minute switcheroo and the waiter didn't blind an eye).  It is quite traditional so you know you're not going to walk in expecting cioppino and find that they are now adding wasabi or sriracha sauce or something else).  Nice to have a place to go that you can rely on.  Bartenders seemed to know what they are doing.  I'm glad Tadich Grill has hung around all these years and I hope it stays around forever.  It's a whole lot better service and fare then what you get in Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Kai T.

description: The Hangtown Fry is the most decadent omelette I've ever had, really delicious. Also had a cup of the beef barley soup. Very good place, though very expensive.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
my 411 on tadich

{ FOOD }
* OYSTERS ROCKEFELLER, B - these were good, but not great to me.  i know everyone loves them and i wish i did too, cause who doesn't love good oysters rockefeller?
* CAESAR SALAD, C : average
* LOBSTER THERMIDOR, B : see description for oysters rockefeller
* CIOPPINO, B+ : again, see oysters rockefeller.  i prefer sotto mare
* BROILED SEA BASS, A+ : so much great flavor, will probably order this from now on
* SEAFOOD SAUTE, B : it was a bit bland for my taste, but tons of seafood

{ SERVICE A- }
* considering how busy they are, i've always received good service (ok, except for one time... too bad i didn't get that waiter's name.  note, i've been to tadich over a dozen times, so i'll overlook one bad dinner service)
* host, always pleasant and goes above and beyond (he went next door to grab a party that was waiting for a table, since their bar was full)

{ THINGS TO KNOW }
* they have valet
* expect to wait and if you don't have to, then bonus for you
* wait time varies.  i've gone in on a saturday night at 6 PM expecting to wait, but was seated immediately.  there are definite times where parties of 2 is key and then others were parties of over 4 is money... not sure what the algorithm is... but i'll try to take note moving forward!
* if you order cioppino, it's enough for two especially if you order a side of pasta or rice and share... i haven't done it, but i've seen people do it... and each time i think it's a brilliant idea!  

hope this helped! happy eating.
author: Tina F.

description: Came here a while back with my parents. We went in knowing their plates were pricey, we left saying every penny spent was well worth it. Their seafood is to die for! Large portions will fill any person with a large appetitive with incredibly fresh food.
author: Johana M.

description:
Tadich Grill is your go-to restaurant if you want delicious and fresh seafood! It's known as the  Original "cold day" restaurant and is the oldest restaurant in the U.S...or so I was told. The look of the restaurant is very old school and classic. It's amazing that after 160+ years, that the food is still amazing. All the dishes are simple but are very high quality. 

I ordered the crab cakes, which could be a hit or miss since usually crab cakes are just full of bread crumbs. However, these crab cakes were amazing! They were filled with fresh crab and were not small at all, In fact, I was only able to eat one crab cake before I was full. My co-workers ordered fish, and they all looked amazing. I'll have to try it next time I come here. 

The desserts don't disappoint either. My manager is very picky with his chocolate, and he said that the chocolate mousse was one of the best he had tasted in his life. 

I'd recommend coming here for lunch, but if you do, make sure to get there early otherwise you'll have to wait for a table. Although the place is pretty big, it gets packed fast.
author: Jennifer R.

description: Have come previously for dinners and remember the baked dishes and cioppino.  Came with work team for a birthday lunch at 11:20 a.m.  Seated immediately and fresh bread at the table.  Service was very quick.  I ordered the seafood ravioli with large prawns in a lemon curry sauce.  Entree was excellent, the sauce was great with bread.  The shrimp was cooked to perfect and the ravioli was soft and al dente.  There were four larger raviolis and four large shrimp.  Along with bread it definitely was enough even though it didn't look like it.  Out of there within one hour.
author: Josh L.

description:
Doesn't take reservations. 

Best Cioppino ever. Huge portion. Crab, scallops, fish, shrimp, mussels, clams w/ 2 pieces of garlic bread.

Enough said. So freaking good!
author: Karen H.

description: The  bartender is really good.  My wife got a lemon drop martinee  which was superb,  best ever.  I got Alaskan  salmon  and she got  red snapper with crab.  Both were great.  The waiters could be  bit more personable,  they seem to be very professional and chatting it up not big on the must do list for them. Ok,  I can deal with that. No women waiting in sight,  OK.  The food was good,  that was important. Pricey,  yes. Good,  yes. The lady next to us had a steak which looked great and smelled better. Most people sit at a bar which is fine for a couple. It is worth a visit for sure. Other than not excepting American Express credit we had no problem.
author: Tim M.

description: Hard to be objective when you wait 75 minutes for a table for two. Maybe we had it coming at 8 on a Saturday night? Who can say. Regardless, once we were seated the food was solid, if not exceptional, and the service was exceedingly professional.
author: Ethan P.

description: Good ambience, good service, loved the free bread. Good amount of food, enough for leftovers. Long wait, reservation needed. Good wine
author: Adam C.

description: Tadich Grill is an old school SF joint serving fantastic seafood. It's been around forever and has some of the best seafood in town. The service can vary but it's pretty good in general. The food is always superb and it's a great place to people watch. It's right in the heart of the financial district, right in the hustle and bustle and definitely worth visiting more than once. I've had the cipppino numerous times and it's pretty incredible. The crab is great and they consistently make a great martini. You can easily make a meal out of the appetizers but the entrees are awesome. Old school vibe, consistency, good service and of course no parking. Classic SF.
author: Sam W.

description:
I would give 5 stars, but although it says it's 'wheelchair accessible,' it's not really in that the restrooms are upstairs. I don't use a wheelchair, but stairs are a problem for me. However, when the chef  saw me approaching the stairs, he invited me to use the staff bathroom at the back of the kitchen.  He even summoned a kitchen helper to take me arm so that I would not slip on the floor. The bus boy escorted me out. So it turned out to be a little adventure. 
We went to Tadich's to celebrate our 39th wedding anniversary. We wanted classic San Francisco and we got it!  
We shared a delicious octopus salad to start, followed by the rex sole for my husband and the trout for me.  
Our waiter was attentive and efficient. I liked the straightforward service.
author: Margit C.

description:
"Are you going to look at your menu or text the whole time?" - Tadich Grill server.

Well sir I am Yelping, my bad. But seriously I appreciate him calling me out on this, it is totally lame that I was sitting there on my phone we he was trying to get my drink order. Food was a 3 but service and very clean atmosphere was a 4. No need to get back there anytime soon but I appreciated the server calling me out on my bad behavior.
author: Charlie H.

description: The best restaraunt in San Francisco. In the new city of wealthy tech kids who have no sense of history . The Tadich is an oasis, a time warp of Old San Francisco. Long may it thrive !  The cuisine in awesome and very old school. Here there is no " fusion"... And no trendy. The Tadich has watched trends come and go..it's fresh and honest American food. Put down your phone and breathe in the history, class and good food. Please ... If you know some tech brats ... Don't bring them here
author: Armando Z.

description:
Enjoyed dinner here.  We walked in with a large group and were seated right away, although the waiter told us that most folks in the city were home watching the World Series.

The seafood sauté was tasty and the clam chowder was good.
author: Eric J.

description:
I went here for lunch on a Friday and boy oh boy was it busy. You are "greeted" by a not so friendly, older staff. I guess thats part of their charm? I usually care A LOT about service, and I wasnt too impressed with it here. I was, however, impressed with the food! I had the Halibut and spinach topped with cheese and a cream sauce. It was very tasty, but you do pay for it (24.99). I would easily give this place 5 stars if the service was a little bit better; something to consider :) 
But if you are in the city and want a good, traditional san francisco restaurant, this is the place to go
author: Tyler L.

description: The food was very good. Calamari was excellent. Crab cakes were very good. Ciopino  was very good. Wine prices were very reasonable.
author: Paul I.

description: Fun place but don't over order. Stick with appetizers snd salads. Service is very good.
author: J F.

description:
Unaccommodating, snooty, and demeaning...if you are a vegetarian. 

I went here on a business lunch, and keep in mind, I've been to plenty of business lunches/ dinners to steak houses & seafood restaurants that I've had to get creative with the menu and ask for options. I certainly don't expect a seafood restaurant to have a plethora of options to cater to vegetarian clientele, but I would expect a place like Tadich Grill to be able to accommodate or sub out something.   

On the particular day that I was subjected to this awful experience, I asked our waiter the following:  
- Is it possible to order any one of the four main salads without the fish? DENIED. 
- Is it was possible to order the pasta without the meat? DENIED because the sauce also had meat). 
- Is it possible to just get the pasta w/ butter (which they must have had since there was some sitting on the table next to the bread)? DENIED

Finally, I asked him: What is possible? 

He said he can bring me a vegetable tray & that was all. I kindly asked if they can use the vegetables & plain pasta to make some kind pasta primavera but of course, this request was also DENIED. On top of that, he gave me attitude & made it seem like *I* was the one being difficult.

Worst part...I ended up eating just bread because the vegetable tray was full of frozen vegetables that couldn't even be eaten. The rest of the people at the table were mortified for me, and given that it was a business lunch, I didn't want to cause a commotion, but looking back I wish I had said something. 

I'd give this zero stars if I could. Seriously, DO NOT GO HERE IF YOU ARE A VEGETARIAN.
author: Koushalya S.

description: I can only echo the sentiments of the previous posts. Quality food with minimal frills. Sometimes that's just the way to go! Not gonna be your anniversary dinner (crap I went there for my birthday dinner) but rather a damn good meal if you don't mind waiting in their crazy lines. The host was super nice and the available options close by to have a drink while waiting make the pain very minimal.  Cioppino cioppino ! There I said it too
author: Mark N.

description: I have had two very special occasion dinners here and have never been disappointed. Great atmosphere at the bar while you are waiting for your table. The service is great and the food is even better! I would definitely recommend the Cioppino their signature dish.
author: Lou D.

description: Tadich's grill- the interior is from the Golden Age of San Francisco - but perfectly maintained. I ate there with my parents as a child, and it looks the same. The small dinner salad with crab and shrimp was mouth-watering. Then I had the poached halibut last night, melted in my mouth. I adore restaurants where the wait staff is composed of men who appear to have spent their entire career (+) waiting tables at the restaurant. Such is the case at Tadich's. Excellence all around,
author: Walter C.

description: Went there tonight and found the wait staff behind the bar to be shockingly obnoxious. They treat customers with complete indifference, rushing to get you in and quickly out of the seat. It was an exceptionally unpleasant experience to be so rushed.
author: Dave F.

description: Very few seafood restaurants have a decent grill for the fish. Tadich does a spectacular job of grilling a variety of filets. My favorite is the Petrale Sole. I love the bowl of lemons at the table. At most places, you have to keep asking for lemons - which is a natural for all fish!  Even if the food were lousy (which it isn't!), I'd come here just for the history of the place.
author: Lindy H.

description:
Fabulous meal - expensive, but then its in a tourist area so I guess that is to be expected and the food was worth it - especially for the Bourbon bread pudding at the end!

Our server Charles was great, very attentive, helpful and patient. 

Two things that REALLY marred the experience - first the VERY LOUD head waiter yelling instructions and admonishing the wait staff right over our heads as he stalked by. Very inconsiderate to the customers and so arrogant I felt sorry for the staff.

Then when I got home I found that my purse had gone missing / was stolen.  I don't know if it happened there or afterwards but when I phoned to check if it had been found the same guy - I could recognize his voice after hearing him shout right in my ear as he walked by so many times during the meal - was very dismissive.  He said he would put me on hold while he checked but forgot to put me on hold so I heard him answering the phone to someone else, shouting out a couple of instructions and then come right back to me to say 'no nothing had been found'. Now he may well be multi-tasking and looking through a lost and found book while instructing, shouting and booking because he is so clever, but I very much doubt he is that talented. And then he hung up before I could ask him to take my phone number in case someone else knew anything and to give me the name of a manager I could call in the morning to check and see if it had been found but he was just not aware. Left a bitter taste that dulled my pleasure in the food and took them from a 4 star review down to a 3 star. we go to SF often but I wont waste my time in here again as you can get the same quality with a better attitude in a dozen or more alternative places.
author: Kaz L.

description: Dry....best description I can think of for the food and service. Walking through the door at 3pm, my first meeting with anyone was aloof at best. I'd rate the waiter about the same. For late lunch, I had the halibut. Easily, I can name ten places in SFO (where I've been coming for 20+ years) that the halibut would be much better and almost half the price. The fish here was extremely dry, vegetables outstanding and fries OK. The only reason I came here is this place is a legend and has been in business forever. If I was forced to come back again it would be vegetables only.
author: Gary S.

description:
I went here based on the reviews and recommendations from friends.  The food was great but our waiter Barry is either the son of the owner or the owner has completely lost touch with his staff.  Complete d-bag.

I have never had a $100 + tab just thrown at me.  When we asked what the doorbells were near the table,  he just said "don't worry about it" and walked away.

If this great restaurant wants to last another 100 years,  management needs to review this crucial part of the operation,  or cut Barry out of the family.
author: Elliott S.

description:
You would think that a higher end restaurant would have better customer service, but apparently if you are dressed casually and look very young everyone will treat you like a burden.
 I just hate the snotty "I'm better then you" type of atmosphere that the staff and customers have in these kind of places. 
 I am usually patient and understanding when I go out to eat considering that I am a server and I know what it's like to have to deal with people on the daily but stereotyping me even before I even down and being all rude and rushed with me, makes me feel very uncomfortable even more when I saw the same waiter act completely differently and more warmly towards a table of well dressed customers. So never again.
The food in all honestly wasn't all that great, I could of gotten the same meal at an olive garden or an Apple bees for cheaper and maybe even gotten treated better then I did here. Just remember, if you even want to give this place a chance make sure to dress super nice or else you'll be overlooked and seen as a table that no one wants to take. How saddening.
author: Lizette Z.

description: It may be the oldest restaurant in SF and it shows as do the waiters who don't seem interested in their customers.  The food wasn't horrible, but it certainly wasn't worth the exaggerated high prices or four stars!!
author: Trish K.

description:
Found myself in the financial district the day after Christmas with my family who was visiting from out of town.  I called ahead to see if we could get in on short notice and was pleasantly surprised to hear they don't do reservations and we should come on in.

So I walk my retirement age parents over from Union Square on a cold day in late December - a perfect opportunity to enjoy this establishment and make an impression on some out-of-towners.

Wrong.

Upon arriving the very same person I spoke to about coming right in tells us it will be a 30-35 minute wait - nice!  Apparently this wasn't worthy of mentioning on the phone conversation I had 10 minutes prior when asking if we can get in.

This is classic institutional entitlement of a such a well established restaurant.  (I had this exact same experience with Zuni.)  No doubt the host genuinely felt that a 30-35 minute wait was not worth mentioning, which just goes to show how little he thinks of other people's time.
author: joe b.

description: My review is a little biased, I am vegetarian, so I knew that will be little for me to choose from on the menu, but I didn't expect that a place with 1200+ review and 4 star rating to have terrible vegetarian food. I ordered the paste with marinara sauce. It was just edible, it was more like someone had opened a can of cheap sauce and poured it over the pasta. Never visiting this place again.
author: Gaurav S.

description: First timer. Gave it a try on the recommendation of a friend who had lived in San Francisco about 20 years ago. Ambiance is fantastic. There just aren't many places like this left around the country.  We arrived a little early for lunch and were lucky enough to get a private booth which was really neat. Long counter service on one side of the restaurant is unique.  Waiters in the white coats... the whole thing. Just as other reviews have described. Really a trip in the time machine. Got the house salad with vegetables and the house dressing which was delicious and probably prepared the same way it was 100 years ago. Ordered the haddock which I have to say was just a little overcooked and disappointing. Asked the waiter for recommendations and all three were expensive fish dishes, not going to say he was bumping the check but he didn't recommend the cioppino or the chowder which apparently are house specialties and looked fantastic. Disappointed I didn't check yelp before lunch to help figure out what to order. But overall loved the atmosphere and the food was good if a bit pricey. would try it again.
author: Fred D.

description:
HAIKU REVIEW

Like Tokyo subways,
Always jam-packed at the bar.
Vodka-doused blouses.

Sterling martinis,
Drunk Financial District boys
Getting way hammered.

Sand dabs should be good.
These scales yanked from some deep-freeze,
World-War-Two crypt.

Way too expensive.
Everything is a la carte.
Slow-service ancienne.

People think you're great !?!
Why !?! Food, service both lousy.
Booze-addled reviews !?!
author: Joe J.

description: Tadich Grill, the San Francisco Original. If by original you mean old and cranky, then yes, this place lives up to its "established" status. I don't know what it is with the waiters but they all seemed to be a bit smug. I felt uncomfortable asking questions or asking for an extra plate, etc. Awkwaaard.
author: CHRISTINE N.

description:
One of the first restaurants I ever went to in San Francisco. Their cioppino is the reason I don't order it ANYWHERE ELSE. Yes, it's $31. But do yourself a favor and order it because it will change your life.

Fish, large shrimp, baby shrimp, scallops, mussels, clams, any and all other seafood you can name is in this delicious dish covered in a tomato garlic broth that is perfection.

I don't have anything else to write about because I never order anything else when I come here. Service is usually stellar (although I have had a few exceptions) and I recommend sitting at the bar! It's always a good time and the servers there will joke around slash chat with you.

Opened in 1849 and one of the oldest restaurants in SF so the atmosphere there is awesome too!

FYI: no reservations and they charge $9 split-dish fee.
author: Nicole W.

description:
When you've been open for 160+ years, you get to have whatever odd rules and procedures you want.  That's pretty much a rule of life.  

We put our name on the list as a table of 5, then proceeded to do the wall-stand to wait for a while.  A friend called and said he'd be joining us, so I informed them that we'd be 6 now, and he said it'd be about an hour.  So we resumed waiting.  5 minutes later, they called our name, but our friend wasn't there yet.  They have a VERY strict policy that they do not seat incomplete parties, so I said he was outside, and ran outside to "get" him.  He said that if we weren't back in a couple of minutes, he'd give the table to someone else.  Fair enough, those are the rules.  Something to be aware of.  

Once that was dealt with, the food was absolutely amazing. 4 of the 6 of us got the famous Cioppino, and it was just to die for.  My wife got an entire sea bass, head to tail, and she loved it as well.  The drinks were reasonably priced, and the service was some of the best I've ever had, from start to finish.  

A truly unique experience, and a must-do if you're in the area.  Some of the best, most legendary service and seafood you'll ever get.
author: Scott S.

description: Had a great time for a late/long lunch...John (our waiter) was amazing...you'd be lucky if he waited on you...
author: Meredith S.

description: Came here for lunch and the restaurant looked totally Italian, old but vintage. I ordered the chioppino and oh boy was it yummy. The portion was very generous with various seafood. It had fish, good size prawns, while scallops, etc. Everything was simply fresh and the broth was well seasoned. I also enjoyed the unsweetened ice tea. I couldn't finished it and took it to go;)
author: Nhung T.

description: First off,  my party was shown to a table and 3 were not here yet.  Apparently they assumed I had my whole party because the waiter decided to harass me about how they don't sit parties unless the whole group is present.  I was never told that and I felt like I did something horrible. If they would have just asked or said something I would have waited.  I dont mind waiting it's not a big deal. Not my fault but the waiter apparently felt the need to tell me they Never let people sit down and even called me lucky for being sat.  Like wtf dies he want me to do?  I didn't know,  and as a customer am I supposed to ask?  This place is overpriced for strictly the novelty and tourism.  Will not eat here again.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Cioppino.
Quite simply, one of the best things that I've ever eaten.
author: Bryan H.

description:
This is hands down a must-do dining event on a trip to San Francisco.

What can I add that the others haven't already said countless times?

No pretentiousness.  Quality oozes from everything in the joint.  Mind-bending good seafood.  It's a little pricey, but it's worth every dime.

Do it.
author: Frank F.

description:
The food here is good, the service polite, and the atmosphere classy. This restaurant's been a round for a while and it shows. They know what they're doing. 

I had the sand dabs, and they were plentiful and cooked perfectly moist but not underdone. My companion had the petrale sole, which is a specialty of theirs, and also enjoyed his meal.
author: Amy F.

description: We ordered the oysters on the half shell, ribs, and seafood sauté for lunch. The oysters were not fully shucked and not very flavorful. The ribs didn't have much bbq sauce. The seafood sauté was cooked perfectly. Perfect cook on the scallops and shrimp. 4 stars for the well prepared seafood and great service.
author: Jared Y.

description:
I've had more delicious meals at Tadich than I can count.  A fantastic place where lobster is still served with a side of french fries!  Tadich can get pricey, but is a great place to treat yourself to a meal.  The Cioppino is one of the best in the city, sharing the top spot with Scoma's IMHO.  I'm also a big fan of the grilled Ahi tuna, which is served steak style with romaine hearts.  In the summer it comes with a whole fresh heirloom tomato as garnish!  Just today I had the lobster thermidor.  Wonderful!  I had just read about lobster thermidor on a website about foods that used to be fashionable but have fallen out of favor.  Nuts to that!  Although the menu says it is a half lobster it is clearly more like a whole, which the server admitted!  The meat is cooked in butter, mustard and cheese and baked in the shell.  Perfect.

The servers are friendly and professional.  If you're a party of two or more, expect a wait at peak times.  Tip: singles can bypass the line and almost always find a seat at the bar.  The decor is classic old-money.  Dark wood throughout.  Many older financial district types come here for lunch.  My only complaint is how they expect someone to eat an entire lobster, fries, broccoli, roasted potatoes, a cup of chowder and a hunk of bread all as one entree?  There are worst problems to have :)
author: Seth G.

description: Had the Tadich platter it was great. The atmosphere was communal and from a time past. Definitely worth a visit if your in SF.
author: Mick F.

description: The Tadich Grill is a must do in San Francisco.  It never disappoints.
author: Chris A.

description:
I felt like I was in another time period when I stepped into Tadich. The men behind the bar were all wearing white coats and looked like pharmacists at a drug store soda bar from back in the days. They were very friendly, remembered our names and our faces, and made sure to call us promptly when our table was ready. 

The menu is extensive, so I'd recommend taking a look online at the regular options. There's also a small section for daily specials. Our entire table got the cioppino, and I was told that the garlic bread that we got wasn't the usual garlic bread they serve. It tasted like frozen garlic bread that was baked and served. However, the cioppino made up for everything. It came out nice and hot, and had a heaping hill of seafood. I was definitely able to split up the cioppino into two meals.

GET THERE EARLY! The line piles up fast! We went at 11:30 and there was a 10-15 minute wait, but people that walked in a few minutes after us had a 30-45 minute wait already.

Will be back again! :)
author: Judy L.

description: Awesome experience here! The food was wonderful...I had the scallop sauté. The scallops were cooked perfectly and were super tender. The sauce with the mushrooms was perfect with it. My boyfriend had the Chilean sea bass and it was also cooked to perfection. Neither of us are fish eaters but it was not fishy at all. You can tell all of the food and seafood is fresh. The service was great. Our server was very attentive and very helpful when we asked for recommendations of other places to try. It was pricey ($100 for 2 of us...2 meals and 2 alcoholic bevs), but it was worth it.
author: Vanessa B.

description: When I'm in town I try to make it to this place.   The corned beef brisket with cabbage is absolutely delicious.   Can't say enough about it.   But my favorite has to be the red clam chowder.
author: Peter G.

description: Good but I think a bit to hyped to be honest. There are many more inexpensive places that r just as good or better.
author: Kavon M.

description: This is a SF classic. Weird spot, popped in with my Mom because a friend from PANAMA had recommended we come here. So thrilled we followed his advice. Go to the bar, order yourself a nice dirty martini and go from there!
author: Carolina Z.

description:
We heard about the history of this place and were very excited to try it out. The Cioppini did not let us down however the waiter and redfish with sautéed crab truly deserve the 2 star rating. 
The problem is: When you are walking away as I am trying to tell you my order, you will probably get it wrong. That is just what happened. When they brought our food to the bar my Redfish was covered in little baby shrimp. I finally got our waiter's attention to tell him that in fact the shrimp will make me sick and that I had ordered Lump Crabmeat topping. When he brought my "new plate" back to me, further inspection revealed that they had only scraped off the shrimp and sauce and replaced it with the watery lump crab sauté. Very bland, very disappointing...and there was just enough shrimp left on my plate to make me sick that night. 
We won't be back just for principle.
author: Charlie B.

description: I found the food to be good but not as good as everyone says.  That was a distant backseat to the rudeness of the staff.  Man taking the order up front was very rude and dismissive, and another guy was the same way.   He was mocking my friends foreign sounding name and apparently thought that was funny.  I won't be coming back, but I don't recall any decent place I've ever been to having such rude and confrontational people at the front.
author: Samhain M.

description:
I never write reviews on yelp but the meal I just had was SO GOOD I had to! This review is solely on the sautéed crab with rice and veggies. The garlic sauce that the crab sits in is ridiculously good. The crab comes De - shelled and there are about 10-15 pieces of crab chunks. The veggies included mushrooms, diced tomatoes, cute little carrots and broccolini. I hate mushrooms but that sauce made them so delicious I couldn't avoid them. This place is a little pricey depending on what you get but it's worth it! 

This was my first time to this place. I would come back for sure.
author: tiffany h.

description:
This is one of the better known restaurants in the financial district. It tends to attract a crowd, so if you hate people or are breaking out in sores, might not be the spot for you...

I thought the food was good, but not overly memorable. The service was quite good, kind of has that old school attentive waiter feel.

But the fact that I am struggling to write this review when I am rarely at a loss for words is probably the best indication of all.
author: Scott G.

description: Good wine and great seafood. Servers are all a little older which is good but they do lack enthusiasm. Will definitely be back to try more items on the menu. The Ciopinno is awesome.
author: Jeshua J.

description:
A friend and I came here after work on a Friday night and there was already a crowd waiting for tables. So we put our names down on the wait-list but attempted to swoop in on any available seats at the bar table. As luck would have it, we only needed to wait 5 minutes when someone got up in front of us. 

There is definitely an "old-fashioned" feel to the place that one can probably assume that every corner of the restaurant may have some kind of history behind it. 

I was able to have a taste of their clam chowder which was pretty rich and chunky. For my meal I ordered the Deviled Dungeness Crab Casserole. I can understand why it was called "deviled" as there was a distinctive mustard taste. Overall the dish was hearty and they definitely did not skimp on the crab. I had big chunky pieces of crab with each bite! But unfortunately it seemed to get the best of me and I gave up with about 1/4 left in my dish. Boo.

Overall thoughts: They don't skimp on the portions and their crab tasted really fresh. I would return,  but would probably order something else.
author: Stephanie K.

description: I had the Sand Dabs, but the star of the show here is the Cioppino.  They load the bowl with fresh seafood (crab, different types of shrimp, mussels, clams, scallops and fish).  Although they all cook at different rates, each was cooked perfectly.  The broth is amazing!  It's a gathering of different flavors from the ocean complimented with a splash of white wine, garlic and tomatoes.  It is served with two slices of garlic bread to soak up all the liquid goodness.  By far the best cioppino I've had.  I'll definitely be back to introduce friends and family to this wonderful dish.
author: Triple T.

description: I only gave Tadich 4 stars because of one mean guy behind the bar who was obviously having a bad day, but other than that, FOOD WAS AWESOME!!  I had the Ahi Tuna came with a Salad and it was DELICIOUS!  I did wake up the next morning with a sore throat from yelling, its very loud in the restaurant, but that's because its a GREAT place to eat!.
author: Jimmie S.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in SF...that is, IF I can get someone else to pay for my lunch! It's pricier than I ever want to pay, but if work contact takes me out to lunch or my family comes into town, I will campaign hard for the Tadich Grill. It's SO good.

All the tables along the restaurant perimeter are enclosed by old-school wooden walls that give you privacy even though the restaurant is always packed. The tables along the inside rim are not enclosed, but if you come with more than two people you have a decent chance of being seated in a private area.

As for the food: They give you a large chunk of bread when you sit down that is quite delicious. I can't speak for their food other than the cioppino because it's all I ever order. It is seriously TO DIE FOR. It's huge, with tons of seafood, just the way it should be. The Tadich Grill may be expensive, but they aren't skimpy. I always end up taking home about half the cioppino. Best leftovers ever :-)
author: Talia G.

description:
The standard for which all others are measured...  

This place is fantastic.  Service is great, value is good, execution is flawless.  There's a reason why tourists and locals alike have been doing here for 150 years.
author: David H.

description:
Con:  The wait took forever even with a reservation on a Saturday night.  But the experience was totally worth the wait!

PRO: Everything!

The food was awesome - bread, chowder, and cioppino with beer.  Need I say more?  We also ordered scrod (not on the menu) but was delish!  Although the food and the ambience is top notch, the highlight of the evening for me was our server, Alvin!  He was funny and entertaining in a sarcastic way and had us laughing the whole night.
   
   Us:  What do u recommend for dessert?
   Server: U do know that we are a seafood restaurant, right?

WARNING:  If you get an Asian server, you better put your phone away.  He called me out a few times (while checking-in on FB and reading other YELP reviews of this place).  

I'm glad that my sister lives in the area coz I'll make sure to come back to this restaurant the next time I visit.
author: Justine B.

description: Tried the lobster pot pie. Super yummy!!! It was rich and full of lobster pieces. Strong flavor left me wanting more. Had a nice cozy experience with a group of 5 people. The sourdough was delicious too.
author: Flo O.

description: When you come here find Pete. He works at the bar and is one of the most delightful people to have serving you drinks and conversation.  However the food,  absolutely phenomenal.  This place rocks and all those bad reviews about "bad service", those people must be social inept. Defiantly a must when you come top SF.
author: Richard S.

description:
Came here around 2PM on a Saturday, and although the place was packed, since it was just 2 of us we were seated immediately. 

We told our waiter that it was our first time, and asked what he suggested. He said "Cioppino" then he walked away from us. Which became a common theme. You couldn't ask him more than 1 question at a time, without him running away. I understand they want to have a quick turn around, but c'mon. Later when a group of 8 was seated behind us, he spent 10 minutes going over the menu with them.... A good waiter knows tips come from big groups and small groups, so treat them equally. 

Besides that, the Cioppino was good, and easily enough for two, witih a small appetizer. It was very spicy, and very hot (temparture wise.)  The seafood seemed very fresh. You get 2 of of everything. 2 shrimps, 2 clams, 2 mussels, 2 scallops, and random fish. The reason it's enough for two people, is that the sauce is so good, you'll want to dip plenty of bread in it.... I'd definitely go back for that.

The calamari came out smokin hot, and was really good for the first few bites. They really give you a generous portion, but the lack of seasoning gets very bland, fast. 

The Dungeoness Crab Legs appetizer, although small, was fresh and good. 

If the waiter was friendlier, we'd have enjoyed it a bit more.
author: Danny N.

description:
I have been coming to Tadich Grill for years, and it is always the same, always incredible. The food is  superb, the service is impeccable (Mostly) and the ambiance and experience is just amazing. 
They do not take reservations, so get there well before you want to eat.
PETER is the best bartender in San Francisco, say hello to him, He's the tall slender handsome gentleman behind the bar.
It is the oldest restaurant in San Francisco tracing back to 1849! Which makes it older than the State of CA itself. Its right on the foot of California street ad watching the Cable Cars roll past in amazing. Cioppino was invented there, and is still the hallmark item on its menu.
They have a charbroiled Calf's Liver Steak with Grilled Onions and Bacon, which is a very niche item that is definitely an acquired taste, but it is probably my favorite meal ever so, I always get it.
But there are many fresh seafood specials to choose from. Their bread is incredible and the walls have nothing on them, the people and their conversations make it richly decorated despite being blank of any art. 
Head in there expecting a good meal and be willing to wait at the bar while they get you a table.
author: Jack W.

description: Great food. Great atmosphere. Our server, David, was especially attentive and accomodating. Overall, a fantastic experience.
author: Debbie S.

description: This is the place if you want great food with a classic dining experience. Classic old interior and the waiters in white jackets.
author: D H.

description: Classic SF restaurant!  Great Cioppino and Osso Bucco!  Great bar and just a fantastic dining experience.  30 years of great meals....haven't a clue about the negative comments I see on yelp.
author: Robert C.

description: This was introduced by a good friend of mine.  He mentioned they had the best clam chowder in town.  He was right!  I had the seafood saute with their red wine.  The sauce was simple yet flavorful.  One of the best seafood dishes I've had...  I also couldnt resist a few bites of their bourbon pudding cake with caramel drizzled over the top!
author: Edelith O.

description:
Tadich Grill, "The Original "Cold Day Restaurant", dates all the way back to the days of the Gold Rush in 1849 where it got its start as a coffee tent.  It would later be known as the Cold Day Restaurant because of an unpopular politician's fondness for the joint.

My adventure at Tadich began on a gorgeous Indian Summerish October afternoon after a morning spent soaking in the beauty and sunshine of Golden Gate Park.  I had some time to enjoy a long lunch before heading to the airport to catch my flight.  After striking up a conversation with some knowledgeable locals, I grabbed the boy toy by the hand and skip raced all the way there.  We eagerly plopped down at the first available seats at the long, but packed bar & ordered up our 1st (of 3) rounds of bloody marys, which were mmmm-tastic! I might have even had a 4th.

Overwhelmed by page after page of titillating offerings, I looked around to see what other patrons had requested.  That's when I spotted the fellow 3 seats down enjoying a spellbinding bowl of seafood.  I urgently grabbed the barmaid, "What is that??" To which she replied, Cioppino. SOLD, I'll take it!  

My first bowl of Cioppino ever, but certainly not my last.  A new love affair had just started on that afternoon at Tadich Grill.  It was so perfectly prepared with a nice balance of tomato/white wine flavors and generous mixture of clams, mussels, shrimp, scallops, crab, and fish, completed with 2 buttery, toasty pieces of bread.  I suppose the barmaid was quite entertained at watching me, clearly a cioppino virgin, delighting in my lustful, passionate foray of this dish because she decided to tell the original fellow about me.  I can only imagine that they were having a grand time watching me because while I was having a true sexual food experience in my head, I was not remotely sexy in my plastic seafood bib and sauce drenched paws.

As I'm licking the final soupy goodness from my fingers and rocking back with a goofy grin and full on after sex glow the barmaid comes over in a giggle frenzy.  To that I can only smile declare that I'm not even sorry, not even a little bit.  I can only attest my new found love for cioppino.  Still giggling, she informed me that my cioppino-gasm was so entertaining that the original fellow 3 seats down had picked up my entire tab & ordered a dessert for me before he left because my performance had made his day.  Awe shucks, me??  Te-hehe, I'm blushing a little, but still NOT sorry.
author: Steph P.

description: Tadich Grill has become my new favorite restaurant. They have the BEST seafood cioppino & tiramisu ever. We had the Tadich sampler which has the pickled herring, anchovies & raw oysters...all very good. My bf had the Chilean sea bass which he liked very much. We're definitely coming back to try other things on the menu but will be ordering the cioppino and tiramisu again. Also, their complimentary sourdough bread was addicting! :)
author: Mimi C.

description: Tadich is a great place to get a high quality, but casual meal especially if you are looking for fresh seafood. The menu is lengthy with literally dozens of seafood options. I had the sautéed scallops, which were delicious. My only issue with them was they out a bit too much sauce on them (great seafood doesn't need to be smothered). Portions were large (5 large scallops in the entree) so sharing is definitely an option. The service was great as always - nothing fancy, but attentive and prompt. Definitely recommend as a solid mid-priced casual option in the Financial District.
author: Ryan L.

description:
What a cool restaurant in the heart of San Francisco. This place has style and class and is all about San Fran. 

The bar, the MASSIVE bar, goes from one end of the restaurant to the other. You can eat at it, or drink at it, or both. Along the long wall is people waiting for a table in the crowded restaurant.

The tables themselves are each divided into their own little walled-off sections. After a quick 20-25 minute wait and a drink the six of us were seated and the waiter brought some bread and took our drink order (a bottle of Cali pinot). 

The waiters are all dressed awesomely. They have these cool white coats on and they're running all over the restaurant. Our guy was great, told us about the specials and gave us some good recommendations that he himself enjoyed. 

I had a cup of the Boston Chowder ("chowda") to start. It was really good. Tons of clam and didn't really need much but a little extra pepper. 

For dinner, I had the cioppino - a San Fran favorite. What a great dish. It came with some garlic bread, had a ton of shrimp, clams, mussels, crab and scallops. It had great flavor and really was a lot of food.

This is going on my list of places to revisit when I come to SF.
author: Jimmy M.

description: Sat at the large bar here and enjoyed the friendly and theatrical service from the bartenders in classic white jackets. The food was classically good. enjoyed oysters on the halfshell and the swordfish. Great martinis and atmosphere. Note that they do not take reservations and a line forms quickly.
author: Allison N.

description:
Tadich is one of my favorite places to eat in the city, but it's not without its issues.

But let's start with the good stuff. They can make a bloody mary, and a martini, to die for. Their bartenders are classy and their servers generally no-nonsense. They also grill, broil or saute simple fish with a nice heaping of steamed veggies--usually broccoli. In a city that feels like it needs to reinvent itself all the time, this is a very good thing.

But as classy as their bartenders can be, they can also be gruff to the point of annoying. And your no-nonsense waiters will sometimes try to push you out the door. And yes, this place is definitely overpriced.

But these are small issues. Go visit this place if you're a seafood or steak fan.
author: Paul C.

description:
Boston Clam Chowder real good!
Staff entertaining characters
Atmosphere old school cafe feel
Side of Ravioli, so much food! It felt like a full order! Real good and meaty.
Sourdough Bread amazing
author: Karen T.

description: Started off great by getting seated within moments of arriving.  But downhill from there.  The waiter gave off the impression that he wanted a different group to serve.  The dinner continued the downhill slide.  The fried sea food was cooked past death.  The chowder was over peppered.  Didn't bother with desert.  Certainly did not impress our guests from Montreal.
author: Ross T.

description:
First off, kudos for surviving a fire on Tuesday and quickly re-opening on Wednesday.  Second, man, you are PACKED on a Thursday at noon.

This is definitely not a place you want to go if you want a quick lunch.  Or even a power hour lunch.  After a brief (15 minute) wait, we were whisked into our booth.  It felt like time has stopped for us just to enjoy our lunch.

Our server was extremely friendly and knowledgeable; didn't hurt that he called us his "lovely ladies" the entire time, either.

We had the seared ahi tuna (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WxxE5kE8omgQhJE8sWIvmA?select=H0m02XIKNdmo7znr1jQvjA), breaded petrale sole (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WxxE5kE8omgQhJE8sWIvmA?select=ICLO2qTq4ajEdsG7hewbbw), and the sand dabs (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WxxE5kE8omgQhJE8sWIvmA?select=mpIN0ws9RDug7Nkeg23Inw).

Don't be fooled by a seemingly small amount of food.  I am stuffed to the brim, and ready for a nap.

Almost halfway through that 7x7 list...
author: Jenny L.

description:
I was craving a hamburger but was not on the menu.  My guy ordered a grilled ground sirloin patty topped with grilled caramelized onions & side of large wedge fries, it darn tasted like a hamburger without bun and fixings and the closest thing to what I wanted, so I got a few bites off his plate, it was too large of a portion for me.  I opted for the Caesar salad (dressing was delish), the small seemed huge for me and I was full at end of meal, my BF finished it off, and they have a large salad as well as a small.

The place was  a buzzing- pretty busy on a Saturday mid-afternoon.  Sit at the counter, it's kinda fun watching the staff do their thing.  Overall service and food were pretty good.
author: Sisi D.

description:
I loved everything about this restaurant &  bar... from the charming bartenders &  waiters buzzing around in their white jackets to the lovely old-world surroundings...so much character!  My visit here with my husband & friends was my first time witnessing first class, highly skilled servers. Plus the dish I ordered was the best I had ever had... Cioppino. 
Anyway,  if you are not (as I am not) accustomed to dining with the hoy paloy &  wish to treat yourself or someone close to you, Tadich will provide a fabulous evening to remember.
author: Marneaux W.

description:
Tadich Grill, you fabulous classic. You're the original cold day restaurant because you were formerly named the Cold Day Restaurant. You claim to be the oldest restaurant in California and you might as well be - you pretty much deserve it.

Tadich Grill is the place to go if you are craving some old men wearing lab coats in your life. Everyone's sassy grandfather works here and they nail the service aspect with plenty of banter and a good old fashioned scolding if you get out of line.

The cioppino is a fabulous production for tourists who've never had it. The red clam chowder is my favorite recurring dish, and you can get it (with bread) to go on days when you just can't afford to wait.

I'll also put in a good word for the bar - which serves only very classic martinis, but is a fantastic old-timey place to sit and reflect on the day that's passed (whether your day at work or your friends' day touring the city). To avoid the wait, go earlier in the week or of course earlier in the day. 

If you are a tourist and you can only go to one restaurant, this is a great contender.
author: Megan G.

description:
I hadn't been here for years, but decided to have dinner there due to a hankering for seafood.  I'm so happy I did.  This is also a place that I often recommend to out of towners when they ask me for a seafood restaurant recommendation and want an SF experience.  

We arrived a bit after 7 pm on a Saturday and didn't have to wait for a table because there were seats open at the counter.   Butter and water were waiting for us and the sourdough bread appeared as soon as we sat down.  They have an extensive menu so it took some time to figure out what I wanted to order.  Too many options...but here it's a good thing.   I knew the portions were on the generous side (ha!) so I was trying not to order too much food.  I ended up ordering the crab cake to share and the cioppino for the entree.  My companion ordered the sea bass, which came with veggies and rice.  

Can we talk about that crab cake?  It was 3 to 4 inches in diameter, one inch+ high and contained NO fillers - no breadcrumbs, eggs, crackers, mayo or any other unnecessary stuff.  Just the crab, formed into a disk and pan fried.  I have never seen a crab cake with so much crab - sweet and delicate.  It came with two sauces and was deee-licious and light.  The perfect start to the meal.  

The cioppino contained a decent portion of clams, shrimp, fish, scallops and crab meat (didn't need to get my hands all messy) and came with two thick slices of garlic bread.  If you order this, you must dip that bread into the cioppino to sop up that broth.  The combination is so good!  The seabass was a larger portion than I usually see and  was well cooked.  They provide a VERY generous pour on their wine.  Goodness!  The same appears to apply to the cocktails as well.  

Yes, the prices are a bit on the high side, but I find that the portions and quality of the food justify it.  Some of the waiters are a bit on the crusty side, but I find that it just adds to the overall ambiance and charm.  All of our servers were great.  Beware of the minimum charge per person and the charge applied to split entrees - both are pretty high.  I will continue to recommend this restaurant to locals and out of towners.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Seafood Sautee - The seafood was good and delicious but the rice was not really what I craved, I'm not sure what kind of rice was used, but it reminded me of cafeteria rice... The vegetable was broccoli which was good in my opinion. 

My water glass was always full which was wonderful. I will give the cioppino a try next time.
author: Sway M.

description:
I was running late for a very important business meeting, due to Delta Airlines planes not working properly from LAX to SFO on August 19th, 2011. I was two hours late for my meeting. My business partners, were able to meet with our Adviser's at Tadich Grill. 

Tadich Grill is a first come serve basis and the group had gotten there. They would NOT allow me to sit in with my group. My party had already spent $500.00 on drinks and dinner! They took my luggage and said, we had to go since I was there at the start of dinner, really? Is this how you treat your customers?

 I will never recommend a business meeting or social meeting there again. Dear owner, change out your Hostess (Male) with someone who understand the players he just kicked out of your establishment.

 I bet you did not know that you kicked out the, recently former, CIO of Yahoo, did you? I bet you did not know that you kick out www.toprecruiter.tv/kimpope, either? I bet you did not that you kick out two of the biggest founders from a nonprofit. 

I hope you that next time a party comes in, you think about who could these people be and maybe start taking reservations. 

Not happy and won't be back.
author: Kim P.

description:
Friends took us here for dinner last night.  Since there are no reservations accepted we waited about 15 minutes for a table in this extremely tiny and crowded restaurant.  I found this very tedious.  

We were finally seated, and our friend who had raved about this classic "steak house" ordered a big NY steak.  In my opinion the menu was mainly seafood.  We had dungeness crab leg cocktail, caesar salad, then we shared seafood cannelloni and their famous cioppino.  

Everything was tasty, but certainly not gourmet quality.  As we have been to some simply phenomenal seafood houses, I can only rate Tadich 3 stars.  It is historic, the food good, our waiter a prince, but do not expect anything more than a nice meal in very cramped quarters.
author: Jess R.

description: Classic American establishment with bountiful portions.  Cocktail sauce is a little sweet for my liking.  Moderately delicious.
author: Matthew P.

description:
The Tadich is an experience worth going for and worth paying for. Is the food anything novel or something you can't get anywhere else? No. But it is very good, the seafood is fresh and the service is outstanding. The ambience and the story behind the 130 years+ restaurant is worth the read on the menu.
The Boston Clam chowder and the Tadich seafood platter - Highly recommend.
The Pino Grigio by the glass, recommended by the waiter - perfect accompaniment to the dinner.
Great place. Definitely recommend and would go back.
author: Judi H.

description:
It's always nice to experience a new city through the eyes of a local.  I made my first trip out to San Francisco last week and had the privilege of spending a few days with a good friend who went out of her way to show me a great time.  

Dinner at Tadich Grill definitely gave me a taste of local flavor!  It was here that I had my first ever bite of fresh Dungeness crab and sampled a fish I had never even heard of before.  The fish itself was mild and flaky just as I like it, and the white wine butter sauce which accompanied it...magnificent! 

Our server, Paschal, was clearly at the top of his game.  I noticed that most if not all of the servers here have made a career out of waiting tables.  These men are professional and take their jobs very seriously - and they do so with class.  

Having been around for over 150 years, Tadich Grill has reached iconic status.  They don't take reservations, so if you show up on a busy night (which I assume is every night!) be prepared to wait for a table or try to snag a seat at the bar if you can find one.

Oh - I completely forgot to ask Paschal while I was there, so for any of you San Franciscans who know....what in the world are "sand dabs" ??
author: Allison F.

description: We walked in at 7:45 Saturday night (don't take reservations).  Were told 1 1/2 hour wait but had option to  stand in line on the wall behind people who were eating at the bar because that was first come first serve. We stood behind people for 2 minutes, they got up, we asked if the others standing wanted to sit but they wanted a table, we sat. Bartenders are the servers. Warm bread/butter arrived, our calamari appetizer was great, fish dishes and beer were fantastic.  Food came out fast. Great service. Would have dinner there again. The rush slowed down about 9:00 pm. Ate and got up right away as others were waiting for our spot.
author: Kay L.

description: This place is top notch.  Go early because it gets busy after 6pm.  The Martinis are great and food was excellent.
author: Ryan B.

description: Walked over Friday night at the recommendation of the hotel clerk.  Had a drink at the bar while we waited for our table, chatting with the very friendly bartender.  Forgot my glasses so the waiter rounded up a pair fir me.  Had the Chilean sea bass; hubby had the filet mignon.  Everything was perfect.
author: Lizlynne H.

description:
Nice atmosphere. Very cool old school vibe with dark wood and white counters/floors. Kinda stodgy and mostly suits, but it was lunch time. They were very busy, but we only waited for a few minutes.
 Had to try the Cioppinio since it's supposed the the house specialty, and it was very nice.  In watching all the food walk by, everything looked appealing. (maybe I was just super hungry) Our service was pleasant and the food was fast. 
Three of us ate lunch and for around $100 plus tip, which I don't think is cheap, but we all ordered seafood, so not unreasonable. Two of us also had glasses of wine. So, actually not bad for a business lunch. I am certain it is a nice place to impress clients and probably a nice quiet date night place.
author: Rachel D.

description:
went for the nostalgia. 
Waiters nice. Food just a little above avg.
Overpriced for what you get but worth just one visit for the old school exp.
Parking hard to find, must use pay parking in the afternoon.
author: The G.

description:
Our third visit in as many years to the Tadich Grill was a huge disappointment. The fist two visits were both good in service and food quality.

Took friends there for a celebration dinner, was surprised to be seated on a Saturday night at 7pm within a few minutes of putting our names in.  As soon as we were handed menus we were quickly asked if we had decided on dinner.  No, we thought we'd have a cocktail first.  One in our party asked what the mixed vegetables were, the waiter looked at someone who had the mixed vegetables at the next table and announced broccoli. Ok, mixed broccoli.

We ordered and three of the four meals arrived promptly.  The 4th, which was a cold plate order arrived about 10 minutes later.  No apologies.  

I ordered the cioppino and it was a salty mess.   The waiter, in an obvious hurry to bring us a bill asked if there was anything else we wanted.  Dessert?  Ok, brought the menu.  We ordered the bourbon bread pudding and coffee.  Pretty good bread pudding but as we were sipping coffee the waiter returned with a bill and said they had a long line and he needed to turn the table over.  Nice.

Mediocre food and fabulously bad service rolled into one.
author: Debra H.

description:
A first-class experience.  

My Lady and I dropped in for dinner, waiting for a table 20 minutes when the restaurant next door had a 1-hour wait.  We had some chardonnay at the bar (2 glasses for $16 + tip), and held pleasant conversation with the other customers.  Before we were ready, our table was.  

The waiter gave us a list of what was sold out, and I asked him what the chefs were having fun preparing tonight.  That was an easy question to answer, as the house special was cioppino.  I listened to his description dispassionately, but when he said I wouldn't have to pick the crab out of its shell I was sold.  

Two cioppinos and 4 glasses of Wente chardonnay for $83 + tip.  That works for me!  The cioppino had large ocean scallops, shrimp, prawns, whitefish of several varieties, and plenty of crab meat, in a light tomato stew, not too heavy on the garlic.  In fact, My Lady said it was the best cioppino she had ever had in her life.  

Considering Tadich has been around longer than any of our lives, that is a pretty strong endorsement!
author: David D.

description: We were there a few months ago.  Agree with another yelper that the usually fail proof cioppino was underwhelming.  Needs a lot more kick and shellfish flavor.  The garlic bread was so soaked and drenched in butter it was not edible.  Get queezy thinking about that.  Great atmosphere though and I will order something different than their world famous cioppino next time. Until then, I can only review the seafood chowder that I have ordered every few years.
author: Hmmmmm O.

description: A classic restaurant and outstanding seafood and fish selection. Pretty much anything you can think of cooked however you like. A little on the pricey side for what you get (not fancy food). Waiters are all old and a little cranky at times. Go early for lunch. Tough to get a spot.
author: W P.

description:
Tadich Grill is one of the oldest restaurants in the city and is a must see if you have never been there.  They are known for their sand dabs which are absolutely D-Lish!  The portions are HUGE and they are generous when it comes to garlic which in my book makes them extra special!
