Service is quick and friendly.  Bartenders are really nice and pour a good drink.  

I mean seriously... what's not to like!
author: Kylie L.

description:
We went there because it was very close to the hotel we were staying in, in SF.

The food was alright - fish, steamed broccoli, potatoes, etc. No big whoop, the old-world steakhouse kind of menu. Not bad but very much forgettable.

Then, one of our little ones who was sitting on my lap pointed to the floor and said "Buh".

A bug it was, at least a 1" inch long cockroach with his other 5 (five) friends under and around our table. I almost upchucked what I ate and, yes, stopped eating at that point.

The old timer waiter didn't seem the least surprised. He blurted out "I'm sorry" and walked away.

If the Ohio University study estimated that we all eat about 1 to 2 lbs of insect parts and "filth" each year (ketchup, chocolate, peanut butter, popcorn, etc.), without knowing it, you can bet that if you dine at Tadich Grill your numbers are waaay better than that.

If it looks like the floor is moving or you get a thrill up your leg at Tadich Grill, look closer. They may be a little hard to see against the dark floor, but you can bet your ass they are either Blattella germanicas or Periplaneta Americanas.

Bon Appetit!
author: Tinsel D.

description:
I heard that Tadich Grill was the oldest restaurant in California, so I had to try it. The place is pretty cool inside...old school. It's in the heart of the financial district....and the prices reflect it! Ouch!!

I had the beef barley soup (excellent!) and the blackened catfish (okay). I also got a lemonade that was pretty small (maybe 10 ounces with ice) and no free refills.

Except for the beef barley soup, I was disappointed in my visit to Tadich Grill. If you plan to go there, check out the menu online first so you don't get sticker shock!  :)

Overall grade:  C+
author: Shannon L.

description:
Ok, I really had my prejudices against this place beforehand. I mean, it's "famous", right?  It's the place to go for "old-school" San Francisco, and all that. Gotta be a real tourist trap, yeah?

Holy crap, was I surprised.

On his recommendation, a coworker and myself wandered in just before the dinner rush, and promptly grabbed two seats at the long wooden bar. I ordered up a mineral water and a Manhattan, both of which were delivered promptly. The drink was an exercise in perfection - I'm a fan of the classic cocktails, and Tadich Grill just bloody nailed it.  My Manhattan was a pitch-perfect proportion of whiskey, bitters, and vermouth served chilled, but not ice cold.  A better cocktail I've not had in quite a while.  As a bonus, it was barely over $7, which is a relative bargain for a mixed drink in this city.

I had a simple green salad tossed with oil and vinegar and a spot of ground black pepper to accompany my entree.  It was all it needed to be - basic, fresh, light, and green. For an entree, I ordered a whole grilled Mediterranean sea bass, which turned up cooked to perfection.  Crispy on the outside, light, tender and flaky on the inside.  I could have eaten two had I wanted to be a glutton.  Dressed with a little olive oil and lemon, this was an outstanding fish. The quarter-round of crusty sourdough bread Tadich provides was put to good use mopping up the plate afterward.  Bless them for serving Brussels sprouts as a side veg, too.  I love the things, though most people unfairly seem to dislike them with a passion.

My desert was a real classic - almost a relic, really - bourbon bread pudding, which was chock full of nuts, berries, raisins, and apples covered in a surprisingly not-cloying bourbon caramel sauce.  I had to stop halfway on this, and I'm not a guy who blithely discards desert.  It's really rich stuff, but it went a treat with a cup of coffee to end the meal.

For those that are used to the new school of restaurant service that includes an overly chipper server chirping the specials of the day at you after introducing themselves and kneeling down at table level to talk, I'm sure that the Tadich staff might seem a little stern.  They're not, though.  They're efficient, professional, and no-nonsense, and they're really good at keeping things moving in a busy place while not making you feel rushed.  And you know, I prefer it that way.

So, if you're visiting San Francisco, just go here.  It's one of those rare places that actually lives up to its reputation.  I'd go back in a heartbeat, even if work wasn't footing the bill.
author: Rob N.

description:
What a hidden gem. Did you know that Tadich Grill is California's oldest restaurant? That fun fact alone gives this place another star. But no seriously, this place is delicious!

ATMOSPHERE
You can easily miss this place so look out for the sign. The restaurant itself isn't too big, nor is it very spacious, but it has a nice cozy feel to it-- the owners did a good job maintaining the authenticity of the restaurant. It definitely felt like I had gone back to the early 1900s.

There were many seating options, but my favorite was probably the isolated boxcar-ish booths along the left side of the restaurant. You can also opt to eat at a regular table or at the bar.

Our waiter was very attentive and he was a sweet old man who definitely took pride in his work.

FOOD
1) White Clam Chowder- OH. MY. GOD. This was THE best clam chowder I've EVER had (yes, better than the street vendors on Fisherman's Wharf). It was very hearty yet light and everything in the chowder was cut into small pieces, so every bite was filled with yummy seafood goodness! 

2) Seafood Saute- absolutely phenomenal. It came with Dungeness crab legs (meat only), giant prawns, and scallops, paired with string beans, wild rice, carrots, and a rich white wine cream sauce. The seafood was SO fresh and tender-- even the string beans were savory!  The portions were generous, but I cleaned off the ENTIRE plate.

This is one of my favorite seafood joints (sorry vegetarians, you're out of luck here) in San Francisco; the food speaks for itself. Unfortunately it's pretty pricy, so I would save this place for a special occasion. I guarantee you won't be disappointed!

Note: They DON'T take reservations, so expect to wait at least 20 minutes for a seat.
author: Krystie M.

description: I had the Chilean Sea Bass for lunch and it was great. The service on the other hand left something to be desired.  We had a party of 7 and needed to split the bill accordingly.  Our server was very impatient with us and quite rude actually.  Not what I expected for an "institution" like this.
author: Jackie J.

description: An absolute must-stop for any tourist in San Fran! The Cioppino is amazing, and this place will be #1 on my list any time I'm in the bay area. No reservations needed, and the wait isn't bad.
author: Eric R.

description:
this place.... is awesome!!! one of the better, if not best seafood joints in san francisco.  i'll come here occasionally during lunch and just get a bowl of clam chowder with some sour dough bread on the side. yea you bay about $12 after tax for a bowl of chowder, but it's a lot!!! 

i've got the tendency to over order when i come here. below is a list of TOO MUCH FOOD FOR 5 PEOPLE:

1 bowl clam chowder
3 cups clam chowder
1 order of calamari (appetizer portion)
1 order sand dabs 
3 orders crabs and prawns a la monza

why does that  sound too much? oh yea.. sometimes they make you wait and when you finally sit down, they put a chunk of sourdough bread in front of you... don't know about you, but i love bread, especially sourdough bread and i will eat the whole thing.  try to avoid that and save room for the crabs and prawn a la monza! delicious dish.  dungenous crab that is shredded and served atop rice pilaf with prawns.  then covered in tomato sauce.. then baked with cheese. yummmmmmmmm... i don't care if it costs $26.  i'm gonna eat it.
author: Tina L.

description: Decent joint with a storied reputation back in the day. A bit tired and uninspired food now. Not bad but not worth the moolah. Given the myriad options they will need to shape up their grub
author: Umair K.

description: I have been to Tadich grill numerous times and every time the food and the clam chowder has been great. This time I had the seafood curry casserole. I don't recommend this for anyone not even a dog.  Trust me, don't try it. It was more cheesy than curry,  watery, and no flavor.
author: Will E.

description: You can't brag that you have visited San Francisco, until you experience Tadich Grill.  A classic restaurant from the old days.  The noise, ambiance, and staff make for a memorable experience.  If you have to drink your tea with your pinky finger extended, this is probably not the place for you.  Anytime we have gone there it is a combination Cheers bar experience with excellent food served and excellent service.  When the Grill is busy, there will be a wait for a table.  Enjoy the wait and meet the other people waiting with you.  It's fun.
author: Norm S.

description: Finally got to come here for hangtown fry. It's a really heavy dish and I didn't like it very much but why the 4 star? the staff and service was exceptional! The staff worked as a team and took really good care of us. Looking forward to trying their other items.
author: Tiff W.

description:
Tadich Grill calls itself the oldest restaurant in the city and that claim made me want to try it.  Also luring me in was the fact its sand dabs were on the 7x7 Magazine Big Eat SF list for the past few years.

Tadich delivers the old vibe with little glitz and rough and ready service.  The bread (as we were starving) was delicious.  The "famous" Bloody Mary is not worthy of fame.  Go with something else for a cocktail.

The sand dabs were presented well but needed more flavor...maybe even more lemon.  It came with a sauce over the fish that added some flavor.  They were cooked extremely well but just needed more pizazz.

The bread pudding was an outstanding dessert and the service ended up being great.

Hit up Tadich if you want old school seafood with an SF feel.
author: Chad S.

description: I read all the reviews and I was excited to try Tadich Grill after reading the reviews. I tried the red snapper and the ribeye steak. The red snapper sauce was bland, it had absolutely no taste. The fish itself was very boney. They didn't bother to debone the fish. They cooked it to the right temperature though, the fish was flaky and moist. I've had the exact same issue with the Ribeye - it seemed to be cooked plain with no seasoning, not even salt and pepper. It didn't have any aged taste like other upscale steak houses or a good butcher. I could do better with a USDA Select value packed ribeye at home. They did properly cook the ribeye to the right temperature and it was moist. Tadich needs to work on their flavor profile.
author: Randy M.

description:
The wait was about 20 min, which was not too bad since they have a bar. It's a pretty small place and everyone waiting against the wall, so it's gets pretty packed and warm. The staff was super friendly. We were outside waiting when our name was called and there was no problem being seated right away when we let the bartender know.
The food was delish. The clam chowder and the linguini with clams in a white claim sauce.
author: Priscilla V.

description: A must stop on the SF tour. Legendary atmosphere. Food is solid but not great. Better quality food elsewhere but you can't match the atmosphere.
author: Bill S.

description: The service and the sea bass were perfect. I haven't visited in almost twenty years and not much has changed, which is a good thing.
author: Kevin S.

description: Fan-frickin-tastic.  The cioppino, while expensive, is one of the best versions I've had. The clam chowder was also exceptional. I'd take a star off for a too limited wine by the glass and beer menu, but the food was too good to do that.
author: Bonobo M.

description: I went here early on a Wednesday evening with a friend, after 30 minutes or so the place was packed. He had the Seafood Cioppino and I had a baked casserole style curry dish with shrimp, scallops and crab over rice. Both dishes were really good. After finishing our meals we were in the middle of a discussion and about 10 minutes later they asked us to leave in order to clear the table for someone else. While I understand they have a business to run we were only there for about 90 minutes in total so it wasn't like we were dragging the meal on forever. Overall, very good food, busy place, the service was pretty good and we thought they rushed us out a bit too quickly. Will try it again with my better half.
author: Jeff O.

description:
Needs to be on your list of must visits in San Francisco. Went in with mild expectations - left a fan.

Food a solid 4+
Service a solid 5
Atmosphere solid 5

Would have rated a 4.5 if that was an option. Check them out.
author: Anthony G.

description: Friday night on Dec 30th and wait wasn't bad.  The cioppino always hits the spot, waiters super attentive, and the atmosphere perfect for a cold night.   An oldie but goodie.
author: Libby A.

description:
Very solid 4 stars!

As everyone knows, Tadich Grill is a San Francisco institution and an old restaurant in the city. I really enjoyed the feeling of history that you get when you walk in. The tiles on the floor look like they are the original ones from when the restaurant opened. I like the setup with the huge bar in the middle and the tables along the walls. Each table is walled off so you are in your own private booth. The servers are very friendly and helpful but the older bartenders can be a bit grumpy.

I would recommend coming in on a weeknight for dinner or come for a later dinner because I heard it can get very crowded. I went on a Wednesday at about 8:30pm and there was no issue getting a table right away.

The food is top notch. Everyone at our table had some sort of seafood dish and the ones that I tried were very good. The one negative I can say is that, as others have mentioned, it is a pretty pricey meal. The serving sizes are fairly large, but expect to drop a good amount of money when you come here.
author: Frank J.

description:
Authentic. Historic. $70 per person. Totally not worth it.

I would come back to this place only if I was showing around SF to some out of towners. This place has a very nice old SF vibe, but it is expensive and the food, although nice, is not worth the price.
author: Ata N.

description:
2 Stars, and I'm being a little generous. 

We arrived at 6:30pm on a Friday, so there were a good amount of people there...but the thing is, they don't have anywhere for you to wait, except along the wall. What? Our group of 6 literally had to stand, each of us with our backs to the wall, watching the people at the bar have a good time. And we were told we couldn't sit down, as those were for people that are eating at the bar. Really now, I'm sure they are just as busy on any other weekend night; you'd think they would build a waiting area.

We were seated, the waiter came over, handed everyone a menu, said that everything on it was excellent, and left. So we go about making our decisions and wave the waiter back. And we start ordering. Only then does the waiter tell us that they are out of their two most popular dishes of the night (it's 7pm!). And as we go around the table, it turns out that they are out of most of the dishes we wanted--I actually ended up with my 6th option. I understand when a restaurant is out of a dish, that happens. But (at least) 5 of them? Unacceptable for a restaurant of this caliber.

Other complaints: The lemons on our table were already squeezed--kinda gross. And we were not given bread plates.

Now that I've griped to no end, the food was decent. Not the best I've ever had, but not the worst either. I ended up with a "Shrimp and Avocado Diablo" which I expected to be spicy, but was just really buttery and cheesy, which I don't mind one bit. The others at my table were happy with their steak, trout and seafood saute. We skipped dessert, so no comments on that. The ambiance was definitely unique, with the waiters in half lab coats, and the bar/table setup. Go for lunch? I'm sure they'll have your food selection then.
author: Sindy C.

description: Worth the wait. broiled Petrale is excellent. Generous portions.
author: Jim R.

description:
Just went back over the holidays and glad to see that business is still booming!
Here is what I had for lunch and excellent as always:
1. Clam chower-the best I have ever had in my short life time.
2. Seafood appetizer platter-not my first time loving it and certainly not my last.
3. Chilean Sea Bass-what more can or should I say about this one?? Loved it :) 

I could come back again and again and try every last thing on their menu. Too bad for me, I like what I like and will continue to come back because they have so much that I already love.  Maybe I will try something new, maybe not...
author: Lindsey J.

description:
I took my family to this place after several people strongly recommending it to me.  The service was excellent and we we seated within 15 minutes after arriving.  I had Boston Clam Chowder and pan-fried Rainbow trout while my wife had seafood curry.  The food was good, but not exceptional and the bread at the table wasn't fresh.  The seafood curry didn't have that much rice in it and that annoyed my wife.  The bill was $74 for both of us (the kids didn't eat) and while the french fries and leeks were good, my expectations weren't met.  It seems like you are paying just to eat at a prime location in the San Francisco business district, or you are paying to eat at a restaurant established in the 1800's or you are paying just to eat at a place next to Michael Mina.  I may give them a second chance with other items in the future, but it will be a while.

Color us unimpressed.
author: Rob H.

description: A great classic SF venue which I first visited back in the 1960s and have always gone to when I'm in the City.  The food isn't extraordinary, but it's unbeatable when combined with the action and interaction of the waiters (always sit at the counter).  The best buy is the small seafood salad which is not small, a tip given me years ago by another patron who struck up a conversation.  Talking to the people next to you is another bonus for sitting at the counter.
author: John F.

description:
You have to accept this place for what it is:  a REALLY FANTASTIC spot to take a coworker or client on an expense account (make sure they like seafood).  The drinks are good, the waiters are old school, and they do a creative and effective job with privacy.  Most of the food is pretty good but you likely won't be longing to come back on your own dime.

Tip:  If you're not insecure about ordering an entre at the same price or a few bucks lower than your boss, have the waiter suggest a dish or two.  He never picks the cheapest but he always recognizes I don't want the stupid Cioppino in business clothes.
author: Matt P.

description: My party of two ended up eating here on a Monday night when our prior plans fell through.  It was MLK Day, and apparently our first option decided to be closed that day and not give us a bit of heads up.  Nevertheless, we were right on The Embarcadero and with no other options and trying to avoid calling an Uber to get around, we walked to this place.  It was a pleasant walk, not a lot of traffic, and it was an interesting sight to see this old-fashioned place at the first level of brand new office building and high rises.  Inside it's cramped and noisy, not in a frustrating way, but the way a good restaurant is when it's in high demand and dang good at what they do.  There were several parties waiting for a table, but one of the waiters behind the bar said we could sit immediately if we wanted to sit at the bar.  As I had no idea why anyone would wait so long for a table, we took the bar.  It was a great experience to see how effortlessly and flawlessly the waiters moved back and forth.  It was sad to see how people wasted food that was exceptional (and not cheap).  I ordered their cioppino on the recommendation of an older gentleman to my left, who omes to this restaurant 4 times a week and I think would know his stuff very well!  My mom ordered the Dungeness crab cakes.  Everything was exquisite!  My cioppino was rich and hot, and there was so much fish in there, I was stunned!  It was expensive, but the quality and quantity was unbelievable.  The whitefish was tender and fresh, the mussels as big as the palm of my hand, the shrimp giant.  The Dungeness crab cakes had no filler and were pure crab. I had been forewarned before coming here that the attitude of the waiters was...interesting.  To say the least, it was different.  They were all older men, white and Hispanic, and had a gruff character to them.  As long as they aren't downright rude (and they weren't) and attentive, it was good in my book.  Definitely a place to try!
author: Kathryn T.

description:
This place wasn't as good as people rave it is.  I'll give it a second chance to try the cioppino and sand dabs.  Came here on a Friday night, it was super crowded, as expected. It was slightly annoying trying to get a drink at the bar.  My guess is that it was packed beyond fire code.  My friend and I had to be swift to snatch a couple seats at the bar.  Don't, under any circumstances, expect a friendly bar staff.

We were seated, and our server was great.  He was kind and knew a lot about the wine selection.  I started out with a shrimp cocktail, and the bread they serve is super yummy.  The shrimp cocktail was a generous portion, aesthetically pleasing, and fresh.  I ordered a red snapper dish that came with crab.  It was okay, I was happy the food tasted fresh.  

I'll write another review when I go back for the cioppino and sand dabs.
author: Sarah B.

description: Surprisingly good food. Ahi tuna salad was delicious. Drinks are excellent, service great too. Solid lunch spot.
author: Ari D.

description: This SF institution has all the markings of what one would expect from one of the oldest places in the city. The grizzly, surly and yet oddly friendly waitstaff likely have worked there since the place first opened.  Oh ya, get some seafood too while you're in here...aside from the classic cioppino, this is the only place in the city I've ever found deep fried dungeness crab.
author: David S.

description:
Imagine an alternate universe with the 1950s-era Woolworth dining rooms you remember seeing photos of in your high school textbook in the section on the Greensboro sit-ins, where instead of being shunted to the colored persons drinking fountain or pressing laundry in the back with the rest of your relatives, you sit at the counter and the old guys in white coats seem happy to serve big hot expensive bowls of cioppino to swarthy little gay *you*! 

Unique atmosphere plus food, ftw.
author: Mandy H.

description:
Ahh, the good ole days.  Never quite as good as you remember but still better than thse kids today.

That is how I feel when I come in here.  I should be old, fat and smoking a stogie.  The place looks as old as San Fransisco itself, as does the waitstaff.  It hasnt changed in years and probably wont change.

The service is decent, its pretty much all business.  You wont get an experience that reflects the price you pay.  That may or may not be a deal killer for you, Im just giving you the warning.

Its high quality seafood though.  Seafood is really all they do.  Portions are HUGE too so plan to share something with a friend.  Id love to point out a single dish but Ive had pretty much everything and its all on the same level.  Just get what you like.
author: Ryan S.

description: Order the Ciopinno ! You will not regret it. Savory, Italian seafood stew. Yum! Service was excellent as well as friendly staff. Loved it!
author: Meshell L.

description:
I went back and forth deciding whether I wanted to review this place or not. Tadich is such a San Francisco institution with lots of old world charm  that giving a two star rating is kind of like telling your grandma that her dumplings were just "ok". 

But honestly, it was really really lackluster food.

We started with the crab cake was was ok. Lots of crab meat in it, which is nice but otherwise pretty standard stuff. A previous reviewer said it was one of the best they ever had, which got me excited and I was let down. I got the scallops and my boyfriend got the sand dab for our entrees. The sand dab was actually nice, simple and unique. The scallops were cooked nicely, but the accompanying gravy or sauce or whatever it was, was just awful. A bland unidentifiable grey pool at the bottom of the scallops. And a random scattering of chopped tomatoes tossed in. I also really dislike it when scallops don't have a nice sear to them. It looked like the scallops had been seared, but somehow lost that crispy goodness somewhere along the way. Maybe while it was sitting in the gray stuff?

And finally, the sides. Oh god, those sides. Some of the worst I've ever had at any restaurant. It was rice, french fries, and some veggies. The veggies were nothing special, but nothing awful either. But that rice was some of the worst I've ever had. You can get better stuff out of a box. And the fries tasted like they had been sitting out for awhile. 

Our bill came out to be about $80 for two people, no drinks. Super high for such mediocre food. 

I think if I had gone into the restaurant thinking of it as more of a classic diner than as a high end restaurant, I wouldn't have been so disappointed. But essentially you get diner-esque food at really high prices. 

Then again, I haven't tried their cioppino which they seem to be known for. And the service really was great.
author: Hannah S.

description:
I've been craving seafood since there hasnt been a lot of food seafood I've tried in the Midwest.  A few of my friends suggested Tadich Grill so I had pretty high expectations of this restaurant. 

We arrived around 6pm.  We placed our name on the list and were told we could not be seated until our entire party was present.  When all of us had arrived, we were seated immediately. No wait! How lucky!

I ended up ordering the sea bass. It arrived flaky but it was overcooked and on the dry side. I was extremely disappointed.

Our waiter was not very enthusiastic as well until the end of the dinner when he knew we would be leaving! Weird.

Unfortunately I wont be back here again, at least not for a long while!
author: Janet E.

description: This place is so "old San Francisco" - great ambiance and great combination of meat and seafood. Convenient location: close to BART, MUNI, and in the heart of the Financial Dist.
author: Izzy D.

description:
This is an institution here in the city one has to try it at least once.  Went here over the week end and was not disappointed, fresh fish and very nice service.  Loved the crab cocktail , and the size of the portions is large.  The style of the place and the plating is very old school but what do you expect from one of the oldest restaurants in the country.

Little pricey but the food is still good.  Don't know if I would make a special trip to go again, you can get good seafood in nicer places and for less money.  Try it at least once though
author: Shirley W.

description: I must say that I haven't thoroughly explored the menu here; however, the only reason I haven't is because the cioppino is so damn good. Gigantic portion of perfectly seasoned broth loaded with fresh seafood, and great wines to boot. This place easily trumps most of Pier 39's overpriced, tourist traps of seafood joints that have so often left me disappointed.
author: Chris L.

description: If you ever eat out in SF and you haven't been to Tadich Grill, you must give it a try.  It is an institution and it feels like that as soon as you walk in.  On this particular night it was just me along with my son, so we ate at the counter.  I had the Branzino, which was a whole sea bass grilled and served on the bone and my son had the Cioppino.  The Branzino was excellent and the Cioppino was the best we had ever tasted - with big chunks of crab and fish along with clams and scallops served with two huge slices of garlic bread for dipping into the sauce/broth that was so yummy we were eating it straight up with a spoon like it was a soup.  The place was hopping on a Saturday night and the line was long.  But to their credit, they kept it moving pretty well.  We also enjoyed a dish of their classic hash browns with our dinner.  What a great place to eat.
author: Lewis C.

description:
Tadich is old school. It is the same today as it was many years ago and will be 20 years from now. Based on some of the reviews, some people get it, others do not. That said the food is well prepared, freshest possible seafood and spot on. Service has style. Last visit the waiter has the plate turned the wrong way and he corrects himself, making a joke about his misstep which leads to a brief discussion on how the waiters are trained.
 I love old school and  professional waiters ( not out  of work actors, nothing against actors).
author: Jeffry M.

description: SF experience. Just go! Have a gin martini and one of the daily specials. Eat shut up. You'll love it. Now, GO!
author: Nicolas E.

description: Love the old-fashioned vibe. It reminds me of meals i had in Boston, old time charm. The spot is filled with people working in Finance dining with clients at lunch time. First come first serve, so go early and grab a bar seat (more fun). Cioppino is amazing, portion is huge.
author: Sherry W.

description: Came in with my aunt last night. No reservations, not sure if they takes reservations but it was a 10 min wait. Got in no problem, I was very excited as this was my first time. The staff was incredible to their service, politeness and just over all personality, I honestly was amazed. Me and my aunt were a little bit of a hand full to begin with as we were having a great night out on the town this place defiantly topped off the night. I will be back all the time and can't wait to tell my friends about this place. Oh yeah, and the food? Exceptional!!
author: Jay V.

description:
We have tradition of visiting Tadich Grill for anniversary dinner; have the famous Cioppino dish every year. This year the 14th, first finding was that we didn't have to wait to get a table: not many people. Then when the Cioppino came, it looked the same but tasted VERY DIFFERTENT! All the flavors, enriched thicken spice, and lovely tomato sensations were NOT there anymore. Only left was the watery thin salty tomato color source.  My wife and I kept going to toilet after dinner and sounded we got the 'sodium poisoning' after the salty Cioppino. I hope it is not because the chef lost his/her tasting sensor. Nevertheless, not sure if we want to go back next year. The recommendation: think twice.
Oh, forgot to mention, the place is pretty dirty. My kid and I got insect bites after sitting at the same corner, not as clean as used to be.
author: Andrew M.

description: Really good food. I had the Seafood Saute which is perfect if you don't like the tomato based Chiopinno
author: Chris S.

description:
Just...awful. We came here and expected something like Gibson's in our home city of Chicago - standard, unimaginative cuisine executed perfectly. Sadly...no.

I started with smoked trout, which had clearly been plated and refrigerated hours before service. The plate was cold, the bread was cold, the fish was hard...it was just not good.

Worse was the Cioppino - all the seafood was obliterated, horrendously over-cooked. The scallops were cracking on the edges, the shrimp was stringy, the shellfish kind of slid right out of their shells in defeat. The broth was oily and scalding hot.

My wife got "deviled crab". I don't know what sort of sorcery that was, but it was a shame, and revolting. I rarely (never) just don't eat my food, even if I think it's not that good. This, I didn't touch.

I ended up getting some popcorn at wallgreens on the way back to the hotel. That was much better.
author: Matthew L.

description: Very rude staff.  Recommended by the staff at our hotel. " Food was good", but the lack of welcoming ruined it.  Came in, give name, and then ordered to move your butt down the wall..  Seated us, and I guess we missed the rule of ordering here.  We did not order huge meals, so was disciplined by the server that we should be ordering full meals.  Trying to finish our glass of wine and the server told us that we had to leave because they have people waiting - WOW, I'm pretty sure we were barely there for 30 mins since we were seated....... Staff was really up tight and tense.  I was a server for years and I would of never never treated people like that.  Oh well, I guess they feel they have the business so who cares...  I'm sure the celebrity reviews are great, they were treated like kings.  Too bad and very sad.
author: Pat W.

description:
So I was visiting San Francisco, and I had some time to myself in the city before I met with my friends, and one of them told me that I must absolutely go to Tadich Grill and order the Seafood Cioppino.  It's a dish that originated in SF, and I can easily say that it's one of the best seafood dishes I've ever had.

I went there during a not-so-busy hour (3pm) and sat down at the bar-like half of the restaurant.  It was somewhat of a mobster-like environment with dim lights, and waiters that were all old men with very little to say.  I ordered without looking at the menu since I knew what I wanted, but I was curious to know what the hell kind of a dish I was getting.  When I took a look at the menu, it turned out to be the most expensive item.  THAT SON OF A BITCH! ($30 actually, so not bad)  From that point on I had high expectations and kept thinking that I'd rather have a McRib (don't judge me...  and if you don't like McRibs, you should really be ashamed of yourself!!!).

When my dish came, it looked like a whatevers bowl of cambell's with shellfish added.  They gave me a bib, but those things make me feel like a fool, so I decided to risk getting my $10 shirt splattered, and tossed it aside.  Once I had a taste however, now that's a different story.  The bowl of campbell's had somehow transcended into an orgy of magical seafood.  Mussels, clams, shrimp, scallops, crabmeat, and white fish in a manhattan chowder-like broth.  All the shells were pealed/cracked, so it was very simple and easy to eat.  And the bread when dipped in the broth was a perfect blend of soft marinated bliss with a nice crispy crust aka damn delicious.  I also had a nice glass of chardonnay to go along with it, but any red would have done nicely as well.  

The only thing that I didn't like, was that the Tadich regulars would roll by and constantly tell me how great the cioppino is, how I should eat it, and how it compares to other restaurants.  I really wanted to smack each one of them in the face so I could enjoy my meal in peace!  

I wish there was a place that serves such a cioppino in L.A., or is there...  Sensational.
author: J Y.

description:
I was dinning in this restaurant every time I was in San Francisco down town for over 15 years.
This is simply the best. From bar, to waiters, to food everything is perfect.
If you are missing the feeling of what restaurants in US was back in 1960's, come visit this place. The nostalgia of old good time constantly drive me to come back.
I will come back and strongly recommend this place.
author: Leo S.

description: Hadn't been there in years. Food and ambiance was just as I remembered. Same old school attitude. The Bronzino was excellent.
author: Ron S.

description: The absolute gold standard of old school SF restaurants. If excellent food, great atmosphere, and unbelievable cioppino are your thing, you can't miss this one!
author: Ron G.

description:
They might as well have invented Cioppino.  I had the dish for the first time at Tadich and nothing else has ever come close.  It's the most amazing cioppino you'll find anywhere.
Love the atmosphere and they have great service.  They have some waiters that have been there for over 30 years!
Only problem is it's hard to get a seat because they don't do reservations (which is one reason I like it - it's still a casual place) and it's so crowded always.
author: Dustin T.

description: How this place does not have 5 stars! I was here for lunch one day a while back and it is hands down one if the best places I have eaten. Food excellent! But the service is what would bring me back time and time again. The kitchen is slammed, and all the old dudes in there are calm and organized and look to be on top of it. That's probably why the food comes out do quickly and good! The place is clean, the staff if super friendly and they are busy! I'll eat here every time i visit San Fran! Oh ya, the pock chop is tasty!
author: Joshua B.

description:
This restaurant was recommended by some friends who visited SF many times as the go to place for some SF history.   My husband & I met up with a couple who live in the area who also thought it would be a good place to go, as they had eaten there several times.  How could you go wrong?   

The food was mediocre, but passable for what it was, so we didn't really have any complaints.  We had the check & had our credit cards out to pay when a cockroach crawled across the table.  One of the men at the table took his napkin & killed it.  We then showed it to the waiter who responded with, "I'm glad you killed it" as he took our credit cards.  We were dumbfounded, so we flagged him down & told him that we thought that we needed some sort of compensation.  He said,  "OK, I'll take it to the manager".  

The manager came over came over & without much of an apology, asked what he could do.  I told him that at least he should comp my husband & I our meals. Our friends made it clear that they had brought us there because they had had good meals in the past but they were pretty upset with the incident.

The waiter came back with the credit cards - they had comped us the two cheapest meals on the bill (not what I had requested). 

The cockroach was bad enough but their lack of sincere response to the disturbing end to our meal will certainly keep any of us from recommending this restaurant.
author: Laura W.

description: Worth the trip to eat Cioppino. Great ambiance and wonderful history in this joint. Make sure to go early as it's first come first serve, and it is always full. If you love seafood, this is the place to go in SF. Any time I'm in the bay area I always make a trip to eat at Tadich.
author: Jose F. G.

description:
Fair food...service poor...overated!!   Had a bite of my dinner which almost broke my tooth on. Ps it was a pearl
Sad to say my food contained no oysters or mollusks  of anykind. Brought to attention of waiter....on way out spoke to manager who showed little or no concern.  There are better establishments where you can dine.
author: Stu S.

description: Nothing wrong with the service. I had been eating very light food for several days. Then I came here and ordered some kind of cheesy swordfish, that sounded good, I thought. It came baked in a casserole. You could tell the fish had been frozen and I felt so sick halfway through it I decided to visit the bathroom. I was not right for hours afterwards. Am definitely not going back. Looks fancy but it's a ruse.
author: Ezekiel S.

description:
I wanted to visit this restaurant because of the History of the restaurant.  It is the oldest restaurant in California and third in the country. There have been short clips of this restaurant on shows from food network and others. Tyler Florence also said that the sand dabs were the best thing he ever ate (the show).

I wanted to really love the place but found myself let down. Not that the food was bad but it wasn't great either. The sand dabs that I ordered were not very good. The fish was bland and the texture seems a little soft for being fresh. The cioppino was good and no complaints. The price tag of the seafood stew left me feeling empty.

The service was good and upon arrival the gentlemen at the bar greeted us warmly. I just wasn't sure about the butcher jackets for their uniforms. I felt as if I was waiting for nice steak to be wrapped. The place needs a little update. Upon being sat at the really old table the server had to fix it with some napkins to balance the table.

I understand keeping the historical aspect of the restaurant but there is time to modernize and have the guest feel more comfortable. The prices were expensive for the ambiance the level of service and even the quality of food was at question. I don't think the prices would be such a factor if not for the lack of detail. I just feel that for a little more money you could experience a more well polish establishment.

Finally, I would not say that there isn't anything positive to take away from the restaurant. The Historical aspect of the place is almost worth dinning here. The food is prepared properly and is edible. I personally wasn't crazy about this place and think there is more ideal places to visit in this part of town.
author: Shaun P.

description:
This place is an old-school money making machine.  Normally when you pay these prices you actually get a table and a nice leisurely dinner rather than a counter spot.  At Tadich Grill you get great old-school service from men in tuxedos but the lunch counter setting is certainly a bit different.  In terms of the food though, it's tough to find too much fault in the crab cakes - in my recent visit they were topped with a great sauce including fish roe which added great flavor and texture.  However, the "famous" sand dabs were extremely bland and really needed a good sauce - or maybe just seasoned breading - to make them worth eating.  I'm not saying I won't go back, but it's just a much different place than I expected and a 50% success rate on the food is less than I was hoping for.  That being said, it seems that cioppino and a number of other dishes are hits with Yelp users so I may have to check it out during future visits to SFO.

For the record, Tadich Grill also doesn't accept American Express which always kind of annoys me at high end places.  I'm just sayin'.
author: Brian C.

description: A staple lunch in San Francisco. Incredible food, atmosphere, drinks, and overall great time. I had the bone in Rib Eye, which was cooked to perfection. As much as the establishment itself is server Barry. If you have not been yet, you are missing out on a San Francisco gem.
author: Tim P.

description:
Vintage Ambiance Fantastic Cocktails.

I decided to stop here for a cocktail while I waited for my reservation at another restaurant close by. When I walked in I was welcomed by a long wooden bar that stretched to the end of the room. From the 20 foot ceiling hung art decco style light fixtures. The walls are covered with mirrors and brass coat hooks.

The restaurant is pretty busy. The handsomely dressed staff; white coats and ties, are courteous and moves swiftly to ensure you are ready for a meal and or a cocktail.

I ordered myself a Cape Code which was served in a footed stem highball and a red straw. The cocktail was delicious, mixed  and ratio-ed well with a twist of lime. I look forward to dining there very soon to experience their food as their menu was very appetizing!
author: Rochelle P.

description: Every time I visit San Francisco I make it a point to visit Tadich Grill and this trip was no exception; however, this time I had a bad experience.  The food was excellent as always; however, the service was terrible.  The waiter was nothing short of rude.  I arrived at the restaurant around 5:30 PM.  I was able to walk in and sit at the bar without a wait.  Right after I sat down a waiter asked me if I was by myself and I replied yes.  He told me to scoot down next to another person.  I indicated I didn't want to and he said I needed to so he could seat other people in my seat.  Oddly there were plenty of open seats.  In fact, they blocked off half the bar as there were so many seats available.  The other issue was that he didn't use manners.  In fact, I thanked him for serving me and he used no manners... even after he told me to move.  He also referred to me as boss.  After bringing my main course to me he said, "do you need anything else boss."  I told him, "no thank you." And he walked off.  What kind of waiter addresses his customer as boss?  Tadich Grill isn't exactly McDonalds.  BTW, no other customer was ever seated in my original seat or the seats next to that seat while I was there.  I am very disappointed in my visit to Tadich Grill and may not return.  There are so many places I haven't tried in San Francisco.
author: Chris M.

description:
Heard a lot of great things about this historical SF restaurant so I dined here with raised expectations. Tadich certainly did not dissappoint. The layout of the restaurant is very old school. There's a long span of seats along the counter like you would see at a diner. Most people sit on the counter (vs. booth seating). The look and feel of the place and the servers are very old school, feels like you are dining in the 60's.

Tons of selection for food with most dishes feature seafood. Cioppino is a big hit, saw many people make like babies and put on bibs to tackle the dish. I ordered the Lobster Casserole which was crazy rich and good. Big chunks of meaty lobster covered in thick cream sauce baked in the lobster's shell. It came with a solid portion of buttery and chunky side vegetables and potatoes. Afrer finishing the whole meal, I think I had a slight case of cardiac arrest but it was well worth it.
author: Ed L.

description:
Tadich. One word for straightforward and timeless.
Tadich is still relevant. My favorite time to go is late afternoon well after the Lunch Crowd and before the usual Dinnertime and enjoy a leisurely cocktail followed by unimprovable Oysters Rocky. Follow that up with chilled seafood, Louie Salad, something buried and gratineed..Uber fresh whether raw, cooked or chilled Seafood, crunchy crusty bread and butter, Some people love the buzz of Lunch time at Tadich and if these walls could talk oh my! Service is no nonsense-attentive and professional.
author: Karen W.

description:
Order the clam chowder and the cioppino. The clam chowder is one of the best I've ever had...thick, hearty, delicious. The cioppino comes with a variety of seafood and some of the best garlic bread that you'll ever have.

4 stars for the majority of the food...minus 1 star for upselling me on the horrible crab cake (they only give you one for $12). From reading the other reviews, it sounds like they try and upsell this dish to many of their customers. At least try and upsell me on something that is good. It was sitting in a cream sauce....and then surrounded by some sort of tomato sauce. The sauces basically overpowered the natural taste of the crab and it really wasn't very crispy.

SKIP THE CRAB CAKE.
author: Lester W.

description:
2 words...Skip It!  

2 hr wait for rude service and dry crab cakes.  This is an "establishment" place that gets by on it's 100+ years of being around.  Every big city has a few.
author: Mr V.

description:
Went here for dinner on New Year's Eve.  Such a classic place!  Feels like it hasn't changed in 50 years, maybe more.

If you have a group of 4 or 5, its a fun place as you'll get your own private booth area.

I ordered Blackened Ahi Tuna which was very good.  It was topped with some seaweed salad and on a bed of a little spicy corn salad/garnish.  Good pairing of some nice flavors.  Others at my table had Chilean Sea Bass, Filet Mignon, and the Vegetarian Platter.  Everyone was pleased.

They don't take reservations.  We had to wait about 30 minutes which wasn't bad.  The host offered to come find us at the bar next door.  A nice personable touch!
author: Paul H.

description: I usually leave these reviews to my gf, but in this case I want to weigh in.  We arrived on a late Saturday afternoon.  We were hungry and anxious to try the restaurant having seen it on an Emeril episode.  The restaurant did not appear particularly busy and NO ONE was waiting.  I told the host there were two of us and he immediately told me it would be a 20-25 minute wait.  He suggested we eat at the counter if we didn't want to wait.  This might be a reasonable alternative at some diner or if there really were no tables available, but as it turns out, tables were available just not for us.  I informed the host that we wanted a table and was he sure about the wait.  He left, I assume to check on the table situation.  While he was gone, a group of 20 something's (that's how they looked anyway) arrived.  Two stayed outside perusing the menu and two waited just inside the door.  It did not appear that they were sure whether they wanted to eat there or not.  A few minutes later the host returned he reiterated to me that it would be a 20-25 minute wait.  The two behind us at the door started to leave.  The host called out to them "are you going to eat?".  One of them said "it doesn't look that way".  The host asked how many in the party and he replied 4.  The host then said (talking right over us I might add) "I can seat you right away!".  They then all came in, marched right past us, and we're seated.  Absolutely no one else was waiting and not another word to us from the host.  Since no one had left after we arrived (we would have seen them) the table/s must have been open when we were originally told 20-25 minutes.  So, why were we told we had to wait while the later arriving group got immediate service?  We neither are nor look like vagrants so I assume it wasn't our appearance.  No, it seems that the restaurant has a policy that party's of two must wait for a table for two regardless of whether anyone else is waiting or how many larger tables are available or how long that wait might be.  In short, whether that group of 4 came in 5 minutes after us or 20 minutes after us it's likely that they were going to be seated before us.  This may make good business sense if your sole goal is to maximize profits and you don't mind your guests feeling like little cash registers to be emptied.  But it makes for lousy customer service.  Don't get me wrong, but if I'm dropping a hundred or so on lunch, I prefer to dine at an establishment that at least pretends to value my business.
author: Thomas N.

description:
Cioppino. Not bad. Suits my taste. They use a light tomato broth which I prefer over heavy tomato sauce. You can taste the subtle flavors of the variety of seafood. Lots of seafood (prawns, clams, mussels, crab, fish, and scallop). Liked the fact they put in whole fresh crab meat rather than putting in the uncracked legs and body. No mess trying to eat it.

Only miss was that it was too salty.  Not sure why they leave out the bread at every station on the bar area.  The bread was cold and stale. Not much flavor for a san francisco sourdough bread.

Good place to take a date if you can get one of the booths. It's cozy and private.

Bathroom can be a little more modern and fresher. Funky smell. I prefer not to use their facilities if I can avoid it.

Also need to turn up the heat. It was cold inside.

Parking was a struggle.

Despite all the negatives, I like their cioppino and would return if i can't find anything better in the bay area.

Price: $40 including tip for just the entree.  Price slightly on the high side, but I think its worth it.
author: Marshall C.

description:
I don't know if it's the "Best Cold-Day Restaurant" but I thought it was pretty good. My friend took me to this old-school restaurant that serves classic seafood dishes. The restaurant doesn't take reservations so be sure to get there early to put your name down. 

We were quoted a 30-40 minute wait so we decided to sit at the bar that is situated in the middle of the restaurant. It stretches pretty much the full length of the restaurant, which is interesting. Although the bartenders weren't friendly, they were fast and efficient in taking and serving our orders. I had the Manhattan Champagne and my friend had the Mojito Martini. My drink was an interesting combination of whiskey and champagne. I really enjoyed the martini though! I also tried the Mandarin Cosmo during and I thought it was just ok. The drinks are strong and they fill your martini glasses to the rim! 

Our table for dinner was nice and intimate, albeit it small. We ordered the Fried Calamari, the Seafood Cioppino, and the Lobster Thermidor. The calamari was extremely fresh and delicious. It did not have too much batter and they provided us with plenty of cocktail and tartare sauce. Out of the two entrees, I enjoyed the cioppino a lot more. It had plenty of fresh seafood (clams, scallops, fish, crab, mussels, etc) and two thick pieces of garlic bread to soak up the delicious sauce. The cioppino wasn't too saucy like other places make it - the seafood definitely stood out. The Lobster Thermidor was simply too rich for me. Although the lobster meat was sweet and delicious, the cheese and the Bechamel sauce was too overpowering. The dish came with steak-cut fries and vegetables, as well as a cup of clam chowder. I thoroughly enjoyed the clam chowder and thought that it was one of the best I've ever had. It was thick, creamy, and had lots of clams and potatoes. 

Our server was funny, friendly, but not always there when we needed him. Overall I would definitely recommend the seafood-lovers to give this place a try!
author: Stephanie L.

description: What can I say other than I simply LOVE Tadich.  I have been dining at the Tadich for more than a decade now and believe that 9 out of 10 times I've been assisted by the same waiter.  The staff are extremely professional and exactly to the point...no bones about it.  If you are looking for one of those places where you look forward to enjoying friendly banter with the waiters, you might want to patronize a very different establishment.  But if you are good to go with straight forward waiters, no frills yet historic atmosphere, and comfort food, this is your place.  I have NEVER had a bad experience here.  However, it is certainly an institution within SF--so be prepared to wait for a table.  While waiting, do enjoy great conversation with the bartenders.
author: Tess C.

description: Okay, decent seafood but never come here with a party of 2. You will wait for a long time as parties of 3 or 4 are seated. Not worth the wait. Lots of places in SF to get good seafood where you won't be treated as a leper because you are a party of 2.
author: Megan R.

description: Excellent seafood choice. Wife and I were treated well and served a delicious meal. This was our first meal when visiting San Francisco. The waiter made great recommendations. Overall we were very happy after eating at Tadich Grill.
author: Carlos M.

description: Went with my cousin for my birthday dinner while out of town. Within seconds of walking in the door you realise this is an institution more than a restaurant. The ambiance is very traditional 1950's I would say, in a very pleasant way. The staff are all very formal yet friendly, and provide excellent service. The perfect mix of formality, friendliness and attentiveness without being intrusive. We shared the oyster rockefellers for starters followed by the freshest meatiest crab cakes ever, and the seafood cioppino, which was superb. Had the bourbon bread pudding for dessert. The bread pudding itself was not special but the bourbon sauce made up for that.   Restaurant experiences this good don't come often. Well worth the visit.
author: Jesus C.

description:
Tadich, old friend. I grew up with you! Well not you, exactly, but the family of some kids at school owned your ancient and hallowed halls. This isn't quite a break-up letter, Tadich, but it suggests you may want to see a therapist about your problems.

It's not me, it's you.

You see, when a business lunch between a couple of attorneys at my office leads to a nice extended conversation it's okay to think "wow, they aren't spending money anymore, I'd sure like to make some more of that green stuff, how could I politely entice them to turn a table?"

I mean, that's business, you're forgiven for thinking it.

At most expensive Financial District restaurants a server might suggest a desert or another coffee and when declined, would politely ask if he or she could bring the bill. Points for tact, this is a no brainer in the service industry - a service standard if you will.

Oh Tadich, how did you mangle this so badly?

You approached an in-depth business conversation between two well heeled older attorneys and blurted out "you know, we have a really long line today so I'm going to have to ask you to vacate the table."

[insert stunned silence]

You have been demoted to a three star grill.

Next time I call in a reservation, it'll be at Perbacco.
author: Ian A.

description: I have had several very good meals at Tadich's.The fish was exceptionally fresh,the potatoes nice and crispy and the vegetables were fresh as well.I found the staff to be friendly and want to do a good job.My food came hot  and the portions were more than plenty.The counter is a great place for conversation and to people watch.
author: Victoria S.

description: I've been eating here since the 1970's. Killer seafood but I love the Petrale Sole! They print the menus daily and make excellent souvenirs, IF you ask the waiter first.
author: Patrick M.

description: If I could give less than a star I would definitely do that. Worst service in long time. At 9pm on Saturday night they were out of filet mignon and garlic bread (how is it possible?!?). Very rude service starting at the bar and later at the table. The waitress was very pushy to order food. At the end when I fill out the survey about the dining experience I only received "Ok" from the Maitre as an answer. I am not sure the owner will ever know about my survey!
author: Cristina R.

description: This place is a joke. Unfriendly, pretentious 80 year olds running the place and thinking they are the sh*t. I attempted to bring a group of international colleagues after 9pm and the door was slammed in our face. Would not recommend to anybody who wants to have a pleasant SF experience. Go to Michael Minnna instead...lovely folks with true class and talent
author: Alberto R.

description:
I've had some of my fondest childhood memories at Tadich's with my dad.  We used to come for a big bowl of clam chowder and sourdough bread.

I returned with two business colleagues last week and we all ordered a bowl of clam chowder.  Our server informed us that we needed to order more since Tadich has a minimum food order.  We told him to simply charge us the very un-friendly minimum food charge since we did NOT want to order more food.  Unfortunately, he insisted we HAD TO order more items and was pretty damn unfriendly about it especially since we didn't order any beverages to boot.   

In the end, we ordered three more bowls of clam chowder at his insistence and then watched him walk away and never check in with us again during our meal.  He was rude, unfriendly, unkind, and grouchy.

In the end, we finished our meal and then left the three additional lonely bowls of clam chowder in the middle of the table and left.

Tadich has always been known for great service -- unfortunately, not on this occasion.  Food minimum or not, please be nicer about it.
author: J. SOMA S.

description:
Second visit here. I think what appeals to me is how fresh the seafood is and how they have retained the historic ambiance of the restaurant throughout all the trendy wave of restaurants in the city. Totally old school service. They have been in business since 1849 so they are probably doing something right.
The first time I had the Cioppino and loved it. It is a big bowl of super fresh seafood and a little broth. This time I had the Sea Bass with fresh spinach as a side. Both amazing. The Sea Bass was seared and melted in your mouth. Can't wait to go back! The large seafood salads looked delicious. Have a Bloody Mary at the bar while you wait.
author: Pamela D.

description: Great place, great atmosphere and fantastic seafood.  the wait was 45 minutes, but we wanted a table so that's the price you pay.  We could have sat down at the bar within 5 minutes, but whatever.  Our waiter was great as well.  I of course had the cioppino, which is some of the best I've ever had.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Jason W.

description: My family has been going to Tadich Grill for generations.  It was my grandpas favorite restaurant so every time we visited SF, we would go not once, but maybe 2-3x.  They have the best clam chowder I have ever tasted.  Every seafood and steak dish is pretty solid.  You cant go wrong with anything really.  I plan on continuing to eat at this place every time I visit!
author: Emily M.

description: If nothing else balm to the maladies of trendy eateries.  Good seafood dishes and great old-style San Francisco sourdough bread.
author: The G.

description: This place is legendary, and it lived up to its reputation!  The servers take good care of you in old school style.  We had the chowder - best I've ever had!  Main course was the sand dabs, which they offered to debone.  It was all served hot and fresh with delicious steak fries. Great atmosphere and old world San Francisco.  I'll be back!
author: Julie A.

description:
This is as good as it gets for seafood in San Francisco.

No reservations, so people wait.  We arrived on a Friday night and checked in at the Hyatt and got over here at 7:00PM - and we were told it would be a 50 minute wait, and it was.  Spot on.  Didn't mind waiting since there is lots to look at outside and in, very interesting classic.  This place has an outstanding reputation and deserves it.

The waiters know what is good and I highly recommend following their guidance.  We ordered the lobster bisque and the clam chowder and BOTH were to die for.  The fish selections were unusual and special for the day and we loved them.  This is one of those places where no matter what you get, everything should be A-OK.  Not having reservations makes it very egalitarian as to who gets in.  The wait staff is old line and WONDERFUL.  You are in good hands here.

So if you are going to San Francisco, this is must eat.  Sure you will drop a few dollars, but never will you eat as well and appreciate it so much.  Well worth the cost and, after all, it is San Francisco.  Enjoy!

See you next time I am in town, Tadich Grill!
author: John M.

description:
Came here for lunch sometime earlier in the year and I must say I really want to come back and try dinner.
We had the Clam Chowder and breaded crab claws and sole which were all tasty.
Great food and lovely ambiance and decor. If you like seafood and an old timey feel come here.
author: Ro M.

description:
The seafood was amazing!!!! I highly recommend the Lobster Thermidor or the Lobster Ravioli! Both were delicious! 

I love the intimate feel of this place and that the staff truly care if you have a pleasant dining experience. The old school atmosphere makes you feel like you are stepping back in time!
author: Erin R.

description: An institution.  Get a martini and some seafood and forget about your day.
author: Sofia V.

description:
When I first moved to the bay area and asked around for a place that makes a killer cioppino, Tadich Grill was recommended several times by local friends. They were so right! This restaurant has the tastiest cioppino I have yet to try! My husband ordered something else, don't remember what it was but he apparently not so good to be memorable. So the 5 stars is only for the cioppino.

While the cioppino is off the charts good, I won't be back for some time. They don't take reservations and we had to stand behind the crowded bar for over an hour to get a table. Because of the long and not so comfortable wait, I won't be a regular. However if I ever find I can spare a few hours and my craving is strong enough, I may return.
author: Foodaholic G.

description:
Tadich Grill, oh how I love thee.
I have spent many precious hours in your arms...with jumbo fried prawns on my plate!

I honestly can't think of another restaurant that is so perfect...to me, anyway. I don't know what took me so long to recite my love for them on Yelp, but I was just there a few nights ago, so this time I'm going to write something. 

They serve classic American seafood (mostly) fare. What? You want foie gras? Well, you're just gonna have to boogie on down a few doors and go to Michael Minna at the old Aqua instead. 

Don't get me wrong. There is nothing wrong with the celebrity chef establishments. But in today's food-snob world, I find comfort in places like Tadich Grill. It is an old restaurant with old recipes, older (and charming) staff and an old bar with the old San Francisco history imprinted deep within its wooden surface. Go there with someone important to you - a good friend, husband or wife, mom or dad...and not just enjoy the food, but enjoy being there. Appreciate the past that we're allowed to peek into, and make your own memories. 

When I saw that there was a fire at Tadich a year or so ago, I thought I'd have a heart attack. It is a precious restaurant and it would've been a shame to lose it to a fire...phew! 

Places like Tadich Grill is what makes San Francisco unique. I've lived in this town for 30 years and have seen many restaurants come and go, and know that Tadich Grill is here to stay. 

Now, go enjoy your clam chowder!
author: Aya C.

description:
This old school joint features the BEST cioppino I've ever had. I would give the cioppino five stars.  

However, the rest of the food is good, but not great. The service is uneven, ranging from cheerfully attentive to grumpily inattentive. I've been here three times and have had the cioppino twice. It is delicious. This rich seafood stew consists of large portions of scallops, clams, mussels, halibut, crab, and prawns in a savory tomato-based broth. It contains no "filler" starches or vegetables and comes with two large pieces of buttered garlic bread with which you can sop up the broth. The portion is large enough for two meals if you want to avoid afternoon food coma. 
 
Most recently, I had the pan fried sand dabs (#67 on the 7x7 Big Eat SF 100 list, http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die) and was a bit underwhelmed. I'm not sure why 7x7 chose this dish over the ciopinno. The fish was undoubtedly fresh and I appreciated that the filets were deboned, but the dish was unremarkable. The pan fried preparation obscures the fish's distinct flavor and tasted very similar to my friend's pan-fried petrale sole. The fish entrees came with roasted squash and pan-fried potatoes (both were solid). 

Next time I'll stick with the cioppino. When you get the cioppino they give you a plastic bib to protect your clothing - a nice touch.
author: Chris T.

description: Came here during non peak hours. This place is a good ole school joint! You won't find fancy lights or young hostesses; instead you'll have friendly waiter(s) and good food. I had the Chilean sea bass, and it was excellent. I plan on coming here again and trying out the other dishes.
author: Tim w.

description:
The food here is good, but pricey. We all got and enjoyed seafood, though perhaps we over-indulged on bread before the entrees. I highly recommend the spinach side and bread pudding desserts. The "rice pudding" is misnamed and is actually more of a custard. 

Overall, it's a solid place for a nice meal, and comes with a lot of history.
author: Ivana J.

description: Another excellent dinner at Tadich Grill. Started with the prawn cocktail appetizer,  which was good. The main course was excellent.  I had the grilled halibut which was perfectly cooked, as were the veggies that accompanied it. Hubby order his favorite - the sautéed scallops.  It's the scallops that bring us back regularly.  Perfectly cooked. Highly recommend!
author: Judy E.

description:
Been here a couple times and have been lucky enough to skip the wait and get a seat at the bar each time. The clam chowder here is probably one of my most favorite things to eat in SF. It is absolutely delicious! I wasn't a big fan of the bloody mary here though.

Love the atmosphere here too. The servers are all extremely nice and personable. Service is also quick and unpretentious.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Had dinner with the bosses and this was definetely not a good place to have dinner and talk about work since the place was loud.
I ordered fish and my boss ordered the steak.
She had to put salt and pepper to her steak because it had no flavor at all.
My halibut was uncooked and with NO flavor at all either. 
Very expensive for HORRIBLE food. 
I couldn't even finish my meal.
author: Cristina D.

description:
The experience here can be night and day on when you go. One day you'll be greeted warmly, watch a friendly bartender make a drink, get seated promptly and have a nice waiter.

On other occasions you walk in and you feel like you must have said something to piss someone off or your waiter probably has been there about 10 years too long.

The food is good. Not blow you away good. Honestly it's on par with a good restaurant down in Fisherman's Wharf. Not the best compliment but not the worst thing to say either.

It's actually kind of unfortunate. The place has history and I love the feel of the place. All wood and completely old school. Just wish everything else was consistent with the decor. 

My food was good. I had a fried seafood platter. Others had the seared scallops which actually looked delicious. Our other coworker said the Clam Chowder was decent. It's disappointing cuz you walk in and it feels like going back in time. Too bad they're not consistent.
author: Hyung L.

description: one has to try the oldest restaurant in San Francisco, the reviews were overwhelmingly positive and i had to try cioppino while in town, so i did.  i came for dinner around 9pm on a Monday night and it was busy but i got a seat at the corner and service was fast and friendly.  everyone around me was ordering cioppino and the portion size was huge so i opted to skip appetizers.  the cioppino came out piping hot, the broth subtle yet flavorful could definitely tell the seafood was cooked in it.  the cioppino was absolutely delicious i will be dreaming about it for weeks, i had to hold back from 5 stars due to the shellfish being over cooked and one of my garlic toast pieces being burnt on one side.  the cioppino however is still that good even with those mistakes.
author: Mars M.

description:
COUNTER SERVICE FALLS SHORT FOR WOMEN. 

I have been going to this restaurant for many years now and the wait staff just seems to be getting more aggressive and nasty.  I guess they are no longer concerned with how their employer makes money to fund their ungrateful and boorish service style.

I had taken a seat at the counter while my friend went and stood in the line to get a drink by the cash register.  We had tried to catch a waiter's eye to beg him to take our drink order as we were trying to get our seats at the open seating counter, but to no avail.  They refused to look at us, even when we tried to make verbal contact.  Mind you, this was at 6:00 p.m., Thursday evening with few people there yet for dinner hour.  There was an open seat at the counter and the person next to the empty seat was just finishing their meal and would be gone within 5 minutes.  I took the open seat after offering it to a gentleman who was with another man who had just taken a single seat up the counter and was waiting for another seat next to it to open.  I asked the friend who was still waiting for a seat who arrived just ahead of us, if he would like to sit down.  He thanked me for asking if he wished to take the seat, but declined stating he would wait for a seat next to his friend to open up so they could dine together.


After I had taken the seat at the counter for approximately 2 minutes, the tall, 50ish, grey, balding, white male waiter, he was taller than all the other waiters by far...announced loudly to me from across the counter that I would need to vacate my seat because he had seen me come in with my friend and I was not allowed to sit at the counter and occupy a single seat!  I graciously told him that my friend was in the process of getting our drinks at the end of the counter, he cut me off and loudly proclaimed to those around us as he leaned across the counter toward me that "I was violating protocol", "get up", "you can't sit there".  

The girl next to me whom had just taken her last bite told him "I am finished, they can have my seat".  The venemous and aggressive waiter once again loudly proclaimed to both of us and those surrounding, "that he didn't care if she was leaving or not, I was violating protocol and had to leave".  The lady next to me then told the waiter to bring her check "now" and told him she was leaving and my friend could take her seat.  

At approximately this same time there were two other women whom had been waiting for seats and told us they had also been rudely and aggressively treated a few minutes before by a waiter further up the counter close to the prep station.

I need to mention that the gentleman I spoke of earlier in this review who took a seat further up the counter and continued waiting for his friend to hopefully get a seat next to him was NOT ordered to leave the counter seat he occupied.  

I was mortified and told the waiter he was extremely rude and out of line, but stupidly got up.

Now I am thinking about how my civil rights as a woman have been violated.  I was not the only woman discriminated against this evening....hmmm.  I think I will be setting up an appointment with a class-action lawyer for a discussion on how my rights as a woman have been violated.

How many other women have had this same thing happen to them?

Needless to say, we will never be returning to Tadich Bar and Grill, and will take our business to another San Francisco restaurant that is happy to serve to women.
author: N D.

description:
If the Tadich Grill was a man...I would marry him. He would wear a Thomas Pink fitted shirt to work and a Polo on the weekends...a little old school, from a good family...with great manners. He would enjoy a glass of Scotch from time to time... and work in finance. 

But really-

I'm a fan of this worn in, seafood joint...it's classy. 

The menu boasts different types of clam chowder, lobster bisque, cioppino. The of course there is a wide selection of crab louies...oysters...I was practically giddy with the prospect that lunch presented...I almost forgot about the client I had with me here....um...hello?

This is a "cold day" restaurant that can definitely be enjoyed in any other type of weather. 

About $60 for three at lunch.
author: Sarah M.

description: This place is absolutely amazing. I had the Petrole Sole Filet and it was cooked to perfection. This place ambiance is superb and the service was great and thus far, the best old fashioned I have had in San Fran.
author: Christina M.

description:
The Up - The food is pretty great here. I even ate brussel sprouts here that weren't so bad and as cliched as it is, I really hate brussel sprouts. The menu is fantastic. There's a lot to choose from, but I didn't find myself overwhelmed. The service is excellent here also. Polite, fast, attentive, but not overbearing.

The Down - You can't make reservations and this place gets quite busy so there can be a wait. I also feel cramped and claustrophobic when I'm here. It's noisier than I expect a place to be when I'm paying prices that are closer to high than moderate.
author: Nailah M.

description:
Come early!

The place is very reminiscent of what a barber shop & gentlemen's club would look like in back in the day. A lot of men and business people in the atmosphere. You can smell the quasi-Don Drapers in the air.

Our server was polite, attentive and charming.

The food was fantastic. The crab cake appetizer is top notch. The scallops main course was delicious! Even the grilled veggies were good. The blacken catfish is a good size and also tasty. My co-worker at every bite. I got the lamb in 4 slices. You have the option of 2 or 4, for medium rare (as I like it) it's best to get 4. It can be quite hefty with the chubby french fries and roast veggies, but the leftovers hold well. I don't recommend the mint jelly if you get the lamb, it takes away from the flavor.

For dessert, we got the chocolate mousse cake. It's decadent, rich and sinful. I loved it! 

I've heard a lot about this place for years and wasn't able to experience it till now. However, I will most definitely be back.
author: KJ M.

description: This is the first restaurant in SF, harking from the Gold Rush.   Great food and service.  Love the cioppino, their signature dish.   Order a martini with your meal and your SF adventure is complete.
author: Eric S.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmmmm...cioppino!

A few years ago, after my first cioppino experience, I decided that if I had a last meal here on earth, it would be a delicious bowl of Cioppino, chock-full of mouthwatering seafood. With a glass of Viognier (or shot of tequila...let's be honest, it's your last meal on earth, might as well go out with a bang).

As a birthday treat, my wonderful and thoughtful boyfriend, who knows this about me, treated me to a wonderful dinner at Tadich Grill (thanks to a recommendation from some of our friends). Arriving around 6:30, we were seated in a matter of minutes at a nice table by the window. I was surprised by how busy they got the longer we were there, especially for it being a Tuesday. (You can't make reservations, so I would definitely recommend arriving a bit before 7/dinner crowd to avoid long waits).

Shortly after we were seated, our nice waiter took our order, I had a glass of Pinot Noir and my bf had a nice pint of Bass. After nibbling on some chewy french bread goodness, we both received our piping hot bowls of cioppino. 

Buckle. Up.

SO good. All of the seafood is fresh and tasty, and the tomato-based broth is seasoned to perfection. They give you two pieces of buttered garlic bread (that you use to soak up the delicious broth of course) as well as a much-needed bib and soup spoon. We had not a drop to spare by the end of the meal, it was that good.

It's a great spot for both a small and large group. They have small tables for 2-4 people, but they also have large booths along one side as well as a long row of seats at the bar. Definitely a great place to with friends, out-of-towners or just your special someone.
author: Emily S.

description: Two words. Seafood. Cioppino. Order it now and you won't regret it. I agree about sitting at the bar - great service and banter. This place is a must!
author: Lindsey W.

description:
Walking in, you feel like you've stumbled onto the set of Mad Men. Men in suits sit at a long bar drinking old fashions and cocktails. The waiters wear traditional white serving coats, and all of them have white hair, if they have hair at all. The atmosphere is very lively.
