The menu contains mostly seafood. The Cioppino is top quality, and can't be beat anywhere. For my entree, I ordered the sea scallop with roasted Duck, sweet potatoes, and mushrooms. This dish has a savory rich taste, with a nice blend of flavors. However, it is VERY rich, so be mindful. 

This old school fish house sets a standard for traditional seafood dishes. However, don't come here looking for light  toothsome meals.
author: Miles H.

description:
Took a client here for lunch, his recommendation.  We both thought the food, service and ambiance was well worth checking out again.  

Didn't have drinks, but I usually see a lot of people there just after work.  I'm assuming they're good, given the number of seemingly happy campers.
author: Michael J.

description:
This has been a family favorite for 30 years. We read some of the negative Yelp reviews and knew it had to be because they hadn't ordered the cioppino . It has always been our favorite food anywhere---Just delicious!!

Tonight, we went there and were VERY disappointed. First we ordered an appetizer, and they wanted us to order our main dish right then. When we didn't, they said the kitchen was going to get behind. In other words, hurry up and order and get out of here.

The cioppino was not the same as we have been eating for years. It was okay, but we go there because it used to be fantastic.

Then, the bread that we have always loved, was not as good as usual.  Worse than that, when we asked for more bread to eat with the cioppino, they brought us BURNED bread. I don't know why I didn't send it back. 

This is not the same Tadich Grill that we know and love. If it comes back to the same quality it used to be, I will become a regular again.

For now, we will look for new restaurants.
author: Patricia B.

description: Food is 4 star but service is a 5 plus! History and vibe of restaurant are great! Great food, fair price. Cioppino is the house specialty!They close too early for us late night eaters.
author: Peggy J.

description: For true one of my favorite restaurant. in history. One of the olderst restaurants in frisco. I have meals for ages and place is reliably delish. I like open round serving approach. you can visit and meet strangers and for very people. People like to share conversation over meal. Hop for beer and vegetable meal was delish with steamed vegetables and my anxiety went away. The clockwork of my anxiety goes away when I eat at Tadich Grill. I like meat and have had pork chops and lamb choppy. Potatoes and pork chop. Pop or beer. amazing
author: James D.

description:
Happy fishin'.  All the credit goes to this joint, as conceivably the ideal choice for the corner-office option we ran mid-day today.  The crew brought our Prez/CEO here as the first-ever guest of OTLB (the Out to Lunch Bunch); a few morning moments of doubt and which-restaurant frenzy turned into the greatest time by making one simple choice.  Tadich in the clutch.  

Somewhere between breaking such great sourdough bread, right-on-the-spot chowder and menu pages of seafood of every stripe...literally...we got into a conversational food groove in an old-time booth - it was all good...no worries - my pan-seared red snapper with sauteed crab was a nice combo.  Not amazing, but much better than good.  Still gotta try the trout, maybe it's up there with the stellar ciopinno.  

The food is a small part of the review in this one, unique case - there's just something pleasantly amazing about everything else in the vibe of this joint.  How many other restaurants have come and gone on this block of California alone, since 1849?  The white-jacketed folks brought classic old-school service. Everything was chill...tho' too bad our boy didn't pick up the bill.  Still, the great spot helped us keep it real.  

Count this as my salute to a hundred and fifty-nine years of being the right place (I'm talkin' way before casual Friday was even dreamed of), Tadich Grill.

Today was even a sunny summer day in San Francisco (did they have those in olden Gold Rush days?).  The walk back to the tower was all that.  I felt lucky, how sweet the TGIF.

T-a-d-i-c-h = S-A-T-I-S-F-A-C-T-I-O-N
author: Ted R.

description:
Tadich Grill is one of those over-hyped places that doesn't disappoint.  Sat at the bar and ordered an Old Fashioned while I waited for my friend.  Lots of older people and business men having drinks and apps.  They don't take reservations so just come by have a drink while you wait.  The bartenders and waiters here are so flirty in an old school kind of way.  "Keep up that pretty smile sweetheart."  Bartenders are super knowledgeable, made my friend a great martini after he explained what he generally likes and I discovered a new drink "scofflaw".  Super tasty if you like bourbon.
The food is totally on point.  Great clam chowder, really thick and not too salty which is key for me.  The sourdough bread is delicious and perfect for dipping.  Love that there is just a pile of cut lemons on the table.  I had the lobster thermidor and the flavors were great and the lobster was cooked just right.  My friend's ciopinno looked tasty and had a ton of seafood and he must have liked it since he finished!
My only blah of the night and why I docked 1 star was because I didn't love the bread pudding which is suppose to be their signature dessert and I like having a good dessert to cap off the meal.  I guess you can't have everything...
author: Jen C.

description:
Simply the perfect restaurant.

I'm a relative latercomer to Tadich (and Sam's), having only discovered them in 1970.

Tadich has always been about good food, perfectly prepared, professionally served, in a simple yet elegantly aged long box of a place with the open kitchen at the end.

Don't expect quick seating if you walk in at prime lunch/dinner time.
Come before or after the crush instead.

To savor the atmosphere and observe the operation (the prep-work, the flow of a well-oiled business), sit at the counter on the right.

The fish will be simple and perfect.
The prices are fair.
And the fact that Tadich has been doing this for about 4 generations tells you that they deliver a great dining experience.
author: SETH F.

description:
I was invited by a couple of older guys of Italian heritage.   Tadich is hard-core old-school San Francisco.

Literally it was like I had discovered the inspiration for all the other classic seafood joints I've ever dined at over the years.  Only, I could see clearly how they had all mostly failed in one way or another - yet Tadich Grill delivered over and over.

This is not the place to visit while on a diet. Nor for those who don't really like seafood.

You can read all the other reviews for insight into their menu.  If you've got family in town and you want to take them to solid, old-school seafood join that can cater your bigger (or smaller) group for that high-end but still family friendly atmosphere... you've found it at Tadich.

[end]
author: jules h.

description:
Yay! My first 5-star review! I don't give those stars out unless they're deserved!

We came here the weekend before my birthday, and my husband planned everything as a surprise. We went to see a movie and then came here for dinner. I knew about this place but had never been before. Hubby said they didn't take reservations, but since we were just a party of 2 we thought we'd chance it. Got there about 6:30 on a Saturday evening. The place was PACKED. However, our name was taken right away and we were told it'd be about 30 mins. We expected that, so it's all good.

Went outside to make a few phone calls, came back in after 10 mins, stand against the wall, and we hear our name called! So even as busy as it was, we only waited 10 mins to be seated.

Our waiter was French, and very efficient. I wouldn't say the waiters are exactly friendly, but they do work hard, they are helpful. We ordered the oysters to start, which were yumminess in a shell. I had the fillet of sole, and hubby had some sort of steak. Everything was delicious. The only snafu we had was that hubby ordered a glass of wine and the waiter forgot to bring it. He did eventually remember (without us having to ask), and was genuinely apologetic about forgetting. Hubby is picky about cheesecake so he asked a question about it, and then decided to get something else. The waiter said "you want the cheesecake" - and it didn't disappoint!! I had the bourbon bread pudding and wish I had had the room to eat it all!

The menu is so big and diverse that you could come here a ton of times and not have the same meal twice. Definitely recommended!
author: Stephanie D.

description: This was our second trip to Tadich and for lunch this time.  We did not want to miss out before we headed home.  I only had the clam chowder since we had a big dinner planned.  The chowder was very good with lots of clams and not overloaded with potatoes.  I gave my experience 4 stars because of the server.  He was not very friendly and when we told him we were done - he made a comment about not getting very much to eat.  As I remember he said our meal was "a good start".  Great place for great seafood though.
author: Heather S.

description:
This is my family place. My dad is a huge fan and we've been coming to Tadich since I was a kid. LOVE this restaurant. Things to understand about this spot:

Yes, it is expensive, but the seafood is fresh and delicious! Don't be mad if you pay $20 for a burger here. It's not going to be good, because this is not a burger place. 

Things to eat here: cioppino, pan-fried patrale (pronounced: pah-trawl-ee) sole, crab louie, fresh oysters, pan-fried sand dabs, clam chowder, the fresh sourdough. Those are what they're best at, according to me. Also- their tartar sauce is the best you'll ever have. The recipe is secret unfortunately. 

Things to drink here: beer, white wine, martinis (gin), manhattans, old-fashioneds, gimlets, bloody marys, negronis. You could try to order something else, but I wouldn't recommend it (the ordering or the drink).

A note on the service: they are fast, they are good, they will make dry jokes if they like you. The servers here have been here forever, literally, I remember some of them from when I was a kid. They are friendly if they know you. They know my dad's name after roughly 20 years of being a patron, and I think that only developed after about 10 years. They are good at what they do so let them make recommendations for you!

The ambiance in this place is great, including the lace curtains and the private booths, don't be surprised when you see Willy Brown or some other politician/lawmaker/big wig, they all know where to find the best seafood.
author: Kat D.

description: Bustling atmosphere, yet attentive service.  Food was fantastic, especially the cioppino.  There aren't many seats for all those folks that crowd into the place, so expect a wait.
author: Reg T.

description: Beef tongue in madeira sauce, awesome!!!  Delicious and tender!!!  Served with two potatoes and garlicky spinach which I loved too! Lunch on 07/01/14.  Had calamari and fresh oysters.  Just okay for me.  I prefer "naked" calamari than breaded.  I like that the male waiters are older and their uniform somehow kinda reminded of pharmacists from the 1950's.
author: Kuting C.

description:
This was the first restaurant my boyfriend and I visited on our trip to San Francisco. Located in the Financial District, it almost seems like a little whole in the wall. It has an awesome vintage look to it and when you go inside, the place looks like its out of an old movie. Its very clean, but a little crowded if you're not sitting at the bar. The place is very fast paced and we must have been at least 20 years younger than everyone there, so it was a little intimidating at first, but the staff makes you feel right at home. 

The staff is very friendly and helpful as soon as you walk in. We were seated fairly quickly in a nice little corner by the window. We ordered crab cocktail and it was amazing! We then ordered the wrong thing (totally OUR fault), but they were happy to fix the problem and make what we meant to order afterwards (no cost to us!). We then ordered the New England Clam Chowder and the smoked salmon and both were fantastic. Everything was extremely fresh and cooked just right. 

The restaurant was a little pricey, but it was definitely worth it for the great quality food and unique atmosphere. One of the oldest restaurants in San Francisco, the Tadich Grill is a must-see for anyone visiting the city.
author: Kaitie S.

description:
What do you do when you get hungry and you would definitely blow above a .2 on a breathalizer after DYL? 

You go to Tadich.

We walked in and there was going to be a massive wait until we informed them that there was no need for a table, we could just try and not slide off the counter chairs during the meal. 

Lo and behold, they have OYSTERS. Now, Rob's been stuffing my face with oysters since I met him. And these weren't your run-of-the-mill can-fit-into-your-mouth-no-hard-time-swallowing oysters. Oh noes. You had to chew these bastards up and THEN swallow. Weird, though, how when I was in my obvious inebriated state I slurped those things down with NO problems, and ate precisely 6. YUM. I woke up the next morning craving them again, but I held back. 

We ordered a buttery Chard to go with the meal, and then ordered the sauteed prawns and crab. SO MUCH SEAFOOD. I'm not a seafood lover--did I just admit that outloud? I think I did. I love sushi, but the cooked kind. No, no. Not anymore. I loved the food here, it was so fresh you could taste the sea in every bite. We finished off the meal with a dessert--and wouldn't you know it, I can't remember for the life of me what it was. 

Oh yea! Sour Cream Cheesecake. Strange taste...but I love sour cream. I'm also lactose intolerant. YOU LACTIC BASTARDS.

Overall, I would say 4 solid stars of good food. Our waiter was wonderful, albeit a little slow in the beginning. He's from Austria! Turns out they make Arnie even more of a celebrity there than here? Awesome. We engaged in some more inebriated conversation, and left thoroughly satisfied. 

Matter of fact, I'm craving oysters right now. Mmm..nomnom :D
author: Jaime L.

description:
Being a SF icon apparently has its arrogant downside.  My tale: Got a gift certificate for Christmas --mailed from Tadich directly with no indication who the gift-giver was.  Called to find out. Went through 2 people - both impatiently rude - and finally left a message on the General Manager, Rick Powers', voicemail.  No return call so a few days later called again.  Once more went through someone with irritating 'attitude' who also said he didn't handle such things; so I asked to talk to the GM.  Was told he was busy and had 2 people in front of me so I left another message.  Still no call more than a week+ later. Hope the food leaves a better taste.
Suggestion to the Buich family (owners).  Run a class for Powers et al in customer courtesy and abandon the culture of studied disdain.  
Joe Moran - Orinda, CA
author: Joseph M.

description:
The grilled fish was good.  Broccoli and carrots were also good.

The ambiance feels festive.

A woman passed out 3 times and vomited next to me.  She was pale as a sheet.  Her friend was panicked and screamed for an ambulance.  The restaurant staff called 911, but then went on as usual and tried to downplay the emergency.  It seems they didn't want to scare the other patrons, but it actually made me feel that they didn't care enough about this woman.
author: Niniane W.

description: Very good food. My fave is the Seafood Cioppino. The broth is soooo good. It's worth every penny. This place gets really crowded so come in early. The Crab Salad is also good. I will definitely come back but on a special occasions only because it's too expensive! Lol
author: Jingle A.

description:
I went here expecting a great meal after reading all the yelp reviews. What I ended up with was some very mediocre calamari that had a long HAIR in it.  With the prices this place has I'd expect better.  The waiter's initial response was, "No one is perfect." Despite his curt statement, he eventually apologized and later took the meal off the bill- which is to be expected. Other than the clam chowder (which was good) - the service, the food and the prices range from poor to mediocre. 

Save your time and money- go somewhere else.
author: Malcolm D.

description:
I love absolutely everything about this place except the food and the service.  The service isn't just brusque, it's a mixture of seething anger and just-below-the-surface disdain that they've polished to a fine sheen for 100 years. Somewhere around 1953, they crossed the line between 'rude' and 'local flavor' and now are beloved for it. The portions are plentiful but I find the fish dishes heavy and bland. I could almost swear that my yellowfin tuna tasted angry.

Edit 9/04/07: They don't have Anchor Steam beer. They want props and kudos for being a San Francisco tradition, yet they can't serve Anchor Steam. I read in another review that the wine list was 'nice' when it couldn't be more pedestrian. I just don't get this place. It's Original Joes with blander food and less room to stand.

I love the Barbary Coast feel of the place...the amazingly long counter. I love the clientele. A mix of FiDi and lawyerly types. It could just be me though. The place is jammed with regulars so it can't possibly be as bad as I think is. Or maybe there's a 'The Emperor's New Yellowfin Tuna' thing going on here. Maybe with this Yelp review, the ruse is over.
author: Brian B.

description: I had a Dungeness Crab Cake with House Aioli as an Appetizer.  For Entrees, I had Chilean Sea Bass Filet Broiled, Lemon Butter and Prawn Garnish with Rice and Vegetables. Last but not least is the Cheese Cake. The Dungeness Crab Cake is to die for!  It's so delicious!  The crab cake combined with the aioli was definitely the dish to go for!  The Chilean Sea Bass with lemon butter is absolutely delicious!  The sea bass was well seasoned with the rice and the vegetables, a good combo.  The Cheese Cake was incredibly amazing dish I ever tasted.  I love the rich taste of the cheese cake with flour on top!  Definitely the best dessert I ever had!
author: David H.

description: Nice old school atmosphere with mature, knowledgable staff. But the seafood tends mostly towards the thoroughly-cooked or heavily-sauced, so best to veer towards the oysters on the half shell and the Caesar salad.
author: Kimba P.

description:
Cioppino...enough said.   The best ever in an old school San Francisco joint.

Do it!
author: Joe S.

description: Recent (all too brief) visit to San Francisco - thoroughly enjoyed Tadich. Wee bit expensive but food was very good.Definitely would recommend.
author: G D.

description:
Here it goes:

Thursday. 11.00 am. Best girlfriend's Birthday. Why not to go to a nice place for lunch? There were seven of us, we all work close buy.

Many people write about being sited very quickly - Truth!. Within a minute we were sited in a both that gave a little privacy and allowed us to enjoy the lunch without being bumped in by others.
Let's break it down a bit:

Our waiter, Yanis (hope I spelled it right) looked like that was not his first day at work :o); quite knowledgeable in the menu and specials.  Gave us lots of possible choices and we ended up with two orders of Olives to start and four cioppinos, two monkfish specials, and an eggplant special for the main dish. 

Olives:
Very dissent ones. Not bitter, seed in. Two pieces of garlic bred on the bed of fresh greens were accompanying olives. 


Cioppino:
WOW!!! Close to the one that my brother-in-law makes (he makes the best one). AWESOME! 
LOTS of shredded crab, fish, scallops, mussels, and only 3 shrimps (to someone who wrote that there are mostly bay shrimps). Two pieces of garlic bread... and whole lot of enjoinment. A bit to much of "solid parts" of cioppino were on the plate; that made it into a seafood stew at the end. Different experience of a cioppino. Loved it!!!

Monkfish Special:
My wife liked it a lot. And believe me, she knows her fish :o) 
I tried a piece: flaky, tender, no fishy taste, with a bit of a smocked flavor. Mashed potato and a sauce was a nice addition to it.

Eggplant special:

Can't say much. The piece that I have tried was a good piece of a fried eggplant. Not oily, nothing fancy. 
There were also five jumbo shrimps on the top covered in a sauce. (I have posted a picture).

The end result: 222$ without tips. 
Was it worth it?  YES, YES, YES!!!
Will we go there again? Definitely!!! Might be not for every day lunch or dinner, but this would absolutely make a very fine addition to any special occasion.    

Definitely would recommend it to anyone who does not expect to get a great food for freaking McD price.
   

P.S. By noon the pace was packet to its roof with its hungry for good food customers.
author: Alex S.

description:
Solid four stars

pros: upscale old-school atmosphere, excellent seafood, great service, free bread is good, you're off to a good start 

cons: bit pricey ($20+ for entree), no free refills on soda, can't seat your party until everyone is there

Order the sand dabs or the grilled or broiled rex sole, and the clam chowdahh.

It's weird, as I started to eat my food, I thought it's good but not great... and suddenly i was wiping my plate spotless with the bread... I think what makes Tadich Grill good is that the meal is cooked so well that while the flavors are there, its not overpowering so much you can't finish your meal
author: Noah P.

description:
Trying to catch up on reviewing...

I went here for the first time with my sig other a few months ago and he was already a big fan but I was also curious bec/ I had just watched an episode on the food network where that Mo guy reviewed them for their cioppino. I was still in search of the perfect cioppino experience since my best one 15yrs ago somewhere in Marin county but couldn't remember the name of the joint since I wasn't living in the area at the time. 

Let's just say, it's what you love about old-school places... where the waiters wear white coats with ties and know how to treat their customers. The menu is impressive in its variety but I knew what I wanted to try since I watched TV. My honey got a pasta dish which he enjoyed. We sat at the bar - a big long bar that wraps around like a racetrack in the middle of the restaurant - with bar stools. You hang your coat on the rack behind you. As the night wore on, there were folks lining up by the racks. 

The cioppino was excellent. Chock full of fresh seafood and I like enough sauce with my cioppino and it did not disappoint. Enough to sop up with the bread.

It's not gonna be like the hip trendy modern type of place that may be of the moment and then disappear a year later. This place has been here for years and remain I'm sure for years to come. 

Glad to have found a reliable place for great cioppino!
author: Kuishingal F.

description: We wanted something close to the hotel so we checked out yelp and it didn't disappoint.  Hubby and I walked in and found ourselves among the locals, clearly a good sign.  We sat at the bar, took in the atmosphere and enjoyed conversation with various other patrons.  Such a unique place and interesting they have stayed true to only having male servers.  We had fun, great food and impeccable service.  Highly recommend and will go back.
author: Dawn P.

description:
Always loved this place, then got treated badly.  Their clams sucked.  I had to spit them out.  It took hours to get the taste out of my mouth.  

When i asked to return them, they insulted me.   

Nothing else that was ordered seemed good.
author: Thomas D.

description: There is no other place like Tadich's. When I got my first exec job in the City, I took my Dad to a 2 hr martini lunch to celebrate his faith in me. I love the wait-staff and the restaurant's unflagging dedication to SF tradition. I love this place.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Came here last Thursday night hoping to play our luck at securing a cozy table for 2.  They don't take reservations, so we were prepared for a long wait at the bar, but we were seated within 5 minutes of walking in.  After Anthony Bourdain made an appearance here for No Reservations, I knew I had to try it (obsessed? Who's obsessed?) and I'm glad I listened to the silver fox, who rarely ever steers me wrong.  

We started off with a bowl of Boston style clam chowder and a dozen Manila clams in garlic butter.  The clams were surprisingly big, not only in size but also in taste.

I had the Mediterranean broiled sea bass and E had some halibut dish that was cheesy, spinach-y, and yummy.  Tadich is very generous with their portions.  We were both stuffed after our meal and we pride ourselves in our gluttonous ways.

I loved that the waiter warned me about my order, telling me that my entree would be a  whole fish - head, tail, and all.  He asked if I'd be OK with that, as if I hadn't grown up eating fish eyes and peering over the fish counter in 99 Ranch to watch the butchering of many a fish with sheer delight.  I politely offered E one of my fish eyeballs, but his eyes widened in disgust while I happily munched on my fish carcass.  Who says chivalry is dead?

This place seems like a no-frills, no-nonsense, warm-you-up-on-a-cold-day kind of restaurant.  I'd definitely come back to explore the rest of the menu.
author: Jen L.

description: Always a treat to come to Tadich Grill.  The waiters are so professional and wonderful.  Very classy place.  And fresh fish is always a specialty.  We had the calamari and mixed olives for appetizer.  For entrees we had the crab cakes-excellent!!  The cioppino, a specialty, was delicious.  But the favorite was the seafood saute.  Very nice combination of seafood and the sauce was wonderful.  Most definitely will return again.
author: Patti A.

description: Loved the atmosphere and the service. It was my first time ever having cioppino and it was great. The sour dough bread did not impress me at all, which is why I took one star away. Pricing was reasonable given the location and type of food it is.
author: Jordan F.

description:
Another heart-breaking review...

Took my friend to Tadich last pm for a pre b-day dinner... he was coming off of Bart so this would be totally convenient. And we both love old school spots that retain their charm/decor. Got in early, had some good Grey Goose martinis ($11 each!) at the bar and got a table fairly quickly (note the positive stars: strong drinks, fast seating & decor).

Now onto the food:

Started off with a Caesar salad... said $10 on the menu but was $14.95 on the bill. Why? Because we got the large but wasn't informed of the up charge. And not worth either price... the lettuce tips weren't crisp and the dressing tasted like a bottled buttermilk generic one, with no hints of garlic nor anchovy. There were some random anchovies on top which gave the salad the only flavor it had. No fresh ground pepper was brought nor offered to us (but saw it offered to other tables).

Next up were our main courses: the pre b-day boy had the cioppino, which had two huge pieces of bread on the side. These were burnt thru so he couldn't eat and instead used the sourdough on our table to mop up the broth. Poor guy: the white fish was overcooked/unedible, the clams overdone and crab on top cold, with the broth being mediocre.

My main course was one of the daily specials: seared salmon and ahi combo. Now to me, seared means the outside is lightly cooked...the ahi was cooked to the point of being grey and rubbery, with the salmon uneven (one side seared, the other dry). This was drowned by a bad Asian inspired sauce that should of been left off a well prepared fish. Oh wait, now I understand why...

Not once during our meal were we asked "how is the food" so we had no chance to say "awful." And when we didn't order dessert, we were given the bums rush out. In looking at our bill ($120 for one app, two main courses, 3 glasses of Zin and tip) I saw that there was a spot to comment about your meal and give to the maitre d'; I wrote my comments about the food and handed it him when leaving. His response "Oh no... you must be joking" then went to tend to some others waiting for their table. And overpriced, inedible meal.
author: Missy D.

description: We came here as we heard the sea food here is one of the best in town. The food is not bad, but the service is really good!
author: Ricki Y.

description: This place was very good and well worth the hour and a half wait. The space is pretty small but surprisingly hold alot of people. The food was beyond what I thought and I thoroughly enjoyed my experience there.
author: Kiley T.

description:
We come for the cioppino, and every now and again, I'll try something other than cioppino.  I think the last time I went non-cioppino, it was a seafood saute, which was quite nice.

Mental note to self: skip the dessert, even if the bread pudding sounds good. 

Love the candor of the wait staff, and we're all for sitting at the bar and avoiding the long wait for a table.
author: .caroline. ..

description: THE BEST STEAK (FILET MIGNON) I HAVE EVER HAD. Having said that we also came to this spot after a friend recommended it. We ordered the crab cakes (entrée) and filet (entrée) and ate the bread which was very nice and fresh. To drink we had vodka martinis and a few beers. The waiter was very nice and professional and all the wait staff was dressed in old time looking suits. The feel of the place was relaxed, but very upscale. The dress of the patrons ranged from tourists in jeans and a t-shirt to business men and women in full suits and cocktail dresses or work attire. The cheesecake desert was absolutely every bit as good as the meal and was worth the calories, every single one. If you plan to come at dinner time would recommend having a reservation. Also, a helpful tip this place is closed on Sunday so don't try to make plans to eat there on that day! One last thing; the booths were actually little private nooks that looked like at one time they had a curtain that would close you in so it did feel very intimate even though it was quite busy.
author: Krysten P.

description: This place is a must-visit for us on trips to San Francisco. The place is a classic, as it has been around forever. The food is beyond delicious. We always get the clams in garlic and they are amazing. I recommend getting there early - after lunch, but before the dinner rush - otherwise you will be waiting a really long time. The only reason I am giving this place 4 stars and not 5, is that the service is not great. The waitstaff behind the bar acts kind of pretentious and I don't care for attitude with my meal. If the food wasn't so good, I'd stay away. But I can't stay away from the clams. They are just too good!
author: Jill Z.

description: Tadich Grill has been my favorite restaurant in San Francisco for the last 30 years.  I had very special guests in town from New York recently who I introduced to Tadich Grill.  And guess what, they saw Tony Bennett come in for dinner.  New Yorkers are not easily impressed but they loved the atmosphere, the ambiance, the hustle/bustle, the food and the authenticity of Tadich Grill.  I have had everything on the menu over the years but seem to order the grilled salmon more often than not.  Every item is perfectly cooked, the salads are simple and wonderful, the portions are generous (always some leftovers for my German Shepherd Dog), and the service is impeccable.  I never tire of going to this restaurant.  I can always depend upon their consistency to please the most discerning of my clients too.  This restaurant is good for romantic dinners, business lunches and dinners and meeting friends for dinner.
author: Paula M.

description:
I was truly disappointed in the food at Tadich Grill. It's VERY old school, and not what I was expecting in this area. Service was excellent. Maybe if I'd been hungry enough to order the cioppino, I'd be a happier camper.

I had a crab cake as well as an avocado salad for lunch. Both had more butter/oil/fat in them than I usually eat in a week. In fact, when I stuck my fork in the salad, the cucumber slice slid right off the oily mound of iceberg onto the floor. Very hard to spear the avocado as well, because it was too slippery with oil to get onto the fork. The lone tomato slice in the salad was the cellophane/tasteless variety my mother used to serve us back in Buffalo NY, not the fresh, flavorful, local type I've enjoyed at other spots in this area.

The crab cake, while well-made and with a delicious spicy tomato relish on top, was atop an unappealing sauce that was both creamy and oily at the same time. Additionally, the cake seemed to be bound with butter, as it, too, was incredibly slippery, both inside and out. 

Altogether a let down. I would not recommend this spot to anyone other than the type of people who like old-school food.
author: Martha R.

description:
3.75 stars

Tadich is a throwback dinner of sorts. Laid out with the left side offering booths and 2 tops, the right side offering tons of counter seats, ppthe middle is the "bar" or where all the waitstaff do their thing from taking orders, clearing tables, and where tons of sourdough loaves reside.

It's an efficient operation, made to churn people quickly - that's the part I didn't like because it felt so quick. From beginning to end our dinner only took 1 hour. That's odd for a nice seafood / steak grill no?

Anyway, when we arrived, there were 6 couples ahead of us in line for a booth so we just hopped onto 2 empty stools on the long bar counter. The table was laid out with sourdough bread, butter, condiments every 2 seats apart. Very 'mechanical'.

We started with white clam chowder (cup $5.50 or so). Very good. Creamy, bites of clams, bites of potato, celery, parsley maybe. Very classic style with the right consistency. VERY filling.

When my Cioppino ($29.95) arrived, I was feeling a bit full. The Cioppino was BIG. Loaded with bay shrimp, 2 large scallops, 2 large shrimps, 4 clams, and tons of fish chunks, all topped with fresh crab meat - it was delicious. Tomato-y, garlicky, and well seasoned, the 2 pieces of (over)toasted garlic bread helped sop up all that goodness.

My friend EF had the Grilled Chilean Seabass ($29.95) served with rice pilaf, and brussel sprouts. Very clean in presentation and cooking - meaning none of that heavy sauce, though there was some creamy dill sauce near his seabass. The seabass didn't need it though. A very generous fillet of seabass was grilled perfectly. Not overdone which is key. Rich and buttery, those are the natural characteristics of the fish that were maintained.

A bit touristy, the crowd that is, Tadich Grill serves up tasty fair. Worth experiencing at least once.
author: Cindy W.

description:
I really wanted to like this place...the simple grill of the fish with some rice or potatoes.  It didn't tickle my fancy, but I can see how it can be appreciated.  

What really turned me away was that their cioppino gave me the runs.  That's not excusable for a restaurant that prides itself on its seafood.
author: Chanson H.

description:
Again, one of those places I'd walk by during my lunch break and wonder about. I finally got to eat there for a work holiday luncheon. We were allotted $50 each, which is alright with me! Once you walk in, you don't see any tables, just the bar so I thought we were sitting there. Well, the tables are in the front and all along the side. They're all hidden and kind of sectioned off. I felt like I was in a train car. Definitely has the old timey feel. It's one of San Francisco's oldest restaurants and I'm pretty sure most of the staff has been working there their whole lives! Service was good thought, prompt and they always made sure we had water.

I ordered the lobster thermidor off the specials menu. For $23.95, you get a big ass, huge lobster tail, steak fries, and soup or salad. Very good deal consider the portion. This is the first time I've ever had lobster thermidor in a restaurant (my mom tries to make it but she got the recipe out of my 4th grade class cookbook) and it tasted pretty good. The lobster pieces were a tad overcooked but I won't complain because I love lobster, no matter the state it's in! The clam chowder was pretty good, not too much on the creamy side but had lots of clam chunks. I also ordered the bourbon bread pudding which was very sweet but delicious! 

I'd like to come back to try that Hangtown Fry because it's what Tony Bourdain ate and anything with oysters is alright with me!
author: Tatiana D.

description:
No complaints about the food we tried.  It was good as I had expected it to be.  Legendary hype, after all.  All of the seafood was fresh, flavorful, and servings were eh,...sufficient.  The crab cocktail, is not to be missed.  

Atmosphere was very formal and a bit too stuffy for my comfort level.  Maybe that's because I like L & L plate lunches but well, Tadich does seem filled with suits who can afford the tab.  Power to the man.  A few in the crowd were a bit too anxious to see and be seen. Tourists, maybe.  Now is that any way to enjoy a meal?  

Glad I went at least once, service was quite polite, maybe we were just lucky?  

As an institution, Tadich is at least once in a lifetime try. Even if I could afford to, I doubt if I'd go there often though.  C'mon!  It's San Francisco!  You can get fresh seafood cooked well ANY PLACE.  Even in Chinatown.
author: O O.

description: Hadn't been in years. Stopped in for lunch because they open 30 mins earlier than everyone else. Ordered the classic lunch.. Cup of Boston clam chowder and sole. Had it grilled. If you want a traditional SF meal, Tadich will deliver. Waiter was way nicer than I remember. ;)
author: Dave H.

description: Very fun place and classic SF environment.  Cioppino was out of this world as were the oyster rockefeller.
author: Tony U.

description:
Tadich Grill is a classic- one of those "if walls could talk" sort of places. In the many times  H and I have been in San Francisco, we had never been to this storied institution. When we were planning our most recent SF trip, I mentioned that I wanted a bowl of Cioppino during our time there. I figured that the Tadich was the place. Thanks to Yelpers for confirming my choice. 

We went on a cold wet Saturday night. The placed was packed. We joined other eager diners waiting patiently in a long line that ran the length of the north wall. Surprisingly, we were seated within 20 minutes. (I think being a party of 2 helped.)

Our waiter appeared at our table with bread in hand just after we were seated. He was attentive and pleasant, with a sly sense of humor. Since we came for the Cioppino (and dry martinis), we ordered right away. 

Sipping our martinis, H and I took in the ambiance of the room and anticipated the great meal to come. We were not disappointed. Our waiter arrived with two huge bowls of Ciopinno piled high with fish and shellfish. It was so delicious-- the tomato-based broth was seasoned perfectly and the seafood was tender and fresh. Tried as we might, we could not come close to finishing. Next time we will probably shared a bowl. Believe me, there will be a next time. 

Cheers to the Tadich Grill!
author: Lisa M.

description: Wonderful food! We both had the creamy chowder to start - they have a few different kinds of chowder though, so I would double-check to make sure you're ordering what you're expecting to get. My husband had the seafood coppino with garlic bread, which he loved! I had the petrel sole, which between the starter soup and the bread was more than enough food. This is one of the few fish the waiter said was filleted on the menu, so again, check with the staff if you're looking for filleted or whole fish. The service was excellent, attentive, and friendly. We will definitely return on our next visit to San Francisco.
author: Eman K.

description: I work at Embarcadero 3 and typically do not have the luxury of taking a long lunch but a client from the Peninsula was in the city last Friday and insisted we meet there for lunch since she hadn't eaten at Tadich in "donkey years".  I decided to give this place a try, to be honest, in my 11 years of working in FIDI, I have never eaten here -- there are too many other good hipper restaurants in the area for me to ever think about this place.  And now I know why.  We arrived at 12 pm and the place was already pretty full with dinosaurs in suits (who still wears suits on Casual Friday?) and tourists (to the Italian couple sitting next to us, I want to apologize for the slop you half ate...and never trust a Fodor's Guide again!) so I tried to keep a positive thought and said to myself, "hey, maybe I have been missing something all of these years".  But alas no.  This restaurants lives in an arrested state going back 40 years and the food was just god awful.  I decided to play it safe and ordered their broiled salmon - the only thing I can say that is nice is that it was a large piece of salmon.  Bland, bland, bland and overcooked to boot.  I left 3/4 of it on my plate.  My client had the crab louie and crab cakes to start.  She said it was fine, until she pulled out a rather long strand of hair from her crab cake.  It just turned both our stomachs.  Service was not the friendliest, didn't even asked if we liked our lunch even though it was obvious we each left 75% on the plate.  The best part of our meal was the bread and our diet cokes.  Take your money next door to Perbacco or if your willing to pay a little more go to Pabu.
author: Hannah H.

description:
We decided to try Tadich Grill because we are always up for eating cioppino. My husband ordered the Ceasar salad and cioppino. Our boys (6 years old and 2 years old) ordered pasta with red sauce and pasta with butter and Parmesan cheese and calamari and I ordered the cioppino. 

The cioppino was as good as everyone mentioned in the Yelp reviews. The broth was flavorful and light and the seafood was hearty. I did think it was too salty. My husband also thought the cioppino and Ceasar salad were good. The pasta with butter and Parmesan cheese was devoured but the pasta with red sauce was untouched. We thought the calamari's breading could have been lighter. 

The service was good. I would recommend Tadich Grill.
author: Sue U.

description:
My solace, my meditation, my Tadich Grill.

Usually I come here during an especially hectic workday, sit at the bar, bring my book, and enjoy the hour of solitude and consistent service I receive. No small talk, no explaining why I am here alone eating clam chowder and drinking irish coffee, no patrons pestering me with needy conversation starters. Just bread, chowder, and a delightful assortment of background noise from the clinking of glasswear and kitchen sounds.  What more can you ask for? The clam chowder is delicious, the bread is always plentiful, the service is impeccable. 

it is all exactly as it should be.

addendum: I recently came here with other people for the first time and had a delightful experience sitting in one of the the mafioso-esque tall booths. It was all the same, great service, great food, great ambiance.
author: LeeAnne T.

description: Our dinner here was almost perfect.  We didn't even have to wait!  The only negative was the blast of cold air that would surge into the restaurant every time the door was opened, but at least we were a little ways from it.  The service and meal were indeed perfect.  You would think from the name "Grill", this was a steak house.  Steaks and chops actually are a tiny corner of the menu.  Most of the menu was fresh seafood!    But we ordered steaks (which were very good).  What I most appreciated was the thing restaurants usually mess up -- vegetables!  Their vegetables were absolutely perfect, crunchy but not hard.  So, if you want to treat yourself to dinner at the oldest restaurant in San Francisco (founded in 1850 or so) and have a REALLY good meal, this is the place to go for sure.
author: Dave C.

description: For an up-scale restaurant, their service really sucks! I took my wife there for lunch. The waiter is not polite. It made us feel not welcome at all. For the kind of price they charge, I was expecting a much better experience. The waiters there are old and snobbish. I'll take my business else where from now on.
author: Jian M.

description:
It's a fish  and sea foods restaurant. You are waiting for something very fine and delicious. It's poor in flavor.
The fish is frozen!!!! scandalous in this type of restaurant where the bill is more salty than the sea!
author: Sylvie S.

description: I work very close to Tadich Grill and wanted to order a salad to go, the Manager Paul was extremely rude and asked me to come in to the restaurant and order my salad because he was "too busy" to take my order over the phone. He complained that they were in the middle of the lunch rush (i called at 1145) Im not quite sure how big of a deal it is for him to place the order, rather than have me walk to the restaurant, walk in, place it with him and he would still have to go through the same process.  I think Paul was very rude and unfortunately I will not dining here. Please work on your staffs manors
author: Leslie M.

description: We were at harringtons around the corner with a bachelor party and it was awful. stumbled upon this place and it was awesome. Pete was our bartender and immediately greeted us like friends. Highly recommended
author: Scott H.

description: Thought we'd give Tadich another visit--it had been 30 years since we were last there. Same decor and funky waiters. However most disappointed with the expensive (mediocre) sand dabs and to add insult to injury, had to pay extra for "skinny" fries. It will be another 30 years before we return. Great clam chowder.
author: don M.

description:
My experience at Tadich Grill was so bad I joined Yelp JUST to write a review of it. 

Tadich's was my husband's favorite San Fran restaurant when he was a kid, and when I made my first trip to San Francisco this last week he insisted we go. 

We were seated at a table for two and had to scream at each other to be heard.  The waitstaff ignored us for about 15 minutes before anyone stopped by our table to ask for our drink order.  The wine list was meh - only one half-bottle was offered on the menu. 

And the food.  Oh, gods, the food was gross.  My husband had a stiff breaded veal chop with a side of overcooked spaghetti topped with a sauce that can only be described as canned.  The taste was blah, the noodles squishy and there wasn't enough sauce to mask the texture.  

My meal - a creole casserole with shrimp and oysters was truly nasty.  It was served in a shallow bowl and was a gross soupy mixture of flaccid shrimp, orange water, a few grains of rice and a Chef Boyardee-looking sauce.  And I shouldn't forget the oysters.  I took one bite of an oyster and thought, "Wow - what a weird texture."  The next day I realized that the weird texture was...  Rotten oyster.

So Thanks, Tadich's.  I got to see all of San Francisco's finest hotel, tourist, retail, restaurant, fast-food, public, and ferry bathrooms all over the city.  Truly a memorable visit and one restaurant experience that I have been able to enjoy for five full days.  Truly a lasting impression. 

p.s. Thanks for the weight loss.  I look super.
author: Angela M.

description: I would have given this  5 stars  but when we sat at the bar, for drinks only, I got the 3rd degree from an old fart, John. Evidentally, I took too long ordering my drink so he kept telling me to hurry because he was due to go on break. Really? How rude! John did make it to his break and we were served by Pete. Pete, you are amazing! Funny, storytelling, fun younger guy, kept us laughing. Please teach the old codgers there some respect! And let them know they can smile too!
author: R. B.

description: Okay, so I am from the Midwest and don't get to eat super fresh seafood on a normal basis.  Tried this restaurant in default because Sotto Mare was closed for the week and I wanted to get some Cioppino.  Tadich did not disappoint.  One of the best Ciopinnos I have tasted.  The food was very tasty and hearty.  Do go for the Cioppino and garlic bread....dip in the broth, but also try some of the crab and fish dishes.  I tried to go back because I enjoyed it so much but my wife made me try a new place in SF.  The atmosphere is a bit unique but I fully enjoyed sitting at the bar/working table.  (The waiters are also bartenders and dish up some of the food, pretty cool)
author: Mike J.

description: Being the oldest restaurant in SF, nothing is like the old school Tadich Grill atmosphere. They don't take reservations but it is worth the somewhat long wait. The clam chowder is excellent! Good for lunch and dinner, good selection on the menu. Possible family dinner as well as night at the bar. The bar has a great selection and the bartender is superb! The Tadich Grill is a great spot!
author: Matt C.

description:
Old school fine dining restaurant. We went here for lunch on a Friday and it was PACKED! Still surprises me that people can spend $30-$40 per person on lunch everyday...wow! Well, it is in the financial district. I was craving seafood while in SF, so thanks to fellow Yelpers, we decided to try this place out.

The Clam Chowder was AWESOME! SOOOOO GOOD! It was our favorite menu item that we ordered. We got the Chilean Seabass with broccoli & rice and the Lobster Thermidor with broccoli & french fries. Both entrees were great, but the sides were mediocre. :( Service was good. They really get you in and out of there fast.

Oh, complimentary bread was yummy, but served cold. Warm bread & room temperature butter get brownie points, and they not. :( Ice tea was not that great either.

So many places to eat in the area, but if we go back, we'll probably get the Clam Chowder again, and try the Cippino.
author: Joanne W.

description: After toiling as a postdoctoral scientist for a couple of years, my girlfriend got a great paying job and she wanted treat me to a restaurant of my choice.  Based on highly rated Yelp reviews, I chose Tadich Grill.  When we first walked in, the place smelled more like urine than the ocean.  Nonetheless, we sat down and ordered. She had the sea bass and I had the cioppino.  Perhaps the food would have tasted good, had the service been better.  I give the place one star for food and none for service.  The server did not once ask how the food was.  I was quite hungry and had a hankering for rice so grabbed the server's attention to ask if they have a side order of rice.  We didn't ask for the price, simply the availability.  The server rudely replied, that's $8, as though he judged that we couldn't afford an eight dollar side dish.  The wardrobe my girlfriend had on cost more than a thousand so $8 is pocket change.  But I digress.  After we ate, my girlfriend took out her wallet to pay.  The check had not been given to us but the server was ready to grab the credit card from her hand.  She asked to see the bill first.  The server walked away with an attitude and returned with the check.  But rather than leaving the checkbook on the table, he opened it for her to see but would not hand it to her.  It was quite a bizarre experience.  We are generous tippers--at a fine restaurant with good service, we tip as high as 40%.  Otherwise we tip 20%-25%.  This is the first time we tipped less than 10%.  We would not revisit this place.  We recommend that you ask for a good server or simply go to another restaurant.  Seafood places are dime a dozen in the Bay Area.  Great services are not easy to find but surely one can find a place with better service than Tadich Grill.
author: Rolo R.

description:
Parents were nice enough to take us here!!!

Hits and Miss:

Hit: Dungeness Crab Cake, because it was packed with fresh, sweet dungeness crab, without a bunch of unnecessary, breading, mayo, etc.  It was just pure crab, perfectly seasoned, and perfectly, lightly pan seared on both sides.  

Hit:  Manhattan Clam Chowder.  Hard to find Manhattan Clam Chowder, let alone one this good.  Do yourself a favor and order a cup or five.

Hit:  Wife's Cioppino.  Wonderful fresh fish and shellfish, both large and in charge; bulging out of the broth.  The brodo was fantastic, rich, hearty, savory, and tasted as wonderful as it smelled.

Miss: My Charbroiled Halibut Steak.  Sounded promising, was fresh tasting, but it was overcooked and dry.  Now I know why they give you a cup or so of tartar sauce to wash it down with.  

Parenthetically, sad that my wife ordered the better entree.  Usually, it is the other way around, but I guess can't win them all.  

To Sum it Up:  If I worked in FIDI, I could see myself coming here, sitting at the counter, ordering a cup of the Red Chowder, a crabcake, and calling it a job well done.
author: ed e.

description:
I had reason to go to the ATM next to Tadich grill and lo and behold there was a parking space right in front. It was "now or never" and we decided to have supper here. The wait was short and we had a table and our waiter was one of those in the photos on their website. Tadich is  an old time experience. If I did not cook at home and bake frequently from sour dough to rye bread and cakes as a hobby, I might think the food is superb. Its okay, I think the experience of dining in this old place is more interesting that the food. 
    When one goes to such a place, its really not de rigeur to criticize anything as this will ruin the experience. But I find the cooking nothing special, its been perfected to serve as many customers as possible with the least amount of fuss. My niece had one of the fish dinners, I had a steak. What can be said about french fried potatoes, as long as they come hot out of the fryer they are going to be good anywhere one goes. The drinks are old fashioned, thank God, and the waiters are still trying to be discovered by a talent agent. My niece, who is 50 and I at 74 don't laugh at being called "young man" and "young woman."  We live in the city same location 40 years and are not exactly rubes looking up at the tall buildings. With so many old time places disappearing, visit the Tadich grill if you want to experience a fast disappearing experience of an era gone by.
author: Andrew B.

description: We arrived a party of 3 at 6 pm on a wednesday evening.  we had to wait 1 hr and 15 minutes for a table which is just ridiculous.  I did have the cioppino which was delicious but nothing is worth waiting that long for.
author: Sal M.

description:
Tadich's is on my top five favorite restaurants in the world list.  It's old school, San Francisco, been there since before Grandpa was born, and will hopefully outlive us all.  The seafood is superb, I've always had fantastic waiters -- albeit with personality -- and I love seeing the famous San Francisco twins!  They're two little old ladies who are identical twins, and dress identically.  They're San Francisco icons and I think I've seen them everytime I've eaten at Tadich's -- naturally, the wait staff treats them like royalty.  

As a side note, after reading the other reviews -- this is old school, not hip, and pricey, not a bargain eatery.  If you're looking for a chill, classy supper to last a few hours and don't mind it being a little pricey, this is awesome.
author: Tasha D.

description:
we wanted sand dabs for late lunch. got to taddich at 3pm. greeter was a very terse
unwelcoming nazi type. plenty of nice tables,not a busy time/maybe 5 patrons. seated us at a tiny table at the extreme back of rest. waiter immediately demanded to know if we wanted water and tossed a plate of bread at us.wifey went to b-room, waiter  insisted on an order while she was gone.i ask to wait-waiter stormed away.
we decided to leave. went to john's grill-- greeted nicely, got a nice table, got a great waiter(michael), calamari dore-fantastic-for half the price as taddich stuff.
GO TO JOHN's.
author: Jim R.

description:
I've only been in to the Tadich to have a drink after work, so this is not a comprehensive review.

Old School!  All of the good and bad connotations of the term are exemplified in the Tadich Grill.  There is no mistaking that it is the oldest restaurant in the city.

The men behind the long wooden bar - and they were all men - are older, I'd guess averaging 50, with white coats, strong voices and a no nonsense demeanor.   

We watched them make a number of Old-Fashioneds, the bourbon cocktail, and they made it in the sickly-sweet traditional way, and always holding the muddler upside down.

We were just drinking whiskey neat, so it's hard to screw that up, but I almost spit mine out when I heard the bartender ask a customer if she wanted her Coors Light "in a can, you know, the classy way."
author: Quinn S.

description:
I had lunch here in March 2011 and a dinner in 2004.  It's a standard in SF.  Great place to go for atmosphere and that "classic" feel.

They have a huge menu with great fish and steaks.  I would rate it a 4.5 star for the food.  I am rating it a 3 star for the service.  This gives me a 4 star overall.

They don't take reservations which really is a pain.  However make sure you get a bloody mary while waiting for your table.
author: Eric S.

description: My first time in San Francisco and this is the restaurant our friend took us to.  It was a very busy restaurant and took a very long time to get a table but I am so thankful we waited.  I ordered the Seafood Cioppino which was absolutely wonderful.  The four of us were all pleased with the food that was ordered.  Would recommend Tadich to anyone visiting San Francisco!
author: T S.

description:
Here's my perfect lunch...

1:30-2:00pm ish.... after the suits have gone back to the office...

Sitting at the counter...

An order of the Cioppino and a glass or two or three of a great California White..

3:30 ish.....head back to hotel for power nap.
author: T W.

description:
This is one of the best restaurants of its type in the nation. It's "type" is old school. The building is old, the decor is spare - but unique. The bar is very long and has most of its seats reserved for people dining (not for drinks only - people just there for drinks have their own area of the bar). There are no TVs. This place was around 100 years before they were invented. 

The bar a huge plus for couples and single business travelers (like me) because the bar seats (not stools) are fixed to the floor, swivel and are comfortable. The spacing is perfect - you get just enough room, but I've gotten into conversations with the people to the right and left of me. For larger parties there are very old school booths. I eat here every time I come to SF - it's by far the best single-person dining experience I've ever had. 

The food is four stars - it's very simple. I always have an appetizer or salad and the cioppino, which is phenomenal. However, the oysters are opened in advance and iced - fine, but I prefer a more freshly shucked oyster. None of the other dishes I've observed are all that fancy. On the other hand, every other appetizer I've had was very good - for example, the salad with crab and bay shrimp shines because of the seafood. 

Drinks are old fashioned. If you want a chocatini, go someplace else. However, a simple martini is served quickly and perfectly done. 

The service is also old school. I try to sit at the same part of the bar where the same waiter is always there. He's probably in his late 50s, has a middle-European accent (as many of the waiters do) and is OUTSTANDING. He's not in my face, but the minute my water is half full, it gets filled up. If I want a second martini, I don't have to remind him that it's beefeaters up with a twist. When I finish every drop of the cioppino, which I do every time, he heartily congratulates me for doing a good job. (old school waiters evaluate their customers) The serving area behind the bar is BUSY and manly. The staff wears starched white cotton jackets and there is some sort of rank system with the number and type of pens in each man's chest pocket. When your drink is put down on the cocktail napkin, the restaurant logo faces you - as it is when your entre plate is put down in front of you. Your water is perfectly iced. Unlike the trendy restaurants, the staff is not up their own @ss - these guys are professionals.

I travel a lot on business and I tend not to rate many mediocre restaurants - so most of my reviews are good. If you like old school places that do what they do so well, don't miss the Tadich Grill.
author: Ben C.

description:
Four stars on Yelp?  Really??  I'm bracing myself for verbal assaults from the community, but my recent trip to Tadich Grill was nothing short of sub-par food, unfriendly wait staff and a "meh" place to put my stuff down for the evening.

I heard of Tadich Grill before in passing, and this recent evening we were in the Financial District and wanted to grab a quick bite to eat at a sit-down restaurant.  I suggested Tadich Grill because I heard about it multiple times.  Without Yelp-ing it, we headed over.

Well....first of all, it does seem iconic enough.  It felt as though we were transported back in time, but not to a fancy schmancy dining establishment that's for sure.  We ended up sitting at the bar, which I don't mind at all.

We ordered the calamari to share, which was ... calamari.  I mean, you must be a HORRIBLE place if you can't fry a squid, in my book.  Although I should have gotten the fish, I opted instead for the House Special ravioli with meat sauce.

Maybe it was because I ordered wrong....but even my fellow dining companions were not impressed.  One had the Fish Florentine, the other the Hamburger steak.  Aside from the fact that our food was heavy, I think our plates would have still half-full.

Finally, when it came time to get the check we asked if it could be split.

"But I already MADE one," said the waiter indignantly, as though we were asking him to cut our food and feed it to us.

"Is there any way you could though?" we asked again politely.  Again, he retorted, "I already MADE one."  We just gave up.

Would I go back again?  Um, no thanks.  And as for recommending it to visitors or fellow SF-dwellers, it would probably be at the back of my mind, shuffled away in an attempt to forget the bleh meal I had.
author: Shay F.

description: The cioppino is fantastic, the best i've ever had. They do not short you on the portions nor do they choose to provide you with less than perfect quality. You guys are doing everything right.
author: Geezy L.

description: My family told me to stop in specificly to Tadich and have the cioppino.  It was wonderful and the staff was extremely helpful.  Totally worth the stop!!!
author: Kristen M.

description:
We spent a quick weekend in San Francisco starting 3/1 and arrived for a stay at the Omni Friday night. Turning on to California Street coming in from the Bay Bridge we noticed the Tadich is just a short walk from the hotel, so we made a spontaneous decision to have dinner there having seen the restaurant featured on numerous television shows.  The staff at the Omni confirmed the raves we've heard for the Tadich, so we checked in and walked over.  At 8:45, the wait for a table was 45 minutes but the maitre d' said that we'd probably have better luck waiting for a couple of seats at the expansive bar instead.  I ordered us a couple of 21st Amendment IPAs on draught for the wait, and sure enough a space for two opened at the bar within 10 minutes. A couple who came in after us moved in to occupy the two spaces, but the alert waiter at that end noticed we had arrived first, shooed them away, and called us over to sit. Not a house policy, but more an unwritten amendment to the unspoken "first come first served" code.

We ordered the huge seafood cocktail and a bowl of white clam chowder, but unfortunately they were out of the lobster and shrimp bisque. Each of these was loaded with seemingly bottomless seafood and clams respectively, and tasted fresh and delicious.  I ordered the Hawaiian Ono with rice and vegetables for my main course and was delighted with the fresh grilled flavor of the ono (known some other places as wahoo), and with the choice of fresh vegetables accompanying the fish (snow peas, broccoli, carrots, and brussell sprout. As an added treat, they topped the ono with a delightful sesame/seaweed salad nested miso glazed scallop coated and cooked to perfection.

Dessert was a really nice tiramisu wrapped in a paper thin chocolate sheet, and the perfect way to cap off a fantastic meal.  Out of the two thousand + restaurants in the San Francisco area and the dozen or so I've tried so far, this is near or at the top of my fine dining experiences in this great, culinary focused city.
author: Alec W.

description: I stayed 4 nights in San Francisco. I had 3 time of eating  Cioppino at several See Foods Restaurants. This was the best.
author: Zak M.

description: Great old setting and loved the atmosphere.  The clam chowder is thick and creamy and probably some of the best I've ever tasted!!!
author: Marcia B.

description:
I love how old this place is.  The servers are all male and where white coats.  They're a little rough around the edges but have a true appreciation for their product.  

I [heart] their cioppino.  It really is the best in SF.  The clams and mussels are tender and the tomato broth is both tangy and salty at the same time.  It comes with huge piece of garlic bread that is perfect for dipping in the broth.  Mm...my mouth is watering.

The seafood platter appetizer is also a winner.  It comes with smoked fish, calamari, salty cheese, raw oysters, cooked shrimp, and a yummy cocktail sauce for dipping.

Just went there on a cold Friday night and waited 45 minutes for a table.  Fortunately I had a couple glasses of wine at the bar and didn't even notice the wait.  Regardless, the food is worth the wait.
author: Nina L.

description:
Yum, I keep trying to get my boss to take us here for company lunch, but so far no dice.

The oysters rocker-feller were incredible.
author: Michael E.

description:
Believe the hype or don't believe the hype, this place is terrible! After waiting for over an hour with no place to sit we asked the host where we were on the list. After a very rude response we were next! 

Ordered the clam chowder and the prawn and crab cocktail to start. The clam chowder had crab shells in it (although no actual crab in it) and so did the cocktail, which only came with one prawn and the rest were bay shrimp.

My husband ordered the linguini with clams. Bland, bland, bland. No seasoning and the pasta was hard and unappetizing.

I ordered the petrale sole charcoal grilled. It was burned! It came with undercooked (raw) steak fries and soggy veggies. The waiter came by once to check on us even though my husband's drink had been empty for about 20 minutes.

Needless to say we each had a few bites and then grabbed the check quickly. They didn't even asked why we didn't eat it or if we wanted it to go. I think they are used to clearing full plates of food!

Bad and overpriced!
author: Jen L.

description:
Service here can be really snobby so minus a star for that. 

I used to come here for lunch when i worked in the FiDistrict and battle with the crowd for a seat at the bar (first come first served) vs waiting for a table. 

Definitely the best clam chowder in San Francisco!! Creamy with just the right amount of clams and potatoes.
author: A. Z.

description: If you order the cod, beware that they put a lot of creamy sauce over it. I had a plate full of grease. The oysters rockefeller gave me a similar experience.
author: Alton Y.

description:
Barry: the worst waiter!!
Food was good but the nasty attitude/mannerism of our waiter Barry will keep us from going back

Caveat: if you go, the host you don't want Barry as waiter!

Food: 3.5
Service: 1 (stay away from waiter name Barry)
Atmosphere: 4.5
Value: 3
Would I go back factor: hell no! 

Waiter name Barry from planet hell was the most obnoxious unpleasant creepy looking dude.
 As one of the yelp reviewer had mentioned waiter barry's attitude...that alone is enough to turn off anyone's appetite.

We sat promptly and we waited Barry creature to take over 20 minutes to take our order.  I am usually very good at describing things in detail but the two words that fits him perfect is 'parking as~whole' 
I am surprised that the management is not firing him after 20 some years he worked there.  He must be sleeping with his boss
author: B K.

description: Great chowder, Oyster Rockefeller and Lobster Thermidor.   I like this place.
author: Jim J.

description: Financial District classic SF restaurant. Been going here for years. Really enjoy having cocktails around the long oval bar. When available the sand dabs are delicious. Because this side of town is densely packed  with many fine restaurants and food of the genre, I can't say Tadich's offerings stand out any better than any other local Italian/Euro-American/Pub/Saloon restaurant serving so called San Franciscanized seafood and meat dishes evolved from European immigrant cooking. Tadich has an old time SF charm and feel in an early 20th century saloon setting. The restaurant is always busy with lots of the City's power and money click, wannabes, as well as out of town business visitors and tourists. A couple of drinks plus 2 course lunch or dinner will run you $60 - $90 per person easy and it's basically good but not chef grade cooking. I love this place for the martinis, nostalgia, people watching, business meetings, and small talk with old timer bartenders, waiters, and strangers over a simple meal at the counter.
author: Giovani T.

description:
Luckily my wife and I arrived shortly before the lunch rush today.  We got there at almost 11:30 and there were like 10 people in the entire place.  When we left at about 12:30 there was a line out the door.

The decor is awesome here.  Totally old school.  I can just picture businessmen in the 40's and 50's having a 3 martini lunch here.  I know this place dates back much farther but that's just the picture I have in my head.

Our waiter was a very friendly older gentleman that clearly had too many tables to tend to.  He only came back once during our meal to see if we needed anything.  This turned out to be a good thing because had he stopped by more often I would have ordered 5 more diet cokes (this will make sense later).

Our food arrived very fast and the portion sizes were good.  Here is what we had:

* The bread they give you to start = EXCELLENT!!! - it doesn't look like much but it is terrific.  Crunch, slightly burned crust with a fluffy, kinda chewy inside.  I'm not sure what kind it was but I think it might have been sourdough.
* Clam chowder (white) - EXCELLENT
* Oysters Rockefeller - best I've ever eaten.  They make them very unique with a kind of spinach and cheese mixture instead of breadcrumbs and stuff like I've had at other places.
* Crab Louie salad - excellent and lots of crab. 

Anyway, I would have given this place 5 stars if they didn't charge $2 for each thimble size refill of diet coke.   Like seriously, WTF?  Who charges for refills these days?

I would like to return soon and often, but I'm not sure when I'll be back in the SF.
author: Jason B.

description: A class act.  Just be ready for the old school simple take on classic dishes.  Don't look for a lot of sauces or any fusion influences here.  Meat, bread, fish, butter form the core of the cuisine.  And I'm ok with that.  Somewhat pricy, but also a one of a kind expeience.  Excellent bread!
author: Patrick S.

description: Especially if you love basic fish of many different varieties --this is a super old traditional place .
author: Ed P.

description:
I went here for lunch for the first time.  I ordered the pan fried sand dab after I asked our waiter to recommend a fish w/o bones (I do not want to spend my time picking out little bones).  He recommended the sand dab.  It came w/ some zucchini that was cooked just right (not too hard and not cooked until it looks like it's decomposing on your plate) and some fries.

My friend ordered the fried calamari.  Both dishes were more than enough.  You don't need to order an appetizer or have dessert because you're full from the entree.

Prices are on par for a seafood restaurant.  

I liked the old SF vibe.  It reminds me of how restaurants used to be minus the dirty factor.  

Our waiter was matter of fact and he even managed to make us laugh.  Service was fast.  We got outta there within the hour!
author: Wendy H.

description:
For a non-seafood eater - OK I flat out hate seafood - this place exudes classic SF native restaurants with excellent service and an impressive array of offerings.

The beef barley soup was quite delish as well as the french fries, although I will say their hearts of romaine salad was very overpriced for 6 leaves and a tomato. The waiter had a grand ol' time making jokes at my salad request (M. family staple to order both Blue Cheese and Italian, on the side), asking which side I would like my dressing on. Our drinks were refilled by charming accents and very little interruption made it ideal for work luncheons.

So really, I would say 4 stars, but since I don't eat seafood - meh, can't justify it.
author: Alita M.

description:
The famous cioppino from this san francisco landmark gave me the most memorable visit ever to a public toilet while taking my partner's family out on a tour of the city. 

I will spare you the gory, rocket propelled details.

Don't get me wrong, the cioppino was great. The best tasting non-filipino stew I've ever had was the tadich cioppino. But damn 30 min after the bill was paid my bowels were MOVING.

Cool old-school resto feel and excellent service. A bit pricey for me to visit more often than not but still worth coming back to. I might pass on the cioppino though.
author: Jason S.

description: I recommend this place ten fold. if you enjoy seafood, straight to the point answers with no BS, this is the place. Service is always great, friendly and fast paced. Thomas was wonderful and my wife enjoyed her bday dinner. I can't wait until our next visit~
author: Jesus R.

description:
I've been working downtown for 13 years and I have absolutely no idea why I haven't tried this place any sooner.  I heard it was a lil pricey and boojie and because of "grill" in the name, I thought it was more of a steak/meat kinda place.  Had no idea...they were known for their seafood.

Took one of my GF's here for lunch one day (around 11:30a) before the lunch-hour rush.  Luckily we were seated right away. We ordered:

Cioppino..... Very tasty
Clam Chowder....clam portions were huge and thick
Seafood Salad... HUGE, filling and very good
Garlic Bread... Dee-lish!

All of the above was able to fill 3 ppl (and then some, we had left over).  The quality, freshness and taste of their seafood was amazing.  I recently seen Tadich featured on "The Originals w/ Emeril" and I can't wait to go back and try other items on their menu.
author: Resa N.

description:
This has been a favorite restaurant of mine and my husband's for a decade.  The fish, chops, drinks and service never disappoint.

Our last visit our group had petrale sole (pan fried) - wonderful - pork chops, and seared halibut.  They make their own tartar sauce, and it is amazing.  They don't take reservations so be prepared to wait, but it's worth it.
author: Kristina V.

description:
Living in San Francisco for the past 10 years I've had multiple opportunities to dine at Tadich Grill.  It has a great history and runs like a well oiled machine.  They don't take reservations so both dinner and lunch is always pretty full so expect a wait.

The wait staff is made up of all men (at least what I've seen) and it seems like they have all been working there for some time.  I'm a fan of the bread that they serve to begin with and the seafood is always fresh.  It's a little pricey but I guess you pay for dining at a historical place as well.  Last time I was there our server wasn't too attentive to us but it was alright and we made the best of it.
author: Blake B.

description:
Tadich Grill may say that the Sand Dabs are their specialty, but I'd go for the broiled Filet of Sole instead. The Crab cakes are supremely seasoned and they can easily complement either the Seafood Cioppino or Filet Mignon (for the surf 'n' turf effect). The Cioppino is one of the best that you will find in San Francisco - it's loaded, hot, and perfect on a cold and rainsoaked day. If available, the Octopus & ginger salad is a refreshing starter... though the side of garlic bread is overkill. Another great starter is the "Coney Island" Clam Chowder.

A table in one of the enclosed sections is must for the complete Tadich Grill dining experience. It's all about the seafood and Bloody Marys.
author: Be N.

description: Our favorite restaurant in the City, very old San Francisco style. Always worth the wait, every time!!
author: Randi C.

description: The servers are quirky, the atmosphere is lively, the food is excellent. The sour dough bread and butter is a great start to the meal. We had a variety of seafood entrees ordered at our table - fish and chips, Lobster Thermidor, Australian Lobster tails, and Crab and Shrimp casserole. All of our entrees were flavorful with nice sized portions.
author: Shicara S.

description: If you're wondering where to eat. Tadich grill is just the place. Tadich Grill is an amazing place for lunch and dinner. The food we had was delicious. It took a while for the food to come but it was definitely worth the wait. Our waiter David  was very kind and friendly and made excellent suggestions which our family loved. The ambience was just perfect. It's a hidden gem in San Fransisco. And the portions were enormous!!!
author: Miriam K.

description:
wow this famous restaurant's food did not disappoint. i can totally see what all the hype is about and no wonder it is always packed!

i love the ambiance first of all, it's such an old skool traditional italian restaurant. you can choose to sit and eat at the bar or in one of the many tables covered with red and white checkered tablecloths. second, you will be served by cute old grandpas- my waiter looked like the adorable character from the movie 'up.' don't let appearances fool you- while old, they move really fast, can remember your order without writing it down and are super knowledgeable about the food and the wine. 

lastly, the food was fantastic- if you want delicious italian food- look no further. also, they have THE best cioppino EVER! it's like tasting seafood heaven in your mouth. i will use any excuse to come back here again.

that being said, the service can be meh. i have been here several times for the past few years- the latest was my birthday. i suggested this place for a family lunch because i was dying to eat their cioppino again. the wait was pretty long but i can't blame the restaurant for being so popular. unfortunately, my table was served by one of the grumpier grandpas. the food was delicious but my dad claims that he got the stinkeye from the guy after he tipped him. (my dad tipped 20%). now every time we do a family get together, my dad would say "as long as it is not tadich grill, i am happy." :(
author: The Hangry Chef O.
