description: Wow, reading the reviews makes me wonder just how yelp is a publicly traded company.  Complaints about not giving their Mom special treatment, wouldn't take a 10 dollar to-go salad order at lunch.  Wow, really people, come on now.  It's the oldest restaurant in SF and one of the oldest in the country.  I went for lunch, had a NY steak, and 1/2 dozen oysters.  Service and food were both excellent.  Pricey, but isn't all of SF?
author: Joe W.

description:
My boyfriend and I ate here for our date night while visiting San Francisco. I checked the menu online before but I think the prices may have been a little higher than I was expecting when we got there. We were lucky enough to get a table as soon as we walked in, which was nice. The lemons on the table kind of grossed me out a little because I don't think that is the most sanitary thing to have in a restaurant.

Our waiter was very nice and the atmosphere of the restaurant was enjoyable. We ordered the jumbo prawns which I thought was incredibly overpriced for what it was. They also ran put of the NE clam chowder which I was looking forward to trying so I ordered the salad instead. I think it was supposed to come with shrimp and crabmeat in the salad but I counted only one piece of each. I also decided to get the lobster, which I did not expect to be so heavy. It was prepared with a creamy wine sauce and chopped mushrooms, which was good but I would have preferred a much lighter and simpler preparation. My boyfriend got the red snapper with crab which was also very heavy and he didn't particularly enjoy.

Overall, I don't think I would care to return to Tadich Grill during my next visit to San Francisco. I'm sure there are other seafood places to try that I would have a better meal at.
author: Lara N.

description: Not particularly innovative, but tasty and reasonably priced food to be had.  Consistent, simple and delicious. Still a San Francisco staple.  Go for an early dinner or late lunch.
author: Susan A.

description:
This is the one restaurant I have been to that has always been consistent. The food is always great, the ambiance is old school & classic, the wait is always a pain in the ass & the service is blunt. The charcoal broiled petrole soul is the best you will ever have. 

This place is classic San Francisco.......
author: A. B.

description: This place has tangible history and a great old time vibe, a large menu with lots of things to try including daily specials.  The food was okay, but I felt that on the large it was way too oily.
author: Mike L.

description: I had a lot of fun and a wonderful meal here.  My date and I arrived around 8:30 on a busy Thursday night, gave our name to the host and took a seat at the bar.  Our table was ready before we had time to order... sat in a cozy spot in the corner and ordered a bottle of Pinot Noir and the prawn cocktail, which was great - not mind blowing, but big, clean shrimp and tasty cocktail sauce.  I had the seafood saute (scallops, white fish, shrimp and mushrooms with a side of rice and veggies, which were califlower and brussel sprouts - YUM) and my date had the clam chowder and crab louie salad.  I snuck a few bites of his soup and it was delish.  All in all the food was great, the restaurant had a fun vibe and our server, Jack, was awesome.  Will definitely be back one day.
author: Jamie R.

description: The atmosphere is what you pay for here.  We went on a weekend night, so the wait was long, but it is amusing and fascinating to see how fast the staff is moving.  They are friendly and knowledgeable if a bit brusque, but we can forgive that because they were so busy.  Although they were out of many entrees, the ones we had were good.  The portions are generous, and the desserts plentiful, though we didn't try any.  All in all a fun place to visit.
author: Steven D.

description:
Phenomenal. 

My Dad has been telling me about Tadich's for years now, wanting me to go there just for their Seafood Cioppino.

Dining alone, I walk in and sit down at the counter. It's quite the experience when you're knocking elbows with the local businessmen, fresh out from work. Immediately I'm greeted by a nice man with an unrecognizable accent. Bread and butter and a water are already waiting for me at the place setting. I immediately knew what to order.

The Cioppino comes out in all its glory - a giant bowl (deeper than you think, too!) of all the shellfish you can imagine swimming in a red broth accompanied by fresh garlic bread. I take the first bite, which was of lump crab and baby shrimp. The flavor resembled french onion soup with tomatoes, and obviously the succulent flavors of shellfish. Crab, lump crab, big shrimp, baby shrimp, mussels, oysters, scallops, and white fish are all included in this beauty of a dish.

The bowl was so large that I couldn't finish it. I felt very guilty in not taking it home as I was staying in a hotel at the time. 

Overall, the experience was unmatched. The service was impeccable, the food outstanding, and the ambiance unique. It truly is a San Francisco treat.
author: Avery W.

description: I wish we had a resteruant that came close to Tadich unfortunatly we don't ..Tadich is magnificent  ..there choppino is exquiste  the service is supreme  .Any time i visit  san francisco  i suggest Tadich Seafood Resteruant   ,its a do over  never a disappointment ..love  this res. and i recommened it to everyone  ....
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Hmm Tadich Grill. Apparently it's the oldest San Francisco restaurant? Definitely has a historical vibe to it. My co-worker told me that the food here is on the heavier side. She wasn't kidding. Two of her friends ordered some baked avocado with shrimp dish served in a casserole hot plate. I think you could taste the stick of butter in that thing. Yes, one bite of that and you are asking for a heart attack. 

Luckily I ordered something on the healthier side -- charboiled filet of trout. It was good but still had so many tiny bones and I thought filet meant deboned? I guess not. 

One thing that I didn't really appreciate was our waiter. He definitely went to the "school of upsell" -- he convinced our table of 6 to each order their trademark dungeness crab cakes. However, we didn't know that these appetizers were going to cost us $11.25 each until we got our bill. Oops.
author: Helen Y.

description: The food at Tadich deserves five stars, the atmosphere a two, and the service a three, at best. This is California's oldest restaurant and, trust me, you can tell. The wait staff is made up entirely by men, which for me isn't an issue, I just find it entertaining that even after 160 years hiring a female is still out of the question. Our waiter was very impersonal and unfriendly, however it fits in because it is not a very inviting atmosphere. I wasn't impressed at all..until I got my food. That waiter could've slapped me across the face and I would be back for their famous 60 year old cioppino recipe. If you're coming to a dinner strictly for the food, this is your place. If you're looking to meet a warm and friendly face, you should probably look elsewhere.
author: Sydney J.

description:
Classic, delicious seafood restaurant with history and charm.

While I may be the only person here under 35, or maybe 55 given the time of day, I always look forward to a Tadich night. Which is usually with 65 yr old dad in tow :)

Highly recommend their Petrale Sole! It's the local sole and this is the best place to get it. Other hits are the sea bass, the halibut, and any salad with dungeness crab. And try not to eat the entire wedge of fresh sourdough before your meal arrives :P

Although it comes with a hefty price tag ($100 for two, without drinks! yikes), Tadich is a true San Francisco institution. It's timeless.
author: Colette H.

description: One of the best meals I've had.  The seafood cioppino was incredible. Highly recommended.  Service was very good.  Ken, our waiter, was very nice and attentive.
author: Alan J.

description:
Very busy and we got there at 6:15pm.  Lucky we only had to wait 20 minutes!  
Servers were great...quick and professional.  Like everybody else said " if you like cioppino you def. should get it here." The sauce is so good you should take it home and put it on some pasta the next day!   You will thank me for that tip later!  :)
Also had the lobster/crab baked with a sherry sauce,  very rich.  Again, you will have wonderful left overs.   You will not have room for dessert! 

**No reservations**
author: A Z.

description:
Tadich delights in being comfortably entrenched in history.  Billed as the oldest restaurant in California, details like bow-tied waiters and a menu that seems to do all the classics make this rainy-day original a standout.  You don't visit a place like Tadich for the modern dining experience--it's a time-traveling field trip.  

Enjoyed lunch here for my sister's graduation and after several rounds of seafood and wine, I can confirm that this place may survive another 150 years in its present state.  Our waiter was funny and helpful, but not intrusive, plates came out quickly, and my glass was never empty...which may be a trick, since I just ate more...

I look forward to another lazy afternoon at Tadich, soon.
author: P D.

description:
Had their famous Cioppino here and boy was it good!!!  These guys are not cheap with their portions either as it had plenty of seafood.  Presentation was nice as well but definitely the best Cioppino I've had before.  Service was not too bad for a place that got very packed in the afternoon. 

Only thing negative to say is the soda refills.  When the waiter asks if you would like another one....take that as: "would you like to pay for another one?".  My friends learned the hard way paying $20 for their soda after multiple refills.
author: Ngo L.

description:
I enjoyed my experience at Tadich Grill. We decided to this was our spendy dinner for the new year, which was a good choice considering we didn't make reservations anywhere else. 

The ambiance is pretty old school SF. The bartenders may look like they were taken out of drug testing facility, wearing white long lab jackets on white shirts, but make up for it with goofy ties and warm personalities. While waiting 45 minutes for our table, my group and I chatted about the pro's and con's of yelp with bartender David. Great guy to talk to while waiting and had a warm greeting and farewell. If you do end up eating at this establishment, mention I wrote about him in a review to change his mind about us yelpers.

The service wasn't quick, but that's not the purpose of a place like this. We leisurely drank our cocktails and snacked on bread until the food came. I had the Top Sirloin Steak with Mushroom Sauce which was delicious and my company also chose beef for dinner. The meet was cooked to our liking, and was all and all a good plate of food. 

To sum it up, Tadich Grill started the new year off right. I'm excited to visit it again in 2011.
author: Colleen F.

description: I don't know if I could give more than 3 stars. The service is good the wine was good but after reading all the reviews I expected knock my socks off clam chowder and amazing everything else. This was just ok for us.  The shrimp were overlooked and fries soggy.  I'd overlook this at an Applebee's price point but at 30 dollars a plate you expect quality execution.
author: Heather K.

description:
Truthfully this 3 star review seems more of a placeholder than anything...

when it comes to Tadich Grill I feel like you can't give a full review of the place unless you get the fish. Seafood is too broad of a term I feel. Fish seems to be what this place is known for, so that is what a review should be for right?

This review is for the lunch I had here a few days ago with a good buddy of mine Cristofer P. 

First off the ambiance of the place is crazy. Feels like you stepped back into time into the Prohibition era, all old school. Glitzy isn't the right word, classy is better. 

Sat down to a table with bread and butter laid out already, which isn't a bad sign. The butter was room temp thank goodness! (i hate cold butter, how do you even spread that on anything?)

Me and Chris ordered a clam chowder each, and decided to split the fried oyster fritata omlete bacon type deal (really I swear that's my description of the dish, don't remember the actual name).

The chowder was solid, again, not the real 'best' new england/boston clam chowder I've ever had, but still good. I mean, it's clam chowder at an old SF mainstay. It's gonna be thick, creamy soup, with a good amount of clams and veggies. Solid.

Then the main entree came and I have to say I was slightly disappointed. Sure I split it with a friend, but I mean for 22 bucks...I'm getting like six fried oysters with some egg and bacon. Really now? As for the food itself, it was surprising in flavor, but lacking in overall quality. The seasoning was off a bit, needed a little more salt and pepper. Chris commented that the bacon in the dish acts like salt if you get a proper bite, but really I only got two bites. One with no bacon, which needed salt, and one with what felt like half a strip of bacon, and became just bacon overwhelming.

But like I said, I'd have to book mark this place to come back and try an actual fish dish to give a full decent review.

Pros: Good service, good ambiance, good bread and butter!

Cons: Expensive, seriously. Around $25-30 per entree. But if you're coming here for food, is money really going to stop you? Get's a little noisy and crowded.
author: David H.

description:
Boom! This place is so good, I had to put the Boom first. Ok. I came to this place because it was recommended by everyone and their mothers. It was an extremely old school restaurant that looked like something straight out of a mobster movie. 

I got the Pacific red snapper with sauteed crab on top. Yeah it was just as good as it sounds. And if you don't get it...this meal was freaking ridiculous. The service was great and I really have nothing bad to say about this place.

There can be a line at this place, but you can always just grab a beer at the bar and wait. If you come to San Francisco...or anywhere close to it, you need to come check it out. Bazzoooom!
author: Aaron N.

description:
This is the kind of restaurant where every aspect - the menu, ambiance, waiters, and food - scream about a long history. I had the sturgeon, which was cooked well and quite flavorful. there was a side of steamed veggies, which were a little bland. But it's steamed veggies! The chefs have been steaming those veggies for a hundred years. It's food your grandparents ate.

Some of the waiters could also have been grandparents. Thankfully, they're the fun kind that joke around and are still full of pep - not the cranky kind that tell you to get your elbows off the table. This place was packed when we came for dinner, but it was worth it overall. A bit of San Fran history and a great piece of fish. Who cares about veggies anyway?
author: Jason W.

description: Dinner review - we were seated quickly. Apps we ordered were decent but our entrees of Crab Louis and Seafood Cioppino were awesome...Yelpers were spot on with those reviews. Entree sizes are huge, so might not need apps unless you are really hungry! Place was probably a 3.5 stars experience/value - but feeling generous to go with the 4 stars.
author: Sean S.

description:
Definitely old school.  Nice atmosphere, reminds me of New Orleans. A little snooty.  The oysters weren't separated from the bottom muscle.  when we mentioned it to the server, he said nothing and walked away.  Service was bad.

Quality was good.  Like the Ciopinno at Soto Mare (and service) much better, but overall good.  They need to try harder instead of just believing they are the best.
author: Rob S.

description: LOVED the filet, great wine selection, and was really, really delicious.  Only complaints are that it was really cold where I was sitting and though they had delicious bread to start off the meal, they didn't give us plates to eat said bread on and it got really messy.  Still, soooo delicious!
author: Ryan S.

description: An atmosphere of anticipation, fresh seafood, best Cosmopolitan I've had, a bit pricey but worth it. Why not 5 stars I'm not sure as I'd go back tomorrow  ...
author: Lisa C.

description:
We went to the Tadish Grill because we wanted to experience this iconic SF restaurant. The historic restaurant's ambience draws heavily on its Gold Rush roots, with endless parade of stools at the long counter which you can not find in any other restaurant. Ken our server was great and made excellent food and wine recommendations for an enjoyable dinner. 

Their number one dish is their Seafood Cioppino with clams, prawns, scallops, bay shrimp, white fish and tons of crabmeat. We have weakness for Cioppino therefore we both order the Cioppino although, we thought it might be too much - it was so delicious that we didn't stop until it was gone. The Wente - Riva Ranch Reserve, Arroyo Seco chardonnay was excellent.
author: Gigi W.

description:
I dream about this restaurant...waited a year to go back to have the cioppino soup.  talked about it for months ...my friends didn't believe the hype until they tried it for themselves. now we're back in miami dreaming of tadich grill's cioppino soup all the time.  can't wait to go back again.  

the crab cakes are really yummy too- but save space for the gigantic cioppino soup.
author: Sandra U.

description: Old-time San Francisco, with Fi-Di heavyweights.  Waiters are nice and the food is good, though.  Not a place I would go to myself, but  hubby will sleep on the couch if I give it a 3, so 4 it is!
author: Sherylle W.

description: Been coming here for years, but we're done. Great atmosphere, lots of character and charmingly cranky old waiters, but the food has gone down hill. Last time (and it will be the last time) my salmon was dried out and overcooked and my husband's liver and onions was one day short of toxic. Sad to see an institution coast into mediocrity, but it happens.
author: Freddie M.

description: The long narrow shape, intimate booths, and old time decorations really give this restaurant a swanky feel to it. The drinks are very traditional. The food is delicious and the service impeccable. You really feel like you are in another era.
author: Kari G.

description:
Memorable place - opened since 1846.  My first place of dinner with my wife before we got married.

Memorable food - Cioppino.  I have tried other dishes at this place, but none is better than the Cioppino, and the Cioppino so far is the best we have had anywhere. We will keep trying Cioppino at different places.

Best time to go:  after 6 pm, so plenty of parking because it is located in San Francisco financial district.

Does not take reservation; first-come first serve.

Will I go again? Yes
author: Patrick W.

description:
On our annual Union Square after Christmas shopping / spend adult time with my wife, we wanted to add Tadich's to our tradition. Logically, this should be a no brainer. It's always busy, well reviewed. (averaging 4 stars). It's often described as Old San Francisco. I don't want to bore you with what that means to me but we all get a mental picture of what an old school SF restaurant would be. From all outward appearances, Tadich's is exactly what we were looking for. READ ON as both looks and YELP can be deceiving. 

The wait is manageable but cliquish. The guy that takes your name must have a system but it seemed pretty random to me. After 25-30 minutes we got a small table for lunch. Fine. Happy to have it. The counter however is large and if you don't know about it, it's grab a seat if you want as there is no waiting list for the counter. Wish I would have know as I passed up a prime spot thinking I had to wait for someone to hail me. 

 Met promtly by a waiter, we decided to split a bowl of New England style chowder and I had a bloody mary. Both really good. Very good if you want to know the truth. For lunch, my wife had the seafood sauté and I thought a burger in a mushroom sauce sounded good. We were both disappointed with our choices. We both got brussel sprouts with our selection. Who the hell likes or wants brussel sprouts?  I also got some nicely chilled fries. Lovely. The waiter told me I could get a different side but it was going to cost me. Screw that, 18 dollars for the burger already seemed like I had spent enough. My wife's lunch choice did have fresh and delicious seafood but the sauce was overwhelming. 

We will continue our search as they gave the vibe that our special visit was nothing special to them. That my friend is not Old San Francisco. 
Forget the indifferent service and brussel sprouts, enjoy a delicious bowl of clam chowder and grab a seat at the counter. Had we have done that, we think it would have been and entirely different experience.
author: Ron L.

description: Great quality seafood, fresh and delicious. I had the ciopinno, which was very good. I think I've been spoiled by my uncle's ciopinno, because his was a little better. The sourdough was out of this world. My lovely date for the evening had Anthony Bourdain's recommendation of the Hangtown Fry. Extremely delicious and complex dish. The fried oysters were amazing.
author: Jessica B.

description:
This place is alright... Very old school professional crowd and vibe. 
The food here just didn't do it for me... maybe I ordered the wrong thing. 
I doubt that I'll ever visit again.

-filet mignon was decent
-good place to drink and just hang
author: L L.

description: I just flat out love this place!  It's noisy and always crowded, but I always enjoy eating here.  Old school San Francisco restaurant that serves pretty much everything in butter.  Price versus quality and quantity is very acceptable, and the atmosphere is so cool.  Have the sandabs or calamari steak, and you won't go wrong.  Service is pleasant and efficient.
author: Joel M.

description:
Old school San Francisco - been around forever and I've never been!! I came tonight for a business dinner. First off, portions are HUGE. The calamari appetizer was the size of a main entree. Delicious and crunchy. The tomato creme soup is delicious and had chunks of onions in it.  I had the avocado salad with crab $22 - huge! It felt like there were more crab pieces than lettuce! The cioppino looked and smelled delicious.

Try to get a booth. You even have the buttons to ring for service. I also like how they  have hooks for your jackets. 

They don't take American Express and they don't take reservations. First come first served.
author: Natalie S.

description: Went here for lunch the other day with the da. Perfectly cromulent. Totally unexceptional.
author: Doug R.

description:
The cioppino here is the most accessible out of the San Franciscan cioppinos I've had. The crab meat is already taken out of the shell for you. The soup is really savory and flavorful. Other places you have to struggle with the cioppino. At Tadich, you can just enjoy it because they've done the hard work for you.

The service is prompt and professional.

The martinis are great, too.

The only down side was a customer next to me who ordered the minute steak and did not like it, but ya, this is a seafood place.

I would definitely go again.
author: Jim B.

description:
Tadich Grill opened its doors back in 1849.   I still don't understand why it took me 161 years to try this place, but I finally did.  My friend and I went to Tadich on a whim yesterday, and we were not disappointed.  Well, I am sure he was disappointed just a "tad," because it was his turn to pay for lunch.

We got there at 11:40, and all tables and booths had already been taken.  We were offered to sit at the counter or wait 20 minutes, so we wisely chose the rather comfortable bar stools (complete with back support) at the counter.  We were told rather sternly to not leave a chair between us and the other diners.  It would only make sense that a seafood restaurant would pack people in like sardines.

My favorite thing about Tadich was seeing bread and butter on the table for everyone.  Yep, we didn't have to wait or ask for it - it was just there.  For people who are perpetually hungry, having food readily available is a sight for sore eyes and grumbling stomachs.  Why don't more restaurants do that?

As I was buttering my sliced sourdough, I had a chance to look around.  The whole restaurant was rather narrow, with a weathered mahogany counter around a large bar area in the middle, an open kitchen in the back and 10-12 booths and tables along the wall. 

I also remembered that a lot of people complained about the service here, so I braced myself for the worst.  The service wasn't bad at all.  If you're looking for a friendly smile and hug, you should probably go elsewhere.  If you're looking for well schooled, efficient and slightly standoffish waiters in smoking jackets, you're in the right place.  Yep, it's old school all the way.

I started with a cup of cream of mushroom soup ($6.95).  If that was a cup, I don't want to know how big a bowl would have been.  The cup was big enough, and the soup was delicious.  It was no Campbell's out of a can, let me tell you.  It was mmm...mmm... good, though.  Due to the abundance of shellfish offerings, my options were slightly limited.  I went with the halibut served on the bed of rice with string beans ($20).  Even the halibut was supposed to have been served with crab, but I asked them to hold the vile crustacean.  The large halibut steak was flaky, but maybe just a tiny bit on the dry side.  I like my fish slightly less cooked.  My friend ordered the cioppino, and he seemed to enjoy it.  I was a little jealous because his dish came with garlic toast.

Both of us left the restaurant a little heavier, although one of our wallets was $71 lighter.  Thanks, Dan!
author: Yan G.

description:
Tadich is amazing! The service is straight forward, and prompt. No waiting no snotty overpaid 23 yr olds at the door ignoring people waiting to be seated.  You come in, you are acknowledged and you are seated or told exactly how long the wait is immediately. 

 Sitting at the bar is an experience, and isn't lacking anything. If you can however wait for the booth.  There really is nothing like sitting in the wooden booths conversing with your cohorts as if you were a banker in the gold-rush days.  The coat hangers and bustling atmosphere outside make the experience cozy and unique. Its your own private little wooden room from which to enjoy your meal. 

 The food here, is wonderful. Everything on the menu, is cooked to perfection and served promptly. If they are out... they are out. If they have it "I will give it to you" is their motto. I ve had the pleasure of eating here on several occasions, my parents were big fans and now a good friend of mine calls the Tadich his favorite spot. The Cioppino is top knotch, and the lamb shoulder is not to be put off either.  Served with crunchy sourdough bread and warm butter.  Or a salad with fresh crab and shrimp perhaps?  Anything on the menu is sure to not disappoint. 

 Thank you Tadich for making my friends birthday such an event, from the VIP seating to the Happy Birthday song complete with his drinking howl...you guys really are the best at what you do. :
author: Charlie B.

description:
I started noticing something about SF restaurants on my trip. All of the best ones have an old-time charm that's so much more genuine than any that I've found in NYC. More importantly, at Tadich, its the real deal as its the oldest restaurant in the state (let alone the city!). 

The food is a bit expensive and it's a tourist trap for sure so be prepared to wait. But, the waiters in white aprons, bartenders shaking drinks, and the rattle of utensils hitting plates is a delight to behold. A trip through time. 

Everyone says it and I'll reiterate - the cioppino is a "have to have it before I die" dish so make sure someone at your table orders it. Preferably you, since you're not going to want to share. I've tried to get cioppino again outside of SF and there's nothing that comes close to how delicious this dish is.
author: Manesh P.

description: The food here has never been bad and today was no exception.  But charging for soda refills, sorry to here you need the extra 2.75 so much.
author: Bill F.

description: Legendary cioppino. I could eat this every day if I worked in the financial district of SF.
author: David M.

description: The cioppino is and always has been the best in the Bay Area. The lobster is definitely a huge portion but it wasn't fresh ... the crab cake was very disappointing :(
author: Benny C.

description: I was in town with my mom and we were looking for a place that was good and close to our hotel since we had been walking all over town that day. Our entrees were very delish and the service was great. Its very old school place but food was good and it was a nice atmosphere to relax and end the day with dinner and some drinks!
author: Amanda J.

description: Some of the BEST Seafood you will ever eat!!!  LOVE the ambiance, the waiters dressed up old-style.  Sit at the end of the bar and watch them work like bees in a hive, especially at lunch.  Oldest Restaurant in SF and worth the wait.  You will adore this place!!  Great for all occasions.
author: Katie C.

description: The wait at the bar is no big deal when that guy Pete from the 1950's is pouring. He's pretty into his job, the right way. There a million seafood places to try in SF...DUH1 we're the city by the bay by the ocean too but, all of their dishes taste fresher than fresh. Whether it's the whole red snapper or the cioppino or any pasta dish you'll be not wanting toi share with whoever you take...so go alone or be sure you really like who your with. No reservations so be patient bu,t be ready for your taste buds to be overjoyed.
author: Wild Style G.

description: This place was amazing. For the oldest restaurant in California, it has the genuine feel you would expect. The drinks were spot-on, and the food was incredible. The appetizer with crab legs was the highlight for me. Highly recommend!
author: Aaron L.

description: Cioppino is excellent.   Clam chowder is average at best.   Don't put on the bib if they give you one because you will look like a fool.
author: Ken F.

description:
Love this place! Their cioppino is the best. I don't eat cioppino any where else because I know it can't compete with Tadich Grill. 

When ever my husband and I are in the Bay area, we try to make a stop here.
author: Ann O.

description: A real SF institution!  The decor looks like it probably did 160 years ago.  Seven of us were crammed into a small little both on the side.  So tight the table was placed on the diagonal.  Good food and good time for all but not outstanding.  May be living off of their reputation.
author: William Z.

description: My wife loved the Lamb shoulder and my Chilian Sea Bass was wonderful. I also loved the Olive appetizer.  Total bill was a little over $100 for 2 entrees, and appetizer dessert and 3 drinks.  Worth every penny.
author: Tom B.

description:
steak and lobster were cooked well but nothing remarkable. and fries instead of mashed potatoes? strangely cheap side item for the pricepoint of this restaurant. seafood appetizer was bland and served on a bed of sad-looking wilted greens. dessert menu is a joke. asked for prosecco with st. germaine from the bar but wasn't given an alternative after the bartender told me they didn't have st. germaine. didn't even suggest the chambord that was sitting right there. just silly.

for what you pay, there are other places to go with better ambience and better food without a 45-minute wait.
author: Diana C.

description: I always eat here when in SF.  The food is good and a great menu selection.  All the waiters are like 80 years old and have an attitude if you don't eat fast and leave immediately afterwards.  It's great for the food but be prepared for the servers.  They should fire all of them and start over.
author: Steve P.

description:
I went here last night with a friend from out of town - and while the food was GREAT, I have to say the SERVICE was EVEN BETTER!  

While we were sitting at the bar waiting for our table, I ordered a glass of red wine - and somehow hit it with my arm!  Red wine spilled ALL OVER my cream coat and cream sweater!

The team behind the bar jumped into action with towels to help dry me off - but David was kind enough to mention that he had some stain remover spray in his locker and would I be interested.  He went and retrieved it for me so I could spray my jacket and my sweater in hopes of it not permanently staining.  I must have used almost the entire bottle.  

I just want to say THANK YOU to David for going above and beyond what is expected!  

I will be back again soon, and not just for the food, but for the great service as well!
author: Sara S.

description: They have the most awesome SEA BASS dish! It was super buttery and delicious! A bit pricey but you can expect that eating in SF financial district. Service was meh..Maybe there were just busy but I don't think they were that friendly. Go early for dinnertime, it gets packed quick!
author: J K.

description: I love the idea of the Tadich Grill and I think the atmosphere is great, but for this type of restaurant, I think Sam's is a much better bet. First, the management and wait staff at Sam's are first rate, friendly, and good to their customers. At Tadich, our waiter, Jan could not have cared less. He left my beer sitting on the bar out of reach for a good 15 minutes while he disappeared. When he finally came by to take our order he upselled us. They would never do that at Sam's. The food was mediocre. The bread was stale, the food underseasoned, and luke warm. I want to love this place but the next time I want fresh petrale, Hangtown Fry, or curried prawns I am sticking with my favorite classic seafood joint - Sam's Grill at Bush and Belden Alley.
author: Christopher V.

description: Busy place...they're good about keeping you engaged...but, the best is that once you get a table, they make the time for you and even though they're moving fast, they allow you as a guest time.  Servers only seem to care for their tables and ignore all the outlying (waiting to be seated) crowd.  Overall a really great meal.  The cioppino was one of the best I've ever eaten.  Stay light hearted and always keep an open ear...forever entertaining.
author: Amber S.

description:
Do you like Cioppino? If yes, you will LOVE Tadich Grill's Ciopinno. By far the BEST Ciopinno I have eaten in SF. The seafood is fresh, cooked to PERFECTION, and plentiful. The broth is rich in flavor that complements the seafood. They also give you yummy garlic bread to soak up all the goodness. 

They also have good Calamari. The batter is on the thicker side, but it balances out with the LARGE pieces of squid they use. The Calamari is perfectly cooked, not over cooked to the point of being too chewy. The portion size is HUGE, you get what you pay for. 

When it comes to the service at this place, they are on it! The waiter was very attentive. I did not have to wait or ask for my glass of water to be refilled. Food was brought out in reasonable time. And recommendations for dessert and food was given upon request.

There is usually a long wait to be seated, so try to arrive early. I can confidently say that the food here is worth the wait.
author: Nick C.

description:
My girlfriend and I went here because she had heard great things about it, and the fact that it is the oldest restaurant in California had me intrigued. It's a busy place that doesn't take reservations so plan accordingly. We timed it right and only waited for about 5 minutes to get a table. The wait-staff is very professional and courteous and really make you feel like you are transformed to a different era of dining. 

The food was outstanding. I had the Cioppino because I had heard/read so much about it and the hype is definitely well deserved. The ingredients are so fresh and after every spoonful I was more and more satisfied. My lady had the Petrale Sole Filet and loved it. 

Tadich is a great special occasion type place to eat as it's a little pricey, but the experience was one that I will remember for a while.
author: Aaron R.

description: The best restaurant i visited in SF.  I had lobster n scalloops.  My husband had one of the seafood medleys.  We thouroughly enjoyed our meals.  All of the staff was friendly & attentive. Hrvat owner.
author: Anica H.

description: To me... the food was a bit hazy.  Don't take it the wrong way..... each dish was probably really good in it's own right but we ordered everything and it all got blurred.  We had the steam clams, raw oysters, cioppio, something that was seafood paella, garlic bread, clam chowder... I mean... it was just too much.   I just remember that all of it was so good.   Next time I have to tell myself is to eat less so that I can truly savor all the great seafood that I had.
author: Albert W.

description:
The atmosphere is cool.  The service was great and they really do aim to please.  You can't go wrong with the Cioppino.  It truly is their signature dish.  

The Coke is actually RC Cola and they do not have free refills.  THAT is the only thing that I could find wrong if I had to be picky.
author: Phillip M.

description: I have been here twice and both times deserved a 5 star. I had the fried oysters wrapped in bacon and the cioppino. Both are delicious. The waiters are great and seem to thoroughly enjoy being there. Definitely recommend!
author: Maci H.

description: Had their dungeness crab grilled crab cakes with rice and seasonal vegetables tonight, which was on their specials menu for the day and it was so very good. It may have even been better than Maryland blue crab cakes! Funky place, definitely not for intimate dining, but caters to business travels who are solo or maybe with one other person, as you sit at a long bar in their narrow restaurant.
author: Rachel R.

description:
From the other reviews you get the gist of what this place is about; it is an old old place with character.

The experience is worth it and the food is amazing.  Ideal for a hungry person with highbrow 'home cooked' on their mind.
author: Duanne G.

description: The bartender was really helpful. I had to wait to get a one seater at the food part of the bar but it was worth it. The food was amazing; Best cooked Salmon I had my whole 2 weeks in San Fran. My server was awesome as well.
author: Ash L.

description: Have i never reviewed this before? Really? I work right around the corner and go here occasionally. Once you get past the schtick of the servers, it's pretty good. i like the red chowder and usually get the cosmo salad, which is seafood packed. A good thing.  Crowded as hell at lunch. Honestly it's good but I don't love it as much as most do.
author: Josh B.

description:
Came during lunch and it was quite packed in there.  Luckily after 10 minutes, we grabbed couple seats at the bar.  

I had the petrale sole and the portions are big!  It tasted great!  Solid and old school and not that pricey.

Service was good. The guys were friendly and they were fast and efficient.  Love the atmosphere here.
author: AhLin C.

description:
One of my favorite seafood restaurants in the US! 

They don't take reservations, but they get people in and out pretty quickly so get a drink at the bar and enjoy the oldest restaurant in California. 

The clam chowder is by far one of my favorite things to get at Tadich, followed up by the Tadich Platter as an appetizer.

For the main course I usually ask the waiters opinion on the best fish on the menu that day... they know their fish and they've never been wrong. 

Had a Chilean Sea Bass the other night... best I've ever had. 

Wish I lived in San Francisco... love this place!

Old school dining at it's best!
author: Iman J.

description: If Peter Luger moved to San Francisco and became a seafood restaurant it would be Tadich Grill.  This is the place to go for cioppino.  The portions are gargantuan here so go easy on the appetizers.  I had the cioppino last night and it did not disappoint.  I also had the dungeness crab cake appetizer and loved it--I am from Maryland.  I have had the salmon here, and the dungeness crab and have always had a good meal.  I love sitting at the bar, or in the little booths when I am with a larger party.  There are no reservations taken here so be wary of the waits during prime dinner hours.  This is my favorite place for seafood in San Francisco.  The bar and open kitchen are legendary.  I need to go back again before I head east.
author: Thomas W.

description: You can definitely tell that this is the oldest restaurant in San Francisco, which isn't completely a bad thing but I was not all impressed by the food or the service.  The calamari was chewy and the sand dabs weren't very flavorful.  The hangtown fry looked unappealing and was bland as well (we've had better somewhere else).  I think the only thing going for this place is that it's the oldest restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Rose A.

description: Great iconic San Francisco restaurant. This place is always busy, so make sure you have time when you come here. The food was really good, but sadly our server was a bit neglectful. Luckily, we were sitting right by the bar so the bartender just walked over our drinks. My husband and I had the Oysters Rockefeller, The SeaBass and Seafood Cioppino and they were all excellent. The drinks were good too. We will definitely be back the next time we are in SanFrancisco.
author: Tara B.

description:
I love the look of this restaurant inside and out. The food was amazing! However, I wasn't very fond of the service. I had to ask for more water at least twice and asking for anything else also took a while. 
Great food, but I think next time I'll just try out the bar.
author: Stephanie U.

description:
It's hard to have a favorite resturant in San Francisco but this is on my top 3 list. What can you say? It's Old School. Men take their hats off. People are polite. The tables are covered with white linens, the food is excellent. Try the simple, big, FRESH seafood salads. Or sand dabs, or any charbroiled fish. The thermidor's are traditional and heavy, perfect for a cold San Francisco day. Martinis & Manhattans are perfect. But the all-time winner is the large bowl of fat manila clams with the best bread in town. Add the clam chowder for a perfect San Francisco meal. When food is this good it does not have to be over seasoned. 
  Yes, there are new tastes emerging in the resturant industry. Curry this, Fusion that. So if you are looking for an OMG wacky-tacky, fun, cucumber, ginger, lime, coconut, sea urchin infused martini served by the fun waiter who is your new BFF, like OMG how arrrrrrre you? And you call one piece of gucci sushi dinner please keep moving and let me enjoy my place in time. Sorry you missed the era.
author: Peter C.

description:
Pretty good flounder fried in flour, was golden brown. Straight ahead American comfort good.
I waited a while to be served. Old old school place. After work is very busy and very crowded with the well heeled crowd.
author: Bert K.

description: The food here is just OK...I never understood all the hype here.  The food is ok... I guess the fact it is old and that the waiters are somewhat rude keeps the lines, but I have never been that impressed here.
author: John F.

description:
Never been here before, researched through Yelp and TA and picked this place. BIG MISTAKE, i would rather flush my money down the toliet. The previous night we ate at Boulevard and it was fabulous.

1) The "bread" was so hard I could have used it to break a window and rob a bank.
2) Clam chower - just ok.
3) Clams with garlic butter. It was more like gum in a water messy. I love clams with garlic butter, I have it almost every time I see it on the menu. I only ate 1/2 of the dozen cause I could swear I was going to get sick from food poisioning. There were so chewy and as for the "garlic" butter - there was no garlic taste, no garlic in the broth, not even parsley. 
4) Halibut florentine - cold throughout, fish not even cooked in parts. Barely eaten.

the server didn't both to ask or notice that we had both pushed our dishes away, barely touched. I will never ever go back, or recommend. As stated in the headline I'm fairly certain this is the worst food I've ever had.
author: Melisa E.

description:
We had a perfect Friday night dining experience here!  Five stars!

-Food
We ordered crab cake with wasabi flavored aioli sauce, pan-fried red snapper fillet, and Caesar salad.  Everything was fresh and cooked perfectly.  I really liked the crab cake, one of the best crab cake that I've ever had. 

-Service
The waiters were attentive and polite, but not too much.  I liked that.

-Ambience
The high-ceiling and its classic interior makes the place really special.  Yes, it was a bit noisy but I kind of enjoyed its lively atmosphere.

We would definitely come back!
author: M Y.

description: I am most likely to order different things off the menu every time, but not so at Tadich.  Something about sitting in one of the oldest restaurants in The City that gets me such that I will stick to my two faves to have time and again: the grilled whole fish and the grilled liver.  Sometimes it's just one or the other, but both are done so well that I don't mind the small pain of working through the fish bones.
author: Emily L.

description:
Yes! another  positive review!
We had a jetsetter weekend, and couldn't have been happier at Tadich!  We arrived before they opened at 11am on Easter weekend( Saturday)  and decided to walk down to the embarcadero, and shop for a while. By the time we walked back up the hill, it was 12pm  We were greeted and seated by a friendly host. and got a small table, not the booth. but it was just fine.  The ambiance is just right , white linen, suited waiters, fresh cut lemons on the table... the Cioppino was fantastic, garlic bread soaked up the flavors so well!  too much to finish!  I tried!  scallops, shrimp, crab, fish, mussels ,clams   mmmmhhhh!  hubby had the Chilean seabass and he loved his too!  at first he thought the portion was small, served with brussel sprouts, ( which we love) but I do make those better! and mashed potatoes ( i  think)  but in the end it was just right , cooked to perfection.  both dishes were in the $30 range ,  bathrooms are up a steep flight of stairs. We decided we liked it  just a little bit more than the Parallel 37  ( see my other upcoming post)  Tadich has the flavor of old San Francisco.  Everything was topnotch! we will be back!
author: Mary H.

description: Good food in a fun historic setting but be prepared to wait. We arrived at 730 and didn't sit down until 930. Granted it was a Saturday night and this place doesn't take reservations.
author: Josephine R.

description:
This place has alot of history. The slogan on all the plates is "The Original Cold Weather Spot" or something like that. 

All the staff where white lab coats and have got alot of sass. We sat at the bar for almost an hour because the place was PACKED and we were a group of 7. We ate oysters on the half shell that were delectable. 

We squished into the side booth and were helped by Barry - a career server who really knew his stuff. 

We ordered mounds and mounds of food. I was stuffed. We were a little disappointed by the "rice" pudding because there wasn't any rice. But, everything was tasty and it was lots of fun.

BOTTOM LINE: Great seafood and fun experience, be ready to wait.
author: Lauren J.

description: Great for sea food & steak.  Ciopino soup is excellent.  The place can be a loud, but overall it's good.
author: Francis A.

description: An example of old San Francisco as this restaurant has been around since the Gold Rush days. The salmon and Italian dishes are very good served in the classic style.
author: Frank S.

description:
500+ reviews usually mean my $.02 aren't worth much more than... two cents, but here goes:

The Charcoal Broiled Halibut Steak was flakey and tasted great just grilled without the need for superfluous dressings or spices. The fries were dry and the vegetables were a little undercooked, but the real 4-star review is for the halibut. The tartar sauce that came on the side was a good accompaniment, but I preferred the halibut as-served. I also had the Mixed Greens salad with their balsamic vinaigrette, basic but good. 

I also tried the scallops, and they were delicious. I may opt to order a more scallop-filled meal next time.

The people behind the bar are entertaining and amicable and the table servers are attentive and efficient.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Where to start! Historic, upscale, great location, great service and perfect for business and an intimate dinner with a date. Street or parking lot parking is your only option. There is a few other deli like places surrounding them. You can sit at this very long bar like seating or in these old cable car like booths that seat 4. The menu is a lot of sea food and some Italian. You can tell they have "old school" cooks in the kitchen that have been there years, same with the wait staff..older, white coat and very proper. Overall a good find, try the chowder!
author: Rose A.

description: Love this traditional old seafood restaurant.  The Grill is a San Francisco Landmark.  One of the three oldest restaurants in the U.S.  The guys that work the bar are johnny on the spot, so while they don't take reservations, they certainly will keep you amused.  My husband and I brought our out of town guests and we celebrated our cousin's girlfriends birthday.  It's a fun place to go, the food is great!  They have the cutest little booths to eat in and I love the guys that work there.  They are so professional.  I've been here a few times and I have yet to try the ciopinno but from what other reviews have said , and I saw some people eating it, next time, for sure.
author: Nicki B.

description:
Tadich is the quintessential San Francisco restaurant. If you only have one meal in the City, this is where I would come. It will never get a Michelin star, but it will be in business decades after the Michelin starred places are gone because there is no gimmick here, just good honest food well prepared.

My father is 81 and I've never seen him order anything but the sand dabs as long as I've been alive and could remember. I'm not one to talk though because I generally waver between the calamari steak served abalone style and the scallops and not much else.

The waiters look like they opened the place, but they are efficient and proud of their station in life to be a Tadich Grill waiter. 

I am the fourth generation of my family to eat here, number five loves and generation number six is quite ready for it, but if he doesn't like it, he is outta granpa's will.
author: Scott M.

description:
I give Tadich Grill 4.5 stars. They would get 5 if they took reservations, but I understand why they don't. 

I ate at Tadich Grill last night with my girlfriend and was already prepared for the no reservations policy. However, we got there a little bit before 6pm and there was a 45 minute wait! The place was super crowded. We weren't not sure if it's because it's the holidays and a lot of people aren't working. The wait was a little less than 45 minutes actually. There's really no good place to wait though because the bar is full and so be prepared to possibly wait outside in the cold. My friend and I walked around in the financial district a little bit so it wasn't bad. 

I really like how they give you a big loaf of sourdough bread with butter to munch on (although don't munch too early and get full!) and then provide LOTS of fresh lemons to squeeze on your food. 

I'm glad that I had read Yelp! reviews beforehand because the menu was a lot bigger than I was expecting and a little overwhelming. There are so many choices but we already had ideas what we wanted to try.

We got 3 things and the portions were huge. It's a little bit on the pricey side but that's what you get for decent portions and really fresh seafood.

1) Dungeness Crab Louie Salad (Large): The selection on the "small salads" didn't look as good so we went for the large option. The salad itself isn't that impressive cause it's just some lettuce, a couple of thick tomato slices, couple of thick cucumbers, 1/4 of a hard-boiled egg, and couple olives. But they PILE on the dungeness crab and then give you this big thing of thousand island on the side. I like that I get to pour on as much dressing as I wanted and it wasn't pre-mixed. Squeeze a little bit of lemon juice on top, and you've got one tasty crab dish. The crab was delicious... not sure if I would get it again just cause the salad part wasn't impressive. I don't remember how much it was. 

2) Pan-fried san dabs: It was on the 7X7 list so we had to try them. They were lightly battered and pan-fried with some lemon/garlic/herb butter on top (just a drizzle). Served with thick french fries that were awful and SUPER starchy. I took one bite and both me and my friend put our fries on the side not to eat them. Also had a little veggie medley with brussel sprouts, broccoli, and carrots. They were good but not like OMG-so-good-I-will-die and I probably wouldn't order them again. $22.50

3) Ciopinno: Total highlight of the meal. I would go back to Tadich Grill just to get this delicious seafood stew. It was a tomato based broth and was almost like drinking pomodoro sauce (obviously not as thick). It was piled high with jumbo shrimp, bay shrimp, mussels, clams, and fillets of fish. I don't know what kind of fish it was but it amazed me how the fish was not overcooked but not undercooked either. How did they do that!? They served it with two large pieces of garlic bread that was perfect for dipping in the sauce. So hearty and perfect for a cold rainy day. $28 but definitely splittable between two people. It would be a lot for one person. This should be on the 7X7 list!!!! Side note but they also give you cute little bibs to wear so your clothes won't get dirty. :)

We were too full for dessert and I read that they were bad on yelp anyways. The next time I go, I want to try their crab cakes! Also, their clam chowder is supposed to be thick and hearty. I saw other people ordering it and it looked yummy. The table next to us had a table of four and they ordered calamari. I overheard one woman say that it was the best calamari she's ever had.

I've seen some complaints about the service, but our waiter was really great. He was attentive and checked in on us and thought he was very friendly.

I will definitely be going back but going early to avoid huge waits!
author: Jackie T.

description:
We ordered the calamari, clam chowder, and ciopponi. All dishes were very good. Had to box up half the ciopponi because the serving sizes are quite generous. Come with an appetite!

Service is fine. Waiter was attentive, but I was disappointed that they served our entrees ten minutes apart, especially when both are hot dishes. I wasn't sure how their seating works, since we were waiting for about 15 minutes while groups that just showed up were seated right away, yet they dont take reservations.

I look forward to returning to try more of their dishes.
author: Amanda S.

description:
You gotta love these old school institutions.

Can't believe it took me this long to come here...

Had the sand dabs for lunch (good not great) but will definitely be back to try other things on the vast menu.
author: David L.

description: After taking my extended family to Tadich Grill I have to say I will not do it again.  The server couldn't get our orders right and got details of mine mixed with others in our group (I noticed his writing was illegible) and forgot items we ordered.  Generally, these folks really try and are genuinely nice, but our server was a bit inept.  We asked him if there was any chance of nut or nut cross contamination in the bread ("do you bake it here?").  His response was more of a pointless lecture on how parents should simply carry their own items (bread) for a child with a life-threatening allergy.  I agree, but they are on vacation and many restaurants can assure that they do not bake with any nuts on the premises.  My lamb was so over-peppered and fries so tasteless that I will not do this again.
author: Richard R.

description:
Came here the other day for seafood. I ordered the grilled red snapper. The fish may have been great had there not been so many bones in the fish. I couldn't even enjoy it. Plus the snapper lacked flavor.

Plus side...ambiance is very nice and it's in a great location in the financial district. May go back; hopefully ordering something different will yield a better outcome!
author: Anisha W.

description:
Yum, yum yum! 

I had all expectations not to truly enjoy this place after reading reviews about mean/rude servers and picky foods. In fact, we had a perfectly wonderful waiter who gave us a dish for free when he realized he wrote down the wrong order (which was really my aunt's fault, I believe, for not being clear). What a lovely man! 

As for me, I had the Ahi-ahi seared tuna and let me tell you - most restaurants create main dishes with side dressings that compliment it. It's been a while since I've gone to a restaurant that actually makes the whole dish enhance itself when you eat everything together. The seared tuna actually tasted even more delicious when I mixed it with the salad. 

I wish I could say more, but it's been so long. All I know is that Tadich Grill is doing something right - after being open for so long - it's definitely worth it as a "Do before I die" trip to an eatery. Yes, I had to wait in line for a while, but this is something you should know after reading so many reviews.
author: Christal Y.

description: This was highly recommended by many people. Granted we did go on a busy weekend, but it was a long wait for food that wasn't that great. Our waiter was pretty rude, we actually have a running joke on the fact that he said "No! " to all our questions. And to top it off it was pricey. The upside was its historical ambience. Although that isn't enough to bring me back.
author: Nicole H.

description: the food is worth the wait. I had the cioppino and clam chowder. More than anyone should eat but it was so good.
author: Gordon Y.

description: For a landmark restaurant that claims to be the best in San Francisco, this place leaves A LOT to be desired. First off, the waiter was a complete and total jerk. Not exactly the way I wanted to start the night. But I am also the kinda guy that can look at my girlfriend, call the guy a douche bag and move on with it. But then the food started to show up. Shrimp bisque was more like carrot soup and tasted funky, the entree's were loaded with grease, steak was not cooked well (when I mentioned it to Mr. douche bag he said something like "that's how you asked for it." and I told him to go away.) Overall, the food was terrible, the service was worse than the food and I will not go back. Maybe they had a bad night, maybe the waiter wasn't having a good day/night, but that being said, if you are going to charge people up the ass to eat at your restaurant, the food and service better be good.
author: Hector G.

description:
Everyone knows the cioppino is great so I won't write about it.

Something else worth mentioning is that I had the best scallops I've ever had here, I'm honestly not sure I knew how scallops were supposed to taste before I had them here.
author: Hamilton W.

description:
Tadich Grill is a San Francisco institution. It and its earlier permutations has been in San Francisco not for decades, but centuries! 

It is your classic old school  restaurant, with its long bar down the middle and private wood framed rooms along the left side, with two rows of small tables in between. They have all the classic old seafood and meats you would expect in an old school institution in the heart of the FiDi on California street. 

But it isn't living up to the legend of its reputation. Yes, it is still packed on a Friday night, with a wait to get a table. Our party of two put in our name and were told a 30 minute wait. So we sidled up to the bar and tried to order a drink. We pulled out the Credit Card, made motions to order, but couldn't get the bartender right in front of us to serve us a drink. He only had one speed, and that was slow and ignoring his potential customers.  We never did get a drink before we were seated.

We looked over the extensive menu and order a drink from our waiter. 10 minutes later, we still had not received our Stella Artois and Tanqueray Tonic.   

We finally ordered from our French waiter, who was also inattentive, and wanted fresh oysters and Clams and Pasta. He said he was out of   the clams and pasta! This is 9:00 pm on a Friday night? Huh? 
I asked, did you run out of Pasta or Clams? WTF? 

So we changed our order to 1 soup and salad and 1 salmon entree.

Our waiter served our oysters with cocktail sauce, but took another 5 minutes to bring us Tabasco and Horse Radish. I can't eat my oysters without Horse Radish mixed with Cocktail Sauce!

Before we could finish our last oyster, the waiter picked up our oyster tray and whisked away our sauce and condiments! We had to ask for them back! Not very attentive, just getting through with his Snooty French attitude! 

The Clam chowder was too thick, with perhaps too much clams (I guess they were out of Pasta, because they had plenty of Clams!)  How can you run out of Pasta? I was dumbfounded! 
The Salmon was fine, served with grilled potatoes and broccoli. The tomato salad with anchovies was decent 

I would rate this place at 2 stars, if it were not for its great, long tradition in San Francisco. That memory is fading fast.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
This place is pretty expensive, but the seafood is really great.  The oldest restaurant in California, it really has that old-timers feel with quality food.  I think that I would appreciate this restaurant even more if I was a bit more mature in terms of age, but until then, I really do believe that this was a very good place to have a business formal lunch meeting.

I didn't get to try the soup thing that was really famous, but did get a sample of clam chowder and oh boy, is that the best clam chowder i have ever eaten?  The answer to that question is obviously YES.  I would definitely come here again and then eat some scraps afterward to recuperate financially, but again, it is one of those restaurants that is just worth it.
author: Min P.

description: I landed at SFO with food on the brain.  My local friend said that she knew just the place and took me directly to Tadich. It was like stepping into a nostalgic photograph with the beautiful carved wood, waiters in white coats and sailors in uniform seated at the long counter bar.  We knew that we had a full day of snacking ahead of us, so we split some oysters Rockefeller and I had a bloody Mary.  It was the perfect way to kick off my trip!  The couple next to us had the cioppino and it did look fantastic, as other Yelpers mentioned.  If I wasn't such a sucker for the Rockefeller, I would have been tempted in that direction.
author: Julie S.

description:
Sadly, this place sucks.  I'd like to come back to Tadich Grill one day when I have more money, more time, and am not forced to order the Sand Dabs!

#67 Big Eat SF List - Sand Dabs at Tadich Grill. Blah. Sand Dabs are gross. They were extremely flavorless and came with bok choy, which in my opinion is straight up weird.  After offering to debone them, we said yes (even though I had a total of 20 minutes to get in and out since I had to get back to work), yet they were still served to us with a ton of bones.  

It was extremely crowded when we walked in, which resulted in slower service.  Our server was good though.  He was very understanding of my need to be in and out and worked as quickly as possible.  It's a classic old and famous SF restaurant with a long bar in the middle of the restaurant and small-ish tables and booths in between.  

I did not like how there was a minimum dollar amount you have to pay in order to dine at Tadich Grill.  You have to spend at least $11.50 and it's an extra $9 to split an entree!! What? You may as well just oder two entrees. 

We also had an order of calamari, which was no bueno.  The calamari was bigger than any I'd ever seen, but rubbery and not chewable. Ugh. The cocktail sauce also tasted weird...
author: Jenny W.

description:
Two words, Lobster Thermidor.   Get it, you wont be disappointed.  I'm not a big fan of lobster because I find it pretty bland and too chewy.  But in this dish is very flavorful and soft.  Watch out, it comes out piping hot.  If you're a martini fan, this is the place to go to dinner.

The restaurant gives you and 1920's feel where servers wear a white coat and white collared shirt.  They don't take reservations so you'll never know who you'll be standing next to waiting for your table.
author: Eleanor L.

description:
This is one of those badass old school kind of places where the line is super long, the people are kind of dicks and the food is consistently awesome.  

We've been here a couple of times and have always had to wait about 30 mins for a table for 4 (no biggie -- this is SF people).  Once seated we typically go completely overboard and order enough food for a party of 17 people.  Such stellar menu items include:  clam chowder, ciopino, sand dabs, OYSTERS ROCKERFELLER.  

The atmosphere is classy and the service is great.  I think you have to be a middle aged white dude with a shaved head to work here but I'm not positive (just kidding --  the waiters are awesome).
author: Greg F.

description:
Our first stop on our SF vacation. Showed up pretty late-- 8:30 PM --as a party of two we were seated right away. The place was still pretty packed at that time and the atmosphere was buzzing with busy worker bee servers and cheerful patrons. The servers work at an incredible rate whizzing from one table to the next--it almost made me feel like I was bothering our server when I would ask for something, but it didn't taint my experience. 

We ordered a couple of Anchor Steams and settled in to our chairs to read the vast menu. Ended up ordering a cup of New England clam chowder, but was told I couldn't order a cup, I had to order a bowl due to the $7.00 minimum order rule (what about the 2 $8.00 beers that I ordered?). I was then told that I had to order the Boston clam chowder because they were out of the New England---fine, whatever! I still didn't want a bowl though because I was pretty full from the beer and can only eat a small amount at a time. The waiter finally gave in and let me just order the cup.

R. ordered the Cioppino based on Yelp recommendations and was in heaven from the moment of its arrival. Bib in place, R. dived right in sopping up the tasty broth with every morsel of bread available. I ate all of the scallops since they are my favorite and thought they were done very well. R was impressed by the fish in the dish.Tadich lived up to all of my expectations, from the fast-paced service to the really great food. BTW, I couldn't even finish a cup of their clam chowder or my second beer, but did enjoy the Boston clam chowder version very much.
author: Bren C.

description:
Stopped here for a late lunch recently on a weekend.  I'd read that it was old, so I expected it to be rundown and funky (like Tommy's Joynt lol), and was pleasantly surprised by the high ceilings, wood paneling, crisp white linens and generally classic ambiance.   Service was prompt, personable and amusing. 

Few starters anywhere can match up to plain old, iconic warm sourdough bread with butter, which I could've made a meal of.  I also had a salad, which I don't remember the details of, other than that it was tasty, large, and unexpectedly had a variety of good stuff in it.  

Sadly, we soon discovered that this is a seafood place (I don't eat seafood).  However, I loves me a good burger and theirs (a "hamburger steak," if you please) was huge and bun-less, smothered in my choice of 'shrooms or caramelized onions--I chose the latter and yes, there were enough to choke a horse.  The burger was tender and cooked perfectly to order, medium-rare.  I ordered pasta with marinara sauce instead of fries, just a small portion but al dente and very flavorful, a nice counterpoint to the meat.  

My friend ordered a calamari steak and absolutely loved it, saying it's something she seldom finds on a menu and when she does, it's seldom as good as it was here.  I'm trying to acquire a taste for seafood so I tried a small corner, which I cut into three smaller pieces. The first bite was very good--the calamari was mild-tasting and very thin, like good scaloppini, with a crispy, buttery crust and very tender inside.  It was topped with an excellent garlic sauce.  I should have stopped at the first tiny nibble because as it cooled, it became fishier in my mind and I'm pretty mental about fishy-tasting food.

We were too full for dessert.  I'll add that my Manhattan was strong yet smooth and very good.  I'm definitely looking forward to an opportunity to go back.
author: LM K.

description: HOLY MOLY this place is good. We had the most amazing Seafood Cioppino I've ever tasted. Although I haven't tried any other Cioppino's in San Fran, I hear this one is the best. Comes with a mountain of seafood in a tasty red sauce that isn't too spaghetti saucy. And I can never forget the ridiculous garlic bread that accompanies the Cioppino. MMmm MMmm Mm! I will NEVER forget this place.
author: Jenna M.

description:
Five Stars:  The décor reflects the longevity of this San Francisco institution.  The waiters and bartenders are old school, curmudgeonly yet welcoming;  I have yet to fully figure out their demeanor. They are extremely knowledgeable and happy to steer you through the huge menu.  

Four stars:  Who else still serves liver and bacon? It's deliciously crispy and flavorful, but such a huge portion I can't eat it all.  The cioppino is the signature dish and piping hot, well spiced and freshest fish.  Choose carefully: some of the fish and seafood dishes are in rich, buttery sauces; just be aware if not to your taste (like me).  

Three stars:  The shrimp and prawn a la Monza was packed with crab, but only two shrimp.  

Two stars.  No reservations, so there's often a line.  However, the wait seems shorter when you're sipping a martini.  

One star: It's always busy so it's always loud - difficult for conversations with the hard of hearing.

SUMMARY:  A San Francisco institution specializing in comfort food - the ambience is old-school conviviality.  Try the Tadich for dinner if you want to feel warm and cozy, or just stop by for a drink at the long, mahogany bar to experience an almost illicit speakeasy ambience.
author: Nerdy G.

description: I have been there lots of time.  Very disappointed in the food last time we went.  The waiter practically told us to leave because we were done with our food.
author: Maddie W.

description:
Don't get me wrong, the old school atmosphere is cool. But, my food was pretty awful. I had the sea bass and maybe it was my mistake to ask for a recommendation on the preparation--I was curious about the soy glaze (I think it was). (The guy seemed a little annoyed). I'd asked the server his recommendation between a couple of options, and he said just go ahead and get the soy glaze. Perhaps that seemed like a fit to him since I'm Asian. It was overcooked and nothing special. 

The cioppino that my friends had was excellent. I would go again some time in the future and stick with a more traditional fish preparation. Also, the portions were ginormous--two huge hunks of fish that were individually a generous full serving already. I guess that's how they justify the prices.
author: Tina Z.

description: I went today after reading the good reviews and because it is located close to my hotel. I ordered the swordfish grilled steak, after the waiter recommended me that entree, and thought that it was not as tasty as I was expecting. The side fries and vegetables were really good but I had to put a lot of extra salt, lime, pepper and tartar sauce to make the steak flavorful. I would go back and order something else to find out why this place is so popular.
author: Guillermo M.

description: Only gave lower stars because you better know not to sit at the counter for a beverage only.  This is NOT a Bar and Grill. Before you know it you have bread and stuff.  Then when you don't want more you are informed you have to order food.  BTW we sat down at 3 places without any silverware place settings.  If I wanted a great dinner this is might be the place.
author: Sandy N.

description:
Fresh seafood from the past and a great bar to boot.

My bosses were nice enough to take me out to a nice dinner at Tadich Grill and it was a delightful meal. The first thing that strikes you about Tadich is that you've stepped back in time. The waiters are all suited up nice like and the tables have white tablecloths. But it's the menu that really comes from a time forgotten.

The first thing that struck me about the menu was its density. The sheer number of options was staggering, and it took me forever to pick an entree. But after I penetrated the destiny, I discovered a significant section dedicated to casseroles. Seriously? I didn't order one, so I can't comment further... but, seriously, seven different casseroles?

Instead I pigged out on delicious deep fried seafood, all high quality with excellent tartar sauce. The only food disappointment was a plate of half dozen oysters I shared with the table. I think the oysters had been sitting in water for too long, and as a result the oyster flavor was washed out. 

Oh, and I can't forget the bar. The wait for a table was substantial, but we enjoyed a full bar with some talented bartenders. As I continue my hunt for the city's best Old Fashioned, I can safely report that Tadich is on the list.

A word of caution... I can't recommend Tadich if your goal is just good seafood. Tadich is about taking a step back in time, and in that way they are selling an ambiance. But if the ambiance isn't the goal, there are better seafood options in the city.
author: Sean K.

description: Went here with some friends while we were playing tourist in our home town. We ordered the tadich platter, crab cake, seafood grill & the cioppino. All of it was really incredible & we loved our little private booth and yummy syrah. The only downfall of the entire night was the tiny little gnats flying around, which we kept having to kill & they would come back and the horrible waiter. Not sure what his name was but he was hard of hearing (not good for a crowded noisy restaurant). It took him forever to take our order & when he finally did, he forgot drinks & had to be reminded about them. We even went early so it wasnt even that busy yet. Definitely go for the food but dont expect too much from that particular serves. The host, he was very friendly and the water boy was great.
author: lindsay f.

description: Get there early because they don't take reservations. The cioppino is everything and more. Every item in it is cooked to perfection. We also had the Tadich seafood appetizer sampler. They advertised crab legs but there wasn't any in the dish. Other than that, it was a great evening.
author: Michael K.

description: Enter the time warp known as Tadich's and you will not be disappointed. High quality food, attentive service and throwback decor make for a near timeless experience. AmEx not accepted so bring another card and watch it light up as it spontaneously combusts from the ala carte prices.
author: Tracy P.

description:
This my fav seafood restaurant in SF.  I came back here yesterday and had the calamari steak and clam chowder with a few of my work colleagues.  BEST CALAMARI STEAK THAT I EVER HAD!

We got a table within minutes during a crowded night.
Thanks Tadich Grill................
author: Raider J.

description: Completely rude service. I'm coming with my 88 year old grandpa who has loved this place since he moved here in the 60's and they won't provide a seat for him while we wait for a table. Eff off! Way to treat your oldest customers.
author: Jenny P.

description: It's an Old School restaurant where the men wear white coats with wood interior and private booths. The bar is long and the drinks are strong. yes it's a little pricey but you are in the Embarcadero where many of the patrons make a decent amount of money or they are tourists visiting an SF landmark. The food was ok, I had the crab cake Benedict,  my husband has the Cioppino our friend had the hash. We all gave it 7 or 8 (which included the experience)  The bartender was spot on and so professional that we should of ordered our meal at the bar, but we went to our table and had a pleasant meal. I would definitely go again where I would  drink and eat at the bar.
author: Tina P.

description:
Stepping foot into Tadich Grill for lunch was not a planned event.  It just so happened that my boss and I were next door at Perbacco's for an appointment, and when we were done, I happened to have noticed Tadich Grill right next door and inquired about it.

Being that it was shortly before noon... my boss so kindly invited me to lunch here seeing that I've never been before.  She said that it would be worth a try since it's one of SF's oldest restaurants which dated back to the 1800's.

Upon walking in the door, this restaurant felt more like a diner and nothing I would have expected to see in the Financial District.  We were quickly greeted by one of the older gentlemen waiters.  As we made our way to our table, I noticed at the left side of the restaurant were these private booths/rooms.  It was quite charming... and definitely something different.

The menu was full of options.....but I will have say that at first glance, my eyes widened a bit because of their expensive prices.  I think I spent almost 10 minutes reading everything on the menu before finally deciding. Everything looked so yummy! =o)

I finally decided on their crabcakes special which came with 2 large crabcakes, a side of rice and some fresh string beans.  My boss ordered the fried cod which came with a side of coleslaw and potato fries.

I don't think I'll ever forget that first bit I took of my crabcakes.  It was full of fresh crab and fried to perfection.  Absolutely scrumptious!!  Every cent of my $25 lunch was worth it.  I would definitely go back again if I had a craving for crabcakes.  I left not a speck of food on my plate. And my boss was so happy with her food, she did the same.

Overall, I think the Tadich Grill is a great place to eat if you are going for the food.  The service is slightly above average and the portions are plentiful.  But I think what bothered me the most which caused this review to only be  4-stars was the noise level.  My boss and I couldn't hear one another talk at all.  Every 2 minutes one of us had to lean into the table to speak to the other person. It was a little annoying after a while.

But all in all, I would recommend this restaurant for those seeking great food and want to get a taste of what old SF use to be all about.  It's worth at least one visit.
