author: Vindy C.

description:
The best cioppino that I've ever had. 

That title was always reserved for Phil's Fish Market in Moss Landing but... wow... Tadich Grill really takes it to another level. The broth is not as rich as Phil's but it's more flavorful because it's not as thick from the tomato sauce so you can taste more of the seafood flavors. I love how the broth is lighter and it is packed, literally, with clams, crabmeat, scallops, prawns, and fish. 

The other items that we ordered were good but nowhere close to the cioppino. We ordered the lobster thermidor, which was good but not something I'd order again. Lobster is already pretty rich and to throw cheese and a bechamel sauce on top is a bit overkill for me. I also tried a bite of my friend's sand dab fillets and again, thought it was good but not sure if I'd order it again as I'm not a fan of pan frying thin delicate fish in general. 

Another important aspect that should not be ignored is the history that this places carries with it. "If these walls could talk...."
author: Victor H.

description: If you like Denny's, you'll love this place.  Banging dishes while waiting for a table.  No, they do not take reservations,,,just like Denny's.  We had to wait an hour while trying to stay out of everyone's way.  There is no place to wait.  They have a long counter (just like Denny's) on which to enjoy your horribly overpriced food. We will not return. And good luck trying to get a drink while waiting.  Sorry.
author: Joe M.

description:
Very disappointed by our meal there.  While the clam chowder was good, the Hangtown Fry was a horribly executed version of this classic.  The eggs were overcooked, bacon clearly deep fried and one of our plates only had one oyster in the Fry.  

We won't be back.
author: Steve M.

description: I love seafood, and I was in San Francisco so I figured they would surely have some great seafood restaurants.  Looked this place up on yelp, the description reminded me of S&D Oyster co. in Dallas which is one of my favorite restaurants here.  Tadich apparently has been around for a very long time and is somewhat of an establishment, just like S&D, both are seafood places, and both kind of have an old school ambiance.  I had the Ciopino after reading recommendations, and it was pretty damn good.  Definitely not cheap ($30 for a bowl), but you get all the good stuff - crab, scallops, mussels, basically every type of fish/shellfish I could ever want.  Ideal food on that particularly cold and rainy day that SF has so many of.  Such a great city, but for the terrible weather.
author: Mark W.

description: A perennial classic, white table cloths, old-style, a stop one should always make in SF, for a crab cocktail and a steak. Comforting ambience and food in the midst of a proliferation of new-age, rapidly evolving eateries and themes.
author: Lee D.

description:
Great food!  Will specially prepare food for dietary restrictions without any question/complaint/attituted!  

Crab Louie salad (with vinegrette instead of the normal creamy dressing) is the best in the city!
author: Jessie R.

description: Tadich Grill is a great place to start your night. It's crowded and you'll likely wait 45-60min for a table, but the bar also looked like it had amazing service. The staff were friendly and gave great recommendations. At our table we had the Chilean Sea Bass (phenomenal), the crab cakes (delicious), and the Branzino. Unfortunately, the Branzino was terribly undercooked and almost half the fish was wasted because it stuck to the bones/insides. The seasoning on the Branzino was tasty though. I will definitely be returning for some fried goodies before a night out.
author: Toshimi B.

description: So, you already get the idea from other Yelpers that Tadich is steeped in history, old school, good seafood, etc. What's not as obvious is that it's an ideal place to go for a drink (or two or three) and dinner if you're alone. Let's say you're in the mood for a fine dinner but don't really feel like talking to anyone. In my case, I was on a business trip. I blew off the group function and headed to Tadich Grill, for one of the best cioppinos you're likely to get anywhere. At $30, it's a little high, yeah, but worth every penny. And, it's all you need, plus some of the fine sourdough bread you automatically get from an efficient and unchatty waitstaff. Tadich Grill is a classic, unlike any other restaurant you're likely to find.
author: Bill M.

description:
I'm so satisfied!

Anthony Bourdain never lied! 

Five stars for the food, service, interior, crowd, and the history!

Things I've noticed: 
-Eating here makes you feel like you aren't in San Francisco...(it's so laid back and classic)
-Expensive
-Cool coat hangers
-The waiters are mostly older men, super friendly, wearing white smocks as if they are working as pharmacists or as physicians...they also carry a lot of pens on their pockets...oh well, this entertains me while I was waiting for my food...
author: Verena S.

description:
my friends and I came here to celebrate my bday (1 month later).
They don't take reservations so we were expecting to wait for awhile.
The place was crowded on a Wednesday night.
Being one of the oldest restaurant (i heard in California), I was already expecting traditional food and service.
We waited for about 20 mins at the bar with our wines before we got seated.  The guy who helped was abit old and was friendly but not very warm.  We ordered our food and about 20 mins later we got our entrees.
Unfortunately, we never saw our server until it's dessert time .  We are already stuffed so we didn't order desserts.
I ordered the pan seared sea bass with shrimp and steak fries.
The first thing I thought when I got my food is that the shrimp looked frozen and unappetizing.  The fish was well seasoned but I was deeply annoyed by the bones that I got while eating it.  the veggies were okay, fries would have been better with ketchup except you can't find our server to ask for one.

I have deep respect to old restaurants still surviving.
I just hope the service and food could be a bit better.
author: Learnee L.

description:
I've been here 3 times and I've enjoyed the food each time.
It's not a 5 star place for me because I feel the desserts are not great and the appetizers are hit or miss. Nothing has ever been bad though. The environment is a bit loud and don't go to this restaurant if you're expecting warm and friendly service. These guys (didn't see any female servers) are very efficient and knowledgeable, but they are not the smiley/friendly type of servers that will strike up a conversation. You still get excellent service and the entrees and drinks we ordered tasted great. The Seafood Cioppino is my absolute favorite. The lamb shank is also terrific if it's a special that day.
author: kris t.

description:
On a business lunch, I stepped into a wedge of 'Old San Francisco' with mostly guys in suits on their 2 martini lunches, wheeling and dealing.

If you plan to go during the lunch rush, expect to stand shoulder to shoulder along the wall as you wait for your party to be called - they don't take reservations.

I recommend the semi-private 'booths' if you can snag one - they are little rooms with mainly dark wood walls (like cubicles) that open out to the main drag. You get a bit more elbow room in these.

Food is old school good. I had the 1/2 avocado + mini-shrimp LARGE salad. Pricey, but filling.  They have a good range of seafood, meats, pasta, salads (large & small - I recommend the dressing on the side), appetizers, and dessert. Service is bustling + efficient.
author: Cathy K.

description:
Get the clam chowder and Cippino. Pure fresh seafood at its very best. I have gotten many grilled fish dishes which are also cooked beautiful, but very simple dishes and sides.

Minus 1- 1/2 star for service (they will hurry you a bit out cause usually there is a long line out the door, and they do NOT take reservations. first come first serve. Small glasses of wine and could improve on the bread that comes to the table (a bit hard, cold and dry), but hey, its free right?

I would definitely go and recommend for a true SF seafood experience.
author: Sunny C.

description:
Wow! I'm surprised by the 4 star average rating- must be all the tourists from Mandarin Oriental, the Omni Hotel, and le meridian! 

I did not expect the entire cast of The Little Mermaid and Finding Nemo on the menu- yes, while the seafood menu is extensive it is overwhelming; only resulting in mediocre dishes and not outstanding specialties.  I ordered the crab and shrimp salad, and the cioppino. Expecting the latter to be flavorful and delicious. The only memorable thing about this was the Louie dressing for my salad. The cioppino seafood tasted as if it was precooked separately and then added to the tomato stew- making the sea meat flavorless and boring YAWN. they place the garlic bread inside the stew- resulting in mushed and soggy bread EWW! The overall experience seemed tired, while the menu is overwhelming, the overall experience was underwhelming. Taddic Grill is in the same lane as Le Central Bistro; needing a revamp. I don't care how long you've been in existence, but you gotta keep up with the times or your clientele will continue to dwindle as it has over the past years. 

With much better options in this great city, I suggest you ask your concierge about that nice seafood place in the Castro, yes, the Castro, as in SF's gay Mecca. Or about that place in North Beach who's menus won't overwhelm you and leave asking if that was really what Taddich Grill was all about: bland seafood and an un memorable service experience. 
Look elsewhere- because you won't find good food here.
author: Dre X.

description: Never liked clam chowdah but gotta admit this is pretty good!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I had an OK meal but nothing outstanding.  Their clam chowder had too much milk and was bland.  I also had a fried seafood platter which was good but not memorable.  

This restaurant looks like a classic San Francisco eatery--wood paneled and dark.  I sat at the bar during a busy lunchtime weekday.  Service was pleasant and attentive.

I'd go back if I happened to be within a block or two but I wouldn't go out of my way; and I won't get the clam chowder again.
author: Leesa S.

description: This place was super busy for lunch. It's an old San Francisco tradition with professional servers. I had the dungeness crab salad and the crab was piled on. Very nice!
author: Robin S.

description:
I am in love. Can't really describe the feeling any other way. If I lived in San Fran, I'd be hitting up this place like crazy. My hubby and I were just gonna check it out because Bourdain has been here and also it is the oldest restaurant in San Fran. We did not expect much. Turns out, This place gave me one of the most enjoyable dining experience of my life. Not all upscale restaurants are created equal. For a truly best restaurant, there is history and experience that seeps in the food they make. That's what I got from this place.

I had the Chilean Seabass Special. That piece of fish was extremely special to me. The thickness, that crusty outside with plumpy juicy white meat goodness just blew me away. Major food-o. My hubby got the Ciopinno and while it was pretty good, I still cannot compare it to that fish. We both agreed that this is the most fantastically cooked piece of fish we've ever had. I could not stop talking about how good it was until long after we left the restaurant. These people really know their stuff. You just had to be there to taste that goodness, that craftsmanship that is involved in their cooking.

We sat at the bar. I recommend that you do. It is so much more enjoyable than just sitting at the table, let alone cutting down the waiting time. Don't forget to order a drink or two while you are there. Man... I loved the drinks!

No wonder why it can be the oldest restaurant in the entire state of California, and the third oldest in the United States. No wonder it can be selected as the best seafood restaurant by several different sources. I am wowed. When I return for another San Fran trip, this will be my ultimate dinner destination.
author: Cassandra S Y.

description:
I love this place. Been going here since i was 4 ft tall and now I'm 6'3".
A must try when in SF. p.s. everything is good there.
author: derek l.

description:
The first time for me wasn't a charm and it took me awhile to warm up to this place. So two weeks ago I came in again on Saturday at 12 noon after the worst thunderstorms in SF in many years.

I heard you all slept thru it.
I'm confused by you sleeping thru types. What's with you people, do you put Qualudes in your hot chocolate  ?

So after not having any sleep all night I wandered into this place to be greeted by a host shouting,  HELLO, HOW ARE YOU, WHAT CAN WE DO FOR YOU THIS MORNING!!!

Holy mother of God, I basically mentally fainted on the floor. So a seat at the noisy packed bar is where I skulked too. Yes, I said skulked. Then regained some color.

So I'm seated next to a guy who's about a million and a half years old eating an enormous sauteed calamari steak, kill me now, and on my other side is a Chanel number five wearing seventy old lady who thinks fried sand dabs are just the bomb !

Basically I have to admit they were probably my parents in another life. 

It was time to order.I looked at the menu and was a bit confused so I just pointed to a sixty five year old guys Tuna with Broccolli .

If I've forgotton to mention I ordered a few Pinot Noirs. Pinot Noir at 12:20 is considered respectable while your shell shocked from a thunder bolt that sounded like three bombs went off above the  building and causing everyone to run into the street at 4:30 am. 

So now we wait.

But it's OK because at the bar they present a show, it's called Tadich Waiters on Wheels.

Did you ever see that commercial where they show the dog watching something going back and forth and his face is going left to right constantly. 

Just loving my life this morning.

Alright so I try to talk to Mr.Calamari, but I get no response .
So I try Chanel #5  but she's too busy slurping on something.

WAITER ANOTHER PINOT NOIR PLEASE

Finally after what seems like watching an entire season of Shouting Waiters of San Francisco County my food arrives.

It was Tuna Steak, and Broccoli and a ton of wild rice.
Perfectly done for the most part. Definitely a large plate of food.
Tuna steak was cooked medium/rare perfect, the huge bunch of Broccoli was tender and the rice was very good. Food 4 stars. The waiter was a doll. 4 stars

So here's what I think
I love this place because I like the idea of this place. And I've come back to the bar after I realized they actually had a bar . 

Katherine to Waiter,  Oh you have a bar, where is it ?
Waiter to Katherine,  Yes we do Katherine, it's right over there at the beginning of the bar .

Sometimes I swear I'm legally blind .

So as in life we get off to slow starts but thanks to the lure of great food and good liquor they pull us back in.

And I left  Mr.Calamari & Ms.Sand Dabs at the bar in the quiet of 2pm just one seat away from each other......mmm ....hope !
author: Katherine N.

description: Like everyone said, the cioppino ain't no joke!  Clam chowda is on point too!  For sure, one of the places I'd recommend if you are visiting SF.
author: JK K.

description: Great service and even better food.  Skip fisherman's wharf and treat yourself to some real seafood and great wait staff.  The Boston clam chowder was excellent, as well as the fried prawns.
author: Troy E.

description: Place is always packed food is always good. The cippino is excellent no scrimping on the seafood in this dish. Old saloon style setting service is professional and helpful. Try it you will like it.
author: Dean C.

description: I realize this is an historical restaurant; but the atmosphere was noisy, the food wayyyyy overpriced and the waiter was very "cool" towards us (probably because we ordered light that evening). We ordered a side of asparagus which was rubbery and bland; I think the white sauce was suppose to be beurre blanc but it was tasteless.  I would NOT recommend this restaurant save for it's historical reputation.
author: Frankie G.

description:
I highly recommend this to anyone who wants to get a glimps back into San Francisco's history.  Not only is the food incredible, fresh, fresh fish and crab and the most amazing clam chowder, but the ambiance takes you back in history. 
I see reviews that complain about the wait and that the service is slow, this is a restaurant for those who want to sit and enjoy, this isnt a fast food restaurant.  This is a place for families and friends to gather and enjoy eachother company.  
It doesnt get any better than Tadich.
author: Stephanie M.

description: the food is fairly good. do not order lobster here  ! I ordered lobster one time and  it was to be boiled and they brought me lobster thermidor .which was in a cream sause with mushrooms .they tried to convince me to take it .I refused and it took about 30 minutes to make me a boiled one. ok so the last time I ordered boiled lobster it looked  ok but parts of it were  mushy .which usually means its old or has been in the freezer too long the lobster looked fine but like I said some parts are mushy .that should never happen .everything else is fine the clam chowder , calamari ,fries.
author: Nellie J.

description: I'm tempted to give extra stars for the Mad Men quality of this place, I half expected to see Don Draper and Rodger having an afternoon scotch at the bar, but alas, beyond that old school "boys club" appeal, this place fails to deliver. Don't get me wrong, the food was rather tasty- we had the crab leg salad, clam chowder, and the infamous seafood cioppino. All of which was extremely fresh and very flavorful. The prices for this kind of food is what leaves me not interested in giving the extra stars. The food is yummy, but really just okay. It's not worth $30 a plate for sure. There are so many incredible restaurants in the city, and especially in that area, that are very pricey, but incredibly delicious. I would rather spend that amount of money elsewhere and just come here for a dry martini and to check out the loads of business men in their sexy suits (:
author: Katie B.

description: If you love historic places with top quality food you will love Tadich. The place is legendary with grey haired waiters serving who've been employed there for over 30+ years. The food is classic and fresh. You must try the Cioppino but don't be alarmed when they hand you a bib. The dish is big but not too overwhelming. Prices are high but worth it for a special occasion.
author: becky r.

description:
This place and Sam's Grill are two of the places that remind me of my Dad. An SF lifer, my dad still runs into his buddies and roommates from Cow Hollow back in the day. 
I love this place.
I can't say either place is a pinnacle of culinary excellence, but the seafood is good, and the atmosphere is priceless. I'm excited to go here for the umpteenth time with my dad and see him settle in with a martini. Love.
author: Catherine R.

description:
*Review is only for the bar*

After the Off the Grid event, we grabbed a drink here.  Had never heard of Tadich Grill but it had an interesting appeal.  Very old-school bar area that had stools all along the outside of it.  It seemed a little "yuppy" to me from the outside, but really I think it's pretty homey.  People mentioned the seafood is top knotch.  Will have to check it out for food sometime.
author: Christopher W.

description: Perfect in every way - food, service, ambiance - this place has it all. The staff was even entertaining and made me feel welcome and special.  This was my 1st time here and I will definitely be back. I had oysters rockefeller & chilean sea bass that were the best I've ever had - and I have had them from coast to coast.
author: Patti G.

description: I have dined here twice in 2 1/2 years with the last time being 2 weeks ago. I was slightly bothered that it took a while to be seated at 2:30 pm on a Friday. They didn't seem particularly busy. So, we sat at the counter. Our server was nice enough though his humor was dry. But, my glass was full and I rarely had to ask for anything. He did not hover or try to make conversation while we were at the counter which I appreciated.  I love the Chilean Sea Bass which is what I've ordered each time visiting Taidch (and why I return).  It is cooked perfectly and the sauce is great. I also ordered the Dungeness crab cocktail as a starter.  I give that a shoulder shrug and "meh." For dessert, I had the bread pudding. The bread pudding was cold but the sauce was warm. It was just ok. I will likely not order it in the future. I thought it was tacky that the entire baking pan just sat on the bar and the servers plated the desert from it. The sauce was in a small crockpot next to the coffee maker and whipped cream from a can. It will be a long while before I return, only for the Sea Bass.
author: Danika A.

description:
Ok I really wanted to eat good seafood, mainly because we had just landed from the East Coast and it was my idea to go here for lunch.  My group was in the mood for fresh seafood and when Yelping on my iPhone, this restaurant came up.  

First of all, the service is so disappointing.  Our waiter was extremely rude, condescending, and seemed to talk down to everybody.  My party thought it was just to us, but then we paid attention to his interaction with others and noticed similar behavior.  Oddly, this didn't provide us with much comfort.

The food was just mediocre.  Fish quality was just mediocre.  All dishes we ordered were very salty, we were a party of seven adults.

I and the rest of my group were very disappointed and will never go back to this place.
author: aliece m.

description: When I heard Dashiell Hammett used to eat here, I had to check it out. Still has the old school flair with the waiters in bow ties and white shirts. Nice interior long bar with some great cocktails, I had the a great bourbon old fashioned , then the Ciapinno of main course, was great. ITs not cheap, but you are paying for the whole experience really, good to get there early, and or plan on waiting at the bar for a while and throwing back a couple cocktails first... Wish there where more places keeping the historic thing going.
author: Richard B.

description:
I can't express enough love for this place...granted I've only dined here for Lunch once on my first trip to San Fransisco but it was all I needed to gush about it now.

My friend and I were starving when we'd landed in Frisco and I'd heard about this place from Anthony Bourdain's program No Reservations. So I suggested we go check it out. So glad we did...the food was delicious, the service was absolutely charming, and overall it's a great spot.

We ordered Iced tea to drink (brewed fresh and yummy) Brussel Sprouts and Caesar salad to start (the salad is authentic and tossed table side, which was so fun and again...delicious). For the main course we both ordered the seafood Cioppino for which they are known for. The Cioppino comes with garlic bread, chock fool of sea creature delights swimming in a tomato broth/stew and a bib is ever so lovingly tied around your neck. Haha It was a great meal and great time.

A special shout out to PASCAL, the best waiter in San Fransisco. We shall meet again soon!
author: Amy A.

description:
holy house of seafood. everything about this place was fabulous... 

Being originally from the midwest now transplanted to Texas, one does not typically trust seafood in Indiana/Iowa/Central Texas. I knew I had to partake during my visit to San Francisco.  I heard rave reviews about this place from everyone I asked for seafood restaurant suggestions, so my mom and I went to try it out for ourselves. 

We walked in to the restaurant and saw the huge mahogany bar, waiters bustling around, the older white jacketed bartenders/hosts behind the bar yelling friendly banter at eachother (and guests), people lined up the entire entrance wall waiting to be seated. We went around 7 or 8 on a Saturday night and waited about 45 minutes for a table (expected). 

Our server was Barry. He made the experience even better--if you're going for the warm fuzzies waiter that coddles you--he's not for you. If you like someone that is efficient, tells you the best things on the menu, and dishes a little bit of sass--he's PERFECT! 

I was being really indecisive and asked him to help me make up my mind--he said I should have the cioppino. Explained it as seafood stew--I kind of gave him a weird look. That didn't sound very delicious. After he said-TRUST ME, and walked away, I ordered it. 

Best. Decision. Ever. HUGE scallops, prawns, dungeness crab meat, clams, and halibut with a tomato/white wine broth. It's sinful and amazing. I was really mad that I had filled up on the bread and couldn't eat all of the cioppino. My mom also has a gluten and dairy allergy-they were great about working around her and helping her find something she'd enjoy. They cooked hers sans butter and double checked everything to be sure it would be safe for her to eat. She had the seafood saute and ate every bite. 

The first thing I did when I got back to Austin was find a recipe for Tadich Grill's Cioppino...I'm going to make it for a dinner party once I get paid again! I'll need the paycheck to be able to afford the recipe-SO much seafood in it. mmmm.
author: Anna B.

description:
Having worked in San Francisco for 7 years I was a little embarrassed to say that I had never been to Tadich Grill up until last week. Came in with a group of 4 people around 7:00 PM on a Friday, we were seated immediately, not too surprising considering that this place is more well known to be lunch destination. 

Having never eaten here before I figured it would be a crime if I didn't have a seafood dish so I went with one of their staples the Ciopinno. I was not disappointed, the Ciopinno sauce was very tasty and well seasoned and the ratio of mussels/crab/shrimp/fish was perfect. The waiter brings out a bib for anyone who orders the Ciopinno and I wore it with pride. I hear breakfast here is killer so that's probably my next visit here. Don't be like me and wait years to come in here, this is a San Francisco institution for a reason.
author: Boby M.

description: Tadich did not let us down again today!  The bread alone will keep you coming back, add the shrimp cocktail and lunch should be over!  The deviled crab and the salmon and crab newburg was delicious.  No room for dessert this time.  Service from Jose was friendly and attentive.
author: lisa g.

description:
What a perfect place for dinner! Food was impeccable except for the bread which was a hard sourdough. The service was just what you would expect at this sort of establishment - great. 

My cousin was spot on when he said this place was the "Peter Luger" of seafood. The decor and the atmosphere are almost identical to that of the Brooklyn steakhouse. I was surprised no one was wearing a fedora or smoking a cigarette inside (yes, I know it's illegal)- I certainly felt like I was in a flashback. 

At the same time though, this place lacked diversity and felt kind of like an exclusive club with most of the men wearing suits and women in business casual. I felt a little underdressed wearing just a polo and some jeans - that is until I saw a little Asian girl about 5 year old happily munching away on some crab. Suddenly, I didn't care cause it didn't seem like she cared about anything else, but the food. With that said, let me get to the best part, the food! Below is what we ordered and my rating of each dish. 

3/5: Clam Chowder is not the best. It was good, but there are better places by the piers. I would liken it to being a potato chowder with clams.

4/5: Half Avocado with Dungeness crab was not great (it's a salad after all), but still very good. They do not skim on the crab meat, so it's certainly worth the price. The Louie dressing (in case they don't tell you what it is) is like thousand island, but with more vinegar. Think pickle/relish juice when you try it. 

5/5: Cioppino was a smidge from perfect, but that's only cause I can't admit it could be better than mine. 

5/5: Turbot Stuffed with crab and bay shrimp a la newburg, rice was my favorite dish. It's essentially a halibut's fish fillet wrapped around a crab cake and then baked in a delicious, but heavy cream sauce. Every last bite was worth the calories though! 

5/5: Dungeness crab legs. 
This was an eyeopener because I am so used to doing all the labor myself. Here, it's all done for you and they give you a lot. I have paid the same for less. This plate deserves a 3 for just the lack of labor involved. 

3.5/5: Rib eye and Dungeness Crab legs. It was good, but not worth it. The rib eye was cooked perfectly medium rare, but lacked luster. It definitely needs a steak sauce (Hint: Peter Luger sauce).

3.5/5: Lobster Thermidor Baked In The Shell was only good. Not worth it in my opinion. Just go to the local seafood market and pick up your own if you want lobster.
author: Dennis P.

description: SF Classic. Kick it old school with classic French brasserie menu. Souffles to die for. Classic SF Petrale Sole. Not just for tourists or Financial district types. live the SF dream ... eat at Tadich today!
author: Jeff W.

description:
Went here for dinner by myself.  I had a couple glasses of wine, oysters on the half shell and the Cioppino.

Everything was amazing!  Spot on for service, quality, taste, and everything.  

The Cioppino is just a big bowl of seafood wonderfulness.  Its amazingly light, hearty and deep all at the same time.  Amozing depth to it.  It was done fabulously.  The serving size was ample and well worth the price.  There was no shortage of quality seafood in this Ciopinno.  Nor was it all just whitefish and mini shrimp like I found at some other places.  Ample amounts of large shrimp, mussles, clams,  scallops and crab!   

This place was great and that explains how it has made it so long.  Well worth a stop.

They dont take reservations, and seating is limited.  But if you go as a single, there is a lot of bar dining seats they keep for people to eat at. I sat down with no wait on a packed night during dinner.  The people next sitting next to me were friendly and had some good chit chat during dinner.  I liked the setup they have here.
author: J T.

description: This place is pretty good but gets so busy at times that the service lacks in terms of seating and ordering beverages, food, and receiving the bill. It is at these busy times I would not recommend this place; no matter how good people say the food is.
author: Dave H.

description:
CIOPPINO (4/5) - Good quality fish, scallops, shrimp, etc. Good taste to the soup. Best part is dipping the toasty garlic bread into the soup, which soaks it up like a sponge and makes it mindblowingly soft.

SAND DABS (4/5) - The flavor was concentrated in the fish and the light sauce that was on top, rather than all in the breading. This was very lightly breaded, if at all, but it was still crisp on the on the outside. The tartar sauce was strong, thick like a heavy blue cheese dip, but not creamy like Hidden Valley Ranch. The best tartar sauce I've had to date.
author: David G.

description:
The cioppino at Tadich is on so many must eat lists, it's there for a reason. I had the pleasure of being treated to a fantastic dinner at Tadich for my bday this year. I was able to snag a seat at the bar for a surprisingly short wait for our 4-top. I am a total sucker for the old-school SF vibe that this place has going on, waiters and bartenders with character in white jackets. My go to drink was well made and as it should be. 

We were soon shown to our table. I was tempted by a giant seafood louie salad, but it's going to be nearly impossible to return to Tadich and not order a whole cioppino for myself! Cioppino can suffer when the components are hastily cooked together. Inevitably, you can end up with an insipid watery broth with overcooked seafood. Not so at Tadich!   The bowl is brimming with a rich seafood-tomato base, super buttery garlic bread, and an over the top jumble of in-shell clams, small bay  shrimp, scallops,  prawns, white fish, and shelled crab. I love that the crab is already shelled, so you don't have to wrestle with it and get messy. I did don the rocking Tadich bib though, just in case. It's a must eat classic SF dish for seafood lovers.
author: Candice L.

description: Great place! Classic SF institution. Love coming here- been a few years, but it has the coolest bar and the food is awesome.
author: F.f. Durst D.

description:
I am a huge fan of Tadich.  It is my favorite spot to go to when I am looking for an upscale, but not over the top lunch or dinner.   Their food is delicious and the portions are generous.  The place is not cheap, but unlike a lot of places in the financial district, I think you really do get what you pay for.

The service is always friendly and attentive.  They bring bread and butter to you when you sit, and refill it if you run low. Even at peak times I have never had to wait excessively long for my meals.

I would particularly recommend the fish here, it has never disappointed me.  Their lamb chops are also very good.

At lunch time you can usually get a spot at the very cool copper clad bar for a couple of people within 5-10 minutes.
author: Derek n.

description:
Been here twice for lunch and had the Seared Ahi.  I was pleased both times, but questioned if it was really worth $22.

Recently came here for dinner and had the legendary it Cioppino.  It really did live up to the hype.  The broth is has nice kick to it, without killing the fish.  I couldn't even list all the different kinds of tasty fish in this $30 bowl.  The only fish in the stew that wasn't that great was the tuna, but then again, I always think the worst thing you could do to tuna is cook it.   

Service is always good.  Expect a wait, as they don't take reservations.  Go for the booth if you can - it's much nicer in there.
author: Dave H.

description: Seafood Cioppino with Garlic Bread was Awesome!
author: Joe L.

description:
Tadich came highly recommended from a few of my friends, so when I made it to San Fran on vacation it was at the top of my list of places to check out. 
I stopped in for lunch on a weekday, so it was pretty busy, but everyone that works there really knows what they're doing and they were able to make sure that everything was running smoothly.
I had a Bloody Mary while I was waiting to be seated and it was the best one I had the entire 9 days i was in the city. 
The food was wonderful and well worth the short wait. Everyone was right, its a classic !
author: Iris C.

description:
If you work in fidi or even if your visiting, you have to experience a meal at the tadich grill. The food is great, the service is traditional and very professional, and the atmosphere really gives you an idea to how it felt to eat lunch 150 years ago.

I ordered the poached salmon with Brusselsprouts. Salmon was cooked perfectly and the vegetables were served lightly salted, and perfectly cooked as well.
author: Jonathan G.

description: Perhaps the food is great.  I don't know, because I hated the noisy Friday early evening crowd and left before eating.  I had been assured that a table would be available for 6 if we arrived before 6:45:  WRONG.  There was an indefinite wait for a table that large, and the place was so noisy we would not have heard conversation across the table.  The place was busy with TGIFers who work downtown.
author: Betsy F.

description: Best clam chowder I've had in a long time. Wish the price of the ciopinno was better - it was tasty though.
author: E T.

description:
If I could give Tadich Grill 3.5 stars, I would. I loved, loved, loved the food. I ordered the cioppino, which was amazing. I craved it for weeks afterwards and would love to return for another bowl full of the delicious seafood and spicy broth. My friend ordered a baked shrimp and crab dish and she loved it, too. The portions are generous and they don't scrimp on the crab meat at all. The decor was also great -- it definitely has that old time feel and the enclosed booths surrounding the restaurant would make for a cozy date.

I wasn't as thrilled with the service. Our server seemed irritated when we only ordered a half bottle of wine and when we asked for a few more minutes to review the menu. He also told us that other people were waiting for our table when we didn't clear out quickly enough, which has never happened to me before. 

With that said, though, I would certainly return. Not the cheapest place, but worth it for a special dinner.
author: Lo P.

description: This is another place that I had set my expectations high, but found the food just ok...  had a fish dish which was almost bland.
author: Monica R B.

description: Uh, you better have really good food since the person who answered the phone just bit my head off.
author: Spooky E.

description: Everytime I visit this place, the bill gets a little stiffer but it remains a SF classic for its consistently high quality seafood. I personally like their cioppino though some might find the broth light to their taste. Their mesquite grilled fish is always lovely. It's an old fashioned unpretentious place that serves really good and increasingly expensive food. The latter point is probably the biggest down side.
author: Boddy M.

description:
Of course, the four stars go for the fresh platter of seafood one can have here with a glass of bubbly and, in that sense, it'll probably stay on our list of first stop for a night out on a special occasion.

However, we were quite bothered by something we witnessed behind the bar and confirmed with a staff membere there: their treatment of Latino workers leaves much to be desired and we once left offended. There was an apparent dismissive attitude towards a male Latino worker. When we asked them directly, they confirmed that was the case and that it wasn't anything new. 

I truly hope management can make some changes to ensure fair treatment for all employees.
author: Nena G.

description: The clam chowder was fabulous. The service was terrible. The fish was over cooked and dry. I guess I was expecting more from a restaurant that has been around for a long time.
author: Winston W.

description: We had always wanted to try Tadich Grill, but for some reason never got the chance. Last night, we finally made it and it was well worth it. We ate at the counter/bar and watched the "team" in action. Nothing like professional waiters in the City. These guys must have been doing this for year. Personable, good timing, organized and the food was fantastic. I had the seafood Cioppino and it was loaded with goodies. My wife had a shrimp/crab caserole and she loved it. Yes, the place was crowded, but for a reason. If you haven't tried Tadich, it's worth the trip!
author: Jim C.

description:
I think my favorite thing about this place is the blast from the past vibe. It's got a classic saloon feel for some reason. 
The food was good, but I think it's a little overrated. Everything is very rich and a little too flavorful for seafood, in my opinion. The oysters rockefeller were pretty yummy...Who would've thought of basically putting creamy spinach dip on top of oysters and baking it? But I think once was good enough for me to try it. I also had this seafood risotto type dish that was pretty good, but i couldn't finish it. My date had a pork roast with apple sauce that was really good, but it did taste a tad dry. It was a cool experience to try the SF historic landmark a try tho!
author: Emy s.

description: One of my favorite places in SF.  It's a little touristy, but I'll forgive it, because the service is quite good still and the food really is great.  My only issue was the chocolate cake they served me was totally stale, and that's just unforgivable at $8.
author: Yan L.

description: Professional staff- quick and efficient.  The host, waiters,etc.  knew what they were doing and kept the table clear and brought what you needed.  Seafood was fresh and cooked well.  Side dishes complimented the meal. Worth the wait.
author: Violet D.

description: Service was great.  I ordered the cioppino and it was delicious.  The scallops were tender and the sauce was perfect.  Also has a great atmosphere.
author: james f.

description: This is by far the most overrated restaurant I've ever been to. What's up people? The food is average; the prices are unbelievably high....the servers are all from retirement home; the only good thing about this place is the portion....I will not go back here. Why spend $200 for 3 people (without drink)?
author: Paolo D.

description: Being Croatian it is difficult to find food as good as family members make it. Go to Tadich Grill if you have that problem. I was so impressed by the delicious food and the fun atmosphere. The waiters came around and attended to all our needs and even sang a few Croatian songs with us. The bar and the nooks are the best seats in the house so ask the hostess to seat you there. If you like seafood, make sure and order a dish with that because I did and mine was great. Sorry I don't remember exactly what I ordered. I take all my friends and family here when they come into town.
author: Hollie J.

description: Hold up, this is the oldest restaurant in CA? That's what the sign says, and I must admit, stepping into this place is the definition of "old school." Albeit not TOO old, like miner times or something. It's more like the 1940s in here--all the waiters were male, middle-aged, and in white coats. When we first walked by this place the line was out the door, but a few hours later things had calmed down and if you don't mind sitting at the bar you can get seated right away, as we did. The menu was also very old-fashioned, with things like liver & onions, etc. We started things off with a seafood cocktail, which was a delicious mountain of bay shrimp, crab meat and prawns served in a sundae glass--awesome! Very fresh and tasty. I got their meat raviolis in their meat sauce (meaty!) and my friend got linguine and clams. I thought my dish was just OK--the sauce was little on the sweet side and the raviolis themselves seemed a little tasteless. Filling, though--they don't skim on the portions. The linguine and clams looked a lot better, with lots of fresh clams atop a bed of linguine and red sauce. Overall, a nice satisfying dinner for a fairly moderate price for that area of SF. I liked reading about the history of their place on their menu, also. The place does have a lot of history!
author: Steph H.

description:
When you walk into Tadich Grille, you're walking into a piece of San Francisco history.  Don't expect top notch service when walking into the restaurant, turn it down a notch and expect service as you would going to the local pub.  Staff wear white lab coats, when we walked in and stood up front at the door, the staff behind the bar just kind of stared at us as if he was thinking "are you expecting us to seat you, go sit down at any table."  He did come from behind the bar and did guide us to a table. 

The food: 

Clam Chowder (Choice of Boston or Coney Island):  Ordered the Boston style clam chowder.  Good until I started to get the sandy grains which I dislike when I get clam chowder. 

Clams in garlic broth:  Okay, not enough garlic or butter, the clams were fresh.  I found when the waiter gave us a bottle of tabasco sauce when the clams arrived, he most likely intended for us to have it with the clams because after adding a few drops to each clam, it masked any clammy taste and gave it a smooth taste along with the garlic.  Went really well with the clams.  

Sauteed Scallops:  Large portions of scallops with a side of broccoli and pilaf.   I was pretty much done for before I had the scallops after all the clams, I think we went too far with the seafood.  I had one scallop which was massive in size.  It was bland and did not have much flavor other than the fishy scallop taste which I believe it was undercooked.  

Minute Steak : 9 oz new york steak - Simply cooked steak.  Nothing fancy, just a grilled steak with no flavorings.  Add some A1 sauce, Lee and Perrins and you're good to go.  

I'll give it 3 stars because they are keeping it simple and close to I guess how it has always been without changing its menu.  I expected fine dining, but it was no more than pub food.
author: W. L.

description: Tadich Grill is a bit over rated, by my assessment. The atmosphere is fast paced, yet accommodating and comfortable. A bit noisy, but that's to be expected in the Financial District. I found the food over spiced to the point that I could scarcely taste the fish. The crusty bread was too crusty. The shrimp cocktail tasted a bit canned & was full of shells.  Stick to what they (apparently) do best...the Cioppino, as the rest is sub par. Really nice staff though!
author: Misti R.

description: I finally tried the Tadich Grill and loved it! The food is really good and worth the wait!! The only thing is that it's quite pricey for lunch!  If you worked some overtime, it's worth a try!!
author: Toia C.

description:
Tadich Grill has been the top restaurant I've been wanting to experience since first learning of it years back during the Food Network's earlier years.  Remember Cordes & Silverstein?  "The Best Of"?

PACKED place, no surprise given its reputation and proximity in the financial district, not to mention it is (or was) the Holidays 2009.  Per the person behind the counter: 30 minute wait, stand and wait by the wall.  Honest, no nonsense, and I like it.

Misis had lobster thermador, and she loved it.  I had the osso buco.  Shanks and gravy were hearty and savory.  Piece de resistance:  the marrow.  Dense, buttery, delicious!  It puts the other osso buco experiences to shame.  I'll always think of Tadich whenever I crave for osso and whenever we have bulalo at home simply because of that irresistible marrow.  Bad for my health, but damn good!

Thank you, Tadich Grill.
author: Erick ..

description: Nice place,  but I thought the service was alittle poor when compared to the price point.  The waiter seemed like he was doing us a favor serving us.  I have no problem with this kind of service at a $1 taco truck or $2 banh mi place, but at $35 per person?    Food, wine, and ambience was fine however so hence the 3 stars.
author: Ryan Y.

description: I love this place.  I was with my co-workers.  You must get there before the lunch rush which is pretty much every day, otherwise it is impossible.  Just impossible.  But my god worth the wait.  Clam chowder awesome.  Some of the best I have had in the city.  Not too salty, not too starchy, creamy/thick consistency, lots of clams, excellent sea flavor, very tasty.  I think my mouth watered for a moment. I had the pacific salmon.  Melted in my mouth which is odd because a lot of restaurant over cook their salmon.  Not here.  Wonderful searing.  My co-worker had the sole.  That was fabulous as well, buttery consistency but not over powering to the taste of the mild fish.  I was going to ask for a second bite but thought against it.  It really is a fantastic meal.  When I have the time to do it, it is a wonderful treat.  Definitely going back, and soon.
author: Sarah O.

description: Nothing beats the old school charm of the restaurant, especially while chatting up with the ageless bartenders at the bar.
author: Ruthie K.

description: Classic, must visit in SF.  Service is unique and good.  Not the best if you're not a well known baller, but nothing to complain about.. good is ok.. Would not recommend their ribeye.
author: Price L.

description: Doesn't seem as good as it was.  At counter, the waiter was inattentive.  Soup cold and had to be returned.  Fish fine, but Fisherman's platter overcooked (asked the waiter to hold the oysters and he forgot so I got more oysters than anything else). Potatoes and vegetables cold. Just didn't like the service.  Will go to Sam's instead.
author: Yella W.

description:
Went for lunch on a Saturday and was surprised at how full the place was.  But not so full that we had to wait for a seat at the bar, which seems to comprise most of the seats in the joint.  The old SF ambiance is a hoot, and I was in love with everything (delish sourdough, amazing caesar salad and clam chowder) until my main course arrived.  I got one of the daily specials:  pork shoulder.  The meat was juicy, but lacked any notable flavor.  The vegetables were very simple, but decent; the potatoes had a bit of flair with rosemary.

We shared a bread pudding for desert, which was OK as far as bread pudding goes, but a bit cold in the middle.

I will still go back, but I think I'll focus more on their seafood.  Again--the white clam chowder was fantastic, so definitely get either that or the perfect, wonderful caesar to start.
author: Em P.

description: When I first stepped inside, I thought it to be quite small. But I didn't notice the little nooks on the sides of the place. Quite a bit of space after all. Heads up, they won't sit you unless your full party is present (not uncommon). Quite expensive, but well worth it. I had some fantastic seared scallops and the portions from the other meals my friends had were quite generous. Our waiter was beyond fantastic as well. The oldest restaurant in SF, can see why it's stuck around for so long.
author: Jason K.

description:
the seafood cioppino was perfect! $32 for a large bowl, best served for two people.
every spoonful actually contained more seafood than soup, wow.

the coney island clam chowder was ok, the dungeness crab salad was alright...

but just order the cioppino.
author: Ethan L.

description: Food is delicious (the cioppino is worth the money), service is wonderful, great cocktails... what's not to like?
author: Alison B.

description: Amazing!  Delicious seafood and great service!  Ken was especially attentive!   Thank you!
author: Tisha J.

description: To me, the Tadich Grill  IS  San Francisco. I love everything about this restaurant...the decor, the waiters, all the food, but especially the CIOPPINO! Yum!
author: Ruth A.

description:
I think this place was pretty much what I expected from an old, old restaurant. You get huge dishes of food for reasonable price ranges. The food wasn't superb, but hey it's an old place. It was cool cuz we got a booth too, so we had this space to ourselves. We started off with the romaine salad, calamari and the dungeness crab. The crab came in a martini glass, which contained fresh crab and lettuce. The calamari wasn't good, batter was too thick and it just made my stomach feel weird. The romaine salad was on the way oily side. Practically drowning in oil. My mom wanted to get the whole grilled branzino, but they were out, so she went with the red snapper stuffed with crab meat. A friend got the fried oysters with fries platter. My boyfriend got the special which was some fish cheeks with seafood and I got the seafood cioppino, The broth was good in the cioppino, but the mussels and clams were overcooked. My family eats clams and mussels at least once a week, so I don't like them tough. After the fried calamari, I couldn't even finish my dish, so it didn't leave a good impression on me.

Also our waiter was so odd. He would pop in and talk really quickly and it was hard to hear him since the restaurant was so loud. He couldn't hear us either, he kept asking us to repeat and he would forget our drink orders.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Tadich Grill is the quintessential San Francisco dining establishment.  Once you walk in, you feel like you've been transported back in time.  The French-accented waiters in white coats, the rustic and woodsy dining room, the smell of charcoal-grilled meats and seafood, and the where-everybody-knows-your-name type of service.  It's everything you'd expect from a San Francisco legend.

As a lover of cioppino, I had my mind made up before I even arrived to try Tadich's cioppino, which is claimed to have been invented here.  And I have no reason not to believe this because Tadich's cioppino is the best I've ever had thus far.  The infusion of white wine was deliciously strong but not too overpowering, but the best part of all: the chock full of fresh fish, clams, mussels, scallops, shrimp and crab that was found with each spoonful.  For $25, this bowl of soup is truly worth every penny.

The service was amazing from the beginning till the end.  From the moment my gf and I walked in and put our names down, we were greeted and served upon with a smile.  Whether it was the guy who served my gf coffee, the guy who brought us ice water, or our charming French waiter Laurent, we were treated like queens.

If I were ever to leave San Francisco (God forbid), this where my heart would be left.
author: Diane L.

description: Absolutely go to Tadich.  Excellent food, great personality and characteric to the place, and clearly a favorite of many locals.  I had the Cioppino fish stew and it was delicious.
author: Mike R.

description: Old school SF joint. Known for fish. Gets busy and people stand and wait for your seat. Bad wine though. Stick to vodka.
author: Lucy B.

description: If we're paying $130 bucks before tip for 4 people for lunch, free soda refills should come with that. Charging another $3 for a small soda just seems cheap and lazy.
author: Melissa M.

description:
I come in for a cocktail at least once a month, it's been a long tradition of mine.  Bartenders are friendly, and there are plenty of locals and tourists. The San Francisco Twins also are spotted there on a regular basis (I love those women).

Though I don't eat there very often, the seafood is always very fresh and simply prepared.  Good place to take out of town visitors who would like to experience nostalgic SF and skip the lousy restaraunts at Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Okay, after revisiting Tadich Grill a few times since my initial visit, I'll have to admit one thing: I LOVE TADICH GRILL. Expect to spend anywhere from $25-$35 after tip/tax (for lunch).

Their baked CASSEROLE dishes are FINELY made. I love it! Your seafood (shrimp, fish, whatever) sits on a bed of rice and is topped off with cheese and baked to perfection. This comes out saucey so it's always good to take their complimentary bread and dip it in there. YUM-O. 

Attention all clam chowder lovers! Tadich Grill makes an awesome clam chowder. It is creamy, rich, and there are actual chunks of clam in there...unlike other places which will remain unnamed. I think Tadich Grill makes the best creamy clam chowder!!

What I like about Tadich Grill is that they always have a set menu so you can always come here to get your favorites but if you're the adventurous one, they have about 10-15 daily specials ranging from all kinds of seafood.

Next time I visit Tadich Grill, I'll have to try their cioppino because apparently it's AWESOME anddd comparable to Scoma's.
author: Heidi C.

description:
As has been said - Old School.  Real, real old school.  And there's nothing wrong with that.

If you need a reminder of what SF used to be, or if you have out of town guests who would be stoked with some Dashiell Hammett motif, or if you miss the ferry, or if there's a BART strike, or if you've just had a lousy day and cioppino would make everything better - hey. Tadich's. That's why it's there.  

Decent pours on scotches (not a huge selection but they cover the basics), mind blowing cioppino, and usually one can grab a seat at the counter without a huge fuss.  

The last 3 times that I've sat at the counter, though, people keep trying to start up a conversation.  And I always have a book.  Didn't books at dinner used to be a tacit signal that you really don't want to talk?  That you're not here to meet people?  Listen, Mr Drunk Guy ('sho whatcha readin?  i'm an author, you know. i jusht finished my book, jusht the other day,') I'm not here to chat, OK?  A counter is not a bar, OK?  I'm here for the CIOPPINO, dadgummit.  

Anyway.  This place is Get Out of Bad Day (though not for free) card.  It's definitely worth a visit.
author: berkeley f.

description: Cioppino with a good deal of fresh seafood, rich tomato and wine sauce, bread to dip. Look for the crab omelette when it is available. Very SF old school with booths and waiters in white. closed on Sunday's. good clam chowder.
author: Calvin L.

description: The only reason I went here was because it is one of the oldest restaurants in San Francisco.  The food pales in comparison to the other top notch restaurants this city has to offer but the historical value was cool.  Just be prepared to have an ordinary meal in a diner type restaurant.
author: Lisa V.

description:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/pacific-coast-highway-san-diego#hrid:VwhCzha1F6nIpKF3Ckk7tw

The Tadich Grill is located in the Financial District and it is the oldest building in the state of California. It is San Francisco's oldest restaurant and started as a coffee stand in 1849. Tadich Grill was the first to grill seafood over mesquite charcoal in the 1920s. 

They reminded me of the old school steak houses of New York City.  Tadich is classified as a seafood restaurant, but the steaks have to be prime.

I was so excited just to be here that I rang the doorbell, walked in and yelled, "we're here!"  Oh, that was a lie!

Oh my what a fine establishment this is. You walk in to finely dressed waiters and tables, lined along cafe curtain dressed windows. There is alot of dark wood, giving it a Tavern feel. 

When I walked in and immediately smelled char broiled steaks, I had no choice than to have the Filet Mignon. I am so smart and it was the perfect choice. The filet could be cut with a butter knife and the juicy goodness just melted on my tongue. My tongue was dancing with joy. Hubby had the NY Strip and he enjoyed every last bite. 

I started with the Oysters Rockefeller which were very good. Hubby had the NE Clam Chowder and my mother had the Asparagus Leek soup. For her entree she had the pan seared Rainbow Trout. 

Everything is Ala Carte, so plan on dropping some cash here. It is very expensive. 

Service is top notch, by very seasoned waiters and the food selection leaves nothing to be desired. When in San Fran again, I shall try the Lobster & Crab Thermidor and ask my hubby to order the Filet, so I can still have that bite of char broiled heaven! 

The desserts sounded amazing and next time I may skip the appetizer so I have room to try a dessert.

Just to let you know, if you would like to check out the Tadich Grill and you are not into splurging, they do have a large selection of salads.  They also have a few pasta dishes and daily specials.
author: DJ M.

description:
It's one of the "gotta do' restaurants in San Francisco; it's a classic!  It's also known as "The Original Cold Day Restaurant" (old politician story attached that you can read while you're looking at the menu).

Tadich is usually crowded with people waiting for seats, some at the bar and others at tables or in booths.  It's not quiet by any means, but not so loud that you can't hear yourself or your table mates talk.  Old school ambiance.

I've never had anything at the Tadich Grill that I didn't like.  That being said, if you want a sure bet, have the Cioppino.  Tadich does this much better than most!  Flavor, portion, fair price - all good!  But tonight I decided to have something different. I started off with a bowl of clam chowder (white) (yes, they have red too).  Extraordinary!  That could easily be my meal sometime!
Then I ordered a grilled sea bass.  It was perfectly grilled, light and it was a nice sized portion. The sea bass was served with green beans and rice.  The green beans were excellent; the rice was... rice.  I would order this dish again, but not until I have another Cioppino.

Oddly for me, tonight I had dessert - the Carrot Cake w coffee.  The carrot cake was moist and delicious, but the coffee - wow!  REALLY good coffee!

So, one odd thing... they have a full bar and beer on tap, but they don't have Anchor Steam.  Just seems odd to me that the quintessential San Francisco restaurant doesn't carry the quintessential San Francisco beer.  
Oh well, I made do with a Sierra Nevada.

One more thing - the waiters here are not kids.  They've been doing this for quite some time, know exactly what they are doing, and the do a terrific job taking care of every guest!

Don't miss this place!
author: Clint L.

description: I'm not a "throw the kitchen sink of any kind of fish into my pasta" kinda girl so I have to order carefully. I took my whole family here and we had the best time. We had to wait because we were a party of seven but that is the fun part. You get to sit at the bar and be heckled by the mean old bartenders. Don't worry, they do it to everyone. We got to sit in one of the cute little nooks with the curtain. The waiter kept on popping his head in and out to take our order  - he was hilarious and awesome (not like all the servers you will find there, this one was a gem). My family thought the food was awesome. We all ordered different things but I think their specialty is the Cioppino and everyone who ordered it was impressed. I stick to the basics so I ordered the most boring fish on the menu and was pleased. It's totally old school and that is what makes it unique and lovable. Go, it will be fun.
author: Kelly C.

description:
I was very disappointed by my experience with Tadich Grill.  We planned a work lunch (for 7 people in my department).  Unfortunately, Tadich Grill doesn't take reservations, and when we got there, they refused to seat any of us until the entire party arrived.  We had to stand around in the middle of the dining area (no waiting area) until our co-workers joined us from their trip to the ATM.

They put us at a table that was too small for our party, it was in a small enclosure, where we found it difficult to get in and out, even to move.  We made some adjustments to our seating configuration, because we just couldn't fit in there the way they had it set up.   The (very rude) waiter gave us attitude about moving the chairs, saying that he would know better than us the best way to fit all of us in.  He argued with us about this for a few minutes.

The food is way overpriced for what you get.  Plan on spending over $50 per person for lunch (for a 3 course meal).  When I got my meal it was extremely bland and tasted like it was not seasoned at all.

In summary: 
1) Reservations not available and can't be seated without entire party present.
2) Insufficient seating.
3) Rude Waiter
4) Way, way over priced
5) Bland food
author: Mike R.

description: Almost always a stop when I visit SF. Yesterday's meal was disappointing. Fish was undercooked and bartender was indifferent when I pointed that out. All he needed to do was offer to bring it back to the kitchen which he failed to do. I appreciate that surly waiters are part of the charm of this place but this went a little too far.
author: T H.

description: This place has to be doing something right since its the oldest restaurant in California. The food, vibe, atmosphere, and servers/bartenders are great. I enjoyed Tadich very much.. I intend to make many more trips in the future.
author: Janine D.

description: this place runs like a well-oiled machine. they also serve exquisite food. prices are very reasonable for what you're getting!! they honestly deserve more than 5 stars.
author: Valerie B.

description: It had been a minute since we had come for lunch.  Definitely a nice splurge date with the hubby.  I had the ny steak and he had the cosmopolitan salad.  Both delicious both perfect.  We also had a cup of chowder that was huge, thick and very tasty.  We lucked out and scored a seat at the bar.  Superb service too.  I love this place!  Highly recommend the salads especially their homemade Louie dressing.  Hopefully we will return sooner than later.
author: La C.

description:
This restaurant is San Francisco!

Good food, I had the ciopinno and the seafood sampler plate, delicious!!!

We also shared a steak which was grilled to a perfect medium!

The ambiance was lively, and the service top notch.  Our waiter even talked some college football with us, Nice!!!

The whole experience was awesome and went down smooth like the three gin and tonics I had!!!!
author: Richard N.

description: Fresh, high quality foods, turned into fabulous dishes with expert preparation and seasoning along with full size portions and expert wait staff eliminate any minute disappointment at Tadish Grill!
author: J R.

description:
Ate here in early April, and it was very good.
Wait staff had energy and personality and offered their favorites. I couldn't quite tell if they were being honest with their recommendations or they were told to offer those that evening. None-the-less, the recommendations sounded worth trying including the Seafood Cioppino which was awesome!
I started with the Boston Clam Chowder which was probably the best clam chowder I've ever eaten... and I've had a lot!
I ordered the Deep-Fried Seafood Plate for my entree, and it was good. I wish now in hind-sight that i had ordered a fresher dish that wasn't fried (the fried batter didn't seem to add any special flavor to the items, thus it tasted like fried food I could've gotten anywhere).
The Seafood Cioppino was unbelievably flavorful. The cioppino and the chowder earned the Tadich Grill my 5 stars.
The tiramisu and chocolate mousse where really tasty with a fresh cup of coffee.
Pros: great tasting food, cool old-school feel
Cons: long wait (understandable though), hovering newly arriving customers for bar seating since it is first come-first serve.
author: Chris M.

description: The Cioppino was amazing!!  It's $30 but a very large portion.  I would recommend that's all you order or have someone to share it with.  I was in SF on a business trip and decided to try it based on all the reviews.  I was dinning alone so I sat at the bar.  I happened to sit next to someone else doing the same thing so we had a pleasant dining experience.  The atmosphere is a little noisy but fun.  A great place to go with a small group or even by yourself.  I will make sure to got to Tadich Grill the next opportunity I have!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
I was looking for something to eat for dinner in the blustery night after I arrived in San Francisco.  (I should apologize for bringing the cold weather - its my fault.)  
Anyway,  the sign on Tadich Grill says "The Original Cold Day Restaurant" or something like that...   So I walked right inside and found an open seat at the counter.  

This place has character and there's nothing fake about any of it.  (Of course, I would later learn that its renowned for its character, as I happened to walk into the oldest continuously operating restaurant in California.)  An older gentleman sat down next to me at the counter.  (He might have been one of the original customers during the Gold Rush days.)    He told me that I should order the "Sand-Dabs" which are one of those flounder-type fish that live on the bottom of the bay (which, incidentally, is still contaminated from the Gold Rush days.)   Unfortunately,  I had already ordered the seafood curry.  Next time I will try what he ordered,  it looked really good.
author: Jeff G.

description:
ice cold salmon and grease soaked soft shell crab.
i would expect this at a low end diner.  (though i would never order soft shell crab at a low-end diner)
author: pablo p.

description:
For years we've been wanting to try Tadich Grill since we are SF residents.  It takes friends visiting from Austin, TX to finally get us there. We were a little concerned about going on a Friday night knowing that they don't take reservations. My friends got there early, got us on the waiting list and found 2 stools at the bar for drinks. 

Tadich Grill is one of San Francisco's oldest restaurant. It's in a wonderful location in the Financial District. The restaurant has a lot of character. Definitely feels like old San Francisco. Loved the ambience!
The bartenders/waiters have a lot of character as well. 

Had a house Chardonnay and it wasn't too bad. We ordered calamari at the bar while waiting for my husband to arrive.  Calamari was lightly coated and very tender. Just the way I like it!! Husband arrived right when our table was called. He unfortunately missed the calamari--one of his favorite dishes!

The restaurant has boothes and tables. We were lucky to get a booth. It had a lot of privacy where we could talk without shouting. Our waiter was definitely old style--very efficient without a lot of personality. Didn't look like any of the wait staff there was under 45 years old. 

The menu is extensive. It was really hard to make a decision. I finally chose the crab cakes. Hubby chose the seafood platter and both of my friends chose a seafood dish "a la monza". We weren't sure what that meant but the waiter explained that it was cooked in a Italian red sauce. One thing really interesting about Tadich's menu is their daily specials. They mention that they might run out in the evening. One of my friends ran into that issue when ordering the special ravioli of the day. At least there are a ton of other options.

The portions are large. They serve wonderful sourdough bread. It's thick and chewy just the way I like it. The crab cakes were delicious. Came with rice and a huge portion of creamed spinach. Everyone else was pleased with their meals as well. Also tried their clam chowder that was thick and loaded with ingredients.

So delighted to have finally been able to eat at the San Francisco landmark! We're definitely going to go back again to try something else on their extensive menu.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I tagged along today with some folks from work for a "special" lunch at the Tadich Grill. I wasnt really familiar with the place -- I had a vague notion of a stuffy old-style San Francisco businessman's joint. However, immediately we entered the place, I was impressed...! When you walk in, you're immediately presented with a long, classic bar in a comforting, wood-paneled area. There are attentive white-aproned waiters, the youngest of which seemed to be at least 60. We were greeted warmly and seated in a booth along the wall, a very private area. Fortunately, we got there at ~11:30, as the place very quickly filled up for Friday lunchtime.

I ordered a "surf & turf" choice, the Fillet Mignon and Jumbo Prawns, and I was delighted with the excellent beef and (obviously - for a place where seafood is a specialty) shrimp and tasty Brussel sprouts. My colleagues got the signature seafood cioppino and Crab Louie, and everyone was extremely pleased. A very pleasant surprise and a most enjoyable lunch. I am going to make a point of going back -- now that I know the place. Needless to say, it's fairly pricey -- but you certainly get what you pay for. A very good venue for a special lunch. (And I'm guessing it'd be a very cozy winter location...)
author: donal c.

description: As part of the local establishment - a great place for lunch, though people like me were thrifty and only ordered a two - course meal including salad.  Atmosphere is excellent and makes the meal experience really enjoyable.  Great place for a working lunch.  Really good.
author: Thomas H S.

description:
This was our first time here.  I remember reading about it in Herb Caen's column.  It is the quintessential old school San Francisco restaurant.  We arrived just before 11:30 after a trip to the Brazilian Consulate to get a visa.  In March we're doing a cruise from Valparaiso to Rio and we need Brazilian visas for our stops in Brazil.  We arrived about 10:45 and were surprised by the masses of people, some of whom had been waiting more than 2 hours.  I won't go into all that.  Suffice it to say we paid a documents processor to take care of it for us rather than wait hours and hours.  Yes, we're spoiled.  But back to Tadich's.

The restaurant was largely empty when we walked in, although as we walked through I noticed the enclosed booth-like side ares were well populated.  According to Herb Caen that's where the politicos and the "cool kids" sit.  We were shown to a two person table and when I looked around 15 minutes later every table I could see was occupied, as were the seats at the bar.  We were given menus and crusty sourdough French bread and butter.  There was a bowl of cut up lemons on the table.  I ordered the local Black Cod w/ Lobster sauce lunch special, which came w/ rice and brocolini.  Alan ordered the crab cakes, were had the same sides.  Both mains were excellent.  The fish was perfectly cooked and like buttah.  The crab cakes were among the best I've tasted here, easily as good as those we had in Seattle or in Virginia.  The brocolini was crisply al dente and the rice was tasty.  Service was perfunctory but correct.  This place is the real deal.  No wonder it's been around 160 years.
author: Toni M.

description: The broiled lobster was terrific!  This 161 year old Tadich Grill is a historic must when in San Francisco.  Loved the long bar that seats over 25 people built in the 1960s. I felt like I was stepping back in time with great service and food....like they must have had back in the "good ole days"!  Love it!
author: CJ O.

description: My aunt lived in the area when she was my age, and used to have dinner here with her parents. She was in town for one night and hadn't been to Tadich in thirty years, so we went. It was good, and we had a good time. I'd go back, but more for the vibe than the food.
author: skylar p.

description:
Well, I finally made it to SF's oldest restaurant.  I loved reading the history of the place on the front of the menu, I had always wondered about that "cold day" tagline. . . I just figured it was a comment on our weather, but the real story is much more fun.  Other than that it was. . .  well, what's the best way to put this.  I'd say that San Franciscans have been eating here for years, and it's still the same San Franciscans eating here.  A much older crowd, with a few younger folks business lunching on a Monday afternoon.  From the staff to the diners, I'd guess the median age to be retirement worthy.  The soft food I received makes it easy to understand why they're here.  Little old lady (or man if you prefer) food if I've ever had it.  Boiled brussels sprouts folks.  Prices are insane and service is slightly bothered that you're there, though attentive enough to bring you what you need. 
The interior is ugly as sin too - I loved the wood and the little booths (similar to what's going on over at Elite Cafe), but the ceiling and walls just don't jive. I've been, and I'm glad I went, but I won't be rushing back any time soon.  Unless I have a bunch of teeth pulled and need some soft foods.
author: Jennifer D.

description: This place first came onto my radar when it was featured on The Food Network.  They're known for their Cioppino, and it is very tasty.  However, my 2 favorite dishes so far are the Crab Louie Salad and the Clam Chowder (cream style).  Both can't be beat.  I look forward to exploring the menu.
author: Jean L.

description:
Ate at Tadich's for the first time yesterday. The Avocado and Bay Shrimp Diablo with rice en casserole was truly DELICIOUS. Had clams for an appetizer, also delicious.

I can't complain about anything, really...it was great!
author: Darshan S.

description: Best cioppino in San Francisco, or any where for that matter.  Return there after 16 years and the food is still just as fantastic.  Service is top notch as well.  Always a required stop for me.
author: Russel Y.

description:
Old school but excellent food.  Feels like you're going back 100 years when you eat there - servers have all been there forever and it shows in the great service.
Favorites: Cioppino (it doesn't get any better), chowder, and almost anything else on the menu.
author: Ric S.

description: Everything looked so good I wasn't sure what to order, so I closed my eyes and pointed to the dungeness crab Louie it was the best salad that I have ever had. my wife and kids loved their meal also ,we will be back when we vacation again
author: Danny C.

description: It is easy to see why this is not only an institution but a destination not be missed in SF.  Everything about the place makes you feel like you are a member of a special club and reminds you of all the great places of memory.  Lots of dark wood, private booths, nice lighting and the waiters look the part.  I don't think any of the food here will knock your socks off and it's quite expensive for what it is, but it is fresh and good standard fare.  We had the manila clams and the clam chowder and both were good and filling.  Next time I would try the seafood stew as it looked great.  It was a great experience overall and it's hard not to leave with a smile on your face.
author: Amy H.

description:
Growing up in SF, I've heard of Tadich Grill through misc editorials, but it was never on the top of my list of places to go, given the wealth of other restaurants out in the city.  But finally after seeing it featured on Anthony Bourdain's - No Reservations, and hearing it almost got burned down, I figured it was time I sampled this old time establishment.

First off, you go in, put your name down, and wait your turn to be called.  Do yourself a favor, find a seat at the bar and order up a few drinks, because on a busy night, you'll be waiting for a while.  If you're not sitting at the bar, be sure to listen out for your name being called, because it will only be called once, and if missed they skip to the next party.  

We started off with the clam chowder, with a generous helping of clams.  It was good, but the gf agreed that the taste wasn't what she expected from a clam chowder.  It wasn't bad, just different.  Then came the ciopinno, mouth watering seafood goodness.  Comes with two pieces of garlic bread to soak up all the juices.  Again, a generous amount of seafood, all very fresh, and done just right. 

Overall, it was a good experience, staff has that old style charm, atmosphere was a little mixed, but excellent food.
author: Timothy H.

description: This is a good spot for fresh fish.  It is always simply prepared, but good. Other items can be a hit, or a miss.  This is an old restaurant, and the food is also "old style".  It is always busy at lunch, and there is often a wait.  Service is also hit, or miss.  We have had great service here, and we have had absolutely terrible service here.
author: Vicki T.

description:
I REALLY loved Tadich. 

From the shouting (but very friendly!) bartender to my amazing buttery scallops - they hit the nail on the head, big time, with me. 

It was rainy and windy and cold the day my family and I went - so everyone was in Tadich getting warm. We waited for a bit at the bar and enjoyed some drinks. 

Once we were seated our waiter was attentive and knowledgeable, as one would expect in an institution like this.

And then the food came. O.M.G. I would eat my plate every day and die from arteries clogged with butter, but I would die HAPPY. The scallops melted on my tongue. The other items in the seafood saute (shrimps & crab legs) were also splendid.
