Everyone else enjoyed their meals too - pasta w/ clams and white sauce, seafood cioppino, and pacific oysters rockefeller. Mmmm.

Good thing Dad was paying too - it's not exactly cheap :) But oh so good and worth it.
author: Liz K.

description:
My parents got engaged here. Then they had a whirlwind romance that lasted about four years. I hear reports that they were extremely happy.

Then came the 70's. Lots of cocaine.Someone may have gotten dragged out of somewhere by their hair?

I hear Tadich has great grilled fresh fish. Three decades later, Dad still has the ashtray he stole. Must have been good fish.
author: H G.

description: great hangtown fry!
author: Bob P.

description: While working in the area we (a mom, a young model and I, the photographer) came upon this hidden gem because everything else was closed during the after lunch pre-dinner hours.  We were about to open the door and a rude old lady and her mother shoved us out of the way, "EXCUSE ME!" they belched and cut right in front of us, and they were promptly seated first.  That was the only negative experience we encountered.  We smiled it off and the staff more than made up for their rude patrons.  We were seated immediately in a wonderful closed off booth which happened to be right next to the rude ladies.  We laughed because our table was by far the better, roomier, more private and classier table.  The food was superb, melt in your mouth deliciousness.  I ordered the clam chowder which was perfect and creamy with tons of fresh tasting clams.  I also had a garden salad with blue cheese dressing which was spot on with lovely tender greens.  The ladies shared a sea food salad (they said it was perfect and that they would be returning the next time they visited the city).  I will also be returning with my husband for a date night.  The server and staff were excellent, very attentive, we didn't have a dry glass or have to so much as glance their way for any wants, even though the place was packed.  It was a perfect lunch.  When we left the rude ladies even asked how our meal was.  I wish I could say better than theirs, but they were chowing on large, bright red lobster tails accompanied by martinis.
author: Anita L.

description: Had dinner with a friend a few evenings ago. Overall experience was really nice, kinda old school with a unique charm.  Food maybe geared towards SF seafood.  I'm more of a steak kinda guy so I thought the meal was good, but nothing off the charts.   Loved thev ceasar salad and sourdough bread though.  Service from Matti (?) was great!  He made the evening.  Definitely would come back with friends as this is a staple here in the city, one of the oldest eateries in SF!
author: Matthew B.

description: I recommend the three martini lunch here.  It comes with a big flat pounded calamari steak in a lemon caper sauce.  Make sure to have this lunch with an old banker or attorney who's been having the lunch here regularly for at least 30 years, that way you have a chance at getting a table.
author: Clarke H.

description:
The oldest restaurant in California!! Wow!!
There was a long wait, but don't let that stop you. They told us about 30 minutes wait, but it only took about 10 minutes before we were seated, not bad at all.

I started with a cup of 7 seas soup, very good. It has mussels, shrimp and crab meat in it. It was kinda similar to the cioppino on the entree but with different kinds of seafood in it. I got the baked seabass for my entree and loved it too, even though it came with very traditional sides (steamed brocolli and rice pilaf). 

There's a full bar for you to get drinks while waiting for a table. Service is efficient and the decor is old but well kept up. It's great to see a place like this still running full swing in SF!!
author: Florence W.

description: I've been to Tadich a bunch. The atmosphere is classic SF and the food is always great. The cioppino and sole are outstanding, and the ahi I had recently was some of the best I've  ever had. Service is brusque, but that's part of the charm.
author: A H.

description:
Go here now!

My boyfriends Aunt and Uncle were in town, and his Uncle asked about this place.  We Yelped it, saw the reviews, and my boyfriend remembered seeing the place on Bobby Flay.  We decided to give it a shot.

Thank goodness we did!

We walked in the freezing cold from the Ferry Building to here.  Lunch on Saturday is not very crowded.  We were seated immediately in one of the infamous booths, very cool.  Hooks for our things, and PLENTY of room for the four of us.

The menu was VERY impressive!!  So many things looked incredible.  They have simple classic seafood dishes, as well as ones that I not only never tried, but never even heard of.  Based on the descriptions of everything though, VERY good!

Our server was efficient.  We weren't ready to order, or even to decide on drinks, but he was great at coming back to check in on us.  Not one of those places where they come back 15 minutes later.

I went with the Dungeonous Crab and Prawn a la Monzo, a casserole type dish, which was DELICOUS.  The other dishes ordered were the Calamari Steak, the Swordfish Steak,  and the Linguine with Clams.

Everyones dish tasted better than the next.  The prices were definitely a little high though.

No worries, if you are on a budget, you can still swing by and get a bowl of clam chowder for about $6!!!  So not EVERYTHING is a $20 dish.

Really cool place.  A lot of history in it, too.  Read the front of the menu when you go!  A lot of people are mis-quoting the history here on Yelp, so go there and read for yourself.  It's pretty interesting!

And I guess everyone who thinks it has a mobster feel hasn't been to New Jersey...  I found it to be warm and welcoming here, definitely looking forward to come back again soon.
author: Jess R.

description:
God, I want to like Tadich's but damn!

The steaks are good enough, the seafood is actually pretty bad. The entire menu is overpriced for its quality. I have no idea how those sand dabs made it on a list of "things to eat before you die".

Plus, they do weird shit like put Asian sweet chili sauce on your fish and chips! A soggy mess and worst I've ever had. Bok choy with their fish dishes... Why? If you're gonna do old SF food, just keep it simple and dated-- that's what we want here! Like their Oysters Rockefeller... not great, but good enough and it works (even though it might more accurately be described as creamed spinach with some oysters in it).

Some complain about the servers but I think they're great. Straight to the point, they leave you alone yet still manage to be attentive, and none of that phony nice guy routine.

What you are really paying for is the lore of Tadich's in it's heyday and just to say that you've been there. If that's your thing, go for it. Unfortunately, Tadich Grill has become one of those SF tourist traps that gouges the dollars right out of your wallet simply because... they can.

By the way, I love chili sauce and bok choy, but this place ain't called Tadich Golden Wok.

Good Tadich Grill experience: Avoid going on a weekday between the hours of 11:30am and 1:30pm (unless you're independently wealthy, fun-employed or have a ton of patience). Go inside (take a cab or public transportation there 'cause the parking blows), take a look around ("Ooh! Aahh!" very cool), maybe sit at the bar and have a drink (a beer or bourbon would do). If you're gonna eat, just fill up on the great sourdough and top-notch clam chowder. Pay your $20 and be on your way. Fun!

Bad Tadich experience 1: Go there for dinner on a first date. It will likely be the last date too. But if that's your intent, cool!

Bad Tadich experience 2: Go with a bunch of friends who have never been before and are expecting something great.

If you're dying for SF nostalgia and a better steak (better everything, really), Alfred's ain't too far away..!
author: Chris O.

description: Bing Bang Boom Old School.  The only place I can get Oysters Rockefeller and, yes, they do rock.  Brought my visiting parents there for the nostalgia and my father said his meal was "really good."   NOTE:  my father never compliments anyones food with anything other than, "yeah, it's not bad."   I couldn't believe my ears.
author: B B.

description: This was my 2nd time here.  I had the Australian lobster, which was larger than I expected and delicious.  My friend had the porterhouse steak which was also excellent.  The lobster came with creamed spinach, steamed vegetables, and the crispiest fries ever.  I can't believe I finished my dinner.  We split a bread pudding with warm bourbon caramel sauce and whipped cream.  Yum!
author: John B.

description:
A stupendous experience. First off - we didn't grease any palms to be seated. Unlike "today's generation," we people from the olden days tend to be patient, and we prefer not to be rushed to a table. We are happy to order a drink and gab and enjoy the few minutes when waiters aren't asking us how our meal is or whether we want soup. 

When the group was seated, after our cocktails were worked on and our conversation had taken its course, our waiter came over and was the best. From the old country, Jonas recommended excellent dishes, appetizers and the like to start things off. 

We ordered those, and some wine, and our main courses, and we all received our dinners in a timely fashion. There was Cioppino here, grilled sole there, a delicious crab and shrimp casserole here, pork chops there, etc. All of it was incredible, fresh and delicious, in the old world, hearty and stick-to-the-ribs kind of way. 

I find it sort of sad that people who review this restaurant and rate it low begrudge a waiter his efforts to earn a living. A waiter who gives extra effort with the intention of maximizing his customer's comfort and enjoyment DESERVES a tip. And the person who can afford to give said tip should feel no shame in paying for the privilege of that service. Someone who HAS money might well have EARNED it, sir! And those who DON'T have the means to tip a waiter before he's served them will STILL get excellent service. Just like we did. They may not be seated before the throng, but THAT'S WHAT THE BAR IS FOR!

Yes, you can have a drink before you're seated, despite info elsewhere in someone's review to the contrary. I know because all 10 or 12 of us did. Or did I imagine having a cocktail before being seated?

We Americans can be so crazy impatient. Relax, have a cocktail, don't spend so much time snarling at waiters and diners. Is that your idea of fun? "Oh, hey Moe, I was victimized at the Tadich! Don't go there!" C'mon! Gimme a spit-take break! And I beg your pardon, Honey, but before this country went insane, it was a term of respect and familiarity to be called honey. Now, apparently, it's the equivalent of "paranoid brat" or "tedious whiner." Whatever. And another thing while I'm at it. Just a little rule to live your life by: if you had a problem with EVERY waiter in this restaurant, I'm going to suggest you look at yourself in the mirror. This shows up elsewhere in your life, don't it, honey? I'm gonna go out on a limb here and guess you've had similar issues with other businesses. The whole world seems to be against you sometimes, don't it honey?

I would recommend this fantastic place to anyone visiting San Francisco. It did not disappoint in any way whatsoever.
author: Shemp H.

description:
I love the unassuming, classic feel of this restaurant! 

You can't put a price on the awakening of your senses as your taste buds are aroused by spectacular culinary art...however, Tadich Grill left my taste buds bored with little to be excited about. It isn't about the money, but the food lacks culinary passion for the price ($30/plate).

The service was good. The food was good. But, just good. 

At the end of the day, I'd like to see this restaurant stay alive for it's fresh seafood, and historic recognition.  After all,  it is the oldest restaurant in California!
author: Matt D.

description:
I had the most wonderful seafood today! OMG! It was $25 but worth the succulent shrimp, crab and scallops in the seafood saute. Good hunk of sourdough bread, not enough butter. Plenty of lemons though.

It's right next door, so I'm doomed...

But will go again, maybe once a month.
author: Natasha M.

description: Extremely rude service.  We informed the manager and promptly left the restaurant before we even had a chance to order anything.  Manager looked like he could have cared less that his server's horrible attitude chased away LOCAL customers.  Bad way to run a business IMHO.
author: Candace R.

description: I don't understand why everyone thinks this place is so great. I went here with a group of people and we ordered several things to share. All of them were fair to mediocre, nothing was great. I could have easily walked out and left most of the food on my plate with no regrets  And the service was pretty slow. I won't be going back, I can get much better and more interesting seafood elsewhere in San Francisco.
author: Sydney L.

description:
I read an article "100 things you should eat before you die" and the Sand Dabs at Tadich Grill was one of them. Then I saw a show that raved about the Cioppino. Since we were in the city on Saturday we decided to give it a try. We arrived just in time, only a 20 minute wait with 4 or so in front of us. We grabbed a seat and a drink at the bar and waited. Shortly there after the place started filling up with people lined up against the wall. Don't think about putting in a reservation, we tried and were informed they never take them. We were hoping to get a booth but since we were not feeling warm fuzzies we decided to take what came first and lucky us it was a booth. Our waiter didn't have much patience and seemed very rushed, maybe that is part of the odd charm of the place. You wondered if the soup lady would yell at you "no soup for you" if you didn't make a quick decision. 
I ordered the cioppino and my hubby had the sand dabs. We also ordered white clam chowder. The chowder was thick and rich but needed more smokey bacon flavor. The Cioppino was out of this world. Chock full of everything from the sea (crab, scallops, shrimp, mussels, fish and clams) but the best part of it was the tasty red broth. I could have had a bowl of that with bread alone. Not only did you get fresh bread at the table but your cioppino came with two pieces of buttery grilled bread, moist and crunchy but a little soft on the inside, like the best crouton ever. I was so full I could barley move and although I tried my hardest I couldn't finish it all. The sand dabs on the other hand were nothing to write about. If you like a mild white fish like talapia, you will enjoy it but I was looking for something special. It was good but nothing special.  Another bucket list item accomplished but this will not be a once in a lifetime experience.  I will go back.  They make the best Cioppino I've ever had!
author: Dianne M.

description: I love the old school feel here.  Makes me want to buy a bowler hat to fit in with the decor.  Also that it's called a "cold weather restaurant" - so fitting for San Francisco.  Simple, fresh seafood - not dressed up.  Big fan of the chowders!
author: Anna V.

description:
I had the opportunity to try Tadich Grill a few months ago for my birthday with a good buddy and must I say, it was a great time out. 

The ambiance of the whole restaurant really brings you back a few decades and the staff is on point at all times. We were promptly seated at the bar for lunch and were waited on in no time. 
We had heinekens for our appetizer, bread/butter for another appetizer and I ordered the seared Ahi with seaweed salad over a bed of caesar salad for my entree. The tuna was seared perfectly and the seaweed salad, was seaweed salad. 

The only downer was when i took my fourth bite and chomped down on a sardine....shieeeeeeet give me another beer. I forgot that i was at the Tadich Grill, where old school doesnt mean will ferrell and good ol' blue, but rather chuckwagons and the oregon trail (no, not the computer game). 
I guess they really do keep it authentic! 

I cant wait to come back for dinner.
author: Jason W.

description: Heart their seafood pasta, steaks, and service. The feel of this place is old schooled and sitting at the bar for lunch is definitely a SF experience. This place gets busy for lunch for sure so arrive early.
author: Eva Y.

description:
I walked into Tadich with my best "You better impress me and it won't be easy, because I already know you think your restaurant rocks" attitude well in place. 

San Francisco has a slug of  classic restaurants that pack a lot of hype when you murmur their names. Tadich has fabulous word of mouth. They do not take reservations and they are nestled in the Fin Dist. Here we go...impress me please. Despite the no res rule,  we only waited about 5 minutes for a table for 2. While you wait for a table in the old-school tiled space, you are more than welcome to sit at the large wooden bar in the center of the room. 

The wait-staff is saucy and I like it! They tend to have a witty sense of humor and a slight sarcastic tone. Very fun and these guys don't mess around when it comes to their knowledge. They're informed so ask away.   TG is known for their seafood and old school charm, so why delivery anything else? Starters like clams and calamari set the tone. Salads with tuna or salmon, entrees highlighting fillets of sole, snapper, bass, etc.... omg Seafood heaven. They even have some veggie salads, a vegetarian plate and veggie side options. 

What TG will not give you: a pretentious atmosphere, a quiet space, or a boring experience. TG is a SF classic, and it's not difficult to conclude why.
author: Theresa T.

description: Have always wanted to eat here, but was never able to get in. Glad to have given it one more try.  The cioppino was probably the best I've ever had, and my husband loved his crab cakes too.  The service was excellent. We now understand why it is SF's oldest restaurant.
author: Patti B.

description: I am a long time customer of Tadich. No more. Our service was dismal. I felt we were being pushed out the door before we were seated. The cioppino was very average with the stock made mostly of "bay shrimp," the kind 300 to the pound. One scallop. Two shrimp. Two soups. Two beers. $100.00. No thanks. I'll go where my business is more appreciated and the food is prepared and --more importantly-- served with care.  They should be ashamed of letting such a fine restaurant sink to such an abysmal level.
author: William K.

description:
I love reading my old-style San Francisco cookbooks. I have books from the 1960s covering restaurants featuring, at the time of publication,  50 to 100 year histories. Back then they called Tadich's cuisine "old San Francisco." There are some dishes in these books which I can barely imagine, and would probably never cook, like Oysters Rockefeller and some of the creamy seafood casserole concoctions. 

Tadich's really makes me wish I lived in San Francisco earlier in the 20th century, back when my father was a kid in the Marina and his in-laws were wisely-invested in bootlegging. The no-nonsense old world decor, semi-private booths and intense seafood smell feel so regional and so ... old. That's partly why, when I saw Deviled Crab on the menu, I could not pass it up. It's a classic Old SF recipe I've read and wondered about countless times, and it's something you'd just never do to perfectly good crab. So, why not enjoy it as constructed by the experts? It was deliciously creamy without being over-rich, a little rice but not too much, and it was a very generous portion. 

Our nice slavic waiter in the white coat looked askance when I ordered a campari cocktail, and I had to tell him what was in it. Nostalgia isn't always a bed of roses.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: The ciopinne. Was fabulous, but the sand dabs were dull.  Staff was very friendly and helpful.  Atmosphere was loud, busy, and fun. I highly recommend.
author: John E.

description:
Giving a bad review to one of the city's oldest restaurants (since 1849!) is like bad-mouthing your grandma. The place has history. The layout is a blast from the pork-pie hats at the bar past. The waiters are friendly, funny and attentive. I respect my elders, I really do. But in the end, food just isn't that good. Ouch. Sorry, grandma.

The best dish of the night was the halibut casserole...but I believe that if you drown anything in enough cheese, it'll taste good. 

My Pacific oysters trio wasn't horrible, but out of the three kinds (rockefeller, creole and curry) I only liked one: the rockefeller. The creole and curry just didn't do it. Both were as if the star ingredients were slapped on top of the oyster and forced to mingle in my mouth. Nice, but I don't think either flavor wanted to be there. And the creole? Doesn't that mean some spice? Or am I mistaken? The rockefeller was more like it, with the cheese and the spinach interacting with the oyster. But like I said before, put enough cheese on something and it'll taste good.

My friends' sole dishes was like institution food. Limp greasy fillets of fish next to string beans and a boiled potato. Everything, save for the beans, was beige. Yawn. And the only way my friend could stomach the meal was with the help of lots of tartar sauce. That's not a good sign. The meat should be tasty enough to stand on its own. Without the help of sauce.

And the dessert? Oh the shame. Cold bread pudding and cold rice custard pudding. The bread pudding was pleasant, very sweet with bits of apple. Edible but eh, a let down. The rice custard pudding was terrifying. A slab of eggy custard on top of grainy rice? Sorry, I couldn't eat more than a few bites. Maybe if they warmed up both desserts, I could have feigned more interest but I must say this is the first time in YEARS that I haven't finished my dessert.

The only reason why I'm being so harsh with the food here is because of the prices. If I was paying Red Lobster prices, then I'd be more understanding. But when you're paying $25+ for a meal you barely care for, it hurts.

Like I said, I really wanted to like this place. Everything else was enjoyable. But man, the food, the most important part, not excusable. I want to give them the benefit of the doubt and assume that maybe I should have come for lunch? Or maybe I ordered the wrong thing? But my tummy hurts right now so I'm not a happy camper.

Last thoughts and tips? If you see a restaurant packed with tourists, it's probably not a good sign. And don't try splitting your bill half on plastic and half in cash. They only do one or the other.
author: Viv C.

description: My friend and I both had the seafood salad at the bar. Service was great. Sourdough bread was fresh and chewy.  Atmosphere was very noisy. Salad was...ehh.  Some lettuce with two slices of tomato, 1/4 of an egg, 2 olives and a handful of shrimp and 3" of dungeness crab for $20/salad.  I can say I've eaten at Tadich. No need to return.
author: Kim W.

description:
This place has that classic feel somewhat reminiscent of a scene right out of the Godfather movie, including the long wooden bar and box car booths. Our luck, we were staying at a hotel right down the street and taking the advice of my fellow Yelpers, we decided to stop by for dinner on 8/17. Since this establishment doesn't take any reservations, we were prepared to wait for a table. We arrived at 8:30 pm and after our customary gin and tonic at the bar, we were seated in less than 10 minutes. This would turn out to be a slow night so to our benefit, service was exceptional. 

Our waiter John was a newbie with only 20 years of service under his belt but from the looks of his lab coat, this old Irishman took his job very seriously: a true professional in his craft. We were immediately served some sourdough bread with warm butter on the side (not that cold stuff you get in lessor places) and decided on sharing the Crab Cake ($12.75) just to get the palate ready. I came specifically for the Seafood Cioppino ($26.25) and my girlfriend ordered the Broiled Salmon Filet ($25.75). We also shared a plate of Asparagus ($8.75). Since we were in the mood to celebrate, we had a bottle of Babcock 2007 Pinot Noir ($45.00).

The Crab Cake was great, the Salmon was exceptionally good but it was the Cioppino that took the gold medal - definitely worth the little embarrassment of having to wear a bib while you're eating it. 

For desert, I had the Bourbon Bread Pudding ($7.25) and she had the Lemon Tart ($8.25). Both were excellent. Two hours and ten pounds later, we were done. Total came to $146.00 not including tip which isn't cheap but definitely comparable to any decent joint in NYC. (AMEX not accepted.)

This was our most memorable meal of our trip to SF and would definitely recommend it to anyone.
author: Jorge S.

description: I love this place, defianlty popular amd crowded, i did a trip down to SF a while back wit bf, and we walking around downtown area looking for a place to dine, and some locals recommended it, people seem nice in sf, the food was awesome but i dont remeber what i ordered. Service was great, and we didnt wait too long for seats. I would come back though, and u get free bread lol.
author: Linh M.

description: This place is great.  We sat at the bar and had a great bartender.  Service was excellent and the drinks were awesome.  We ate at the bar too.  Shrimp bisque and calamari and sourdough bread.  Yummy!  Eat and drink here, you'll love it.
author: Yvonne S.

description:
Authentic. Charming. Enduring.

Tadich Grill, billed as the oldest restaurant in the city, has an iconic presence that is felt as soon as you step foot into this establishment.

I've been fortunate enough to come here a few times and all have been quite memorable. It starts from the moment you sit down, and you are transported to an old prestige that the Michael Mina's and Slanted Door's are absent of. You can tell the wooden walls and tables have been worn down by years of conversation, laughter, and discussion.

The long wooden bar is inviting and so are the staff. You can tell that the members who have been working here have been around for quite some time and it makes you feel like family. Outgoing, humorous, and always willing to engage in conversation.

The starter bread is delicious, and the dishes are phenomenal. They don't craft their food by sight, but rather on taste and simply knowing that it's good.  

The cioppino is wonderful, with a true taste of multiple blends of the sea. Fish, shrimp, mussels and all the extras are not spared and make this a true delight.

Tadich also has fantastic creamy casseroles and a fresh fish selection.

It's a landmark defined by its firm hold to not move with the times, but remain a constant of it's time.

A must visit.
author: Mike K.

description: Had not been back in ten years... dinner last night .  half hour wait at crowded friendly bar.  Food still is outstanding!!  Real SF historical style. Large menu with many choices .  I always stay with the seafood and has never disappointed me. If you have never tried it is a check off on the SF famous restaurants .
author: Michael G.

description:
We had a customer to take out for drinks after work and headed to the hotel bar across the street from Wells Fargo, but there were no seats at the bar or tables. So we headed out for a walk.....I am always "up" for trying a new spot to have a beer.

We wandered into the Tadish and found 3 seats at the bar around 5:30 pm. This is a classic spot, been there since the 1850s and I don't think much has changed. At part of the long circular bar you can eat and drink, and at our spots you could drink.

Excellent bartender, friendly, good drinks, and good conversation....but not too overbearing. Easy for the three of us to chat, and we all had a cup of soup. I had the Clam Chowder and it was EXCEPTIONAL -- so good I wanted another. 

We stayed for about an hour, and after several cocktails and the soups the check was under $100 (hard to believe I didn't have to pay).

We did ask if we could have dinner where we sat, and the answer was only for apps, and the wait was 20 minutes (they don't take reservations).......so we headed out to find another spot....
author: Matthew W.

description:
Back when i lived up north, Tadich was a favorite stop when I had visitors or just when I was in the city.
Tadich has amazing fish, probably the best petrale sole in the city, and I'm partial to their clam chowder.  Fantastic bread too.
The bar is amazing as well, great, well made classic drinks.  Combine all that with a really classic environment and you have a San Francisco classic.
The service is fairly friendly, which I actually think is a low point.  Tadich used to have gruff, to the point servers and I think I miss that.  Is that weird?
author: Nick M.

description:
Went at a slow time on a Friday, perfect to get in the door without having to wait. Service good, nothing out of line, solid waiter, but he couldn't remember bringing a straw for some tea. I had the best shrimp bisque I've tasted in years. The clam chowder was loaded and yummy from what our tablemate said. I had filet of sole and sorry to say but the Spanish, strangely enough in Spain, are the ones who know how to cook and serve it as they do any seafood put in their pans. 
This was semi-warm and totally bland. Wife and friends had a seafood dish but it looked quite ordinary, very boring, dry and unappetizing. All in all, this place is where it is because of its reputation. I'm big on places that please my pallette and don't bounce the CC. All the rest is window dressing. Next.
author: Carson W.

description: Some people don't like the old-school vibe.  I loved it.  Especially since the bartender knew exactly what a classic martini is without having to repeat myself or tell them what "Classic" means.  The sea food is outstanding...period.  If you don't like the sea food here, you don't like sea food.   I'll repeat what others have said about the Sand Dabs...amazing!
author: Kurt L.

description:
I won't go here again. I have given this place every opportunity to not impress me, but to just not piss me off. My last visit was during lunch. Actually, it was closer to 1.30. I went to the bar, ordered a bowl of clam chowder (cold day restaurant, right?) and a beer. They said they had a $15 minimum during lunch time... At the bar? I said, OK, give me two beers - you'd think that'd do it, right? Wrong. There is a $15 FOOD minimum. 

I have to say, the food is mediocre, the wait staff is bitchy, and the prices are unreasonable. If I want this type of environment without the downsides, you can find me at the Royal Exchange for 1/2 the price. There must be something good about the place, their sign says it is the oldest restaurant in the state (which is a rather dubious claim...). Feel free to tell me what that something is.
author: Scott S.

description:
Been going there for a a few years after seeing some good reviews on it. It's a great place to eat at the bar, where you can watch the interesting staff on the other side, or look over at the open kitchen and watch them cook (if you are sitting close enough). 

I've had the Cioppino, which was excellent. 
Grilled lamb, good too. 
The latest dish I tried was the Mediterranean bass, grilled, drizzled with some olive oil and capers.  Great tasting fish and very nicely cooked.  That is if you like eating the whole fish, head and all.  I do.
Seems like anything seafood or grilled will be good.

Anyways, this place is quite unique and very conviniently located close to the Financial and hotel areas.
author: Jim T.

description:
Do yourself a favor - please don't go here.

The waiter was a gruff asshole, acting like we were a terrible inconvenience.  The food was awful.  No one ate there under 60.  And the bill was ridiculous. 

Save yourself!
author: Braden T.

description:
My third and final trip to Tadich was last night.
The calamari appetizer and the sauted scallops might as well have been block erasers.  The sauce on the scallops was fantastic but even that could not cover the sins.  I almost sent the calamari back but we waited 40 minutes for it.  My wife's veal seemed to be missing the saddle horn and stirrups.  In the past I thought the food was alright and love the atmosphere but I am tired of just alright food and last night was not good.  We rode BART home and barely made it to the restroom before getting ill.  I give it two stars for the bar and the atmosphere but I will not go back to eat there.  They have ridden on their old San Francisco charm long enough.
author: B G.

description:
I've been here three times....went there for lunch twiceI worked in the Financial district and was underwhelmed.  Severly boring, bland food.  

Went back thinking dinner might be better....it wasn't.  

The thing that most people don't realize that if Tadich Grill closed down there'd by default be another place that's the Oldest Restaurant in SF....and I bet most people would like the food more.  Go to the Library if you're interested in SF history....go somewhere else if you want to eat well.
author: Nobody M.

description:
Of course Tadich gets 5 *'s!!!  This is old school SF at it's best.  I just came back from a business lunch from Tadich and though it was packed, but what's new, it was one of the best lunches ever. There is a bar you can sit and wait for a table or eat your meal at the bar the full menu is available and it is first come first serve.

I ordered the Dungenous Crab Louie salad with Italian dressing.  You have a choice of small or large. There was so much crab meat and fresh toppings.  My business partner had the stuffed portabella with crab, side of rice and spinach.  He described it as comfort food.

This is a great place for any type of occasion whether it be a business or personal, it is a real treat for you seafood lovers, food lovers really!
author: Frankie F.

description: Expensive menu but huge and reasonably priced appetizers.  I shot into Tadich while walking between job sites in the financial district to grab a burger in the rain.  Wow, very pricey and somewhat exotic mix of char broiled meats and seafood, a straight up burger - i think i was in over my head.  I opted to go with a bay shrimp cocktail and a bowl of Boston clam chowder.  They offer two styles of clam chowder and in fact this was a huge hot and yummy portion of New England style chowder that took the outside chill away.  The combination of the shrimp cocktail and chowder didn't set me back very much and i enjoyed both.  Be aware of sticker shock when looking at the larger menu.  It is the financial district.  Cool funky meat and seafood destination that originally opened in 1849.
author: Sean H.

description:
I used to walk by and glance in the windows of this place when I was a teenager making it up to the city to go clubbing. There was always something so captivating about this place. Tadich Grill evokes an old school New York dining establishment transplanted to San Francisco.  Yet the famous cioppino, the clam chowder to die for and some of the best seafood this city has to offer makes it unequivocally San Francisco.  Even if you are in the mood for something light, the crab or prawn louie is fresh and delicious. Then again, piled on with so much seafood, you are hardly having a salad. The sourdough bread is not the best I've had but it is very good and great for dipping - chowder, creamy casseroles and hearty stews. 

While this place is certainly more straightforward than trendy, sitting at one of the booths is like dining in a private dining car (isn't that a Johnny Cash song?) where you are surrounded by dark woods and brass accents and served by a waiter in an all white jacket. The restaurant does not take reservations so arrive a little earlier for lunch of dinner if you don't feel like waiting.
author: Annie Y.

description: I love this restaurant. It serves very frrsh seafood (both fish and shellfish), steaks and chops). You order most of the fish the way you want it prepared (saute, fried, broiled, grilled, etc). They have a diverse menu that also has some favorites like an excellent Crab or Seafood Louie. They also prepare an excellent clams in garlic wine sauce appetizer and a wonderful Boston clam chowder. I'm sure you will enjoy anything you order.
author: Patricia B.

description:
I've been holding off on this review. no doubt, the food is simply grand, the drinks and bar are marvelous, the service is impeccable, the whole ambiance is old-time SF -- an amazing thing. the building itself (and the surrounding bldgs also) are beautiful testaments to true architecture. stroke the marble and tell me you don't admire it.

so I haven't written this sooner for this reason: why is it that after the man and I come from here, we wind up in a frickin humongous godawful nasty drag-out fight ?! Tadich is damn cursed or something. 3 times in, 3 bitter hate-fests. I would lick that tartar off the plate but being a bit superstitious, I am avoiding another return. if I want to enjoy some crying good calamari, delicate scallops, orgasmic crab cakes, and wonderfully fresh fish, do I risk Round 4 of Fiasco in San Franpsycho ? or do I ditch the man and partake with someone else ? oh decisions. what we would risk for some screaming fine eats . . .
author: Prima D.

description: In a city with what seems like thousands of great places to eat, this is my favorite.  I have eaten at this classic San Francisco restaurant at least half a dozen times in the past 2 years, and it is my go to place for anyone who visits San Francisco and has not experienced it.  The food, ambience, and service are truly a throwback to the past, when dining out was an experience.  Everybody I bring to "The Tadich" finds it a fantastic experience.  It is not stuffy, or over the top in any way.  It is simply a classic that has earned its place in dining history, and continues to earn it every day.  Their Clam Chowder is positively addictive.  The Boudin sourdough bread is fantastic.  The Lobster Thermidor is scrumptious.  The Oysters Rockefeller are outstanding.  The waiters are as professional as waiters possibly can be.  I keep going back expecting something to be off, but it never is...so now I will keep going back knowing it will be just as I remember it.  Classic!
author: Mike A.

description:
I came here at 11:45am on a Tuesday and it was packed!  I was looking for a light lunch so I had the crab leg salad.  It was basically a bed of iceberg lettuce with some tomato and cucumber but the crab meat on top was really great.  A good amount of meaty, flavorful crab.  Comes in a little pricey at $23 but it is a San Francisco institution afterall.  My dad used to come here when he lived and worked in the city so it was fun to come here with him 30+ years later.  He had the smoked trout (which was really good) and the broth-style clam chowder (Manhattan but I think they called it something else).  If I come back, I'll be sure to try one of their fish dishes.

Would have given 4 stars if the service was better.  Our waiter may have been there since they opened the place and had zero personality.
author: Carrie L.

description: Get there early, first come first served, they take no reservations. My party arrived at about 11:30am for lunch. By then the tables were gone so they opted the counter seats. My seat was about to be given to the next guest but I made it just time. GOOD THING, because I would have been one cranky stomper. The waiters are quick to get to your order and friendly. I went with the half dozen oysters (pure perfection) and a dozen garlic butter manila clams (next time I'm going for the TWO dozen portion). 2 items I would definitely order again if I don't go for one of their amazing looking crab or shrimp louie. Mind you the seafood on the salads trick you into thinking there is actually lettuce underneath. Talk about generous portions. Left there 4 hrs ago and already plotting my next visit :)
author: Stephanie D.

description:
I will start off by saying, that this spot is really for a particular personality type - it kind of has an old school "old boys club" vibe, and if memory serves me right, that may be because they only started allowing women in the place in the 60's or 70's or something (my history may be totally wrong - this is just what I heard by word of mouth). 

At any rate - despite the reputation of this place being like that, I have always had more than pleasurable experiences there, and the food is pretty damn good - not GREAT, but pretty damn good. 

I enjoy both bar seating and dining at a table there - either way, the service is typically impeccable. They tend to specialize in either classic cuts of meat, or classic seafood dishes, and they portion well and the flavors are well rounded. 

My favorite part of each visit to Tadich is saddling up to the bar, and having Adam (one of the bartenders there) serve up classic cocktails. This spot can't be beat for their manhattans, martinis, etc. Perfectly balanced mixology = banging drinks! 

And honestly, the staff are interesting and all a bunch of characters. Non-invasive when you're eating, but attentive to your needs. 

For a nice time out wit good food, reasonable prices, atmosphere, and some of the best drinks in town - try out Tadich, it's a little slice of the old school!
author: Marco M.

description:
Wow, Wow, Wow is what i say. Having never been here before i was really impressed. Busy? Extremely. Crowded? Extremely. Noisy? You bet.
So it had most things i don't like in a restaurant but its old world charm, service second to none in classy outfits and food that left you walking out saying "that was jsut soooooooooo good" When in San Francisco this is a MUST visit restauranteven though they don't take bookings it is so worth the wait. It also has THE best clam chowder i've had anywhere.
author: Brian W.

description:
We came on Valentine's Day... yes I know big mistake!
However we were seated at the counter almost immediately, ordered cocktails and COCKTAILS! Shrimp and crab to be precise. Oh man delicious sweet seafood...stella on tap. We had some chowder too. Probably the best chowda I eva tasted in all my life.
The wait staff was outstanding, exactly what you would expect from a place like this. Not overbearing, classy, funny and knowledgeable. 
We will return for a sit down traditional dinner one day.
The only slight disappointment were the mixed drinks. I would stick with beer or wine- they go better with seafood anyways.
author: Edi B.

description: Food, service, friendliness, humor  definitely a 5 star.  However, disappointed that their system declined my gift card due to invalid expiration date of 6-22. Evidently the gift card people said that this is happens  occasionally with restaurants.  Love the place.
author: Tony N.

description:
Classic San Francisco.

The way we were in a simple, more refined time.

Strong, old timey cocktails.  A dine-in semi-circular counter.  Professional waiters which look like they might have once had ties to the SF mob.

Amazing, simple fish dishes prepared in a variety of ways, always with potatoes and fresh vegetables.  Crusty sourdough bread and butter -- not olive oil -- butter.  

And that my friends is the heart of the Tadich Grill.  Old world charm and style.  Un-health conscious and refreshingly plain.
author: Rachel G.

description: Went to Tadich last weekend while staying with friends overnite in the Union Square hotel scene for the Christmas season...I had the Chilean sea bass and it was to die for good...you simply cannot get enough of the french bread they serve...we bought a loaf for the road !...had a chance to sample four other served entrees at out table and they were all nicely prepared and seasoned beautifully...great atmosphere...friendly service...moderate to pricey...would definitley return
author: Richard G.

description:
I guess I get the fascination with this place. Old time San Francisco place with crusty-yet-genial European service...I just thought the food was repulsive.

I ordered the sand dab plate, which I was told is their speciality. What the hell are sand dabs anyway? I got fried (which is fine) fish that were ok tasting, not knock-your-socks-off or anything, big tasteless fries and a glob of weird creamed spinach...ech. This would have been fine had I been paying $7.99 at a local diner (it had that local downtrodden diner kind of taste - food from 30 years ago), but I was paying much, much more...

I knew I should have gotten the cioppino. I was going to get the cioppino. Then I didn't. Then the guy next to me got the cioppino and I was sad. It actually looked much better than what I was eating.

Dessert was definitely not "home made". Or at least it looked and tasted pre-fab. I think I saw a similar thing a week later at a cheapo chain. 

Fun experience sitting at the bar, until I realized there was a row of hungry diners waiting to grab my seat when I left. A bit disconcerting at the least.

So yeah, I get the allure of this place...I just resent paying so much for mediocre food.
author: G O.

description: I was really excited to come here since it is supposed to be the oldest restaurant in San Francisco, but I was disappointed with the food. The interior of the place is really neat but a little loud. If you order a soda you will have to pay for refills so make sure you don't drink too much. My sister and I split the ravioli and the filet mignon. For the price I have definitely had much better steak. My parents had a seafood dish which they said was good but nothing special. Overall, the food is alright but overpriced for what you're getting.
author: Hayley J.

description:
Overall, the experience was less than favorable.

Upon arriving at Tadich Grill Restaurant with my boyfriend, we were greeted by a gentleman who took our name down for a table.  The bar service was actually the best part of the experience since our bartender was kind enough to actually provide excellent customer service, as should be expected for a higher end establishment. 

When we got seated at our table, we waited up to 15 minutes before we could even get a server to greet us and acknowledge that we were there.  There was a ceramic bowl of lemons that looked like they had been sitting there since the lunch crowd, and it was now 7:30 in the evening.  

Trying to remain in good spirits, when the server did finally arrive at our table, I asked a few things about the menu, specifically about the sauteed crab leg dish.  I wanted to find out if it was already shelled for the dish.  The server responded by saying yes, it is and also added that this way, they can turn the table over faster.  Sit, eat, go.  What????  Repulsive.  A dinner that costs an average of about $30 per plate should be handled better than "sit, eat, go".  

So I went with the sauteed crab legs and my boyfriend had the lobster tail.  The food came to our table with the poorest presentation I had ever seen.  The vegetables were overdone, the rice was bland, and the crab meat was tough probably because they cooked and shelled it with the early morning prep.  My boyfriend's very expensive lobster ($50) was tough and overcooked, accompanied by a mediocre stuffed tomato and the same disgusting vegetables.

I would not recommend this place beyond the bar scene.
author: Angela C.

description: Really old-school style restaurant with excellent seafood. Best Cioppino I ever had.
author: Brian S.

description:
Next door, but light years away from neighbor Aqua. Don't get me wrong, I liked Aqua (see my review) but Tadich is different.. different like a well worn leather jacket, that looks and feels better every time you wear it. Step into Tadich and step  back a few years... maybe a 100 or more. The center bar is the hub and center of the action. Tables surround the bar in small clusters and narrow aisles. Grab a pint at the bar you feel the action and energy of the place, but once seated Tadich becomes a warm and cozy dining spot. There are no reservations, so grab that drink and expect to wait a little while... it's worth it though.

The food is simple, fresh and nicely prepared. Warm sourdough bread is a great way to start any meal. Follow that with some large, generously topped Oysters Rockefeller and you'll be doing the happy dance before your entree hits the table. I've had the grilled halibut  steak twice and I have to say I will no doubt order it again the next time I'm here. Thick, flaky, tender on the inside with golden-brown grill marks as the only embellishment. Sides are simple - like Mom would do it, and my Mom is a good cook. My gf ordered the Petrale Sole Filet which I liked, but not nearly as much as the halibut steak. It was pan-fried beautifully, but had a creamy sauce I didn't love. Dessert isn't fancy, but we split a sour cream cheesecake and were quite happy. 

Wheelchair access: Getting in is easy, there's even an automatic door. Space is a bit tight seeing as it was built way before the ADA. Some of the tables clearly wouldn't be good to sit at if you were in a chair - either you'd be in the way or too cramped to dine comfortably. The staff however knows what they're doing and will seat you at a good table. Sometimes this means a shorter wait as they'll jump you up the list if one of the good tables opens up...  other times they might have you wait a bit longer for a good table. Trust them, they want you to enjoy your dinner. I'm not sure about the bathroom situation, might be tough getting to though even if it is accessible.
author: Ken O.

description:
Anytime you have a restaurant that makes a superlative claim as this one does, claiming to be the oldest in California, you're caught in a bit of a Catch-22.

Is it the oldest restaurant because it's so good that people have continued to go there for year after year, or is it the oldest restaurant because people think it must be good because it's the oldest and they go there, even if it might not be that great anymore?

Tadich Grill is definitely the former.

Reasonably priced high-quality seafood with all sorts of interesting flavor combinations. Good bread too; and great service. We had a hilarious waiter. The bar is also a nice place to grab a drink or two beforehand.
author: Mark A.

description:
Another National treasure.

As a third generation native San Franciscan who has not lived in SF for many years, a recent trip back demonstrated that the culinary heart of the city is this little place. Cafeteria style counter made me wonder how many business men fed their  tired souls on fresh-made Seafood Coppino and SF sourdough. I felt like I was part of those black and white photos from the 40's and fifties- and I think I now know how really good food from the pre-health craze days was. 

The waiter also stepped out of the past. I kept thinking they ask what I thought of Willie Mays or Joe Dimaggio's game last night.

The single most important stop you can make to taste San Francisco.
author: H R.

description:
We weren't in SF 45 minutes and already we were seated at the bar at this place - a quick cable car down California from Nob Hill and kaboom.

I absolutely loved it. Old. Wooden. Genuine. Bryllcreemed guys in white aprons behind the bar, three martini lunchers poring over their bond yields at the bar.

I had never heard of it - The Honey knew about it and took us here. When we got back my buddy asked if did we get to Tadich's? Dude - how did you know?

I love Old School. Too many places overload the  Barcelona chairs in the lounges and decorate like they hit the jackpot at the stainless steel closeout sales. There is nothing like a massive fine oval bar and wood panelng aplenty.

It was Dungeness Crab Season  - that's what we had and it was quite possibly the best crab I have ever tasted. Add on  a few glasses of pinot grigio and you have a remarkably pleasant afternoon.
author: Paul M.

description: Yep, you will want to eat here. Our waiter made suggestions all the way around and all of us loved the food. I had the seafood curry special. So delicious!
author: Kristi M.

description:
New years day we went in for lunch. Had the chicken parmegion (sp?) and seafood cannaloni. Breading on chicken was oily and boderline gross. Seafood was smothered in cheese sauce and good. Brocolli. Was crunchy which I like. 

Atmosphere awesome. We sat at the bar where each seat has bread water lemon and butter put out already.  Service was great.
author: Jack F.

description:
The perfect place to connect further with folks I came to see this weekend. We sat; we spoke; we enjoyed the old school digs with white coat waiters and bartenders. It was all very as Tadich's has always been. Good bar service and very good calamari. Good late afternoon banter with city lore thrown in. 

I hear dinner is so-so these days, so we went elsewhere. But for an oasis and asylum from our North Beach trekking, this was just right for cocktail hour.
author: Michael S.

description: Amazing atmosphere. Feels old world. Skip the table and sit at the bar, then get ready for true service from the staff. It's incredible. Oh yes, the FOOD! Order off the lengthy specials menu. We stuck with seafood (one broiled and one that was in a delicious sauce almost like a casserole). It was truly a culinary experience!
author: Katie M.

description: Arrogant bartender? Really? Can you say oxymoron? Can you spell oxymoron? The food in SF is all good. Do you know how hard I'll try to find good food? Not very. In the end we ate minimal and tipped zero. If you go... go for the outstanding staff!
author: Howard S.

description: Best classic fish place in the City.
author: Chris H.

description:
Yum...call me sentimental, but this place is pure San Francisco to me. Dad brought the family here when I was just a fat little thing (don't say it!)

This was so cool because my Dad knew the owner, so we had access through the "back door" where the, ahem, "special guests" (cough) entered back in the day. One of my favorite parts of this place is the old school train car booths with the curtain pulled for "business purposes" (sorry about all the quotes, by the way). It was awesome; total San Francisco feel and vibe. I had my first Seven and Seven there (thanks for letting me use the fake ID, Daddy) and learned to love salmon, too. 

As much as I like keeping some of my favorite places a secret, you should definitely go, regardless of whether you like seafood. The atmosphere and shrimp cocktail alone are enough to change your mind. If you're a drinker, ask for a Sidecar (if they still make them). Definitely one of my best memories in the city by the Bay.
author: Hilary L.

description: Never going back!  I've been there several times but the last time my son took me for Mother's Day . As with the 1st time I went... the waiters are sooo rude!  Plus, the food was awful!  If you go there 6 times 3 of those you'll get served terrible food so couple that with the awful waiters and I'm done with the "joint"!  I recommend it at work all the time but from now on I'll tell people to avoid it!
author: Louisa V.

description: Awesome old school place. The best things to order for lunch consist of their homemade clam chowder, filet of sole, and a gin and tonic...
author: Jim B.

description:
You don't even know it, but your dad loves this place.

Mine likes to say repeatedly, "this is a REAL San Francisco restaurant" and "this is a REAL piece of fish".  And he is right.

Like Emily G., bring your dad here for 20 years. You won't regret it.
author: Hayley W.

description:
It was the right meal at the right time. We were craving for something hearty and wholesome, and Tadich hit the spot. We ordered the Cioppino, lamb chops, and steak. It was perfect. 

The Cioppino is a crowd favorite, and I can see why. There's a bite of seafood in every scoop. The garlic bread that comes with it was excellent as well...about $25 for the dish. 

The lamb chop...$33, and steak...$28, were seared nicely, charred and blackened. Although it wasn't really seasoned much, the freshness of the meat made up for all of the flavor.

Service was friendly, the bartender was extremely entertaining and funny. Great place.
author: Jun W.

description:
Everything about this place is old school except for the prices.

Tadich Grill has been around since the Gold Rush, and I fear they haven't updated their menu since then.  Expect ice berg lettuce, heavy cream sauces, and outdated options.  

The long lunch counter, waiters in white coats, squeaky-clean tiles and starched linens set a very nostalgic theme.  Unfortunately, the charm stops there.

Large salads start at $20, and well, I expect better vegetables than iceberg on a twenty dollar salad.  I had the Crab and Shrimp a la Newburg.  The sauce was so heavy and rich that I could barely eat half.  It was a very 1960's recipe which sat like a rock in my stomach for hours.  On a positive note, there were huge chunks of real crab in there and they didn't skimp on the shrimp.  They use quality ingredients, albeit very old fashioned.

Lunch for two without cocktails or appetizers, just two average-priced entrees, ran $50.  Frankly, if I'm going to splurge on lunch in the FiDi, I feel that Belden Place and other spots have much more to offer.
author: Amy A.

description:
Was taken here recently by my husband for dinner, he eats here a lot, but it was my first visit there to eat, I have been there once before just for drinks.
We went there around 8pm on a Friday night, we didnt make a reservation so had a 30 min wait, if you are waiting the bar area can get very crowded.
When our table was ready someone called our name and pointed out a table to us, I thought this was a bit strange as normally you are shown to your table and welcomed by your server, this may have been as the place was so busy.
Our server came over and asked if we wanted drinks, he never mentioned the menu at all, i was expecting him to recommend the specials or at least one thing on the menu, he also never introduced himself.
After about 10 mins the server came back and was ready to take our order, we ordered the crab cakes as appetizers and I ordered the cod, at which point I was told they had no cod, along with two other fish they didnt have. He did recommend a few alternatives, so i went for the monkfish. My husband then ordered steak (cant remember which one) and was told they didnt have that either, so he had to chose again. Surely it is the norm to tell people when you seat them what isnt available!!
The rest of our experience was good, the food was good, nothing spectacular though, especially not for the price. Also we ordered the rice pudding for dessert, it isnt rice pudding like I know, it was nasty :(
The complimentary bread was good, and they were quick to give us more when we had eaten it, and also they were pretty good at keeping our water topped up - although the glasses were the smallest water glasses i have ever seen.
I personally wanted to give this place 3.5 stars, but my husband goes there all the time and loves it, so i gave it an extra half star
author: sarah s.

description:
This is easily my favorite restaurant in San Francisco ... not only does it remind me of the old school restaurants back home but I've tried about everything on their menu (um, not in one sitting) and its all lovely.  I highly recommend the calamari, the halibut and their new york cut minute steak.  so good.

Last night we shared a crab crake appetizer, which was spectacular.  I had the lamb dish with vegetables, he had the salmon.  Fantastic!  My only complaints are: 1) this place does not take reservations, and 2) they close too early - we met up at 9:00pm and an hour later, they were practically rushing us out the door.  Oh well, as they are high on my list, I'll let go of the few irritations.

Finally, the service is as its supposed to be - don't expect any pampering and/or royal treatment ... old school ... the service isn't rude, its just highly efficient.  You want to be loved up, go get a massage cause this isn't the place.  

old school.
author: Sarah K.

description: Thumbs up on this place. Great service with no wait early on a Friday night. Food was well prepared with a reasonable price point for San Francisco.
author: Bill S.

description: Lunch or dinner, the Tadich Grill never disappoints. Food is great (if you don't mind richer food...) and the cocky service reminds me of Europe, i.e. home.
author: Davy C.

description:
Stumbled into this place about 9:00 PM after arriving in SF on a Friday.  Amazing experience!  Best calamari I have ever had.  Also, fantastic clam chowder.

 Wait staff was very good, striking up conversation and event giving my group and I suggestions on where else we should go.

Meals were generous portions.  Old school look and ambiance.  I will make this a "must do" every time I am in San Francisco from here on out!  Decent micro brews with 21st amendment on draft.  Cannot recommend this place enough
author: Nick B.

description: Absolutely great food and service. Costs a small fortune for what you get but the clam chowder is amazing!
author: Rachel S.

description: Ordered the Tadich appetizer platter - good but not great. Also ordered the scallops which were the most amazing scallops we had ever had The red snapper was good, but also nothing amazing. Everything was very nice- the one downside was the waiter. He would come by our table to talk to us and then leave without a word. We would be sitting there dumbfounded looking at each other wondering when we could actually get to our question. This happened 3 times. I guess next time we would just scream out our question forcefully so he would have to actually "wait" on us, otherwise he is gone.
author: Paul P.

description:
After almost 160 years, I finally got by to check out the Tadich for a casual "business lunch." That really just means that we blew off an hour and a half at the company's expense, right. 

This is as Old San Francisco as you can find, in a rare class with the Tonga Room, The Buena Vista, The House of Prime Rib and Tommy's Joynt. These places have endured for generations, and won't be going anywhere anytime soon. 

First off, don't expect a good deal on lunch. The Tadich is not cheap, and the menu doesn't so much as consider having food between a bun. The menu hearkens back to an era was lunch was meant to be savored, an important meal, and if you wanted fast, you went to a deli. 

The menu is geared towards fish, mostly the traditional kind our parents would love -halibut, salmon, sole, grouper. I had a New Zealand Grouper that was stuffed with crap, shrimp and lobster. My god, it was like heavenly chickens laid golden eggs in my mouth. 

The service is mostly older fellows in crisp white jackets that address you promptly and properly. The food comes quick and you can get a good hot lunch in 45 minutes at the Tadich. 

Not for the brazenly nouveau trendy in San Francisco, but more for those of us who savor a moment frozen perfectly in time and a glimpse at "how things were" in the days of our fathers and grandfathers.
author: Brandon B.

description: Another stop on a day of dishing around San Francisco. This place is what the Berghoff used to be and should still be. White-coated bartenders provide actual SERVICE, not indifference. Wonderful stop for happy hour, and delicious calamari. And icy fabulous martinis.
author: Erika G.

description:
A great place for lunch with wonderful service and dinner-like options.  I had the Halibut, which I'd recommend.  As others have said, the price is a bit high (about $25-$30 per lunch with a drink) but well worth it.

I went here for dinner recently.  To wait in line for SOOOOooo long to eat seafood with so many restaurants that serve similar dishes, I don't get it.  If you can get in, do it, if not, skip the wait and go elsewhere.  The food is good, but I don't think it's good enough for the mix of good and bad service.  Three of us got our food, 5 minutes later the 4th plate came... service matters, if they haven't learned that since 1849....
author: Jared F.

description:
I have a crush on the Tadich Grill, the "original cold day restaurant."  What does that really mean?  I don't know.  But it makes me even more swoony at its old school charm.  The restaurant is bustling during peak hours but still intimate with dim lighting and gorgeous, dark wood partitions that divide the room into cozy compartments.  It's got an air of old timey romance that no top-notch restaurant decorator can conjure with distressed furniture and faux antiques.  Do try to arrive before noon for lunch and 5:30pm for dinner, especially if you're a pair and don't want to sit at the two-tops in the main passage between the kitchen and the dining room that feel a bit exposed.  

Seafood and grilled meats are the specialty here, with the cioppino--a mountain of crab, fish, prawns, scallops, and tiny bay shrimp in a robust tomato broth--being Tadich's thing.  Eat it proudly wearing the paper Tadich Grill bibs they bring.  The steaks are fabulous and come with huge "longbranch" potatoes, which are like fries on steroids.  Other highlights include the mixed fried seafood, clam chowder, and the crab bisque.  I have yet to try the other Tadich treat of hangtown fry, which is supposed to be a gold rush legend.  Definitely get a cocktail to ease into your lovely dinner.  The drinks are stiff and they come with a green and gold cable car swizzle stick.  Just, please, don't order an appletini or flirtini or whatever--make it classic, like a martini (with gin) or Manhattan.

The service here, I think, is superb in a sexy steely, manly way.  Just the sight of the waiters in their white jackets and long aprons gliding along is a pleasure.  (On my many visits here, I've seen a woman server once)  The staff here aren't the chummy modern-day waitstaff who squat next to the table whilst taking your order or write "thank you!" with a heart on your check.  But they do make sure that your glass is never less than half full, that you have all the condiments you could possibly want, that you're happy and content.  They're polite, if slightly gruff, and know how to make you feel important with their "sirs" and "ma'ams"; but if they warm up to you, then they will joke with you and have a good time.  

Seriously, if the Tadich were a man, I will totally elope with him.
author: maiko h.

description: Very old-San Francisco.  I've been going here for years and it's my favorite Cold Day restaurant.  Their raviolis are phenomenal, as well as their steak.  The seafood is also very good, or so my fish-eating friends tell me.  The restaurant is very male-dominated, however.
author: Claire N.

description:
A farily pricey retaurant in the heart of the financial district.  I went to meet a few people for lunch.  I was instructed to try to be sure and get there by 11:30 as they run out of tables early, which is true.  This is because the place is pretty popular as well as it having an old kind of lay out with a large bar area in the middle of the restaurant.  But we were able to get a table and the service was very prompt.  You got a little sense that this is in part due to them wanting to get you in and out but the waiter was very polite.  The food was great. I had the swordfish that came with these large french fries and green beans.  Thye portions were large also.  The waiter came by to refill our drinks (ice tea) about four times or so which I love.  

Not a place I would go regularly, but it is a nice place to head if you want to get away from the monotony of all the chain restaurants downtown.
author: Tom K.

description:
I have been to Tadich many times over the years. I loved the classic "old school" feel of the place, and the fish, while simply prepared, was always fresh and the portions generous. It had been at least 10 years since I had visited Tadich, and looking for a classic San Francisco experience to entertain some out of towners, we decided Tadich would be the perfect place. What a mistake. Where to begin? The waiters and bartenders who still wore their freshly starched and pressed classic white jackets and who once welcomed you as if you had just arrived at the best party in town, have grown bitter and downright rude. As we waited for our table, I was shocked and offended to hear racist jokes being told to a customer by one of the bartenders. Next, he yucked it up loudly with a couple who he pressured to tip him $20, on two cocktails, for which they received a ring of the bar bell, signifying their stupidity.
Once we finally were sat, the evening got progressively worse. As so many other yelpers have also complained about, our waiter was downright rude. It was to the point that we thought perhaps we were on Candid Camera and in a moment Alan Funt, Jr., would come out and make us all blush on National television. No such luck. 

It is not even worth going into telling you the sordid details of how poor the service was. Suffice it to say, our waiter was horrible in virtually all regards. 

As many have said, the Cioppino was excellent. That's why Tadich got my one star.

Based on my recent experience, I can certainly see why management may be taking stock of its staff as some have written about.  The Tadich has a reputation to uphold as a "classic old-school" San Francisco restaurant." There was nothing "classic old-school" about the attitude, rudeness, and ineptitude of the staff we encountered.  Let's hope that with some new blood, Tadich can regain its reputation as a beloved San Francisco institution worthy of patronizing.  If they do, I'll be back for the Cioppino.
author: T.L. M.

description: Best Cioppino ever!!! Not too tomatoy, not too seafoody, just perfect. You can taste the spices and the bread is perfect. I wish you were open Sunday to help my terrible experience at Scomas. Thier Cioppino will never live up to your. Im in love.
author: Kris K.

description: Thrilled to see some posts here regarding the untimely, unprofessional and unceremonious dismissal of Adam and Matt, the two geniuses who tended bar and helped run the front of the house at the Tadich.  My wife and I have been coming here a couple times a month for a solid decade and frankly, we always relished a long wait because it meant time spent at the counter being served by those two, enjoying their company, and watching them do their routine.  The new management was clearly looking for a reason to dump them and further its initiative to continue staffing the place with soulless country-club douche bags.  Good call - you've lost us for life.
author: Archie L.

description:
This is one of the restaurants that has been on my "to try" list for many years and I finally tried it a couple of years ago.  I took some friends there tonight and which reminded me to yelp it!   One word, Ciopinno!  Love the ciopinno here.  It's the only thing i have ordered here so I can only speak to that.  The flavors are really wonderful and delicious.  The ciopinno comes with crab meat, nice big prawns, bay shrimp,scallops, fish and mussels.  The only thing that I would complain about and thus the 4 stars instead of 5 stars is that the prawns and scallops were a tad over done...but the flavors, oh the flavors of that stew!

Background info for ciopinno:  It was developed in the late 1800s by Italian fishermen who settled in the North Beach section of San Francisco.  Originally it was made on the boats while out at sea and later became a staple as Italian restaurants proliferated in San Francisco. The name comes from ciuppin, a word in the Ligurian dialect of the port city of Genoa,meaning "to chop" or "chopped" which described the process of making the stew by chopping up various leftovers of the days catch.  (Wikipedia)

My friend ordered the clam chowder which smelled wonderful!  Next time I am getting that too!
author: Gordon S.

description: I saw this place talked about on the Travel Channel a while back and I finally got a chance to go. If you like GOOD SEAFOOD and a lot of it this is the place to go. There may be a bit of a wait but it is worth it. I am going back soon. I can only give it 4 stars because it was my first time.
author: Michael M.

description: I've been here a couple of times and love the food and the service.  I came here yesterday to try the clam chowder and it blew me away.  Easily the best chowder I've ever tasted.  These guys do seafood well and the service is hard to beat.
author: Lester B.

description:
I took the husband here for his birthday on a Wednesday night. We were seated quickly despite hearing it would be a 30 minute wait. We had a couple of yummy cocktails while we waited and the bartenders were great: Just the right amount of wiseguy attitude and helpful friendliness. 

Our server was an old timer who really knew his stuff. He helped us pick out a bottle of wine and I was impressed that he recommended the cheaper of two we liked. 

Unfortunately, the food was just meh. 

For appetizers I got the sliced tomato salad. I thought the salad was fine. The vinaigrette had a bit too much oil and not enough zest so I ended up using sliced lemons instead. Husband got a half dozen oysters. He said that of the six oysters, two were great, two were just okay and two were mushy. I'm not an oyster eater myself, but I am pretty sure that mushy is a bad thing. 

I ordered the fillet minion. It was cooked medium rare and had a nice crust on the outside but the meat itself had very little flavor and a slightly mealy texture. I used steak sauce to perk it up. Sadness. The side of mixed veggies came unpleasantly cold even though my steak was nice and hot. I vetoed the cold veg. 

Husband ordered the cioppino. He was disappointed that they pre-shelled the crab legs but tucked in enthusiastically as he is a seafood freak. He felt that overall, the sauce was lacking that robust kick that you expect from cioppino.  Also he thought it was too bad that a place that prides itself on its seafood should fill out the cioppino with mostly bay shrimp. 

We had champagne and the bourbon bread pudding for dessert. It was just fine. 

I really wanted to love this place, given the history and the wonderful staff, but I just can't justify shelling out that much cashola for a dinner that is so far from excellent.
author: Miss Information X.

description:
Don't give it a second thought...It's crab season and Tadich does it right. After living in the bay area my entire life (parents raised in the city) it took 67 years (dad's b-day) to get there. It's been over a week and he still can't stop talking about what a great lunch/time he had at Tadich. 

It's a special treat to find a traditional San Francisco establishment that serves fresh, great tasting food.
author: Anna R.

description: HUGE portions...(huge prices on entree) Fantastic Calamari appetizer, the BEST tarter sauce and chili sauce EVER..such a huge bowl of delicious clam chowder and the real deal sourdough and sweat cream butter!  MMMM!  OK oysters on the half shell...My son had the ravioli w/meat sauce and he wouldn't eat them.  They were delicious!  We were full all day after the meal! We sat at the counter and it was fun!  I felt like I was back in the old days in SF!  I used to come here almost 35 years ago as a small child with my Mom.  It brings back fond memories....it's a must go to when in the city!
author: Adorah L.

description: Classic place, oldest restaurant in California. Good oysters, good seafood, decent prices and always an enjoyable time.
author: Steven T.

description:
This place will take you back 50 years in time. Def feel like an old San Francisco restaurant. The seafood - shines in this place and is really tasty!
Their cioppino is divine  and is probably some of the best I have ever had. Everything in the stew was fresh and delicious - and the broth which you dip with these garlicky pieces of bread = DIVINE! My wifes crab cakes were really meaty, fresh and tasty! My friend ordered a sea bass which was awesome as well. The only lowpoint were the sand dabs - not really impressed - but everything else was so good! Big Portions too - which is a BIG BONUS :)  Love that its next to my favorite restaurant Perbacco as well :)
author: Christian S.

description:
The Tadich is soooo not set up for vegetarians! I asked about the veggie plate (with an old school place its admirable they have one!) and it was essentially the veggies from the sides menu, and pretty much standard wedding fare for the veg-head; creamed spinach, roasted tomato, etc. So, I made my own veg plate of sauteed spinach, asparagus and french fries. It was all well cooked, but not terribly exciting.

My lunchmates enjoyed their meatier fare quite a bit and the server was friendly and fun. I'm not sure I'll be back since its not really my cuisine of choice, but if I have some old schoolers in town, I will consider it.
author: Lise L.

description:
There is only one restaurant in the world that is allowed to get away with surly service, and that is a Chinese place in New York that probably doesn't exist anymore. Old school East Coasters - you know which one I mean. 

I sat at the bar for lunch at about 11:45 on a Thursday morning, and was quite pleased to have beat the rush. Shortly after I sat down I could feel my back prickling with the weight of the eyes of all of the people waiting. 

I had several different wait staff serve me, but only one older gentleman seemed to fit the ambience and price of the place. The rest ranged from bored/annoyed to stressed/sad. I was expecting more because I had heard so much about the place. 

The seafood bouillabaise special I ordered was possibly not worth the $23.75 - I am not sure, since it isn't something I normally order  -  but the dish was quite tasty and satisfying. 

I understand and appreciate the retro mood of Tadich Grill. I would happily return as long as I was not paying the bill. I like the clubby feel of Tadich Grill. If you are in San Jose and looking for that sort of "feel," try sitting at the counter at Original Joe's. The guys at OJ know how to treat their customers.
author: lois g.

description:
We have been here many times and now for a review. Arrived last Friday evening early, around 5:00 pm. My wife thought it was too early for dinner, so we went in for drinks. We ordered cocktails and were being entertained by the crazy bartender/maitre de and having a great time. We decided to eat and were seated. The waiters here are very friendly and old school. We ordered Boston clam and Manhattan chowders, both were full of clams. I thought the Boston was better as the manhattan clams were toughened by the tomato based stock.
   My wife had the grilled seaood trio of calamari steak, scallops and prawns. It was very good. I had my favorite fish, sand dabs which were as always, very good. They were served with steak fries and fresh sauteed vegetables. We watched the lady next to us demolish a crab cocktail that was huge. I am getting that next time, if we are here during crab season. They don't take reservations, but get here a little early , have a drink or two and enjoy....
author: David L.

description:
This place was excellent.  I had the Seafood Cioppino which was quite tasty.  Full of seafood, and not just cocktail shrimp.  There were two scallops that were roughly the size of my head, tons of flaky fish, crab meat and prawns.  The broth was uber tasty and went well soaked in the garlic bread served on the side.
