Gas rating (1-5): 3.5
The bread was very garlicky and gave me gas.  I'm not saying the bread wasn't tasty, just that it really filled me up with garlicky air.  I burped garlic for the rest of the day.  My conference room really enjoyed that.
author: Soo C.

description: Came here on a Friday night with my family. (5 total)  Outstanding sourdough at the table.  Cocktails were good .  They were out of Ahi Tuna, so I had the crab cakes, which were very good.  Others had Petrale Sole, Red Snapper w/crab, halibut.  The star of the meal was the Chilean Sea Bass.  Place is pricey and crowded, but it is fun and the food is very tasty.
author: Michael M.

description:
I've known of Tadich Grill for almost 30 years, 15 years when I lived in San Francisco and the last 14 in St. Louis, but I never ate there. Don't exactly know why, I even used to work downtown SF, but just never got around to it.  I always knew it was a good place for seafood, but I didn't go there ... until today (7/2/2010) and I was fully and totally blown away.

Maybe it was the day (70 degrees F, sunny and not foggy all week).  Maybe it was nostalgia, as I was at the end of an 8 day conference here and leaving tomorrow.  Maybe it was the pent up anxiousness about really getting to eat at a landmark that I had always wanted to eat at.  Whatever it was, it worked today.

First of all, it was lunch. It opens at 11a and I remember it always had a line out the door by noon, so I went at 10:30a and was first in line (ok, so I might have been a little overzealous, but it's who I am :-)).  Let's just say I was determined to eat here today.

I got a corner table near the front, with pressed white table cloths and napkins, and no waiter under 50 years old ... good way to start a classic SF dining experience.

To my way of thinking, at a fresh seafood place, the order in which you consume the food is also important, as some of the oils and sauces might alter the taste of the food being consumed.  So I had a half dozen fresh oysters, crab and avocado salad, and a bowl of clam chowder, in that order.

The fresh oysters were Pacific oysters from Washington State (Crassotrea gigas (scientific name) - Pacifics originally came from Japan in the 1940s, part of the war reparations, I imagine).  These were plump and so very fresh.  I ate the first three without any sauces just to get the true flavor.  And then I mixed the freshly ground horseradish with the cocktail sauce and added that to the other three.  All amazingly good (I have to watch out because i may run out of superlatives soon).

Then I ordered the dungeness crab (my favorite kind of crab) and avocado salad.  Sometimes when you order such a salad at other places, you get a big pile of iceberg lettuce with a little bit of crab and a couple of pieces of either too hard underripe or too dark and too soft overripe avocado.  No this place.  It was one of the most delicious salads I have ever had.  It was served on a large white oval place with a thin layer of extremely fresh and sweet romaine lettuce. Next was a layer of the best and freshest dungeness crab I have ever tasted, both claw and meat from the body under the shell, sweet and briny and (did I say) fresh. The next layer was a half an avocado, cut thinly and covering the crab, and the avocado was PERFECTLY ripe.  Not hard, not too soft, sweet and creamy with several shades of green.  Beautiful.  And then there were also a couple of Greek olives, 1/4 hard boiled egg, big sweet wide carrot ribbons, thick cucumber slices, and the obligatory parsley, with the Louie dressing on the side (very important).  So I ate the top layer of vegetables first, fresh with only dipping a little of them in the Louie dressing and then I ate the crab, bite at a time, savoring each one, no Louie dressing here.  Then I ate some of the romaine, spotted with the Louie dressing, which was also exceptional.  Not a thousand island like some give you, but their own house blend, thinner and easy to eat. 

Then I had a bowl (I ordered a cup, but it came in a bowl, I'm not complaining, I assure you) of their New England, white clam chowder, which was THE BEST clam chowder I have ever had, and I've had a lot of clam chowders. (My now next best favorite is the Legal Seafood clam chowder btw.)  And finished that with some slices of their amazing crusty sourdough bread and butter.

So I just sat there with every mouthful shaking my head in wonderment and saying "wow" to myself. And the service was impeccable and my server, the maitre d', and all the staff were very, very helpful.

At the end, I had tears in my eyes in tribute to this meal (I also cry at Lassie reruns btw).  It is now my new best meal ever and it was definitely worth waiting 30 years for, definitely!  But it won't be another 30 before I return, I assure you. 

My visit to Tadich Grill was simply put a peak experience in my life.
author: Mark P.

description:
This restaurant can't be adequately rated by Yelp.  Try a different league such as Michelin.
-Seafood Curry Casorole- crab on the bottom, crab in the middle, I thought this dish was supposed to have rice, I can't find it between all these jumbo prawns and crab meat.
-Ciopino- savory
-Grilled seabass- largest whole fish entree I have ever seen on a single plate in this country.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Tadich is "The Original Cold Day Restaurant" just like the sign says.  

No B.S. - this is the place for Man or Woman alike to go for a satisfying bowl of clam chowder (they have both styles) , Louis salad (crab or shrimp), or ANY classic fresh fish dish you can think of.  As with any popular place in FiDi, before 12 or after 1, unless you like to wait in line to get an actual table.  Even the counter has a wait when it's really busy, but, assuming you have the time, it's probably worth it.

Quick-Dash-Lunch: You can order a great meal at the counter, even just a glass of white and a steaming bowl of chowder.  The sourdough is so good and they just keeeep bringing it !!  Once, I ordered the side-Louis as well and had to take it to go because they have such generous portions.  Salad was packed nicely & was enough to split with coworker!

Ladies:  Do you ever feel like "Everything that needs to be done right You Have to do Yourself"???  Then I highly recommend Tadich-therapy :

After you are done pulling everyone **else's** fat out of the fire for one day, why not stop in and recharge at Tadich? God has given us a place where the all-male-wait-staff will treat you with just the perfect amount of appreciation, admiration, respect, caring - then they leave you alone to enjoy your meal, checking in at just the right intervals.  There's a whole cast of interesting characters to see: kindly older gentleman waiters, edgy-looking bartender with finesse and charm, and the smiley-faced busboys filing in and out. Plus there's a world of activity going on inside the restaurant.  I bring a book and just relax there.

Yes, it's a man's restaurant, but it's a great place to be a lady.
author: Herb C.

description:
I went on vacation here 4 years ago and ate here for the first time.

I heard all about how great the cioppino was and I had to see for myself
if it would live up to its reputation.

Usually nearly all seafood places will overcook a  seafood stew.

Tadich grill does not however because they cook the seafood separately and then add it to the broth which gives them more control over the cooking time of each type of seafood in the cioppino.

It was just about perfectly cooked and the scallops were done correctly and not overdone which to me is a good test of a seafood place.

That is all I tried but it was excellent.

I have heard that the sand dabs were also great but didn't get a chance to try them.

Maybe next time.

Enjoy, it is an excellent place.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Last saturday night, we stopped by Tadich for a quick bite. If you arrive after 9pm, you can usually get a table relatively quickly. We were seated promptly. Our waiter was Jannis.

We were provided the usual menus, and received burned frenchbread from the busboy. The waiter asked us if we wanted to order a drink. We told him no thank you, he seemed disappointed. We asked for water with no ice. When the busboy brought us our water, with ice, we noticed the menu had a new disclaimer.

The restaurant is not responsible for seafood tainted with mercury, or other containinants. Well I hope Tadich checks their fish purveyors! Maybe I shouldn't eat seafood from Tadich's? Mmmmm...I am paying for cancer?

We signaled the waiter we were ready to order. The waiter asked us if we cared for appetizers or salads. We said no thank you. He looked very disappointed again. We ordered petrale sole and the mixed grille.  

We were ignored with burned bread and no water until the food came. When the food arrived, the portions were small and there were 3 french fries on each plate. We said nothing, ate our food and signaled the waiter for our check. When the waiter came to the table, he asked us if we cared for dessert or coffee. We said no thank you. He seemed again disappointed.

We came to Tadich for a quick good meal. We left there hungry, and annoyed at the waiter who kept trying to sell us items we did not want. We realize the waiters make over $100,000.00 or more at Tadich, but they should not be trying to up their check averages as to get higher tips.

I am a native San Franciscan. I have gone to Tadich sporadically all my life. The quality has slipped substantially. The restaurant is not focused on quality or value, but on check averages and volume.

The waiters are pompous and need a lesson in humility. They need to  understand that the customer is the focus, not their wallet. When someone orders water with no ice, do not bring a glass full of ice because you feel jilted because the customer did not order a $10.00 cocktail.

I like professional waiters who are usually caring, and real professionals. I tip them accordingly. However I felt Jannis my waiter was not deserving of a tip. I left a 15% tip anyway.

I will not be going back to Tadich. This is my goodbye. This restaurant has lost its' lustre, value, and charm. The waiters have ruined the place with their greed. The restaurant is focused on making big money, not on their customers.
author: john g.

description:
This place is quintessential Old San Francisco. My dad has been taking me here for lunch for over 20 years. It is very very good seafood. I've never had the meats here. 

The seats are solid wood and many of them are booths. You get table linens and very polite adorning waiters without the extreme prices. This place isn't cheap, but it's also not Boulevard either. 

I usually get the calamari, but my dad has tried everything on the seafood part of the menu. Although he will eat anything, he does have relatively refined taste. He thinks this is the best place to get well cooked seafood. It's never too buttery or oily. But note, some dishes can be heavy, fish or not. 

If you're looking for a very traditional old school SF restaurant this is it.
author: Emily G.

description: Hands down the best meal on the trip...Hangtown Fry with a Martini for lunch.  Very cool vibe with friendly staff.
author: Andy W.

description: Yes, it is been around for a long time, the old fashion decor is very interesting, but the dishes were just OK. I expected something better given the whole fuss, the wait and so on.
author: Luca R.

description:
I finally ate at Tadich Grill!! And it was everything I expected...and more!! Dubbed, "California's oldest restaurant," the restaurant had a bustling down to earth but chic vibe, reminiscent of sea food restaurants in Seattle.  My old manager Rick took me out here and told me that he had been coming here for 30 years! 

Anyways, we got there at 11:30am, thinking we would beat the lunch rush, but there was a 25 minute wait for tables already! Luckily there was room on the bar and we were able to sit down right away. 

I'm usually not too into seafood, but I got the crab cakes, and they were mouth watering goodness!  It came with fresh brussel sprouts and seafood fried rice, which were both very good complements to the juicy crab cakes.  Rick got ciopinno which looked very good, filled with all types of fish, shrimp, clams, and other seafood.  

The service was really fast, as the food came within 5 minutes of ordering.  The staff were nice, but definitely had that vibe about them which screamed, "I work at a top notch popular restaurant, and I'm better than you." Minus 1 star for that. 

All in all, it was a great experience, sitting back and enjoying some good food and good conversation.  What more can you ask for?

Tip: Come early! They don't take reservations, but they do take out.
author: James C.

description:
Tadich Grill is one of my new favorite restaurants. I went here on a Friday evening around 7:30p and the wait wasn't horrendous for 4 people - only 30 min. While waiting, friends and I had some drinks near the bar where a friendly older couple engaged us in conversation (they were surprised that we were the youngest people in the restaurant in our early-mid twenties).

Two of my friends were visiting from France and SWORE that the table bread was authentic French style bread and gave it two thumbs up. We started with the crab cakes which were absolutely heavenly - pure crab meat, baked, not fried.

My other friend told me that he'd been to Tadich a dozen times and has consistently only ordered the Seafood Cioppino. A great choice. Crunchy garlic bread in this tomato-stew style seafood dish. It has shrimps, clams, fish, scallops, etc. Only word of advice is to take the bibs the waiter gives you and put it on yourself - I didn't know and sat there rather foolishly as the waiter tied it around my neck. Though I'm not sure the bib is needed since I didn't a splash on me!

I will definitely come here again and struggle to order something else :)
author: Wendy T.

description: The food is always fabulous here.  We had an early dinner, so seating was not a problem.  My favorite is the Chilean sea bass and I always get a side salad with crab and shrimp.  I've also had their cioppino.  Their servers have a weird sense of humor, but are fairly attentive.  I love their semi-private rooms - makes you go back in time.  By the way, they're the oldest restaurant in SF.
author: Jay S.

description: Based on all the other reviews, we decided to come here for a late lunch to avoid the crowds.  I loved the service at the bar, which was quick and no hassle.  We ordered the crab cakes and grilled tuna.  When the tuna came out I was a little disappointed as it was cooked to a medium.  I usually prefer my tuna just seared.  My boyfriend mentioned that the menu stated raw fish was not served unless requested.  I guess I must have missed that, or I'm not sure if that even had anything to do with it but a note to make sure you ask for rare just in case.  Either way, the tuna was still excellent.  The blackening was perfect and the tuna was moist.  I don't think I have ever had tuna cooked medium and liked it.  The crab cakes were also good.  They were light and flaky and not overwhelmed by breading.  A great place to stop for a late lunch.
author: Christina K.

description:
My guts are gurgling!  "Old" school cookery doesn' t agree with me anymore - too much fat from either cheese or cream is the way my parents ate fish.  My mistake.

The waiters are great - they are almost up there with the French.
author: Berty B.

description:
Mmmm...chowda'

I love a cup of good classic chowder. I love Tadiche. Everytime I go, I feel like I just got invited to an important business lunch with old men with white mustaches and bow ties. Food is always consistently good. Fresh seafood, great deep-friend prawns, and fresh sourdough bread.  The place is always packed and the service is always good. I love it.
author: Fallon F.

description: 20 years ago this place was great with an attitude. Now it's just attitude.
author: JT K.

description:
Tadich is a tradition in my family. We go there for most special occasions and anytime the family can get together in the city. It's the oldest restaurant in the city and has the most amazing ambiance. When you step in the door it feels like you just time warped to 1935. The deep wood paneling, long bar, old fashioned light fixtures make it feel cozy and romantic on a cold SF day. I adore the wait staff and their white coats and upscale style of service. I was just there this past Saturday and was able to chit chat with our waiter and practice my French.

Who's kidding who though, it's all about the food. Their crab cakes are still the best I have ever tasted in my entire life. The crab and shrimp louie is perfection and the seafood cannolini is truly decadent. This place is great for family get togethers and also an intimate date with someone special on a cold afternoon. It does get crazy busy certain times however. I recommend getting their right at 11:30am for lunch or between 2 and 4pm to be seated quickly and hopefully score one of the private booths or coveted window seats.
author: Lynsey C.

description:
One of the best seafood places in the city hands down. We ordered the crab legs and smoked trout to start. First off, I never want to deal with actually getting meat out of a  crab again. They bring you the meat already removed and it's awesome. The smoked trout is to die for. So good with the bread, cream cheese and onions. 
For the main course, soooo many options. We went with the sole and halibut. Both were fantastic. Just be careful with the bones.They were not overly seasoned and other than the fresh tartar sauce, you didn't really need anything. The quality of the fish speaks for itself. They don't care as much about how it's presented, just that it is amazingly good!!!
Note - they don't take amex.
author: shadi m.

description:
Ambiance=place was cool and old school!
Waiter=awful, personality of mop
Crab cakes in Marinara=Meh
Dungeness crab salad=Delicious!
Cioppino=RIDICULOUSLY GOOD!

Overall, the crab salad and Cioppino were so worth it, everything else we could have done without.
author: melissa b.

description:
This venerable San Francisco seafood restaurant has been serving classic dishes for 150 years, and they have generations of regulars now. Regulars, Financial District drones out for a "splurge," and savvy tourists make the bulk of the crowd. No reservations are accepted, and you'll need a large party on most days to get a curtained booth during the lunch rush.

Lunch is probably pricier than most other places nearby, but the quality is there and the portions are fair. This is a place where no one will look askance if you're ordering a drink (or four) with your lunch because they were serving drinks with lunch back when that was expected.
author: Timothy O.

description:
Truly a historic landmark in the city.  From the original 100+ year tile floor to the best dressed staff in town.  

If you like seafood and don't mind waiting a bit, this is a great place.  I've found that while they lock the doors at closing time 9:30, as long as your inside (like having a cocktail at the bar) you'll be seated.

Upon seated my suggestion is to start with the crab cocktail and finish it with the Cioppino (easily the best in the city).
author: Michael W.

description:
You'll have to skip breakfast if 11 AM is too early for lunch, but it will guarantee you a seat.  They don't take reservations.

You'll be feasting on great, fresh seafood here amongst the old timers of the SF business crowd.  I love the pan fried petrale sole, sand dabs, louie salad and New England clam chowder.  I also hear that they make fantastic cioppino.

I really love this place!
author: Christine T.

description: Clam chowder, sand dabs and a glass of chard for lunch Friday.  It certainly was a Good Friday.  The wait for a table is half the fun.  Keep a sharp ear out for interesting conversations going on at the counter.
author: Gary J.

description:
I love the Tadich.  I've now been there 3 times and I've been very happy every time.  I'm definitely a creature of habit and when I find something I like I do it the same every time.

I visited yesterday for an early lunch with my good friend.  I knew already I was getting the Petrale Sole, my friend ordered the Clam Chowder and Caesar salad.  I was thrilled, because I could try her food too.

My Sole was the same as before.  Just perfect.  Its a fat bomb, but so, so good.  The sides are just so/so but I really wasn't there for the sides.  The Clam chowder was great, a little too thick, but has great flavor and lots of clams and potatoes.  The caesar was excellent, not too eggy with yummy (mild) anchovies.

I've only ever sit at the bar because the waiters crack me up.  So very serious, but with a twinkle in their eye.  

Ask to take a look at their book while you wait the 5 minutes for your food.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Not going to overkill my words here for an SF institutional restaurant.

Old male professional waiters
Good traditional preparation of fish and chops
Nice bar
A truly represenative old SF restaurant -- great for tourist and business lunch
author: Laurence H.

description:
The menu tells has the history of the Tadich Grill on the front.  Alarm bells started ringing when I discovered it was started by Croatians and continues to be heavily Croatian.  

If you travel to Croatia you will be treated to a wealth of sour-faced servers and mediocre but expensive food.  You may even get fleeced by a cop.  No surprise to find that Tadich Grill offers a small taste of a trip to Croatia, (minus the potential to get fleeced by a cop).

If you're into old-school you will probably like this place.  Decor seems frozen somewhere between 1920 and 1940.  Choose a stool at the prodigious bar counter or a secluded booth.  The staff wear classic white coats.  Unfortunately what comes from the kitchen is also straight out of the 1940's.  You will not find any of the creative dishes that make San Francisco one of my favorite places to eat.  

Love the old-school atmosphere.  The food is expensive and nothing to write home about.  Pop in to take a peek and then move on.
author: Eli B.

description: I came to this place for lunch with 4 co-workers. Around 12:30, we have to wait for about 15 min. I ordered Cioppino & it was the best I have had in a very long time. We have to wait a little bit and the servers never smile :(, other wise I would have given 5 Stars.
author: Sean S.

description: Great food and outstanding service.   Bartender kicks ass.   Made to order cioppino was excellent as was the sea bass.
author: L C.

description:
"The Original Cold Day Restaurant" is what is advertized on the front window of the oldest restaurant in San Francisco (1849).  As a buddy of mine put it, "It's kind of like the Peter Luger's of Seafood". Old school with large portions, gruff waiters that don't want to hear your BS, and a tried and true system.   Get in, eat large, and then get out.
  
Don't expect any kind of fancy fusion or green movement menu, but do expect excellent renditions of cioppino, seafood sauté, clam chowder, herring, smoked trout, oysters, etc...

If offered, don't shy away from eating at the bar.
author: Brett M.

description:
3 stars because of the overall ambiance and experience. I guess if I were 45+ I would enjoy it more but as soon as we stepped inside, it was hard not to notice that everyone was over 45 years old, balding and Caucasian (to be totally PC ha). Crazy how there was zero diversity! 

We were craving clam chowder and one of us had heard that this place served one of the best. I guess "best" is always subjective right?

Anyway, the chowder itself was good - no complaints. They give you a hunk of sourdough bread too which is perfect for dunking.

The pain points were that there is a $11.50/person minimum charge - LAME! So our server wasn't all too thrilled when the majority of us only wanted a cup of chowder ($6.95). Annoyed/exasperation was written all over his (wrinkly) face but in the end, he let us slide - so thank you for that! Oh, and it's $8.95 for a bowl.

So okay, it's one of SF's oldest restaurants so just take this with a grain of salt because it's coming from a 20-something year old. I'd choose Embarcadero's chowder from one of those stalls anyday :)
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
I came to eat at Tadich grill with my parents because their hotel was nearby.  We totally loved it!  The staff is friendly and efficient and the food came out fast ( a nice treat after waiting 45 minutes for a table on a Saturday night).

I got the hangtown fry--I had to, it is one of California's first attempts at cuisine!  Breaded and fried oysters are thrown in with bacon in a really big omelet.  It was a little, um, heavy (to say the least) but worth it for the experience.

My mom had the sand dabs (boned) which were lightly breaded and tasted heavenly with the chunky homemade tartar sauce.  My dad and boyfriend got the sea bass which was a generous piece of fish grilled to perfection.

Dessert included a moist and delicious chocolate cake and berries with butternut creme--blackberries and strawberries floating in a sort of eggnoggy (not in flavor, but in consistency) concoction that was absolutely amazing.

I would love to go back again.  This place is my new alternate to Spenger's!
author: Sarah L.

description: Had my hopes up to high.  Food was old school-bland and borring. Service was super quick. Felt like their goal was to get you in and out. Not very personable. Very pricey for what you got.  The clams in the chowdr were rubbery-over cooked. Whats up with the tartar sauce? They put potato flakes in it for thickness. It was thick but not tasty.  Calamari steak was also rubbery.  Vegis borring. And the french fries were petrified. If your into paying for the experience-history behind the restaurant then live it up!
author: Nicole G.

description:
I have been going to Tadich Grill for 43 years, have always loved the no nonsense service where regulars were treated well and newbies got to experience a tad of old school SF attitude. One of the few places in SF where being a native SFer still meant something. 
Fire old staff, lose old customers. I guess those are the breaks.
author: G. John E.

description: My sister and I came here for lunch and had the seafood risotto.  This restaurant does have the ambiance of old San Francisco. The inside has a large bar and beautiful dark woodwork. The host who seated us was very cheerful while the waiter was rather grumpy. Though the risotto was pretty good, I really need the service to be good as well. The waiter was impatient while taking our order and grabbed my sisters credit card off the table abruptly when it was time to pay. Would I go here again? Maybe if I'm in the neighborhood but I probably won't go out of my way.
author: Cindy K.

description:
Clam Chouder...Great.  Seafood Salad....Great. grilled Mediterean Seabass...Great. Calamari.  Great, Service: wonderful.  This was an absolutely terrific dining experience...I went to this restaurant over 20 years ago and service was so rude that I promised I would never go back...I had an out of town visitor and he had heard of Tadich Grill and wanted to try it...

So we did and it was wonderful...I will be going back.
author: Vrede B.

description: This has for years been THE place to get the best bang for your buck for me.  I mean the food was great and second to none for flavor and tenderness and succulent and juiciness of the 1/2 grilled chicken with a large baked potato with butter and sour cream and toasted buttered garlic bread and (salad which I agree was not their deal breaker) but the other food:  the grilled chicken that I watched them place on the fire as it was being grilled or the succulent steak which was enjoyed by my dinner guest.  Topped off with a cup of coffee or glass of Iced tea and dessert.  It doesn't get  much better than this and the price has increased due to the economy and it's still affordable.  Nothing but good reviews  (KUDOS to Tadich Grill)!!
author: Edna C.

description:
This place is great.

The food is fantastic; old fashioned seafood, but prepared with real class.  I enjoyed one of the best seafood meals I've ever had when I ate here.

The service was good, and quite accommodating.  

One of the memorable parts of the meal was sopping up the sauce in which my seafood came.   The bread alone makes this place worth the trip.

One minor gripe: the enclosed booths can be cramped with a large party.

But the food and atmosphere cannot be beat.
author: Doc D.

description: Best Cioppino in the city. This place is a destination for a visitor and a go-to for a local. The Crab Louis salad was great, too!
author: Cheyenne C.

description: Great place to have lunch.  You need to get there before 12 or you won't get a table.  Its always packed.  Great sea bass.  If you roll solo, you can most likely grab a seat at the bar which is fun too.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Walking through the doors into Tadich surprises you at the restaurant's depth.  Enough has been said by other Yelpers on the interior. However, the efficient nature of the bartenders can be interpreted as attitude. It's definitely an interesting experience.

The menu is large and so are the portions. I wouldn't go to Tadich for anything but seafood because that seems to be their specialty. My meal, Petrale Sole, was fresh and done well. Honestly, I have had better Sole elsewhere, but the Tadich Sole was definitely worthwhile. Try Tadich at least once!
author: Charles B.

description: I had the Seafood Cioppino which was the best I've ever had.  Hearty sized scallops, loads of flaky fish, crab meat, many small shrimp and prawns.  The broth that it came in was mouthwatering yummy, especially with the two thick slices of garlic bread that it came with. Service was decent, soda was in the smallest "tall" glass ever and there's no free re-fills.
author: Mayana P.

description: the waiting is LONG. but the food were great!!!!! i will def come back AGAIN!
author: Annie C.

description:
I Love this place! This is San Francisco Old School, at it's finest. 

Tables can be a wait, but the counter where we sat is first come and we had a great time chatting with the other patrons next to us. 

Our service was excellent, the waiters were a joy-they kept us laughing, the dishes were timed perfectly never arriving before the last was finished, but still hot and fresh each time. 
The menu is large and they have daily specials and the sourdough is sour.
Save room for dessert- yum rice pudding!
author: Margaret M.

description: For some reason I am just not excited about review Tadich.  It was honestly forgettable.  I am always skeptical of places with HUGE menus because how can chefs prepare that many different meals at once and make each one really good...   Maybe I'm just paranoid about ordering something I don't like and paying $30 for it. I ordered a tuna salad with some sort of dried fish on top of it (see i can't even remember!) It was good and the lettuce was fresh. Everyone comes here for the sand dabs and that was initially what I was going to order.  My dad ordered it instead and I was glad I got the salad.  The sand dabs were extremely delicate and literally tasteless.  I like my fish to have a little more flavor and sustenance.  It's a restaurant that is famous for its bar and the fact that it's pretty old but I got the feeling that the wait staff there were arrogant, grumpy and just done with being nice to paying customers.  All I can think about is when Anthony Bourdain went here and the bar tender was a complete ass. Not quite the impression you want to have of a good restaurant.
author: Hayley H.

description:
Classic San Francisco restaurant at its finest. Fresh seafood is what they serve here (over 125 menu items to choose from!).

 My friend took me here recently for my birthday and we had a great experience from the impeccable service to the stiff cocktails. 

We started with the crab legs appetizer and wow was this delicious! They shell the crab legs for you- so its just sweet crab meat. The star of the meal was the Chilean Seabass with the most perfectly grilled crust and moist delicious fish inside. Every bite was amazing. I highly recommend ordering this! My friends ordered a crab and prawn casserole baked dish- which I have never really seen on a menu but they really enjoyed it. 

I can't wait to go back!!  They don't take reservations so show up before six and you shouldn't have to wait!
author: Erica B.

description:
The ambiance of this place , being the oldest restaurant in San Francisco, is very cozy. You can either sit on the bar and have a meal or wait for a booth or table. 

I had dinner here during my last visit to the bay area. The ciopino was awesome! My friend had the filet and it was also good. The menu looked really well put together. I could not try anything else but I shall do so the next time I am out there. 

As a matter of fact. There is an exact replica of this restaurant in downtown Las Vegas. It is called The Triple George Grill. A little weird if you ask me.
author: EJay D.

description: This is one of those restaurants that you wait to eat all day until you're served a decicious one of a kind dish from Tadich Grill. I try to come as often as I can when I'm in the city.  The Chapino is so out of this world... I found this restaurant featured on an episode on Food Network and I just HAD to come here!!!! You really can't go wrong with this place. It's a bit pricey but oh so worth it.
author: Mish A.

description:
First place and last place we eat at when visiting San Francisco.  On the last trip, we would have eaten there everyday if they were open on Sundays.  Other restaurants paled in comparison, and we said, "We should have gone to Tadich."  One of my favorite restaurants on the planet.   We always take a menu home from the times we eat there.   

Great atmosphere, great service, great people watching.  Go when they open at lunch if you want a table, because the restaurant gets crowded fast.   

A true San Francisco experience with the cable cars right outside.  I would fly up for a day just to eat here.  And I'm serious.
author: Robert M.

description:
I've always walked pass this restaurant, and never had the patience to wait in the long line during my lunch hour until today. All the hype about the crab louie salad is true!  It amazes me how a simple salad made of a bed of romaine, 2 slices of tomatoes, 1 red radish, 2 olives, a shaving of carrot, a quarter of a boiled egg, a mountain of fresh chunky crab meat with frothy Louie dressing can taste so good & oh so fresh. If you're not in a salad mood, the Calamari steak with tarter sauce and garlic butter is a great choice.  It is breaded and pan fried and comes with a side of steak fries & veggies of the day.  Today's was creamed Swiss chard.  

This historic venue has an old world feel,  with wood paneled walls and they even have a buzzard installed right by your table so that you can request for a waiter to bring you an extra bloody Mary, extra sauce or what have you.  I never pressed it for myself so I can say that it still works.

The service is excellent, and the only thing that sucks is that it's extremely loud and they don't take reservations.  If you want table seating, be sure to come with a party of 3 or more.  Otherwise, you'll be waiting for a seat at the bar counter.  

Thank you to Tadich as my search for the best Crab Louie is over!
author: Nancy G.

description:
Tadich is what it is.  "The original cold day restaurant" I believe is the slogan it has on it's window, as well as the claim to fame of  being San Francisco's oldest restaurant.  So, why would you go to Tadich expecting anything besides good ol' seafood?  The waiters can be a bit gruff, but they make a pretty mean drink.  The seafood is pretty amazing and I love their clam chowder.  

Perhaps it is most fun when I go with my dad who loves San Francisco classics, but just keep in mind that this isn't a place with ANY glitz.  I'm pretty sure the mahogany bar is the same one that has been there for decades.  A solid, yummy classic.
author: Lauren H.

description: BE CAREFUL! My friend and I had not seen each other in several months. We went to dinner here tonight, a Monday night. The food was fine, the cocktail was good. But, then the waiter asked us to leave. He said his manager was angry that there were people waiting and he needed the table. The manager denied it, said he didn't even need two tops anyway and offered us a drink but now we were out of the table and disrupted. I have not ever been asked to leave an establishment. I did not expect that the first time would be at what I thought was such an established, professional establishment. They wouldn't have treated Willie Brown that way. Shame on Tadich Grill.
author: David L.

description: Old San Francisco and still one of the best.  Old time wait staff , great drinks and bread, white table cloths and great seafood.  When I was there July 5 I had the cioppino and it was wonderful  I had to make the choice of Patrale or Sand Dabs.  No Sand Dabs that day so I went with the cioppino.  Wife and son had the scallops, prawns and crab and daughter had the prawns.  Everything was great and the waiter was very engaging.  He had been there 30+ years.  Great variety on the menu!
author: Bob D.

description:
Tadich Grill is pricey, but it lived up to expectations. I almost never give five starts, so this one gets a solid four. We will be back, and I would recommend it to others.

They have a huge menu, and the food is very good. I don't know what "authentic" tastes like, but Tadich seems very old-school, with quality ingredients and good, simple dishes. Plus, it's a very charming place-- the ambiance is sort of like the appeal of a good, classic diner, gone upscale.

They don't take reservations, and it can be tough to get a table during the dinner rush. We were polite to the hostess and she was polite in return. Other patrons were abrupt with her, indignant about the wait for a table, and she was abrupt right back. (We also got seated more quickly than they did; I can't say whether our manners helped.) The service was good, but not cloying, from beginning to end.
author: Gregory J.

description:
The walk-on-water reviews must have gone to this restaurant's head.  We were six of seven friends  who arrived at Tadich Grill just as it opened at 11:30 a.m. on a Saturday.  We were third in a line of about 10 people -- the restaurant wasn't crowded at all.  

The host was rude and arrogant.  He simply informed us that he would not seat us until the entire party had arrived.  We asked about having a drink first while waiting for our friend who had phoned that he was about 10 minutes away.  The host responded that he could seat us at a table for six, but when our seventh friend arrived, he would have to sit at the bar by himself.  We were so astounded at this attitude that we decided to leave.  I should note that there was no sign in the window or at the host's podium that said "All members of a party must be present in order to be seated."  Nor did the host seem at all inclined to give any explanation -- let alone express any regret -- "Gee, I'm sorry, but I am not able to seat any party until  the entire party is here,"

I would not recommend this restaurant to anyone who expects professional courtesy or a welcoming attitude toward visitors to San Francisco.    Who cares what the food tastes like if the attending staff make you crawl to get a seat?  In fact, I would go so far as to say that this host's attitude ruined an otherwise pleasant trip to northern California.

So we walked about four blocks to the Yank Sing Chinese Restaurant in the old Post Office Building for dim sum.  Oddly enough, our "late" seventh friend beat us there -- as one in a party of seven, he was able to hold a table in a large, bustling restaurant for the rest of us!  So we know not every restaurant in SF has the same arrogant attitude as Tadich Grill.  And the food and service at Yank Sing were escellent!

Shame on Tadich Grill!
author: E.L. Y.

description:
I have been here several times and always enjoy the food.  It is a super busy place and not open on Sunday.  The portions are of decent size and the fish always tastes fresh.

This is the oldest seafood restaurant in San Francisco and has stayed open in my opinion for some good reasons.  One they have consistent quality and two they offer great service with realistic prices.  The Tadich has not tried to get overly upscale or faddish but relied on tried and true business practices.  Feed the masses with not the few.  I have never seen it slow when I have been here.  You will see many restaurant in the city come and go but I bet this will remain for many years to come.
Stay away from Pier 39 and come here for some decent seafood without the hype.
author: Scott A.

description:
I love love love Tadich's.  This is one of the oldest restaurants in San Francisco, and I love it!  The sourdough is still made the original way- the chef (back in the day) used to sleep with the starter in a bucket next to his bed, so nobody would steal it!   The special is the Pacific Snapper- formerly Petra Sole- it has been on the menu for YEARS!!!  They're known for their fish, so order some.

There are no tables for 1, so you had better get used to the counter- which I LOVE!!! It really hasn't changed much over the years- and did you know... the current chef is only the 6th head chef in the last 75 years of the restaurants history?!  It's amazing.  Anyway, Cioppino is amazing, all the fish are excellent, and the sourdough is to die for.  I always want to slip a little in my handbag every time I go, but that is just gross... so I don't do it!  

They used to be all cash up until the late 80's, and now they take minimal credit cards.   Best to go with good old cash, or Visa/MC just in case.

THis is a piece of SF history, so enjoy every last detail about the joint- including the fact that they don't take reservations.

I love it here, and hope you will too!!!
author: Carrie U.

description: I loved everything about this place! The food, service and enviorment is amazing!! I had the Ahi tuna which was most excellent!
author: Danielle D.

description: i had the seared ahi tuna and it was nice and tender. the fish was fresh, along with the other ingredients.  it was a business lunch, so i did not try the ciopinno, but it looked amazing.
author: Scott L.

description: Had a great lunch with my two grown children yesterday. Good food and good service once seated. The host was unpleasant and combative. Too bad. Went back today with my four family members. Host was so unpleasant we left and ate elsewhere. I have made a point of eating at Tadich's for pleasure and business a couple of times per year for 20+ years. Sadly, no more. The attitude of the host has turned me off.
author: David B.

description: I've been coming here since I moved to the city in 2006. It's comfortable, easy and the food is consistent.  I am in love with their casseroles that are baked with a thick white cream sauce with prawns. Delicious. Although nothing else on the menu has been original or out-of-the-box delicious, its a solid establishment where one can enjoy cooked seafood and beers.
author: Chieko H.

description:
This place was a delightful surprise after we were scared away from all the high roller steak houses. You know, the Mortons, the House of PR, etc. This $$$$ nonsense was simply not in our budget. Ultimately, we wanted a big fat steak to fulfill the craving of European visitors who swore that meat in America is always a thousand times better than it is in Europe. 

All that said, this place is known for seafood, and the seafood is great - one of us had the crab cakes and also the dinner salad - and the crab in the salad was so good I can almost say it was not from a can. But, do not discount that they do most everything well. The service is top notch - entertaining, expeditious, and attentive. Warm fresh bread, which is, no joke, almost worth going there for. 
Delicious home-made soups and a New York strip steak that will surely satisfy even the frequenters and followers of Morton$-esque steak joints.

We did not have to wait long and we opened a bottle of wine at the bar to start - it was an all around success. I also love the old school vibe - and even more so the 'factoid that this is the oldest restaurant west of the Mississippi.
author: Julie H.

description: Was there for lunch on a weekday.  Do not be fooled.  The food is mediocre, but people pay the premium prices, wait an hour for a table, and tolerate the absolutely rudest staff in town because it's "an institution."  There's better seafood at better prices with better service all over town.  Ugh...pretty weak, and overpriced by about half.  Plus the place is super loud (staff creates most of the noise) and everything is uncomfortably tightly jammed in.  Hope you like hearing the waiters yelling at each other!  This place is for tourists -- everyone else can easily find something better.
author: Roger S.

description: The food is outstanding. The portions are generous too. I'd recommend lunch over dinner, as the wait time can be excessive. This is a Croatian owned restaurant, without any Croatian menu items. No Croatian beer either. Not a big deal, but it would be nice if the restaurant kept some of its heritage. Overall a very positive experience. Waiters can be testy and  flustered at times. That's the only star deduction.
author: William C.

description:
Everyone and their great-grandfather has reviewed this place so I'll be quick:

Came with a few business contacts and scooted in twenty minutes before closing. The place still had a line (!) and we were still seated efficiently (!!). 

The crab legs came pre-cracked and were amazing. Order with a glass of white wine.

Tip: Get a booth if you can; makes an already classy place feel like a private club.
author: Elisabeth S.

description: Just go...food is very good but expect to pay a very good price.  I would return and order the cioppino (again).
author: Tom W.

description: My friend arrived early and saw the waiting list , went ahead to put our names down as we did before,  She got yelled at by a grey haired waiter that no one touches the pad and if she does it again, he threatened her that she would never eat at Tadich again.  What the 'eff?  I know they are packed during lunch but that is definitely not a way to treat your customers.  No matter the food, ambiance etc, when the wait staff start behaving like thugs, it is time to take our business elsewhere.  We went next door and surprised that the food is better, cleaner, and the service is cordial.  Never again, Tadich.  You will be serving your last meal if your staff's attitude continues.  I plan to tell 3 people everyday about the treatment my friend received today.  Word of mouth will win.  Sorry to burst your bubble if that is where you are planning to eat there.
author: Ynez S.

description:
Service is great and the food has been good and consistent.

*Atmosphere - Both times I have been it has been busy.  You have to wait for the both, but sitting at the bar will expedite the wait.  Noisy with an old feel with the green padded benches and the waiters in white coats
*Service - Very prompt wait staff in white coats  and they are always going by so you can get their attention - Great
*Menu - Seafood to Steak to Salad
*Meal - I had oysters - good, the rib eye medium rare - good, chocolate cake - average
*I would go back

Great service + I haven't had a bad meal yet (been twice) = 4 Stars

Read the menu about the restaurant that has been around since the gold rush and had a feud with another restaurant about the name.  This place is a good place to go for seafood to steak, but nothing sets it apart except for it's history and atmosphere.  I have been twice and the food has been good and consistent.  I would go again if I had too, but there are too many restaurants out there.
author: Po L.

description: Beautiful old school restaurant that reminds me a lot a history east coast place. To start we had the clam chowder which was fantastic, some of the best i've had. The wife had the lobster thermador which was ok although just a tad overcooked. I went with the the cioppino. The stew had generous portions of  scallops, shrimp, and mussels to name a few. The cioppino was excellent if a tomato based broth is your thing. On a side note the place is so busy that is can be a little difficult to really relax and enjoy your food...but that's just me. Good food, expensive but large portions....worth a try.
author: David P.

description: I love the old fashion style of this place. And top of their great environment, the food was great too. I was very pleased with the service as well. We got there late and there were many people in front of us. Despite of the line to get seated, they managed to seat us at the bar in less than 10min. And trust me, seating at the bar is ten times better than the getting a table at this place.
author: parviz d.

description:
This is old style San Francisco with waiters that have made it a career to be a waiter, they know what they are doing, they are pro's.

The waiter service was super fast, attentive, we felt they kept an eye on us to check if we needed something and they took our order super fast.

The kitchen was a bit slow to get our order out (but then it was the night the Giants had won yet again against Texas in the finals so they can be forgiven?) and you can't really customize the orders.  For example, the vegetables came all together in a medley and you could not pick just one kind of vegetable.

The halibut and the sole were delicious, a bit too salty, but very good.

All in all, we would go back here, we walked in at 9pm, the place was full and I just loved the old-time waiters, so professional!
author: Sailing A.

description: I have a friend who thinks that this restaurant is an epic landmark in San Francisco.  It does have that fun, old school vibe going on.  If you want a classic SF seafood dinner then you can get that here.  It's expensive though, you always have to wait a long time in an awkward little aisle, and the food, while good, does not make you go 'sweet jesus' when you take your first bite.  There has too be better seafood in SF, but I'm too lazy to find it.
author: Elizabeth W.

description: Just had lunch here this week and Tadich is still one of my all time favorites. Wish they took reservations but the short wait is just part of the deal. The gruff waiters are the other part! But the food is extraordinary and no matter when I go, it is consistently great. Easy to see why this place is a perennial classic. You've not eaten in San Francisco until you've eaten at the Tadich Grill.
author: Kevin E.

description: I decided to eat dinner here because it was next to our hotel and it was our anniversary so we had a good reason to celebrate. The service was good and the food was ok. The amount of people I witnessed waiting to get seated I figured that this place must be amazing! However, I ordered the filet of sole  and it was a bit over cooked but not too bad and my husband ordered Dungeness crab legs and he didn't like it at all and there was no flavor either. The fact that we waited almost over an hour to get seated and it was not worth it because the quality of the food was good not great! and Service was extremely slow. We had to call on our waiter twice to get us drinks and water. He was an older gentlemen who was in his sixties or seventies with no personality at all. I prefer fast service and reservations.
author: Sabrina T.

description: Above-average seafood, but I knocked it down a star because the waiters and especially the bartenders are rude.  Check the attitude, guys - if you've got a large party 15+ waiting for a table WITH reservations, at least try to be nice.  Decor is a bit blah - very plain, kinda shabby... don't go there for the ambience.  They will cram you into the smallest table possible.  Food is good, but old-school American, so lots of butter on everything.
author: Oliver S.

description: Great atmosphere - one of the oldest bar/restaurants in the country. A favorite after work watering hole for the financial district set. Best thing on menu is the Cioppino, well worth the price - although i once got it and it was only ok and not spectacular. Great place four beers for visitors or to chill out with friends. Can eat at the bar or in one of the cool booths.
author: Sam P.

description: The food is fairly predictable and mild in flavor, the menu features many classic "old school" dishes like oysters rockefeller.  However, everything was really fresh and consistent.  Waiter service was excellent, really old school approach by guys who are career waiters and probably work in the same restaurant for decades.  Overall a classic lunch experience and a window into SF of another era.
author: Oleg A.

description:
My husband and I visit SF once or twice a year.
The last time we were there we put the Tadich Grill on our "visit next time" list.
It's a very old time and well kept place....Quite spacious overall, with a huge bar to sit at (along with scattered booths that take longer to get).
We had decided we wanted to sit at the bar from the start (it was a late lunch) so we settled in there.
You have to watch out because some of the seats closest to the door are only for drinks. We managed to get one right past that section.
There seemed to be some confusion as to whether or not we got the pre-order bread (which we didn't) but it was solved fairly quickly.
I ordered the Cioppino which they are famous for.
My husband ordered the Sea Bass.
The orders were delivered fairly efficiently, and everything was very good.
However....My husband was a bit surprised that everything but the sea bass (vegetables, etc) was a little on the "cool" side.
He didn't bother having it re-heated.
Servers are good, but a bit distant in their approach.
The Cioppino was very good, but I have had better down the coast a bit.
I would probably return, but I think it was a little over priced and over hyped.
author: chinesegirlinLA c.

description:
A lot of reviewers have gripes about Tadich Grill.

The servers are cantankerous?  They can be.

The decor is barely post-Gold Rush?  It's not that bad.

It's too crowded? At times, without a doubt.

They don't take reservations?  If you know that going in, you are a step ahead of the tourists who do not.

The food is overpriced?  Here's where I get cranky.  There is the idea of value..  If one perceives the price too high, one should dine elsewhere.  Why?

Because the seafood at Tadich is as fresh as it can be and prepared simply, to the diner's taste.  This is as good as it gets.  You cannot find a better grilled swordfish steak in San Francisco.  Period.
author: Traffic G.

description: I agree with the review below, if you have only time to visit one restaurant in San Francisco, this one is it. Excellent food. Excellent service.  Lots of locals.  White linens.  Exceptional!
author: Dodo H.

description: This is plain, good food.  No fancy sauces, no layering of flavors.  All that is totally unnecessary when you cook excellent food in an excellent manner.  What you order is what you get.  Real food. Service is very old fashioned.  No reservations, you get seated when they have a place for you.  And you never know who you may see in this financial district institution that dates back to 1849.   I love it.
author: Delaine Z.

description: Very good! Had avocado and bay shrimp diablo - casserole.   Tons of bay shrimp(was pleasantly surprised) , great  rich sauce.  Not alot if rice, which to me was just perfect amount, definitely would order it again. Dessert was good, had better, but was still good. Great atmosphere, wait staff was great.
author: Marlena C.

description: Probably my favorite restaurant in SF. Cioppino is to die for! The waters/bar tenders are all wonderful! Sitting at the bar is just as enjoyable as sitting at a table.
author: Lauren E.

description: I've been here twice, a few years apart, and the waiters were surly both times. At the first visit, when my friend asked if the waiter was from NY he got offended, stormed off, and didn't come back to take our order. I had to seek him out and apologize (for nothing!) to get him to wait on us. Second visit: the Lobster Thermidor was dry and overcooked, and, worst of all, when I asked the waiter to break a $20, he brought me a five and five ones and insisted that I had only given him a $10. Never again.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Good....
Dungeness crab leg cocktail, yeah.
Clam chowder's not bad.
Old school old school old school.

Bad....
Oysters were from WA and mealy, enormous, watery, tasteless and nasty.
author: Melanie C.

description:
The only gripe that I have with Tadich is its unwillingness to accept reservations. Wait times can be prohibitively long, but alas, I return time after time for spicy bloody mary's (I get em extra hot- with a big dollop of horse radish), ciopinno so full of fresh seafood and in such a flavorful broth that I won't order it elsewhere and a dash of true San Francisco history. The menu is a spectacular blend of really traditional home-style daily specials and seafood that is presented in massive quantities with little doctoring.  You can actually taste the freshness of the fish!  
I also find their prices to be more than reasonable, given the quality and size of the dishes.
author: Jenni D.

description:
Very "Old San Francisco" place that I actually find to be pretty good. 

The prices aren't exactly on the cheap side of things so if that's what you're after, you may want to skip this one. 

Nothing fancy here, order seafood and you'll likely be happy. 

Unlike a certain other "old San Francisco" seafood restaurant, this is one I truly recommend.
author: Anita B.

description:
Stumbled into this place looking for a quick bite to eat for lunch.  So my review is based on that.  Soon as me and my wife walked in, we knew we made a mistake, looked a little to pricey for lunch but we said oh well, lets do it.  The menu is full of 20.00 dollar items that neither of us were looking to order for lunch.  Ok so after 10 mins we finally get a waiter to come over, although we had water in our glass from the other server.  Pasta and meat sauce, was the order for my wife.  Waiter says sorry you can't order that alone.  Your meal must total at least 11 dollars. LOL.  I was like wow, that's a bold standard to enforce.  I just wanted a bowl of seafood bisque, so I had to order Garlic bread to bring my meal up to par.   So we waited, food came out avg timing, and it was actually really good.  

We ate our food then waited another 20 mins for him to come back to check on us.  


Basically, really good food, but too pricey for a quick lunch, and very slow service for lunch time was my experience.  Would I go back, most likely, but not for lunch.
author: Elliott J.

description: I went there with a friend for lunch while I was in town and it was amazing! We each had the clam chowder to start and then split 2 dozen clams. I am from CO and have amazing seafood so it was a perfect treat! We sat at the bar and had great service and were able to sit right down. If you are in the Financial District and need a great taste of SF, Tadich Grill is a terrific place to be!
author: Nina B.

description:
I'm Croatian and there is nothing about this place that makes me feel like I am back in Cro nor eating some of my Teta's cuisine.  

Dined here twice, and that will be it for Tadich Grill.  

The food is nothing special and the waiters are always trying to build their checks by recommending way too much food.  It's crab season and the crab cakes were very big and tasty.  The veal cutlet was a slab of grease and not good at all.  

Tip: Try Perbacco next door for far better food!
author: Joe U.

description: You can see why Tadich has been around for so long. Great attentive service and portions to add an inch or two to your waistline. Food is better than average and specials are, well special. My companion had halibut in a yummy sauce, I opted for the fire grilled version, a little dry, but still good. I would recommend you tell the server how you like your fish cooked, I will next time.
author: Steve S.

description:
Yeah, yeah the history is great but this place has always been about the quality of the food.  We went early on a Friday with the kids (hoping to avoid the typical work week after work crowd) and were rewarded with a short wait at the bar while being entertained by the friendly barkeep who taught the kids how to gamble on a dice game (he came out slightly ahead but who cares, my kids now know how to throw dice!).

Once seated we were promptly attended to and served a delicious meal (the calamari left much to be desired however).  The dishes were tasty, hot and fresh.  The price was way over the top (even for SF) but my kids can now say "been there, done that" (the wife and I had been before years ago).
author: Jeff W.

description: A gem which stands out in a city of many gems. Glad I didn't have any preconceptions before coming here...just come and see for yourself. The shrimp bisque plus a couple Anchor Steams is a good start for sharing with a friend at the bar.
author: Peter B.

description: Can't go wrong here. I giving it five stars because Tadich is a place that if you can't make up your mind where to go, go here. It's great food and a fun environment. Well even if you can make up your mind I would go here. I you want a nice quite place, this may not be the right place for you. It is usually a loud environment.
author: Matthew T.

description:
I just love this place. Had the Lobster Thermidor special and it was delicious -- lots of big lobster chunks and a great sauce. It amazes me that they have such a huge menu and do everything so well.
I really like these old-school places with traditional -- albeit heavy -- cooking. A welcome relief from so many precious Bay Area restaurants where the parsley decorating the plate rim is considered a vegetable course and you end up leaving hungry.
author: James G.

description: California's oldest restaurant with a wide, fresh, wild seafood selection.
author: Marc C.

description: I came here in Friday night with high expectations. I read several yelp reviews and some friends of mine were raving about it from out of town so I decided to give it a try. The setup of the place is kind of cool takes you back to an old fashion type of place I really liked the service I felt that the severs were attentive, however when I ordered I told the guy that I was lactose intolerant and asked several times if the artichoke had any milk in there and he assured me no. A few minutes later after eating the artichoke I got very sick and couldn't figure out why until saw the cream from the "sauce" they put on the artichoke. I feel that certain items were good their wine list sucked and I can't ignore the server who lied and told me their was no milk in my meal. I don't think I will be coming back again. Bummer the seafood was pretty good.
author: Tracie V.

description: Came here two years ago and had a great meal......this time round not so much. First the fresh halibut was great, no complaint there.....then the so called fresh King Salmon......well it looked like Sockeye to me...very red and was very dry, and  a small portion, sent it back and the next one came out cooked medium rare, however the salmon was still dry and tasteless... after two bites didn't eat any more....Ordered the fresh oysters and they were wimpy & limp and nothing special.....got the bill after commenting on the salmon and the salmon meal was on there....so called forth the waiter who then took it off the bill......overall, Disappointing...for excellent seafood go to Scomas.....
author: steve d.

description: Old school place.  Feels like the sort of place that probably hasn't changed much in years and years.  The service feels a little stiff and crusty, but overall a relaxed atmosphere.  Sat at the bar and had cioppino while my friend had a Chilean bass.  The bread is delicious and addictive, with a lovely brown crust, and appears to be a little famous on their own from a little googling.  Cioppino is enormous, contains large amount of all kinds of seafood but not really any crab in shell (lots of crab meats though).  The broth is topnotch.  I haven't tried other San Francisco cioppinos to compare it to, but this is definitely a superb dish.  I think it's almost big enough for two people.  The bass on the other hand was good but unspectacular, buttery and full of umami like you would expect of a fresh piece of this particular fish, while the side veggie and rice are of old school style which is consistent with this place's feel, and not all that great.  It's a little pricey like people mentioned.  Hopefully I can compare after I've tried more cioppinos, say from places like Sotto Mare.
author: Kozmo C.

description:
The girlfriend and I dined here last Friday night and had a wonderful meal. Tables can be a wait, but the counter where we sat is first come and we had a great time chatting with the other patrons next to us.

Our service was excellent, the dishes were timed perfectly never arriving before the last was finished, but still hot and fresh each time. The Clam Chowder is a must do, the Oysters are fresh and clean, the Salmon is prepared very finely. This place is definitely a classic.

After reading other reviews I was mentally prepared for a great meal with hurried calloused service, but I find that quite untrue. While the service is not the bubble gum smiles you may get at a chain restaurant, IT IS courteous and professional. This is service the way it used to be, silent and invisible, but always there. The proof... you're never asked "would you like more water?" The glass just stays filled.
author: Dave A.

description:
By far one of the best restaurants I ate at while in San Francisco. Went here for lunch and it was very satisfying and filling. They are known for their clam chowder so you should get a cup (the bowl is huge and my honey ate it all). 

I had the ahi tuna and it was rare, the way I love it. I would go back here for dinner if I am in the area again. I love this place and you will too!
author: Sarah L.

description:
This is my kind of place: The old stalwart that will never die! It also had my kind of food: Fresh, local seafood with simple preparations. 

They start you off with a piece of sourdough bread, and have a very classic menu. I had the Petral Sole, pan fried. It came with a sort of butter-cream sauce. for dessert, I had the rice custard pudding, a very interesting dish with a very scrumptious caramel sauce. When I discovered that the restaurant didn't accept AmEx (be warned. I found that many places in the Bay Area don't take AmEx), the waiter had no problem letting me go get cash. He also had no qualms with steering me in the direction of a dish I would like when I asked for his opinion

To my New Orleans friends, I have described the place as a cross between Galatoire's and Camelia Grill (erring more towards Galatoire's), with San Fransisco cuisine fixed in an almost creole style. It certainly had that loud echoy atmosphere one gets from tile floors, that just encourages you to be youself eat, drink, laugh, and have a good time that both of those New orleans classsics have, and it also happens to have the no reverations policy that results in a line.

Don't miss this place.
author: Ryan W.

description:
Loved it!  It reminded me a bit of Shaw's in Chicago.

Fair prices for great food.  I appreciated that despite the fact that they were very busy yet our party of 4 did not feel rushed at all.
author: David K.

description: The historical element of Tadich Grill gets it an automatic star, and the lively atmosphere gets it another, but the seafood is only worth one more in my opinion. The meal was good, but I have to believe Tadich's popularity is due to the history of the restaurant and what it once was. Tadich has an old school feel, which is great, but the food itself falls a bit short of the accolades this place receives. It's a must do, but unless I have a visitor who wants to go, I doubt I will be back.
author: Nick C.

description:
Old style seafood restaurant.  You don't come here for creative fare but you do come here for delicious and super fresh seafood.  I love their dungness crab--amazing.  

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
A great place to bring out-of-towners, or friends-of-your-parents-visiting-SF type people. They make an excellent Bloody Mary, and the food will put you in a serious coma.

If you ever want to play hookey on a Friday, I highly suggest heading to Tadich for lunch for a nice food/alcohol buzz. Then go to an afternoon movie and let your brain just turn to mush. So relaxing. Oh and if you can't get a table, just sit at the bar. It's quicker and the bartenders are very nice.
author: Kristen D.

description:
Having read about this place so much we went there for an early dinner on my day off in the middle of the week. The place fills up quickly even on a Tuesday night. By 6pm there is a line already. I like the old gold rush deco.  It also reminds me of an up scale Little Joe with old time waiters and no nonsense service. They are there to take your orders and bring you the food. They are not there to chat you up. Had the mix seafood appetizer and a salad. Both were excellent. Watch a man ate a steak next to us at the bar. The steak was perfectly cooked, charred on the outside and evenly pink on the inside. 

Will come back and try other items on the menu.
author: Mr P.

description:
California's oldest restaurant, since 1849 (!) I've enjoyed many a lunch here, sat by myself at the long bar. Seats at tables and cool weird private booths along the West wall to grab a bite w/ your wifes best friend, (4-shame). 

Fresh Sourdough bread  w/Clam Chowder, real fresh clams, nice flavorful broth, Fresh shucked Oysters, yes 1 dozen please, high quality delicate bivalves ready for a smattering of cocktail/horseradish(sorry purists)  to compliment the Draft Bass beer.  
The Sand Dabs are great too,- shit , it's all great! Serious waiters in the traditional white coats, no-nonsense career chefs turning out the best no-nonsense seafood in the city. Forget about driving as it's on California street, take a cab or dork out on the cable car. AWESOME!!!
author: Matt E.

description:
I have said it before and I will say it again, I am not a huge fan of Seafood...so why the hell did I choose Tadich for a business lunch? Well, because it has been in SF since the begging of time and SURELY they had to have non fish options.

They don't take reservations. So go early and get over it!

We got there at 11:45ish and had NO PROBLEM being seated immediately!

I did try a bite of the crab cake and was pleasantly surprised when I wasn't overcome with a feeling of needing to retch...so that has to say something!

I choose the pot roast with mashed potatoes. You CANNOT go wrong. The meat was done to perfection and my mom couldn't have made better mashed potatoes and hers ROCK!

The service - OUTSTANDING, as it should be for such an old school establishment!

I could not have been more pleased!
author: Becky M.

description:
Oldest restaurant as well as oldest waiter!  I came here yesterday before hitting up the St. Patty's day festivities and was not impressed.  We were walking down California looking for some food to grab and we saw this grill.  We didn't bother looking at the menu because we thought grill means sandwiches, burgers, salads, etc.

We sat down right away at a very nice private looking table and had water and sourdough bread waiting for us at the table....those are my 2 favorite things and the reason that I gave 2 stars.  Our water never got less than half full and that is a big help.

Do not bring someone here who doesn't like seafood because it is 95 percent seafood.  It is also really expensive.  They have a lot of different types of seafood and some interesting looking salads, but the guy that was at our table ordered a salad and it was an average sized salad, not too big, not too small, but it was 20 dollars!!!!!  You also need to make sure that you read the fine print in the menu because each seat has to spend at least 11 dollars which is almost impossible not to do, you can split a plate, but it will cost you 9 dollars, and they can split a check, but they will only split it equally and only on 4 credit cards.  We only had 4 people in our party and we all had cash anyways so it wasn't a big deal, but if you go to dinner with someone just know that if they order the 40 dollar beef medallions and you order the 20 dollar salad, you will be paying the same amount!

Our waiter was old and kind of....let's just say weird for lack of a better word.  He asked us if we wanted any appetizers and while I was perusing the appetizers that were an average price of 15 dollars, he grabbed the menu out of my hand!  Guess I won't have any!  He dropped off a side of dressing at our table and his thumb was in the dressing as he put it on the table, but did he apologize and bring a new one?  No, he left that one and sucked the dressing off his thumb as he walked away!!!  Raise your hand if you think he washed his hands after that...nobody?  Me either, I highly doubt that he did, but hey, maybe I am wrong!  They also have the really good sourdough bread, but no bread plates so he came with a crumber or whatever it is called and said wow you guys made a mess!.  I was like yah, we couldn't help it because there are no bread plates.  He said, you don't need bread plates, you need plastic a tablecloth so you can wipe it.  I was like woah dude, we just spent over 100 dollars on a "quick dinner" and you are telling me that?? Really? 

All in all, the food wasn't terrible, but it wasn't worth the price either.  I probably would not go here again unless someone came into town and REALLY wanted to try it.
author: M M.

description: Let's rate the Cioppino, their signature dish. The soup/sauce is wonderfully flavorfull. However, this is a dish which when prepared masterfully is served right after the dish is done. Otherwise the scallops, shrimp, shell fish and fish get tough. And tough they are at Tadich. The portion at $31.00 is double what any fatman needs, but it does encourage the guest to make it at home to discover seafood that has not been leatherized. My wife had the crabcakes, and said, as she always says, "They're bettter in Maryland!" Howver, I'm beginning to think that might have something to do with ambiance and nostaligia. I love the setting, old wood, waiters in white, hints of another earlier era. It is a place not be missed, one of SF's treasures.
author: David Z.

description:
maybe the hype was too high... but i was not impressed.

i got the cioppino. i like seafood and tomatoes. but i feel the soup was very mediocre, not bad but also nothing special.

the garlic bread was really good.
author: Danielle A.

description: I first discovered this restaurant in 1958 in its former location, I think on Turk St. When they moved around 1968, it was reproduced exactly. It's a sea food place for me. I have never tried anything else. I always start with the crab cocktail, then a fish, usually petrale sole or poached salmon in egg sauce, with fries, a side of spinach, a glass of white wine, and their sourdough bread that is like no other. If I have room, then the rice pudding, and if I'm really feeling decadent, I pour some cream over it. I love the atmosphere, always sit at the counter, preferably as close to the kitchen as possible to overhear the banter. You can get a book on the history of the Tadich Grill, or Tadich's as it's known to regulars. It's the oldest restaurant in SF and If every other restaurant in the world were to disappear, I could eat here for the rest of my life. I just wish it it was open on Sunday.
author: Ken M.

description: 2 words...old school...presented in the most respectable and gracious manner possible! Tadich Grill is an SF icon for fans of traditional American food. In particular, however, the petrale sole is highly recommended as well as any seafood offering on the menu. I also had a dungeoness crab salad that was very fresh and served perfectly chilled. Along with a side of asparagus with hollandaise and glass of red wine (I'm not prone to social pressures), this was a very tasty meal indeed. The all male wait staff is witty and entertaining. There are not many restaurants of this caliber still in existence that provide fare at this level of quality, so I highly recommend it.
author: Al K.

description: The Tadich has the privilege of being the oldest restaurant in the city, and I think they serve roughly the kind of food that was popular during the Gold Rush: giant portions of meat and seafood, prepared classically (re: likely as it was popular in the 1850s) and simply. I went with my dining out buddy as our last San Francisco meal before we both moved away for graduate school, and I think we were more pleased to be there than we necessarily were with the food. That is not to say that my grilled Pacific Salmon wasn't well-cooked and tasty, but simply that the Tadich Grill is the kind of place I'd go back to for the experience rather than the food. The portions are giant, so if I return when I'm back in SF, I'll definitely split my plate with someone else. But I would not split my drinks: Tadich makes strong-ass cocktails. And I'm down with that, for sure.
author: Stevi C.

description:
Tadich is like stepping back in time - artichokes, sourdough, sand dabs, oysters rockefeller, pickled herring - not a micro-fusion-green in sight - 
I love to go with my downtown friends - we sit in a booth at lunchtime, drink martinis, and conspire like Old Money.
author: Robyn C.

description:
When I was a kid my parents would take me to Chuck's Steak House, and my favorite thing ever was their salad bar.  The bar had amazing pumpernickel bread, hard as rock block jello, and nothing but iceberg lettuce.  And of course, for the rest of the meal, we all ordered steak.  That's what I think of when I hear "old school" regarding restaurants- and at a reasonable price.

I guess Tadich is "old school" all fancified with expensive wines and plain-coat waiters with fake dignified airs.  So dignified in fact, that after spending a hefty sum for our dinner and leaving a generous tip, they asked my date if we could basically leave since there were people waiting for a table.  Is that all they have to show for their long tradition?
author: CAKE E.

description:
Excellent seafood served by the same waiters for the past 80 years. Gorgeous, dark wood, including a long bar/lunch counter, lends to the old-fashioned feel. Wood paneled booths are excellent for 2 or 4. I think they moved from the original Clay location  to California about the time I was born.
There is actually an extensive menu, but we always have some incarnation of seafood. Also good to come here early afternoon on a weekend.
author: Colleen B.

description:
