I love this place. I just have to get this out in the open right at the top. The long bar, the dark wood, the brass, the over-50 brick-faced European-accented waiters... All that rates five stars. And the food, I hear you say? Well that is a well trodden road with a few potholes.

First off, do not even set foot in the place if you are only interested in trendy, stylized food being noshed on by metro 20-something's who haven't got a freakin' clue what they are eating. This is old school baby. This is food that is totally stuck in the '60s. No fancy presentations, no miniature portions, nothing is done three ways and all of the ingredients can be found at your local Safeway. Once you understand all that, and really appreciate it, then it's easy to settle in to an ice-cold Manhattan, a bowl of Boston chowder and an obscenely rich crab leg saute.

The catch is that most of the time it'll be great and but you will get some times where it will be crap.

The sweetbreads (on the rare times that they serve them) are flawlessly prepared. Tender, buttery and delicious. The lobster thermador on the other hand turned out extremely tough, bitter and otherwise flavorless. The mequite broiled porterhouse steak is surprisingly excellent. And so on. Also, the service can be a bit more brusque than I'd like. I always order my Manhattans "up" and when I was brought one that was "rocks" I returned it and the bar-tender got a little pissy about it. So due to the occasional bad meal and the occasional bad service, I have to sadly give them only four stars... but I really want to give them five.
author: Thomas S.

description:
This place really is an amazing cross section of the Financial District.  I think I saw a guy wearing one of those cowboy raincoats with his boots and cowboy hat.  But it was a Friday, and I was pretty tired.  Maybe I was seeing things.

Anways, while waiting at the bar for our 2-top to come up, my friend started a conversation with one of the guys serving.  "25 years," was the answer to: "How many years have you been working here?"  I leaned over to H and asked her, "WHO works for ANYPLACE for 25 years?!"

The portions are huge.  And you really can't go wrong with any of the special casseroles of the day.  And if you're a hot girl named Heather, you may even manage to get a glass of wine on the house and reheating tips from your server.

But remember folks, this place gets mighty packed, even on days where it's dumping gallons of water outside.  Don't be surprised if you have a 20+ minute wait to get a seat.  Make sure you've got time to come and enjoy the ambiance and the waitstaff.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
I used to love this place until last week.  We ordered half dozen oysters to share, asparagus,  broiled snapper, crab salad, bread pudding and a gin martini. Total was $87 plus tip.

Large entree portions and good stiff drink. The oysters are delicious as were the crab salad.  Unfortunately, the snapper was bland and overcooked and tasted like it was frozen- and the bread pudding was cold.

Overall it's an okay dining experience but I wanted more.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
As a  SF native I've been loath to participate in the touristy traps in the City.  I have a visceral reaction when house guests want to go to Alcatraz, Fisherman's Wharf and Chinatown.  

So when my dad suggested Tadich for dinner last night, I was skeptical to say the least.  Since I was happy he didn't insist on Chinese food, I accepted.  

I warn you to expect a wait and you need to listen carefully for your name b/c they read it twice and they move on.  There is no effort to be made to find you.  And since the restaurant's acoustics are off the charts, it can be difficult to hear your name.

The interior looks as if hasn't been altered in forever so that is nice.  We got a coveted spot in one of  those great old fashioned private booths.  I only wish that the call bell still worked!  And for good reason, the service is inattentive.  They seem to have an apathetic manner based on the endless line of patrons.  

The cioppino is definitely the thing to get.  The tomato broth has pleasant depth and spice.  The seafood is very fresh and the portions are quite large.  I loved the two huge  hunks of garlic bread to sop up the broth.  I ordered the sand dabs which were a little greasy for me.  The roasted potatoes were quite tasty and the veggie medley was passable.  I was simply amazed at the amount of seafood they give you.  

The desserts were unimpressive.  Our waiter suggested the triple chocolate mousse and panned the other desserts.  I give him points for being honest.  The triple chocolate mousse was passable.  I don't really like white chocolate in anything.  

I would return if a house guest said they absolutely had to try ciopinno.   But I would find somewhere to indulge in something sweet.
author: Monica L.

description:
As others have said, this is an old school San Francisco landmark.  You can tell by the career waiters, the old patrons shuffling around the bar, and the hostest yelling out "see you next week Charlie".

The seafood was overall pretty good, but our calamari was alot chewier than other high-end places.  My husband's sea bass was cooked to perfection and my scallop saute was tasty.  Their tarter sauce and cocktail sauce was the best I've ever tasted (lots of horseradish).  

Overall, when it comes to old-school, I think I'd give the nod to Scomas, but this is definitely worth a try for a taste of San Francisco history.
author: Jo Anne G.

description:
I was excited to finally eat here since I have heard so much about this place. Not sure what I expected it to look like on the inside but I was surprised how low key the atmosphere was. Maybe I was expecting something a little fancier?

We ordered a bottle of champagne and the Tadich Platter to start and then split the Seafood Saute. This so hit the spot! I was a little miffed at the service (apparently we got there as they were ready to stop serving) but I assume when you have a reputation like they do, they don't care so much how they treat you.

The second waiter that helped us was much friendlier and a bit more polite. I would love to go back again for some of their prawn cocktail, king crag legs and lobster.

Definitely a 4 start- better service might have made this a 5.
author: Jen S.

description: Although the restaurant came highly recommended and the maitre de was great, once we were seated the service was so speedy the waiter barely waited for me to finish my order before running off to the next table.  We ordered the 'famous" garlic bread. It came bland.  we send it back, it was returned soaking in oil. We ordered creamed spinach (my favorite and a dish I enjoyed the evening prior at Morton's) and it never was served.  The salmon was served uncooked and when I showed our (unconcerned and uncaring) waiter he remarked: "oh it's always served like that but I'll reheat it" and it came back reheated, but still raw inside and both fish dishes we ordered were bland and tasteless.  My husband didn't want to leave a tip but I insisted so at least the bus boys serving water would not be forgotten.  As we left and told the maitre de our dissatisfaction, he remained jovial and made light of it.  The place is busy.  They turn tables every 40 minutes and are open restricted hours.  I am quite sure they could care less if they receive bad reviews.  Tadich Grill is over-rated.  In a city like San Francisco there are more restaurants per capita than in any other US city - a factual statistic.  Find another fish/seafood restaurant.  I'm sure you'll enjoy it much more than this place.
author: Renée S.

description: Stopped in after dinner for a glass of wine and the "parade of desserts." Friendly staff and the dessert sampler was fantastic. Highly recommended.
author: Dan R.

description: The best ciapinno in town. Reasonable prices with great menu. We are from nyc and were impressed. Great atmosphere with no tourist type hyper. Old school class. Close to the Omnibus Hotel onCalifotnia St. We ate there twice for dinner.
author: Billy V.

description: Great spot.  I love the atmosphere.  The service was fabulous.  I was hoping for some delicious classics.  The salad was good.  The fish I ordered was overly charred tasting and tough.  Fun for a cocktail, but dine elsewhere.
author: T H.

description:
I been here 3 times as well and the food isn't all that impressive.  Sure it has old time world charm but the food is all but lack-lustring.  The group I was with all order different food but we all didn't feel well afterward.   My order took a full 20 minutes after everyone else. I told them to start eating first.   It was lunch hour for me and needless to say. I rushed big time to eat.

Go there for the history but I doubt I will ever go there  again.
author: Chris C.

description:
Five stars.

Old school.

I think that says it all.  I first ate at the Tadich Grill 20 years ago.  It hasn't changed since then, and I get the impression that it is still the same as it was a hundred years ago.  This is a man's restaurant.  The service and the menu are no-nonsense.  There's no California organic cuisine here and there are no $500 bottles on the wine list.

Come and sit at the counter or wait for a booth.  They don't take reservations and until a couple years ago they only took cash.  The service is faultless.  Water and bread appear and are replenished literally before you ever THINK that you might want more.  The waiter (and no, there are NO waitresses) is there before you think you might need something.  Very East Coast.

The food is absolutely excellent.  They specialize in seafood and in my experience it has always been cooked to perfection: tender, juicy, succulent, and full of flavor.  Every time I come back to Tadich, I realize how weak (I guess "subtle" is the West-Coast terminology) the flavors are at most other restaurants.

Prices are in the $15-20 range for most entrees.

At Tadich, the flavors are bold, the meals honest, and the portions large.  Peerless in its class and revelatory.

The iconic American restaurant.
author: Adrian B.

description:
I went here with some of my coworkers for our team's Christmas lunch. The feel is a throwback to another era....everything from the long bar to the coat hooks along the walls to the predominately older male clientel, this place has a touch of the past. 

The seafood is out of this world. I had the dunganess crab cakes, which were incredible. We split the seafood platter appetizer, which was also delicious. For dessert, my AE and I split a chocolate mousse that was a bit of a letdown after the abovementioned fabulousness. 

Overall, an interesting place to dine with tasty options for the seafood lovers.
author: Jenn G.

description:
Open since 1849 is right...  Every server in there is dedicated to maintaining the reputation of well over 100 years of fantastic service and happy customers.  Just being in this place takes you back in time --- it is easy to envision that group over there at the bar in 1920 might have been talking about (2 dapper men in their suit jackets on either side of a well dressed maiden - hair combed over slick across her forehead with swirls of hair just to the front of her ear, curling up above her cheekbone) with a new era of jazz playing in the background.

The food and the service are both stellar at Tadich.  Great place for a business dinner (to impress a client of course --- make sure to get a corner booth)
author: Benjamin G.

description:
Family was in town so this was my chance to get a free meal. Tadich Grill was my view outside of my office window so I have been waiting and wanting to go for a while.

I knew that it could get pretty crowded so we went early for lunch at 11:30 am on Friday. Glad we went early because that lunch crowd quickly started to line up.

I thought my Mediterranean Scallops and Shrimp Risotto was tasty. It filled me up along with the half of loaf of sourdough they place on the table. I didn't need a salad or soup - the serving was perfect for me. 

My entree was around $18 - for me that's pricey for lunch but it was fun for my family since it was a "historic" San Francisco restaurant.

I think my fiancee would love this place because it feels like a guys place to eat. The wood, the big bar and the comfort/expensive food. If he has clients he would definitely take them here. 

Service was unbelievably FAST. These people are professionals and they get 'em in and get 'em out. It got pretty loud with the lunch time diners and the high ceilings so we just watched the wait staff do their magic instead of shouting to each other.
author: Wendy B.

description:
Atmosphere was nice, waiters were friendly, and um... that's about it.

I ordered the calamari steak with a garlic butter sauce. Have had it elsewhere, and loved it so thought I couldn't go wrong. What came out (for $17) were 2 thin limp pieces of calamari DROWNING in pure butter. No spices other than the mound of garlic on top that I had to scrape off because it was so harsh. Bland and boring. I couldn't even eat the 2 broccoli pieces that came on the side because someone got a little salt heavy back in the kitchen. So disappointed.

My dinner partner got the Cioppino, which wasn't bad, but for $24, I've had better.

Bummer - I was hoping this would have been better.
author: Sarah P.

description:
I got a bib.  I know I look young, but 5?  

Anyway, they needn't worry because the cioppino they were trying to protect me from was so delicious I woudn't have dared let any fall on my shirt.

Tadich is a bit on the pricey side, but for the old school decor, secluded high booths, and friendly Croatians it's worth a visit.
author: Dubs W.

description:
The people there were very abrupt, almost annoyed by us. Our waiter was kinda rude, and would ask us questions then walk away before we could answer.

The calamari was was too breaded and extremely chewy. The rest of the food was very tasty. Unfortunately there is more to a good restaurant than good food, especially at that price.
author: Jaime M.

description: Came here on a Thursday night for dinner. Apparently this is the oldest restaurant in San Francisco, but I think they advertise that because they don't want to spend the money to renovate. I guess that allows the charm about this place to transpire. Everyone continues to wear what they originally wore when it first opened, the staff looks like 1950s scientists. I had the 21st amendment for a beer and it was great. My friend and I had a discussion of chowder, so he ordered the coney island (Bleh! Anything from New York!!), and I had New England Clam chowder. We tried each others and of course the New England clam chowder was the clear winner, but not as good if it were actually from New England. Their entree menu changes daily,  so you can't really expect the same thing when you come here. I had the sea bass with a ceasar salad side, and it was fantastic. This place is pretty pricey, but worth every penny.
author: Phan H.

description:
Haters: it's Old School, 
You know about the fresh Crab, 
Time to try the clams.
author: Brian J.

description: Old school SF. Cioppino was great, lots of seafood. Sauteed fish was tasty as well. Clam chowder was not that great according to the two young clam chowder experts in the group. Lunch for two entrees and two soups was over $100. A good experience and I am sure the corporate types go there often but not something that I would go to on a regular basis. Much try at least once.
author: Racer X.

description:
The food here is OK, and it is an SF landmark... but I wouldn't go here on a weekday after work unless you dig standing around with a bunch of banker-types who are greasing the palms of the waiters to get seated themselves; unless you can play that "old school" game... good luck!

Granted, my one experience happened a year ago on my birthday.  We actually got seated before the banker-run, so the waiter was trying to push us out of our table so he could pocket more money.  Not fucking cool.

I hear this place is a different story on the weekends, so I might give it another try when I don't have to compete for decent service.
author: Stephen B.

description:
We raced over the bridge after work in Beth's car to catch a movie at the Embarcadero. There is so much crap in Beth's car it's like being incased in portable walls of bulletin boards. Clips here, stickers there; I pulled down the sun visor and junky toys came tumbling down on my lap. Yes, we are that car that can be seen with bits of paper flying out open windows. 

Traffic was clear and we parked allowing us about an hour and a half for dinner. Beth suggested we stop into Tadish Grill; she stated she had a fondness for their seafood salad. We entered the establishment and were provided two seats at the bar immediately.  I love eating at bars. Tadish's is one of those old historic San Francisco restaurants that have been around since the 1800's.  Private cozy booths, plenty of wood paneling, and wait staff in matching white dinner jackets. Beth tells me that the private dining booths were used for men having dinner with their hookers "back in the day." Women were not allowed to go out to dinner "back in the day."  I don't know where she gets this stuff, it could be true. Beth likes to say, "back in the day."  My friend usually speaks with such conviction that if you didn't know her you would think she knows things, but usually 75% of the things she speaks of is wrong or inaccurate. One just nods.

The menu is expansive, the way I like it. There are daily specials for each day by date! The menu is printed daily - very cool. There is a strong seafood component as well as old time classics.  I opt for an old fashioned favorite - breaded veal cutlet with pasta and veggies, Beth orders red chowder and the seafood salad that she was craving. I go ahead and add white chowder to my selections. 

I enjoy the hustle and bustle atmosphere. The single woman sitting to my left groped my thigh and crotch area and apologized, she acted as if she was fumbling with her purse, but her purse was not on my lap. I nodded and let her have her cheap thrill. Chowders arrived and they were thick and tasty, the way I like many things. Entrees came at the perfect time and it was good. Good old fashioned food. Not creative, not fancy, not memorable, but filling and fine. Maybe it was what I ordered, but I would describe it as eats from a GOOD coffee shop served on a large oval plate. This is not a complaint, just an observation. Beth's seafood salad looked good and had many items - and of course Thousand Island dressing was on the side in a small silver cup.

Dinner was done, and its time to go. Timing and service was quick. Total tab, $70 bucks for the 2 of us, including 1 beer, ice tea, tax and tip. The movie we caught was a good one! Nice evening.
author: Blade L.

description:
My boyfriend and I went here on a last minute dining out because we were hungry and we were thinking of places in the downtown area where we were at the moment.  He's been to the restaurant before and was raving about it but I never gave it a second thought and boy, I have to say I was missing out and wished then someone had knocked me over the head and dragged me in.

They're crab cakes are TO DIE FOR!  Seriously yummy.  I've tried a lot of crab cakes but these guys cook it to perfection.  Combine that with oyster shooters and you've got a delicious appetizing meal.  We slathered horse radish, hot sauce, and their marinara sauce on the oysters to give it that extra ooomph.....yum yum yum!

We finished off with our own entree plates afterwards.  Their entree plates were good but I think if we had stuck to more crab cakes, oyster shooters, and possibly a bowl of their clam chowder, that would've been the perfect eal.

Our waiter btw was uber friendly.  Really friendly guy, gave great advice on the food.  Overall it was a sweet meal!  A must recommendation if you're in the area.
author: Nerinna V.

description:
I've been coming here for a few years but I only stick with the cioppino which is to die for. It comes with two big chunks of garlic bread to soak up the flavorful broth. 
The crab cakes are also very good with big chunks of flesh.

The waiters are gruff but so am I so I have no problems with them. The wait can be long at times even waiting for a seat at the bar.
author: Evan W.

description: There's nothing better than a seafood dinner at Tadich. The food is always excellently prepared, the ambiance is truly San Francisco, and the service is, well Tadich at its best. All in all Tadich is a must visit when in San Francisco...
author: John T.

description: True, the waiters won't hold your hand. It is one of. The food, service, and ambiance of the Tadich Grill make it a "must visit" eatery in San Francisco. Tadich Grill is a great place to hang out and have a great meal that doesn't cost that much. A great Californian restaurant! Being from Minnesota, this was a treat! The seafood was excellent. My. Great ambiance!. The booths are the best part of the place, get one and.
author: Ryan D.

description:
A wonderful institution.  If I worked or lived nearby and could afford to, I could eat here almost daily.

I don't need to be friends with my waiter, I want them to get the order right and provide service - which they do here with a style that reminds me of New York, or a water-front  which is appropriate, since this is also about fresh seafood.

The reason I could dine here daily is they always have superior fish, which they can be prepare and sauce a variety of ways.  Nothing really fancy, just fresh and not f##ked with.  Good bread, butter, wine list...

I guess I could move closer...
author: T T.

description:
My husband and I dropped in at this restaurant after we saw Emeril's new show called "The Original" on the Cooking Channel.

Overall, very good experience. Great food great service...& friendly customers.

We sat at the bar.  I had their Seafood Cioppino which was out of this world. I'll be gladly pay $30 a plate for it!  It is definately large enough plate to make it a full meal and the best Cioppino i've ever had.
As for my husband, he had the mesquite charbroiled swordfish. It has all the charbroiled flavor with non of the over cooked rubbery texture. Fish remains very moist and tender inside.

It was definately a well worth paying experience!

Plan ahead.  Get there right before dinner rush....that way, doesnt matter if they take reservations or not, or how long the wait is...you'll most likely have a good experience with their service as well as their food that's not being rushed out during dinner peak time.  That's just my personal opinion.  Good Luck!
author: Bc M.

description: When you walk into this place you feel like your walking through a place of importance.  This is old school as old school gets.  Got together with some college buddies and had dinner here.  Had the calamari steak and it was really great.  I'd like to try the other seafood selections sometime.  I'll be coming again.
author: Norm P.

description: The history and story behind this place is reason enough to give it a try. I went for my first time last Friday, on a whim just walking by and was very happy. I had the steak and lobster, which was delicious and very reasonably priced. She had the 'pork hash'... I forget what exactly it was called. Both were delicious and the service was snappy and professional. We ate at the bar, diner style, and really took in the old world feel of the interior. I'd go back to Tadich anytime.
author: Lee S.

description:
Know what you want soon after sitting and you'll feel like you a pro!

If I wore a suit and tie and had an expense account I would eat here more often, but you'll get the same old-school/to-the-point service mentioned in the other reviews. The waiters border on rude if you don't know what you want, but, oh yeah, that's the old-school service I was talking about. You'll find that their specialty is slappin' down a hunk of fish (cooked your way) with some veggies on the side, and washing down San Francisco's epic sourdough with a martini. Much better than Sam's. And, yes, get there early or stand behind a stool at the bar with a patron paying their bill - it's not tacky, just smart.
author: Dave R.

description:
I love this place.  In part because it always reminds me of my dad.  He went here while in town for a conference several years before I moved to sf. When I got here, he would always ask if I made it to Tadich yet.  We still go together everytime he's in town.  So, the four stars are in part based on nostalgia but that said, the food is good.  The service is good.  The location is convenient to may hotels in the city.  And it's fun.  

Plus, you know those twins in SF who must be in their eighties who still dress to match each other?  You can see them dining here if you're lucky.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Sorry Tadich i want to like you but I'm just not gonna do it.  I was wondering while I stood in line with 500 others, why am I here?  Was it cause its the oldest restaurant or was it cause my BF loved their bread so much.  I started wondering also are we all tourists cause I don't think there is any locals here which = it sucks.  I understand it has been around forever and so have the waitstaff which means they do not need a personality and could give a shit less if your there since 50 others are standing in line.  Food is nothing spectacular in fact my braised lamb was almost grossing me out.  I would never recommend this place to anybody, it's not worth waiting 10 minutes for.  Do yourself a favor and go to the three nice restaurants next door to it.  I wish we did.
author: C Y.

description:
This place could charm the skin off a snake. Thinking about Tadich makes me smile and feel warm and fuzzy. It's love. 

The lobster bisque was the best i've ever had, crab cocktail was plentiful and just the right amount of spicy in the cocktail sauce. However, the ciopino and sand dabs were nothing to write home about. After having both of these things at Sotto Mare, nothing has yet to compare. 

They lose a starfor the above and because our waiter disappeared for much longer than the 5 minutes we said we needed to chose from the very large menu. We never saw him again. The rest of the wait staff were great.
author: Erin D.

description: We came about 2 pm and there was no wait. The calamari steak is one of the best things I've ever eaten. The seafood sauté was delicious too. The nearby parking garage is pricey so take a cab if you can. Absolutely recommended.
author: Adrienne A.

description: We dined here because it was a popular tourist attraction and claims to be the oldest restaurant in California. We heard that there might be a wait because of the restaurant's popularity so we went early. Upon arriving at 5:30pm we were seated at the bar with no wait (which was a good thing because people started lining up shortly afterward). My friend ordered the seafood cioppino and I had the Dungeness crab and prawns a la Monza. Both dishes were delicious! They were both piping hot and fresh. Now, some reasons this place didn't receive 5 stars is because the servers seem to usher you in and get you out for the next waiting customer. The drinks are not refillable. Also, we had originally ordered an appetizer, the lobster bisque, but we had learned that they had run out after waiting 20 minutes which by that time our main entrees had arrived. All in all, if someone asked for a good restaurant while visiting San Fran, I'd recommend Tadich Grill however, I don't think I'd visit only because there are so many more restaurants in the area that offer the same dishes.
author: Jensen B.

description:
This place is totally old school San Francisco, complete with an all male waitstaff dressed in white coats and black ties.  It hasn't changed a lick in the last 15 years that I've dined here.  The food is impeccable and is aimed at highlighting the freshness of the fish.  Man, I've missed the West coast.

I personally love any of the offerings simply grilled with a big ol' side of tartar sauce (the bit of potatoes they add are what make it texturally AWESOME).  The portions are enormous and the price is right.  

Minus one star for the fact that they don't take reservations and are therefore intent on a quick turnover of tables.  Service is awesome right till the moment they deliver the bill, then prepare to get a progressively stinkier stink eye till you leave.
author: Ashley S.

description: Like this place a lot.  Not too great of a beer selection but the food is awesome and they have an extensive menu.  Great ambiance and interior.  Open late too!
author: A V.

description: This place is so so so good. The Cioppino is amazing! Hand downs the best I've ever had. This is a little piece of history in San Francisco's Financial District. Its one of the oldest restaurants in the city. Its old school with a charm. The waiters all where white coats and tend to be older gentleman. They do not take reservations so get there early. Its a great place to go have great food and feel like you have gone back in time a little. Enjoy!
author: Sara B.

description: This is truly a gem of a place. We had to wait 45 mins for a table but the bartenders kept us happy. This place brings you back to the way restaurants use to be and how classic old school service makes you smile. You can tell the employees really enjoy working at Tadich. We ordered the crab cake and the waiter did an upsell and sold us 2 crabcakes. Yeah he got us a $25 appetizer but it was so good we didn't care. My hubby had the cioppino and I had another dish (it was great but forget the specific name). If you are staying in the financial district you need to stop in. It will cover all of your seafood cravings.
author: D G.

description: There are no words to explain how good my dinner was! I had the Cesar salad made with fresh dressing laced with anchovies, steamed asparagus with cream, and their famous Cioppino. Thanks Anthony Bourdain for the recommendation! Best to go during off hours or you'll have to wait about 45mins. If you have to wait, keep waiting because the food is worth it! The waiters are all men and "old". They act stern and feisty like an old mafia joint but they were all very sweet and funny.  One guy looked me in the eyes and said, how's the food and I replied good and then he said "that's what I thought" and winked.  The experience was wonderful and I'd definitely come back again!
author: Nghi L.

description: Yeah!  I can't write a taste... except it's great.  Just go and try... and you won't have any words to describe how yummy the food is, at Tadich!
author: Allen S.

description:
Ate at the Tadich Grill last night.
Crab cakes not browned and all food came with heavy gross sauces..a terrible experience.
Waiter was tired and old and service pitiful.
author: z z.

description: Horrible! My wife got sick half way through her meal and all the manager Rick could say was "our policy does not allow deducting the meal price when more than half has been eaten". She got food poisoning , but no apology. High prices, mediocre (or worse) food in a charming atmosphere. I had the $26 crab Louis, which had less crab and less flavor than the $8 crab sandwich on the wharf. There are many great choices in SF, this is not one of them.
author: Steve M.

description:
Best seafood in town.

Bay Shrimp Curry casserole is amazing.

A little pricey but worth it. I eat there once a month.
author: Thor M.

description:
A long standing tradition that dates back to 1849.  How can you not feel the obligation to go to the longest standing institutions in San Francisco.

Inside, I definitely felt like I was entering another time period.  It just adds to the atmosphere.  

While it took a while to get seated for lunch, I'll have to say the service was incredibly.  I was in a bit of a rush, informing the waiter of my time constraints, our food was prepped quickly and we got our food immediately.  Service was very timely and considerate.

The food just oozed of freshness.  From the clam chowder soup, to the grilled salmon that I had, it was savory and delicious. Certainly nothing to write home about.  Good nonetheless. 

My only complaint would have to be their seating arrangements and not taking reservations (although I can certainly understand why). You can be sure to wait for a while, and even get bumped back when you thought you were ahead a few patrons on seating.  

As one knows, San Francisco has fierce competition for restaurant customers for service and dining.  One can only admire this restaurant having been around for so long.  Obviously Tadich is doing something right.  This place must go off at night for happy hour and drinks around their bar area.
author: Rishi D.

description:
Tadich Grill is the place to go for simple, unadorned food.   

Their bread is a crusty sourdough, inexplicably served initially with a single patty of butter.  Never fear, more butter is forthcoming, a single patty at a time.

The whole, charcoal-broiled branzino is a perfect plate of food.  The fish is accompanied by a few potatos, a simple carbohydrate, and a fresh vegetable. Health food that tastes good.

An appetizer of fried calamari served with their wonderful tartar sauce is a great way to begin a meal.  French fries here beat those at McDonalds.  Stay away from the out-sourced deserts.

Service is rough and tumble and can be spot on or forgetful.  Don't order anything complex that requires saucing and you are in for a great time.
author: David D.

description:
I had lunch here a few weeks back with Will H.  

What a place!  I understand that it is 155 years old. We are talking about old time San Francisco elegance, with a bar as long as you can see. 

My friend and I both had the dungeness crab salads - amazing.  There was so much crab that I could not finish my plate.  And I am an eater.  A big eater.  Especially when I am being treated.

This is a perfect place for a business lunch, or to meet a friend if you feel like dropping a bit of coin.  I loved it.  

There is a modern restaurant just next store (Aqua?) that is supposed to be excellent as well. I think i would prefer Tadich!
author: Jill D.

description:
Four stars is really good/excellent, only because we cannot place it into the "fine dining" slot.   .   .  

but, hey:  get n.y. cut,  the chowders to die 4, sole d'ore, again FRIES, [and, prolly could round up some Bearnaise sauce there], and lovely 'sides'

It was known as the original cold-weather restaurant, we don't know Y.  . . .  .
in the post -Gold Rush days??  [It's older than I am.]

not fancy, but excha clean and tasty.

Go early they (used to) don't take reservations.

O  yummmmmmmm
author: Clifford L.

description:
i have not been there in  over 4 yrs...but if memory serves me well , my family and myself loved Tadich. it was very reminenscent of east coast places to eat , saloon/bar/ type establishments.  we loved the menu , could not chose , we wanted to try eveything.... decided on the rockerfekker chowders and cocktails and crab salads. our waiter very nice , started talking to us about east coast & etc...my husband and i are from NY and Conn areas.  he even allowed us to have a  Menu ,as a memento.. we are southern cali residents, but as soon as we get back to N cali 1st place we will stop by is Tadich .
we tend to stay away from tourist areas   and stray off the beaten path...as 'they' say
author: Debra S.

description: I worked downtown most of my life and eating at Tadich for lunch was a high point of the week.  ate there tonight, and it was a geat disapontment.  The Petrale sole waa covered with  a sauce, the sand dabs were tough and over ooked, and my friends hangtown fry resembled a over cooked fritatta.  The potatoes, once described as "long branch" were shaken out of a bag.   I guess you can never go back.
author: Kendall P.

description: Yum, yum, yum. What else can I say? My hubby and I decided to grab a quick bite and a drink here before going off to do some salsa dancing, and we were shocked at how packed this place was on a saturday nite. We somehow managed to finagle 2 seats on the bar that also serves food, and from then on, we were treated to a wonderful culinary and service experience. Our waiter, Laurent, is a frenchman, and a spicy one at that. He gave us very wonderful suggestions for food and we were not disappointed. The crab cake that I ordered had lots of crab in it, and was soooo good. The fried calamari was hands down THE BEST that i have had anywhere. It was meaty, tender (not rubbery), crunch on the outside, with a hint of wasabi. Just superb. I couldn't stop eating it. I pretty much stole the whole plate from my hubby and ate it all. We also ordered the clam chowder, which, I must say, I have had better, but it had almost all the essentials (rich, hearty, full of clams and potatoes) that I simply couldn't complain. So, all in all, service was spectacular and the food, as simple as it was, was delicious. We will definitely go back to treat ourselves to a real seafood binge in the near future.
author: Mei W.

description: Over-rated and expensive for what you get. Living off it's rep as the oldest restaurant around. Waiters were very un-friendly and food was not bad but it just didn't meet expectations set by the prices they charge. I did like the interior of the place though and ambiance was not bad. Looks like they got a pretty good bar too.
author: Chris H.

description: This is one of the oldest restaurants in San Francisco and offers the best seafood around.  No reservations allowed so be there early for lunch.
author: Jason H.

description: I guess I like the idea of Tadich Grill better than the place; that is, it's pretty cool that it's been in operation in one place or another since 1849, and I like the old world wood atmosphere, and I sort of like the surly waiters, but as for the food, not so much. After the recent article in the Chron about it, I went there last week, and was underwhelmed. First of all, even though it was at an odd hour and there were some empty, small tables, their policy is to never give a single diner a table. Usually I like sitting at the bar, but I was tired, and I had a big tote bag with me, and just wanted to relax. Although I didn't this time, I usually spend as much as two people when I try a good restaurant, having wine, appetizers, dessert and not the cheapest thing on the menu. So, I was sort of miffed at this policy. Oh well. The bar was OK. But, the tastiest things on the fried seafood platter (oysters, scallops, fish, shrimp)  were not seafood: delicious broccoli and french fries.  The oysters were pretty good, because their flavor was so strong as to stand up to the breading. The rest of the seafood was tasteless.   BIG disappointment.  There are way better places, including Pacific Cafe, where I've never had anything that wasn't lip-smackin' good.  I realized at the end of my Tadich meal that I had had the exact same opinion the last time I was there about five years ago. This time I won't forget and fall for the idea and history instead of the flavor.
author: Crystal C.

description: just checked-in to this old favorite while christmas shopping....signs of concern...oysters were overly cold and dry (signs that they are pre-schucked and stored in the fridge) and the crab cocktail was clearly frozen crab (admittedly during the SF crab strike, but thought that an institution like this would replace with fresh crab from oregon, like swans does when its out of season in sf) and they did not have anchor steam...bring back the magic!
author: nick g.

description: This is a fast-food restaurant at not-fast-food prices.   The food was ok - not bad, but nothing special.  My problem is that we were told more than once that they needed to turn the table, and we were not permitted to order dessert.  By the way, we had been there maybe an hour and a half at that point, which doesn't strike me as excessive for a party of 4 at dinner.  I understand the restaurant business is tough, and turning tables is important, but really??!!!
author: Sharon W.

description: Nice service, beautiful bar from the past, but food wasn't worth the price, not even close. Don't get me wrong, the food was fresh, simple, and good but nothing extraordinary and the price was far too high for what you're receiving. There are just too many restaurants in SF to choose from in this price range with more flair in their cooking. Seems like most people come in for the "Cheers" effect. A lot of regulars where everyone knows their name. :)
author: Sabi M.

description: Good food, nice atmosphere, very friendly staff.  The crab-cakes were to die for.  Overall, a very enjoyable evening out. We'll definitely be back soon
author: Donald B.

description:
This is a restaurant that knows what it is and does it very well.  

Old-style San Francisco complete with dark wood, booths, white tablecloths and businesslike waiters.  Good quality seafood offered in a wide variety of ways.  The waiters do their job perfectly without trying to be charming.

It's quiet enough to have a good business conversation.  It's the perfect place to go if you're alone and want a good meal but don't want to feel like you're alone: you can sit at the bar and get the same good food and service.

Basically: it works.
author: H. G.

description: small and noisy but the food is so definitely worth the 1 hour wait we had on a Saturday evening.
author: D H.

description: I haven't been here a while, so I met some friends here for lunch.  We shouldn't have showed up at 12:15, but that 10 minute wait turned into 30 minutes.  Food was good, but I had forgotten how expensive this place is... I guess somebody else usually picks up the tab.
author: Brian P.

description: Overrated. Only come here when friends from out of town INSIST this place is a must according to their tour books.  Each visit ends with "I told you so..."  Overrated!  Food is just meh.
author: Bayarea K.

description: My San Francisco dream came true.  Trying to knock out all my food desires and finally got to Tadich Grill.  Went during the recommended lull between lunch and dinner so no wait.  Best clam chowder ever.  Love love the chowder.  And I eat a lot of chowder everywhere.  Best steamed clams.  One dozen more than enough.  Husband's cioppino could have fed us both, but he ate it.  Lamb chops were delicious, I ignored the brussel sprouts.  Waiter was great, and brought me the 2 desserts I wanted, even though we had had quite enough.  Yum.  I want to have that chowder again right now.
author: stacy c.

description:
A lively old school upscale seafood grill.  

The joint was a bit narrow with a long counter with single stools.  On one side there were private booths, with 2 seat tables in between each booth.  The decor is dark wood with the feel that at one time the place would be filled with cigar smoke.

The wait staff were neatly dressed in traditional white jackets...did not see a woman working there though.  The place really had a traditional feel to it.  

Seafood is their specialty.  I had the whole grilled Branzino sea bass...tasty semi-oily white flesh fish.  The steak fries that came with it was a bit on the soggy side though.  The sauteed squash was excellent.  The Boston Clam Chowder was piping hot and did not need any additional pepper.  The Hearts of Romaine salad was good, I recommend the "Creamy French", sort of the like a Thousand Island without the relish.  My wife had the crab & prawn Monza casserole (a casserole made with rice, tomato based sauce, crab meat and prawns all topped with melted cheese.  Very tasty, but watch the plate...its really hot.

Tony our waiter was friendly and very attentive.  The Men's room is upstairs and really clean.  The only negatives, was the place was a bit noisy and catastrophic.
author: Jerry W.

description:
Food was good, but I think you can get better seafood at Fisherman's Wharf for 1/2 the price. 

It had a nice old school feel; and suprisingly, I didn't wait long for a table during the lunch hour rush.

However, all was undone when I saw the prices.  Who eats here everyday and how much money do you make?!  Nothing under $20 and this is for lunch!  Again, better seafood and less expensive at Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Meghana A.

description: I love the Tadich.  Went on New Year's eve with no reservations (they don't take them).  Table for two in minutes after a drink at the bar.  Best bread in town.  Best Oysters Rockefeller anywhere.  And dungeness crab louis chock full of fresh crab.  Excellent service, old-school, wonderful.  Did I mention that I love the Tadich?
author: John H.

description: Simply the worst food and horrible service I have ever had in SF. We had been coming here for over 30 years, and last Saturday finished us off. A rude and unhelpful Croatian waiter named Joe, whom we have encountered in the past, served us the worst sand dabs and steak combo we have ever tried to eat. We couldn't finish the dinner. Cold bread and butter was literally thrown onto the table in front of us. The steak was grisly, undercooked and inedible, wine was overpriced, like most everywhere. This place needs to go away and stop preying on the tourists and the sentimental suckers like us. We were insulted and so should many potential future customers. This place has definitely exceeded its life expectantcy.
author: Paul W.

description: a staple classic restaurant, and also the oldest restaurant in california.  i've been waiting a while to try this place, and was delighted when the mister said we could eat here to start our new year's eve evening.  the place does not take reservations, but luckily they were not busy when we arrived that night.  we started with the seafood salad.  be warned that it is huge.  we were pretty stuffed by the time our entrees came, but managed to eat a fair bit of it.  he had the halibut with potatoes and green beans, which he pretty much finished.  i had the cioppino, which was deliciously flavored and generously filled with an assortment of seafood.  i had to leave more than half of it behind, and could not doggy bag the rest since we were headed staight to a party after dinner.  i was pretty bummed about that.   no room for dessert, but the bread pudding caught my eye for the next time.
author: Sheri N.

description: Superb! Will definitely make this a regular stop when in San Francisco. Great atmosphere and history. Blackened grilled red snapper was amazing.
author: Nathan E.

description: I'm glad I finally got to experience the Tadich Grill.  I was craving sea bass, and I was not dissapointed. Possibly the best fish I have ever had.  The crabcakes are good, but pricey, and they are very rich.  The tiramisu for dessert was kind of dry and tasteless, I wouldn't recommend it.  Total tab (no alcohol) came to $100.00 for two people.
author: Lisa W.

description: This place is a down right dining experience. Been there three times now. It has become a must whenever we visit the city. The food is excellent. Lot's of old SF history and atmosphere. One of the longest running business's in the city. Can I recommend the Cioppino.
author: Robert R.

description: Very classic feel.  Food was good.  Service was great and would definitely go back.
author: Alex P.

description: I've heard it before and I need to repeat it, this place is old school San Francisco. 5 stars for the service which was flat out awesome and 4 for the food which was above average but nothing too spectacular. First the bartender, damn I wish I knew his name (tall skinny dude with slicked back hair) was wayyyy cool and really talkative. I was standing against the wall waiting for my wife while waiting for our table and this guy leans through the crowd of people to ask me what I want to drink, I didn't want one at the time but all of a sudden I did. I told him I was waiting for my pregnant wife and he made a shirley temple for her with extra cherries, just overall a real great attitude on him. When we got seated which was quite fast for no reservations on a friday night our waiter was on point and gave his recommendations, again a real cool and funny guy. Food was all pretty tasty but the real standout was the clam chowder it is a must try.
author: Justin S.

description: If you like seafood, this is the place!  The clam chowder is by far the best I have ever had.  Service was great and also valet parking.  Everyone I know has tried Tadich Grill so I had to try it.  Well worth it and not too pricey.
author: Jeremiah B.

description: Loved it.  The dinner salad with shrimp and crab (and Louie dressing) was excellent.  Service was quick & classy.  Interior is old school-- not a place for a swanky romantic date.
author: Com P.

description: Sitting at the counter is fun and a good place to people watch.  The food is generally good and reasonably priced, but often the veggies are a little overdone.  The old school atmosphere is also nice.
author: David H.

description:
It's not the people-watching or the latest cocktails or sauces.  People are lining up at the door for the fresh seafood prepared in standard ways with such skill and reliability, Silicon Valley folks might call it an ISO 9000 operation.

The thing about Tadich is, it's almost anti-trendy.  They're into very fresh seafood with butter, lemon, and parsley, or something similarly simple.  Naturally the local seafood is the preferred choice.  Red snapper was probably swimming yesterday, while lobster was probably flown in from Alaska or Maine, in a time period only slightly longer but using lots more fuel and ice.

My last Tadich meal was on a Saturday, a good day to visit for lunch because the business line isn't there and you can usually sit down and eat immediately (they're really quick if there's not a huge line).

My mother ordered an appetizer; I got the red snapper.  Her appetizer was about three-quarters of what I'd call a meal, and my snapper was more than I could eat.  Fortunately she ate about a fifth, so we didn't have to leave anything.

Simple, reliable, high quality, fresh seafood.
author: Chuck D.

description:
This is only from a hamburger lover point of veiw  :)
Great hamburger - steak.. but more of a steak.  As I ordered my hamburger steak I found out that Tadich does not serve sandwhiches, so no hamburger bun, but a choice of mushrooms, salad, or steamed vegetables.  What!  no hamburger bun!!  What's a hamburger without a hamburger bun!!  Oh well, the ham... steak was good.  Good quality beef, but definitely not your traditional hamburger, the way I like it (toasted bun, mustard, relish!!... godah have it!)    :)  Btw, have not tried other dishes there, yet..
author: Diane V.

description: Very old fashioned San Francisco establishment.  Food was good (not excellent) but the wait, the smell of fish, and the dated decor detracted from the experience.  Good to do once since it's a classic, I guess.
author: David A.

description: Prices are too high.  Fish selections are very good and everything is fresh but their prices have gone up dramatically over the past 2-3 years.  I like their poached salmon with the egg cream sauce.  Would go back to splurge and try their Ciopino dish.  Otherwise there are other options in the city for fresh seafood at more reasonable prices.  Nice old-San Francisco atmosphere, however.
author: Mark N.

description: Walked in here late on friday to eat by myself at the bar.  Cool spot.. very old-school restaurant feel.  large bar, wooden decor, bar tenders all in white jackets... you get a different vibe coming in here...  looked at the menu and I wanted to grub on a lot of things, but also dind't want to be too full/bloated since I was going out later, so I just got a tuna steak... it was good... i mean can't mess up tuna right?  I didn't like the seaweed thing they put on top of it... it's very rare that I'll actually move food to the side of my plate b/c I don't want to eat it...but I did that.  I was also kind of disappointed in the side... it was just romaine lettuce wedges w/ a couple tomatoes instead of actual veggie side.  Having said all that, i enjoyed the meal and ate talking to some random stranger while sipping on bourbon... service was also very good and attentive... next time I'm gonna order something like cioppino or something.... kinda pricey, but what do you expect in that area for that kind of restaurant?
author: Easter E.

description: What a classic spot.  Friendly bartenders, speedy service, old-school vibe, oodles of history, and fresh fish - what else do you need?  Their crabcakes are to DIE for - and the crab & shrimp dinner salad with blue cheese is divine.  Stop there, and you'll be satisfied - but you won't stop there, because you need to try the cioppino, the sand dabs, and crab & prawns a la manza.  Mangia!
author: Julie L.

description: The Cioppino is one of the tastiest things I have ever enjoyed. Absolutely great. We sat at the bar with two small kids and had a wonderful time.
author: John C.

description: Great spot. Old school done right. I had eaten seafood for lunch so I opted for the meat ravioli along with a few seafood appetizers so as to not spoil the adventure completely. I am a big Italian fan and the ravioli was very tasty. In fact everything was tasty (except the house Chardonnay, which another person in my party ordered and I tasted - gag). All-in-all, I enjoyed the evening. I am definitely a return customer.
author: Brian R.

description: By now, Tadich Grill is a SF institution.  Claims itself to be the first restaurant in SF, although it has moved places thanks to waterfront development, fires, and general changes in the city.  Down in the Financial District and "old school" - white jackets and wood booths.  Cioppino is one of the best in the City - try it and be happy.  Have enjoyed my time here and have been here several times, reminds me that I have to go again when I am next in SF...
author: Todd S.

description: Such a cool place to come for lunch.  Being a seafood lover, this is one my favorite places in the Financial District to eat fish for lunch.  Servers have always been attentive and the food, although not "amazing", has been consistently good and the portions are very large.
author: Jason N.

description: shrimp and crab casserole? sold. it was the most delicious seafood dish i have ever had.
author: Jenny B.

description: Tempted to give fewer stars but would only be because I felt the high price (between $25 and $45 per plate) was inexcusable considering the diner-quality of the food my party was served (this is not to diss diners, but you know what to expect if you head to Denny's).  The food was fine.  Not great.  All members of the party commented on a certain lack of flavor.  With all of our dishes (liver, steak, pork chop) the meat tended toward overdone (we all requested "medium").  Ambiance was cozy--very 1960's (in a good way).  No reservations so arrive early or be prepared to wait (no waiting area, just a small standing space).
author: H B.

description:
Let me start off by saying I love Tadich Grill. I love it there and would recommend it to anyone, whether a tourist or a local. Forget trendy and chic. This place defines Old School San Francisco. No pretense, no airs -- think traditional steak house but for seafood.

The service was great and super friendly. And the food was awesome. Started with oysters Rockefeller, had shrimp cocktail as well. I had the swordfish steak, which is a good as swordfish gets.

The house specialty is crab cakes. Don't leave without getting one. Among the best crab cakes I've ever had. It was the highlight of the meal.

I only knock it down a notch because of the price. I know you have to pay for quality seafood, but I still found the prices exorbitant. Perhaps the place feels it caters to a business crowd, but I was there on the weekend for lunch. The price would keep me from going there on a regular basis; it's just too much.

So go and experience it, or go for a special occasion. Or try to to grab a high quality meal after work or during lunch.  Just make sure you budget for it. Not a complaint, but it is what it is.
author: Scott G.

description: Iconic seafood mecca: I'm in.  Went with the sand dabs based on some reviews here (as well as some TV shows I've seen in the past).  While tasty (nice light breading, tasty subtle sauce), they were by no means something to write home about.  The bigger issue I had was with the oysters.  You can get some phenomenal oysters in San Francisco, so one would expect that they are sourcing similar fresh ingredients at a place like Tadich.  Minimal preparation required -- store correctly, make sure the stock turns over quickly enough to keep them fresh, shuck and serve.  One would think this would be child's play for the folks at Tadich, but these were pretty much the worst oysters I've ever had (and my dining companions agreed).  Not one or two bad ones, but all two dozen were a little funky, mealy, and lacked any semblance of ocean flavor that makes oysters so great.  Granted, I don't try oysters at every restaurant I visit (I'm sure you could find a worse set at some dodgy pub in the middle of nowhere), but there's really no excuse here.  Definitely a one-and-done in my book.
author: Julie M.

description: We go here every time we go to the city.  Seafood is fresh and delicious, service is prompt and efficient.  To those that think the waiters are rude, that is their shtick.  Perhaps folks should lighten up a bit.  Love the history of this place.
author: Christina M.

description: Tadich Grill reminds me of old New York- cranky, white guys over 45 becoming impatient when you try to decipher their mile long menu.  Luckily, New York City has changed and San Fran isn't entirely full of pissy pants, but our lunch at Tadich was good; our fish dishes were fresh and our waiter was nice (unlike the guys at the bar).  What really made our meal extraordinary was the lemon pie we had for dessert; creamy filling and a soft but somewhat crunchy crust- a show stealer and the perfect ending to our afternoon.
author: Shannon W.

description:
humenah humenah.

for a seafood junkie like me, i could barely keep my eyeballs settled on one or two choices.

a half dozen of hama hama oysters! and a small bowl of clam chowder as well as a poached lobster.  yum! could a gal ask for more?
ok, they aren't known for their desserts so the rice pudding was a miss.

and they don't take rezzies so first come first serve.

not the youngest of crowds but the service and seafood were both solid.

the service may seem old school but they treat  you like an old time regular!
author: Anh V.

description: We walked into the oldest restaurant in California for dinner last night and were put at the counter. Fine by us, the staff was like the old boys club, refined and entertaining.  They were out of Boston clam chowder so we tried the Coney Island clam chowder and it was no disappointment! Then came the main entrées of halibut for him and salmon for me.  The sides were steak fries and a cauliflower and Brussels sprout medley, all extremely tasty.  We finished the meal with Bourbon bread pudding...oh..my..goodness! Talk about delicious.  So overall, highly recommend it, for the food, the drinks, and the atmosphere.
author: Sara S.

description: I am from out of town and never heard of Tadich Grill.  We just stumbled upon it after wandering around inside the Embarcadero Center (nothing worth reviewing in there).   The place was fantastic.  The interior was combo old style oyster bar and small table restaurant.  It was packed on a Saturday for lunch, but we were seated promply.  The local crab season had just begin so not being especially hungary we both orderd the dungeness crab salad.  It was so delicious with the Louie dressing.  I had a house Cabernet Sauvignon.  Very nice.  The service from the more mature waiters was marvelous.  We enjoyed it very much.  Highly recommended!
author: L A.

description: It is old San Francisco! Seriously, you get to be in the middle of an old school cold-day restaurant now dominated by the business power lunch crowd. Food was ok and service was prompt, like a well oiled machine. Live the way all wait staff are dressed in white jackets, v much like a restaurant in the 70s as seen in an old black and white movie.
author: Ada W.

description:
Sadly, my last visit may have been the last. I'd only dined there perhaps 7 or 8 times over the 35 years I've lived in the Bay Area, always tempted by other menu items, but always ending up ordering the cioppino and a martini. Either I'm getting bigger or the bowl and martini glass both got a LOT smaller since the last time I visited 6 months ago. I was truly surprised and asked the waiter about it. He claimed, "No, they've never changed." But he may be new, I didn't recognize him. 

The waiters: I don't get  why people think they're surly. They've always been courteous, helpful and humorous. A dry humor, but it's been there nonetheless...

Now about the martinis and cioppino...Has anyone else noticed a 25-30% shrinkage????
author: Steve B.

description:
This SF institution has been my favorite restaurant since the first time I ate there back in 1983!

The grilled halibut is always awesome and there is the fried or grilled option for those who desire their fish oily.  The homemade tarter sauce is the best ever, and the sourdough makes you know why this type of bread is popular.

It is definitely an old boys type place, they don't take reservations and career waiters suits are probably older than most of the patrons.  Have a drink while you wait for a table or seats to open up at the counter.  While the service may be curt it is always efficient and never hurried.
author: Aj D.

description: I don't know how the waiters can carry a martini glass that is that full! The Petrale sole was very good as is the bread and butter served with your meal. The crab leg cocktail was pricey but very good. If all of the tables are taken, you can sit at the bar and enjoy your meal there...
author: Bob M.

description: 2 stars for it being an SF institution.  The food was mediocre and WAY too salty.  I'm still parched hours later.  The server appeared bored and as if he couldn't be bothered.  I was taking clients to lunch and when I indicated I wanted the bill, he tossed it on the table in front of me.  I put my AmEx in, he opened it said we don't take AmEx and threw it down on the table in front of me.  Zero graciousness/service.  Two food/history.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Come here for the atmosphere and the characters, you can really feel the city here.  I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it for tourists looking for a SF experience.  TG is old and historical and all that.  

I wouldn't go back for the food.  It wasn't bad, but it wasn't great.  I had the cioppino which had 2 big shrimp, 2 big scallops, 4 clams, some fish and lots of small shrimp and shredded crab meat.  I have had better.  The more I ate the less I wanted to eat and the taste kept coming back to me all day. The bloody mary was not good.  I guess they use their own mix from a bottle.  It was pretty strong if that's what you're looking for.

I could immediately smell cooked fish oil  when we walked in.  When we left our clothes smelled like burned fish oil for the rest of the day.   It was not pleasant.  I won't go back unless I know I can change my clothes immediately after leaving.
author: Dave P.

description: Don't go there expecting warm and friendly service and saccharine smiles.  They are brisk, but in a wonderfully old school way.  If this is your first time, then the Seafood Cioppino is a must.  It's a busy place, so get there early or prepare to wait...but well worth it either way.
author: Danny O.

description: I went to this place a few years ago. I do not get the big deal. At all. Food...so-so. Atmosphere...meh. Service...so-so. All in all, very, very blah.
author: Jenna L.

description: I guess this place is "dialed in," given the generations of San Francisans trained on its unremarkable food.  At any moment you can actually witness people paying for steamed shrimp with buttered noodles as a side dish.  What?, you say.  Well.  Eat your creamed spinach and stop asking questions.  TG is not for the culinary.  It's place for steamed fish dishes, chilled or otherwise.  It's for people who want a glimpse of history too.  The servers, quite old themselves, look like barbers in their white schmock- shirts.  How to impart the experience...?  Expensive for what it is.  A high-end diner for its food.   A place that became accepted as part of the SF business scene one-hundred years ago that stuck to its old-fashioned fish dishes and never looked back.  It's a living museum of sorts, and, somewhat bizarrely to my taste, very popular to this day.
author: Patrick B.

description: Great ambiance, delightful, sophisticated service and VERY good food.  Was reccommended by concierge at our hotel and was all he promised and more.  would return and reccommend!!!!
author: Jessica A.

description: One of my favorite places in the city. The food is expensive, but very reasonable because the portions are delicious and generous. I like the atmostphere because it's unique and interesting. My only complaints is the place always smells hella fishy and the wait can be really long on the weekends.
author: Allen Y.

description: Tadich Grill was a great find for my husband and I and by far the best Cioppino I have ever had.  I loved the old décor atmosphere.  I don't ever think I ate somewhere were the waiters wore white coats and it was possible that all waiters were men.  There was a great vibe from all the staff not to mention that they paid attention to detail and were very efficient.  This restaurant was recommended by an employee that worked in the crazy shirt store at Fisherman's Wharf he felt it was the best Cioppino in San Francisco and I will agree.  I though this was the best value and the best restaurant of all the places we dined in San Francisco.  FYI Scomas in Sausalito had Cioppino on the menu at $35.00, I believe Tadich was $24.00 and it was delicious and the portion was huge!
author: MB C.

description: I've only had the cioppino here, courtesy of Jeannie's uncle.  Thanks to him I got to try this place and their delicious stew.  Loved the decor, loved the history, loved my cioppino.  Next time I'm coming back and having a martini.
author: Ann F.

description: I was very happy here!  It reminded me of Galatoire's in New Orleans.  It is old, has old tile on the floors, lots of character.  Everything was really good, from the bread to the salad to the clam chowder, to the entrees (filet and tortellini/salmon).  Our waiter was a very nice French guy with a good sense of humor and caring.  I will definitely go back here.  They were out of lobster thermidor so that was disappointing, but it was all good.  No reservations, first come, first served.
author: Magic M.

description:
We arrived at the Tadich Grill on a Saturday night and opted to sit at the bar in exchange for no wait. The atmosphere is great with the long wooden bar tended by a large wait staff. Service was good, but not great. Our server was fairly attentive, but could have been a bit moreso, but was not much for smiling or conversation.

Wife had a seafood salad which was a sad bit of lettuce with some tiny shrimp piled on top. She remarked that the blue cheese dressing was good.

I ordered a filet with shrimp and some sort of cream based sauce on it. The sauce looked like it had been sitting for sometime and was congealed. The steak was burnt on the outside with a carbon flavor, but was slightly undercooked on the inside. Ordered steak fries but received shoestring fries instead which I decided to keep, and they were very good.

Overall this was not a good dining experience, and I would not return, nor recommend to others.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Simply put, I love Tadich.  It's been around for 159 years and still rocks.  Not only is the food fabuous -- I've never had a bad meal there -- but they have HANDS DOWN the best Manhattan Clam Chowder  I've ever had.  Tadich refers to it as Coney Island Clam Chowder.  All I can say is, TRY IT  with plenty of Tabasco.  It will cure anything that ails you.  Really.  The portions are generous at Tadich.  A cup of soup is what most people (and restaurants) consider to be a bowl of soup.  A bowl of soup is a large enough to be your entree.  

WHAT TO KNOW:  If you are looking for a light lunch  (i.e., no entree) or want to have a few martinis and a light lunch, don't try to sit at a table.  The waiters get surley with people who don't order enough food.   Instead, grab a seat at the bar and eat and drink to your heart's content.  If you ARE planning to order something more substantial, the table service is great and each booth comes with a call button to summon your waiter.  The seafood is no-nonsense and delicious and the salads are hard to choose between because they are all very fresh and tasty.  

Just go.  You won't be disappointed and you might even be entertained by the ambiance.
author: Anne M.

description: The food is just average.  It's famous and has a good mix of locals and tourists but I have yet to have a solid meal.  Much better places to eat.
author: John N.

description: Dined for the first time tonight. Wife had the large Crab Louis salad. Delicious and full of Dungeness Crab. The sauce was a little too heavy on dill however. Scale back on the dill guys. I had the Scallop Saute. It was excellent. Four large scallops (1" thick and 2.5" across) in a delicate sauce with tasty rice and zucchini. The wines by the glass were a bit weak-not many choices. I'd rate them a 4.5 overall. Thumbs up.
author: Phil E.

description: Whoa....hungry and spontaneous, a friend and I decided to stop here for an early dinner.  We've been here a handful of times but this visit was absolutely terrible. Biggest shock was the overpriced menu?   Are they kidding charging so much for mediocre food, terrible service and an attitude of "who cares, the tourists will pay for this establishment"  If it wasn't raining, I would of run out of this place.  What a disappointment!!  Unfortunately, I'll never recommend any out of town guests to even consider this place There'sso  much better elsewhere - it's really ashame Tadich's has taken this atttitude - rude and crusty  waiters isn't cute!
author: teri g.

description: A landmark. and still has excellent food. Try the Cioppino, it may be the best in the city.
author: Larry B.

description: BAD FOOD, HIGH PRICES.   really.   BAD.   This place is a tourist trap.  It's in the French Guide de Routard, more as a curiosity, not as a place for good food.   Our French friends love the guide, and wanted to see something uniquely San Francisco.    We'll I'm sad to say that must mean really crappy food and a big dose of kitch.  Japanese tourists posing for pictures out front, and college kids finding the sign as part of their "treasure hunt".   but there is no treasure to be found here.   the novelty of SF's oldest established restaurant, and the charm of cranky old waiters does not compensate for 6 people having truly bad meals and going away embarrassed to have spent $50/person for bad food in San Francisco!    not just "less than great", but actually bad tasting food that we all left big portions uneaten on our plates.  I am a big, voracious eater and don't balk at mediocre food usually, but at Tadich's I left 3/4 of a horrible tasting bass steak on my plate.  i was really shocked that a $24 plate could be so unacceptable.   at first I thought it must be me.   then I tasted my wife's bland, horribly sauced petrale sole, and saw she refused to eat even half.  then everyone else in our party of 6 reported their supposedly "fresh" fish and shellfish tasted BAD also, dry, old, probably frozen a long time.  halibut florentine had dry overcooked fish, completely overwhelmed by cheesy sauce.  split pea soup was too rich, over-seasoned, thick and pasty,   no selection of wine by the glass (2 choices for chardonnay) and neither were even passably good.    the menu for my house special bass plate said "potatoes" which I selected in part because many other menu items came with steak fries, which I didn't want.    the plate came with fries, and the waiter acted shocked when I asked for some potatoes, as listed on the menu.  (he did bring them though).   only the french bread and butter is good, plus ample quantify of decent steamed vegetables.   Don't eat at Tadich.   Go have a drink and take a picture.
author: david h.

description:
Great restaurant, excellent service and fresh food prepared the way you like it!

The decor and atmosphere of this Tadich Grill is like that from a Godfather movie. They have a full bar, and their waiters are all uniformed in clean white chef's jackets, and ties. I saw quite a few traders, and financiers when I ate dinner here. Gentleman, take your girlfriends here.

There's a variety of dishes to choose from, and you're not limited to ordering the items from a limited dinner menu (which usually consists of 8 items max at the fancier restaurants)

- Fresh seafood, caviar, fois gras if that suits your fancy
- a full assortment of casseroles 
- a mixed green salad or traditional caesar with seafood, shrimp, or just vegetables with avocado
- Lamb Chops bacon, eggs, and roasted potatoes

Save room for desert and coffee as you finish your evening off. Coffee is fresh and refilled by your waiter as you sip away.
author: Michael K.

description: The oldest restaurant in San Francisco serving the best cioppino in San Francisco.  YUM!
author: Kara C.

description: We have been to Tadish Grill twice and both times we had a great experience. We didn't wait on either occasion and sat at the bar. The waiters we had were entertaining and knew their menu items. The lobster tail is amazing and melts in your mouth. The fried calamari was one of the best we've had. The shoestring  fries are scrumptious--they tast like they are probably cooked in peanut oil. Crab cocktail had a genereous portion of crab and a kick of horseradish. The vegetables are a bit bland and I would have liked the tomatoe topped with spinach to have been hot. I am sure we will be back.
author: G R.

description:
A great place to spend some time.  

This place is one of my favorites in the City.  A wonderful seafood menu, great services, and an historic feel hard to find elsewhere. My favorite thing to do is to go with a friend or two and sit at the bar for dinner.  

A personal favorite is the cioppino, bread and butter, and a Anchor Steam Ale.
author: Dean A.

description: Ciopino = the place; large portions, fun experience with the white shirt waiters. Loud. Fantastic food and truly old school. This place is a landmark. You'll want to go back again and again. If you're from out of town, or local trying to show off a place for a guest, this is a great place. You'll have a great meal and they'll get to be in a part of San Francisco's history. Stick with anything from the water when ordering!
author: Darin A.

description: What more can be said. Not new or trendy - just classic. If you are looking for a great "old school" seafood place, look no further.
author: Mark B.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place - its has a great history and an old time SF feel (if you can't tell, I really dig old SF restaurants).  Went there with family who were visiting from Southern Califorina and I was very happy with the service.  The food was not as good as Scomas seafood, but it was very good.  I had steak and prawns - which was very good.  Also, the cocktails and appitizers were good.  

So I hope to be back in there before too long.
author: Richard C.

description:
There are dishes I've never had (cioppino) that people like. But in general, if you want great food, sit at the counter, and if you want a romantic or friends experience, wait for a booth. Either way, the wine is not first-rate, but all the food is. Order a simple preparation of fish (no one, and I mean no one, makes a better Petrale sole). Or, if you are tired of fish, pay whatever absurd price they are charging for lamb chops, because as far as I can tell there are no better lamb chops in Northern California, and maybe not in the United States.

And in recommending the petrale, once you have had that, you have to have the sand dabs in season (hardly anyone else offers them and no one does it better) and if you like salmon or really good halibut, that also is something that should be on your list.
author: oz c.

description: I feel like young people aren't apt to "get" this restaurant, though they might like it, or humor it. Most people won't appreciate the gold-rush era restaurant layout, surly service, and oily pan-fried seafood, in the same way that most people don't know what Fort Gunnybags is, or that Grant Avenue used to be Dupont Street, and the Tadich Grill used to stand somewhere else, because where it is now used to be water. But I find that for a group of people who spend their lives talking about discretionary review periods and restoring original modillions, it's a fine place for a Maker's Mark Manhattan and a plate of pan-fried sand dabs, a hunk of crusty bread and a bowl of seafood soup. Just be careful if you're talking about local politics; you never know who could be in that next booth.
author: Megan W.

description:
I'm really, really going to try and refrain from my soap box on this one.....but here it goes...

I went here knowing what it was like- cramped, rude, abrupt, noisy, over-priced, etc.  Tried to sit at the bar, but kept getting overrun by folks who seemed like they were getting preferential treatment by the bartenders.  Now, I DO appreciate being a regular, and I have my places, but this is not only a local historical kind of place, but also a tourista trap.  Mingling in are parties of a bazillion looking for a table to fit 10 and all 15 of their kids...fat chance...and did I mention there's NO room by the door, and NO, you can't have a drink while you wait for your table.  Eventually we were seated at the smallest 2-top ever, right in the walking path of the bus boys.  I loved getting that extra shower from your dirty dish rag.  Server was brash, and seemingly volatile.  Was waiting for him to go into some sort of Turret's expletive mode if one more person pissed him off.  Ordered calamari steak, soup, and another seafood salad.  Then I noticed....the entire place...ran by male's.  Not a female worker in sight.  Weird.  So, you guessed it, yes, I went there.  Adding fuel to Mr. Turret's fire...where are all the women?  His response, "well, we had one a while ago, and they just can't handle the job.  All day on your feet is tough, then they get pregnant, and have issues, it's a mess.  Men only."  Did that make my food taste any better?  Me thinks not.  Time to call in 20/20 or Dateline- this could be a major story.
Oh yeah, food just ok.  Overly salty, expensive, and no, I will never step foot in this place again.  It's San Francisco, there's 10 million other places to go.
author: Katie M.

description:
herd much about there ciopino,definetly did not disapoint.add a ketel one dirty martini,a quirky bartender,big pieces of sourdough bread,and im a set piece.
love the old san francisco feel of this place.
author: Betty T.
