description: I have been going here for years! Now I have started taking my kids. Yesterday, child had pasta in meat sauce. I brought back memories from my childhood with the delicious dish! I had a bowl of the clam chowder.  It was creamy and delicious. Husband has the crab cakes. He said they were fresh (no fishy taste, crispy outside and moist.) We will continue to go there!
author: j m.

description: One star off for the price, but went here after being talked into it by my friends after work. Get a taste of San Fran back in the day and treat yourself to a cocktail like a real gentleman.
author: Niners F.

description: One of the city's landmark restaurants, it's a family business that's been in continuous operation since the start of the Gold Rush era in 1849. The menu is straightforward, with calf's liver, hamburgers, lamb and pork chops, chicken, and four cuts of steak coming off the charcoal grill, but it's the large selection of seafood in a wide variety of preparations that's the main draw. The cioppino, overloaded with clams, prawns, scallops, bay shrimp, whitefish, and crab meat, is among the best in town, as is the  excellent sourdough bread, guaranteed to be every carb-counter's downfall. Hopefully you'll be seated in one of the enclosed booths, complete with a doorbell to summon the notoriously cantankerous waiters. Many will be aghast at how rude and sullen they can be, but regulars realize their attitude is one of the place's long-standing traditions and shouldn't be taken seriously. If they accepted reservations and were more reasonably priced, they would have won all five stars.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I was vacationing in SF and every website and person had recommended Tadich Grill.  I had my share of seafood and Cioppino while in SF, but this place definitely beat the rest hands down.  When we got there it was already packed and people were waiting to be seated at the bar having drinks.  It's an old school decor, very classy and the waiters are dressed in white jackets and very pleasant.  We had to wait about 45-60 minutes to be seated, but time flies when you're drinking!!  We started with some clams and oysters and both got the Cioppino for the entree.  It was definitely a healthy serving with good chunks of fish and seafood in a delicious broth.  I had to ask for extra bread to soak every bit of the broth.  If you're ever out in SF, I highly recommend you stop by for their Cioppino.  They don't take reservations, so get there early if you want to avoid the long wait.  The cost of the meal can add up quickly, but it's well worth it with the high quality food and service you get!  Writing this review made my mouth water a little bit....
author: Alan H.

description: What a disappointment.  The people were just so rude and it was unbelievable.  I don't understand why they choose to call female customers "honey" when they don't even know them.  I couldn't wait to get out of there.
author: Ayelet B.

description: Totally overrated tourist trap. Wine list consists of bottles you could buy at Safeway.
author: Reality Check S.

description: It had been YEARS (I'm talkin' Y-E-A-R-S, people), since I had eaten at The Tadich, so when my husband and I were headed to the Sting concert up on Nob Hill, we decided to catch dinner here (he had never been before) prior to the concert. It is still the same wonderful old school SF seafood restaurant that I remembered and love! We snagged a seat at the counter and had a nice interaction with our old school Austrian waiter, as well as the lady next to me. But the food...oh, the food....if you like SF seafood, then this is the place. I started off with a cup (be warned - it is more like a bowl) of their famous clam chowder and my husband had a small dungenous crab salad and we shared. Both were very good. For my main, I had the Oysters Trio (6 oysters fixed 3 ways) and my husband had a whole fish special of some kind - I think it was Branzino. Again, we shared both dishes and they were so good! The local  famous SF sour dough bread was really fresh and it was hard not to keep eating it! (unlike Melisa E.'s experience!)  I was glad to see that this restaurant was still serving great seafood and we would go back in a heartbeat!
author: Leslie T.

description: The Cioppino here is to die for ! I order it everytime I go to Tadich. Remember...this place is first come first serve.
author: Carlos G.

description: After months of hearing from friends how I had to try this local after work spot. I met a friend for dinner. I felt welcomed from the first step in the door. The bar and side bar had far apart seats I like that so I don't feel like I'm rubbing against the person next to me. We were seated soon after she arrived. Yannis (sp?) our server was very sweet, he answered all our questions about the menu and made some excellent suggestions. The menu changes daily but there was easily a handful of dishes I wanted to try and the cioppino ordered did not disappoint. The food was delicious and the service was excellent. I will become a regular.
author: Analise T.

description: I had never been to this legendary establishment, the oldest restaurant in the City, so I decided to have my 47th birthday dinner there with my wife Monica. Great choice: this is old school, "film noir" San Francisco at its finest. The waiters, decor, cocktails and food all contribute to the timeless ambiance. If you want a taste of the stylish past, this is the place to go.
author: Will V.

description: As far as seafood in San Francisco, it doesn't get any better than Tadich.  One of the oldest in the city and has survived all the dining fads.  Carbs be damned.  Sometimes they have some good lunch specials.  But for my money, anything off the seafood menu and you are golden.
author: Jeffrey Q.

description: Sorry, but the only thing good here was the bread.  Service was inefficient and rude at best and the food was barely adequate and over priced.  Not to mention how annoying it is to have people swarmed around you watching you eat and waiting for your seats like hyenas.  Leave this one to the tourists...
author: Spidermonkey J.

description: I was not impressed.  I'm not a seafood lover, so perhaps the food is fantastic and I just didn't appreciate it.
author: Kevin D.

description:
I'm going to be sick.  After eating a few bites of the overpriced "Avocado and Bay Shrimp Diablo" lunch casserole, all I can think is, "Get it out of me!"
Moments after it was served, I asked a passing waiter to remove the offending dish from the table.  As he walked away, I saw him stop to show our waiter that neither my friend nor I had eaten more than a couple bites.  When our waiter eventually returned to our table, he left the bill without a word of apology or regret.  He quite obviously did not care in the least that his guests found their meal revolting.
I asked the staff person who cleared our plates if the shrimp had been frozen.  He responded, "I don't think so."  Judging from the taste, they could not have been fresh.  The sauce in which they were cooked was watery and tasteless--the devil himself would have flown into a fury upon seeing his good name lent to this ceramic boat of slop.
There were three or four tasty bussels sprouts on the side, so it wasn't all bad.
author: Major M.

description:
i hear its an institution although i wasnt as impressed with the food as i thought i would be.  that said, i didnt really eat a full meal - i only had clam chowder and a salad with crab and shrimp.  both of those were fine but nothing special.  my friend had the halibut florentine and he liked it.  
i thought the atmosphere was fun - very old san francisco.  we sat at the counter, and our waiter was nice, in an old grumpy sort of way.  he wanted to make sure we were eating and drinking enough.  they had the place all done up for the holidays - very festive indeed!  
would i go again?  not sure - maybe to have a full meal, and to sit at a table instead of the counter.  i hear its a big lunch spot too, since its right downtown.  so maybe for lunch.
author: Carolyn B.

description: All I can say is YUMMY!!!!! The best Cioppino I have ever had! In fact I am craving it right now!!!
author: Adina R.

description: One post-Thanksgiving day, I went out with some out-of-town friends for lunch after seeing a TV magazine (I forget which one) review where they hailed its "Old World" San Francisco-style and it being the oldest restaurant in SF.  Well, I really can't see how they got their reputation based on my experience.  It took us about 40 minutes to get us seated.  The five of us got a table near the back along a well-used walkway for their wait staff.  We ordered our food and had to wait nearly as long before eating.  Okay, I'm totally not into the whole "being served" experience, but being totally ignored by the waiter is just ridiculous.  The food was mediocre at best.  Everyone left thinking we'd just wasted our time and money.
author: Michael W.

description: Maybe, just maybe the Palm Two in NYC as an old man waiter steak house is better, but only the Palm Two is better
author: Mark W.

description:
I strolled in here for a late Friday lunch since I have lived in SF for quite some time and have been meaning to check out the oldest restaurant in CA. Mainly I was itching for a beer and I figured the food would be good. 

I noticed 3 things I might be into and my waiter steered me toward the Oysters Rockefeller and I thank him for it, they were incredible. Truthfully the Rockefeller was incredible and the oysters were mediocre, but damn the Rockefeller fixing was good. I thought the $19 was a little steep, but the service was so good and the meal was so massive it was definitely worth it. I noticed the patrons around me all had huge portions Not to mention the service was great, my cup was never empty, and the Irish coffee to finish it all off was one of the best I've had yet.

Surprisingly it seemed to be filled mainly with local business folk, not annoying tourists. I would come back, not every week, but if you have never been you should definitely check it out.
author: Erich G.

description: It can be hard to get a seat depending on what time you go, but the wait is worth it!  The seafood is so fresh and everything off the menu is great.  The waiters are all so nice and I just love the atmosphere in there.  Such a fun place to go on your lunch break for a great meal!
author: Lauren B.

description: The food simply didn't impress me. For a seafood place, there didn't seem to be fresh product. Service was friendly and the atmosphere was cool, but I wouldn't come back for the food, especially at the prices they charge and with the plentiful options nearby.
author: Amy C.

description: The food here is mostly great. Not great great but mostly great. If you're here for clam chowder then you're in the right spot. However, if you're here for cioppino, then there are two other places that do it better. One place is Anchor Oyster bar and the other place is The Old Clam House out on Bayshore. The reason people find this place great is the fact that it's been around since 1856. It's the oldest restaurant west of the Mississippi and the people who work there are just as old. If you ever want to relive the days of being yelled at by your drunk grandfather then this is the place for you! With the exception of a few who work here, this has to be the grumpiest restaurant west of Uranus. (You know Pluto is not a planet anymore but a floating heart of the owner Mike Buitch in outer space) There used to be two bartenders that worked there named Adam and Matt who were the life of the party (and the youngest) that kept the mood flowing as well as the drinks but alas have moved on to greener pastures due to the fact that bar/restaurant owners don't like it when your happy customers buy you drinks. Lame reason guys. You act like they were pro-football players that ran off with your daughter. A piece of advice Tadich? I know you think you're an institution and all but It doesn't hurt to smile and walk in the sunshine once in a while.
author: Jason C.

description: Not much to say except this is the up there with the best seafood I have had.  Great, knowledgable staff, nice casual atmosphere, tasty desserts, priced to match the quality of the fish.  You cannot go wrong here.
author: Frank R.

description: Tadich is one of those places you go back to time and time again.  We really love the ambiance, the service and food.  Honestly, it feels like home.  Nothing says San Francisco better than this restaurant.  Although I usually come with family and friends, I also feel very comfortable going alone and eating at the bar.
author: Judith S.

description:
After doing my research (if nothing else I do great research!) we decided to go to the Swan Oyster Depot for dinner.  Unfortunately, we decided too late and they had just closed.  I called them and asked where they would recommend that we eat.  They suggested Tadich Grill and I am glad they did!  This was one of the best meals I (and the other two in our party) have ever had the pleasure to enjoy!

We started off with the a very good section of Sourdough bread, a Dungeness Crab Cake and Fried Calamari, both were fantastic!  The crab cake was full of huge chunks of tender crab smothered in a wonderful sauce.  The Calamari was equally as good, it was tender, not tough and seasoned just right.

For the main course I had the Fresh Alaskan Halibut Steak.  This was very light and tender and melted in my mouth.  It was served with a boiled potato and a mixture of vegetables.  The others relished the incredible Seafood Cioppino and the Mediterranean White Branzino Sea Bass.

This meal was simply unbelievable, as I said earlier, one of the best we ever had.  

Oh, I almost forgot about dessert, this WAS the best we ever had.  We all shared a single Chocolate Mousse (with wonderful drops of raspberry sauce on the side).  I am a self proclaimed chocoholic and have enjoyed Chocolate Mousse more than a few times in the past.  Hands down, this was the best Chocolate Mousse I have ever had.  It was presented in a hardened chocolate shell that contained the smoothest, lightest Chocolate Mousse you could ever imagine.  This is the LAST time I ever share one of those again!
If you don't go to Tadich's to enjoy a very fine meal and help them celebrate their 161st year in business, then at least go there for the Chocolate Mousse.  You will be very glad that you did.
author: Joe H.

description: You want fish? Here's great, non fussy, fish. Good portions too. Along with Sam's, the last remaining authentic SF seafood retaurant.
author: Dr. B.

description: A few weeks ago, I was somewhat embarrassed to call myself a Bay Area / San Francisco native who had never dined at Tadich. Now, I think that was just fine. Disclaimer: This review should be disregarded if you are an ultimate seafood lover. My friend and I both got fish. The food was definitely average at best. The sides were not even redeeming. As for the service, the waiter did not have many tables at all and was as slow as Molasses. I almost felt like he thought we wanted to be there for an hour and a half. It was a weekday after work... not so much. Anyways, I would say, if you are not very adventurous when it comes to seafood, share something with someone in case you hate it to save yourself 30 bucks or avoid the very fishy fish.
author: Nicole L.

description: 4 stars for an old SF institution that feels like you've stepped into a time warp. Don't come here on a Friday night if you don't like the hustle and bustle and you're allergic to the financial district crowd. Stick with the seafood....steamed clams are the best. Meats are a little over done.
author: Arlene C.

description: Tadich Grill was one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  It is the oldest restaurant in SF and had that old skool cozy feel to it.  The bartenders were funny and welcoming, no one working there seemed under 45 years old, but that kept with the ambiance.  We had cocktails at the bar while we waited for our table, the drinks were good, the house red wine was good as well.  I ordered the cioppino and my husband had the steak.  Ridiculous!  You could definitely tell that the soup had been stewing for awhile, the seafood had marvelous flavor and nothing in it seemed over or under cooked.  The steak was exactly as ordered with wonderful flavor.  It definitely gets busy, but rightfully so, this place is deserves high marks and is a must if you visit!  I also hear that the lunch is good, but the dinner is outstanding!
author: Janet S.

description:
We went here because someone had recommended it. We had no idea what to expect, as we were not even sure what kind of food it served. We just heard it was good, and that we needed to visit.

Good thing we did. What a good dinner we had. We went on a Monday night, and got seated right away. Even still, the place was full. We were seated at a table that was partially enclosed, so it had a bit of privacy to it, which was very nice. 

We started off with the appetizer platter. It had smoked trout, crab, oysters, shrimp, and a couple other things that i ate but forgot. This was an appetizer platter well worth the price. The fresh seafood was center stage, and tasted great. 

I was not sure what to get, and our waiter recommended the cioppino. So i ordered that with a octopus salad. The octopus was good, but the salad was way too sweet for my liking. I would of preferred it served with a regular vinaigrette or something. But i still ate it because of the good, not chewy, octopus.

The cioppino i got was probably the best dish i had all week in SF, with the HOPR's king Henry cut a close second. I had never heard of this dish before, and so have no other version to compare it to. But it was verging on perfect for me. The broth was saucy, but not too thick or thin. And packed with flavor. All of the seafood was very good, and the fish was not overcooked which can happen easily in seafood stews. The toasted bread that it came with was all used up soaking up the sauce. I was so full but happy when done with my bowl. 

Our waiter was one of those old school types, he didn't write anything down and was not afraid to voice his opinion on what he thought, which was refreshing. But i did bet my boss that he would get someone wrong on our order, and sure enough he did, although as soon as we pointed it out he was aware of it and took care of it right away. 

Very pleased with my whole experience here, and would go back again for sure. The prices seemed reasonable for good quality seafood
author: Andy C.

description: I walked in at 6pm on Friday night and I was seated immediately.  Apparently we arrived just before the rush because there were 2 other tables available.  I have the Ciopinno which was AWESOME! My friend ordered a curry dish which I tried and would NOT recommend.  The crab cakes are 'muy delicioso'.  I will make a point to come here whenever I visit again :-)
author: Latisha R.

description: What can you say about Taddich Grill? It's a no frills old school restaurant. It lays claim to being the oldest restaurant in California. Gentlemen waiters in white coats, dark wood and brass decor, stiff martinis and solid food. The male waiters are serious but funny, attentive but not overbearing, and packed with knowledge that you would normally expect from someone working in a restaurant like this. This place isn't going to awe you with it's trendy ambiance. It's always packed with tourists and regulars alike. I love this place for the Cioppino. A poor man fisherman's stew filled with crab, fish, mussels, clams, and shrimp in a tasty broth. This is one of my father's favorite places to dine at in the city, just because of the Cioppino. I have been here on countless occasions. Most recently, I took a friend visiting from NY and I had to take them to experience the Cioppino. The quality is always solid. Unfortunately this last visit the cioppino was slightly over-salted but having been here so many times before I knew it wasn't the norm. Solid food and a must experience while in SF.
author: Anthony V.

description:
This is definitely an old San Francisco classic.  The decor is dark wood with heavy curtain material.  If SF still allowed smoking you could just imagine this place filled with cigar smoke.  Definitely an old school place with that old boy feel.  

Warning, the portions are huge, so think about sharing if you're not famished.  My friend and I had the fried calamari to start, and it was not just the rings, but all parts of the squid.  The calamari was lightly battered and fried, very crispy and not oily.  It is probably some of the best calamari in the City.  

For the main course, I had the cioppino.  I usually do not like cioppino because it tastes fishy, but the seafood in this cioppino was fresh and there was nothing fishy tasting about this dish.  The tomato broth was just the right consistency and flavor, and the seafood was to die for (crab, shrimp, fish, clams, etc.).  There was more than enough to share and take home.   

My friend had the seared scallops.  While I do not usually order scallops because they are usually overcooked and chewy, these scallops were done to perfection.  They were flaky and buttery and just melted in your mouth.  For anyone that loves scallops, these should not be missed.

Tadich is a SF landmark and should not be missed.  Though you need to be ready to wait as this place is often very crowded.
author: Deborah H.

description:
no reservations, so you could be waiting up to an hour at popular weekend times.
old school -- no female waitresses!
i do however, feel the cioppino is worth it.  even edges out sotto mare, which i already love.
the difference here is in the broth.  the heartiness and complexity is fully satisfying.  the seafood is a bit less (total amount) when compared to sotto mare but the work is done for you.  the garlic butter bread slice is heavily soaked and crisp, thus very tasty.  jumbo shrimp and scallops, lots of crab,  clams, everything is very fresh.
thinner broth and less tomato-y compared to sotto mare, which also happens to serve you more seafood (crack your own crab style)
also shared the sand dabs, but here i feel sotto mare is better on the seasoning.  be careful of the little bones.
some of the crab specials had run out, so we also tried the Turbot Stuffed with Crab and Bay Shrimp a la Newburg, casserole style, rice inside, creamy, now this dish was certainly tasty and no skimping.
also had the fried calamari app, and crab louie salad.  lots of classics.
author: Rob C.

description: Color me impressed.  Somewhat reminiscent of the Oyster Bar in Grand Central Station yet truly San Francisco (and predating the Oyster Bar by 50 or so years). We sat at the bar and got top notch service. I had a nice martini, a bowl of Boston clam chowder and the Pacific Pair (Mahi Mahi AND Wild King Salmon) with rice and broccoli.  My friend ordered the Cioppino and while it was a little salty for her, she still liked it a lot.   We'll be back.
author: Matt K.

description: Tadich Grill is classic and classy.  It has dependably great food, service, and ambiance.  Everyone should eat here at least once.  It's worth the wait.
author: Iris J.

description: One of my all time favorite restaurants.  I always get the Cioppino.  Great   For single diners also - just sit at the counter
author: Kenneth B.

description: After reading the many positive reviews here, I thought I MUST HAVE the wrong Tadich. There must be ANOTHER "oldest restaurant in S.F.", one that WASN'T a nightmare experience. Then, I see the comments on service such as "obnoxious and a-holish"...."sarcastic"...and, sure enough--I was in the same poor excuse for a restaurant. The wait staff apparently have the same deal as school teachers with tenure--once they stay past old age, you just can't get rid of them no matter what they do. Really, from the moment we entered, we got shabby treatment. No one acknowledged us. The bar staff did not know their products. (How is that possible when they've been there since Moses floated down the Nile?) The singular friendly person there, a man, offered us a taste of the Bloody Mary Mix--their signature drink. It was the same as any generic V-8-like mix. Signature drink???  When, we were lead to our table, I mistakenly thought we were going to sit at the first empty table I saw. The waiter leading us said, harshly, "Not that one!" Then, as we had been waiting a while and already decided what to order, we told him that we were ready to order. To which he responded, "I'm not your waiter." Um, ok, well, then let the waiter know. Normal, right? Our "real" waiter was less than friendly. It seems like they don't fully grasp the concept of working for tips. I asked for recommendations for something vegetarian. I know, I know, this is a surf and turf place, but even such places have veggie options, usually made up of delicious side dishes, etc. Nothing like that here. The ONE option was a plate of steamed "rabbit food": random veggies which waiter told me were not seasoned, just plain, served with boiled potatoes. UGH. What is this, Ireland? I asked if I could get a couple of side dishes in a half order. NO. Seemed everything was a "no", not even willing to ask the kitchen. They were so unaccomodating. Our food--TOTALLY MEDIOCRE AND WAY OVER-PRICED. They charged $18 for what was basically a small bowl of Rice-a-Roni with mushrooms on top. Regular, button mushrooms--you know, the cheap ones--not anything exotic i.e. expensive. My friend got Chilean bass and said it was good. But, she, too, was put off by the horrid service. Then, for the FINALE, a second waiter (why?) came by to ask if we wanted dessert. We said that we did. He then left and came back with our check! Huh. We just sat there, dumbfounded. TOTALLY CLUELESS as to why this establishment is so popular. It, in a word, sucks.
author: Sadie J.

description:
Cioppino, Cioppino, Cioppino!!!!!

This place is my favorite and I am long overdue to write a review

I love the fresh Alaskan halibut steaks as well when they available.    

Service is always good.   I like sitting at bar when there is just two of us.   Bread is awesome.  

This is a must do on my frequent trips to the Bay Area
author: Dan T.

description: I watched a segment on one of the cooking shows which had Emeril visiting here and being served the Hangtown Fry. Being as my family and I were in town for Memorial weekend, decided to pay a visit, also in part due my fellow Yelpies reviews. MISTAKE!!!  I would have given a one star rating, but I gave it two as the maitre'd and the bartender helped boost the rating. The wife had scallops, B+, son had lamb chops, B+, daughter ordered the New York steak med rare, D+, came med well and tasteless, and I had the same as Emeril L. had .... Hang town Fry. A frittata of bacon and oysters. I give it a D-! It was nothing like what the TV show had. I could have done better at home. I got back home last night, and this morning I got the ingredients and actually 'pleasured myself'. The appetizer Tadich platter came without the crab legs and oysters. When we asked for them it was only said that they were coming. They never did. Finally the waiter...at one point you have to stop keeping them as an institution. I am beginning to wonder if he was Mr. Tadich? He acted like he was. The only other place I have seen this attitude was at Gallagher's in NYC. The ' I don't really have to be here' attitude. Knock this place off your list, you'll do yourself a favor.
author: Ifti K.

description: I wanted to like them because we were seated after 45 mins (which wasn't too bad because we were comfortable at the bar enjoying our drinks) and going by the long lines it had seemed that it might take longer. I wanted to like them because locals waiting in the line for food can't all be wrong, because people were celebrating anniversaries and birthdays and maybe because Bourdain liked them. I had the Cioppino and my wife got the pan-fried sand dabs. The Cioppino broth was excellent, the fish wasn't the best (as they claim) and the garlic bread was very ordinary. The thick cut fries that came with my wife's dish were stone cold and she sent them back. She had also asked for the fish to be boned but she found more than a couple of bones later on.  I have been thinking maybe it wasn't the right place for us (like perhaps being too old school for us) but then indifferent service, hurried food and middle-of-the-road quality seafood for a dish that cost more than $30 is just not right.  I really wanted to like them.
author: Amit B.

description: I happened to be in the Financial District on 1/14 to take the GRE. After I finished the test about 2:30pm I was walking along trying to find a cab when I ran across this place. I think I got very lucky from what the other reviewers report. The restaurant was almost empty. I was seated at the bar, my server was incredibly attentive and we had fun chatting. I had a glass of Pinot Grigio on the recommendation of my server and I enjoyed it quite a lot. I ordered oysters on the half shell to start, the seafood saute (prawns, scallops and BIG pieces of crab leg meat with a white whine/garlic/butter sauce) and bread pudding for dessert. I dearly wish I had caught my server's name so I could recommend him to everyone. The prices are a little high... I was eating alone and spent about $70 before tip. However, I figured after melting my brain for a couple of hours I was entitled. :) I gave then 4 stars mostly because it's so pricey. I know, it's in the financial district but the prices make it hard to afford to eat there very often. The food is good enough I'd drive in from Fremont to eat there regularly.. IF I could afford it lol. Overall, I was incredibly pleased.
author: Kris S.

description:
For better and for worse, Tadich's is an old school restaurant.  It survives and thrives because the better far outweighs the worse.

The food is centered on top quality, very fresh seafood.  The preparations range from simple (mesquite grilled swordfish) to more complex classics (lobster and crab thermidor) with very little evidence of any influence of the culinary trends of the last 3 or 4 decades.  I am surpised that some people find it "pricey"; given the quantity and quality of the seafood, the prices are reasonable (though not cheap).

The service is formal and efficient without any of the casual chit chat or fawning that many have grown accustomed to.

The decor is classic art-deco that does not need to be updated because it is timeless (though here and there a little bit of paint would be helpful).

The drinks are made by bartenders who know their stuff.  The wine list, unfortunately, is prepared by someone who knows a distributor and not much else.

If you want to enjoy a bit of classic San Francisco (I saw the Twins there at my last visit) this is one of the few remaining places.  if you want a hip atmosphere, bubbly waitstaff and cutting edge cuisine, go to Perbacco next door.
author: Peter H.

description: After a disappointing and expensive "snack" at Scoma's in Sausalito we came here for dinner. For only about $20 more we had delicious clam chowder, dungeness crab cocktail, corned beef hash, snapper with more dungeness crab (I can't get enough!) and drinks. Everything was delish!!! I know this place is known for seafood but my dining companion loved his corned beef hash so much so that he couldn't help but describe it with a string of expletives! Luckily our waiter was amused and agreed. I can't wait to be able to come back here again.
author: Fawn P.

description:
Great ambience, waiters are dead, but they  just don't know it yet. Food..well, it's food and I didn't get sick, but when you think the potato salad is some kind of sauce, it's time to try Acqua. 
I've seen it not change for years. I like fish. I like white table cloths, but my father would have loved the place. There's better to be had in this city.
author: Otto S.

description: I like coming here for lunch - the long lunch counter, the white-jacketed waiters, the wood paneled walls, and all the businessmen having lunch - I feel like I'm in a place my grandfather would have frequented.  It's pretty pricey, but the food is good.  The menu is continental, and a little old fashioned, but the old standbys are good.  Portions are large; I had a bowl of delectable clam chowder and the broiled salmon plate, and it was too much for me to finish.
author: Asteridae A.

description: This place has "Old School" charm and great food. I love the Choppino. I just wished they would serve fresh baked warm bread instead of the dry crusty stuff in the beginning. I overall liked this place. The servers and bartenders all wear the white Dr's smock...it's like going into a time capsule! Love it!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Yes, I did give Tadich a big rating.  I live in texas far from the ocean, the doorman at our hotel sent us here when I asked for seafood where the locals eat.  The cioppino stew was to die for!  It was gigantic, I really tried to eat it all because I don't know when I'll be in SF again.  It was full of fresh seafood with a little hint of spiciness.  Yum!  I also had a big bowl of garlic butter clams and ate all of those too.  My beau is not the seafood adventurer type so he ordered the bolognese.  This is not the place for that. It tasted like the sauce in Chef Boyardee ravioli.  
the ambience was fine. Loud, crowded, and dark wood.  But we got in without a problem.  Not the best table, I hate 2 tops, and chairs that you cannot hang your purse on.  Purse hooks under the table are a good thing.  Service was great, and they have bubbly by the glass.  I left my heart in SF.
Was back in SF in June and visited the Tadich for lunch.  Unfortunately, the cioppino was nowhere near as good as it was before and it seemed much smaller for the same price. Maybe dinner the cooks are better?
author: Leslee V.

description: The ultimate business lunch place in San Francisco.  If you need to ask why, you don't need to be there.
author: Michael L.

description: Interestingly, SF Magazine doesn't 'star' this San Francisco institution; it's 'unrated' and I suppose that's the way a 'legend' should be treated. If you've never been; it's worth trying. The turn of the century decor and charm is worthy of a meal; but the lines, 'brisk' service, difficulty getting a table at lunch, 'ok' food at surprisingly high prices might cause you to rethink a return. Stews and seafood platters are hearty but hardly 'fine dining'. Aqua is next door and costs the same...I think the choice is obvious.
author: John B.

description:
Try to go here each time I visit San Francisco.

The food is fresh and flavorful and I love the rustic feel of the place.  Try the pan fried trout...awesome!

Some words of caution:

1.  They DO NOT take American Express...don't even try.
2.  It can get really busy in the evenings and they do walk in only, no reservations.
author: Tom T.

description: Tadich Grill is located in the Financial District on California Street and is one of the oldest established restaurants in the city.  The interior is finished with classic wood complete with tile floors that has to be decades old.  They don't take reservations and until a few years ago only took cash.  It can get crowded at lunch time and if you get there late, you will wait a while to be seated.  I'm usually there by 11:30 a.m. and get seated right away.  Tadich is known for it's Cioppino as well as other seafood (sand dabs) and is to die for.  They have tons of other entrées on the menu and a large selection of seafood salads.  The prices are a little on the high side, but the portions are huge and the quality is always the best.  The service is usually quick and the guys are always friendly.  They have a full bar as well, so if your in need for a good stiff cocktail over lunch, this s the place.
author: Chris F.

description:
if you want some heavy, but super-satisfying seafood, Tadich Grill is your spot!  it seems like no matter how little food i order or how light the food is supposed to be, i leave Tadich Grill feeling like a frickin beluga whale!!  

seriously, i've eaten here twice in the past two months and each time i leave completely stuffed.  both times i've had the clam chowder (i prefer the white to the red) and the seafood cioppino.  i am a HUGE fan of the cioppino, it comes with a ton of seafood; shrimp, white fish, clams, etc. and two slices of heavenly garlic bread that bed to be dipped in the tomoto sauce/soup base.  wash it all down with a Stella and you are good to go!!  

i don't normally smoke cigarettes, but i remember being so full after the first time i ate here, that i stumbled outside and bummed a cig off a guy smoking outside of Aqua.   it was do or die, seriously.  

i just ate here tonight and although i loved it, i don't want to come back for a minimum of TWO MONTHS.... ugh...... still tho.. 4 stars.  love this place, just can't come too often.
author: Scott K.

description: Great old fashioned San Francisco restaurant for seafood and a great time. They have booths or tables to dine at, yet no reservations :-(. They have a great bar wich you can sip a cocktail as you wait for your table. I have never had to wait long to be seated. I personally love the ciopinno. Great place to take guests and friends.
author: Amy H.

description: No reservations. Great San Francisco restaurant. Everytime we go there we have meal here. Service is great and so is the food.
author: Colin B.

description: I have been going to Tadich for over 50 years.  The food is good.  The ambiance is great.  The martinis are superlative.  Tadich does not take reservations.  The wait (30+ minutes) has always been one of my favorite features of Tadich.  If you want fast food, go somewhere else.  If you don't like people you should probably go somewhere else.  I really enjoy having a huge martini while waiting to be seated.  I stick with standards and my favorite is the halibut.  Never go with a large group, they don't want to see large groups, they dread large groups, especially groups of young people.  This is a traditional place.
author: Tom R.

description:
Tadich is my third favorite restaurant in the city for a number of reasons.

#1-  I am not a big fan of seafood, nor fish in general.  Sushi?  Absolutely.  Cooked fish? Not so much.  I went here one day with my GM to discuss some new hires we were thinking of bringing on, and wow...  I haven't ever had swordfish like that before in my life.  Everything was fresh, well-portioned, and had very simple flavors.  I hate nothing more than when 15 different flavors are present on one place.  They keep the food simple, well-seasoned, and executed extremely well.

#2-  The decor is simple.  I also hate restaurants that go out of their way to create an over-the-top theme.  Keep it simple, keep it about the food, and you keep me happy.  Nothing but a long counter, wooden floors, and white napkins here.  

#3-  My only negative- the service is somewhat unique here.  While the men & women in white lab coats aren't exactly attentive, they do bring a certain "old San Francisco" charm to the establishment, and I can't dock them any stars for that. 

Tadich is a San Francisco institution, and I would argue everyone should experience this place at least once in their lives.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Jason B.

description: Haven't been here in many years, but remember it fondly. I went the other evening (on a weeknight, and early-ish), having persuaded my husband & son that the wait wouldn't be too bad & the food well worth any wait. Alas, we were all disheartened by the experience. We had to wait for nearly an hour, pressed standing against the wall behind the bar, with people passing to & fro constantly, people at the bar in front of us sitting with young babies on their laps, drinks being passed to us standees over the heads of those seated in front of us, shouts from the headwaiter at the front of the room,summoning people whose table was ready---it was bedlam, boring, tiring, noisy. Somehow the barkeep managed to keep his cool & remain pleasant despite lots of very boorish customers, & the same goes for our waiter when we were finally seated. However, my calamari salad was overloaded with non-calamari items, the steaks ordered by my co-diners were on the tough side, and although my whole sea bass was good, it was underseasoned and bland. Everyone's french fries were soggy. The wine & the bread were good, but---this was by no means the kind of meal that was worth the wait, the price, and the high reputation. I guess Tadich is the victim of its own success, and people will keep coming no matter what the food is like, just to say they've been there, or out of habit. SF has so many wonderful restaurants, it's a shame that tourists will go here & miss out on better fare.
author: Helen P.

description: The Tadich Grill is an SF institution that has never failed to deliver awesome old-school seafood dishes such as Lobster Thermador, Seafood Saute, Calamari steak and the like. This is a no frills place so don't expect a port wine reduction sauce or a fancy drizzle of sauce around the plate. What you will get however, is large, fresh seafood with lots o' butter or cream or marinara just as they served back in the day. I visited the Tadich for the 5th time this past weekend and it was an hour and half wait. I also noticed the prices have increased significantly :( but the food won't disappoint. As the other Yelpers indicate, be ready with ALL your guests when your table is called or promptly go find another restaurant to eat at. This place is busy, really busy so the hosts don't have time to wait and hold table until your Uncle Pete arrives from out of town. Have a seat at the bar, order up a Martini or Old Fashion and take in the ambience of old San Francisco. The wait is worth it...
author: Jill M.

description: Best seafood I've had in a long time.  Great service and very enjoyable atmosphere.
author: Chris B.

description: I love this place!  I've been eating here for years and years and the food is always wonderful and I enjoy the old world atmosphere.  One of the few restaurants in San Fran that has been around forever, literally,  but still has the same excellent food and service.   My Dad worked a few blocks away so we had lunch here many times.  I  have great memories of eating there with dad back in the day.  If it is crowded the bar is a great place to grab a quick meal if there is space.  The fresh crab, and clam chowder is reason enough to eat here but their fresh fish entrees are excellent also.  I think over the last 30+ years every time I have eaten here it seems exactly the same.   My favorite seafood place in San Francisco!  Consistent, consistent, consistent!
author: debbie l.

description: Went for an early dinner on a Saturday night. Did not have reservations but they were able to seat us (party of 2) right away at the counter (most of the seating is diner style). Our drinks came about 10 minutes later in what had to be 4 ounce glasses. For $8 a piece, quite the robbery to begin with.  Waiter then began crossing out numerous meals from the paper menus, telling us what they were out of (please keep in mind it was before 6:30 on a Saturday night. All told he crossed off about 7 items leaving me with what looked like a used bingo card). Ordered a cesaer salad to start with which was unfortunately the best part of the meal. My wife ordered the lobster themadore which looked a lot better than it tasted. She had three bites before calling mercy. Hardly the quality of seaford we have grown accustomed to in New England.  I ordered the chicken parm style dish however was informed by Pascal "I already told you we're out of it. Why would you order something we dont have. Do you think we keep some aside especially for you?" I proceeded to show him his Picasso impersonation for a menu which had the chicken not crossed off. He ended up saying it wasnt his fault, they were new menus and they had moved some of the items. Fine, lets move on but an apology would have been nice. Ended up ordering the veal cutlet which was the dryest piece of gristle ever passed off as veal.  Got a $3 cup of coffee to top off the evening. All told, $81 for two inedible meals, a decent $10 salad, two mini cocktails and a cup of coffee. I have to believe this place purely gets by on tourists who want to be able to say they went to the oldest restaurant in San Fran.  I think the veal i had was from their grand opening.
author: Matt R.

description:
UPDATE: Umm, yeah... a true SF classic.  Why?  Tons of personality and drinks & dishes that don't disappoint.  Superb dirties, clever 'tenders, nice wine list, the Oyster Rockefeller are sinfully good, can NOT go wrong with the cioppino, and the seafood scampi was superb!  It feels good to always leave with a smile on your face! 

I think Tadich Grill is the best historic spot south of Coit Tower!  Quaint & old school with a great diner kinda feel, I had a fabulous meal there.  Our server Clifton was so witty and entertaining!  Dressed all cute in his little white outfit with a huge smile, he helped make our dining experience exceptional... even though it didn't need it because the food sold itself!  I was so impressed by the sizes of the plates I saw going by and everything looked great, from the fish to the flanks.  Clifton served us a tall stiff drink to start, very classic SF, and we each got a big hunk of sourdough.  I had been craving cioppino since the Gold Spike closed and I figured this was as good a place as any to give it a try considering they're renown for their seafood.  The bf tried ordering the Hawaiian Ono and the Ahi but they were all out at 9pm so he settled on the sea bass.  We both wanted a glass of sav blanc to compliment but Clifton insisted we try the small bottle for two of the Fume Blanc, which was a great recommendation.  He also handed over a bib for the cioppino, which I thought was hilarious until I actually got my dish.  Talk about a mound'o'seafood!  There was more meat in that thing than broth!  And I was thrilled : )  It made the Gold Spike's look like tomato soup.  The sea bass was ok... but it was great after I lathered some of that homemade tarter on there.  Good greens and thick potato fries to go with.  But I doubt anything on the menu could hold a candle to that mouthwatering, tummy-filling cioppino... best ever!
author: Tara G.

description: Simple, great, old-school seafood restaurant.  The same professional waiters have been here in the dozen or so years that I've eaten here -- or at least it seems so.  My favorites are the crab cocktail and the seafood stew -- and I'm allergic to shrimp (not the epi pin kind of allergic, much more mild), but I still have the stew.  YUM!
author: Patty W.

description: really great experience anytime one is in sfo....very old world, great selection of food, the dungeness crab was fresh and just in season...great staff and service...when ultra modern is getting old, try tadich grill, it is refreshing.  it reminds me and feels like my hometown jakes bar and grill back in pdx somehow, which is a nice feeling
author: Jason Michael B.

description: Pricey yes, if your young - customer service treats you that way (im 22). I normally bring a guest and leave with a 60-80 dollar bill. The pasta (raveolles' or whatever) are amazing and kinda cheap... if you go for steak its about 20 bucks a plate... and the garlic bread is to die for...
author: David C.

description: We ate here one evening while spending a wonderful weekend in San Francisco. I had the best Cioppino I have ever eaten !!! Every spoonful was filled with crabmeat, shrimp, delicious tomato broth and the bowl was huge ! This IS the place to go for Cioppino in the city. We are ready to return with friends next time so we can request a booth. Very charming place. We loved it.
author: Catherine D.

description: I love this old Croatian restaurant and the grouchy old Croatian men working in it. Reminds me of my family. The food is comforting and very tasty. Go for lunch on a cold foggy day and get a bowl of clam chowder. Fill your belly with warm goodness.
author: Courtney R.

description: A definite old reliable in downtown SF/Financial District.  This place has it all, steaks, chops, fresh fish and seafood.  And keeps it simple, to the point.  Always the buzz around lunch, and just as busy and line wait after work.  Kind of place you wanna grab a nice side car, while waiting for your medium ribeye or Hangtown Fry (oyster and bacon omelet - OH MY!) to be served.  Staff, on point, takes your order, gets your food, gets you out, NEXT!  Not exactly the type of place to spend a romantic dinner, though my husband and I have found this to be one of our faves in the City.  But it did get us out on time for both of us to head back to the office.  Tip, try getting there no later than 11:30 to beat the crowd...
author: Jennifer V.

description: Get your butt to Tadich order the ciopinno and what you don't finish take home and put it under your pillow. If you don't like martinis order a gin martini from hear and you will ask your friends to call you Bond, James Bond. Straight up with olives. My mouth is watering for a martini now just writing this review.
author: Clint B.

description: I adore this historic SF restaurant. It has the most delicious sourdough bread. I had grown rather tired of sd bread until I bit into their crisp, sweet manna. The food is greasy and seafoody and perfect. Sit at the bar and maybe you'll see the SF twins.
author: Nicki R.

description: Love this place. My first time though my family has been coming to Tadich since the 60s. The atmosphere at lunch was busy and noisy..in a good way. Lots of activity and lots of people enjoying themselves or deep in conversation. The food was outstanding. The staff was old school in their pressed white coats. Our waiter was efficient but not impatient. If visiting from out of town, forget the touristy restaurants at the Wharf. You won't have a water view, but you will have a excellent meal.
author: josh k.

description: Eating at Tadich Grill is like having a meal with the Sopranos.  Waiters are old school with bow tie in full effect.  For those who are faint hearted you might be easily scared off as it feels like you're about to dine with the mob but once you get used to the atmosphere, you'll find that the waiters are pretty awesome and you'll end up having a grand time.  There's no reservations so if there's a line for a seat, grab yourself a spot at the bar, chat with the bartender and enjoy a beer or two.  I love the Ciopinno here as it is deliciously prepared and large enough to share between 2 people.  The crabcakes are also really good.
author: Cathy L.

description: This place doesn't take reservations and every time I've walked by, it's been packed so I hadn't ventured to even go through the door.  We showed up early yesterday (before noon) for lunch and didn't have to wait for a table.  It has an old-time, guy's restaurant kind of feel.  I think all of the waiters were men (which is pretty rare).  I had the crabcakes, which were yummy.  They came with rice and vegetables.  You'd never guess what the vegetables were that day though....brussel sprouts!  I am not a big brussel sprout fan.  But that being said, they weren't bad.  I still left two out of six of them on my plate at the end of the meal though...
author: Kris L.

description: I had the Cioppino here for an early 11:30 am lunch during a recent trek to up north and now I felt that I had the real thing in terms of that classic San Francisco dish.  It was good but there was a lot of it. My wife and I actually split the dish and yet we both felt like we overdosed on food and weren't hungry even when dinner time rolled around.  Despite Mark Twain's famous quote, too much of something can be more than enough rather than just enough.
author: Robert M.

description: Ok, this place was AMAZING.   Went on a Saturday night when I was in town visiting a friend.   The place was packed, lots of regulars.  Everyone knew everyone else's name.  The bartenders and waiters were all happy and positive and friendly.   You  have to wait a long while to get in, but they make it interesting.  Once you're in, you're treated like gold.   The waiters are all old school and know how to do classy service.  The food was exceptional (especially the cioppino and the bread pudding).   I would recommend this place to anyone, anytime, anywhere and i'm definitely going back.
author: Tom M.

description: Absolutely the WORST CUSTOMER SERVICE I have ever experienced in my 30+ years of business dining experiences around the world.  My customer (guest) and I  were so offended that we chose to exit  TADICH GRILL and will never return.  We arrived at 11am for lunch.  The doors were opened at 11:05AM and the woman behind the cash register was so UNBELIEVEABLY RUDE to us when we asked a question about being seated.  She immediately called over a waiter as backup and he continued to belittle us for asking about seating.  Both my business guest and i looked at each other in shock, and decided to exit and NEVER RETURN.   Everyone has choices on where to spend their money and no one should be treated poorly by an employee at any establishment.   We chose to dine next door at Barbacco's and had both a fantastic meal and exceptional customer service.  I would think twice before subjecting yourself to paying top dollar for fish at Tadich and then being verbally abused by a Tadich Grill hostess and waiter.  Go to BARBACCO's next door.  MUCH BETTER FOOD AND CUSTOMER SERVICE AT BARBACCO'S RESTAURANT NEXT DOOR.
author: Tyler H.

description: Walked 25 blocks in the cold to try the Cioppino and to soak in the history. 8 of us were shoved into a space for four.  The prices were a premium - the waiters seemed like Longshoremen or Union Thugs that were doing us a favor by waiting on us. The bread was good too. I wouldn't go back but it was fun to go.
author: Glenn B.

description: how fitting for my 100th yelp review! the oldest restaurant west of the Mississippi. classic seafood and grilled meats served by guys in white jackets. can't go wrong with the clam chowder! awesome. menu changes daily and depends partly on what fresh fish is available. i had a trio of local halibut, sturgeon, and swordfish. grilled to perfection. highly recommended!
author: Jeff W.

description: Today was my first experience at Tadich, and must say I was pleasantly surprised. The ambiance of this place definitely takes one back to the old school, and they even have private little booth area's for groups of 4. Our waiter was awesome, and truly knew this eatery inside and out. I had the Monday special of Boiled Beef Brisket which did not disappoint. The cioppino that my colleague had was also very good. As we work on the same block at Tadich, we will definitely be around more. There are no reservations at Tadich, however, we went at 1pm and were seated right away.
author: C R.

description: I wanted to try this place because I have been hearing that this place is historical. Lots of menu choices: steaks and seafood. The heavy, dark wood decor along with the waiters are what make this place an institution.  The seafood is great too. The line can be long unless you opt to sit at the counter.
author: Trish P.

description: Went up to the City to see my old boss, and he brought me here for lunch.  We were seated fairly quickly, considering how busy it was, and my lunch was very good (pan-fried trout).  It has a very old-fashioned feel, great bar (*I* didn't have to go back to work!), which made it a fun place to have lunch with a friend.
author: J T.

description: Great scene in this historic place---wait staff in white jackets, lively people watching , and good food. Tadich oozes with character---sit at the bar/counter for the complete experience. I will make it a regular stop on any future trip to San Fran.
author: Ann E.

description: a standard! for an old-school San Francisco dining experience. Great seafood. Huge variety. Good beer on tap.  Good first date place if she's kinda conservative. lol  definitely not new school hip...  it's been around since 1849. Long bar to dine at.. cool old booths for private dinners... everything reminds you of back in the day.
author: Steven G.

description: A san francisco treat. The fish is fresh and tasty with very little flash. Go here for lunch. Dont go here for dinner on the weekend as it gets way too packed with las touristas!
author: Not M.

description:
My friends and I decided at the last minute on a Friday to try the Tadich.
We found parking pretty quickly which was a miracle but I think it had a lot to do with the timing, when people were leaving work but those arriving for the weekend weren't there yet.  When we got there it was pretty full, but we got our names on the list before a huge crowd was waiting.  It pays to get there early.  We got a "booth".  I wish more places had enclosed dining.  That adds so much to your sense of being able to talk with your companions. We all ordered drinks at the Bar.  The Bar Tenders don't have time to be chatty, its like running an Airline at that long bar. The food is very good, and I think reasonably priced considering the quality.  
The reason it gets 4 stars and not 5 is because they are so popular and so busy and so crowded that you almost feel rushed.  They really need to get you served, fed and the heck out of there because there's a line out the door.  So as long as you want an experience that says you've seen an icon of San Francisco, then this place is fine, if you want a really relaxing evening, maybe not a great idea.
author: Sarah H.

description: The best old-world dining experience in SF. The place somehow  blends gobs of nostalgia and tradition with a very fun, hip vibe. Cioppino and a martini.....heaven.  :)
author: Regina C.

description: My semi-annual trips into San Francisco aren't complete until I've had the Chapino at the Tadich Grill.  To sit at the bar with a good cold beer, the Chapino & Sour Dough bread for about $35.00 is a GREAT bargain. I've never been disappointed, if you hit it right, there's no waiting, just move in and get the job done.
author: E Paul L.

description:
I've been coming to Tadich since 1970 , at that time I was working in downtown San Francisco , Tadich has been famous for the seafood , always fresh and well prepared , good service and the great old time San Francisco atmosphere .
I've seen the restaurant come down hill over the last year , particularily since the fire that took out the charcoal broiler .The wine selection has gone downhill while the prices have gone up .
Maybe things will improve once they get the broiler back up and in operation .
author: Daniel M.

description:
If you're looking for the best cooked fish this is the place. 

Service is not their stronger area.
author: DM C.

description:
We're from out of town and thought dining at the Tadich Grill would be a great experience.  Wrong!  Even though they weren't that busy, we were made to feel as though they were doing us a favor by having our patronage.  Our waiter was incredibly arrogant and rude, speaking down to us as if we knew nothing.  When we asked if there was a child's menu, we had a 2 year old with us, he couldn't even be bothered to speak, but rudely pointed to the adult menu, as if to imply we couldn't read!
      The food was fine, but the ambience and dining experience ruined any efforts of the chef.   We'll never go back and will make sure that any of our friends who visit San Francisco hear about the pompous attitude of this restaurant.
author: virginia s.

description: Highly recommended for lunch, especially if you also get a drink.  Seafood is fantastic.  Be sure to get there early or late to avoid the rush, otherwise you'll sit at the bar.
author: Sean J.

description:
Tadich is my go to spot when I'm at my SF office and just want to eat well by myself without having to make reservations at any of the FiDi spots that require them for lunch. Tadich does not take reservations and that policy has actually saved me in a town where you often have to make your reservation prior to 10pm for lunch and prior to 4pm for dinner.

The food is solid and borders fine dining. The china says, "The original cold day restaurant" and I couldn't agree more after having either the cioppino or any of the dishes "en casserole" such as the lobster and crab thermidor. The sea bass is great, be careful of the bones in the branzino... I prefer the chilean. There is something special about a place that serves fries with broiled lobster, it's a move that is grandfather and uncle approved... especially when washed down with a Molsen. Remember that long lost beer from Canada? It's on tap. But wait... rewind to a Basil Hayden's manhattan first. When the chron did a story on the manhattan Tadich was the benchmark. Text book classic cocktails.

I am fully guitly of bs'ing with a few of the staff here, it's a regulars kind of thing to do. The place definitely has a sense of male ego running through it and has that old school SF bankers history but every single girl I have ever taken here feels a bit of charm.
author: Don B.

description: Cool, old SF atmosphere, with waiters to match.  I've had better oysters, but the cioppino looks amazing and it's worth it just to sit at the bar, chomp on some fresh sourdough, and chat with the servers.
author: Danielle B.

description: So...I'm slightly confused..the brash attitude the guys that work there...do they do that on purpose kinda like it adds to the old world charm of the place?  I like the food here, it's your basic seafood fare, nothing too fancy just good ole seafood! but I've had a couple of my scariest dining experiences here...I felt like if I didn't tell my server I liked the food he'd start yelling at me or lecturing me or something.
author: Tanger T.

description:
chowda! chowda! chowda!

as we beat the table with our spoons in one hand, placating our hunger with fresh sourdough from the other... chowda is served after a short wait. would have eaten with my fingers if not for the spoon. must remember to breathe; don't want to be the first to drown from a bowl of chowda.

staff doesn't put up with much in this sf monument. no reservations either. get there early for lunch, like 10am to ensure getting in.

'mmm...'mmm... good!
author: Marcus W.

description: I like the atmosphere, the traditional charm, the superb food, the professional service. Sure there are times when you have to wait a lot but it is worth it.
author: A. M.

description: Surprisingly good food, but a very, very loud dining experience.  Couldnt complain about my casserole made of lump crab meat, jumbo prawns, shrooms, rice and cheese, served in a savory tomato-y sauce, and with veggies (mmmm, brussel sprouts).  The bourbon bread pudding dessert had a great bourbon sauce, but the bread pudding itself had a little too many raisins and apricots in it.   I would go back.
author: brewgirl b.

description: The only bad thing about this place is that they don't take reservations and will only seat you when all parties have arrived.  The mixed seafood salad, linguini with clams, and steak is a must try.  The sourdough is so fresh and so good.  Make sure you get their early if you don't want to wait.
author: Mary L.

description:
Tadich is old school.  

My first boss took me to Tadich to celebrate a promotion.  We sat at the bar, ordered our food, lingered a bit, joked with the bartender and left.  18 years later, I have the same routine and I always order the same dish --- the Dungeness Crab Legs.  I love them!!!  I attempted to order something else, twice, and was crushed.  Nothing can replace my Dungeness Crab Legs with the side of tender thick fries!!!!!

Tadich opens Saturday at 11:30am.  It is pretty quite on Saturday afternoons. Perfect for a lingering lunch after a day of shopping.
author: Camille W.

description: This is one of my regular favorite spots of SF.  It has an old world charm with waiters in white coats and have a high regard for their professionalism and the art of good service.  They have struck seating - where all your guest need to be present before being seated and they have a lock-out curfew so check their serving times. The salmon is delicious and the atmosphere makes me feel a little bit like I am in old world Europe. Love it!!
author: Jacinta P.

description:
meh is a very appropriate assessment of my experience.  crab louie was the best thing i had; and the crab meat was quite good. however the seafood bisque was horrible, my mesquite grilled fish was essentially flavorless and the waiter only recommended the most endangered/overfished options. 

service was extremely annoying as well:  the waiter was at first constantly badgering us for our order, then he forgot it and had to come back and ask again, then he only brought one bowl of soup when we ordered two and we waited at least 10+ minutes for the other (so the first got cold).  at check time, he placed the check on the table and literally hovered until we broke out our credit cards and figured out the bill *while he watched*  i had to say a few times WE'RE NOT READY YET, after another hot 30 seconds ticked by.  the food was overall very bland and unappealing, though the portions were enormous.  i would not return.
author: katy r.

description: ...the feel of an old school restaurant... :) excellent sea bass. Lobster, clam chowder (tomato based) and cioppino  were very good.  Come early, we had to wait for an hour and a half -they do not take reservations...
author: Vanessa V.

description: Great old-school food -- yet another place that is getting destoyed in the maw of the yups. The Crab Louis is really really great. This was the first restaurant I ever went to in SF, back when I was 10, so it made me sentimental for a time when I was a bit more innocent and less destructive.
author: Nathan J.

description: Pretty decent food and atmosphere, if you are going there as a party of 3 or more, you will want to get a table or booth on the "outskirts" as that will be more conducive to conversations.  Great Soup and Main course, a little on the loud side for holding business conversations.  Otherwise pretty good overall.
author: W M.

description: Good, but maybe a bit over-rated I would say... only been here for boozy late lunches (never dinner).  Food is good, but I think I've always ordered the wrong thing -- lobster termidor, which is too heavy for me -- and the servers are not friendly (come on people, crack a smile, i dare ya').  Bisque and crab cakes are really good though - and I like the secluded booths.  I think it's a good place to take out-of-towners for that "SF" dining experience.....
author: A B.

description: One of the stars is for the experience more than the food.  The food is okay, not spectacular, but the experience of Tadich is a must for any San Franciscan.  My 88 year old dad loves this place and insists on going whenever he visits.  No reservations, can be a long wait -- but it is almost more fun to sit at the counter anyway.
author: Robert M.

description: Very old school! I loved it......I have a thing for restaurants that serve items that are rarely seen on menus these days. This place quaitfies. A bit pricey, but worth it....
author: Tressi J.

description: love it love it love it.  Sooo San Francisco, the oldest restaurant in town. not a tourist trap. this is where you can come as you are or dress hot. Sit at the counter and BS with the wait staff. Very clean place too. the food, well it is simply fabu dahling. The best freah fish, soup, french bread. Hang out or rush thru your meal. they dont care. This is what SF dining is all about. Simply the best.
author: Donna S.

description: Solid, no-bullshit seafood - love it!! It has a very old-school feel, but there is definitely nothing "old" about the food. I had the crab and bay shrimp curry casserole - the casseroles are definitely amazing. If you want swoon-worthy service with your seafood, go to Aqua next door. If you want good, no frills seafood, come to Tadich Grill.
author: Adrienne C.

description: I cannot believe you people have not tried the garlic calimari steak.  Cut it with a fork.  Soooo good.
author: Kay D.

description: Minus the price, the food is excellent.  I have been here several times.  The last time I had lunch, I had their Calfornia Sea Bass and it was great.    Friendly staff and great service.  If you want a table for lunch, get there before 11:45 or you will have to wait.
author: SF A.

description: I've been here for lunch a couple of times. The place is very nicely decorated and feels genuine. Though it gets very loud, so don't expect quiet conversation. Everything I've ordered has been spectacular - and pricey. The loud atmosphere really takes away some of the experience. Maybe evenings are better.
author: Dennis G.

description: The wait that you'll have (they don't take reservations) will go down smooth with excellent, strong cocktails prepared by old-school bartenders.  The seafood is amazing, just make sure what you order is sustainable before oyu order! http://www.montereybayaquarium.com/cr/seafoodwatch.asp
author: Andrea M.

description: Great traditional service. let them know if you are Irish and they will sit you at the bar, no waiting. Speaking from experience. Very historical and an older crowd. The seafood soup is famous. Get their early to get a seat.
author: Sarah D.

description: Definitely a good place to go.... the seafood is awesome.. and the ambiance not bad.. the only problem here is that its layout.. the bar is long in a long room.. this makes seating confined.. it also makes for less seats.. therefore .. it is always crowded even at the bar.. the fact that you have to wait forever to sit here .. is one of the tradeoffs.. but when you finally get seated the experiences will be lovely.. both the service and food here are awesome..
author: Kaio T.

description: Gosh, what else to say that hasn't been said.  This place breathes San Francisco history!  From the white-jacketed waiters to the chipped tables to the fresh seafood, it's altogether the atmosphere of it all that makes this a stop for anyone visiting SF.  One of the best Maker's manhattan I've had and I was thoroughly impressed with the service.  The waiters are informative and attentive, not solicitous, and they leave you alone until you want something.  We had the rex sole and cioppino--both were good, but I don't think it would be the food that would bring me back, but just the totality of the experience.
author: Calvin L.

description: My dining companion and I both had the seafood cioppino. It was quite good. The service was especially for tourists... You know what I mean. We got a nice quiet table for two in about no time, and the server painfully explained what the "San Francisco specialties" were. And then he was gone in a flash and didn't return regularly.  I would return for another business lunch, but probably not for any other reason.
author: Sahra H.

description: Another old-school San Francisco restaurant (claims to be the first in the City, I think) that might as well be embalmed and stuffed and put in a museum somewhere, where it would better serve the public. The menu, like this establishment in general, is old and tried. Honestly, I have very little patience for the iconic eateries of San Francisco's past. Move on.if anything, come here for a beer and a plate of fries.
author: Andrew K.

description:
came here for my friend's bday dinner couple years back and we had a party of 9.  even tho we made reservations, they won't seat you until your entire party is present.  since we were running late, the rest of the party had to wait for us.  

i don't eat in the financial district much so i never knew of this place.  i probably just knew Aqua next door.  service was ok.  food was ok.  kinda noisy in there.  food was very average.  not very impressed.  i guess i won't be coming back here again unless someone has their bday dinner here again.
author: Kapo T.

description: This place is kinda an anomaly on this street, it is sandwiched between Aqua and Perbacco where everyone is so posh.  You go into Tadich and its totally old school.  Sat at the counter, because that seemed to be the most fun.  The waiters are all very seasoned, been there forever.  The dishes are those old school ones with the restaurant name on them!  They charge for refills on soda!  Anyway, I will say that this place had damn good clam chowder.  being from the east coast I am very particular, and they did an excellent job with lots of clams.  I had the dungeness crab in white wine and buttery sauce.  it was a good size portion and very good.  If you are looking for solid seafood this place is good and definitely a lot less maintenance than most other places around.
author: Jaime C.

description: Came here on date night with my husband and friends, thought because its supposed to be the oldest and one of the best restaurants in the city it'd be a nice place to enjoy....yea no! seafood was too fishy, bleh. SUPER pricey for the crap we got. Although the clam chowder was good.... but other than that...we won't be back.
author: Missi M.

description: The Tadich Grill was recommended to me by a coworker friend. He highly recommended it so I knew Daniel and I had to try it. They do not take resevervations and we were told that the wait could feel like an eternity.  We went around 8:30 and we only had a 5 minutes wait on a Saturday night.  You can feel the history when you walk in the door. The waiters were all men and dressed in old school uniforms. The service was good and we were treated well. I ordered the Crab and Lobster Thermidor, Potato Baked en Casserole and savored every last bite. The serving was generous so I took most of it home to eat later. It was very rich and fully of yummy goodness!! Highly recommend!
author: Tara P.

description: Sometimes you don't bother with the details and just say "that was really good' and leave it at that, and everybody nods along with a grin. If you're making a dining selection and Tadich is one of the choices, go and see for yourself. You'll see what they really mean when they say "happy ending."
author: Eric E.

description: What a great surprise! We frequent SF several times a year, and had heard abouth Tadich, but didnt have the opportunity to eat there until this past week. We sat at the bar and fully enjoyed the experience. The waiter has been there 15 years, and it was a pleasure to engage him in conversation. The food was excellent, my wife having the branzino and I the cioppino special...wow! A hearty recommendation!
author: gerald s.

description:
Went here late on a Friday night. Spontaneous decision to go. Had to sit at the bar a little bit while waiting for a table, but that was a given.

The first thing I notice is the old school ambiance. Like I was guest-starring in an episode of Mad Men or something. Bring on the martinis and oysters (unless stairs are to follow)! 

Ordered a cup of the shrimp bisque and the hangman fry (basically omelet of oysters and bacon with side of potatoes and sliced tomatoes). The bisque was memorably good and tasty, superior to some lobster bisques I've had recently. No table seasoning needed. I have thought about making another trip to get this bisque again. The hangman fry was a little more boring and bland. Maybe I should've accepted the ketchup the waiter offered because it needed some sort of binding agent. I ended up using some tabasco instead, but still, something was missing. And the sliced tomatoes seemed random, wasn't sure how I was supposed to combine them with the rest of the dish. 

Despite that, I would definitely be willing to go back.
author: Andrew C.

description: Good food.  Service is okay.  We had the Calamari which was good if you enjoy the taste of Calamari because they don't do much to it but cook it to perfection.
author: Daniel C.

description: My incredibly cute and sweet pumpkin butt took me to Tadich Grill for lunch the other week. I've never been, but have always wanted to try it. The place is CROWDED at lunch, we even had to wait a bit to get seats at the counter. The crowd is mostly suits and people above 40, the ambiance was fast-paced and noisy. Very old-San Francisco feel to it. We ordered rainbow trout and crab cakes. Both very hearty and tasty meals. Also a bit heavy for lunch due to the rich tarter sauces, & you can definitely count on walking out of there feeling FULL. Saw other people eating the shrimp louie salads and cocktails, also tasty looking. Would recommend it for family, out of towners who crave seafood, and business lunches.
author: Miss Lili F.

description: The Cioppino makes me happy, the sourdough can't be beat, and the crab bisque is the best money can buy. Need I say more? I almost 4-starred it for the wait factor. But isn't that a surefire indication of just how good it really is? I think yes.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Best place in SF for a Friday business lunch.  Fills-up quick and people stay put, so plan on a playing a little hookie.  Relax, spit a bottle of wine, and enjoy the fruits of a classic grill.
author: Bob F.

description: A restaurant with mediocre& bad food that relies on his historical status and its location. Too bad because I love seafood and this place is cute.
author: Marina N.

description: We've been going here for generations, and I can't say I have ever had a bad meal. I'm a BIG fan of the cioppino, and the fish is awesome. Be ready to eat alot, and don't expect hand holding from the waiters. This is old school SF, and all the better for it.
author: Alessandra J.

description: I've only been here for happy hour(aka 3:00 "sales call")  and some bookbinder soup. I think I remember my friend knowing the bartender so they treated us really well.
author: Carson H.

description: My mom and dad tell stories about how they used to go here back in the 70's, so when I moved out here, I had to try it. It was great- the best crab cakes I have ever eaten. I'll defnitely be back.
author: Allie H.

description: A bit pricey, but the Seafood Cioppino is absolutely amazing. I can't really base my review on anything other than the Seafood Cioppino, so this may not be the best review. However, the Seafood Cioppino is everything everyone else on here says it is. ITS AMAZING. I also like the set up of the restaurant. I would definitely go back and recommend this place to everyone.
author: Fabian S.

description: My wife had a petit mignon with shrimp. I totally enjoyed the sand dabs. We were facing a 30 minute wait, but two places opened up at the long bar. Our server was quick and efficient. We were both impressed with the potato wedges and the Brussel sprouts. Finished up with a flavorful rice custard for dessert.
author: Ken B.

description: Old school restaurant. Perhaps the best clam chowder that I've ever had! Would give this a 4.5, because I'm not a fan of brussel sprouts.
author: Rod M.

description: I really enjoyed the Tadich Grill.  I love eating at the main counter.  Very attentive and fast service.  Definitely not a place where you can keep the carb intake low.  As soon as you sit down they immediately give you a loaf of bread with butter to chew on as you gaze at the menu.  The menu has a lot on it.
