I usually go here when I'm hungry after work and want a steak.  But they have good pasta, chicken, veal etc.  It's a casual atmosphere and although its usually busy, you can always find a place to eat at the main counter.  I can see why this place has been around so long.
author: V C.

description: My first time at Tadich. I had always heard about it. It is everything one would expect of old SF. I had the Cioppino, and it was GREAT! Loved every bit, and finished it off, even soaked up the broth with the fantastic garlic bread. Loved the waiter with his straight talking no BS style. I sprung for dessert and a drink. Spent way more than I wanted to, but I don't regret it.
author: Jonas S.

description: I love this place.  Whenever I am in the mood for some old school traditional, nonbs seafood cooked american/sf style, this is the place to go.  Their seafood casseroles are the bomb and the calamari steak is big and no bs.  Clam chowder is also delicious.  Great old school feel.  Only downside is most likely a wait will be involved.
author: Charles C.

description: Great martini, great service, great food.  Chilean sea bass and clam chowder is a strong lunch but get some coffee or its siesta:30 afterwards.
author: Porfirio R.

description:
2.5 stars.

Image all of the foods you would expect in a classic American seafood restaurant, and then add a stick of butter. Not to say this is bad thing, but that's what you're going to get.

Crab leg cocktail and ciapino are the best picks here.

Get ready for a wait and some surly service (although I suppose that's part of the charm).
author: Brian S.

description: YUM! I went here for lunch and the service was great. The waiter was funny and very personable which made me feel relaxed & comfortable. The food was even better. Their seafood was amazing and so was the soup. Decent sized portions too.
author: Kimberly P.

description:
crab salad crab salad crab salad. you should be able to feel when you're ordering if you're making a good choice or not...this place has been and will continue to be exactly what it advertises.

also they have the best drink stirs ever.
author: Sophie S.

description: Just had lunch with party of 3 and would not agree with some of the recent negative reviews.  Went there on a Monday lunch, arrived 12:30'ish and was seated in a booth within 5 minutes.   Greeted quickly at door by friendly staff.  Seated and waited on within minutes.  Waiter was not overly friendly but was far from gruff (Hey it is a busy restaurant during there busy lunch rush!).  Had Adriatic Branzino which was grilled to perfection (as Croatian's know how to do sooo well).  Others had scampi's and cippino which were both good to excellent.  Octopus salad was excellent.   We were out in hour.  Without tip bill for 3 was approx $100 with a couple of drinks (no bottle of wine ordered).  Not cheap but not too bad for high end SF lunch.
author: Damon S.

description: Parking is obnoxious and the crowd can be snotty, but this old bay area establishment serves some of the best fresh seafood. The Chilean Sea Bass is to die for and their clam chowder is one of the best I've had! Their martinis are perfect and if you have room for dessert go for the bread pudding!
author: Charles C.

description: Best Seafood restaurant in SF..  On California Street at the bottom of the hill from The famous Fairmount Hotel..  Impeccable service and food..Straight out of the 1920's..think its been there that long!  Must see/do if your in SF. A+++
author: Jason U.

description: Previous posts describe surly waiters...Laurent served me and was very good and a nice guy.  Red clam chowder was great!  Clearly made in-house.  The biggest halibut steak I've ever seen...yummy.  Atmosphere was pleasant and not too crowded.  I would def. Eat here again!
author: Mark P.

description:
Quite possilbly the rudest service in San Francisco.  I happened to be in the financial district at an art opening.  I was entertaining some friends from Switzerland who were up for something traditionally San Francisco.  We thought Tadich's was on the mark...far from it.  We walked in and the first thing I heard from the host's mouth at the register was FUCK!  He was yelling at the register for misbehaving.  When he finally acknowledged us, we were greeted with a stone faced "How many?"  We waited for our table for about 20 minutes.  After we were sat, our waiter arrived and said "hello folks, the kitchen is closing so you better order right now, you might want to consider going somewhere else if you want to have a leisurly meal"  Everything else that came out of his mouth was a sales pitch for us to leave.  And as he said all this he didn't even have the courtesy of looking us in the eye.  I was shocked, I have never been treated this poorly by a restaurant staff in San Francisco.  I bit my tongue as I did not want to make a scene in front of my international guests.

This place obviously makes a living off of over charging tourists for mediocre food.  They don't treat people well because they figure they will never see them again.  So if you are looking to show guests something that is traditionally San Francisco, do not take them to Tadich's or they will get the wrong idea about our city.


Update: Weeks later my friends went by this place a second time just to make sure they did not get the wrong idea.  Though the line was long, they were treated better and told me they came out with a better impression of the place.  I upgraded my rating.
author: Cameron Y.

description: Just had lunch here today, crab and shrimp caserol with a glass of Merlot. it's soooo good! I had seabass there too before and it's also good. Too bad the line is out the door everyday or else I will be there every other day for lunch, actually maybe once every two weeks because it's a little on the expensive side.
author: Daniel W.

description: Another slice of old San Francisco. Opened in the gold rush by Croatians in 1849. Named the "cold day restaurant" when Alexander Badlam Jr. was defeated in the 1882 Assessors Election and some folks dumped a load of ice outside while he was lunching (he said "it'll be a cold day in hell when I'm defeated"). The servers run around behind the long counter in barber-shop white coats giving customers just the right amount of surly guff. Don't sit next to the guys from Maine who are going to chew your ear off about how much better their seafood is, and how you've godda have their laaaabsta. Pretend it's 1920. Take your great-grandpa who thinks its 1920. He'll love it.
author: Alex C.

description: Tadich Grill is old-school. People always comment about 'surly' service. The service isn't surly at all. It's just that the waiters don't put on the phony, 'welcome to Raisins' spiel that everyone is used to. The service is efficient and understated. The food is fantastic, although I expect many will say otherwise. The reason is that the food is not fancy, but it is hearty. Like the service, that goes against what many people expect in a restaurant. If you like lightly-flavored, broiled seafood, this may not be your place. If you want to feel like you've walked into a Gold-Rush era restaurant, check out Tadich Grill.
author: Joe H.

description: BEST CIOPINO EVER.  I love seafood stew, and no one seems to hit it better than this classic.  Nothing in it is over cooked, and it hits all the right notes.  I'm from the east coast, and have taken many out of town guests here and everyone loves it.  Yes, the don't accept reservations.  Yes, the servers can be gruff.  Yes, the decor is completely dated.  But - it's an icon, and everything on the menu is fresh, well executed and damned good.  I love this place.
author: Chad K.

description:
Great place for lunch(once in a while-$$$$) 
The best Manhattans and all the fish dishes a very freas and tasty.

Love SF and Tadich
author: David F.

description: SHORT & SWEET: the white-jacketed waiters are almost as crusty as the legendary french bread served with the old-style pats of sweet butter; this is not a light lunch; the place has a certain timelessness, but you'll also be 'history' after feasting on what you thought would be a healthy seafood lunch; all the fish dishes are equally solid (anything cooked in butter and topped with a rich sauce of crab meat and cream should taste pretty good); sit at the bar and order an ice-cold Anchor Steam on tap to help grease the skids; get there early for lunch and don't be intimated by the scowling latecomers who stack up behind you at the bar, impatiently waiting for you to finish.
author: Corey S.

description:
This is definitely a go once and be done with it place. The food is OK, very overpriced though.

The set up inside, however, with the dark wood, long bar, and private tables is really cool, so check it out, enjoy, don't fret over the bill, and don't make it a habit is my advice.
author: Kaveh A.

description: We were in town as "visitors" - visiting friends, doing a few touristy things, but mostly happy to wander around different neighborhoods a bit off the beaten path.  This was one of our "touristy" things, and it didn't disappoint.  After a 30 minute wait (we got there at 7:30pm, we weren't surprised by the line), we were seated and served by a great waiter.  The sand dabs are the way to go - delicious, delicate fish.
author: Anjali B.

description:
hard to rate....i LOVE seafood....sea bass is my favorite-i absolutely hated it here. my boyfriend was bummed because he has been raving about this place. he will be back for work meetings...not with me.

the atmosphere and service was excellent.
author: melissa c.

description: This is an unpretentious gem. I have been here several times and it is definitely worth a visit. The decor is classic and our waiter was attentive, jovial and courteous. Our seafood entrees were very good although I could have done without the brussel sprouts which were the vegetable of the day (not a fan).
author: Jim R.

description: The best Cioppino in the whole entire world. I love this place. I go whenever  I can. My parents are here from Atlanta, so that's my excuse for tomorrow night. Everything has been super every time.
author: Malia D.

description: This place may be the oldest restaurant in California; the service is exemplary, drinks perfection, but the food is just not on par with the cost. Being from Boston, i know good seafood. It should be rich but light, not the overly cornmeal crusted offerings that Tadich has on the menu.Please dont get me wrong here. I adore this place and what it represents. I wish i could rate the food higher, but i know better and my bar for the oldest restaurant in California is set far higher than they presently have. Instead of cornmeal maybe they should try cornflour. It seems to work well for all the long established seafood houses in New England. Tadich, you're a gem but please take the criticism constructively and make some simple mods to your menu. Regardless, I'll keep coming back just because you're the oldest restaurant in California.
author: Bill C.

description:
We first discovered Tadich Grill about 10 years ago during our first time living in San Francisco and it is now a necessity for lunch or dinner whenever in the Bay Area.  It came highly recommended from family friends who had lived in the Bay Area.  We had worn out the usual San Francisco seafood restaurants (ie. Alioto's, etc.) and were looking for a change and change was what we got.
 
This is the oldest restaurant in San Francisco and has been around since the days of the Gold Rush.  The first thing you notice about the restaurant is that it is so non-descript that the only thing letting you know that you have arrived is the neon sign out front and the branding on the window.  As soon as you step through the door, you definitely feel like you've left the new world and traveled back to when restaurants were more than just places to get a quick bite to eat.  There is a long wooden bar that stocks innumerable bottles of liquor and there's always beer on tap...not to mention the respectable wine list.  Down the end of the bar (right by the kitchen), there are seats for either a single or couple to sit at without having to wait for a table with the rest of the crowd.  These seats are highly coveted as the bartenders are always good for a conversation.
 
The decor is definitely old school featuring wood everywhere and they even have the larger tables tucked away in "private" areas that are partitioned from the rest of the dining area. There are no reservations taken and it is a case of putting your name on the list when walking through the door.  Trust me, not even flashing of cash will get you past this step as I have seen bartenders laugh at people pulling out a few bills to grease their palms.  I've never had to wait there long for a table, with the longest probably being in the range of 45 minutes (for a group of 6).  This just serves as a chance to lean back with a cocktail and watch the crowd as you wait.  As far as the crowd is concerned, this is a real hodge-podge.  The dress code is definitely not formal but everyone is usually dressed in a casual to business casual presentation and you can expect to see a number of professionals.
 
Now to the food.  I've never been disappointed in any seafood dish that I have ordered at Tadich Grill, and trust me I've been around to quite a few seafood restaurants in my day.  Everything is extremely fresh and cleanly presented.  The best item on the menu is far and away the Seafood Cioppino.  Over the years, the portion size seems to have gone down a bit but it is still one filling entree.  The dish is stuffed with fresh clams, fish and the occasional mussel.  Served with garlic bread, I've seen two people struggle to take down this dish before the portion size was reduced.  The seafood platter appetizer is also a must have and is plenty for either two or three people.  As mentioned, all of the other seafood on the menu is great.
 
The staff is always knowledgeable and willing to steer you towards some of their personal favourites.  The place can get loud and crowded, but make sure you arrive just before the usual lunch and dinner crowds and you'll be fine.  The portions are still great and the prices are what you expect to pay for quality.  Tadich Grill is a must at least once when in SF.
author: Trent C.

description: If I could get a tattoo to profess my undying love for this restaurant I would...well ok, not a big tattoo. As soon as I entered this restaurant filled with hum of people's conversations and took one long look down the bar, I knew I was home. My favorite part of this restaurant is the ambiance. This is not a place where you have whisper or worry about having that one additional drink. It is completely unpretentious which I find admirable especially in this city. Tadich is known for its great food [esp. the Cioppino] and boy does it live up to it's reputation!
author: Nik S.

description: Great old fashion place! I'm glad that there is a place like this in the city that's ultra-retro. Good fresh fish and huge portions! The fried calamari is a must, but I must warn you that it's huge for an appetizer. Also, they are heavy handed with the salt and oil so don't come here if you are looking for Californian food.
author: Lily C.

description: Unpretentious, plain and old like the days of private booths...that's the restaurant.  The food is inexpensive, fresh and down to earth.  Service is fast, all male waitstaff, courteous, serious in there business like the old English butler but pleasant.  Been here both lunch and dinner, prepare to wait in line if you don't show up early like before 11am for lunch or 5pm for dinner.
author: Kui T.

description: 2 of us ordered the Cioppino, which was the best I've ever had. It was full of rich, tomato-spicy goodness on top of a grand heap of fresh seafood consisting of crab, scallops, oysters and clams. Someone else ordered the scallops and she seemed to be pretty happy with her order, so a good choice.
author: Geith M.

description: I love an experience where I can feel the history of a place preserved in the care of those who run it. Plus some good grilled fish or meat - and a frequently full bar that passes you good medium-sized drinks. The Ferry Building has a wider and quicker array of options at lunch, but if you have a bit of extra time you can have lunch at the noble Tadich Grill.
author: Mark A.

description: Ah, yes, ye ol' Tadich.  A very bland decor with seating at the bar and some pretty cool private booths.  Ate here for dinner.  The fried calamari were good but my main dish fish was really rich yet lacked flavor.  But you got to love a place that serves you bread before dinner!  Service was pretty bad, too.  Pricey as hell.
author: Scott G.

description: This place is super cool.  An old school feel, old school menu items, but fresh and delicious every time.  Also, a nice mix of downtown businessmen, tourists, and regular joe locals.
author: Warren M.

description:
the seafood is always clean and fresh.  been here at least half a dozen times and have not been disappointed.  

you should go by 11:30 or 1 pm to get a table for lunch.  if you're there at noon there's almost always a long wait to be seated.
author: Almira C.

description:
I've always heard great things about Tadich Grill, but I must say my experience was awful. My fiancee and I went for Valentine's Day lunch. 

The wait wasn't long, which was good. The bartender was very friendly which made the wait feel even shorter. But when it came to the meal, we were both VERY disappointed. 

Both of our meals consisted of steak. I ordered mine medium and got rare. The same with my fiancee, he ordered medium-well and also got rare. 
I could see how they could screw up my steak but a medium -well to come out rare....NOT HAPPY! And the waiter never asked how everything was. 

So needless to say we both only ate the outside, more cooked portions of our steaks. 
And when the busboy came to clear the plate I let him know the steaks were VERY under cooked. It didn't seem to matter. The waiter come by a moment later just to drop the check on the table and move on. 

I WILL NEVER GO BACK THERE AGAIN!!
author: DeAnna K.

description: Me and my friends come to this GREAT Restaurant at least once a year.And I always have the Corn beef with the egg on top, with boil potatoes and spinach, And to drink I have Irish coffee, Best in the City---sorry Buena Vista Cafe. The sourdough bread is also the best in the bay area. My only complaint is, I wish they had a restaurant like this in the East Bay, we are still eating out of cans on that side of the bay.
author: David J.

description: If a city could have a cullinary heart, the Tadich grill is that place in San Francisco.  Whenever we fly into this mysteriously wonderful, eclectic and historic American city, our first stop, before even going to our hotel, is the Tadich Grill.  I cannot bare to breath the air or wander the streets of this wonderful place without a stomach full of the Manhattan Clam Chowder.  If I could eat every meal here, I would be in heaven...the steak is perfection, the service is perfection, and the waiters have mostly been there for decades working their magic, usually with the ladies.  John, our favorite, simply makes you feel as if you are his only table.  And he remembers us, despite the intervening two or three years...at least he makes us feel as if he remembers us...and I tip him accordingly.  This is, in our opinion, the best San Francisco has to offer.  It is usually crowded by 6 PM so go early, grab a window seat and watch the crowds standing at the front door while you enjoy the ambiance and the marvelous food.  My suggestion...eat nowhere else while in San Francisco...eat every possible meal here!  No point wasting time elsewhere.
author: Bert B.

description: great seafood dishes at this san francisco landmark.  somebody told me this was the oldest restaurant in SF, but I'm not sure.  I love the service here and the formality of the employees goes a long way to offset the seemingly high prices
author: Tony S.

description: Pretty good steak, but not the best.  More a drink whiskey while you eat place.  Never had the seafood, but there's alot of it on the menu.  I've had dinner there a couple of times with people who ordered seafood and they seemed to be picking out a lot of bones.  I guess, that's normal, I don't know.  Anyway, it's an old school place with a killer long wood counter to sit at.  The waiters wear smocks like dentists.  It's a good place to watch drunk weirdos from the nearby offices.
author: Aaron P.

description:
Tadich is a monument to the glitz of early San Francisco- From the gold mines, to the newly established financial district, Tadich is a static monument in a district subject to perpetual evolution. 
Upon first glance, the establish does not resonate with any semblance of fine dining. Narrow aisles, a massive bar, patrons pushing for their respective drink orders in bovine rows, their collective body heat makes the wait almost unbearable. However, this does not detract from an experience that is worthy of its seemingly immortal name. 
Fortunately for my father and I, our arrival preceded the lunch rush by mere minutes. As the throng of oh-so-chic employees of the financial district clogged the aisles, our waiter approached in a polite, yet fraternal manner.  A novice to the bar and grill, the middle aged waiter advised me to try the clam chowder before ordering the entree. The man had it pegged- The bowl of thick, hearty chowder with a welcome kick immediately climbed its way to the top of the list, (especially considering the last occasion in which chowder was consumed....**see first entry.**).
A sad separation from the bowl of chowder, the entrees were served, and I was given a brief visitation of pescotarian heaven- The grilled petrale sole before me shone with not only a perfect texture, but a tangy charge that danced with each tastebud before its fall into a welcoming hearth.
It's definitely worth a second visit.
If you'd like to accompany me, please keep in touch.
author: Adam F.

description: Tadich Grill is the one and only Tadich Grill.   I love it because it's back to the past, and feels like the history, ghosts, and a day gone by is back with you. I went to the TG with my father as a child, and it hasn't changed a bit.
author: Diane S.

description: I was very uncomfortable eating here.  When we walked in after work in the Financial District on a weekday, the staff stared at us as if they were shocked that we were there (even though we were well dressed, we are not Caucasian).  After looking around, we realized that we were the only non-Caucasians in the restaurant.  The other patrons also gave us inquisitive stares.  As for the food, it was mediocre.  Do not come here if you are a minority.
author: P H.

description: Like everyone else, I had the Cioppino. Maybe it was an off night, but I'd say it was average.
author: Ted F.

description: Bad 'tude.  So I don't get just because a restaurant has been around forever why an old grumpy server that acts like he is totally doing you a favor is employed there.  Started with the octopus salad, totally so sweet but still ok, then grumpy poured wine into like a wine tasting glass at a sad winery and gave the table a good spray, oh well shit happens but not even an acknowledgement or oh so sorry.  On to the cioppino, it was good but I have had  better and grumpy recomended the asparagus, would you like that overcooked and swimming in some weak hollandaise?  Meh, I think not, could we pair that with in season but tasteless?  Pour some more wine in that piddling little wine glass and oh woopsy there goes some more onto the tablecloth.  So paid the bill, still tipped that cranky old bastard more than %20 and water glasses are empty, here he comes by with the pitcher, "May we get some more water please, Sir?"  Looks at us like we are a dog turd and utters"Yeah" and proceeds to water our glasses and table like it is a garden.  So silly, we think let's go to the bar, have another glass of wine and whine about our server, think again.  Apparently they breed shitty service here, bartender pours our wine, turns his back on us, begins chatting with the other bartender and when our wine and water glasses have long been empty we finally disengage them from their very important personal conversation, pay our bill and leave the turd service grill.  With all the choices there are why has this place stayed in business so long?  Maybe we just had a bad service day but it was really bad.
author: Happy L.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in all the world.  Have been going there since the 50's. The location has changed but not the appearance.  I don't live in SF but the grill is the first place I head when in town. This is probably the only place I would wait in line for over an hour to eat and have done so more than once.  SF has world class restaurants  in and on every block but they come and go and the consistency varies.  Not so with the grill which is, I believe, the oldest restaurant in continuous operation in the city.
  The waiters who have been there for over decades  offer quick but very professional and attentive service.
  Last but certainly the most important, the food is simply too good to describe.  There is absolutely nothing on the menu that isn't excellent. Seafood is the specialty but there is something for everyone.  Have never been disappointed and if you go you will return.
Craig R.
author: craig r.

description: I kind of feel like when a place has been operating for 160 years it's gotta be good. And Tadich Grill is GOOD. Really, really good. I love any old school restaurant in San Francisco and Tadich fits the bill. The space is dominated by a big bar in the middle of the room and the sides have semi private booths and tables. In the middle of each table is a hunk of sourdough ready for you to dig in and feast which is exactly what I did as soon as I sat down. The sourdough was tangy and delicious and a wonderful start to the meal. In a restaurant like this you gotta go with the classics so I started with the shrimp and crab dinner salad and had the sand dabs as my main. Both were classically executed and totally delicious. Especially my salad which had a very generous portion of crab meat under the delicious Louis dressing. The sand dabs were delicate and delicious and came with thick cut potatoes and broccoli, green beans and carrots. I finished up with the mixed berries and zabaglione for dessert and could not have been more happy with my meal.
author: Cathy T.

description: I have been coming to Tadich for 45 years ... it's a must for lunch every time we're in SF.  Love the atmosphere, the service (busy waiters, but efficient) and the food (though, to be honest, I ALWAYS order the same thing -- panfried petrale sole).  We have taken many friends there, and no one goes away unhappy.  Yes, there are tourists; yes, there can be a wait (so sit at the bar and have a drink); and yes, it can feel crowded if you're not in one of the great little side table "booths."  We found a little oil painting taken from the bar at Tadich looking out the front window at the Laguna Beach art fair a couple of years ago.  It now hangs in our kitchen and reminds me of one of my all-time favorite restaurants.
author: Laurie M.

description: Tadich Grill is simply one of the very best restaurants in San Francisco. The ambience, the food and drinks, and the service are simply spectacular.
author: Darrin A.

description: this place is completely charming.  waitstaff is super friendly and attentive.  i swear i wanted to give my waiter a hug after my meal.  i had the crab and shrimp with rice and cream sauce casserole (its menu listing sounded way more sophisticated, but that's what i remember and what it boiled down to) and it was delicious and super comforting.  really nice atmosphere for chill meal and to hang out, and you won't get that feeling of "deng, get me the check already," or at least i didn't.
author: El E.

description: A San Francisco institution, Tadich Grill was one of those restaurants I kept meaning to get to and never did...until now. They don't accept reservations, so you give them your name at the front of the bar and then stand against the wall for 40 minutes or so until they call your name. OR if you're really lucky, you score a bar stool at the bar. Either way, it's San Francisco-esque at its best. When asked, the bartender recommended the cioppino for our girl's party of three. He said if we didn't get it, one would order it and then the other two would wish they had ordered it. So that's what we got. Out came three large bowls filled to the brim with a brothy tomato-based cioppino sauce and mounded with a variety of seafood from clams to shrimp to crab to scallops.....way more than we could eat. And I'm a power eater, so that's saying a lot. Excellent service. Good bread. Kind of loud but we weren't there for a romantic dinner. We were there to see if they lived up to their reputation. And they did. Will definitely go back!
author: Stacey H.

description: We have been coming to Tadich's for over 30 years.  The fish is great.  Service is quick. We eat early, so we don't run into the lines everyone complains about. The waiter was friendly, and had come from Paris.  The  crab salad was great. The french fries were mediocre.  The bread was perfect. The Martini ok. The house chardonnay was Wente, a good wine for a house wine.  We have made a visit to Tadich's an SF tradition during our many visits over the years, and we plan to continue in the future. In a city that has lost a lot of its charm over the last 30 years, Tadich's is consistently excellent.
author: John S.

description: Ate at the bar again tonight, stuck with the basics, clam chowder and sauteed petrale sole. Both were excellent. Chowder was piping hot and served with tobasco without asking for it. This is a great basic old school restaurant that some folks don't understand. Same people that slam this restaurant won't like Scoma's either. But then again there is always Bubba Gumps....
author: Tom R.

description:
Worth the wait, the attitude you get from the host and the loud crowds.

The food is excellent and the bar is authentic. If you live in the the bay area, you got to go to this place, have a martini and some seafood.
author: Luke O.

description:
What happened to the food?  

Normally, I do not write critical reviews. In fairness anyone can have an off night. But our meal at Tadich was so disappointing- I felt compelled to write.

I have always had a soft spot for this restuarant. it's such a classic: old style dishes,great super cold drinks, the no nonsense, old time SF atmosphere and quirky fun waiters.

As to our meal:
With the exception of our  fired calamari and tarter sauce --everything else was third rate! 

My sand dabs were encased in a cement of breading, the side dish of spinage was a odd sepia  tone and seasoned copious amounts of salt and cheese,  the potatoes were this side of burnt-- 
My husband's lamb chops well prepared but fatty!  

All in All...really surprising. It's very sad to see such a great place lose it's way....with just a little more attention to detail, they would be back in the game-- Hey Tadich, we know you can do better.
author: kathy f.

description:
We went on a Saturday night around 8:00 and we along with everyone else that came in the door was told it would be a 30 minute wait, which it was. The "waiting area" is a seat at the bar or standing along the wall.  The bartender's were really on top of their game - and also very friendly. We stood along the wall but quickly got a seat at the bar for the rest of our wait. 
Once seated I ordered the cioppino - very very good and you are also required to wear a bib when eating it :-) . My boyfriend got the NY strip which was also very tasty. It is a very loud restaurant but you can just hear the noise of everyone around you, not individual conversations and you also have no trouble hearing the person/people you are with. I had a great time at this restaurant and I think it's mostly owed to the staff. I would definitely return.
author: Emma S.

description: I had high hopes coming to this restaurant.  I've been here two times before in my lifetime.   First of all I had a Stella Artois on tap which was a recommendation from our server.   I've had this before in a bottle and was less than impressed,  however on tap it turned out to be a different story.  It was GOOD.  For appetizers we had the Tadich Platter which is a variety of seafood.  Although it wasn't visually outstanding I did sample some things I hadn't before sampled such as the anchovies and smoked trout.  The raw oysters were very good.  The rest of the sampler platter was okay.  A Ketel One Vodka shaken not stirred was another recommendation that turned out just fine.  For a main entree I had the cioppino which was recommended by colleagues at work.  It was fine but didn't leave me in awe.  A margarita was yet another recommendation from our server which was right on.  For dessert I had a chocolte mousse.  Delicious.    The service was good.  The drink and dessert recommendations were on target.   All in all a nice early evening meal.
author: Robert C.

description: Best seafood around but come in mid afernoon to avoid the crowds.  (it is popular).  Also they won't give you a table unless everyone is there.  This is a good place for friends from out of town - they live up to the reputation of really good San Francisco seafood.
author: mike d.

description:
We live in the East Bay and only occasionally travel to SF for dinner, so when we do, we are expecting a fine dining experience. I used to work in San Francisco in the 70s and 80s and loved this restaurant. It was very popular amongst locals and commuters with great atmosphere and even greater food.
Imagine my surpise Thursday night, when three of us decided to forego reservations at Fleur de Lys and go to one of my old favorite haunts. I think the waiters and bartenders there have an over inflated sense of their importance due to the long running popularity of this restaurant. We found them to be haughty, smug and totally non-friendly. I loved petrale sole and order it a lot. It is usually served with mashed potatoes, but when I asked the waiter if he would substitute roasted potatoes for mashed potatoes, he looked like I had insulted him. He told me "no mash potatoes". The petrale sole came with skin, fins and tail attached-the first time I had ever had it served that way.. When I complained he did not offer to get me something else from the menu, but rather stated"that's the way we server it here". The fish was dry and had very little sauce and when I requested more, he begrudginly brought more.
One of my friends, on the other had, had the grilled trout and loved it. I tasted it and it was, indeed, very good. My other friend loved the grilled King Salmon, but complained about being sick to her stomach several hours later,.
Bottom line, great atmosphere, however, the help need to get over their sense of entitlement and treat customers as they would like to be treated. Also, don't order the petrale sole if you are expecting it to melt in your mouth. It's not going to happen!
author: lynn e.

description: This place is historical and worth visiting. I wish I would have been able to sit at a table, but the place was packed during lunch hour. Nonetheless, I had wonderful company, wonderful service, and a delicious sea bass. My water glass was always full, and this makes me very happy.
author: Cynthia R.

description: As we walked through the door of Tadich Grill and saw the old-fashioned interior and men in cowboy hats, I immediately thought of the days of the "wild west" and the gold rush. Surely enough, this place has been around for over a hundred years and was started by Croatian immigrants, which I thought was an interesting story. The atmosphere was festive and based on the type of socialization that was going on, I was under the impression that a lot of people there were regulars. Once I saw the food the waiters were bringing out I could see why. This place serves generous portions of classic seafood dishes, including cioppino, oysters, several kinds of fish prepared different ways, lobsters, great seafood salad.... I could go on and on about the variety in the items on the menu themselves, as well as the preparation. Unfortunately, when we visited Tadich's they were out of BOTH oysters and clams (which is why they didn't get five stars from me) but everything else we had was really good. Someone at our table ordered the crab and fish a la newberg, which turned out to be this delicious, creamy casserole of cheese, white sauce, fish and crab. The salmon was good, although not amazing, and the sides were drenched in butter. The lobster, according  to my friend was amazing. The service was fast, very friendly and attentive and the prices were fair. All in all, I was pretty happy with our dinner.
author: Daniela A.

description: i think this is the oldest restaurant in SF... but i could be wrong. i do know its one of the oldest though. very good seafood, authentic and old school with great service. i love coming here!
author: Michelle I.

description: this place looks and feels old school, in a good way. dark wood is used throughout the restaurant, making it seem more cramped than it really is. you are greeted by the bar when you walk in with a long row of bar seats on the right. there are booths around the perimeter tucked away into the wall that give you a mini private party feel. not sure how i feel about bread and water already at our table waiting for us when we were seated. i'm sure the turnaround time per table is quick, but i would've liked to think that my bread was fresh from the kitchen. o well, i still ate it. the menu selection stretches from salad to seafood to steak, there's something for everyone. they seem to update their menus daily, my menu was stamped with today's date on it. i ordered one of "today's special", which was oven roasted mahimahi with king crab dijon and lentils and veggies. it. was. good. the lentils were al dente cooked in some kind of vinegar/sugar combo. the fish was extremely flaky and delicious. the king crab sauce was like icing on a cake. the whole dish was scrumptious. i would come back if the prices weren't as steep. overall a great neighborhood gem of a place.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Fish is the hardest thing to cook, but this place has atmosphere out the ying-yang. One of my favorite places to go. So back to the fish, I don't think they will ever be as good as poor departed Aqua which was fantastic, but I love to sit at the bar and get lunch. I like the waiters and the bread. Hard to beat.
author: Miguel E.

description: Tadich.  Wow...  Now I've read many reviews, on many sites, about Tadich.  Mixed feelings, it seems, but at the end of the day, you'll walk out of Tadich a very happy (and full) camper.  I've been there twice, for lunch, and both times enjoyed sitting at the counter.  Gotta sit at the counter!  The waiters can be less than attentive, true, and a couple seem to have the personality of Lurch  from the Addams Family unless you engage them a little, but don't let that stop you from checking out this San Francisco institution.  There's a good reason it's been around since 1849 -- the food rocks!  My friend has twice raved about the cioppino and last time I had the most amazing piece of fish: a very fresh and flaky piece of Chilean Sea Bass that was to die for!  If you get a salad, I recommend getting it with their blue cheese dressing which is off the charts...  So, don't take my word for it; grab a stool at the counter, enjoy some fresh bread 'n' butter, a cold draft beer, and some nice (albeit pricey) food at the oldest haunt in The City.
author: Jeff B.

description: is always a great place to eat in the city. great service. swordfish is excellent and the halibut is great. i had chillian seabass the last time i ate there and it was cooked to perfection.
author: biker b.

description: The menu reminds me a lot of the Palm, but the atmosphere is a bit more relaxed. Excellent food quality and service. I always ordered seafood and they make a great Arnold Palmer.
author: J R.

description: this place was great!  the food was perfect.  the staff of all elder white guys was comforting and added a sense of comfort - like grandpa was serving dinner.  the fish was excellant.  i had the halibut.  tons of it loaded into my spinach florentine.  the clam chowder was also delicious.  i will definitely be back.
author: Hammer Time H.

description: We tried Tadich Grill for the first time this past Wednesday evening.  Rather than wait for a table (20 minutes) we sat at the counter.  It was a nice atmosphere, sort of like an old world cafe.  The service was excellent.  We tried the shrimp and crab cocktail, which the latter was superb.  I had the calamari steak and it was seasoned very well and delicious.  The clam chowder was creamy and delightful.  The prices were reasonable too.
author: Adrian R.

description: When I worked in the financial district I would have lunch here at least once a week, sitting at the bar (faster seating, excellent service!).  I have never had a bad meal in Tadich's AND it's easily the best seafood restaurant in San Francisco (rivals Elliot's in Seattle).  As with The Hunan on Sansome, whenever I am in San Francisco nowadays I always head for these two restaurants -- everything else is secondary.
author: Lee C.

description: You know what, I'm sick of places picking up five stars just because they've been around forever.  Tadich is hardly out-of-this-world on the food, and their service borders between surly and hostile.  No thanks.
author: Alice T.

description: Best seafood in the city.  Good drinks.  Great atmosphere. What else needs to be said. Definitely a must in San Francisco.
author: Suchil S.

description: I love this place! Great cioppino. Great sand dabs (a favorite of mine). Great San Francisco atmosphere.
author: Howard B.

description: Love this place. SF tradition. I've got to say I've only had the cioppino, but it's amazing. The oysters for appetizers are also very delicious. The wait staff is very SF... been there a long time and are always on the move. The bartender knows the regulars and has been there for long as well. This place is the greatest!
author: N L.

description: Tried to go there on Tuesday at 11:40 and couldn't get a table. Went back on Friday at 11:25 and walaa!  Table was ready for us. Make sure you get there early. Ahi tuna and scallops were amazing. Nice atmosphere, and friendly staff.
author: Matt M.

description: surprisingly good food, and a totally great space if you're into new-england style faded glory (dark wood, green leather, low light, etc.)
author: James R.

description: the cioppino here rocks!!  it is filled w/ a ton of fresh fish and seafood and was very filling.  i probably only ate half and took the rest home.  my friend had the sand dabs, which were pretty good as well.  be careful, b/c there is lots of bones in those little fish.  we had the bread pudding for dessert, which wasn't that great.  i usually like bread pudding warm, and this one was cold and super sweet.  everyone talks about how the servers here are gruff and old school, but our server was very pleasant and helpful.  we shoulda taken his advice re the dessert and gotten the choc mousse.
author: Helen T.

description: I love old School restaurants and this one is great!  I love the atmospher and the staff.  It's a must see while in San Francisco.  They pour a great drink too!
author: Roby R.

description: This place isn't among my faves obviously but it's ok.  The service always seems to be hit or miss.  Last night was a major miss!  The waiter in front of us was just down right rude.  We were having fun, laughing, joking and this guy was just a total downer!  The food isn't bad.  I love the old school feel but service man, it can bring it down and well it did to 3 stars!
author: Misti L.

description: Mmmmm, this place is awesome for anyone who loves good, old-fashioned seafood in huge portions.  I got a nice plate of steaming hot sand dabs, perfectly seasoned brussel sprouts, and some nice roasted potatoes to round out the meal.  I actually thought the serving size was a bit much - I'd much rather have smaller portions, and lower prices, especially considering if you want to split a plate they will charge you an extra $9, so either shell out the cash, loosen your belt or take out a doggy bag.  On the upside, the booths are warm and inviting, I dig the wood paneling all over and all the history behind the place.  I came in a group early (around 5:30pm on a weeknight) and service was great, although got markedly more abrupt as we stayed until the middle of dinner rush hour.
author: Lisa C.

description: We went here last week for a work lunch. It was a fun experience just to finally check out this SF classic. Very, very old school just as expected. Our server was great, really hammed it up a bit for us, which I liked. I felt like I had to try the sand dabs. Again, it was fun to finally try them here but I wouldn't get them next time. The bread was great, my friend's crab cakes were pretty good, but the winner at the table by far were the orders of cioppino. If I were to come back, I'd definitely get that, it was a really great cioppino. MASSIVE though so I'd be interested in sharing that and maybe a Crab Louie with someone. As far as whether I will be back, I think it could be a fun place to take out of towners looking for something very SF in this area, like my Dad for example. Otherwise I don't see myself dying to go anytime soon, unless I was having a real hankering for cioppino. Just one of those places it's fun to go once really. Definitely kind of pricey for a weekday lunch unless you're expensing - all lunch mains are around $20.
author: Sarah R.

description: i wanted to try this sf landmark restaurant for a while, and luckily was nearby when looking for a good place to eat dinner once. what a treat. the food is excellent, and it felt like a real sf experience eating there. i ordered some of the best cioppino i've ever had, and i would definitely recommend this place if you love seafood. it's not a surprise how they've managed to stay in business since 1849!
author: Jon N.

description: Amazing old school restaurant.  Huge portions and super high quality fish.  We ordered the salmon and crab casserole which had much more lump crab meat than salmon which is opposite of what you would find at most places.  Does not take reservations and we arrived at 7pm on a Friday.  Wait for a table was 45 minutes but we were seated at the full service bar without any wait.  Definitely a must try!
author: Stacy N.

description: The old wait staff and the wood paneling makes this place charming.  The Cioppino is excellent.  The other seafood dishes are average, and the pasta is sub-par.
author: LT B.

description: This is old school San Francisco, the oldest restaurant in California!  I like it because I took my dear Grandmother there and she loved it!  I don't know what San Francisco would be without Tadich Grill!
author: Antony E.

description: all class, all the time.  the food is great, the atmosphere is throwback and top notch, and the service never falls short of excellent.  you gotta go at least once so that you have a benchmark by which to compare other diner -style restaurants to.  they specialize in seafood dishes which are hearty and wholesome, and served by some real characters.  There's one guy with this really distinct voice that projects across the place that says witty things from time to time and another guy with a Scottish brogue (or maybe an Irish brogue, it should be enough that I know what a brogue is).  There's this blind guy that comes in a lot I guess (I've seen him a few times when I've been) and every time the waiter reads the menu to him, since the menu changes daily.
author: grant f.

description: What a fantastic experience.  We had heard about this place from friends, but had never tried it.  We happened to walk by.... The wait for a table was quite long, but the bartender, I think his name was Doug, made our wait quite enjoyable.  He was friendly, charming, funny, and seemed not to mind that he was extremely busy and we were only having drinks.   Some of the other customers were eating at the bar.  I have to say that the best thing about the restaurant was the bartender.  Everyone else was a little busy and distracted.  The food was very good, etc.  But what really stands out in our minds was the first experience.... Doug.  We will be back!
author: kathleen h.

description: Awesome.  The best Cioppino in the city. The ambience is great as is is the service.  Not really anything to complain about at this place.  The only downside is that it is expensive but thats' kind of what I expected.
author: Marko C.

description:
Went there with a friend, the Friday after Thanksgiving, just before lunch hour.  There were still seats at the giant counter (didn't seem to be that many tables in the place).  The menu is huge with plenty of variety (and big San Francisco prices).  
We ordered a recommended calamari appetizer; a huge platter arrived that we could barely finish.  It was perfectly cooked (rings and tentacles) with bowls of red and white homemade sauces on the side.  We ordered lunches of poached Halibut (big fresh portion) and Crab Cakes (lots of crab meat and not to much bread).  Very impressive portions and quality.  We were too full to try any desserts. 
The coffee was very good, the bread plate was good crunchy sourdough, the red wine was good, and the Service was attentive.  When we left at about 12:30, the place was packed with a line of 10 plus waiting against the wall for seats.  
My only complaint is the prices; we had 1 appetizer, 2 coffees, 2 glasses of wine, and 2 entrees.  With tip, the damage was $98.  
It's really an excellent restaurant, but I'm probably not rich enough to go there very often.
author: Rick P.

description: Tadich Grill is the best food i've had in SF. Old School, great waiter staff and great bartenders.  They chat with you like they know you...it makes you fell welcome you fell happy about being there.  Our waiter has been working there for over 25 years, and  he knows his stuff... and was the friendlist waiter i've had in any resturaunt in the bay area.  This will always be on top of my short list of great resturaunts in the bay area.
author: Garrick R.

description: I've been here a couple of times for lunch and the food is always really good.  The portions are all pretty big and the it tastes amazing.  It's a cool place to go to, and the restaurant has an older/historic feel to it.  Probably one of the better seafood places I've been too.  If you're planning on going its a good idea to head there during non-peak hours since they don't take reservations and this place is always busy.
author: Joe V.

description: nice atmosphere in an old-fashioned way, and the food is definitely good, but for the price it's nothing special.  worst thing is the soft drinks are expensive and come in kids' sized glasses with no free refills.  feels a bit like being ripped off.  overall a fun place to go on occasion, but one can definitely get better food for the price at other nearby restaurants
author: Rex S.

description: Tadich is a great place for a max party of four. The establishment is long and narrow. If you don't want to wait I would recommend for you to arrive before the evening rush crowed but do go! From what I observed the staff and cooks are all men. The prices are nothing out of the ordinary for an upscale seafood restaurant. I saw people dressed down and up so don't worry about wearing business causal attire. I ordered the special, crab cakes, bottle of wine, and dessert. I don't remember the names of the dishes but everything was mouth watering delicious. The restaurant is native to the city for 150 years. Go and give it a taste. Tadich is crowed for a reason!!!
author: Will F.

description: i was extremely disappointed with this restaurant.   i ordered the sauteed scallops.   the scallops were flavorless and the sauce was as well.  it was served with rice and unappetizing veggies.  my dad ordered the meat ravioli and it looked like chef boyardee.  a definite no no.  the only thing that was tasty was the sourdough bread that was served.
author: katie v.

description: Was here over 30 years ago and the place hasn't changed much.  Same older waiters in white jackets, same high ceiling and wooden booths.  There is something comforting about this place that has been in business for 161 years.  And I think I know their secret.  Great food and service.  The guy at the front might be a bit brusque but when people are pouring in at all times of day maybe he is the "discouragement factor".  When I asked the bartender if he knew we were there waiting for a table he said  "It might not look like we know what we are doing but we do!"  Touche.  As I was waiting I spotted a salad that looked delicious and pulled the waiter aside to question what it was.  No attitude he just gave me a menu and pointed it out.     Anyway if I had been in business for 161 years with great success I might have a smidgeon of an attitude too.  The prices seem to go with the portions and quality.  Yes, my Dungenesss Crab Louise was $21 but must have had 8 ounces of crab on it.  You know the fish is ultra fresh when there is a line out the door at 11:45am.  Decent well priced wine list with many good by the glass choices.  My husband's whole Bronzino was $21 as well and perfectly prepared.  Who cares if they don't give you a bread plate?  Get over it!!!  Go here to see what old time SF was all about.
author: June H.

description: We've been talking about coming to Tadich Grill for so long we decided to finally make good on it. On a recent Saturday evening my wife and visited the venerable SF culinary landmark. With absolutely no wait we were seated at a small table that had a bowl of lemons, a loaf of bread, and a small plate with two pates of butter. Hmmm...I said to myself, what's up with that? Our server, who sounded like he was from France was very attentive, bringing over more butter and a round of martini's which surely hit the spot. We ordered a dozen oysters which were fantastic as was the crab cakes. These cakes were a generous handful of dungenous crab that were hand patted in a light breadcrumb batter and gently fried. These were incredible from the first bite. My wife ordered the chippino which, as others here have pointed out, was superb in every way, and I ordered the sauteed scallops which was mouthwatering. The desert was the only thing that disappointed as rice pudding pie left a lot to be desired for both of us. And the place isn't cheap either, however, the memory of paying the bill leaves you long before the memory of eating the best seafood meal that we ever had does. One more thing, upon leaving the restaurant, the valet in front asked if we needed a car. As there was a stretch Lincoln limo parked and ready to go out front, I asked him how much it would be to go to the Orpheaum Theater. $10 was his reply. What a deal as we paid $12 for a cab ride from our hotel to the restaurant earlier in the evening. Tadich Grill is a first rate old school restaurant which we'll be visiting again. (That is, when we have the dough to do so).
author: Nick C.
